sentence: Sir, your supporters are eager to see you confront your accusers. Is there a strategic reason behind your decision to remain absent from the impeachment proceedings? [SEP] Believe me, I'd be thrilled to be there, front and center, watching those folks try to justify their witch hunt. It would be must-see TV.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, are all existing sanctions going to stay as they are? [SEP] Right now, they're in place. I've been watching you folks saying we gave up something – that's just not true. I actually think we're going to end up being good friends with Chairman Kim and North Korea. They've got huge potential, I've been saying it all along. Incredible potential. We'll see what happens. But the whole thing was about sanctions. They wanted them lifted, but they weren't willing to do what we wanted in return. They were willing to give us some things, but not the things we needed.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given your Nobel Peace Prize and the looming decision on Syria, how do you balance these conflicting roles? Furthermore, could you elaborate on how your conversation with Prime Minister Reinfeldt contributed to addressing the climate crisis? [SEP] On the Nobel, I refer you to my remarks upon receiving it, where I expressed my own sense of inadequacy relative to previous laureates. I spoke of the inherent challenge of advocating for peace in a world often defined by violence. The fundamental question is, what are our obligations? I've worked to end the war in Iraq, reduce our presence in Afghanistan, and champion diplomatic solutions. However, the question we all face is: at what point do we intervene against acts that offend our shared humanity? Witnessing the gassing of children, the senseless deaths of civilians, and possessing the means to alleviate this suffering, the ethical imperative is to act. This is the most challenging aspect of this office. I would prefer to dedicate my time to education rather than preventing chemical warfare against children. But as President, these are the choices I face. When crises erupt globally, the immediate question is always: what will the United States do? Libya, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, now Syria. That's the burden we carry. Now, remind me of your second query?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with anti-LGBTQ+ sentiment seemingly on the rise, particularly targeting transgender youth, what concrete steps will your administration take beyond symbolic gestures to ensure their safety and well-being in the face of discriminatory laws? [SEP] I want to tell you, I want to speak to that family. We're here for them, and this administration has their back. We ended the ban on transgender troops. We signed the Respect for Marriage Act. But it's not enough. There are some prejudiced people who are pushing fear. It's wrong. These are our kids. We're strengthening safety, addressing civil rights violations, and boosting mental health support. Congress needs to pass the Equality Act. LGBTQ+ Americans, we will protect you.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, your reaction to the Al Qaida intelligence report, please? [SEP] Pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, in the wake of the midterm elections, what legislative outcomes concerning abortion rights should the American public anticipate from Congress? [SEP] I don't foresee any significant shifts. We'll likely remain entrenched in our existing stances. Frankly, I shouldn't have even addressed that question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: How do you view the Pope's recognition of Palestine? Does it help or hinder the two-state solution? [SEP] Let me begin by praising the Senate for empowering me to negotiate and enforce a forward-thinking trade pact with countries in the Asia-Pacific and Europe. I thank the Senators who backed the start of the debate. I will persist in attempting to persuade those who opposed it. Despite past issues with trade agreements, my strategy is advantageous to businesses of all sizes and, most crucially, to American workers. I would not champion any agreement that did not create jobs and boost incomes. My conflict with Elizabeth is not personal; it is a policy difference. Many of my Senate and House colleagues disagree with me, and I appreciate their concerns about plant closures and the relocation of jobs overseas. They are concerned about labor and environmental norms, as well as fair trade practices. They are also concerned about inequality and the repercussions of automation and globalization. They share my ideals, with the exception of trade. It is a policy disagreement on what is best for our people. I maintain that we are better off establishing stringent regulations with strong protections against child labor, deforestation, and other issues for the world's largest and fastest-growing market. If we do not, China will. Concerning outsourcing, companies can already engage in it. We have a chance to entice businesses back. Nike is bringing back 10,000 jobs as a result of technological advancements. We must sell our goods there. We need a high minimum wage, job training, infrastructure investments, collective bargaining, overtime pay, paid sick leave, and honest budgets. Preventing a trade agreement will not help. Existing trade regulations are harmful to workers. I am in favor of enforcement. I have misgivings about the currency language. I need to speak with Schumer and Brown about language that does not jeopardize our monetary policy. What was your other question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, you spoke of a softer tone. Yet, given the constant media scrutiny, is that truly feasible? And specifically, how will this new tone translate into legislative action, considering the changed dynamics in Congress? [SEP] Frankly, a softer tone would be a welcome change. It's exhausting fighting back against the constant stream of fake news and biased reporting. But let's be clear: I won't be a punching bag. I'll defend myself and my policies. As for Congress, they need to understand that the American people want results, and I'm willing to work with anyone who's serious about delivering them, regardless of tone.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Pope's actions concerning the Palestinian state, would you share your perspective on its potential impact on the two-state solution, steering clear of unrelated trade matters for the moment? [SEP] Look, I appreciate the Senate's work on trade, and it's vital for American jobs. But the Pope's decision is a complex issue. It touches on deeply held beliefs and international relations. My focus remains on ensuring a fair and lasting peace in the region. That means engaging with all parties, understanding their concerns, and working towards a solution that respects the rights and aspirations of both Israelis and Palestinians. We need to create an environment where negotiations can succeed, and that requires careful diplomacy and a commitment from everyone involved. It's not just about trade deals; it's about building a future of peace and security for generations to come. And that's what I'm dedicated to achieving. I'm also dedicated to ensuring that we have the best possible trade deals for American workers. It's a balancing act, but I believe we can achieve both.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. I'd like to ask each of you leaders about economic issues. For President Bush, will the United States intervene to support the dollar if your current efforts to talk it up don't succeed? And what also is your reaction to the Saudi Arabian proposal for a summit on energy prices?For Prime Minister Jansa, what effects are you feeling in Eastern and Central Europe from the rising energy prices and the rising value of the euro? Did those factors pose a risk to growth and integration for those countries, for your countries?And for President Barroso, given the proliferation of disputes between Europe and the United States over food safety issues, is there a concern that the EU is being too restrictive on those issues? [SEP] Okay, John, interesting idea by the—His Majesty, the King of Saudi Arabia. Secondly, I articulated a policy that I had been articulating ever since I have been the President. It's the same policy, which is, we believe in a strong dollar and that relative value of economies will end up setting the proper valuation of the dollar. Past growth, or growth with little comparison in the his-tory—this is the growth of energy and food prices. And the food prices are going up due to high cost of energy or oil, and this has a significant effect on the economy in Slovenia and throughout Europe. This is one of the key questions being dealt with at the national level and at the level of the European institutions, as has been mentioned by President Barroso. This is a serious problem. It will, on the one hand, make us search long-term solutions. I have mentioned this in part before. And on the other hand, it will make us search short-term solutions, and one of these is energy efficiency.We have also discussed this at today's summit, and this is a strong message. The investment in research and development, the investment into what the economy can do, an economy that is less dependent on carbon, less dependent on fossil fuels, this will have a long-term strategic effect on the price.So the key is the technology. I remember the President of the United States saying 2 years ago at the summit meeting in Vienna that the key thing is investment in the development of new technologies. This is the key strategic reply to these challenge. And as far as the euro is concerned, on the one hand, we are satisfied and happy that euro is a strong currency. And since the 1st of January of last year, Slovenia is also part of the euro zone. And I can say that in the majority, the effects are positive. When calculating the high prices of oil in dollars, this slightly mitigates this jump. And on the other hand, this is also a problem for importers in the European Union. We wouldn't like to see a weak euro and a strong dollar.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, can you say whether you yourself think that annexation should be off the table for Israel? And if so, have you communicated that to the Prime Minister? [SEP] Well, not off the table. No. It's something they've discussed, but Israel has agreed not to do that. I mean, more than just off the table, they have agreed not to do it. And I think that was very important, and I think it was a great concession by Israel, and I think it was a very smart concession by Israel.But, David, do you have anything further to add on that?
label: Explicit

sentence: Chancellor Merkel, beyond general statements of concern, what specific new sanctions or economic penalties is Germany willing to impose on Iran if it rejects the EU's offer? Are you considering targeting specific sectors of the Iranian economy, such as banking or energy, and how would you mitigate the potential impact on the Iranian population? [SEP] We are exploring all available options, in close coordination with our partners. We believe that a strong and united front is essential to exert maximum pressure on Iran. We are carefully evaluating the potential impact of any new measures, both on the Iranian regime and on the Iranian people. Our goal is to achieve a peaceful resolution to this issue, and we are committed to using all available tools to achieve that goal.
label: General

sentence: Concerning the Khashoggi murder, if Saudi Arabia is found culpable, what specific punitive measures would you consider? [SEP] It's a fluid situation. We're gathering information from multiple sources. I'm not going to jump to conclusions. We'll make a determination based on the evidence, and then we'll decide what to do. But it's too early to say.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Edward Snowden, NSA's Rick Ledgett proposed a conversation about amnesty. What was your reaction? What circumstances would lead you to consider a plea or amnesty? And what's your message to Americans who see Snowden as a whistleblower who improved surveillance practices? [SEP] Major, I must be cautious, as Mr. Snowden faces indictment and criminal charges. The Attorney General, a judge, and a jury will handle this. I can't comment on the specifics, but I'll address the core question. I've said this is a vital conversation. However, the leaks harmed the US and our intelligence. We could have had this debate without that damage. For example, the US, despite flaws, respects the law, privacy, civil liberties, and our Constitution. Because of these leaks, nations that do what Snowden fears—surveillance, targeting dissidents, suppressing the press—criticize the US. That's a distorted view. This debate is important, but remember it hurt US intelligence and diplomacy. I'll let the courts and Attorney General address Snowden's case.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, for both of you, during your meetings, did you discuss Canada increasing its stimulus? And what will the Canada-U.S. relationship, the auto sector, border, and carbon market look like in 4 years? [SEP] Whoa, that's a whole bunch of questions rolled into one. Are you trying to overwhelm me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Dr. Ronny Jackson's nomination to lead the Veterans Affairs Administration, he's facing some serious accusations. What's your take on these allegations, and will you continue to back him? [SEP] I haven't been briefed on the specifics of these accusations, but I can vouch for his character. He's a top-notch individual, and I think Melania would agree. He's been the doctor for President Obama, President Bush, and myself. He's a fantastic doctor. It was just a suggestion, and I'm aware of the experience concerns. The Veterans Administration is very important to me, and we've made significant progress with the Accountability Act and other things. And we're working on choice. We're going to take great care of our veterans. I even asked Admiral Jackson, 'Why do you want this job?' It's a brutal process. But he's an admiral, a great leader. They'll nitpick everything. Look at Pompeo's confirmation; everyone was shocked. I heard he wouldn't get approved, but Rand Paul came through. Rand's a good guy. I knew things others didn't. Rand flipped his vote, and he was approved.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Anyway, moving on to the subject of the day, I talked to James Clyburn before this press conference. He said, As a man thinketh, so are we. And Americans believe we are in a recession. What will it take for you to say those words, that we are in a recession?And also, on Zimbabwe, what's the next step? And does South Africa play a part in that? [SEP] Yes, thank you. I've answered my—the question on the words and terminologies. I will tell you that these are very difficult economic times—very difficult. And we'll let the economists define it for what it is. I would hope that those who worry about recession, slowdown— whatever you want to call it—make the tax cuts permanent as a way of helping to address this issue. Because if you're somebody out there trying to plan your future and you're worried about the future and you think your taxes are going to go up, it's going to cause different behavioral patterns.Secondly, I do want to thank the Members of Congress. And the man you talked to is a leader and did a very good job of helping shepherd through this billionsof-dollar package that is now beginning to hit America's pocketbooks. And we'll see how that goes. I hope it's as stimulative as we think it will be. But you can tell the good man you talked to, who is a good guy, that I fully understand that people are concerned. And they're concerned about high gasoline prices. They're worried about high food prices, worried about staying in their homes.The new issue, of course, is student loans. The House of Representatives passed a bill that—sponsored by Mr. Miller, George Miller, that is a—that we think can do the job. I hope the Senate moves a version of it very quickly so that we can help address this issue. I mean, one of the things that Government can do is either create more anxiety or less. And if you think your taxes are going to go up, that's going to make you anxious. If you think the Government is going to step in with a good policy that will help your child get a student loan, that will make you less anxious.One of the things we've done on home-ownership is the HOPE NOW Alliance, which, hopefully, makes people less anxious. Hopefully, it helps—has kind of brought some sense of not only concern but action into the marketplace. And I was told this morning that HOPE NOW has affected about 1.4 million homeowners and helped a lot of them refinance, get refinancing, or helped a lot of them get different interest payment schedules, all aiming for creditworthy people to be able to stay in their homes during this difficult period.Zimbabwe—first of all, the will of the people needed to be respected in Zimbabwe. And it is clear that they voted for change, as they should have, because the—Mr. Mugabe has failed the country. It's a country that used to be an exporter of food; it's now got terrible human conditions there.Secondly, the violence and the intimidation is simply unacceptable. The Government is intent upon—and is—intimidating the people there.We support the U.N. Security Council discussions that are going on. But the truth of the matter is, April—and you mentioned this—it's really incumbent upon the nations in the neighborhood to step up and lead and recognize that the will of the people must be respected and recognize that that will came about because they're tired of failed leadership.Thank you all for your interest. Enjoyed it.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, thank you, sir. And previously, when asked about Israel's September bombing of the Syrian facility, you refused aggressively to discuss it. Then suddenly last week, your administration released classified photos and details of that bombing, intelligence officials claiming that it showed that this facility was a North Korean-designed nuclear facility being actually built with the help of Pyongyang. Why the turnaround, sir? What did you hope that that would accomplish? And what do you say to lawmakers of both parties on Capitol Hill who are quite concerned that, indeed, if this was what this facility was, that it took some 8 months for you to inform them, sir? [SEP] Thank you. Let me correct the record. We briefed 22 Members of Congress on what I'm about to tell you. First, we were concerned that an early disclosure would increase the risk of a confrontation in the Middle East or retaliation in the Middle East. As I mentioned to you early on, we did notify 22 Members of Congress, key committee chairmen. And I was—I'm mindful that there was going to be this kind of reaction. And we—of course, we wanted to include more Members of Congress at a time when we felt the risk of retaliation or confrontation in the Middle East was reduced. And so that moment came upon us and then extended the briefings.We also wanted to advance certain policy objectives through the disclosures. And one would be to the North Koreans, to make it abundantly clear that we may know more about you than you think, and therefore, it's essential that you have a complete disclosure on not only your plutonium activities but proliferation as well as enrichment activities.And then we have an interest in sending a message to Iran, and the world for that matter, about just how destabilizing a—nuclear proliferation would be in the Middle East, and that it's essential that we work together to enforce U.N. Security Council resolutions aimed at getting Iran to stop their enrichment programs. In other words, one of the things that this example shows is that these programs can exist and people don't know about them and—because the Syrians simply didn't declare the program. They had a hidden program.And finally, we wanted to make it clear to Syria and the world that their intransigence in dealing with—helping us in Iraq or destabilizing Lebanon or dealing with Hamas, which is a destabilizing force in our efforts to have a Palestinian state coexist peacefully with Israel, that those efforts are—it gives us a chance to remind the world that we need to work together to deal with those issues. So that's why we made the decision we made.Yes, sir.
label: Explicit

sentence: With many viewing the election results as a referendum on your leadership, what's your response? Should we expect a different White House and leadership style in the next two years, considering your new congressional landscape? [SEP] Jim, I'll continue to be direct about our country's priorities, with winning the war on terror as the most important. Sustaining economic growth and ensuring quality education for our children are also key. With the shift in Congress, bipartisan cooperation is essential for legislative progress. Expect increased engagement and dialogue with Democrats, as they now control committees and dictate bill flow. The Iraq War undeniably influenced the election, especially with televised images of conflict. Surprisingly, despite a strong economy, which often dictates off-year elections, a different sentiment prevailed among voters. The positive economic indicators were overshadowed by the challenges of the war. I recognize that some disagree with my decisions, but I'll continue to act in the country's best interests. I've never prioritized short-term popularity over my principles or decisions. I understand the public's frustration, which I share, wishing for a faster resolution. Secretary Rumsfeld agrees. However, this is a tough fight, and we will win. Our only path to failure is premature withdrawal. Yes, Jim.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the New Yorker's report on the Red Cross findings concerning CIA interrogation techniques amounting to torture, have you reviewed it, and what are your thoughts? Furthermore, despite your stated intention to close Guantanamo a year ago, progress seems stalled, reportedly due to resistance from within your administration. Who's calling the shots on this issue? Are you taking action, and do you foresee Guantanamo's closure by the end of your term? [SEP] Closing Guantanamo, as I've stated, remains a goal. The challenge lies in the practicalities – finding suitable destinations for the detainees. The Senate's near-unanimous opposition to housing these individuals domestically highlights the difficulty. We're actively engaged in repatriation efforts and working to establish trial proceedings. So, while I can't offer a concrete timeline for Guantanamo's closure, it's a matter we're addressing with diligence. Now, circling back to the Red Cross report, could you remind me of the core question you're posing?
label: Clarification

sentence: Given the concerns, are you at all apprehensive about the situation? [SEP] I believe I've addressed that matter sufficiently. Next question, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, Mr. President, can you give us a firm timeline for when this initiative will be implemented? [SEP] To be perfectly honest, I couldn't give you an exact date at this moment.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, given your commitment to a smooth transfer of power, what's your take on the Democratic boycott of the Inauguration? And did you attempt to influence the President-elect on issues like the Affordable Care Act or the DREAMers during your discussions? [SEP] I won't divulge the specifics of my conversations with President-elect Trump. Suffice it to say they were cordial and substantive. Whether I succeeded in persuading him is a question for him. I offered my counsel, but he was elected on a platform divergent from many of my policies. I anticipate he will pursue his own agenda. It's possible he may arrive at similar conclusions regarding healthcare or job creation once he assumes office. Time will tell. His advisors will undoubtedly influence his views. A strong team providing sound information is crucial for this job. Isolation and echo chambers lead to errors. Regarding the Inauguration, I will be in attendance, as will Michelle. And the weather forecast is more favorable than my first Inauguration.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Sir, concerning the annexation of Crimea, what specific measures are you prepared to implement to reverse the situation and potentially remove President Putin's presence? [SEP] Well, that's a multifaceted issue with no easy solutions. We're evaluating all potential courses of action, but I'm not going to publicly disclose our playbook. Rest assured, we're actively engaged in finding a resolution that serves American interests.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with all due respect, why are you deflecting blame to China when Americans are dying here at home? [SEP] The world is suffering. If you seek accountability, direct your questions to those responsible. China holds the key to many answers. Yes, you in the back.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. We're coming up on the 1-year anniversary of the killing of bin Laden. I wonder if you would share some thoughts on that anniversary. And I also wanted to mention that your likely opponent says anybody would have made that call, even Jimmy Carter. So I'm curious to see what you would say about that.And, Mr. Prime Minister, if I may, on the same topic, you mentioned the international fight against terrorism in your opening remarks, and I wonder if you could reflect on President Obama's record here and if you think from an international perspective the U.S. is playing it right in marking this anniversary? Or if you think it--you might advise against excessive celebration? [SEP] Well, let me make a couple of points. First of all, Christi, I hardly think that you've seen any excessive celebration taking place here. I think that people--the American people rightly remember what we as a country accomplished in bringing to justice somebody who killed over 3,000 of our citizens. And it's a mark of the excellence of our intelligence teams and our military teams, a political process that worked. And I think for us to use that time for some reflection to give thanks to those who participated is entirely appropriate, and that's what's been taking place.As far as my personal role and what other folks would do, I'd just recommend that everybody take a look at people's previous statements in terms of whether they thought it was appropriate to go into Pakistan and take out bin Laden. I assume that people meant what they said when they said it. That's been at least my practice. I said that I'd go after bin Laden if we had a clear shot at him, and I did.If there are others who have said one thing and now suggest they'd do something else, then I'd go ahead and let them explain it. President Obama has been standing at the very forefront in the fight against terrorism, and I hold him in very high regard for that.Now, although bin Laden has been killed, terrorism has not been rooted out, and I think continued efforts will be needed in cooperation with the United States. We also would like to continue all our efforts against terrorism. I think the forms of terrorism are being very diverse, amongst them, cyberterrorism, for example. This--[inaudible]--between Japan and the United States not just in the cyber--in the space and ocean, but we also decided to cooperate in cybersecurity as well. So, inclusive of all these, Japan and the United States shall work together to root out terrorism of all sorts.Let me call on Takatsuka-san of Mainichi Shimbun.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. ——and asked him to take responsibility? And what did he say to you? And why do you call him your friend? [SEP] I have. And I have, and we have talked about it. And I really don't think it was in his interest at all. I know the Warmbier family very well. I think they're an incredible family. What happened is horrible. I really believe something very bad happened to him, and I don't think that the top leadership knew about it.And when they had to send him home—by the way, I got the prisoners back. I got the hostages back. And Otto was one of the hostages, but Otto came back in shape that was not even to be talked about. I find it—I thought it was horrible. Now, the others came back extremely healthy. But Otto came back in a condition that was just terrible.
label: Dodging

sentence: So, about Chavez's influence, do you believe it's as significant as people claim? [SEP] My opinion on the matter is...?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, now that you've chosen a location for your Presidential library, the challenge shifts to fundraising. Reports indicate a goal of $200 million. Is that a reasonable estimate? Do you believe the public is entitled to know who is making such substantial donations to their President? Will you make contributions public as they're received? And will you establish any restrictions on donor identity or donation amounts? [SEP] Don't know, maybe, we'll see. The final budget isn't set, and as Donnie Evans has indicated, we'll comply with the disclosure regulations. Some individuals prefer to donate privately, and we'll consider that. What was your other question?
label: Clarification

sentence: What advice would you offer Democrats regarding the incoming administration, and what are your views on Nancy Pelosi's continued leadership? [SEP] Let's start with Nancy. She's an extraordinary leader. Our accomplishments are largely due to her. I generally refrain from party endorsements, and as I depart office, I should probably abstain. Nevertheless, I can't overstate my admiration for her. She embodies strong values and exceptional political acumen. She confronts challenging issues, even when unpopular with her constituents, because it's the right course of action. To the Democrats, I suggest giving the new administration a fair opportunity. Avoid replicating Mitch McConnell's strategy of complete obstruction. That's not the purpose of being elected. Uphold your principles, but if the new administration is implementing policies that benefit the country, cooperate. Always prioritize the well-being of the American people. That's been my guiding principle. You'll inevitably err, but you'll remain faithful to your oath. Remember, the U.S. is a crucial nation on the world stage. We must defend democracy, the rule of law, a free press, and work with other countries to better the world.
label: General

sentence: With the Pope's recognition of Palestine, how do you see this impacting the prospects for a two-state solution in the region? [SEP] Let me be clear, my priority is creating jobs and growing the economy. We're talking about investing in American manufacturing, bringing jobs back home, and ensuring that America remains the global leader in innovation. Now, some folks are saying we can't afford to make these investments. But I believe we can't afford not to. We need to invest in our future, and that's what I'm committed to doing. Now, remind me again of your original question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the European bailout, there seemed to be some tension with European leaders regarding funding. You pointed out that TARP was solely a U.S. initiative. Are you now confident that European leaders will fund this firewall independently, without seeking handouts, and that they'll take the necessary steps? Also, how difficult was it to advocate for stimulus measures when your own efforts are currently stalled in Congress? [SEP] The conversation about stimulus measures was short, a while back. We discussed ways to boost economic growth, which don't always involve government spending. The rebalancing agenda, for instance, can significantly increase global demand through adjustments by countries, without traditional fiscal stimulus. There wasn't a disagreement with the Europeans. They agree it's important to show that the European project is strong, that they're committed to the euro, and that they're determined to solve the crisis. European leaders know this starts with a unified approach. We've seen all the pieces for dealing with the crisis put in place, which we think are the right ones. First, a solution for Greece, involving debt reduction, reforms, and structural changes, despite recent issues. Second, recapitalizing Europe's banks, which is key for market confidence. Third, creating a firewall to show that Europe is supporting the euro. The details are being worked out. We gave them some ideas. The G-20 will assist and cushion the global economy from market shocks as Europe works through these issues. They have a strong partner in us. But European leaders know that the markets want a strong signal of Europe's support for the euro.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, if the Nebraska judge approves the route, will you immediately authorize the pipeline, despite concerns about climate change? [SEP] We'll review all the information and make a decision that's in the best interest of the American people. We'll consider the economic benefits, the environmental impact, and the geopolitical implications. We're not going to rush into anything. We'll make a responsible decision based on the facts.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Gaza situation, will it conclude before you leave office, and what's your stance on Israel's conduct? [SEP] Look, I'm aiming for a lasting cease-fire. That means Hamas stops the rocket attacks, plain and simple. The ball's in their court. We're collaborating with Egypt to cut off the arms supply to Gaza, which fuels Hamas's aggression. Those supplying the weapons need to be held accountable, and the world needs to put pressure on them. If Hamas wants peace, they need to disarm. Neighboring countries need to crack down on smuggling. It's a challenge, with those tunnels and all. Now, remind me, what was the second part of your question again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Regarding the shortages, when will we see items like hand sanitizer back in stock? And Mr. President, about a potential cruise industry bailout, is that still on the table, and what's the estimated cost? [SEP] Well, let me clarify, I didn't commit to anything. But the cruise industry, a vital part of our economy, has been hit hard. We're exploring options to assist them, as we are with the airlines. We want to ensure their stability. Now, about the hand sanitizer, I'll defer to my colleague here.
label: General

sentence: Sir, regarding the Mayor's order in DC, will you recommend that federal properties, including the White House, comply, even though they're exempt? [SEP] We're still evaluating the situation. Expect an announcement on our course of action soon.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regardless of your personal beliefs, does the QAnon conspiracy theory, with its outlandish claims of satanic cults and pedophilia, represent a dangerous and harmful ideology? [SEP] I'm not familiar with the specifics, but if it's about protecting the world from harm, then I'm on board. We're battling a radical-left ideology that will destroy our country and, ultimately, the world. We need to be strong.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Are you contemplating direct discussions with Iran, Mr. President? [SEP] To ensure I'm addressing your question accurately, are you asking if I will be meeting face to face with Iranian representatives?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, the public is anxious for progress on this issue. Can you provide any concrete details regarding the expected timeframe for implementation? [SEP] If I'm being completely transparent, pinning down a precise schedule right now is simply not possible.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Senator Leahy wants a 'truth commission' to investigate the Bush years. Your thoughts, and will you rule out prosecuting Bush administration officials? [SEP] I haven't seen the specifics of his plan, so I can't really say. Look, we're committed to doing things the right way, no torture, Geneva Conventions, the rule of law. But I'm more interested in looking ahead, bringing people together, including the intelligence community. I'll take a look at it, but moving forward is the key.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. But do you think we're winning? Do you think we're winning? [SEP] I do. I think we're making good progress. I do, yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, could I ask a question, since I am from the New York Times—— Q. Mr. President—— Q. ——before this gentleman? [SEP] Since you're where? Since you're where?

sentence: Q. Did he brief you on his plans? [SEP] And if you ask him, he will tell you, and he'll tell you very nicely: You have the money, it's sitting there, it's ready to go. The Democrats don't want to approve it, but I want money for other things too. I want money to go to people so they can live very nicely, because China caused the problem; they didn't.Go ahead.

sentence: Following your earlier statements regarding 'fire and fury,' could you clarify whether that approach remains relevant in the current context? [SEP] Well, the context is everything, isn't it? At that moment, 'fire and fury' seemed like the appropriate response, perhaps even a necessary one. We couldn't stand idly by while that kind of capability developed, especially with the potential impact on the United States and our close partners like Japan, which, as everyone knows, is just next door.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, what specific steps is the United States prepared to take to ensure that he is held accountable for his actions? [SEP] We are considering all options. We will work with our allies to impose sanctions, to provide support to the opposition, and to pursue all available legal avenues. We will not rest until he is brought to justice.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: How would you define torture? [SEP] Define what, exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence:
Mr. President, your party seems to be plagued by scandals lately, with members quick to point fingers. Why do you think so many Republicans are struggling to meet basic ethical standards? [SEP] Look, Richard, if someone messes up, they should pay the price, plain and simple. We need trust in government, and that means holding people accountable, no matter who they are. I take responsibility for my actions, and everyone else should too. We all have a duty to act with integrity. People can disagree, but we need standards, and we need to enforce them.

Thanks, see you out there.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Oracle and TikTok deal, are you willing to sign off on it even if the Treasury isn't getting a cut? And does it actually satisfy your national security concerns? [SEP] Look, they're still running the numbers and giving me the lowdown on this deal. It's gotta be airtight when it comes to national security, 100%. And no, I'm not just gonna rubber-stamp it. I need to see the specifics. Security is key, especially given everything that's been happening. We need to be protected. They're briefing me first thing tomorrow, and I'll let you know where we stand.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, to be clear, did you authorize an investigation into the Hadley memo leak before meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki, and do you suspect internal sabotage? [SEP] Let's just say that leaks are a serious problem, a real thorn in the side of any administration. I wouldn't want to speculate on the specifics of any particular investigation, but I can assure you that we take these matters very seriously. Finding the source is like finding a needle in a haystack, but we're always looking.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Ukraine, the US has been exporting heavy weapons while Germany has only provided helmets. Shouldn't NATO act unanimously, with Germany providing heavy weapons? Also, should Germany rethink Nord Stream 2 given the Russian threat? Finally, do you understand the criticism from US media and Congress about Germany's reliability as an ally? Is Germany a reliable partner? [SEP] There's absolutely no need for Germany to 'win back' trust. They have it, unequivocally. Germany is a cornerstone ally, without question. Their partnership is rock solid. Germany is a leading financial supporter of Ukraine, spearheading economic assistance. Regarding media criticism, Germany is completely reliable. Absolutely, totally, and thoroughly. We are united. The transatlantic partnership is a permanent fixture of German policy and will continue to be. Within NATO, Germany is the top continental European contributor, financially and militarily. They've provided approximately $2 billion in direct aid and $3.8 billion through the EU since 2014. This is an unbreakable friendship. We'll act as one on sanctions concerning the Ukrainian border situation.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Given Kim Jong Un's history of human rights abuses and economic mismanagement, what specific assurances did you receive that he is genuinely committed to a brighter future for his people and open to economic reform? [SEP] We had a frank and open discussion about the need for North Korea to change course and embrace economic reform. While I cannot guarantee that he will follow through on his commitments, I believe that he understands the potential benefits of a more open and prosperous society. We will continue to engage with him and to monitor his progress closely.
label: General

sentence: Q. The Azerbaijan—the Karabakh. And the civilians are killed. And according to the officials from Azerbaijan, they say the first shoot came from the Armenians. What's your comment on this? [SEP] So we're looking at it very strongly. It just happened. And I know about it. I learned about it today and yesterday. And we're looking at it very strongly. We have a lot of good relationships in that area. We'll see if we can stop it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the allegations of forced labor in Xinjiang by the Chinese Communist Party, your administration has imposed a limited ban on certain products from the region, falling short of a comprehensive ban. How do you respond to the CCP's denial of these allegations, claiming that forced labor does not exist in Xinjiang? Additionally, have any of our allies expressed interest in joining us in taking measures against the alleged forced labor imposed by the Communist Party? [SEP] Yes, we are very concerned about that. We have been very clear about that. We are receiving reports as we speak. In the next few days, we will have a much clearer understanding of the situation, and we will then determine what actions need to be taken. Next question. World Trade Organization/-U.S. Trade
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. And just very quickly, you mentioned Republicans and reaching out to them. Some Republicans who may be open to major changes on voting rights—for instance, like Mitt Romney—he says he never even received a phone call from this White House. Why not? [SEP] Well, I like Mitt—look, Mitt Romney is a straight guy. He's—and one of the things that we're doing, I was trying to make sure we got everybody on the same page in my party on this score. And I didn't call many Republicans at all.The fact is that there—I do think that Mitt is a serious guy. I think we can get things done. I think—I predict to you they'll get something done on the electoral reform side of this.But rather than judge what's going to get done and not get done, all I can say is, I'm going to continue to make the case why it's so important to not turn the electoral process over to political persons who are set up deliberately to change the outcome of elections.The—Allison Harris [NewsNation], please./2022 Congressional Elections/Voter Turnout
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. How can you guarantee the executive action will be effective against Republican obstruction, and are you now considering a scope of 2 million or more? [SEP] Look, the details are still being ironed out. When we roll it out, you'll have all the specifics. We're aiming for maximum impact.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you very much. My first question is to President Trump. Mr. President, you've spent the last 2 days reaffirming the U.S.-Japan alliance, and you've begun sketching out this vision of a free and open Indo-Pacific. But in 2 days, you're going to travel to China, a country that is neither free nor open. So my question is, how can the U.S. be a force for freedom and openness in this region without inevitably coming into conflict with China?And then, to the Prime Minister: Mr. Prime Minister, the President has spoken on many occasions in the past about hoping to see the Japanese take a strong role in their own defense. He'd like to sell Japan military equipment, and there have been press reports that the President was disappointed that the Japanese didn't shoot the North Korean missile out of the sky, the one that was shot over Hokkaido. I'm wondering, did this subject come up? And what message did you have for the President about the role you'd like to see Japan take in its defense? [SEP] Thank you, Mark. I will say, if I could just take a piece of the Prime Minister's answer, he will shoot them out of the sky when he completes the purchase of lots of additional military equipment from the United States. He will easily shoot them out of the sky, just like we shot something out of the sky the other day in Saudi Arabia, as you saw. And that was a very rapidly moving missile shot out of the sky. That was a needle in the sky, and it was hit immediately and exploded without damage.So one of the things, I think, that's very important is that the Prime Minister of Japan is going to be purchasing massive amounts of military equipment, as he should. And we make the best military equipment, by far. He'll be purchasing it from the United States. Whether it's the F-35 fighter, which is the greatest in the world—total stealth—or whether it's missiles of many different kinds, it's a lot of jobs for us and a lot of safety for Japan and other countries that are likewise purchasing a lot of military equipment from us that, frankly, a year ago and 2 years ago were not.As far as China is concerned, my relationship, as you know, with President Xi is also excellent. I like him a lot. I consider him a friend. He considers me a friend. With that being said, he represents China; I represent the United States. His views are different on things, but they're pretty similar on trade.The problem we have with China is that for decades they've been—you know, it's been a very unfair—let me be very kind to previous administrations—it's been a very unfair trade situation. Our trade deficit is massive. It's hundreds of billions of dollars a year, anywhere from $350 billion to $504 billion, and that doesn't include intellectual property. And we've already started discussions with China because it has to come down. It has to come down. And that has to do with, really, free trade, fair trade, or reciprocal trade.And frankly, I like reciprocal the best of the group. Because when you explain to somebody that you're going to charge tariffs in order to equalize or you're going to do other things, some people that don't get it; they don't like to hear that. But when you say it's going to be reciprocal—that we're going to charge the same as they're charging us—the people that don't want a 5-percent or a 10-percent tariff say, oh, reciprocal is fair—and that could be 100 percent. So it's much more, Mark, understandable when you talk about reciprocal.And reciprocal trade is very important to me. We have many countries, not just China or Japan, or so many others that we see. I mean, we have one country that charges us a hundred-percent tax if we sell things into that country, and yet when they sell the same product into ourcountry, we charge them nothing. Now, I've been against that for a long time, and you will be seeing, we do things about it.Now, it also takes a period of time to do that, because, as you know, you have statutory limitations in time. You have to put out notices. You have to wait 90 days before you can put out the next, and then you have to wait another 120 days, and then a hundred—then a 30-day. Now, much of this has already been caught and caught up. Some of it was unnecessary, statutorily.But you will be seeing things of countries that have been treating the United States and the United States worker and companies—because I view the companies not as a company, I view it as an extension of the worker—but that have been treating our companies, our country, and our workers very unfairly.You will be seeing that the United States will take very, very strong action. It's already started, but most of the legal foundation has now been done. And you're going to see a very big difference, and it's going to happen very soon. Because the United States, by many countries, has been treated very, very unfairly when it comes to trade.Thank you very much. Regarding Japan defense equipment, a lot of them we purchase from the United States. North Korean situation becoming very tough, the Asia-Pacific security situation becoming very tough, we qualitatively and quantitatively, we have to enhance our defense capability. As the President mentioned, F-35A is a case in point. SM-3 Block IIA is another plan for purchase from the United States. Aegis vessels, the quality and the quantity must be enhanced. In that process, we will be buying more from the United States. That is what I am thinking.Now, North Korea: North Korea launched missiles. Immediately after that, we traced them; we were able to grasp and trace where they were going. Missile defense is something which is based upon the cooperation between Japan and the United States. Missile defense system is a cooperation between the two countries. For the intercepting and shooting down, if it is necessary, of course, we will do that—if it is necessary. But in doing so, U.S. and Japan will closely coordinate our actions. Thank you.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Medicare reform, are you open to exploring alternative approaches that would remove the issue from the political arena and entrust it to a panel of independent experts? [SEP] Well, on the second point, that's exactly what our proposal is. It—called the MedPAC program. By the way, it was originally a Republican idea. I want to give credit where credit is due. The Republican Congress passed a bill that created a panel of health care experts to make recommendations to Congress on how we could get better quality, lower cost. The problem is, every year it would just go on a shelf and nobody would act on it.So what we've said is let's give that body some power. Let's require Congress to vote on the proposals that they're making every year. Congress can still reject them, so it's not completely removing it from politics, but they have to reject or accept it as a package. And that, I think, would incentivize and empower important changes.But here's the thing I want to emphasize, Chip. It's not going to reduce benefits. What it's going to do is to change how those benefits are delivered so that they're more efficient. Let me give you a very specific example. You've heard that as a consequence of our efforts at reform, the pharmaceutical industry has already said they're willing to put $80 billion on the table. Now, why is that? Well, the reason is, is because there's probably even more waste than $80 billion, in terms of how the drug plan in is administered. We might be able to get 100 billion out or more, but the pharmaceutical industry voluntarily said here's $80 billion.You know what that translates—what that means? That means that senior citizens who right now have a so-called doughnut hole in their plan, where after spending a certain amount on prescription drugs suddenly they drop off a cliff and they've got to pocket the entire cost, suddenly half of that is filled. That's a hard commitment that we already have. So that's a change in how we are delivering . But you know what? It turns out that it means out-of-pocket savings for seniors. That's why AARP has endorsed us. Okay.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. On the second question, your objections are well aired, but do you feel responsibility notwithstanding a move in that direction or help President-elect Trump move in that direction? [SEP] I will help President Trump—President-elect Trump with any advice, counsel, information that we can provide so that he, once he's sworn in, can make a decision. Between now and then, these are decisions that I have to make based on the consultations I have with our military and the people who have been working this every single day.Peter Alexander [NBC News].
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, could you elaborate on the nature of this person's Twitter follow and any potential implications? [SEP] It's a simple matter of someone following me on Twitter, as far as I know. The platform is widely used, and many individuals engage with my account. We received a communication, indicating their interest in potential collaboration, though nothing substantial. I pride myself on maintaining positive relationships across the board. As I've previously suggested, my approach to foreign policy may surprise some. We are currently exploring potential agreements, and it would be wise for all parties to reach a resolution. I am patient, unlike those who are struggling. They were in a dire situation when I assumed office, facing numerous challenges. However, my focus on foreign policy has shifted the balance, and we are no longer being taken advantage of. We were essentially subsidizing the defense of certain nations while simultaneously incurring trade deficits with them. This is being rectified, and they are aware of it. I even questioned Prime Minister Abe about the trade imbalance, and he admitted that it had gone unchallenged for years. Similarly, with China, the tariff discrepancies were blatant. They confessed to gradually increasing them without consequence. But I am addressing these issues directly. Now, let's move on.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Is it your position that an agreement hinged on Israel's temporary halt to annexation? [SEP] I didn't hear you. Could you repeat that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. So within that $2 trillion band, if you end up going for this middle-of-the-road package, which I think you referred to as the second option, would that need to have, for your signature, some sort of stimulative measures, either payroll tax extension or the extension of the unemployment insurance? [SEP] I think both would be good for the economy. A payroll tax cut is something that has put a thousand dollars in the pocket of the typical American family over the last 6, 7 months and has helped offset some of the rising costs in gasoline and food. And I think that American consumers and American businesses would benefit from a continuation of that tax cut next year.Unemployment insurance--obviously, unemployment is still too high. And there are a lot of folks out there who are doing everything they can to find a job, but the market is still tight out there. And for us to make sure that they are able to stay in their homes potentially or they're able to still support their families, I think, is very important and contributes to the overall economy.So I think there are ways that you can essentially take a little over a trillion dollars in serious discretionary cuts, meaningful discretionary cuts, and then start building on top of that some cuts in non-health-care mandatory payments, ethanol programs, or how we calculate various subsidies to various industries. That could potentially be layered on. And we could still do something like a tax cut for ordinary families that would end up benefiting the economy as a whole.That is not my preferable option, though. I just want to be clear. I think about this like a layer cake. You can do the bare minimum, and then you can make some progressively harder decisions to solve the problem more and more.And we're in a position now where if we're serious about this and everybody is willing to compromise, we can, as I said before, fix this thing probably for a decade or more. And that's something that I think would be good for the overall business climate and would encourage the American people that Washington actually is willing to take care of its business.
label: General

sentence: Given the economic strains on American families due to inflation and high gas prices, and considering your administration's promotion of foreign investments, should Americans brace themselves for an economic downturn, Mr. President? Is a recession unavoidable? [SEP] Absolutely not. We're building a stronger, more resilient economy for the long haul.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you name any additional Chinese tech companies under scrutiny for potential bans in the U.S.? [SEP] We are constantly assessing potential threats to our national security. We will take appropriate action if necessary to protect American interests.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, a few minutes ago, when you were explaining the purpose of sanctions against Iran, you said the point is to change Iranian Government calculations, leading to altered behavior. Why hasn't that happened in the case of North Korea, which, unlike Iran, actually does have nuclear weapons? [SEP] Well, I'm not going to give you a full dissertation on n behavior. I think it's fair to say that has chosen a path of severe isolation that has been extraordinarily damaging to its people and that it is our hope that as pressure builds for to improve its economic performance, for example, to break out of that isolation, that we'll see a return to the six-party talks and that we will see a change in behavior.Now, as I said, I--sanctions are not a magic wand. Unfortunately, nothing in international relations is. But I do think that the approach that we've taken with respect to makes it more likely for them to alter their behavior than had there been no consequences whatsoever to them testing a nuclear weapon. Okay?Chuck Todd [NBC News].
label: Dodging

sentence:
Mr. President, you've said Qadhafi must go. What specific actions, beyond sanctions and diplomatic pressure, are you willing to authorize, and what are the potential risks and consequences you've considered? [SEP] Look, we've been extremely proactive. We immediately secured our people, then we froze Qadhafi's assets – a record amount, by the way. We've also pushed for international sanctions and are working with NATO on various options, including a possible no-fly zone. Hillary's meeting with the opposition soon, and we're sending someone to talk to them directly. So, all options are on the table.

But let's be clear: sending in the military isn't something I take lightly. There are risks, and we need to think everything through. I'm talking to Gates, Mullen, everyone. Plus, we need to keep our allies on board. That's key.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Sir, with respect to the general's warning, what exactly do you mean by 'the big war' he mentioned? [SEP] Elaborate on your understanding of 'the big war' in question.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, what assurances can you offer to the American public that these alternative approaches will ultimately lead to a resolution, given the complexities of the situation? [SEP] I want to assure the American people that we are fully committed to resolving this matter and bringing our citizens home safely. We are working tirelessly, exploring every available option, and engaging in constructive dialogue with all relevant parties. While I cannot guarantee a specific outcome, I am confident that our efforts will ultimately bear fruit.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Regarding the executive action, what measures are in place to counter Republican attempts to defund it? And can you provide any insight into whether the target is now closer to 2 million or even higher? [SEP] I believe that when we unveil the specifics of the executive action, it will be incredibly detailed. I'm sure there will be plenty of follow-up questions.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, I have three questions--[laughter]--starting with Mitt Romney. Just one question, I promise. [Laughter]You started with a $447 billion jobs bill. Two months later, many speeches later, you've got virtually nothing from that. You've got the veterans jobs bill, which is important, obviously, and a lot of Executive orders. Are you coming to the realization that you may just get nothing here and go to the American people in 2012 without another jobs bill, 9-percent unemployment, and them wondering about your leadership, sir? [SEP] Well, I think, first of all, the American people at this point are wondering about congressional leadership in failing to pass the jobs bill, the components of which the majority of Americans, including many Republicans, think are a good idea.And that's part of the reason why the American people right now aren't feeling real good about Congress. Normally, by the way, the way politics works is if the overwhelming majority of the American people aren't happy with what you're doing, you start doing something different. So far that hasn't happened in Congress, and the Republicans in Congress, in particular. They don't seem to have that same sense of urgency about needing to put people back to work.I'm going to keep on pushing. My expectation is, is that we will get some of it done now, and I'll keep on pushing until we get all of it done. And that may take me all the way till November to get it all done. And it may take a new Congress to get it all done. But the component parts--cutting taxes for middle class families, cutting taxes for small businesses that are hiring our veterans, hiring the long-term unemployed, put teachers back in the classroom--here in the State of Hawaii, you have a bunch of kids who are going to school 4 days a week because of budget problems. How are we going to win the competition in the 21st century with our kids going to school basically half time?The jobs bill would help alleviate those budget pressures at the State level.Rebuilding our infrastructure. Every world leader that you talk to, they're saying to themselves, how can we make sure we've got a first-class infrastructure? And as you travel through the Asia-Pacific region, you see having better airports than us, Singapore having superior ports to ours. Well, that's going to impact our capacity to do business here, our capacity to trade, our capacity to get U.S. products made by U.S. workers into the fastest growing market in the world. And by the way, we could put a lot of people back to work at the same time.So I'm going to keep on pushing. And my expectation is, is that we will just keep on chipping away at this. If you're asking me do I anticipate that the Republican leadership in the House or the Senate suddenly decide that I was right all along and they will adopt a hundred percent of my proposals, the answer is, no, I don't expect that. Do I anticipate that at some point they recognize that doing nothing is not an option? That's my hope. And that should be their hope too, because if they don't, I think we'll have a different set of leaders in Congress.All right? Thank you very much, everybody. Thank you.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, intelligence agencies are reporting that Russia is already interfering in this year's election to hurt Joe Biden, and that China is considering interfering to hurt you. Do you find this credible, and what are your plans to address it? [SEP] It's possible. Russia probably doesn't want me in office, since I've been tougher on them than anyone else, ever.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: The question is, do you believe it was justified for the United States to use nuclear weapons against Hiroshima and Nagasaki? [SEP] Now, was that the only question you wanted to ask?

sentence: To be clear, Mr. President, are you endorsing that specific proposal? [SEP] Not that one, precisely, but we're moving in the right direction. We're nearing an agreement. I strongly support directing substantial resources to those who were unfairly harmed because they had the power to stop it. They could have blocked its entry into their country, our country, Europe, and its spread to 188 nations globally. It's crucial to remember that.

sentence: Regarding your meetings with Chairman Kim Jong Un, is there a written record of your conversations? [SEP] Excuse me?

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, could you perhaps repeat the question? I didn't quite catch that. [SEP] Pardon?

sentence: Q. You've mentioned media impatience and your willingness to be a one-term president for the right reasons. Why not invite Republicans to negotiate now, and what are you doing to foster cooperation? Do you think the markets will remain patient? [SEP] I should have brought a notepad! My brain is getting overloaded here.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, considering the setbacks on your domestic agenda and your current approval ratings, would you concede that this has been the most difficult year of your time in office? [SEP] Julie, I don't really frame it that way. I've been at this for five years, running for two before that. There have been ups and downs, as you all know. I'm focused on whether we're helping the American people, giving families more opportunity and security. There have been frustrations this past year, Congress should have moved more aggressively. But even when Congress doesn't move, we're still doing things. The ConnectEd program, wireless capacity in every classroom, will make a huge difference. A manufacturing hub in Youngstown will create innovation and connect universities, manufacturers, job training. We're producing more oil and natural gas here than we're importing. That's a big deal.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, can you elaborate on the specific economic benefits that support the auto industry? [SEP] It's about jobs. It's about manufacturing. It's about keeping America strong. We need to support our industries.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. A question about the Iraq Study Group Report. One of the things that it recommends is greater dialog, direct talks with Syria and Iran. James Baker himself, Secretary of State under your father, says that it's a lot like it was during the cold war when we talked to the Soviet Union. He says it's important to talk to your adversaries. Is he wrong? [SEP] Let me start with Iran. We made it perfectly clear to them what it takes to come to the table, and that is a suspension of their enrichment program. If they verifiably suspend—that they've stopped enrichment, we will come to the table with our EU-3 partners and Russia and discuss a way forward for them. Don, it should be evident to the Iranians, if this is what they want to do.I heard the Foreign Minister—I read the Foreign Minister say the other day that, Yes, we'll sit down with America, after they leave Iraq. If they want to sit down with us, for the good of the Iranian people, they ought to verifiably suspend their program. We've made that clear to them. It is obvious to them how to move forward.The Iranian people can do better than becoming—than be an isolated nation. This is a proud nation with a fantastic history and tradition. And yet they've got a leader who constantly sends messages to the world that Iran is out of step with the majority of thinkers, that Iran is willing to become isolated, to the detriment of the people.I mean, I was amazed that, once again, there was this conference about the Holocaust that heralded a really backward view of the history of the world. And all that said to me was, is that the leader in Iran is willing to say things that really hurts his country and further isolates the Iranian people.We're working hard to get a Security Council resolution. I spoke to Secretary Rice about the Iranian Security Council resolution this morning. And the message will be that you—you, Iran—are further isolated from the world.My message to the Iranian people is: You can do better than to have somebody try to rewrite history. You can do better than somebody who hasn't strengthened your economy. And you can do better than having somebody who's trying to develop a nuclear weapon that the world believes you shouldn't have. There's a better way forward.Syria, the message is the same. We have met with Syria since I have been the President of the United States. We have talked to them about what is necessary for them to have a better relationship with the United States, and they're not unreasonable requests. We've suggested to them that they no longer allow Saddamists to send money and arms across their border into Iraq to fuel the violence—some of the violence that we see. We've talked to them about—they've got to leave the democrat Lebanon alone.I might say—let me step back for a second—I'm very proud of Prime Minister Siniora. He's shown a lot of tenacity and toughness in the face of enormous pressure from Syria as well as Hizballah, which is funded by Iran.But we made it clear to them, Don, on how to move forward. We've had visits with the Syrians in the past. Congressmen and Senators visit Syria. What I would suggest, that if they're interested in better relations with the United States, that they take some concrete, positive steps that promote peace as opposed to instability.Knoller [Mark Knoller, CBS Radio].
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Would you accept a political settlement with him involved as success from the American perspective? [SEP] I would accept him stepping down so that he is not directing armed forces against the n people. He needs to step down. He needs to go.Laura Meckler [Wall Street Journal]./Tax Reform/National Economy
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Is there any possibility of including an assault weapons ban in the legislative package? [SEP] The specifics will be outlined later this week.

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, many Americans feel that you are not listening to their concerns. What steps are you taking to ensure that all voices are heard and that your policies reflect the needs of the entire country? [SEP] I'm listening to everyone. I'm traveling the country. I'm meeting with people from all walks of life. And I'm doing my best to represent their interests. But it's not always easy to please everyone. And I have to make tough decisions.
label: Dodging

sentence: Given the potential inclusion of homeowner assistance in the bailout, how do you ensure that the funds are used responsibly and don't create moral hazard, encouraging further risky behavior in the housing market? [SEP] We're working with Congress to get this done quickly. It's a serious problem, and we need a robust solution. I'm a market guy, but this is bigger than that. This is about systemic risk. The collapse of one part of the system could affect everyone. So, we have to act boldly. It's going to be expensive, but the risk of doing nothing is far greater. We're going to get a lot of the money back over time. But right now, we need to send a clear signal that we're not going to let the system collapse.
label: Deflection

sentence: With Russia banning food imports and amassing troops on Ukraine's border, are sanctions failing to deter aggression? [SEP] We're still assessing the impact of the sanctions. They're designed to exert significant pressure on the Russian economy, and evidence suggests they are doing just that. Capital flight is substantial, and economic growth projections have been revised downwards. President Putin faces a choice: pursue a diplomatic resolution respecting Ukraine's sovereignty or continue on this path, harming his own economy and people. We are acting appropriately, with the support of our allies. However, the situation remains unresolved. Fighting continues, and civilians are dying. We need meaningful dialogue to ensure the rights of all Ukrainians and the implementation of reforms. President Putin must acknowledge Ukraine's independence. Until then, the problem persists, but the sanctions are having their intended effect.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, concerning Build Back Better and the pandemic, your 'big chunks' comment suggests breaking it up. True? And after the Supreme Court's ruling, will you mandate vaccines for domestic flights? [SEP] Okay, two things. The Supreme Court, I think, got it wrong. But companies are still testing, so it's not a total loss. That will probably increase. What was the first part again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Regarding Libya, when you mention transferring command, what's the projected timeline? And is NATO the preferred entity to assume that command? Also, concerning your vision of an alliance among equals in the Americas, what specific outcomes are you aiming for after this trip? And President Pinera, what's the essence of this partnership to achieve regional goals? [SEP] On Libya, the situation is fluid, and the transfer timeline depends on our commanding officers' assessment of mission completion. Our initial focus was neutralizing Libyan air defenses for the no-fly zone, ensuring coalition aircraft safety. Humanitarian aspects are also key. We anticipate this transition in days, not weeks. The Pentagon will brief the public. NATO will coordinate due to its capabilities, but Admiral Mullen will detail the transfer. As for the Americas partnership, I don't want to spoil my speech! But Chile offers much, like clean energy expertise. We seek a clean energy partnership. While we excel in alternative energy, Chile may have transferable initiatives. In education, we want American students to look outwards. A broad exchange program is crucial. Security cooperation is vital against narcotraffickers. Colombia's progress offers lessons for Central America. Joint training would be more effective. This partnership is a two-way street, not just aid to a poor country. Chile, a regional power, collaborates for peace and prosperity. We lag in Americas integration compared to Europe. They abandoned war for the Maastricht Treaty. President Bush Sr.'s free trade area idea never materialized. Latin America is ready to fulfill its potential. We share territory, hardworking people, and fewer racial/religious conflicts. We aim to recover lost time. We have much in common: Harvard ties, sports. The First Ladies admire each other. We seek a Partnership 2.0 with shared responsibilities, not existentialism. This alliance should be comprehensive: democracy, freedom, rule of law, human rights. We must improve the OAS democratic charter. It should open doors to free trade faster and include education, science, technology, innovation. These are pillars for Latin America to overcome poverty. We can learn from the US's innovation. This alliance addresses energy, water, organized crime, terrorism, drug trafficking, global warming, and world security. We need a new international order beyond Bretton Woods. The time is right to end past encounters and initiate collaboration. We must face problems and seize opportunities in the knowledge society. Latin America missed the Industrial Revolution; we can't miss this one. No child should be left behind, and no country should be left behind. Thank you.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the deficit reduction targets, what specific measures are under consideration to guarantee their achievement in the years ahead? [SEP] I beg your pardon? Would you mind restating the question? The acoustics aren't great.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. You've correctly suggested that the media can be impatient about seeing you--seeing both sides come to a deal, but this is your third budget, your third year of your Presidency. You've said many times that you'd rather be a one-party--one-term President if it means you've done the hard things that need to be done. Now, I know you're not going to stand there and invite Republicans to the negotiating table today to start hashing it all out, but why not? And since you're not, though, what more are you doing to build the spirit of cooperation you mentioned earlier needs to happen before there is bipartisanship?And finally, do you think the markets will wait 2 years? [SEP] I should have written all this down, Jackie. [] I'm running out of room here in my brain.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. How many? Q. Mr. President, how many people? Q. Was it at the event last night? [SEP] A very—from what I heard, a very small number. I think you can probably give the number out later on when you find out what it might be. Yes, it's one person. . One person?
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Of the Biden administration. And accused the United States of containing China while pushing for diplomatic talks.How would you respond to that? And do you think President Xi is being sincere about getting the relationship back on track as he bans Apple in China? [SEP] Well, look, first of all, theI am sincere about getting the relationship right. And one of the things that is going on now is, China is beginning to change some of the rules of the game, in terms of trade and other issues.And so one of the things we talked about, for example, is that they're now talking about making sure that no Chineseno one in the Chinese Government can use a Western cell phone. Those kinds of things.And so, really, what this trip was aboutit was less about containing China. I don't want to contain China. I just want to make sure that we have a relationship with China that is on the up and up, squared away, everybody knows what it's all about. And one of the ways you do that is, you make sure that we are talking about the same things.And I think that one of the things we've doneI've tried to do, and I've talked with a number of my staff about this for the last, I guess, 6 monthsis, we have an opportunity to strengthen alliances around the world to maintain stability.That's what this trip was all about: having India cooperate much more with the United States, be closer with the United States, Vietnam being closer with the United States. It's not about containing China; it's about having a stable base, a stable base in the Indo-Pacific.And it'sfor example, when I was spending a lot of time talking with President Xi, he asked why we were doingwhy was I going to have the Quad, meaning Australia, India, Japan, and the United States? And I said, To maintain stability. It's not about isolating China. It's about making sure the rules of the roadeverything from airspace and space in the ocean isthe international rules of the road are abided by.And soand I hope thatI think that Prime Minister XiI mean, Xi has somesome difficulties right now. All countries end up with difficulties, and he had some economic difficulties he's working his way through. I want to see China succeed economically, but I want to see them succeed by the rules.The next question was to Bloomberg.
label: Explicit
