sentence: Q. New jobless numbers today back in the States. You're on a pace to face the voters with the highest unemployment rate of any postwar President. And doesn't that make you significantly vulnerable to a Republican who might run on a message of change? And if I may add, given that you have just witnessed the difficulties of averting economic problems beyond your control, what state do you think the economy will be in when you face reelection next year? [SEP] Jim, I have to tell you the least of my concerns at the moment is the politics of a year from now. I'm worried about putting people back to work right now, because those folks are hurting and the U.S. economy is underperforming. And so everything that we're doing here in the--here at the G-20 mirrors our efforts back home. That is, how do we boost growth, how do we shrink our deficits in a way that doesn't slow the recovery right now, how do we make sure that our workers are getting the skills and the training they need to compete in a global economy? And not only does the American Jobs Act answer some of the needs for jobs now, but it will also lay the foundation for future growth through investments in infrastructure, for example.So my hope is, is that the folks back home, including those in the United States Senate and the House of Representatives, when they look at today's job numbers--which were positive, but indicate once again that the economy is growing way too slow--that they think twice before they vote no again on the only proposal out there right now that independent economists say would actually make a dent in unemployment right now. There's no excuse for inaction. That's true globally; it's certainly true back home as well. And I'm going to keep on pushing it regardless of what the politics are.Chuck Todd [NBC News].
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, given the current economic pressures facing American families due to high gas prices, are you prepared to directly ask Saudi Arabia to increase oil production during your upcoming trip? And if so, how will you reconcile that request with your administration's stated commitment to holding Saudi Arabia accountable for its human rights record? [SEP] Look, the trip isn't primarily about that. I'm starting in Israel, and they see this trip as vital. It's also about the G-7, the Gulf States plus three. It happens to be in Saudi Arabia, but it's not *about* Saudi Arabia. I might see the King and Crown Prince, but that's not the main event. The focus is on deepening Israel's integration in the region, which is good for peace and security. That's why Israeli leaders support my trip. We're also working to reduce casualties in the Yemen war. It's a broad agenda that extends far beyond Saudi Arabia's specific interests.
label: Deflection

sentence: Concerning the executive action, how do you plan to guarantee its potency should Republicans attempt to obstruct it through funding cuts? Furthermore, could you offer some perspective on whether the envisioned scope now encompasses 2 million individuals or more? [SEP] I anticipate that the unveiling of this executive action will be replete with granular information. And I'm sure there will be a lot of follow-up questions.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Considering your value of loyalty, were you disappointed by Scott McClellan's views on Iraq? And with improvements in Iraq, what guidance would you offer Senator Obama as he evaluates the situation? [SEP] I won't comment on Scott's book. Regarding Obama, I'd urge him to heed Crocker and Petraeus. Politics can distort perceptions. That's why I rejected arbitrary withdrawal dates. We shouldn't let polls drive policy. Listen to the people there. It's hard, with groups like MoveOn.org influencing candidates. But they'll gain insights beyond news reports. John.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the potential for economic fallout, what specific measures are in place to shield the U.S. economy from the repercussions of a possible Greek departure from the Eurozone? [SEP] We had a very thorough discussion about the situation in Europe. Everyone is focused on finding a solution. I'm not going to speculate about what might happen if Greece chooses to leave, especially with their upcoming election. The G-8 expressed a strong desire for Greece to remain in the Eurozone, provided they adhere to their existing agreements. It's crucial for Greece to determine its path forward. The situation in Greece has implications for the United States. Uncertainty in Europe can make businesses think twice about investing. We need to have safeguards in place to protect countries that are following the rules. European banks need to be strong. We need a plan for growth alongside fiscal responsibility. There seems to be a consensus on this balanced approach. They'll be meeting soon to discuss these issues further. We've offered our support and expertise. Ultimately, Europe needs to coordinate its efforts more effectively. It's a complex situation with so many countries involved. But I believe there's a greater sense of urgency now. We took decisive action in 2008, and that proved to be the right approach. It's better to act decisively.
label: General

sentence: President Obama, could you address the rumors surrounding Chen Guangcheng's whereabouts? And Prime Minister Noda, what's your assessment of the likelihood of a North Korean nuclear test, and what actions do you expect from the United States in response? [SEP] I'm aware of the reports, but I'm not going to comment on specifics. Human rights are always a topic of discussion with China. We believe China will be stronger if it embraces openness. As for North Korea, we've been in close communication with Japan. We've made it clear that provocations will lead to isolation and sanctions. We stand united in demanding that North Korea adhere to international norms.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Can I ask you one more—one more question. Sorry, sir. Mr. President, one more question, if you don't mind. I'm so sorry, sir. It's a rare opportunity. [Laughter]A lot of people are going to be rushing to Iowa, rushing to New Hampshire. You know that the Democrats are already looking ahead to 2020. Do you want to lock down your ticket right now, sir? Will the Vice President be your running mate in 2020? [SEP] Well, I haven't asked him, but I hope so. Where are you? [] Mike, will you be my running mate? [] Huh? Stand up, Mike, please. Raise your right hand. No, I'm only kidding. [] Will you? Thank you, okay good. The answer is yes. Okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. ——NATO membership process? [SEP] ——Finland is already a strong, vibrant nation. I think what Finland's joining NATO does—and with Sweden as well—when the Nordic countries are all members of NATO: It just makes the world safer. It significantly increases the prospect that there is less likely to be war.We'll—we're deadly earnest about the notion. We'll defend every single inch of NATO territory. And now we're going to—we're on the way of getting to 32 NATO nations. That's a significant commitment. And so the likelihood of any nation voluntarily deciding they're going to attack one of the nations or Finland is highly unlikely.And so—but if it were to, they understand they're not just attacking Finland; they're attacking 31 other countries.
label: Dodging

sentence: With the clock ticking, Mr. President, can you tell us who you'll nominate to chair the Federal Reserve Board? What's your thinking as you weigh your options, especially given the time constraints if you choose not to reappoint Jay Powell? [SEP] I'm not going to get into that discussion right now. The process is moving forward, and we'll have announcements in the near future. We're confident we'll have all the key nominees in place before their terms end. I've been carefully considering the options with my economic team. We have a strong pool of candidates, but I'm not going to speculate at this point.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, have you seen any indications of an increase in the pace of Iran's nuclear development? [SEP] I'm not at liberty to discuss any intelligence findings, regardless of their nature. However, I want to underscore the gravity with which we view the Iranian nuclear issue. It's a fundamental aspect of our Iranian policy. That's why we're collaborating with friends, allies, and concerned parties to garner international support and convey to the Iranian people that there's a more favorable path for them. We have no quarrel with the Iranian people. We respect their history and traditions. But their government is making decisions that will further isolate them and deny them a better economic future. So we take the issue very seriously.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Mr. President, back on Iran, can you talk a little bit about— well, Iran has signaled that it seems likely to reject Mr. Solana's offer, presenting on behalf of you and the EU. What have you and your European counterparts agreed upon in terms of new measures against Iran if that is indeed the case?And to Chancellor Merkel, what is Germany willing to do specifically, whether in implementing the sanctions already in place or taking further measures beyond those? [SEP] That's exactly what we discussed: How do you implement sanctions that are already in place, and should we levy additional sanctions? Our position is, is that we ought to enforce the sanctions that are in place, and we ought to work with our allies to levy additional sanctions if they choose—if the ians choose to continue to ignore the demands of the free world. I personally have always come out very strongly in favor of seeing to it that sanctions are decided at the level of the United Nations Security Council too, because including China and Russia obviously makes for much greater effectiveness of such sanctions. But that doesn't exclude that within the European Union too, we may discuss, for example, are further possibilities open, for example, in the banking sectors? But these further possibilities, these further measures, must not lead to a situation where at the great-er—the bigger stage, so to speak, we then relent, because the more countries are in on this, the more the effect—the more effective the impact will be on , for example.We always think that quite often, on the one hand, people like to reject certain measures to be taken, but let us think of the people in . This is what is essential. I think these people deserve a much more—sort of a better outlook also, as regards their economic prospects. And we would hope for the leadership in to finally see reason. I mean, just look at the reports of the IAEA. They—it says clear-ly—the report states clearly that certain violations of agreements that were entered into have taken place. And we—it means that we need to react to this, even if it— with further sanctions, if that's necessary.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the election results, do you feel a need to adjust your agenda for the next two years? What changes will you make in the White House and in your dealings with Republicans to address voter concerns? [SEP] The American people believe Washington isn't working for them. As President, I'm accountable to fix that. They want me to bridge divisions and get things done. So, my priority is to get things done and help Congress do the same. On agenda items, like a minimum wage increase, voters support it. The key is to find areas where my agenda overlaps with Republican ideas, even if it's not a perfect fit. I'll reach out to Republicans, listen to them, and find common ground on issues like infrastructure and exports. We can start with areas where we agree 70, 80, or 90 percent, build trust, and improve how Washington works.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you winning the competition with China? [SEP] We're winning all the competition.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Good morning, Mr. President. A lot of lawmakers in Congress are saying that China has not done enough to allow its currency to appreciate, and they're talking about things like duties. What is your view about that, and are you prepared to do more to encourage the appreciation of the yuan? [SEP] Thanks, Ed. I spoke to Madam Wu Yi today, as a matter of fact, had her into the Oval Office, wanted to thank her for bringing her delegation in and also to ask her to pass on a message to Hu Jintao that I appreciate his willingness to work in a strategic—with strategic dialogs in order to put in place the type of measures that reflect a complex relationship, in other words, the ability to discuss issues such as beef or intellectual property rights.And one of the issues that I emphasized to Madam Wu Yi, as well as the delegation, was, was that we're watching very carefully as to whether or not they will appreciate their currency. And that's all in the context of making it clear to China that we value our relationship, but the $233 billion trade deficit must be addressed. And one way to address it is through currency evaluations.Another way to address it is for them to help convert their economy from one of savers to consumers. And that's why Secretary Paulson worked very assiduously with this strategic dialog group to encourage openness for capital markets; that China must open its capital markets to allow for different financial institutions from around the world to go into the country. It not only will be beneficial to the United States, but we happen to think it will be beneficial to the Chinese economy, for the consumers to have different options when it comes to savings and purchases.And so this is a important dialog, and it's one that I thank the Chinese Government for engaging in. And there's been some progress. Yesterday they opened new air routes. That's beneficial for U.S. airlines. It also happens to be beneficial for China, as far I am concerned. It's beneficial for that country to open up its access to more travelers, whether they be business or tourists.Anyway, this is a complex relationship. And there's a lot of areas where we're working together, and there's areas where there's friction. And we've just got to work through the friction. One area where I've been disappointed is beef. They need to be eating U.S. beef. It's good for them. They'll like it. And so we're working hard to get that beef market opened up.Ed.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, if you had extensive global business holdings prior to your presidency, would you have divested them into a blind trust? Or is it acceptable for the President to be personally susceptible to foreign policy decisions? Also, briefly, what are your concerns about the NSA and Cyber Command, and are you considering replacing Admiral Rogers? [SEP] That first question was purely hypothetical, wasn't it?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Concerning the G-7 agenda, what specific shortcomings have you identified in the fight against the Islamic State, and will the increased assistance to Iraq involve deploying additional U.S. military personnel? Furthermore, did you assure Chancellor Merkel that fast track authority would pass the House, and what are the implications if it fails to do so? [SEP] Let's not talk about failure on trade. We're going to get it done. As for ISIL, we've made progress, but they're adaptable. We need to train Iraqi forces faster. When we train them and equip them, they do well. When we don't, they struggle. So, we're looking at ways to accelerate training and equipping Iraqi forces. President Abadi wants the same thing. The Pentagon is working on a plan, and I'll share it when it's ready. But it requires commitments from the Iraqis as well. The details are still being worked out.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. And, President Buhari, I want to ask you: You're the first leader from sub-Saharan Africa to visit President Trump here at the White House. Did you address his reported comments from early this year when he reportedly used vulgar language to describe African nations? [SEP] Well, I'm very careful with what the press says about others than myself. I'm not sure about, you know, the validity or whether that allegation against the President was true or not. So the best thing for me is to keep quiet. . We didn't discuss it. [] And you do have some countries that are in very bad shape and very tough places to live in. But we didn't discuss it, because the President knows me, and he knows where I'm coming from. And I appreciate that. We did not discuss it.Mr. President, you can ask a question. Yes, that lady is already up. Yes.
label: General

sentence: So, you don't believe the Koran burning incident has significantly damaged the relationship? [SEP] These are complex issues. There will be ups and downs. The important thing is to keep working towards a stable and secure Afghanistan.
label: General

sentence: Sir, with the QAnon movement gaining traction, what are your views on its ideology and its potential influence on the political landscape? [SEP] I'm not really in a position to comment on that. I'm swamped dealing with the pandemic and the economic fallout. I'll leave the analysis of fringe groups to the experts.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, Senator Leahy is proposing a truth and reconciliation committee to examine potential abuses during the Bush administration. Will you support this, and will you pledge not to prosecute any Bush officials? [SEP] I haven't reviewed the details of Senator Leahy's proposal, so I can't comment definitively. However, my focus is on ensuring my administration operates with transparency and adheres to the law. While accountability is important, my priority is moving forward and uniting the country.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, General Mattis views China as a revisionist power, yet you seem positive about your relationship with President Xi. Is China a friend or foe? Also, regarding North Korea, if sanctions fail, are all options still on the table? [SEP] On North Korea, we'll see. I'm not going to reveal my hand. If sanctions fail, we move to phase two, which could be very rough and unfortunate for the world. Hopefully, sanctions will work. We have global support. North Korea is a rogue nation. A deal would be great; otherwise, something will happen.As for General Mattis, many share his view on China. They're tough and getting stronger, partly due to poor U.S. leadership. The U.S. allowed them to get away with murder.However, we can have a great trading relationship with China. My relationship with President Xi might make that happen. Time will tell.I can confirm that President Trump and President Xi see eye-to-eye. Their respect is clear at meetings like the East Asia Summit and APEC. It's the most important relationship. It's respectful, frank, and clear-eyed.Australia sees China's rise as positive for the region and world, provided the rule of law is maintained. Some try to paint the U.S. and allies like Australia as being against China, like a Cold War rerun. That's inaccurate.We must ensure the rule of law protects everyone, preventing big countries from pushing around little countries. This has enabled growth and lifted millions out of poverty. Maintaining this order is vital.The President's presence in our region last year sent a powerful message. Regular visits by Secretaries Tillerson and Mattis, and the U.S. Navy's presence, are important for maintaining this order. It's been the foundation of success for 40 years.We've never had a better relationship with China. Trade is the only potential obstacle, as it's one-sided. Past leaders shouldn't have allowed that. It's unfair to the U.S. and its workers. It's hard for companies doing business in China due to barriers, while our barriers are foolishly low.I believe in reciprocal trade. If they do something to us, we do something to them. That never happened and has worsened. We'll correct it. This is the only thing that can hinder a long-term, great relationship. We have all the ingredients for friendship.From the Washington Examiner, Gabby [Gabby Morrongiello, Washington Examiner].
label: General

sentence: Q. Given Ghislaine Maxwell's imprisonment, do you believe she will expose powerful people? You've previously discussed Prince Andrew and Bill Clinton. [SEP] I haven't been paying much attention to that. I simply wish her the best. I've encountered her on several occasions, especially when I resided in Palm Beach. I'm unfamiliar with the Prince Andrew situation; I'm not informed about it. Yes, please, next question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Biden, with respect to the US-Iraq partnership, why wasn't Prime Minister Maliki there? [SEP] I honestly couldn't tell you. I wasn't involved in the arrangements for that event.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. But as President, shouldn't you take the high road, sir? [SEP] I am taking the high road. I'm taking the high road by not seeing them. That's the high road.Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. But you won't change the definition right now? [SEP] I'm following what the—the answer is, yes. Get the booster shot. It's all part of the same thing. You're better protected.Okay. Alex Alper, Reuters./North Atlantic Treaty Organization
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, were you ever informed, directly or indirectly, about any discussions involving your name? [SEP] That remains to be seen, doesn't it?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President, your thoughts on Hillary Clinton's chances of winning the nomination? [SEP] I'm staying out of the political fray. My job is to lead, not to handicap elections.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Now that you've cut off these payments, are you going to ensure that those people will still get help from the Federal Government to pay that insurance? [SEP] Well, that's what we're looking to do, Joe [Jonathan Karl, ABC News]. We want to get it down so that people can have affordable health care. Look, you look at some States—116 percent up. In Alaska, over 200 percent up. In other States, 50 percent, 70 percent up, and those are some of the States that are doing better. Obamacare is a wreck, it's a mess, it's destroying lives. We want to get it in those States—the States that I did so well in—but also in States that I didn't win.I want to get health care that's much more affordable and much better health care, and that's what we're doing.Yes.
label: General

sentence: So, about that Executive Order on birthright citizenship, is it still on the table? [SEP] We'll circle back to that later.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. What about the NRA? [SEP] Well, the NRA is an organization that has members who are mothers and fathers. And I would expect that they've been impacted by this as well. And hopefully, they'll do some self-reflection.And here's what we know: that any single gun law can't solve all these problems. We're going to have to look at mental health issues. We're going to have to look at schools. There are going to be a whole range of things that Joe's group looks at. We know that issues of gun safety will be an element of it. And what we've seen over the last 20 years, 15 years, is this sense that anything related to guns is somehow an encroachment on the Second Amendment. And I—what we're looking for here is a thoughtful approach that says we can preserve our Second Amendment, we can make sure that responsible gun owners are able to carry out their activities, but that we're going to actually be serious about the safety side of this, that we're going to be serious about making sure that something like Newtown or Aurora doesn't happen again.And there is a big chunk of space between what the Second Amendment means and having no rules at all. And that space is what Joe is going to be working on to try to identify where we can find some common ground.So I've got—I'm going to take one last question.Go ahead, Jake [Jake Tapper, ABC News].
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, assuming the drug proves effective, would you commit to accelerating its regulatory path for American citizens? [SEP] Well, that's a hypothetical, isn't it? I'm focused on the here and now. We're monitoring the situation closely, but I can't offer any guarantees at this stage. We have to let the process unfold naturally.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Could I go back to the issue of debt privatization? [SEP] Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. The intelligence community believes that Russia is trying to meddle in the 2020 election. Do you agree with their assessment? And what is your message to Vladimir Putin about potentially interfering regardless of the candidate they support? [SEP] Well, you know, what I'm reading—and again, I'm over here for the last number of days—but they went to see Bernie, and they told Bernie about something having to do with they want Bernie to win. They did not tell me. Intelligence never told me. And we have a couple of people here that would know very well. They never told me anything about that. And it was sort of a strange thing that they went to Bernie.And now I find out, if I believe what I read in some of your documents, in some of your papers, that it's a highly—it was highly exaggerated. And frankly, I think it's disgraceful. And I think it was leaks from the Intelligence Committee, the House version. And I think that they leaked it. I think probably Schiff leaked it, but some people within that. Schiff leaked it, in my opinion. And he shouldn't be leaking things like that. That's a terrible thing to do.But basically, they would like to see—Bernie is probably winning, and it looks like he's winning. And he's got a head of steam, and they maybe don't want him, for obvious reasons. So they don't want him, so they put out a thing that Russia is backing him. This is what they do. I've gone through it for a long time. I get it. I get the game better than anybody. And that's the way it is.A terrible thing to say. And they didn't say it about me. I will say this: Somebody leaked it in intelligence, but nobody ever told me that. We have Ambassador O'Brien in the audience someplace, and he can tell you that this was never discussed with us.So I think it's terrible. They ought to stop the leaking from the Intelligence Committee. And if they don't stop it, I can't imagine that people are not going to go after them and find out what's happening.Yes, please.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, sir. Have you made up your mind whether to take action against Syria whether or not you have a congressional resolution approved? Is a strike needed in order to preserve your credibility for when you set these sort of red lines? And were you able to enlist the support of the Prime Minister here for support in Syria? [SEP] Let me unpack the question. First of all, I didn't set a red line, the world set a red line. The world set a red line when governments representing 98 percent of the world's population said the use of chemical weapons are abhorrent and passed a treaty forbidding their use even when countries are engaged in war.Congress set a red line when it ratified that treaty. Congress set a red line when it indicated that—in a piece of legislation titled the Syria Accountability Act—that some of the horrendous things that are happening on the ground there need to be answered for.And so when I said in a press conference that my calculus about what's happening in Syria would be altered by the use of the chemical weapons, which the overwhelming consensus of humanity says is wrong, that wasn't something I just, kind of, made up. I didn't pluck it out of thin air. There's a reason for it. So that's point number one.Point number two: My credibility is not on the line, the international community's credibility is on the line. And America and Congress's credibility is on the line because we give lip service to the notion that these international norms are important.And when those videos first broke and you saw images of over 400 children subjected to gas, everybody expressed outrage: How can this happen in this modern world? Well, it happened because a Government chose to deploy these deadly weapons on civilian populations. And so the question is, how credible is the international community when it says this is an international norm that has to be observed? The question is, how credible is Congress when it passes a treaty saying we have to forbid the use of chemical weapons?And I do think that we have to act, because if we don't, we are effectively saying that even though we may condemn it and issue resolutions and so forth and so on, somebody who is not shamed by resolutions can continue to act with impunity. And those international norms begin to erode. And other despots and authoritarian regimes can start looking and saying, that's something we can get away with. And that then calls into question other international norms and laws of war and whether those are going to be enforced.So, as I told the Prime Minister, I am very respectful of the U.N. investigators who went in at great danger to try to gather evidence about what happened. We want more information, not less. But when I said that I have high confidence that chemical weapons were used and that the Asad Government—through their chain of command—ordered their use, that was based on both public sourcing, intercepts, evidence that we feel very confident about, including samples that have been tested showing sarin from individuals who were there.And I'm very mindful of the fact that around the world—and here in Europe in particular—there are still memories of Iraq and weapons of mass destruction accusations and people being concerned about how accurate this information is. Keep in mind, I'm somebody who opposed the war in Iraq, and I am not interested in repeating mistakes of us basing decisions on faulty intelligence.But having done a thoroughgoing evaluation of the information that is currently available, I can say with high confidence chemical weapons were used. And by the way, Iran doesn't deny it. Even Syria doesn't actually deny that they were used. And that is what the U.N. investigators are supposed to be determining. And frankly, nobody is really disputing that chemical weapons were used. The only remaining dispute is who used them, which is outside the parameters of the U.N. investigation. So the U.N. investigation will not be able to answer that preliminarily; they're not supposed to.But what we know is, is that the opposition doesn't have the capability to deliver weapons on this scale. These weapons are in Asad's possession. We have intercepts indicating people in the chain of command, both before and after the attacks, with knowledge of these attacks. We can show that the rockets that delivered these chemical weapons went from areas controlled by Asad into these areas where the opposition was lodged. And the accumulation of evidence gives us high confidence that Asad carried this out.And so the question is, after we've gone through all this, are we going to try to find a reason not to act? And if that's the case, then I think the world community should admit it. Because you can always find a reason not to act. This is a complicated, difficult situation. And an initial response will not solve the underlying tragedy of the civil war in Syria. As Fredrik mentioned, that will be solved through, eventually, a political transition.But we can send a very clear, strong message against the prohibition—or in favor of the prohibition against using chemical weapons. We can change Asad's calculus about using them again. We can degrade his capabilities so that he does not use them again. And so what I'm talking about is an action that is limited in time and in scope, targeted at the specific task of degrading his capabilities and deterring the use of those weapons again.And in the meantime, we will continue to engage the entire international community in trying to find a solution to the underlying problems, which brings me to the last question. And that is, what happens if Congress doesn't approve it? I believe that Congress will approve it. I believe Congress will approve it because I think America recognizes that, as difficult as it is to take any military action—even one as limited as we're talking about, even one without boots on the ground—that's a sober decision.But I think America also recognizes that if the international community fails to maintain certain norms, standards, laws governing how countries interact and how people are treated, that over time, this world becomes less safe. It becomes more dangerous not only for those people who are subjected to these horrible crimes, but to all of humanity. And we've seen that happen again and again in our history. And the people of Europe are certainly familiar with what happens when the international community finds excuses not to act.And I would not have taken this before Congress just as a symbolic gesture. I think it's very important that Congress say that we mean what we say. And I think we will be stronger as a country in our response if the President and Congress does it together.As Commander in Chief, I always preserve the right and the responsibility to act on behalf of America's national security. I do not believe that I was required to take this to Congress. But I did not take this to Congress just because it's an empty exercise; I think it's important to have Congress's support on it. Okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Just following up on what Ben just talked about, you don't seem to be reflecting or second-guessing any of the policy decisions you've made, instead saying the message the voters were sending was about frustration with the economy or maybe even chalking it up to a failure on your part to communicate effectively. If you're not reflecting on your policy agenda, is it possible voters can conclude you're still not getting it? [SEP] Well, Savannah, that was just the first question, so we're going to have a few more here. I'm doing a whole lot of reflecting, and I think that there are going to be areas in policy where we're going to have to do a better job. I think that over the last 2 years, we have made a series of very tough decisions, but decisions that were right in terms of moving the country forward in an emergency situation where we had the risk of slipping into a second Great Depression.But what is absolutely true is that with all that stuff coming at folks fast and furious--a recovery package, what we had to do with respect to the banks, what we had to do with respect to the auto companies--I think people started looking at all this and it felt as if government was getting much more intrusive into people's lives than they were accustomed to.Now, the reason was, it was an emergency situation. But I think it's understandable that folks said to themselves, you know, maybe this is the agenda, as opposed to a response to an emergency. And that's something that I think everybody in the White House understood was a danger. We thought it was necessary, but I'm sympathetic to folks who looked at it and said, this is looking like potential overreach.In addition, there were a bunch of price tags that went with that. And so even though these were emergency situations, people rightly said: Gosh, we already have all this debt; we already have these big deficits; this is potentially going to compound it. And at what point are we going to get back to a situation where we're doing what families all around the country do, which is make sure that if you spend something, you know how to pay for it, as opposed to racking up the credit card for the next generation.And I think that the other thing that happened is that when I won election in 2008, one of the reasons I think that people were excited about the campaign was the prospect that we would change how business is done in Washington. And we were in such a hurry to get things done that we didn't change how things got done. And I think that frustrated people.I'm a strong believer that the earmarking process in Congress isn't what the American people really want to see when it comes to making tough decisions about how taxpayer dollars are spent. And I, in the rush to get things done, had to sign a bunch of bills that had earmarks in them, which was contrary to what I had talked about. And I think, folks look at that and they said: Gosh, this feels like the same partisan squabbling; this seems like the same ways of doing business as happened before.And so one of the things that I've got to take responsibility for is not having moved enough on those fronts, and I think there is an opportunity to move forward on some of those issues. My understanding is Eric Cantor today said that he wanted to see a moratorium on earmarks continuing. That's something I think we can work on together.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the recent intelligence reports concerning foreign interference in upcoming elections, what specific measures are being implemented to safeguard the integrity of the democratic process, and can you assure the public that these measures are sufficient to prevent any undue influence? [SEP] Look, we're always monitoring potential threats. We have the best people, the smartest people, working on this. We're aware of the reports, and we're taking them very seriously. We're doing everything we can, believe me. Nobody wants to see interference. We want fair elections, totally fair. And we're going to make sure that happens. We have it under control.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, to be clear, are you threatening to pull federal funding from uncooperative states? [SEP] I wouldn't put it that way. I believe we can find common ground. They'll understand the benefits of cooperation. They depend on the federal government for resources and advice. And I must say, we've made significant progress since I arrived. The previous administration, well, they were caught off guard. But the governors will respect the office. It's about the Presidency, not me. We can discuss the Constitution and federalism, but the most effective approach is to empower the states and provide support when necessary. Yes, John.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Khashoggi case, do you hold Saudi Arabia accountable, and what specific penalties are you contemplating? [SEP] The situation is fluid. We're working diligently with various stakeholders, including Congress and international partners, to ascertain the truth. My opinion is evolving, and I'll share it when I'm fully informed. It's a delicate situation, and we must proceed cautiously.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, despite the recent retail sales figures, which were lower than anticipated, do you still maintain that the U.S. economy is not heading towards a recession? And would you consider a second stimulus package if the economy continues to falter? [SEP] Matt, all I can say is that we experienced growth in the first quarter. I recall a press conference where similar concerns were raised, and we proved the doubters wrong. While the growth wasn't as robust as we'd like, there are steps we can take to strengthen the economy. First, we need to allow the current stimulus package to fully take effect and avoid raising taxes, which would be a detrimental move. Second, Congress needs to pass housing legislation that reforms FHA, Fannie Mae, and Freddie Mac, including a strong regulator to ensure these institutions stay focused on their core mission of providing mortgages. Third, we need to pass energy legislation. While it won't immediately produce more oil, it will signal to the world that we're committed to using new technologies to find reserves here at home. Finally, Congress should work on trade legislation to open up markets to Colombia, South Korea, and Panama. One of the bright spots in the economy is our increasing exports.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with the Electoral College meeting on Monday, and some electors considering changing their votes, should they receive an intelligence briefing on Russian interference? Should they adhere to the state-level vote outcomes? And looking ahead, do you believe electoral college reform is necessary to align it with the popular vote? [SEP] Right, so you packed a lot into that one.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, if Congress sends you an E-Verify bill without legalization, will you veto it? And on Fast and Furious, with Congress and Mexico still seeking answers, will you replace ATF leadership? When will the investigation conclude? [SEP] Let me be clear: my Attorney General would never authorize gun running into Mexico. The investigation is ongoing, and I won't comment on it. Appropriate actions will follow its completion. On E-Verify, we need comprehensive immigration reform. We must uphold our traditions as a nation of laws and immigrants. This requires border security, targeting illegal hiring, and a path to legal status. A balanced package is essential. E-Verify can be useful if accurate and protective of U.S. citizens. We must avoid errors that harm qualified candidates. The goal is to perfect E-Verify and ensure safeguards. We also need to address DREAM Act kids, who deserve a chance to contribute to our country. A verification system alone is insufficient.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And how long did it take before you were at ease in the job? [SEP] Well, I didn't really have time to worry about being at ease, because you'll recall, we were losing about 800,000 jobs a month.So the good news is that in some ways, my experience is atypical. It's hard to find an analogous situation. By the time FDR came into office, the Depression had been going on for a couple of years. We were in the midst of a free fall. The financial system was locking up. The auto industry was about to go belly up. The housing market had entirely collapsed. So one of the advantages that I had was that I was too busy to worry about how acclimated I was feeling in the job. We just had to make a bunch of decisions.In this situation, we're turning over a country that has challenges, has problems, and obviously, there are people out there who are feeling deeply disaffected. Otherwise, we wouldn't have had the results that we had in the election. On the other hand, if you look at the basic indicators of where the country is right now, the unemployment rate is as low as it's been in 8, 9 years. Incomes and wages have both gone up over the last year faster than they have in a decade or two. We've got historically low uninsured rates. The financial systems are stable. The stock market is hovering around its alltime high, and 401(k)s have been restored. The housing market has recovered.We have challenges internationally, but our most immediate challenge with respect to ISIL, we're seeing significant progress in Iraq, and Mosul is now increasingly being retaken by Iraqi security forces supported by us. Our alliances are in strong shape. Ourthe progress we've made with respect to carbon emissions has been greater than any country on Earth. And gas is 2 bucks a gallon.So he will have time and space, I think, to make judicious decisions. The incoming administration doesn't have to put out a huge number of fires. They may want to take the country in a significantly different direction, but they've got time to consider what exactly they want to achieve. And that's a testament to the tremendous work that my team has done over the last 8 years. I'm very proud of them for it.Athena Jones [CNN].
label: Deflection

sentence: So, Mr. President, if I understand correctly, a troop withdrawal is something you're actively considering? [SEP] Pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your administration's approach to Iran is too confrontational and that it has only served to escalate tensions in the region. What alternative strategies are you considering to achieve a more peaceful and stable relationship with Iran? [SEP] Well, let me be clear, we're not looking for a confrontation with Iran. We want a peaceful and stable relationship, but that requires Iran to change its behavior. We're willing to engage in diplomacy, but only if Iran is willing to negotiate in good faith and address our concerns about its nuclear program and its support for terrorism. We're also working with our allies and partners to build a coalition to counter Iran's malign activities in the region.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. How, sir? What are you going to do about it, sir? [SEP] Okay, go ahead.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the proposed bill extending voting rights to D.C. and granting an additional seat to Utah, a matter seemingly aligned with your advocacy for democracy abroad, particularly in Iraq, could you clarify your stance on this domestic issue, given its potential consideration during the upcoming lame-duck session? [SEP] Well, I'll be honest with you, this is the first I'm hearing of it being brought up during the lame-duck session. It hasn't been brought to my attention yet.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Leader McCarthy seems confident Republicans will regain control of the House. Do you share his assessment? [SEP] Well, let's look at the facts. We've only lost a few seats so far. The House is still within reach, though it's going to be tight. We had some great wins in Nevada, for example. It's a dynamic situation.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. To deal with Iranian directly? [SEP] Am I going to meet with the Iranians directly, is that the question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, and Prime Minister, I have a two-part question. First, did you discuss the possibility of Canada boosting its economic stimulus during your meetings? Second, how do you both foresee the Canada-US relationship evolving over the next four years? Specifically, what will the auto sector look like, will border security be strengthened or relaxed, and will a carbon market be established? [SEP] You've packed a whole lot into that one question. Were you talking to Jonathan? Is that--?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, in light of Prime Minister Netanyahu's pre-election declarations opposing Palestinian statehood, what specific actions could he undertake to convince you of his genuine commitment to peace? Is it too late to mend the relationship during your tenure? Additionally, are the allegations of Israeli spying on the Iran talks credible? And President Ghani, could you comment on the stalled reconciliation talks with the Taliban and the potential for U.S. involvement? [SEP] I typically refrain from commenting on intelligence matters in public forums. We regularly brief Congress, the Israelis, and our partners on the Iran deal's progress. A successful agreement will be transparent and verifiable, ensuring security for America, Israel, and the region. Concerning Israeli-Palestinian relations, the crucial factor is what the parties themselves believe is possible. Netanyahu's pre-election statements suggested a Palestinian state was unlikely, and his subsequent conditions were unrealistic. The question is whether a process exists to give Palestinians hope for a secure state alongside Israel. Based on Netanyahu's statements, it's hard to see how that can happen. Our commitment to Israel's security is unwavering, but we must reassess our approach to Israeli-Palestinian relations, as the two-state solution seems increasingly improbable. This could lead to a dangerous deterioration. Our military and intelligence cooperation with Israel continues, but we must be honest about the situation. This isn't a personal conflict; it's a fundamental policy difference. We support two states, while Netanyahu has a different perspective.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Can you tell us anything about the suspect's gender? [SEP] I'm not at liberty to disclose that information at this time. There will be a press conference later today with more details.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Sir, at a fundraiser last month, you said, quote, The rest of the world is looking at this election . . . both the good guys and the bad guys. You noted you're going to G-20 in a couple days. You'll come face to face with many of those leaders at the same moment that your predecessor is considering launching his reelection effort. How should those world leaders, both good guys and bad guys, view this moment both for America and for your Presidency? [SEP] Well, first of all, these world leaders know we're doing better than anybody else in the world, as a practical matter. Notwithstanding the difficulties we have, our economy is growing. You saw the last report; we're still growing at 2.6 percent. We're creating jobs. We're still in a solid position. And there's not many other countries in the world that are in that position.And I promise you, from the telephone calls I still have and from the meetings I have with other heads of State, they're looking to the United States and saying: How are you doing it? And what are you doing? What can we do together? How—so I think that the vast majority of my colleagues—at least those colleagues who are NATO members—European Union, Japan, South Korea, et cetera—I think they're looking to cooperate and wanting to know how we can help one another.And what was the other question?
label: Explicit

sentence: Some claim your rhetoric has emboldened White nationalists, leading to the perception that the Republican Party now supports them. How do you respond? [SEP] That's absurd. My support among African Americans is higher than ever. Why would that be if I were supporting White nationalists? That's a ridiculous, frankly racist question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, the public wants to see those photos. Why are you resisting? [SEP] Hold on, that's a different can of worms. The crucial thing is to let the Iranian people know we're with them. Their courage is inspiring. As I said before, and it's something I've always believed, Dr. King's expression about the arc of the moral universe bending towards justice is key here. We must trust that justice will ultimately prevail.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Can you give me your timetable? Are we talking next week, 2 weeks, a month? [SEP] Steve, what do you think? Within the next week or two, we think the States will be able to execute.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, beyond the summit, what specific new information did you glean about Chairman Kim? And what is your reaction to Michael Cohen's testimony accusing you of being a liar, a conman, and a racist? [SEP] Well, first of all, it's incorrect. And it's very interesting, because I tried to watch as much as I could. I wasn't able to watch too much because I've been a little bit busy. But I think having a fake hearing like that and having it in the middle of this very important summit is really a terrible thing. They could've made it 2 days later or next week, and it would've been even better. They would've had more time. But having it during this very important summit is sort of incredible. And he lied a lot, but it was very interesting, because he didn't lie about one thing. He said no collusion with the Russian hoax. And I said, I wonder why he didn't just lie about that, too, like he did about everything else? I mean, he lied about so many different things, and I was actually impressed that he didn't say, Well, I think there was collusion for this reason or that. He didn't say that. He said, No collusion. And I was, you know, a little impressed by that, frankly. Could've—he could've gone all out. He only went about 95 percent instead of 100 percent. But the fact is, there is no collusion. And I call it the witch hunt. This should never happen to another President. This is so bad for our country. So bad. You look at this whole hoax, it's a—I call it the Russian witch hunt and now add the word hoax. It's a very, very bad thing for our country. But I was impressed with the fact that he—when—you know, because the most important question up there was the one on collusion. And he said he saw no collusion. So we'll see what happens. But it was pretty shameful, I think.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Does Mr. Putin intend to cease disrupting NATO and the US? What penalties did you specify for interfering with US critical infrastructure? [SEP] Let me answer the second question first. I told him we have significant cyber capability. He knows it. He doesn't know the specifics, but it's substantial. If they violate these norms, we will respond with cyber. He knows.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: While you've characterized these commutations as primarily for minor drug offenses, a significant portion also involved firearms. Can you explain how that aligns with your stance on gun control? [SEP] Hmm...
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering the lingering pain caused by the Pinochet regime and the documented US involvement, are you prepared to issue a formal apology and provide material support for investigations into human rights abuses during that period? [SEP] We acknowledge the difficult history between the US and Latin America, including Chile. While I can't speak for every action of prior administrations, I can assure you that my administration is dedicated to promoting democracy and human rights globally. We stand ready to assist Chile in its pursuit of justice and reconciliation, within the bounds of existing laws and agreements, while focusing on our shared future.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, Mr. President——Payroll Tax Cut  Q. Sir, the payroll tax cut was opposed by both parties on Capitol Hill. Can you give your rationale as to why you think that's important, particularly since it doesn't help Americans who—[inaudible]? [SEP] Yes. Okay. It helps people greatly. It helps our country get back. And anybody that would say anything different, I think, is very foolish. Everybody wanted it. By the way, the Democrats want it. The Republicans want it. They just couldn't get it—they just couldn't come to an agreement, but everybody wants it.And the very important thing is, the people want it, and the people need it, actually.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the complexities of the US-China relationship and the potential for economic disruption, what specific metrics will your administration use to determine whether its policies are successful in addressing these trade imbalances and intellectual property concerns? What benchmarks are you setting to measure progress? [SEP] We're looking at a range of indicators. We're looking at the trade deficit, the level of intellectual property theft, the value of the RMB, and the overall health of the American economy. But more importantly, we're looking at whether American businesses are able to compete fairly in China. Are they getting a level playing field? Are they being treated fairly? That's the ultimate test. We're not just looking at numbers on a spreadsheet. We're looking at the real-world impact on American workers and businesses. And we're going to keep pushing until we see real progress.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the increasing instability in Pakistan, what specific assurances have you received from President Musharraf regarding the security of Pakistan's nuclear arsenal? [SEP] The security of Pakistan's nuclear arsenal is a matter of utmost importance. We have been in close communication with the Pakistani government on this issue, and they have assured us that they have robust safeguards in place to prevent any unauthorized access or diversion of nuclear materials. We continue to monitor the situation closely, and we are confident that the Pakistani government is taking all necessary steps to protect its nuclear assets.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, critics say the Iran deal doesn't go far enough in preventing Iran from developing nuclear weapons and supporting terrorism. How do you address these criticisms, and what assurances can you provide to the American people and our allies that Iran will not pose a threat in the future? [SEP] Well, let's be clear. No deal is perfect, but the Iran deal was the best available option to prevent Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon. It put in place unprecedented monitoring and verification measures that made it much harder for Iran to cheat. And it's important to remember that the alternative to the deal was not a better deal, but no deal at all, which would have allowed Iran to continue its nuclear program unchecked. We are constantly reassessing our strategy towards Iran and working with our allies to counter their malign activities in the region. We will continue to use all available tools, including sanctions, diplomacy, and military force if necessary, to ensure that Iran does not pose a threat to the United States or our allies.
label: Implicit

sentence: Madam President, while Brazil positions itself as a significant global leader, the U.S. often views it as a regional player. How do you reconcile these differing perspectives and ensure a balanced partnership? [SEP] The United States recognizes Brazil's growing influence on the world stage. We see them as a key partner in addressing global challenges, from climate change to economic development. While we may have different perspectives on certain issues, we value Brazil's contributions and are committed to working together to achieve common goals.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: What steps will be taken to close the disparity? Will the U.S. pledge more doses internationally? And considering the discrepancy, is a 2022 pandemic resolution actually achievable? [SEP] Well, it might take a tad longer globally. The U.S. is committed. We might, just might, be able to offer another billion doses, maybe in 2022 stretching into 2023. But that's not set in stone. I've been upfront about what I know and what I think we can accomplish. I don't want to overpromise and underdeliver. The G-7 consensus was clear: we're in this for the long haul, until we meet the world's needs. It's not just morally right, it's strategically sound. You can't wall off new strains. This will be an ongoing effort, and there might be future pandemics. We need a system to detect threats early. So, as long as nations need vaccines, we're in it. We're also helping countries manufacture their own. India can do it, but lacks the materials. We're working on that. It's not just about giving vaccines, it's about enabling self-sufficiency. Last question. The President. I'm not answering that. Just kidding. Last question. Peter Alexander, NBC News.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, looking back at the Afghanistan campaign, can you confidently assert that the extensive sacrifices made were worthwhile, considering the current state of affairs in the region? And President Karzai, in light of persistent allegations of corruption and ineffective governance, how do you defend the allocation of international assistance, and will you guarantee a seamless transition of power following the upcoming elections? [SEP] We went to Afghanistan for one reason and one reason only: to take out Al Qaeda after they attacked us. We accomplished that mission. We degraded their capabilities, killed their leaders, and made it much harder for them to attack us again. Our troops did an incredible job. Now, did we turn Afghanistan into a Jeffersonian democracy? No. That was never the primary goal. But we created the conditions for a more stable and secure Afghanistan, one that is less likely to be a breeding ground for terrorists. We are in the process of achieving that goal. And for that, I think we have to thank our extraordinary military, intelligence, and diplomatic teams, as well as the cooperation of the Afghan Government and the Afghan people. As for corruption, it's a serious issue, and we're working with the Afghan government to combat it. It's not just about money; it's about building institutions and promoting good governance. We need to make sure that international aid is used effectively and that the Afghan people see the benefits. On the elections, I'm committed to a free and fair process. The Afghan people deserve to choose their own leaders, and I will respect their decision. On elections, for me, the greatest of my achievements, eventually, seen by the Afghan people, will be a proper, well-organized, interference-free election in which the Afghan people can elect their next President. And certainly, I would be a retired President and very happily a retired President. Last question from one of yours.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the sacrifices made by our military families, why haven't you prioritized a meeting with Gold Star families over your golfing schedule? [SEP] Correct.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, considering the Paris attacks, how do you foresee this affecting the upcoming climate negotiations? Additionally, how do you plan to address concerns regarding persuading less affluent nations to commit to climate objectives, especially in light of Republican opposition? And lastly, could you provide your perspective on the reports suggesting that intelligence officials have been manipulating assessments of the ISIL campaign? [SEP] Let me address the intelligence matter first. Since assuming office, I've been adamant about receiving unbiased intelligence, free from any political influence. Accurate intelligence is paramount for effective policymaking. I trust that our intelligence agencies grasp this principle. Regarding CENTCOM, we will thoroughly investigate any potential misconduct. I've directed the relevant authorities to uncover the truth. Disagreements in interpreting information are inevitable, but unwavering honesty is crucial. I haven't encountered overly optimistic accounts of the situations in Iraq and Syria. Turning to Paris, we must demonstrate our resolve. We will not succumb to intimidation. Terrorists cannot prevail if we deny them that victory. They are, at their core, simply murderers. We have triumphed over greater adversities in the past. The G-20, APEC, and ASEAN have all emphasized the significance of a robust Paris agreement. I remain optimistic. 160 nations have established targets, accounting for 90% of global emissions. Key components include differentiation, accountability, transparency, and regular review. Climate finance is indispensable for assisting developing nations in pursuing sustainable development. We are making headway toward fulfilling our $100 billion commitment. Critics contend that unilateral action is futile, but China's commitment has reshaped the landscape. Supporting nations like India is of utmost importance. Finally, the Paris attacks underscore the need for unity. We must not permit fear to dictate our course of action.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You have been a strong supporter of the idea of a peaceful transfer of power, demonstrated not terribly far from here, out in the Rose Garden. And yet, even as you and I speak, there are more than five dozen Democrats that are going to boycott the Inauguration of the incoming President. Do you support that? And what message would you send to Democrats to better demonstrate the peaceful transfer of power?And if I could follow, I wanted to ask you about your conversations with the President-elect previously. And without getting into too much of the personal side of it, I'm just curious, were you able to use that opportunity to convince him to take a fresh look at some of the important ideas that you will leave this office with: maintaining some semblance of the Affordable Care Act, some idea of keeping DREAMers here in the country without fear of deportation. Were you able to use personal stories to try to convince him? And how successful were you? [SEP] Well, I won't go into details of my conversations with President-elect Trump. As I've said before, they are cordial. At times, they've been fairly lengthy, and they've been substantive. I can't tell you how convincing I've been. I think you'd have to ask him whether I've been convincing or not.I have offered my best advice, counsel about certain issues both foreign and domestic. And my working assumption is, is that having won an election opposed to a number of my initiatives and certain aspects of my vision for where the country needs to go, it is appropriate for him to go forward with his vision and his values. And I don't expect that there's going to be enormous overlap.It may be that on certain issues, once he comes into office and he looks at the complexities of how to, in fact, provide health care for everybody—something he says he wants to do—or wants to make sure that he is encouraging job creation and wage growth in this country, that that may lead him to some of the same conclusions that I arrived at once I got here.But I don't think we'll know until he has an actual chance to get sworn in and sit behind that desk. And I think a lot of his views are going to be shaped by his advisers, the people around him, which is why it's important to pay attention to these confirmation hearings.I can tell you that—and this is something I have told him—that this is a job of such magnitude that you can't do it by yourself. You are enormously reliant on a team: your Cabinet, your senior White House staff, all the way to fairly junior folks in their twenties and thirties, but who are executing on significant responsibilities.And so how you put a team together to make sure that they're getting you the best information and they are teeing up the options from which you will ultimately make decisions, that's probably the most useful advice, the most constructive advice that I've been able to give him. That if you find yourself isolated because the process breaks down, or if you're only hearing from people who agree with you on everything, or if you haven't created a process that is fact-checking and probing and asking hard questions about policies or promises that you've made, that's when you start making mistakes. And as I indicated in some of my previous remarks, reality has a way of biting back if you're not paying attention to it.With respect to the Inauguration, I'm not going to comment on those issues. All I know is I'm going to be there. [] So is Michelle. And I have been checking the weather, and I'm heartened by the fact that it won't be as cold as my first Inauguration—[]—because that was cold.Janet Rodriguez [Univision].'s Post-Presidency Plans/Immigration/Cuba-U.S. Relations
label: Dodging

sentence: Can you definitively state that a shutdown will not occur? [SEP] Well, I'm not in a position to make any ironclad promises at this juncture. The situation is fluid, and many factors are at play.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, the Vice President is reportedly maintaining distance due to potential exposure. How can you assure Americans of their safety and the government's ability to function when even the Vice President is taking precautions? Furthermore, why is widespread testing still not available despite your previous assurances? [SEP] The Vice President is fine. He's been tested, he's negative. He's being very careful, and that's a good thing. As for testing, anyone who wants a test can get a test. We've done more testing than any other country in the world. It's a tremendous achievement. So, the question is, frankly, ridiculous. We're doing a great job on testing, and the Vice President is doing a great job. Everything is under control.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Senator Obama's remarks on Iraq, would you characterize them as indicative of a lack of experience in foreign policy? [SEP] With all due respect, the Senator from Illinois should perhaps focus on securing his party's nomination before offering commentary on complex geopolitical situations. The nomination process is far from settled on either side of the aisle. Perhaps a more appropriate time for such discussions would be after the respective parties have chosen their candidates. Next question, please.
label: Dodging

sentence: So, no further comment? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Do you still have confidence in Secretary Azar? [SEP] I wish him well, in what?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Trump, if the intelligence community provides evidence that China is actively working to undermine your re-election, what specific actions would you take to deter such interference and hold them accountable? [SEP] We'll take very strong action, very strong. Nobody is going to mess with our elections. We're going to protect our country, and we're going to make sure that everyone plays by the rules. We're not going to let anyone interfere, believe me.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. As you well know, there are four Americans in Iran: three held on trumped-up charges, according to your administration; one, whereabouts unknown. Can you tell the country, sir, why you are content, with all the fanfare around this deal, to leave the conscience of this Nation and the strength of this Nation unaccounted for in relation to these four Americans?And last week, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said, under no circumstances should there be any relief for Iran in terms of ballistic missiles or conventional weapons. It is perceived that that was a last-minute capitulation in these negotiations. Many in the Pentagon feel you've left the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff hung out to dry. Could you comment? [SEP] I've got to give you credit, Major, for how you craft those questions. [] First, the notion that I am content, as I celebrate, with American citizens languishing in Iranian jails, Major, that's nonsense, and you should know better. I've met with the families of some of those folks. Nobody is content. And our diplomats and our teams are working diligently to try to get them out.Now, if the question is why we did not tie the negotiations to their release, think about the logic that that creates. Suddenly, Iran realizes, you know what, maybe we can get additional concessions out of the Americans by holding these individuals. It makes it much more difficult for us to walk away if Iran somehow thinks that a nuclear deal is dependent in some fashion on the nuclear deal. And by the way, if we had walked away from the nuclear deal, we'd still be pushing them just as hard to get these folks out. That's why those issues are not connected. But we are working every single day to try to get them out and won't stop until they're out and rejoined with their families.With respect to the Chairman's testimony, to some degree I already answered this with Carol. We are not taking the pressure off Iran with respect to arms and with respect to ballistic missiles. As I just explained, not only do we keep in place for 5 years the arms embargo under this particular new U.N. resolution, not only do we maintain the 8 years on the ballistic missiles under this particular U.N. resolution, but we have a host of other multilateral and unilateral authorities that allow us to take action where we see Iran engaged in those activities whether it's 6 years from now or 10 years from now.So we have not lost those legal authorities. And in fact, part of my pitch to the GCC countries, as well as to Prime Minister Netanyahu, is we should do a better job making sure that Iran is not engaged in sending arms to organizations like Hizballah. And as I just indicated, that means improving our intelligence capacity and our interdiction capacity with our partners. Okay?April Ryan [American Urban Radio Networks].Criminal Justice Reform/'s Upcoming Visit to Kenya/Presidential Medal of Freedom Revocation/Rape
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you've expressed optimism about resolving the North Korea crisis. Can you point to any specific successes in your diplomatic efforts thus far? And do you still consider direct talks unproductive? [SEP] Well, you know me – I don't like to telegraph our successes in situations like this. We prefer to keep our cards close to the vest. But I will say this: it's in 's best interest, and the world's best interest, to do the right thing. There's a lot of good reason behind it. With that said, I think we're making significant progress. We're showing great strength. They understand our unparalleled strength. We've deployed three of the world's largest aircraft carriers, and a nuclear submarine. We hope we never have to use any of it. But I believe it makes sense for to come to the table and make a deal that benefits both its people and the world. I see movement, yes. But let's see what happens.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, have you abandoned the possibility of using the 14th Amendment, or is it still on the table? What's your response to those who argue that your actions and the G-7's policies will lead to greater global instability and division? Lastly, is a congressional agreement the only option, or are you still considering unilateral or executive actions? [SEP] The simple truth is, we haven't found a unilateral action that could be effectively implemented in the next two or three weeks. That's the heart of the problem.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, Tokyo will host Summer Olympic Games this July. Do you expect Tokyo will be? [SEP] I hope so, because Shinzo Abe is a very good friend of mine. I love the people of Japan. And I hope it's going to be in good shape.As you know, you have a number of people in Japan who have been infected. I hear they're doing a very professional job, which doesn't surprise me at all, with Shinzo and with all of the people you have. I know Japan very well. I think they're going to handle it very well.It's a little tight, you know. It's a little tight. They spent billions of dollars building one of the most beautiful venues I've ever seen, and your Prime Minister is very proud of it. I hope it's going to be fine. We hope it will.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the lack of progress on your jobs bill, are you concerned about facing voters in 2012 with high unemployment and a perception of failed leadership? [SEP] The American people are more concerned with Congress's failure to pass the jobs bill, which has widespread support, even among Republicans. Normally, politicians respond to public dissatisfaction, but Congress, particularly Republicans, seems unconcerned about putting people back to work. I will continue to advocate for it, even if it requires waiting until November or a new Congress. It includes tax cuts for the middle class, incentives for hiring veterans, and support for teachers, addressing issues like Hawaii's shortened school weeks. It also focuses on infrastructure, which is vital for global competitiveness, as demonstrated by the superior infrastructure in Asia. I'll keep pushing, and if they fail to act, the voters will elect new leaders.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. The peace process is over? [SEP] Who?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Will this be one of them? [SEP] I never release my full movie list.But let's talk of the specifics of what we now know. The FBI announced today and we can confirm that North Korea engaged in this attack. I think it says something interesting about North Korea that they decided to have the state mount an all-out assault on a movie studio because of a satirical movie starring Seth Rogen and James Flacco [Franco].because of a satirical movie starring Seth Rogen and James Flacco [Franco].because of a satirical movie starring Seth Rogen and James Flacco [Franco]*.They caused a lot of damage, and we will respond. We will respond proportionally, and we'll respond in a place and time and manner that we choose. It's not something that I will announce here today at a press conference.More broadly, though, this points to the need for us to work with the international community to start setting up some very clear rules of the road in terms of how the Internet and cyber operates. Right now it's sort of the Wild West. And part of the problem is, is you've got weak states that can engage in these kinds of attacks, you've got nonstate actors that can do enormous damage. That's part of what makes this issue of cybersecurity so urgent.Again, this is part of the reason why it's going to be so important for Congress to work with us and get a actual bill passed that allows for the kind of information sharing we need. Because if we don't put in place the kind of architecture that can prevent these attacks from taking place, this is not just going to be affecting movies, this is going to be affecting our entire economy in ways that are extraordinarily significant.And by the way, I hear you're moving to Europe. [] Where you going to be?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Will it end by the time you leave office? Do you approve of Israel's conduct? [SEP] I hope so. I support a sustainable cease-fire, defined as Hamas stopping rocket fire into Israel. A sustainable cease-fire is impossible if rockets continue. It's Hamas's choice. The best way to ensure a sustainable cease-fire is to work with Egypt to stop arms smuggling into Gaza, enabling Hamas to fire rockets. Countries supplying weapons to Hamas must stop. The international community must pressure them. Hamas must stop arming if they want a cease-fire. Countries near Gaza must stop smuggling. It's difficult due to tunnels. What was the second part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the ongoing debate surrounding gun control, what specific measures are you considering to address the issue of gun violence while respecting the Second Amendment rights of law-abiding citizens? [SEP] We are committed to exploring a range of options to address gun violence, including strengthening background checks, enhancing mental health services, and supporting law enforcement efforts to combat illegal gun trafficking. Our goal is to find common-sense solutions that protect our communities while upholding the constitutional rights of responsible gun owners.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, your budget relies on tax increases for multinational corporations that ship jobs overseas and on the oil and gas industry. You've pushed for this for years. If you couldn't get it through a Democratic Congress, why now? And doesn't it hurt your push for deficit-neutral corporate tax reform? [SEP] I still think I'm right. So, we'll try again. What's different is everyone's saying they're serious about the deficit. If you are, you have to look at unfair spending through the Tax Code, tax breaks that don't make us more competitive or create jobs here. The examples you gave, most economists would say don't help long-term growth. If they don't, why are we letting some pay lower taxes than those creating jobs here and investing? Why not invest in future energy, not just the past, especially if the past is profitable and doesn't need a break? If we're serious about cutting the deficit and debt, we need to look at all sources. We can't just pick and choose. The same goes for Democrats. Some things in this budget are hard for me. Cities and states are struggling because of lost revenue.
