And I would suggest that part of the test is that what we ended up seeing was a peaceful transition, relatively little violence, and relatively little, if any, anti-American sentiment or anti-Israel sentiment or anti-Western sentiment. And I think that testifies to the fact that in a complicated situation, we got it about right.My message, I think, to demonstrators going forward is, your aspirations for greater opportunity, for the ability to speak your mind, for a free press, those are absolutely aspirations we support.As was true in Egypt, ultimately, what happens in each of these countries will be determined by the citizens of those countries. And even as we uphold these universal values, we do want to make sure that transitions do not degenerate into chaos and violence. That's not just good for us, that's good for those countries. The history of successful transitions to democracy have generally been ones in which peaceful protests led to dialogue, led to discussion, led to reform, and ultimately led to democracy.And that's true in countries like Eastern Europe. That was also true in countries like Indonesia, a majority Muslim country that went through some of these similar transitions, but didn't end up doing it in such a chaotic fashion that it ended up dividing the societies fundamentally.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, many Americans remain skeptical about the Justice Department's ability to impartially investigate figures associated with your administration. What steps are you taking to rebuild public trust and demonstrate its independence? [SEP] Trust is earned, and I'm earning it by respecting the process. I have not, and will not, attempt to influence the Justice Department's decisions. Their independence is paramount, and I am committed to upholding that principle. Judge me by my actions, not by the insinuations of others.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the supercommittee's potential failure and the resulting sequester, and given Republican attempts to modify the automatic cuts, will you veto any such legislation? Furthermore, could you shed light on your 'hot mic' exchange with President Sarkozy regarding Prime Minister Netanyahu? [SEP] Regarding the supercommittee, we agreed back in August to a trillion dollars in cuts over the next ten years, primarily from discretionary spending. We also acknowledged that to achieve a more stable fiscal footing, we'd need at least another 1.2 trillion. The whole point of the sequester was to force both sides to move beyond their rigid stances and do what's best for the country. Since then, there have been many discussions, but it seems people are still clinging to their entrenched positions instead of finding solutions. I've put forward a comprehensive plan that would achieve over $3 trillion in savings, a balanced approach that the American people prefer. It means everything is on the table: discretionary spending cuts, non-defense and defense cuts, adjustments to entitlement programs, healthcare cost reductions, and additional revenue. When it comes to revenue, it makes sense to start by asking the wealthiest among us to pay a bit more before asking seniors to pay more for their Medicare. This is the same proposal I made to Speaker Boehner in August, a balanced approach that every independent committee has endorsed. It seems people keep trying to tweak the numbers to get a different outcome. But the equation remains the same: a balanced approach is essential to avoid crippling Medicare and Medicaid. I hope the congressional leadership on the supercommittee will step up and do what needs to be done, because the math won't change. I'm prepared to sign legislation that's balanced and solves the problem. As for the 'hot mic' incident in France, I won't comment on private conversations with other leaders. However, my main discussion with President Sarkozy revolved around my disappointment with France's vote in favor of Palestinian membership in UNESCO, which would require the US to cut funding, undermining direct negotiations between Palestinians and Israelis. I had a very frank conversation with President Sarkozy about that issue, consistent with my previous statements.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Convalescent—convalescent plasma, as a treatment, has been around for, you know, a hundred years. You mentioned Warp—Operation Warp Speed, which enabled this process to move along a lot faster. What into the—what went into the effort for this to be approved for COVID-19? And was that holdup political in nature? [SEP] Well, I think that there might have been a holdup, but we broke the logjam over the last week, to be honest. I think that there are people in the FDA and actually in your larger department that can see things being held up and wouldn't mind so much. That's my opinion—a very strong opinion. And that's for political reasons. This has nothing to do with politics; this has to do with life and death.So we are being very strong, and we are being very forthright, and we have got some incredible answers. And we're not going to let them be held up, because every day is lives. And we're not going to let that happen. Okay?Very good. Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the dire situation in Syria, did your discussions with President Putin and President Hu yield any indication of their willingness for Assad to step down, and were any concrete steps agreed upon to halt the bloodshed? [SEP] Well, Syria was definitely a key topic in both meetings. The violence there is completely out of control, with civilians being targeted and Assad having lost all legitimacy. When you massacre your own citizens, it's impossible to imagine a peaceful transition that includes Assad. Now, achieving that transition is a complex matter. Russia, with its historical ties to Syria, and China, generally hesitant to interfere in other nations' internal affairs, have been reluctant to apply the necessary pressure. Our conversations were frank. While the U.S. and the international community aren't fully aligned with Russia and China on this, I believe they recognize the dangers of a full-blown civil war. I don't believe they condone the massacres, and they understand that a mechanism for ending the violence and establishing a legitimate government would benefit everyone. I've emphasized the importance of working with the UN and Kofi Annan on a political transition plan. Hopefully, we can continue these discussions and present a clear path forward to the Syrian people. However, it's premature to say that Russia and China are fully on board. They acknowledge the gravity of the situation and its negative impact on their interests and the Syrian people's. We all agree that helping the Syrian people find a resolution is in everyone's best interest. Personally, I don't see a scenario where Assad remains in power and the violence decreases. He failed to uphold his end of the Annan plan, leading to further escalation and the deaths of innocent civilians. Even the international monitors have had to withdraw due to the violence. While some argue that the opposition is also engaged in violence, the horrifying images from places like Homs are a direct result of the Syrian government's actions, for which Assad is ultimately responsible.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your first two years, you mentioned a softer tone. Critics doubt that change. Given the House loss, will you adjust your tone to pass legislation? What would this 'olive branch' look like in practice? [SEP] Look, I'm perfectly capable of a softer tone, believe me. But when the media constantly twists my words and attacks me unfairly, I have to defend myself. It's a constant battle against misrepresentation. I'd prefer a calm, even approach, but the constant attacks force me to fight back. So, while I'd love a 'boring' tone, it's just not possible when I'm constantly under fire.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, given Rick Ledgett's comments about Edward Snowden and potential amnesty, what are your overarching thoughts on the balance between national security and individual privacy in the context of government surveillance? [SEP] Well, look, it's a very complicated situation. Snowden did some bad things, very bad things. He revealed classified information, and that's a crime. But, you know, he also raised some important questions about government surveillance. So, it's not a black and white issue. We have to protect our national security, but we also have to protect the privacy of our citizens. It's a delicate balance.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, in which specific areas of the Defense and Veterans Affairs budgets do you intend to find cost savings, particularly given the political sensitivity surrounding many potential cuts? [SEP] I'm sorry, could you repeat that? So many what, exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence: Bloomberg's Simone Iglesias wants to know Brazil's reaction to a possible U.S. military intervention in Venezuela. Can you clarify? [SEP] Some things are better left unsaid. Publicly stating our strategy would only undermine it. We're keeping our cards close to our chest.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you. Just to belabor the point on that question, Mr. President, the—your people have said that the framework agreement, that what's in it stands, that they are not renegotiable points, although the implementation of them can be renegotiated in some way. And I wonder how, within that framework that's already been agreed, how we can come up with something that satisfies the kinds of concerns that he raised: no inspection of military sites, immediate lifting of all sanctions the day that the thing is signed.And also, on Cuba, I wanted to ask, as you discussed the state sponsor of terrorism list with President Castro, the Cubans have raised some issues about the 45-day waiting period. I wondered if that came up. I know that your government is eager, assuming that the recommendation is approved—is to remove it and is approved by you—that we move ahead quickly with Embassies. The Cubans have raised concerns about that 45 days and how something could go wrong in those 45 days. And it really doesn't give them access to the kinds of things they think they can have once the—they're—if and when they're removed from the list. Did that come up? And is it your belief that once they're removed from the list, then there is no impediment to go ahead with opening Embassies, once you approve their removal from the list? [SEP] Okay. So I'll make one last run at Iran here. There's a political framework, the outlines of which were established between Iran and the P-5-plus-1. In some cases, there was great specificity around, for example, the reductions that need to take place in the number of centrifuges in Natanz or the conversion of Fordow into a facility that does not permit the potential production of weapons-grade uranium. And in other cases, there were—there was language of intent, but the details matter. And how those details are interpreted are going to be subject to negotiation.So it's not accurate to suggest that—and I don't think my team has ever suggested that—somehow everything is all done and it's just a matter of writing it up. This is a situation in which we have a framework that is, if implemented, powerful and will achieve our goal of making sure that Iran doesn't have a nuclear weapon. But the details make a big difference, how they're structured. And I guarantee you, there will be some tough negotiations around that.And that's what I said the first day when we announced that we had an agreement, and that's what we've continued to say. So there's really no contradiction here. And keep in mind that when we started this process off, even with the interim agreement, when we signed the JPOA way back at the beginning of this whole thing, there was a similar back-and-forth in terms of interpretation of how this was going to be implemented. And the Iranians were saying that's not true, and we were saying this. But once we actually got through the negotiations, it turned out that we had something that was substantial, that was subject to review by everybody involved, and that has proven to be highly effective, even by the assessments of critics of the policy like the Israelis. They've said, yes, this actually has worked, Iran has abided by the agreement. In fact, now they're suggesting, why don't we just stay here, it's worked so well, despite the fact that they had made almost the precise same argument they're making now about the final deal. But consistency is the hobgoblin of narrow minds.Cuba. I will tell you, we did not get into the level of detail, Karen, that you just described. And I'm impressed with how many details you seem to be aware of. [] As I said before, the state sponsor of terrorism recommendation will be coming to me. I will read it; I'll review it. There's a process whereby if in fact I accept those recommendations, Congress has an opportunity to review it as well, and it will be there for people to see.I think that the concerns around the Embassy are going to be mostly on the Cuban side. They haven't dealt with an American Embassy in Cuba in quite some time. And changing in this way is, I'm sure, an unsettling process. We're accustomed to this. I mean, we've gone through now a number of times where, with China and with Vietnam and other countries, we opened—reopened diplomatic relations, and we understand, I think, are familiar with, how that gets done in a way that's consistent with improving diplomatic relations over the long term. This is probably a more profound shift for them than it is for us.But we stand ready to move forward. We're confident that it can lead to an improved dialogue. And our bottom line in the end is, is that it can lead to an improved set of prospects for the Cuban people.And I'll say just in closing, to all the people here from Latin American countries, thank you for this extraordinary opportunity. I want to thank the people of Panama. I am very optimistic about this region, and the main reason I'm optimistic about this region is because of its people. They are extraordinary. And it is a great gift to the United States to be able to have such strong friends and partners in tackling many of the challenges that we have in common.Thank you very much.
label: General

sentence: Q. ——at the end of your administration. Can you describe for us specifically, what do you mean by sustainable? Do you have specific goals and objectives that, in your mind, would meet the criteria of sustain-ability? [SEP] Yes, which is to keep enough troops there so we can succeed. And David Petraeus will come as—for example, David Petraeus will come back, along with Ryan Crocker, here later on this spring and will make a recommendation as to what that—what those troop levels ought to be.The idea of having a request by the Iraqi Government for a long-term security agreement is part of sustainability. And obviously, we're going to be pushing hard at the same time to get the political process moving forward.I don't know if you noticed yesterday, but it was a very interesting moment in Iraqi constitutional history, when part of the—a member of the Presidency Council utilized his constitutional right to veto one of the three pieces of legislation recently passed. I understand the use of the veto, intend to continue to use it, and I—but I thought it was a healthy sign that the people are thinking through the legislation that's passed, and they're worrying about making sure that laws are constitutional. And I feel pretty good about the fact that they're, of course, going to continue to work to make sure that their stated objective of getting Provincial elections done by October of 2008 will happen.So there's going to be a lot of work. My only point is, sustainability is political, economic, and security.Yes, Ed [Edwin Chen, Bloomberg News].
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, if Iraqi political progress stalls by September, will you disregard General Petraeus's recommendations and prolong the surge? [SEP] I'm not going to box myself in with hypothetical scenarios. We'll cross that bridge when we come to it.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, your reaction to the Biden-Harris event, if you could summarize it succinctly? [SEP] Look, I caught a glimpse. That's all I needed. She was nasty to him, said awful things. Now she's his running mate? Please! Her poll numbers were in the toilet. She attacked Biden relentlessly. The radical left wants to defund the police. We can't let that happen. The military is stronger than ever. We're doing great. I was surprised he picked her, very surprised. She went down hard, said terrible things. It's a strange situation, to say the least.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you're now promising that everyone who needs a test will be able to get one at some point soon. Can you give us some figures on what you're changing to ramp up testing? When will that be a true statement, exactly? And how exactly are you going to accomplish that? [SEP] Well, it's a true statement already. We have more testing than any country in the world by far. But I'll let Admiral go into a little bit of the future. When you look at the testing numbers that we worked with collaboratively with the State leadership—it's not just with the Governor, but the State health officers, the State epidemiologists, the public health labs—it's really a combination of testing those who need something for diagnosis, diagnostic testing; tracing—so testing those who have been around the people with a diagnosis.[]The other thing I would say is, particularly as we move into the summer, there are surveillance mechanisms—and I talked about them before—like a weather radar. And just think about that weather radar. The influenza-like illness network, which is at about 75 percent of health care institutions and syndromic surveillance. So if we see a blip on that weather radar, combined with CDC personnel in every single State, and with contact tracers, we really run to the fire, right? And that's when you detect, you trace, and you shut off that outbreak right when it starts.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. What would you do differently? [SEP] What I will do--look, we're going to be putting forward, as we have done before, a framework, a proposal, legislation that can move it--move the ball forward and actually get this thing done.But ultimately, I can't vote for Republicans. They're going to have to come to the conclusion that this is good for the country and that this is something that they themselves think is important. And depending on how Congress turns out, we'll see how many Republican votes we need to get it done.Norah O'Donnell [CBS News]. How are you?
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, what's your message for President Moon, who's hit a wall on inter-Korean cooperation because of sanctions? And what's next for U.S.-South Korea military exercises? [SEP] Look, I like President Moon a lot. We've got a fantastic relationship. Believe it or not, I get along great with almost every world leader. Some try to take advantage of us, of course. But when they realize I'm onto them, it tends to slow them down. But yeah, we have a lot of good relationships. I'll be calling President Moon very shortly, as soon as I get on the plane. He'll be one of the first calls I make. I'll also be calling Prime Minister Abe of Japan, to update him on our progress. He's working hard, President Moon is. He's very keen to see a deal happen, and he's been a big help.
label: General

sentence: Q. So, Mr. President, you're saying you weren't explicitly told the virus was airborne until later? [SEP] The details are hazy, to be honest. We were dealing with so much information, so many conflicting reports. The key thing is, we took action. We took decisive action to protect the American people. Woodward should have immediately, right after I said it, gone out to the authorities so they can prepare and let them know.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, given Prime Minister Maliki's visit to Iran and the warm reception he received, do you share your Iraqi counterpart's perspective on Iran, and what message does this send to our allies and skeptical Americans? [SEP] I haven't had a chance to review the details of the visit. I'd prefer to get a formal briefing from our embassy before commenting on the specifics of their discussions. Generally speaking, diplomatic interactions often involve displays of cordiality.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. What are you doing to make sure it's free and fair? [SEP] Well, we have been very strong. Now, if you remember, President Obama was informed about Russia by the FBI in September. The election was in November. President Obama decided to do absolutely nothing about it. People don't mention that very much anymore. That's a lost fact. But he was informed very powerfully that they're going to do—and President Obama did nothing. We have done a lot, and we've really shored it up.But what people can never prepare for are millions and millions of mail-in ballots. Because they can be forged. They can be captured. They can be taken.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. What is your reaction to the MoveOn.org ad that mocked General Petraeus as General Betray Us and said that he cooked the books on Iraq? And secondly, would you like to see Democrats, including Presidential candidates, repudiate that ad? [SEP] I thought the ad was disgusting, and I felt like the ad was an attack not only on General Petraeus but on the U.S. military. And I was disappointed that not more leaders in the Democrat Party spoke out strongly against that kind of ad. And that leads me to come to this conclusion: that most Democrats are afraid of irritating a left-wing group like MoveOn.org— or more afraid of irritating them than they are of irritating the United States military. That was a sorry deal. And it's one thing to attack me; it's another thing to attack somebody like General Petraeus.All right. Leavitt is going to answer some questions, if you have any for him. Make sure they're—tone them down a little bit; this is his first time in here. Martha, you and Gregory be polite on him. Thank you for your time.Michael.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, if you were to encounter President Putin on this trip, would you engage in conversation, or are such interactions out of the question? [SEP] Look, he's going to be there, so I imagine we'll see each other. We can't forget Russia's contribution during World War II, which is part of what Normandy is about. But let's be real: things have changed east of NATO's borders. We're dealing with aggression, armed aggression, against a neighbor. Remember Georgia? Now it's Ukraine, especially Crimea. Putin hasn't exactly been secretive about Russian forces being involved. We have to recognize that, just like Russia hasn't hidden the fact that they've doubled their defense budget in the last four years. We've got to ask ourselves, why? What's the end game? What does it mean for NATO countries? We all want Russia to modernize, so we can do good business, be good neighbors, and work together in lots of different areas. But right now, we have to deal with this situation by backing Ukraine's independence and their right to choose a pro-Western path. We also need to support Ukraine's modernization. I think that's the right way to go, a good example for Russian society, just like Poland's democracy, free market, prosperity, and security were a good example. It had a positive effect on Ukraine, and I think it was part of their dream to follow the same path, towards the same values. I'm also convinced that if Ukraine is successful, democratic, and independent, and if they can overcome their economic and political problems, it will have a big impact on how people in Russia think. It's pretty clear that Russian public opinion has been behind Putin's aggressive behavior in Crimea. But Russian public opinion should be on the side of Russia's modernization, not trying to rebuild some kind of empire. That's all for today. Thanks.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the situation in Syria, do you trust President Putin's account of Russia's objectives? If Russia targets groups aligned with the U.S., will the U.S. provide protection? And regarding the train-and-equip program, can it be reformed, or should we explore alternatives like a no-fly zone? [SEP] Well, let's be clear about Syria. It started with peaceful protests against Assad, which were met with unacceptable brutality, leading to a civil war. This isn't a U.S. conflict; it's the Syrian people against a ruthless dictator. Russia and Iran have supported Assad all along, so their current actions are just more blatant. I told Putin that the only way forward is a political transition that includes everyone except Assad. I'm open to working with Russia if they can facilitate this transition, but a military solution is not viable. We share a common goal of defeating ISIS, but Putin's failure to distinguish between ISIS and the moderate opposition is a critical error. We're engaged in technical discussions to prevent aerial conflicts. Regarding our support for opposition groups, they are essential for a future political transition. The train-and-equip program hasn't met expectations because of their focus on Assad's attacks. We're assessing successful strategies, such as our collaboration with the Kurds. Putin's intervention in Syria is a sign of weakness, not strength. His coalition is limited to Iran and Assad, while ours encompasses the rest of the world. We're willing to collaborate with Russia and Iran on a political transition, but it requires a change in government. Their airstrikes against the moderate opposition are counterproductive.
label: Implicit

sentence: Will the United States officially recognize [Country]? [SEP] I'd suggest you familiarize yourself with the Ahtisaari plan. And, of course, how do we get more peacekeepers into Darfur? The delay has been the lack of agreement between the U.N. and Sudan on the status of forces. Now that it's signed, I think it's cleared the way. We have many volunteers, and as Chair of the African Union, we seek more contributions. We've volunteered a battalion. If another is needed, we'll do that.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the narrow margins in several key House races, what role do you believe your personal endorsements played in influencing voter decisions? [SEP] My endorsements are very powerful. Everyone knows that. When I endorse someone, they win. It's like magic. I have a great record of endorsements, and I'm very proud of it. The people I endorse are strong, they're smart, and they're going to do a great job.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Do you know if you have the legal authority to do that? [SEP] Because it wasn't a real decision that Boom this is the way it is. It was like Now. Right? Now.It depends on what happens I guess. It was a very strange decision. It was a very very sad decision. Not in terms of voting. Not in terms of—just a very sad because it was so convoluted. It was—to get to that decision had to be very very hard.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Just to follow up on Alexei Navalny: You just said you—you haven't had any proof yet. Do you have any reasons to doubt the results from Germany? [SEP] No, I don't. I mean, I don't. I hear Germany has made a—was it definitive, or almost definitive? But we have not seen it ourselves, no. But we have not seen it ourselves.But I would certainly be okay with that. They want to do something. They want to take action. Shouldn't happen. Shouldn't happen.But again, we are working very closely with a lot of countries on a lot of different things. We've taken stronger action against Russia than any other country in the world, as you know. I'll tell you, President Putin would tell you that right now.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the escalating tensions between Russia and Ukraine, you mentioned that you believe Putin will 'move in.' Has your administration made a determination as to whether President Putin intends to invade or otherwise move into Ukraine? [SEP] Let me be clear: Putin is the sole decision-maker here. No one else is impacting his choices. His decision might even hinge on his daily disposition. He could be considering discussions on strategic doctrine and force structures in Europe, but I'm uncertain if he's committed. Our meetings have been unproductive because those engaging with him seem unaware of his intentions. A full-scale occupation is possible, but contingent on ground conditions. We're reinforcing Ukraine's defenses and monitoring the Baltic and Black Sea regions. He's undoubtedly assessing the repercussions for Russia, but I suspect his final decision is pending.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the situation in Libya, there seems to be a lack of consensus among coalition partners about who will lead the next phase of the military campaign. Can you assure the American people that the U.S. role will be limited to just a few more days? Also, what is your response to concerns about the financial and human costs of this intervention? [SEP] First of all, we were very relieved that the two pilots were safe. It seems to have been a mechanical issue, and our military responded quickly. I had discussed recovery efforts with Admiral Mullen beforehand. There are always risks in these operations, and that's why it's a difficult decision. We will transfer control to an international coalition. NATO is working on the command structure. We've already reduced the number of U.S. planes involved. Our job was to create the space for the no-fly zone and address humanitarian needs. We've saved lives in Benghazi. This was a matter of days, not weeks, and that hasn't changed.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Health care--as you're well aware, obviously, a lot of Republicans ran against your health care law. Some have called for repealing the law. I'm wondering, sir, if you believe that health care reform, that you worked so hard on, is in danger at this point and whether there's a threat as a result of this election? [SEP] Well, I know that there's some Republican candidates who won last night who feel very strongly about it. I'm sure that this will be an issue that comes up in discussions with the Republican leadership. As I said before, though, I think we'd be misreading the election if we thought that the American people want to see us for the next 2 years relitigate arguments that we had over the last 2 years.With respect to the health care law, generally--and this may go to some of the questions that Savannah was raising. When I talk to a woman from New Hampshire who doesn't have to mortgage her house because she got cancer and is seeking treatment, but now is able to get health insurance; when I talk to parents who are relieved that their child with a preexisting condition can now stay on their policy until they're 26 years old and give them a time to transition to find a job that will give them health insurance, or the small businesses that are now taking advantage of the tax credits that are provided, then I say to myself, this was the right thing to do.Now, if the Republicans have ideas for how to improve our health care system, if they want to suggest modifications that would deliver faster and more effective reform to a health care system that has been wildly expensive for too many families and businesses and certainly for our Federal Government, I'm happy to consider some of those ideas.For example, I know one of the things that's come up is that the 1099 provision in the health care bill appears to be too burdensome for small businesses. It just involves too much paperwork, too much filing. It's probably counterproductive. It was designed to make sure that revenue was raised to help pay for some of the other provisions, but if it ends up just being so much trouble that small businesses find it difficult to manage, that's something that we should take a look at.So there are going to be examples where I think we can tweak and make improvements on the progress that we've made. That's true for any significant piece of legislation.But I don't think that if you ask the American people, should we stop trying to close the doughnut hole, that will help senior citizens get prescription drugs? Should we go back to a situation where people with preexisting conditions can't get health insurance? Should we allow insurance companies to drop your coverage when you get sick even though you've been paying premiums? I don't think that you'd have a strong vote for people saying those are provisions I want to eliminate.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Do you think China is bullying India? [SEP] I hope not. I hope not, but they're certainly going at it. They're going at it much more strongly than a lot of people even understand.Yes, please, go ahead.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. I want to ask you about a comment that Vladimir Putin said today. But why do you think he hasn't changed his behavior in spite of everything the U.S. has done to this point? [SEP] [] He's Vladimir Putin.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, despite the progress you cite, critics argue that your administration's approach to Iran has been ineffective. What specific steps are you taking to ensure that Iran does not develop nuclear weapons, and what leverage do you have to compel them to comply with international norms? [SEP] We had a great meeting with the Amir. They're very excited about what's happening in the Middle East. We signed the first two countries, and others want to be a part of it. The Middle East is straightening out. We're talking to them about various aspects of the Middle East. We're out of Syria, except we kept the oil. We'll probably be dealing with the Kurds and the oil. We're down to very few soldiers in Iraq, and we'll be down to less than 4,000 in Afghanistan. We're dealing very well with the Taliban. They're very tough, they're very smart. But we'll be out of there, knowing that certain things have to happen.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Is it fair to say that additional military personnel—U.S. military personnel are part of what's under consideration? [SEP] I think what is fair to say is that all the countries in the international coalition are prepared to do more to train Iraqi security forces if they feel like that additional work is being taken advantage of. And one of the things that we're still seeing is, in Iraq, places where we've got more training capacity than we have recruits. So part of my discussion with Prime Minister Abadi was, how do we make sure that we get more recruits in? A big part of the answer there is our outreach to Sunni tribes.We've seen Sunni tribes who are not only willing and prepared to fight ISIL, but have been successful at rebuffing ISIL. But it has not been happening as fast as it needs to. And so one of the efforts that I'm hoping to see out of Prime Minister Abadi and the Iraqi legislature when they're in session is to move forward on a National Guard law that would help to devolve some of the security efforts in places like Anbar to local folks and to get those Sunni tribes involved more rapidly.This is part of what helped defeat AQI—the precursor of ISIL—during the Iraq war in 2006. Without that kind of local participation, even if you have a short-term success, it's very hard to hold those areas.The other area where we've got to make a lot more progress is on stemming the flow of foreign fighters. Now, you'll recall that I hosted a U.N. General Security Council meeting specifically on this issue, and we've made some progress, but not enough. We are still seeing thousands of foreign fighters flowing into, first, Syria, and then, oftentimes, ultimately into Iraq.And not all of that is preventable, but a lot of it is preventable, if we've got better cooperation, better coordination, better intelligence, if we are monitoring what's happening at the Turkish-Syria border more effectively. This is an area where we've been seeking deeper cooperation with Turkish authorities, who recognize it's a problem but haven't fully ramped up the capacity they need. And this is something that I think we got to spend a lot of time on.If we can cut off some of that foreign fighter flow, then we're able to isolate and wear out ISIL forces that are already there. Because we're taking a lot of them off the battlefield, but if they're being replenished, then it doesn't solve the problem over the long term.The final point that I emphasized to Prime Minister Abadi is the political agenda of inclusion remains as important as the military fight that's out there. If Sunnis, Kurds, and Shia all feel as if their concerns are being addressed and that operating within a legitimate political structure can meet their need for security, prosperity, nondiscrimination, then we're going to have a much easier time.And Prime—the good news is, Prime Minister Abadi is very much committed to that principle. But obviously, he's inheriting a legacy of a lot of mistrust between various groups in Iraq. He's having to take a lot of political risks. In some cases, there are efforts to undermine those efforts by other political factions within Iraq. And so we've got to continue to monitor that and support those who are on the right side of the issue there.Colleen Nelson [Wall Street Journal].
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. So, you're not going to elaborate on that point? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Given the historical tensions and conflicting interests between the United States, Iran, and Syria, what specific mechanisms would you propose to ensure transparency and accountability in any potential collaboration, preventing these nations from exploiting the situation to advance their own agendas? [SEP] Any engagement would have to be carefully structured and closely monitored. We would need to establish clear benchmarks and verification mechanisms to ensure that they are fulfilling their commitments. We would also need to work closely with our allies in the region to ensure that their concerns are addressed and that their interests are protected. Trust, but verify – that's the only way to proceed in this kind of situation.
label: General

sentence: Q. Okay. My question is very simple. You mentioned interpretation. I know part of the difficulty being the American President is that some of the decisions that you take, actions you make will be interpreted in a way that are not what you thought they would be or what you meant they would be. For instance, some of the actions you've taken were interpreted as antibusiness domestically in the United States. And as someone just mentioned, some of the actions taken by the U.S. Government that you represent as well were interpreted as sacrificing other countries' interests for America's own benefit. So it's--you find yourself constantly being interpreted in a thousand different ways. How do you address these interpretations? [SEP] With wonderful press conference like this that give me the opportunity, hopefully, to provide my own interpretation. But look, you make a valid point. We live in a connected world. Everything I say, everything my administration does, anything one of my aides does is interpreted in one fashion or another. In America, we call it spin. And there's a spin cycle that is going on 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. And I think that in this media environment, it is in some ways more challenging to make sure that your message and your intentions are getting out in a consistent basis.But I think that if I'm consistent with my actions and I'm consistent with my goals, then over time, hopefully, people look at my overall trajectory and they can draw accurate conclusions about what we're trying to do.With respect to business, for example, we've had in the United States some battles between myself and some in the business community around issues like financial regulation or health care. At the same time, I've said repeatedly and I said on this trip, we can't succeed unless American businesses succeed. And I'm going to do everything I can to promote their ability to grow and prosper and to sell their goods both in the United States and abroad. And the fact that the economy is now growing and trade is expanding and the stock market is up, I think, is an indication that I mean what I say. And hopefully, by the end of my administration businesses will look back and say, you know what, actually the guy was pretty good for business, even if at any given point in the road they may be frustrated.So all right, now I'm stuck with this last one, but I think I've got to go fly a plane.
label: Explicit

sentence: Given the concerns raised about your conversation with the Ukrainian President, can you assure the American public that you haven't leveraged your position to solicit damaging information on a political rival? [SEP] Look, the real story here is the corruption, the deep-seated corruption. You see these Senators grandstanding, these media types feigning outrage, but where were they when Biden's son was raking in millions from Ukraine and China? This whole thing is a manufactured crisis, a desperate attempt to distract from the real issues facing this country. The American people are smart, they see through this charade. We are draining the swamp, and they don't like it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, can you state definitively that you will release your tax returns to the public? [SEP] I've been audited for years. You know, people don't understand that. And when the audit is finished, I'll think about it.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, first, I just wanted to get a clarification. Your Press Secretary said today that you sometimes take more than one test a day. Why is that? And how often is that? [SEP] Well, I didn't know about more than one. I do take probably, on average, a test every 2 days, 3 days. And I don't know of any time I've taken two tests in 1 day, but I could see that happening.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Bolsonaro, are you open to the idea of a U.S. military presence in Brazil to assist with the situation on the Venezuelan border? Was this a topic of discussion with President Trump today? [SEP] Indeed, we explored the possibility of Brazil achieving the status of a major non-NATO ally. We recently sought assistance from the U.S. in facilitating the delivery of food through Boa Vista to provide humanitarian aid. This is our current position. Brazil is prepared to exert every effort to resolve the issue of the Venezuelan dictatorship and restore freedom and democracy to that nation, which once enjoyed prosperity but is now plagued by starvation and violence. We must address this pervasive issue. Mr. President?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, regarding military actions, does that include Syria? [SEP] Elaine, I appreciate the question, but I'm not going to comment on ongoing operations. I understand the angle you're pursuing, but I'm going to refrain from commenting one way or the other. Elaine.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: In hindsight, was Theresa May the wrong leader for the UK, and is Boris Johnson capable of achieving a Brexit agreement with the EU before the deadline? [SEP] Theresa tried her best, but she just couldn't seal the deal. I offered my advice early on, but she decided to go in a different direction, and well, we all saw how that ended. She's a very good person, a very strong woman. But Boris, I truly believe, will be an outstanding Prime Minister. We have a great rapport, and we spent some very productive time together recently. I've been anticipating his leadership for quite some time. He's incredibly intelligent, incredibly resilient, and incredibly passionate. And most importantly, he loves your country. Next question, please.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President, Prime Minister.Mr. President, as--after a difficult and violent summer in Kashmir, perhaps the chief flashpoint between your chief ally in the Afghanistan war and India, could you explain your administration's policy towards Kashmir and what role the United States might play in resolving that crisis? And if I might, could you please--this morning you called India a world power. Is it possible anymore to stand in the way of India's bid for a permanent seat on the U.N. Security Council?And, Prime Minister----Moderator. Sir, I will request you to please restrict yourself to one question. Q. Not one each?Moderator. Please one question, if it's possible. Please restrict yourself to one question to one of the leaders. Thank you. Q. Okay. Prime Minister--may I address the Prime Minister?Moderator. All right. Q. Thank you. To follow on a question that was asked yesterday by a student in Mumbai, do you believe that the United States should refer to Pakistan as a terrorist state? [SEP] With respect to Kashmir, obviously, this is a longstanding dispute between India and Pakistan. As I said yesterday, I believe that both Pakistan and India have an interest in reducing tensions between the two countries. The United States cannot impose a solution to these problems, but I've indicated to Prime Minister Singh that we are happy to play any role that the parties think is appropriate in reducing these tensions. That's in the interests of the region, it's in the interests of the two countries involved, and it's in the interests of the United States of America.So my hope is that conversations will be taking place between the two countries. They may not start on that particular flashpoint. There may be confidence-building measures that need to take place. But I'm absolutely convinced that it is both in India's and Pakistan's interest to reduce tensions, and that will enable them, I think, to focus on the range of both challenges and opportunities that each country faces.I do want to make this point, though, that I think Prime Minister Singh, throughout his career and throughout his Prime Ministership, has consistently spoken out both publicly and privately on his desire, his personal commitment, to reduce tensions between India and Pakistan. And for that, I very much commend him. I think Prime Minister Singh is sincere and relentless in his desire for peace.And so my hope is, is that both sides can, over the next several months, several years, find mechanisms that are appropriate for them to work out what are these very difficult issues.Mr. Prime Minister.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your assertion that mail-in voting is rife with fraud, could you provide specific instances or evidence to support this claim, particularly in states like Nevada? [SEP] Look, the evidence is all over the place. The Fake News media won't report it, but you can find it if you look. Even the failing New York Times reluctantly admitted there are problems. In Nevada, they practically throw ballots at anyone, no signature verification, nothing! It's a total disaster waiting to happen, and everyone knows it.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding the Meng Wanzhou case, will it also be delayed until the end, or is dropping the extradition possible? [SEP] Wait, when was this? About what?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Putin has indicated satisfaction with your response to his 'killer' label. Can you share your perspective on this matter? [SEP] He's content with my response, and that's all that matters, isn't it?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. You've noted media impatience for a deal, but this is your third budget, your third year. You've said you'd be a one-term President to do hard things. You won't invite Republicans to negotiate now, but what are you doing to build cooperation? Will the markets wait two years? [SEP] Jackie, that was quite the barrage of questions. My mind is starting to feel a little overloaded here.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with the Federal Reserve facing potential leadership changes, what assurances can you provide to the markets and the American people that the transition will be smooth and that the Fed will maintain its independence and effectiveness in managing monetary policy? [SEP] The Federal Reserve is a critical institution, and we're committed to ensuring its continued independence and effectiveness. We're taking the selection process very seriously, and we're confident that we'll find highly qualified individuals to fill these important roles. We're looking for people who understand the importance of price stability and full employment, and who have a proven track record of sound judgment. We'll be making announcements soon.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Mr.——Corruption Issues in Ukraine  Q. What about Biden? What about Mr. Biden? Q. What did you want about Biden? What did you want him to look into on Biden? [SEP] Look, Biden and his son are stone-cold crooked. And you know it. His son walks out with millions of dollars. The kid knows nothing. You know it, and so do we.Go ahead. Ask a question now.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, Kevin McCarthy believes the Republicans will retake the House. Do you agree with his assessment? [SEP] Well, as of today, we've lost very few seats. We might still keep the House, but it'll be close. We won all three contested seats in Nevada. So, it's a moving target, but it's going to be very close.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, following up on Russia and Ukraine, after your meeting with President Putin, you stated that he didn't want a cold war. Since then, we've seen troop build-ups, cyber attacks, and demands for a sphere of influence. Do you still believe he doesn't want a cold war? Has your view of him changed? And if he invades, would you consider a containment policy? [SEP] I still don't believe he desires a full-blown war. However, I do think he will test the West, the United States, and NATO. He'll pay a price for it, one he doesn't anticipate. He's grappling with the perceived tragedy of the Soviet Union's collapse. He's trying to find his place between China and the West. I suspect he will move in; he has to do something. He wants guarantees that Ukraine won't join NATO and that strategic weapons won't be stationed there. We can discuss the latter, but the former is more complicated due to international treaties. Ukraine joining NATO in the near term is unlikely anyway. There's room for negotiation, but I suspect he'll make a move that will ultimately hurt him.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, and Mr. Prime Minister, in your discussions, did you consider Canada expanding its stimulus package? Furthermore, what's your outlook for the Canada-U.S. relationship over the next four years with respect to the auto industry, border security, and carbon emissions trading? [SEP] That's quite a collection of questions you've presented. [] Were you getting help from someone? Is that--[].
label: Clarification

sentence: President Biden, could you offer any insight into President Zelenskyy's assessment of the counteroffensive's progress and the timing of the F-16 deployment, considering Jake Sullivan's 'exigencies of the conflict' remark? [SEP] I appreciate the question, but divulging such information would be imprudent. Let's just say we're providing Ukraine with the tools they need, when they need them. Details are for the battlefield, not the press briefing room.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. The deadline for Kosovo's independence, sir? [SEP] Pardon me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding climate change, Mr. Howard prioritized it at the APEC meeting. However, your Washington meeting seems to contradict his efforts. How important is ratifying Kyoto in addressing climate change, in your view? [SEP] Well, let's unpack that a bit, shall we? On Kyoto, it's a complex issue. Look, it might be suitable for some nations, but it simply wasn't a good fit for the United States. The Senate, before I even took office, overwhelmingly rejected it. It wasn't just my opinion; there was broad consensus. Instead, we've focused on innovation and technology, and we've actually reduced greenhouse gases while growing our economy. As for Mr. Howard's efforts, I support addressing climate change, but we need a global approach that includes everyone, including countries like China and India. We can't impose solutions; we need collaboration. And frankly, focusing on tariffs that hinder the export of clean technologies is a smart move. We need to get these technologies to developing nations. Our strategy is the most effective way to tackle this seriously. I commend Mr. Howard for bringing this to the forefront.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Anybody on Capitol Hill will say that there's no chance that the American Jobs Act, in its current state, passes either House. And you've been out on the campaign trail banging away at them saying, pass this bill. And it begins, sir, to look like you're campaigning and like you're following the Harry Truman model against the do-nothing Congress instead of negotiating. Are you negotiating? Will you? [SEP] I am always open to negotiations. What is also true is they need to do something. I'm not--look, the--Bill, I think it is very clear that if Members of Congress come in and say, All right, we want to build infrastructure, here's the way we think we can do it; we want to put construction workers back to work, we've got some ideas, I am ready, eager to work with them. They say, We've got this great idea for putting teachers back in the classroom; it's a little different than what you've proposed in the jobs bill. I'm ready, eager to work with them. But that's not what we're hearing right now. I mean, what we're hearing is that their big ideas, the ones that make sense, are ones we're already doing.They've given me a list of, well, here's the Republican job creation ideas: Let's pass free trade agreements. It's great that we're passing these free trade agreements. We put them forward; I expect bipartisan support. I think it's going to be good for the American economy. But it's not going to meet the challenge of 9-percent unemployment or an economy that is currently weakening. It's not enough.Patent reform, very important for our long-term competitiveness. There's nobody out there who actually thinks that that's going to immediately fill the needs of people who are out of work or strengthen the economy right now.So what I've tried to do is say, here are the best ideas I've heard. Not just from partisans, but from independent economists. These are the ideas most likely to create jobs now and strengthen the economy right now. And that's what the American people are looking for. And the response from Republicans has been, no, although they haven't given a good reason why they're opposed to putting construction workers back on the job or teachers back in the classroom.If you ask them, well, okay, if you're not for that, what are you for? Trade has already been done; patent reform has been done. What else? The answer we're getting right now is, well, we're going to roll back all these Obama regulations. So their big economic plan to put people back to work right now is to roll back financial protections and allow banks to charge hidden fees on credit cards again or weaken consumer watchdogs. Or alternatively, they've said we'll roll back regulations that make sure we've got clean air and clean water, eliminate the EPA. Does anybody really think that that is going to create jobs right now and meet the challenges of a global economy that are--that is weakening with all these forces coming into play?I mean, here is a good question, here's a little homework assignment for folks: Go ask the Republicans what their jobs plan is, if they're opposed to the American Jobs Act, and have it scored, have it assessed by the same independent economists that have assessed our jobs plan. These independent economists say that we could grow the economy as much as 2 percent and as many as 1.9 million workers would be back on the job. I think it would be interesting to have them do a similar assessment--same people. Some of these folks, by the way, traditionally have worked for Republicans, not just Democrats. Have those economists evaluate what, over the next 2 years, the Republican jobs plan would do. I'll be interested in the answer. I think everybody here--I see some smirks in the audience because you know that it's not going to be real robust.And so, Bill, the question, then, is, will Congress do something? If Congress does something, then I can't run against a do-nothing Congress. If Congress does nothing, then it's not a matter of me running against them; I think the American people will run them out of town because they are frustrated, and they know we need to do something big and something bold.Now, the American people are also concerned about making sure that we have a Government that lives within its means, which is why I put forward a plan that would also reduce our deficit and our debt in a more aggressive way than what the special committee has been charged with.Folks want to talk about corporate tax reform. I've already said I'm happy to engage with them on corporate tax reform. I'm happy to engage with them, working to see what we can do to streamline and simplify our Tax Code, eliminate all the loopholes, eliminate these special interest carve-outs and potentially lower rates in the process while raising more revenue.I am happy to negotiate with them on a whole host of issues, but right now we've got an emergency. And the American people are living that emergency out every single day, and they have been for a long time. They are working really hard. And if they're not on the job, then they're working really hard to find a job. And they're losing their homes, and their kids are having to drop out of school because they can't afford student loans. And they're putting off visiting a doctor because when they lost their job they lost their health insurance. They are struggling.And as a consequence, by the way, all of us are struggling, even those who are well off. The irony is the same folks that the Republicans claim to be protecting, the well off--the millionaires and the billionaires--they'd be doing better, they'd be making more money if ordinary Americans had some money in their pockets and were out there feeling more confident about the economy. That's been the lesson of our history: When folks in the middle and at the bottom are doing well, the folks at the top do even better.
label: General

sentence: Do you still believe North Korea and the U.S. could have a relationship like the U.S. and Vietnam? [SEP] Pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Will the conflict be resolved before your term ends? And do you approve of Israel's actions? [SEP] I certainly hope so. I advocate for a lasting ceasefire. And a lasting ceasefire means Hamas must stop firing rockets into Israel. It simply cannot be sustainable if they continue their attacks. The choice, in my view, rests with Hamas. We believe the best way to achieve this is to collaborate with Egypt to halt the flow of arms into Gaza, which enables Hamas to continue their rocket attacks. Countries supplying these weapons must cease their support. The international community must maintain pressure on them to stop providing arms. Hamas, of course, if they genuinely desire a sustainable ceasefire, must stop arming themselves. And neighboring countries must work together to prevent smuggling. It's a challenging task, given the tunnels and the opportunities for those who seek to disrupt democracy. Now, remind me of the second part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Prime Minister Netanyahu said that you have a situation where Iran can delay 24 days before giving access to military facilities—— The President. I'm happy to—that's a good example. So let's take the issue of 24 days. This has been, I think, swirling today, the notion that this is insufficient in terms of inspections.Now, keep in mind, first of all, that we'll have 24/7 inspections of declared nuclear facilities—Fordow, Natanz, Arak, their uranium mines; facilities that are known to produce centrifuges, parts. That entire infrastructure that we know about, we will have sophisticated, 24/7 monitoring of those facilities. Okay?So then, the issue is, what if they try to develop a covert program? Now, one of the advantages of having inspections across the entire production chain is that it makes it very difficult to set up a covert program. There are only so many uranium mines in Iran. And if in fact we're counting the amount of uranium that's being mined and suddenly some is missing on the back end, they've got some explaining to do.So we're able to track what's happening along the existing facilities to make sure that there is not diversion into a covert program. But let's say that Iran is so determined that it now wants to operate covertly. The IAEA—the international organization charged with implementing the nonproliferation treaty and monitoring nuclear activities in countries around the world—the IAEA will have the ability to say, that undeclared site we're concerned about, we see something suspicious. And they will be able to say to Iran, we want to go inspect that.Now, if Iran objects, we can override it. In the agreement, we've set it up so we can override Iran's objection. And we don't need Russia or China in order for us to get that override. And if they continue to object, we're in a position to snap back sanctions and declare that Iran is in violation and is cheating.As for the fact that it may take 24 days to finally get access to the site, the nature of nuclear programs and facilities is such, this is not something you hide in a closet. This is not something you put on a dolly and kind of wheel off somewhere. And by the way, if we identify an undeclared site that we're suspicious about, we're going to be keeping eyes on it. So we're going to be monitoring what the activity is, and that's going to be something that will be evidence, if we think that some funny business was going on there, that we can then present to the international community.So we'll be monitoring that that entire time. And by the way, if there is nuclear material on that site, your high school physics will remind us that that leaves a trace. And so we'll know that, in fact, there was a violation of the agreement.So the point is, Jonathan, that this is the most vigorous inspection and verification regime by far that has ever been negotiated. Is it possible that Iran decides to try to cheat despite having this entire inspection verification mechanism? It's possible. But if it does, first of all, we've built in a 1-year breakout time, which gives us a year to respond forcefully. And we've built in a snap-back provision so we don't have to go through lengthy negotiations at the U.N. to put the sanctions right back in place.And so really the only argument you can make against the verification and inspection mechanism that we've put forward is that Iran is so intent on obtaining a nuclear weapon that no inspection regime and no verification mechanism would be sufficient because they'd find some way to get around it because they're untrustworthy.And if that's your view, then we go back to the choice that you have to make earlier. That means, presumably, that you can't negotiate. And what you're really saying is, is that you've got to apply military force to guarantee that they don't have a nuclear program. And if somebody wants to make that debate, whether it's the Republican leadership or Prime Minister Netanyahu or the Israeli Ambassador or others, they're free to make it. But it's not persuasive.Carol Lee [Wall Street Journal].Iranian Arms Embargo and Ballistic Missile Prohibition/The President's Middle East Policies Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I want to ask you about the arms and ballistic missile embargo. Why did you decide—agree to lift those even with the 5- and 8-year durations? [SEP] Right.
label: Dodging

sentence: But will the U.S. formally acknowledge this? [SEP] I'd steer you towards the Ahtisaari plan. It's not about being difficult, but how do we get more peacekeepers into Darfur? The delay has been the status of forces agreement between the U.N. and Sudan. Now that's resolved, many are volunteering. As African Union Chair, we want more contributions. We've offered a battalion; we'll add another if needed.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, in light of your expressed concerns regarding the rise of a particular form of nationalism, would you advise those protesting against Mr. Trump's rhetoric to discontinue their demonstrations? Did you offer your successor any counsel regarding the selection of staff, especially given these troubling trends? And lastly, in these final weeks of your presidency, do you believe you retain any influence to stop the bombing of Aleppo by Assad and Putin? [SEP] One of the strengths of our democracy is its diverse expressions, including protest. I've been the target of protests throughout my presidency. I wouldn't advise people to remain silent. However, I would emphasize that elections matter, voting matters, and informed engagement matters. Don't take our system of government for granted. Democracy requires constant effort. If a significant portion of eligible voters abstain, democracy is weakened. If we can't distinguish facts from propaganda, we face challenges. If people are unwilling to compromise, democracy suffers. Understand the foundations of a healthy democracy and engage continuously. There's a degree of complacency. Some young people forget the lessons of the Cold War. There's a tendency to equate the U.S. and Russia, but we have flaws and make mistakes. The U.S. has been a positive force for Germany, providing security and aiding in its rebuilding. We've generally strived to uphold free speech and civil liberties in our foreign policy. Remember that in an age of misinformation. Don't equate isolated incidents with systemic repression. If distinctions are blurred, we risk losing what we've gained. Apologies for the lengthy response.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: But what about within the White House itself, sir? You have a large staff, and there are rumors of departures. General Kelly, in particular, is rumored to be leaving. Is that accurate? [SEP] Well, people come and go. That's the nature of things. People leave.
label: General

sentence: Q. Sir, may I, as a representative of the international media, pose a question? [SEP] Which outlet are you with?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, your previous statements suggested Brexit would complicate U.S.-U.K. trade. Given the 'special relationship,' was it appropriate to publicly criticize the Prime Minister's Brexit strategy? Prime Minister, do you believe Mr. Trump is correct that Brexit might restrict future trade agreements, and what was your reaction to his critique? [SEP] I have tremendous respect for the Prime Minister. The fake news didn't include all the great things I said about her. We record everything, so we have the truth. She's going to decide what to do with Brexit. I just want to make sure we can trade. We want to trade with the U.K., and they want to trade with us. We're their biggest trading partner. We can make it even bigger. So, if they go a different way, I hope we can still trade. I've heard it might not be possible, but I think it will be. So, we'll see. And she's doing a terrific job. Thank you. And just to confirm what the President said, there will be no limits to our trade deals after Brexit. We can trade with the U.S. and everyone else. We're taking back control of our borders, our laws, and our money. We will be able to make our own trade deals. The U.S. is eager to work with us.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. The number-one concern for many Americans right now is jobs. Taking a look at your budget, there are tax hikes proposed for energy, for higher income people, and also for replenishing the State unemployment funds. Do you worry about the impact on jobs, sir? [SEP] Well, actually, if you look at that budget, there's a whole bunch of stuff in there for job creation. I think some folks noted, for example, our infrastructure proposals, which would create millions of jobs around the country; our investments in research and development and clean energy have the potential for creating job growth in industries of the future.My belief that the high-end tax cuts for--or the Bush tax cuts for the high end of the population--folks like me--my belief is, is that that doesn't in any way impede job growth. And most economists agree.We had this debate in December. Now, we compromised in order to achieve an overall package that reduced taxes for all Americans, and so I believe--I continue to believe that was a smart compromise. But when it comes to over the long term, maintaining tax breaks for millionaires and billionaires, when that will mean additional deficits of a trillion dollars, if you're serious about deficit reduction, you don't do that.And as I said, I think most economists--even ones that tend to lean to the right or are more conservative--would agree that that's not the best way for us to approach deficit reduction and debt reduction.So I do think it's important, as we think about corporate tax reform, as we think about individual tax reform, to try to keep taxes as simple as possible and as low as possible. But we also have to acknowledge that, in the same way that families have to pay for what they buy, well, Government has to pay for what it buys. And if we believe that it's important for us to have a strong military, that doesn't come for free. We've got to pay for it. If we think that we have to take care of our veterans when they come home--and not just salute on Memorial Day, but we actually have to work with folks who have posttraumatic stress disorder or traumatic brain injury--well, that requires services that are very labor intensive and expensive.If we think it's important that our senior citizens continue to enjoy health care in their golden years, that costs money. If we think that after a flood, we help out our neighbors and our fellow citizens so that they can recover, we've got to pay for it.So the circumstance that's changed--earlier Julianna asked why I think I might get a deal. I think some of the questions here generally have centered about what's going to be different this time. My hope is that what's different this time is, is we have an adult conversation where everybody says, here's what's important and here's how we're going to pay for it.Now, there are going to be some significant disagreements about what people think is important. And then that's how democracy should work. And at the margins, I think that I'll end up having to compromise on some things. Hopefully, others will have that same spirit.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. It sounds like you're moving closer to eliminating the filibuster. Is that correct? [SEP] I answered your question./Tax Code Reform/Deficit Spending/The President's Agenda
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Obama, can you confirm the reports that Chen Guangcheng is under U.S. protection in Beijing? How do you see this situation resolving itself? And would the U.S. offer him asylum if requested? [SEP] I am aware of the reports, but I cannot comment directly on the specifics. I will say that human rights are always a topic of discussion with . We believe that is stronger when it embraces freedom and human rights. We want to see strong and prosperous, and we believe that human rights improvements will only strengthen that relationship. On North Korea, we have consulted closely with . We are unified in our insistence that North Korea abide by international norms and understand that provocations will only lead to isolation and sanctions. We will continue to work with our allies to ensure stability in the region.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Iran, ABC News is reporting they could develop a nuclear weapon within two years. Have you seen intelligence corroborating an accelerated nuclear program? [SEP] I'm not familiar with the specific report you mention. However, I share the concern that Iran intends to acquire a nuclear weapon. If they were to succeed, it would severely destabilize the Middle East. Therefore, we've been working to build an international coalition to persuade Iran to abandon its nuclear ambitions, emphasizing the choices they face between isolation and economic opportunity. We take seriously any attempts by Iran to obtain a nuclear weapon.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. But why do you need, sir, to do an Executive order if it's already a part of existing law? [SEP] Just a double safety net and just to let people know that the Republicans are totally, strongly in favor of preexisting condition—taking care of people with preexisting conditions.It's a signal to people. It's a second platform. We have—preexisting conditions will be taken care of 100 percent by Republicans and the Republican Party. I think it's a very—I actually think it's a very important statement.Yes, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, Mr. President—— Federal Coronavirus Response  Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You've been saying for months the virus would simply disappear, and now you're saying that it's likely to get worse before it gets better. If it does keep getting worse, if Americans keep dying, are you responsible for that? [SEP] Well, the virus will disappear. It will disappear. I think that—I always like to say, as—you know, either way, when you look at it, the Governors are working with me. I'm working with the Governor. We're working hand in hand. I think we're all responsible. I view it as a team. Very good relationships with the Governors. Very, very good relationships.I could say I'm fully responsible. But you know, one day, we had a virus come in, and I closed the borders, did a lot of things that were very good. In fact, Dr. Fauci said we saved tens of thousands of lives when I closed the border. And nobody wanted to do it. I wanted to do it. We closed the border to China. We put on the ban. We didn't want people coming in from heavily infected China.Fairly shortly thereafter, I closed the borders from Europe—coming in from Europe. Those were tremendous moves. We would have—if it's one person, it's too much. But we're at, let's say, 140,000; we could have double, triple, quadruple that number if we didn't.So we did a lot of things right. We did a lot of things right, including with equipment. So it's a shame that it happened. It shouldn't have happened. China should have stopped it.Please.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Lee, given North Korea's planned missile launch, what specific actions will South Korea take, and what is the status of discussions with the U.S. regarding extending South Korea's missile range? [SEP] Let me reiterate: a launch by would be a clear violation of UN resolutions and its own pledges. The international community is urging them to reconsider. If proceeds, they alone will bear the responsibility, deepening their isolation. The people of will see their leader spending vast sums on a missile launch while they suffer hardships, understanding the true nature of their leadership. Domestically, they may hope to achieve some goal, but they will face a difficult position. I urge them to act responsibly. On missile range, we did not discuss it directly, though working-level discussions are ongoing within the broader context of enhancing our defense capabilities against . We will remain calm and rational in dealing with this situation.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. But Mr. President, with Americans dying daily, why frame this as a global competition? [SEP] People are dying all over the world, not just here. Perhaps you should direct your inquiries to the source of the problem. Ask China. They might have some explaining to do. Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding E-Verify and Fast and Furious, can you give us a straight answer? Will you veto an E-Verify bill without legalization, and what's the timeline for accountability in the Fast and Furious scandal? [SEP] Look, I've addressed these issues repeatedly. The ATF investigation is proceeding, and we'll act accordingly. On immigration, I've been clear: comprehensive reform is the only viable path forward. We need to fix the system holistically, not piecemeal.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Could you tell us anything about the individual or the instrument involved in the incident? [SEP] That information is not available to me at this time, unfortunately.

sentence: Q. Do you agree the House and Senate bills can't pass anymore? [SEP] What I agree with is that the public has soured on the process that they saw over the last year. I think that actually contaminates how they view the substance of the bills. I think it is important for all of these issues to be aired so that people have confidence, if we're moving forward on such a significant part of the economy as health care, that there is complete transparency and all these issues have been adequately vetted and adequately debated.And this gives an opportunity not just for Democrats to say, here's what we think we should do, but it also gives Republicans a showcase before the entire country to say, here's our plan, here's why we think this will work. And one of the things that John Boehner and Mitch McConnell both said is they didn't think that the status quo was acceptable, and that's, right there, promising. That indicates that if all sides agree that we can't just continue with business as usual, then maybe we can actually get something done.All right. Jake [Jake Tapper, ABC News].
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. It's great. You get tested; you know very quickly. Do you think that it would be easier to reopen and restart businesses if we could produce more of those machines for people? [SEP] We're trying to do that. That's a great question. We're trying very much to do that. So rather than sending your tests in—and you know, it goes through the mail 1 day, comes back another day, no matter how they send them. It's a day and a day, so that's 2 days already wasted. And then, if it spends—by the time you get it back, it's 3 or 4 days, if they do an efficient job. We're trying to get the testing on site.
label: Explicit

sentence: So, who in the GOP needs to get the memo about being more inclusive? [SEP] After a loss, people tend to circle the wagons and get all picky about who's a 'real' Republican. We'll bounce back, but we gotta show we're open to different ideas. Look at immigration – some folks came away thinking we hate immigrants. If that's the vibe, others might think we don't like them either. We gotta be compassionate and show we care about everyone. Back in '64, my dad got wiped out in the Johnson landslide, and the whole party took a beating. But we came back in '66.
