We can do it again, but we gotta send the right message: we care, and we've got a plan.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, as the war in Afghanistan winds down, can you honestly say that the immense human and financial costs were justified, considering the Afghanistan we are leaving behind falls short of the initial visions of reconstruction and democracy? And President Karzai, do you stand by your claim that foreign influence is largely to blame for Afghanistan's corruption, and are you fully committed to stepping down after next year's elections? [SEP] We went to Afghanistan because we were attacked. Al Qaeda attacked us, and they were based in Afghanistan. We had to go after them. We've largely achieved our goal of dismantling Al Qaeda. Afghanistan still has a long way to go, but it's in a better place than it was before. As for President Karzai, I'll let him speak for himself.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, Mr. President, you're unwilling to even acknowledge that we've conducted drone strikes in Yemen? [SEP] I'm not prepared to discuss ongoing operational matters.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, many believe this troop deployment is simply a veiled attempt to counter China's growing influence. Can you provide a more transparent explanation of the strategic objectives, and what specific benchmarks must be met to justify the continued presence of troops in Afghanistan? [SEP] This deployment is about enhancing cooperation and building capacity in a critical region. The Asia-Pacific is the engine of global economic growth. We need to update our security framework. This enables us to address various challenges, including natural disasters. We welcome China's growth, but they must adhere to international norms. They need to play by the rules. In Afghanistan, every loss of life is deeply felt. We're there to safeguard our security. We're transitioning to Afghan leadership. We need to complete the mission effectively. And I thank Prime Minister Gillard for her dedication and her empathy for our troops.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, if there are legal impediments to the Treasury receiving these payments, why did you initially suggest it as a possibility? Were you unaware of these obstacles at the time, and what steps are you taking to ensure that future proposals are thoroughly vetted for legal feasibility? [SEP] Look, I'm not a lawyer, okay? I'm a businessman. I think outside the box. I come up with ideas. Sometimes they work, sometimes they don't. But you can't be afraid to think big, you can't be afraid to push the envelope. That's how you get things done. So, I suggested it, it seemed like a good idea at the time. Maybe it's not possible, maybe it is. We're looking into it. But I'm not going to apologize for trying to get the best deal for the American people. That's what I do. And I'm going to keep doing it, even if the lawyers tell me it's impossible. Because sometimes, impossible is just a challenge waiting to be overcome.
label: General

sentence: President Lee, North Korea's impending launch is a serious concern. Beyond condemnation, what tangible steps will South Korea take to deter further provocations, and what is the latest on the missile range extension talks with the US? The public deserves to know the specifics. [SEP] A launch would be a grave mistake, a clear violation of UN resolutions. They will be held accountable. Their isolation will only worsen. Their people will suffer. We urge them to reconsider. The US and South Korea are in complete agreement. As for the missile range, that's being handled at a lower level. It's part of our broader defense strategy.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Regarding the Pope's move to recognize the Palestinian state, what's your reaction? Good idea, mistake, help or hinder the two-state solution? [SEP] First, congrats to the Senate for giving me authority to strike a smart, progressive trade deal in Asia-Pacific and Europe, and to enforce those agreements. Thanks to the Senators who voted to start the debate. I'll keep trying to convince those who didn't. Despite past problems with trade deals, my approach is right for big, medium, and small businesses, and especially American workers. I wouldn't promote any deal that didn't create jobs and higher wages. The issue with Elizabeth isn't personal. It's fun for the press, but we're close allies with a policy disagreement. Many friends in the Senate and House disagree with me, and I understand their concerns about plants closing and jobs going overseas. They worry about labor and environmental agreements and fair trade. They're concerned about inequality and the effects of automation and globalization. They share my values, except on trade. It's a policy difference about what's best for our people. I believe we're better off writing high-standard rules with strong provisions on child labor, deforestation, etc., for the largest, fastest-growing market. If we don't, China will. Regarding outsourcing, companies can already do it. We have a chance to attract companies back. Nike is bringing 10,000 jobs back because of new technologies. We need to sell over there. We need a strong minimum wage, job training, infrastructure investments, collective bargaining, overtime pay, paid sick leave, and honest budgets. Blocking a trade deal won't help. Existing trade rules are bad for workers. I'm for enforcement. I have concerns about the currency language. I need to talk to Schumer and Brown about language that doesn't hurt our monetary policy. What was your other question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with prominent Republican economists like Greenspan and Feldstein advocating for government intervention to avert a recession, specifically addressing home foreclosures and tax cuts, what specific actions is your administration prepared to take, and when can the American people expect to see these measures implemented? [SEP] We are constantly evaluating all available options. The economy's fundamentals remain strong due to our competitiveness, flexible workplace, low taxes, and export growth. I share Americans' concerns about rising costs and potential foreclosures. We won't bail out lenders or speculators, but we'll assist creditworthy homeowners. Secretary Paulson and Secretary Jackson's HOPE NOW coalition is working to establish standards for refinancing. The housing market's complexity stems from the securitization of mortgages, making renegotiation difficult. We're addressing these realities effectively. Congress can expedite this by passing the FHA modernization bill. Regarding further stimulation, we're considering all options and monitoring the situation closely.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, regarding the Bidens, what specific actions did you want the Ukrainian government to investigate? [SEP] Look, the Bidens are totally corrupt. Everyone knows it. The son gets rich for no reason. It's a disgrace. Next question.
label: Deflection

sentence: Can you confirm whether Syria was specifically discussed? [SEP] Proliferation was definitely a focus of the conversations.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your focus on broad, sweeping legislation has made it easier for the opposition to block progress. Would you consider a more targeted, incremental approach to address the urgent needs of the American people? [SEP] We are exploring all available options to deliver results for the American people. We are not afraid to be bold, and we are not afraid to compromise. But we will not compromise on our core values, and we will not compromise on our commitment to creating a more just and equitable society for all.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, Republican and Democratic Presidents before you sat down for face-to-face talks with the Soviet Union, a nation that was clearly hostile, tyrannical, and had a huge nuclear arsenal. Why do you think that face-to-face talks between yourself and the leadership of Iran would be any more compromising for you? [SEP] Richard, if I thought we could achieve success, I would sit down, but I don't think we can achieve success right now. And therefore, we'll want to work with other nations. I think that we're more likely to achieve our goals when others are involved as well. I really don't want to put the situation—listen, let me put it this way: I want to make sure that in the ian issue that the whole world stays engaged, because I believe that's a more effective way of convincing the ians that—to give up their nuclear weapons ambitions. That's why.Look, I know this is a world in which— and I'm not suggesting you're this way— but this is a world in which people say, Meet, sit down and meet. And my answer is, If it yields results, that's what I'm interested in. And so I believe the strategy that—and by the way, I remember this during the North Korean issue, debate. People kept saying, Well, all you've got to do is sit down with the guy. And I kept saying, Well, I think it's going to be more effective if we have other people at the table with us saying the same thing, so that just in case he decides not to honor the agreement, there will be other people saying the same thing I'll say, which is, ‘You said one thing; you did another.' It will make it easier for us to send that message that the world, pretty well united in solving this problem peacefully.And so that's why I made the decision I made. It sounds tempting for somebody to say, All you've got to do is sit down with the people. I'm in a little different position in that I'm trying to achieve certain objectives. And we are making progress on the ian issue. If you step back to early on in the process, there was doubt as to whether or not the world would come together, sometimes because of the reason John mentioned, in other words, the conflicting interests. And I believe we are making good progress toward solving this issue peacefully.And we'll continue to try to solve the issue peacefully. It's an important issue whether or not ends up with a nuclear weapon. It's one of these issues that people are going to look back and say: You know, how come they couldn't see the impending danger? What happened to them? You've heard me say that often about what would happen if we don't—if we were to abandon our efforts in the Middle East for stability and peace through forms of government that are more likely to defeat an extremist ideology that would like to be able to prevail.And it's a—at any rate, that's why I made the decision I made. Presidents have to weigh different options all the time. Look, I fully understand there are some who are—don't agree with every decision I make. I hope the American people understand I make those decisions because I believe it's going to yield the peace that we all want.Listen, thank you for your time. Enjoyed it very much.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, if E-Verify passes without legalization, will you veto? And regarding Fast and Furious, will you replace ATF leadership and when will the investigation conclude? [SEP] Regarding Fast and Furious, the Attorney General assures me he would never authorize gun running. The inquiry continues, so I can't comment. I disapprove of such actions and await the findings. As for E-Verify, comprehensive reform is essential. We must balance law and immigration traditions with border security, employer accountability, and a path to legal status. E-Verify can help if accurate and fair. We need safeguards to protect citizens. We must also address DREAM Act kids. A balanced approach is key.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: In light of the Oregon tragedy, Governor Bush stated, 'Stuff happens.' How do you, sir, respond to such a sentiment? [SEP] I believe the American people are capable of forming their own opinions on that statement, considering the frequency of mass shootings in our nation. My administration is actively exploring all available avenues to enforce existing laws and prevent firearms from falling into the hands of criminals. However, substantive change necessitates a shift in the political landscape. I intend to maintain a consistent dialogue on this issue, as our inaction is, in itself, a political decision.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Are you considering firing him, Mr. President? [SEP] I consider firing everybody. [] At some point, that's what happens.Jennifer [Jennifer Jacobs, Bloomberg News], do you have something, Jennifer? You're working so hard.
label: General

sentence: Do you believe Mr. Putin will stop disrupting NATO and the United States? What consequences did you outline for interfering with US critical infrastructure? [SEP] I'll address your second question first. I made it clear to him that we possess significant cyber capabilities. He is aware of this, although he doesn't know the precise details. If they violate these established norms, we will respond with cyber warfare. He understands this.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning your discussions with Kim Jong Un, does a transcript of those conversations exist? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President——The President's Federal Income Taxes/News Media/New York Times  Q. Quick follow-up: Chris will definitely ask tough questions. And one of the ones that's going to—likely everybody is going to be talking about is there's a New York Times story that came out about an hour ago that says that, when you came to the White House, you were paying about $750 a year in Federal income tax.They are not releasing what—they're not publishing the tax returns. They're not showing that out there. They're saying—to protect their sources. In your tax returns, sir, does that sound right, that you were paying a couple hundred dollars a year in Federal income taxes? [SEP] No. No. It's fake news. It's totally fake news. Made up. Fake. We went through the same stories. You could have asked me the same questions 4 years ago. I had to litigate this and talk about it. Totally fake news. No.Actually, I paid tax, but—and you'll see that as soon as my tax returns—it's under audit. They've been under audit for a long time. The IRS does not treat me well. They treat me like the Tea Party—like they treated the Tea Party. And they don't treat me well. They treat me very badly.You have people that—in the IRS—they're very—they treat me very, very badly. But they're under audit. And when they're not, I would be proud to show you. But that's just fake news. The New York Times tried it—the same thing. They want to create a little bit of a story, a little bit of—they're doing anything they can.Not only—that's the least of it. I mean, the stories that I read are so fake. They're so phony.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the intelligence agencies' assessment of election interference, are you concerned that focusing solely on Russia and China might overlook other potential actors who could seek to influence the election? [SEP] It could be many people, many countries. Who knows? But nobody wants to see me in office less than Russia, that I can tell you. I've been tougher on them than anyone, ever.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, what's your message to the young men of America? [SEP] Look, it's a tough world. It's a very big moment for our country, because you have a man who is very outstanding, but he's got very strong charges against him—probably charges that nobody is going to be able be—to prove. You have to be careful, very careful.
label: Dodging

sentence: Alright, what's the actual point you're trying to make? [SEP] It's a total sham, a political hit job. We've got the head of the World Trade Organization here, and he has to listen to this garbage about a perfect call. Nobody ever mentions the transcription, nobody ever talks about the call itself, because there's nothing there. Read it! Somebody should just read the call! Everyone would say, 'That's an impeachable offense?' If that were impeachable, Lyndon Johnson and Kennedy would have been out of office on day one. It's a hoax, a complete and utter hoax. You know it's a hoax better than anyone. Yes, go ahead.
label: Dodging

sentence: From the US standpoint, would a political agreement be deemed a success, even if it meant he remained involved? [SEP] For us, success means him leaving office. He needs to stop leading the military against his people. He has to go. That's the bottom line.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with the pandemic continuing to evolve, what specific conditions must be met before the United States can confidently commit to donating another billion vaccine doses, and how does this commitment align with the stated goal of ending the pandemic by 2022? [SEP] Well, let me state unequivocally that the United States remains deeply committed to global vaccine equity. The possibility of providing an additional billion doses is under serious consideration, potentially extending into 2023. However, I am exercising prudence in making definitive pronouncements. We are constantly assessing our capabilities and the evolving global needs. The G-7 shares a consensus that this is a sustained effort, driven not only by moral imperative but also by considerations of national security. No barrier can effectively contain the spread of novel variants. This will be an ongoing endeavor, and we are actively developing systems for the early detection of future pandemics. Our approach extends beyond mere vaccine donation; we are actively empowering nations to establish their own vaccine manufacturing capabilities. This undertaking presents significant logistical complexities, and we are diligently addressing them. Last question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. So you're declining to elaborate further? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President—[inaudible]—Valentinovna, Sputnik News Agency. Have you discussed the issue of possible inspections to North Korea's nuclear sites during your negotiations? [SEP] Speak up, please. And remind me, what news organization do you represent?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given Prime Minister Netanyahu's recent statements seemingly walking back his commitment to a two-state solution, what specific actions could he take to demonstrate a genuine commitment to peace negotiations with the Palestinians? Is there anything he can do at this point to regain your trust? And, turning to Afghanistan, President Ghani, what gives you hope that reconciliation talks with the Taliban will succeed, and what role do you envision for the U.S. in those talks? [SEP] On the matter of spying, I am not going to comment. As for Prime Minister Netanyahu, it's not about what I believe, it's about what the parties involved believe. He said what he said before the election. Now, he says something different. Actions speak louder than words. As for the Palestinians, they need to see a path forward. As for Afghanistan, that's a matter for President Ghani.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Under what conditions would you meet with President Castro in Havana? Would you have certain preconditions that you would want to see met before doing that? And on the hack, I know that you said that you're not going to announce your response, but are you—can you say whether you're considering additional economic or financial sanctions on North Korea? Can you rule out the use of military force or some kind of cyber hit of your own? [SEP] I'm going to stick with what I said before. We've confirmed North Korea was behind it, and we're weighing our options. They'll be presented to me, and I'll decide based on what's proportional and appropriate. As for Cuba, a visit from me or President Castro isn't happening right now. I don't know how the relationship will evolve, but I imagine I'll visit Cuba someday. But there's no specific plan for a visit.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics like Romney are saying your Iran policy is a failure and that they'll have a nuke if you're re-elected. Care to respond? [SEP] Well, I'm not going to engage in a tit-for-tat with the folks on the other side of the aisle until they've settled on their nominee. But let's be clear: we've built a global coalition against Iran over the past three years. It's been a steady, determined effort to isolate them and send a clear message that a nuclear weapon is a red line. Is it easy? Absolutely not. Anyone who says otherwise is playing politics or doesn't know the facts. But I believe the world, and the Iranian regime itself, understands our resolve to prevent nuclear proliferation in the region. This isn't just about Iran; it's about preventing a nuclear arms race and upholding non-proliferation norms globally, including in places like Asia where we have similar challenges with North Korea.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. You don't seem like you want to go ahead with the sanctions? [SEP] I love our country but I have to tell you President Erdogan who has done—he gave me our pastor back Pastor Brunson. Nobody else could get him back. Remember? They couldn't get him back. President Obama he was in jail for 35 years. He was going to be in jail forever. Pastor Brunson he was an innocent man.I called him. And after a very short period of time Pastor Brunson was standing in the Oval Office with me. And he was back. So you know he's been—from my standpoint—and he's a tough guy. Okay? When you talk about tough. He's tough. But I get along with him.I think he was unfairly treated where you were told you can't have it and then after he bought another system we were said—we said: We'll sell it to you. We'll give it to you right away. But he couldn't use it then. But by that time he had already bought the plane.So it's a complicated deal. We're working on it. We'll see what we can do.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President and Mr. Prime Minister. I wanted to ask you a little bit more about BP. You mentioned, Mr. Prime Minister, your decision to cooperate, et cetera, but you said we shouldn't confuse the two. Have you flatly ruled out opening a Government investigation into the events around the release of the bomber?And, President Obama, how do you feel about a congressional investigation into this? Would you like to see that happen, or do you think that confuses the two events? [SEP] Well, why don't I start off, and I'll throw it over to David. I think all of us here in the United States were surprised, disappointed, and angry about the release of the Lockerbie bomber. And my administration expressed very clearly our objections prior to the decision being made and subsequent to the decision being made. So we welcome any additional information that will give us insights and a better understanding of why the decision was made.But I think that the key thing to understand here is that we've got a British Prime Minister who shares our anger over the decision, who also objects to how it played out. And so I'm fully supportive of Prime Minister Cameron's efforts to gain a better understanding of it, to clarify it. But the bottom line is, is that we all disagreed with it. It was a bad decision. And going forward, that has to inform how we approach our relationship with respect to counterterrorism generally.Now, one of the things that I want to emphasize that I think may get lost in this current debate is the extraordinarily strong ties between our two countries when it comes to fighting terrorism. We probably have the best coordination and cooperation of any two countries in the world. And those relationships are vital, and they keep people safe on both sides of the Atlantic.And I want to make sure that even as we may express concern about what happened with respect to the release of this particular individual, that we stay focused on the cooperation that currently exists and build on that cooperation to make sure that there is no diminution of our joint efforts to make sure that the kinds of attacks that happened over Lockerbie do not happen again. Well, I agree with actually what's been said about the importance of the security cooperation, something we discussed today. On Megrahi, look, I'm not standing here today and saying it was a bad decision to release Megrahi because I'm here. I said this a year ago, at the time, that it was a bad decision. It shouldn't have been made. The British Government, as well, should have been clear that it was a bad decision, rather than going along with it. I took that very clear view. This was the biggest mass murderer in British history, and there was no business in letting him out of prison.In terms of an inquiry, there has been an inquiry by the Scottish Parliament into the way the decision was made. The British Government--the last British Government released a whole heap of information about this decision. But I've asked the Cabinet Secretary today to go back through all of the paperwork and see if more needs to be published about the background to this decision.But in terms of an inquiry, I'm not currently minded that we need to have a U.K.-based inquiry on this, partly for this reason: I don't need an inquiry to tell me what was a bad decision. It was a bad decision. And if you like, the big fact that's changed over the year that makes it an even worse decision is the fact that, of course, Megrahi is still free, at liberty, in Libya, rather than serving the prison sentence in Scotland, as he should be doing.So that's what we're going to do, is go back over this information, see if more needs to be published, and of course, in terms of the congressional hearing, make sure that proper cooperation is extended to it. Somebody you want to call? Right. I think James Landale [BBC News].
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, Rick Ledgett's suggestion of amnesty for Edward Snowden has sparked debate. What was your reaction to this 'trial balloon'? Under what circumstances would you consider a plea agreement or amnesty for Snowden? And what message do you have for Americans who, after recent revelations, believe Snowden's actions were justified in exposing the scope of government surveillance? [SEP] I must be cautious here, Major, as Mr. Snowden is currently under indictment and facing criminal charges. This matter falls within the jurisdiction of the Attorney General and, ultimately, a judge and a jury. Therefore, I cannot provide specific commentary on this case at this time. However, I will attempt to address the underlying sentiment of the question, even if I cannot delve into the specifics. I have previously stated, and I maintain, that this was an important conversation that needed to occur. I have also stated that the manner in which these disclosures were made has been detrimental to the United States and damaging to our intelligence capabilities. I believe that there was a way to have this conversation without causing such harm. To provide a specific example, the United States, despite its imperfections, is a nation that adheres to the rule of law, deeply values privacy, civil liberties, and our Constitution. As a result of these disclosures, countries that actively engage in the very activities that Mr. Snowden claims to be concerned about—such as surveillance of their own citizens, targeting political dissidents, and suppressing the press—are now able to stand on the sidelines and portray the United States as having problems with surveillance and intelligence operations. This is a distorted view of the situation. While this debate has been important and necessary, it is also crucial to remember that it has caused unnecessary damage to U.S. intelligence capabilities and U.S. diplomacy. However, I will leave it to the courts and the Attorney General to publicly weigh in on the specifics of Mr. Snowden's case.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, how do you assess the House immigration bill's prospects, and what's your take on Mexico's new approach to U.S. law enforcement cooperation? [SEP] The Senate's Gang of Eight produced a commendable immigration bill. While not precisely what I'd have authored, it addresses key elements: improved border security, employer accountability, a more efficient legal immigration system, and a challenging but attainable path to citizenship. I'll carefully consider the House proposal, evaluating whether it meets these same fundamental requirements. Regarding Mexico, I look forward to engaging with President Peña Nieto to bolster our economic ties while addressing security challenges. The adjustments to Mexican law enforcement coordination appear to be primarily internal restructuring.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding your authority to ease sanctions to finalize the agreement, could you clarify the extent of your unilateral power? [SEP] Look, we're talking about a tiered system here. We've got international sanctions, UN resolutions, and then sanctions that we, the United States, have put in place ourselves. Each one operates under a different framework. But let's not jump the gun. First, we need to secure a deal. If we can get a verifiable agreement that prevents Iran from developing a nuclear weapon, an agreement that inspires confidence both here and abroad, then we'll bring it to Congress. We'll make the case that this is the best path forward, far better than military intervention or any other option. But it has to be a solid deal. I've always said, no deal is better than a bad deal. We can't lift sanctions and legitimize Iran without ironclad guarantees that they won't pursue nuclear weapons. Got it? Okay, next question.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, after stating in Geneva that President Putin didn't want a cold war, given the troop movements, cyber attacks, and demands for a sphere of influence, do you still believe that to be true? Has your perspective on him changed, and if he invades, would you consider a containment approach? [SEP] I maintain that he doesn't desire a full-scale war. However, I anticipate he will test the limits of the West, the United States, and NATO as much as he can. He will suffer significant repercussions that he doesn't presently foresee. He will regret his decision. He sees the dismantling of the Berlin Wall and the loss of the Soviet empire as a major setback for Russia. He controls vast territory, but is struggling to establish his role between China and the West. I'm unsure if he has a definitive strategy. My expectation is that he will intervene. He feels compelled to act. He wants guarantees that Ukraine will never be part of NATO and that strategic weapons will not be stationed there. We can potentially reach an agreement on the latter, depending on his actions. The former is more challenging, as international agreements guarantee the right of nations to choose their alliances. However, Ukraine joining NATO in the near future is unlikely. There's room for negotiation if he's willing. But I think, as usual, he's going to—well, I probably shouldn't go any further. But I think it will hurt him badly.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, considering the complexities of North-South relations, is it realistic to expect a single individual, even the President of the United States, to resolve such a deeply rooted conflict? [SEP] It's not about being a 'single individual,' it's about leadership, about bringing parties together, and about creating an environment conducive to progress. While the challenges are significant, I believe that with perseverance and a commitment to diplomacy, we can achieve a breakthrough that benefits all stakeholders.
label: Implicit

sentence: So, Mr. President, are you now considering Kim Jong Un as an equal on the world stage? [SEP] In what respect are we defining 'equal' here?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, considering the government's intervention in Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, how do you assure taxpayers that this won't lead to further bailouts and that financial institutions will be held accountable for their actions? [SEP] The situation with Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac is unique. They play a critical role in the mortgage market, and their stability is vital to the economy. Secretary Paulson's plan is a targeted intervention designed to address specific vulnerabilities. It's not a blank check. It's a responsible approach to managing risk. And let's not forget that the FDIC insures bank deposits up to $100,000. So, the vast majority of depositors are protected. We're taking steps to ensure the stability of the financial system while also protecting taxpayers.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, following your meeting with President Bachelet and your upcoming meeting with President Uribe, what concrete steps have you seen in Latin America towards promoting democracy, as you requested at the Summit of the Americas? [SEP] First off, President Bachelet is a top-notch leader, one of the best in Latin America. Look at how Chile navigated the recession. They were smart. They saved their money when copper prices were high, so they had the resources to weather the storm. A lesson for us, frankly. We squandered our surpluses. We see huge potential for progress in Latin America. I'll be discussing clean energy cooperation with President Bachelet. We'll have an announcement later. We're also making strides in cancer research exchanges. Our trade relationship with Chile is strong. And Chile has partnerships with states like California. Our relationship with Chile is respectful, even when we disagree. It's a partnership. We don't dictate to Chile. We want to learn from President Bachelet how to expand this model throughout Latin America. Next question?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Madam President, given Brazil's ambition to be a global leader and the U.S.'s perception of Brazil as a regional player, how do you bridge this difference in perspective and foster a stronger partnership? [SEP] Well, I think President Obama answered part of that question already. But I want to emphasize that countries go through challenges. That doesn't diminish their importance. Brazil is committed to overcoming its current challenges and continuing to be a strong partner with the U.S. We have much in common, including a shared history of overcoming slavery and a diverse population. We are two strong democracies, and we will continue to work together to build a better future.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. And what about your own family, sir? [SEP] Say again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, the Red Cross is calling the CIA's interrogation tactics torture. Care to comment? And about Guantanamo, you promised to shut it down, but it's still running. Any progress? Will it be closed before you're out of office? [SEP] Right, Guantanamo. I said it should be closed. Big issue is, where do these guys go? Nobody wants them. The Senate basically said, 'Keep 'em out!' So, it's a practical problem. What do we do with them? Saying nothing's happening is wrong. We're trying to send them back, but these are killers, and nobody wants them. Plus, we gotta treat them humanely. We also want trials. The courts are involved, Defense is trying to figure it out. Faster we get those trials going, the better. Can't say for sure if it'll be closed or not. It's a mess. I set a goal. We'll try. It's not as simple as it sounds. Look at that Senate vote again. Nobody wants these prisoners in their backyard. What was the other part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, have you been informed about the recent accident during the marine's training exercise off the coast of California? [SEP] I'm due to be fully briefed on the specifics shortly.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Trump, with all due respect, the intelligence community has presented a unified front on Russian interference. Your own advisors have confirmed it. Why the hesitation to simply and directly condemn President Putin and Russia for their actions? [SEP] Well, let me tell you, it's not that simple. You have to ask, where's the server? Nobody ever talks about the server. The FBI should have taken that server. I have my people telling me one thing, Putin is telling me another. He was very, very powerful in his denial. And frankly, he made a very generous offer. We should look into that. And what about Hillary's emails? Everyone forgets about those. It's a total double standard.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Sure. Sure. But can you talk us through a bit more on the focus on distributing to minorities and how that would work?And then for you, Mr. President, you mentioned the drop in the poverty rate. Specifically, we noticed at—just the news that the poverty rate for African Americans hit historic lows, that the household wealth increased historically for African Americans. What was driving that increase in wealth for African Americans?And now, in 2020, with the coronavirus, with unemployment spiking, what would be your plan for the second term to improve lives for African Americans? [SEP] Well, I'll go first, because of your question—I appreciate your question. And yes, we've had a tremendous drop in poverty for all people in our Nation, but in particular for African Americans. And that statistic came in. And it's because the African American community, the Black community has had the lowest—the best employment numbers that we've ever had—both employment and unemployment, depending on how you want to define it.But we've had the best employment numbers we've ever had. Now, we had the greatest employment in the country ever, almost 160 million people. We've never been close to that number, but we were just 6 months ago.And yes, the—I'm very proud of the numbers. African Americans, Hispanic Americans—they had the best numbers they've ever had, by far—both employment and unemployment, depending on definition.Thank you very much for that question. Scott, do you want to answer that too? Okay. Yes, so what I—to clarify, I said that the first prioritization is the high-risk people and frontline health care workers.But just to reiterate, what I said, there are 51,000 outlets for distribution for vaccination, and there's over 14,000 Federally ualified Health Centers that are particularly targeted to minority and low-income areas. So that's a focus.And I want to point out two other things. We're also prioritizing testing at Historically Black Colleges and Universities and we're in the process of getting that finalized because we know that there's high—there's a higher morbidity with—in certain ethnic groups.And last thing I would say is, it's particularly heinous—an egregious abuse of the media to instill fear into people about taking a vaccine, because there is no shortcut here. Everything is safe. Everything is effective. And for people who have particularly an influence on minority communities to instill fear and doubt is a particularly, you know, outrageous abuse of public policy and of leadership. These are people that have higher risk.And so I implore everyone who is in a high-risk category that when we get a safe, effective vaccine, they should take the vaccine. . I will say, this is a phenomena that only happened when they realized that we may very well have the vaccine prior to a certain very important date, namely November 3. Once they heard that, the Democrats started—just to show you how bad the intention is, they started knocking the vaccine. Had nothing to do with a vaccine, it was totally made up. It's all disinformation.Just like they put an ad in about football. Just like they put—with respect to me. I'm the one that got football back. And I was always against them going out. It was ridiculous that Big Ten and now, hopefully, Pac-10 [Pac-12]* goes back.And I say that, just like—even worse, they put out a totally fake ad, totally made-up story. It was a made-up story by a third-rate magazine, where the head guy—I guess, the head person—I have no idea who he is; I don't know him, but he's friends with Obama and Clinton. So they made up this horrible story, and then they did ads. Well, they made up this story too.This story is very simple: They started knocking the vaccine as soon as they heard that this actually may come out prior to election. Now, it may or may not, but it will be within a matter of weeks. It will be within a matter of weeks from November. It's ready to go and it's ready to—for massive distribution to everybody—with a focus, again, on seniors.And I will say, also, the Historically Black Colleges and Universities, we are doing, at my suggestion—because they have had a difficult problem there—we are doing more testing there and finer testing. We have our great apparatus there.But we—when you look at what we've done on testing, in terms of the technology and the amount, it's been really amazing. In fact, I think we're going to crack a hundred million tests very soon, in the very near future. We're going to be cracking a hundred million tests.Now what that does do is, it shows up more cases. If we didn't test, we wouldn't have cases. You would have no cases. Other countries, they don't test; they don't have cases. And then they say, Oh, the United States—well—but we're proud of it, because it shows where there may be a problem, and it helps people. But we're doing tremendous testing at the Historically Black Colleges and Universities. And that was a suggestion I made, and I think it's a good suggestion.Yes, please, go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, what specific actions have you threatened against the Pakistani government if they fail to extradite him? [SEP] The specifics of our diplomatic exchanges remain confidential. However, I assure you that we've communicated the gravity of this matter with utmost clarity. Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: If the clinical trials are successful, will your administration expedite the approval process for this potential treatment? [SEP] Well, it's really too early to make any definitive statements. I need to see more comprehensive data before I can offer a considered opinion on that matter.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Retirement age specifics, sir? Can we get some clarity? [SEP] I'm not diving into specifics. We've looked at everything. If seniors pay a bit more, millionaires have to chip in too. It's about balance.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given the seriousness of the allegations, Mr. President, will you release the full, unredacted transcript of your call with the Ukrainian President, and will you allow key members of your administration to testify under oath before Congress? [SEP] We've already released a transcript of the call, and it shows there was nothing wrong. The Democrats are just trying to score political points. They're obsessed with me, and they'll stop at nothing to try to take me down. But they won't succeed. The American people are smart, and they know what's really going on.
label: Deflection

sentence: During your meetings today, Mr. President, was there any discussion about Canada potentially expanding its stimulus initiatives? Furthermore, for both of you, what are your expectations for the Canada-U.S. relationship in four years? What will be the state of the automotive industry? Will the border become more or less restrictive? And will a carbon market be established? [SEP] Hold on, you've crammed several questions into one. [] Were you coordinating with Jonathan on that? Is that--[].
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Would you do it if the room was empty? [SEP] I think it—I think it better represents the country. Also, I feel, sort of, a—at least a semiobligation as the President of the United States to be at the United Nations to deliver what will be an important speech.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, observers in Baghdad suggest that while military progress is evident, political reconciliation remains stalled. Given that the surge aimed to create space for Iraqi governance, and progress is lacking, shouldn't the American people hear more than 'Maliki must do better'? [SEP] Look, General Petraeus and Ambassador Crocker are preparing their report on the surge's impact, covering both military and political dimensions. My assessment is that while there's been some movement, it's not enough. This is a tough situation, complicated by years of tyranny that bred distrust. These leaders need to build trust. They're learning how to lead democratically, which is a new process. Yes, they haven't passed all the laws we expected, and that's where the focus often is. But there's also a Presidency Council, representing different parties, working through these challenges. The July 15th report to Congress showed they met about half the benchmarks, falling short on some political ones. Interestingly, their parliament has passed around 60 laws this year, some directly related to reconciliation, like judicial reform and dismantling Saddam's laws. People ask, 'Is there even a functioning government?' I asked about the budgeting process – is there a central system for oil revenues? About 97% of their revenue comes from oil, and they're using it for military operations and expenses. But there's also revenue sharing with the provinces, which surprised me, given the impression of total dysfunction. In 2006, the central government allocated $2.3 billion to the provinces, benefiting Shia, Sunni, and Kurdish regions. Some of this money is being better spent now thanks to bottom-up reconciliation efforts. The point is, there's still a lot of work to be done. If you look hard enough, you'll find evidence that the government is learning to function. We need an oil revenue sharing law, but revenue sharing is already happening. The fundamental question for America is: is it worth it? Does it matter if we stay long enough for an ally to emerge in the fight against radicals? My answer is yes. Leaving prematurely would have long-term consequences. The troop configuration will depend on Petraeus's recommendations.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Sir, with respect to the bank bailout, will you require banks to use the money to increase lending? If not, how do you justify this bailout to the American people after the last one failed? [SEP] Helene, I'm trying not to get ahead of my Treasury Secretary – you should all be at his press conference; he'll be great. But – and this relates to Jake's earlier question – my main concern is whether credit is flowing to those who need it. Is it flowing to businesses, large and small? Is it flowing to consumers? Are they able to operate in ways that lead to jobs and economic growth? The package we've put together is designed to help with that. I'll make sure Tim gets his moment tomorrow. Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you just said that you had lunch with Prodi today. Then later you'll have a coffee break with Mr. Berlusconi. What do you enjoy most, the lunch or the coffee break? [Laughter] Or would you have preferred to be on a diet today? [Laughter]And to Prime Minister Prodi, now, I'm perhaps not going to be so ironic in my question. Now the friendship is wonderful. You've made progress. But I know that there have been some differences between the U.S. and Italy over the months, even though the friendship is solid and progress has been made. So President Bush is asking you to perhaps change your rules of engagement in Afghanistan, and even with regard to Iran, there are some differences of opinion and, in general, in the Middle East. So have you managed to close that gap a bit? Or how do you think you might be doing that in the future? [SEP] Yes, I'm going to have coffee with the former Prime Minister, Prime Minister Berlusconi. I'm doing so for a couple of reasons: One, he is the opposition leader; two, he is a friend. And I mentioned this to Romano, and his attitude was, I don't blame you; it's the kind of thing he does when he goes to other countries. And I'm looking forward to seeing Silvio. It's a—one shouldn't read anything into it, other than we made some decisions together. We've known each other for a while, just like I've known Romano— actually, I've known Romano a long time too. He was President of the EU early on in my Presidency. And so I consider it an honor to have friends with two important leaders here in Italy. We spoke very frankly about many of the issues that you've just raised in your question. And, yes, there certainly is an active cooperation between us. And this is with regard to problems we've had in Afghanistan and, of course, the very difficult situation in Iran. And we both share the same position, the same views when—with regard to the danger that we are running if we allow the proliferation of nuclear weapons, and we also agree on the course of action that should be followed.So I think that in the future we'll certainly be able to work together, and we'll be able to exert pressure, both of us, on the Iranian Government. We don't want them to exceed the limits, as it were, of a peaceful and monitored or controlled use of nuclear technology. So, this is our position, and, as I said, we share the same view.Now, of course, we also discussed other issues on our common agenda, and we were able to reiterate the fact that there is an interdependence here and a need to work together, not only because it is helpful or useful, but it is a strong need that we have to focus on to restore peace in the world.Now, we spoke about climate change, about global warming in our meetings over the past few days. And I think that this has somehow set out a course of action for the future: how we can perhaps harmonize our production systems; how we can make sure that our political decisions are, in fact, in conformity with these needs. And I think, again, that we'll definitely be able to make huge progress together.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Biden, considering your third budget proposal and the challenges in achieving bipartisan consensus, why haven't you directly invited Republicans to negotiate? What steps are you taking to promote cooperation? And will the markets remain patient? [SEP] That's a lot to unpack! Remind me, what was the first part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, how much are you willing to give? How much money are you willing to give Congress if they're going $6 billion more than you've offered? [SEP] We'll we're going to see, but we'll take care of States, because States are working very hard. We have hospitals in states that make rooms available, and they—they're building quarantine areas—areas where you can keep people safely. We're working really well with States. It's a very big part of it.So you know, my attitude: If Congress wants to give us the money so easy—it wasn't very easy for the wall, but we got that one done. If they want to give us the money, we'll take the money. We'll just do a good job with it.Yes, please. Go ahead. Go ahead.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, could I ask you about a domestic matter? [SEP] Sure.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I will have a question for you and one for the French President, if I may.For you, first, you now are saying that you are going to better coordinate, especially your green economic policies. But yesterday Emmanuel Macron said that the Inflation Reduction Act is, in fact, superaggressive, I quote, toward European companies. Does that mean that you are ready to grant exception—exemptions of the regulations to European industries?And now my question to you, Monsieur President.[The reporter spoke in French, and her remarks were translated by an interpreter as follows.]Mr. President, will you leave Washington with the assurance that you will be able to deal with these massive—[inaudible]?Interpreter. The journalist doesn't have a microphone. Q. Do you think there is risk of generating divisions? [SEP] I'll answer the last question, since I didn't hear any of it. I didn't understand a word of it, so I'll answer it. [][] Can we take care of it? [] No, look, the United States makes no apology—and I make no apologies, since I wrote it for—the legislation you're talking about.But there are occasions when you write a massive piece of legislation—and that has almost $368 billion dollars for the largest investment in climate change on all—of all of history. And so there's obviously going to be glitches in it and need to reconcile changes in it.For example, there's a provision in it that says that there is the exception for anyone has a free trade agreement with us. Well, that was added by a Member of the United States Congress who acknowledges that he just meant allies; he didn't mean, literally, free trade agreement. So there's a lot we can work out.But the essence of it is, we're going to make sure that the United States continues—and just as I hope Europe will be able to continue—not to have to rely on anybody else's supply chain. We're—we are our own supply chain, and we share that with Europe and all of our allies. And they will, in fact, have the opportunity to do the same thing.So there's tweaks that we can make that can fundamentally make it easier for European countries to participate and/or be on their own. But that is something that is a matter to be worked out.There is no fundamental—it was never intended, when I wrote the legislation—I never intended to exclude folks who were cooperating with us. That was not the intention.The intention was to make sure we no longer were in a position—when there was a pandemic in Asia, and China decided they're going to no longer sell us computer chips. We invented the damn things, you know? []So it's—anyway—but my point is, we're back in business, Europe is back in business, and we're going to continue to create manufacturing jobs in America, but not at the expense of Europe.[.] What we've been discussing with President Biden and what, as a matter of fact, he just said—and that's what I talked about with the caucus yesterday—that simple: The United States of America adopted a piece of legislation for their country, for their industry, which—with a common objective, goal that we share: creating jobs, creating opportunities for the middle class, and succeeding in implementing the energy transition.The reality is that the consequences, as we've seen in our discussions—it is certainly not the intention of the United States, but, as a matter of fact, projects that were growing—being developed in Europe, there's such a difference in subsidies that these projects might come to an end.And a number of Senators, yesterday, like—said it was certainly not their intention. So France simply did not come to ask for an exemption or another for our economy, but simply to discuss the consequences of this legislation.And the news—the circumstances mean that we have no alternative, but to work together. So, therefore, I believe we need to resynchronize, as I say, find a new policy to clarify our goals and continue together. And the discussion we had this morning was extremely clear. And I could feel the very same intent on behalf of the Members of the Congress yesterday.And the wish of President Biden is to rebuild a strong industry here and to have somehow to secure some technology solutions for the future. France wishes exactly the same thing for itself. And we're—we've been fighting, day in, day out, to do the very same thing in our country. And this will enable us to put an end to some 15 years of industry loss in our country and to have new manufacturing jobs.And so we'll be working on that. And we decided to do that together with the other members of the European Union and the European Commission. So we will work on the technical elements to make sure that there is no domino effect on ongoing projects in Europe. We want to succeed together, not one against the other.It's been clear. This is the outcome of our discussions this morning. And this is exactly the philosophy that I share, and it is the one that we need. []
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thanks, Ma'am. This is Mark Riley from 7News, Australia. Mr. President, I wanted to ask you about the other rising giant of our region, India. And the Prime Minister might like to add some comments. How significant is it for the U.S. that Australia is now considering selling uranium to India? And could you clear up for us what influence or encouragement your administration gave Australia as it made that decision?And also, the decision is so India can produce clean energy. In that regard, you're aware that our Parliament has passed a new bill pricing carbon, a carbon tax, if you like. But we're intrigued about where America is going on this issue. And countries like Australia don't see a carbon trading system in the world working unless America is a big part of it. Can you tell us, is it your wish that American will have an emissions trading scheme across the Nation within the next 5 years or so? How heavily do you want to see America involved in an emissions trading scheme globally? Or has this become too politically hard for you? [SEP] Good. Well, first of all, with respect to India, we have not had any influence, I suspect, on Australia's decision to explore what its relationship in terms of the peaceful use of nuclear energy in India might be. I suspect that you've got some pretty smart Government officials here who figured out that India is a big player and that the Australia-India relationship is one that should be cultivated. So they--I don't think Julia or anybody else needs my advice in figuring that out. This is part of your neighborhood, and you are going to make bilateral decisions about how to move forward.I think, without wading into the details, the discussions that are currently taking place here in Australia around that relationship and the nuclear issue with India are ones that are compatible with international law, compatible with decisions that were made in the NPT. And I will watch with interest what's determined. But this is not something between the United States and Australia, this is something between India and Australia.With respect to carbon emissions, I think I share the view of your Prime Minister and most scientists in the world that climate change is a real problem and that human activity is contributing to it and that we all have a responsibility to find ways to reduce our carbon emissions.Each country is trying to figure out how to do that most effectively. Here in Australia, under the leadership of the Prime Minister, you've moved forward with a bold strategy. In the United States, although we haven't passed a what we call a cap-and-trade system, an exchange, what we have done is, for example, taken steps to double fuel efficiency standard on cars, which will have an enormous impact on removing carbon from the atmosphere.We've invested heavily in clean energy research. We believe very strongly that with improved efficiencies and a whole step--a whole range of steps that we can meet and the commitments that we made in Copenhagen and Cancun. And as we move forward over the next several years, my hope is, is that the United States, as one of several countries with a big carbon footprint, can find further ways to reduce our carbon emissions. I think that's good for the world. I actually think, over the long term, it's good for our economies as well, because it's my strong belief that industries, utilities, individual consumers, we're all going to have to adapt how we use energy and how we think about carbon.Now, another belief that I think the Prime Minister and I share is that the advanced economies can't do this alone. So part of our insistence when we are in multilateral fora--and I will continue to insist on this when we go to Durban--is that if we are taking a series of steps, then it's important that emerging economies like China and India are also part of the bargain. It doesn't mean that they have to do exactly what we do. We understand that in terms of per capita carbon emissions, they've got a long way to go before they catch up to us. But it does mean that they've got to take seriously their responsibilities as well.And so ultimately, what we want is a mechanism whereby all countries are making an effort. And it's going to be a tough slog, particularly at a time when the economies are--a lot of economies are still struggling. But I think it's actually one that over the long term can be beneficial.Jackie Calmes [New York Times].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. In your opening remarks, you talked about that if your plan works the way you want it to work, it's going to increase consumer spending. But isn't consumer spending or overspending how we got into this mess? And if people get money back into their pockets, do you not want them saving it or paying down debt first before they start spending money into the economy? [SEP] Well, first of all, I don't think it's accurate to say that consumer spending got us into this mess. What got us into this mess initially were banks taking exorbitant, wild risks with other people's monies based on shaky assets. And because of the enormous leverage where they had $1 worth of assets and they were betting $30 on that $1, what we had was a crisis in the financial system. That led to a contraction of credit, which in turn meant businesses couldn't make payroll or make inventories, which meant that everybody became uncertain about the future of the economy, so people started making decisions accordingly, reducing investment, initiated layoffs, which in turn made things worse.Now, you are making a legitimate point, Chuck, about the fact that our savings rate has declined and this economy has been driven by consumer spending for a very long time, and that's not going to be sustainable. You know, if all we're doing is spending, and we're not making things, then over time other countries are going to get tired of lending us money and eventually the party is going to be over. Well, in fact, the party now is over.And so the sequence of how we're approaching this is as follows: Our immediate job is to stop the downward spiral, and that means putting money into consumers' pockets, it means loosening up credit, it means putting forward investments that not only employ people immediately but also lay the groundwork for long-term economic growth. And that, by the way, is important even if you're a fiscal conservative, because the biggest problem we're going to have with our Federal budget is if we continue a situation in which there are no tax revenues because economic growth is plummeting at the same time as we've got more demands for unemployment insurance, we've got more demands for people who've lost their health care, more demand for food stamps. That will put enormous strains on the Federal budget as well as the State budget.So the most important thing we can do for our budget crisis right now is to make sure that the economy doesn't continue to tank. And that's why passing the economic recovery plan is the right thing to do, even though I recognize that it's expensive. Look, I would love not to have to spend money right now. I'd--this notion that somehow I came in here just ginned up to spend $800 billion, that wasn't how I envisioned my Presidency beginning, but we have to adapt to existing circumstances.Now, what we are going to also have to do is to make sure that as soon as the economy stabilizes, investment begins again; we're no longer contracting but we're growing; that our mid-term and long-term budget is dealt with. And I think the same is true for individual consumers. Right now they're just trying to figure out, how do I make sure that if I lose my job, I'm still going to be able to make my mortgage payments. Or they're worried about how am I going to pay next month's bills. So they're not engaging in a lot of long-term financial planning.Once the economy stabilizes and people are less fearful, then I do think that we're going to have to start thinking about how do we operate more prudently, because there's no such thing as a free lunch. So if you want to get--if you want to buy a house, then putting zero down and buying a house that is probably not affordable for you in case something goes wrong, that's something that has to be reconsidered.So we're going to have to change our bad habits. But right now, the key is making sure that we pull ourselves out of the economic slump that we're in.All right. Julianna Goldman, Bloomberg.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. At the stakeout, the Republicans were saying: Well, the jobs package we've seen, it's not really ready yet. We're a little worried about the cost. Are you satisfied that there is something that can be quickly moved through Congress on jobs? [SEP] Well, my understanding is--first of all, the House has moved forward a jobs package that has some good elements in it. My understanding is, is that there is bipartisan talks taking place as we speak on the Senate side about some elements of a package.I think there are some things that a lot of people agree on. Just to give you an example, the idea of eliminating capital gains for small businesses--something we can all agree on. I talked about it at the State of the Union Address. My hope would be that we would all agree on a mechanism to get community banks who are lending to small businesses more capital, because that is something that I keep on hearing is one of the biggest problems that small businesses have out there.So I think that it's realistic for us to get a package moving quickly that may not include all the things I think need to be done, and it may be that that first package builds some trust and confidence that Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill can work together, and then we move on to the next aspect of the package, and so forth. It may take a series of incremental steps, but the one thing I'm absolutely clear about is, is that we've got an economy that's growing right now, a huge boost in productivity. That's the good news. The bad news is, is that companies still haven't taken that final step in actually putting people on their payroll full time. We're seeing an increase in temporary workers, but they haven't yet taken on that full-time worker. And so providing some additional impetus to them right as the economy is moving in a positive direction, I think, can end up yielding some good results.All right? Thank you, guys. That was pretty good. Thanks.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, why single me out to ask China about this issue? [SEP] I'm not singling you out. I'm saying that to anyone who asks a question like that.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, and to both of you, what do you think the Canada-U.S. relationship will look like in 4 years? What will the auto sector look like? Will the border be thicker or thinner? And will you have a carbon market? [SEP] Wait, wait, wait. Which part are you asking me about?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, the intelligence community has assessed that Russia is actively interfering in the upcoming election to benefit your opponent, Joe Biden, while China is considering similar actions to undermine your campaign. Do you accept these findings, and if so, what measures are you prepared to take? [SEP] Look, it's possible. Anything is possible, really. But let me tell you, nobody has been tougher on Russia than I have. Nobody. They know that. And China? They respect strength, and I've shown them strength. So, we'll see what happens, but I'm not worried.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. You talk about all the troops now being in place and only in place the last 3 weeks or a month. Yet three-quarters of the troops for the surge were in place during the period when this July interim report was written. Are you willing to keep the surge going, no matter what General Petraeus says, if there is no substantial Iraqi political progress by September? [SEP] Thank you. You're asking me to speculate on what my frame of mind will be in September, and I would just ask that you give General Petraeus to come back and brief me. And then, of course, I'll be glad to answer your questions along that line.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, despite your repeated calls for vaccination, especially targeting hesitant Republicans, parents are understandably upset about the continued lack of vaccine access for young children. Can you address their concerns and explain why this delay persists, and when they can anticipate a resolution? [SEP] The bottom line is that the science hasn't reached a consensus yet. The experts aren't convinced it's safe enough. That's what they're working on at the moment. You could have asked me this same question a few months back about children aged 7 to 12. They eventually reached a point where they were confident in the number of tests they'd performed and the results they'd obtained, and they felt it was safe. So, it will happen. It's just a matter of time. But I'm not a scientist; I can't give you a specific date. But it's absolutely crucial that we get to that next phase.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, regarding the hypothetical scenario of foreign electoral assistance, would you entertain such an offer? [SEP] That's a hypothetical, and frankly, I'm not in the business of dealing with 'what ifs.' We're focused on securing our elections. Period.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, on the matter of Russia and Ukraine, if Moscow only undertakes a 'minor incursion,' will the full weight of the promised sanctions be brought to bear? Or does that constitute a de facto permission slip for a limited invasion? [SEP] A very interesting line of inquiry.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. What's the status of the payment, Mr. President? [SEP] Run that by me one more time?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, can you share the specifics of your requests regarding Afghanistan, particularly concerning the role of U.S. troops? [SEP] Well, he actually asked about Afghanistan first. He expressed his hope that we could maintain some semblance of peace and security there. I pointed out that a lot of that depends on him. He then indicated that he was prepared to offer assistance on Afghanistan – I won't go into the details right now – as well as on Iran and other matters. In exchange, we shared our plans for bringing stability and security to the people of Syria and Libya. So, those were the topics we covered.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, the wave of anti-LGBTQ+ legislation across Republican states is causing immense fear, particularly for transgender youth and their families. Some are even considering leaving the country. What's your message to these families, and what concrete steps are you taking to combat this discrimination? [SEP] Let me address the first part of your question directly. If you can provide me with the contact information for that family you mentioned, I'd like to personally reassure them that my administration stands firmly behind them. We've made significant strides, from ending the transgender military ban to championing the Respect for Marriage Act, but the fight is far from over. There are, unfortunately, elements within our society driven by prejudice and fear-mongering, and it's creating a toxic environment. It's simply unacceptable that someone can be married in the morning and fired in the afternoon for being gay. The rising violence and hate crimes are appalling, and these hateful bills targeting transgender children are nothing short of cruel. These are our children, our neighbors, and we must protect them. That's why we're launching new initiatives to bolster the safety and well-being of the LGBTQ+ community, from increased security at Pride events to addressing civil rights violations and expanding mental health resources. Congress must also act by passing the Equality Act. To all LGBTQ+ Americans, especially our children, know that you are loved, you are heard, and this administration will not waver in its support. Regarding AI, it's clear it presents both incredible opportunities and significant risks. We're working with international partners to establish necessary safeguards, learning from the challenges we've faced with climate change. The urgency is paramount, and we're committed to addressing this issue swiftly.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, Mr. President, just to confirm, your stance is that the U.S. was justified in dropping the atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki? [SEP] Hold on, I believe there were multiple questions, correct? You initially inquired about...?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Bush, considering the challenges facing Africa, what specific actions do you believe African nations must take to foster progress and development? What type of leadership is essential, and how will the United States support these efforts? Additionally, what are your objectives for this five-nation tour, and how will you ensure the sustainability of any initiatives launched during your visit? [SEP] Well, this isn't my first trip to Africa, you know. I've come to remind folks that it's in our best interest to help countries fight diseases like malaria and HIV/AIDS, promote trade, and invest in education. And Ghana is a great place to see this firsthand. It's one thing to talk about it in America, but it's another to be here and meet the people making a difference. Africa has changed a lot since I became President, thanks to African leaders. We've helped resolve conflicts, like in Liberia, and supported the first democratically elected woman on the continent. We're not trying to impose our will, just be a good partner. Democracy is growing, and our aid program is now tied to good governance and investing in education. I believe in setting high standards for African leaders, and I'm confident in their capacity. That's why I'm here, and I'm glad to be here. And John McKinnon from the Wall Street Journal is here too.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, you've touched on many topics but haven't directly addressed Japan's specific role in countering both Russian aggression and Chinese influence. Can you elaborate on the concrete steps you expect Japan to take? [SEP] Japan is a vital ally, and we're working closely with them on a range of issues, from security to economics. They're a key partner in maintaining stability in the Indo-Pacific region, and we appreciate their commitment to upholding international norms.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. That was very specific. That's a lot, though. Do you think you can get that done by August? [SEP] Well, I—you know, August is a date that I was musing about, and that date came to mind because I understand how difficult it can be coming down the stretch in the legislative session in a calendar year, because the appropriations bill—you're learning more about this than you probably want to know—but the appropriations bills begin to crowd out the calendar in the latter part of the year. And they can consume a lot of time.And therefore, my hope is—it's certainly not a promise, but my hope would be— that we'd be able to get something out of the Senate and then into the House, and something—then they can work the conference in the fall. That would be the hope.And—but I'm not the person that sets the calendar. I'm just a simple member of the executive branch. [] It's the legislative branch that decides the calendar.And—go ahead. I would like to say that, in fact, the Guatemalan people would have preferred a more clear and positive response, no more deportations, so to say. But, as the President has said, there is a legal framework that needs to be respected. But historically, I think that we have never been so close to finding a solution to this problem as now.I was very pleased to hear President Bush say that this is a problem that they also have. It is not only a problem for migrants, it is a problem for the American citizens who have—and a problem that has to be resolved. We have never before been as close as we are at this time of seeing a light at the end of the tunnel and, in a near future, in getting the undocumented status changed for 13 million illegal aliens who are living in the U.S.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, what's your plan B if the courts rule against you? [SEP] With all due respect, that's a hypothetical I'm not going to entertain. We are confident that this will be over--that this will be upheld. We believe in the strength of our case and the integrity of the judicial process. That's not just my opinion, that's the opinion of a whole lot of constitutional law professors and academics and judges and lawyers who have examined this law, even if they're not particularly sympathetic to this particular piece of legislation or my Presidency.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. You mentioned that Americans are frustrated. And, in fact, 75 percent of voters say the country is heading in the wrong direction, despite the results of last night. What in the next 2 years do you intend to do differently to change people's opinion of the direction of the country, particularly as you contemplate a run for President in 2024? [SEP] Nothing, because they're just finding out what we're doing. The more they know about what we're doing, the more support there is.Do you know anybody who wants us to get rid of the change we made on prescription drug prices and raise prices again? Do you know anybody who wants us to walk away from building those roads and bridges and the internet and so on? I don't know any—I think that the problem is, the major pieces of legislation we passed—and some of it bipartisan—takes time to be recognized.For example, you've got over a trillion dollars' worth of infrastructure money, but not that many spades have been put in the ground. It's taking time. For example, I was on the phone congratulating a Californian recently and then someone in—up in Scranton, Pennsylvania—the Congressman who got elected. And he said, Can you help us make sure we're able to have high-speed rail service from Scranton to New York—New York City? I said: Yes, we can. We can.First of all, it will make it a lot easier, take a lot of vehicles off the road. And we have more money in the pot now already out there—we voted for—than the entire money we spent on Amtrak to begin with.And it's the same way—for example, I talked about, through the campaign, that we're going to limit the cost of insulin for seniors to $35 a month instead of $400 a month. Well, it doesn't take effect until next year.So there's a lot of things that are just starting to kick in. And the same way with what we've done in terms of environmental stuff. It takes time to get it moving.So I'm not going to change—as a matter of fact, you know there's some things I wanted to change and add to. For example, we've—had passed the most bipartisan, we passed the most extensive gun legislation—you know, rational gun policy in 30 years. And—but we didn't ban assault weapons. I'm going to ban assault weapons. They're going to try like the devil—so I'm not going to change the direction.I said I ran for three reasons. I'm going to continue to stay where I'm—and I know—I fully understand the legitimate concern that what I'm saying is wrong. Okay?One is that I said we're going to restore the soul of the country, begin to treat each other with decency, honor, and integrity. And it's starting to happen.
