sentence: Q. Mr. President, Ross Palombo from ABC News Miami. As a relatively new Floridian, what is your message today to the cruise line industry and the travel industry that Florida depends upon? And since Senator Rick Scott and Miami-Dade Mayor Carlos Giménez have the same exposure as you, and they are self-isolating, what's your message to them, that they shouldn't be? [SEP] Well, I don't know that I had exposure, but I don't have any of the symptoms.And we do have a White House doctor and, I should say, many White House doctors, frankly. And I asked them that same question, and they said, You don't have any symptoms whatsoever. And we don't want people without symptoms to go and do the test. The test is not insignificant.As far as the cruise line business, we're with them all the way. It's a great business. It's a great U.S. business, frankly. And I know how important they are to the country. That includes airlines. But the cruise line business, obviously, was hit very hard.We had a tremendous success out in Oakland where we moved it. Vice President Pence did a fantastic job with that. We worked with U.K. We worked with Canada. They took their people back. And Canada has approximately 600 people; U.K., likewise, took a large number of people back to the United Kingdom.And we have people quarantined. It was a big operation, and it worked out really—you don't hear about it anymore. It worked out really well.Mike, you may even want to say something about that because that was really done properly. Well, thank you, Mr. President. And that program with the Grand Princess, the ship, is continuing to be administered in the highest standards, orderly way, as the President directed. And Americans that needed treatment have received them.[]And what the President has directed us to do is, whether there is a pause in the moment, as some cruise lines are doing, and as we all continue to discuss, we want to work with the cruise line industry to ensure that when we come through this, that cruise lines and the medical services that are available, and for the passengers and all of the crew, that cruise lines are safer than ever before and can prosper for many years to come.
label: Explicit

sentence: So, do you believe the election signifies a turning point, a move towards greater unity and civility? [SEP] Well, you're not going to convince the hardcore folks, but I think the vast majority of people, even those we disagree with, are good people. The world is looking at us, wondering if we're still a reliable democracy. After what happened on January 6th, they were questioning our stability. We need to show them that our institutions still matter, that we can work together.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, concerning Syria, what is the general consensus in Europe regarding your administration's decision to withdraw American forces? [SEP] I've already spoken on Syria. My priority is defining and acting upon my country's position. While I won't criticize the decisions of other nations, I must reiterate our condemnation of Turkey's recent actions. There should be no ambiguity on that point.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, public confidence in the government's coronavirus response is waning, largely due to inconsistent messaging on issues like mask usage and testing procedures. You've expressed confidence in your team, but why are you unwilling to consider personnel changes at the CDC or other agencies to address these communication failures? [SEP] The evolving nature of the science is the root cause of any perceived inconsistencies. Scientists are continually gaining new knowledge, which necessitates adjustments to recommendations. While the CDC's communication effectiveness has been a subject of discussion, it's crucial to remember that the Director is a scientist, not a communications professional. This is an unprecedented virus, a completely new situation. We're learning as we progress, similar to our experience with polio. This is a developing narrative. Consider the remarkable speed with which we created a vaccine that has saved hundreds of thousands of lives. Did we get everything right? No. But it's been an incredible undertaking.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Are the sanctions going to be against the Venezuelan entities or the Indian companies who are continuing to buy the Venezuelan oil? [SEP] You're going to see in a little while. You're asking a question right in the middle of us doing something. []Go ahead, please.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the rise of what you've called a crude form of nationalism, would you advise protestors at home to cease their demonstrations against Donald Trump's rhetoric? Also, have you advised your successor to be mindful of potential staff picks? Finally, do you believe you have any leverage to stop the bombing of Aleppo? [SEP] Protesting is a part of our democracy. I've been protested against, too. I wouldn't tell them to be silent. I would advise them to vote, organize, and be informed. Don't take our government for granted. Democracy is hard work. If 43% don't vote, democracy is weakened. If we can't tell facts from propaganda, we have problems. If people won't compromise, democracy will break down. Understand the foundations of democracy and engage in citizenship. There's complacency. Some forget the Cold War. Sometimes, there's an easy equivalence between the U.S. and Russia. We have flaws, but we try to align with our values. The U.S. has been good for Germany. We've provided security and helped rebuild it. We've tried to apply principles like free speech and fighting corruption. Remember that. There's misinformation out there. Don't equate overzealousness with repression. If everything seems the same, we won't know what to protect. That was a long answer.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given Russia's ban on food imports and the troop buildup on the Ukrainian border, are the current sanctions ineffective? [SEP] Well, the jury's still out on whether the sanctions are working, isn't it? They're designed to put pressure on the Russian economy, and that's exactly what they're doing. Look at the markets, the capital flight, the projections for growth. The Russian economy has basically stalled. Putin has a choice: resolve the situation diplomatically, respecting Ukraine's sovereignty, or continue down this path and hurt his own people. We're doing what we should be doing, and our allies are with us. But the issue isn't resolved yet. There's still fighting, people are still dying. We need serious discussions to ensure all Ukrainians are heard and that the reforms are implemented. Putin needs to recognize Ukraine's independence. Until then, the problem isn't solved, but the sanctions are working as intended.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you saying you can't even comment on whether the United States has engaged in drone strikes within Yemen's borders? [SEP] I understand the public's interest, but I must defer to established protocols regarding sensitive military matters. A detailed discussion is simply not feasible at this juncture.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. President Bush, good afternoon. Mr. President, deportations continue. At the end of 2006, and only a week ago, this practice of deporting, of arresting immigrants and beginning a process of deportation, continued. In Guatemala, information of abuse of authority and lack of respect for the right of the Guatemalan immigrants has been disseminated. My question is, now that you are in Guatemala, is there a commitment from your country to the 13 million Guatemalans to cease these deportations since you expect to have a comprehensive immigration reform? [SEP] The commitment is, people will be treated with respect, but the United States will enforce our law. It's against the law to hire somebody who is in our country illegally, and we are a nation of law.The best way to solve the concerns of the citizens of Guatemala—listen, I fully understand that the citizens of Guatemala are concerned about their relatives or friends who are in the United States. And I appreciate that. The best way to address the concerns inherent in your question is for me to work with Congress to get a comprehensive bill. And I'm optimistic we can do so. It's going to be tough work— don't get me wrong—but I believe we can get a comprehensive bill out of the Congress.And I think you'll find that—let me say, I certainly hope you'll find that people who are in the—that are interfacing with our Government are treated with respect and decency. That's certainly the instructions. Now, I'm sure they don't want to be sent home, but, nevertheless, we enforce laws. And I readily concede the system needs to be changed, and I hope I can convince the majority of both the House and the Senate to change the law in a rational way.Massimo [Massimo Calabresi, Time].
label: General

sentence: Concerning the former President Carter's parley with Hamas, did it produce any tangible benefits? Did anyone within your administration advise him against such engagement? And will this affect your forthcoming Middle East tour? [SEP] Look, I haven't had a direct conversation with President Carter about this, so I'm not privy to the specifics of his discussions. My overall assessment is that Hamas is unlikely to change its ways; their words and actions rarely align. This has been a consistent observation during my time in office. While I initially supported the elections that brought them to power, their failure to improve the lives of Gazans is deeply troubling. My priority during my Middle East trip is to work alongside Israelis and President Abbas to establish a shared vision and empower Palestinians in the West Bank through enhanced security and economic opportunities. While I remain optimistic about reaching an agreement before the end of my term, Hamas's continued rocket attacks, designed to sow chaos, present a formidable obstacle. The true measure of any dialogue with Hamas will be their future conduct.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, do you believe the Saudi government bears responsibility for Mr. Khashoggi's murder? And if so, what repercussions should they face? [SEP] Well, we're looking into it very seriously, working with Congress, some very talented people, and also with Turkey and Saudi Arabia. I'm developing a very strong opinion on this. I'll have more to say next week. Next question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Here in Rome, you've tried to showcase that America is back. But back at home, your poll numbers have fallen. Your party's nominee for Governor of Virginia is facing a very tough—a tougher-than-expected race. Your party spent months trying to negotiate the centerpiece of your Democrat—of your domestic legislative agenda.We're 1 year now since your election. What—and you have done a lot in your year in office to try to turn the page on the last administration. But we've seen how Presidents can turn the page very quickly from one to the other. So why should the world, you know, believe that when you say America is back, that really it's here to stay? [SEP] Because of the way they reacted. You were here. They listened. Everyone sought me out. They wanted to know what our views were. And we helped lead what happened here.It's just very simple: You know, if you're honest—you are honest; I didn't mean to imply you weren't—but that we were—we got significant support here. Significant support. We're the most—the United States of America is the most critical part of this entire agenda, and we did it.And by the way, look, the polls are going to up and down and up and down. They were high early, then they got medium, then they went back up, and now they're low.Well, look, this is—look at every other President; the same thing has happened. But that's not why I ran. I didn't run to determine how well I'm going to do in the polls. I ran to make sure that I followed through on what I said I would do as President of the United States.And I said that I would make sure that we were in a position where we dealt with climate change; where we moved in a direction that would significantly improve the prospects of American workers being able to have good jobs and good pay; and further, that I would make sure that we dealt with the crisis that was caused by COVID. We've done all of those; we continue to do them. And we'll see what happens.But I'm not running because of the polls.
label: Dodging

sentence: President, concerning Mayor Bowser's order, while it exempts Federal properties, will you urge Federal entities, such as the White House and military bases, to follow suit? [SEP] We're reviewing the matter and will communicate our decision within the next day. We'll let you know.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, Donald Trump keeps saying the election will be rigged. This undermines our democracy. Can you promise Americans a fair election? Are you worried his words will hurt faith in the result? And if he wins, even though you've called him unfit, what will you tell the country? [SEP] At the end of the day, it's up to the American people. I've got one vote, same as you, same as everyone. I've shared my opinion, but they decide. If someone wins, I'm constitutionally obligated to hand over power peacefully and help them succeed. This talk of a rigged election? Come on. The feds don't run elections. States and cities do. Trump's pushing conspiracy theories, even in places like Texas. It's ridiculous. We're serious about election integrity, watching for hacks and fixing any federal law violations. But this election will be normal. People whine about being cheated when they lose, but never before the game's over. Trump should focus on winning. If he's way ahead and still loses, then maybe he can complain. But that's not happening.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all the information at your disposal, do you believe President Putin will authorize a full-scale invasion of Ukraine before the winter concludes? And what message do you have for the approximately 30,000 Americans currently in Ukraine – should they consider evacuating? [SEP] I've had numerous discussions with the Russians, particularly with Putin. I don't know that he's even made a—I don't know that he knows what he's going to do. And I think he has to realize that it would be a gigantic mistake for him to move on Ukraine. The impact on Europe and the rest of the world would be devastating, and he would pay a heavy price. I have been very, very straightforward and blunt with President Putin, both on the phone and in person. We will impose the most severe sanctions that have ever been imposed—economic sanctions—and there'll be a lot to pay for that down the road. It will affect others as well. It will affect us somewhat. It will affect Europeans. But it will have profound impact on his economy. And I—but I don't know. I know that he's in a position now to be able to invade almost—assuming that the ground is frozen above Kiev. He has the capacity to do that. What he's going to do, I don't know. And I don't think anybody knows but him.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Libya, when do you anticipate transferring command, and is NATO the preferred partner for this transition? Also, what specific outcomes are you aiming for with your 'alliance among equals' initiative in the Americas? [SEP] Well, with respect to Libya, obviously the situation is evolving on the ground. And how quickly this transfer takes place will be determined by the recommendations of our commanding officers that the mission has been completed--the first phase of the mission has been completed. NATO will be involved in a coordinating function because of the extraordinary capacity of that alliance. But I will leave it to Admiral Mullen and those who are directly involved in the operation to describe to you how exactly that transfer might be--might take place. With respect to this new partnership, I don't want to give you all my best lines from my speech; otherwise, no one will come. But the thing that I'm most excited about is the fact that in a country like Chile, it's not just a matter of what we can give to Chile, it's also a matter of what Chile can offer us.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the commitment to avoid competitive currency devaluations, how will that specifically impact China's behavior? What are your expectations? And do you think the Democratic Party needs new leadership in Congress? [SEP] Since taking office, I've consistently stated that we welcome China's rise. Their impressive growth has lifted millions out of poverty, benefiting the world and America by allowing China to be a responsible partner and a large market for us, Korea, and other nations. It's positive to see people escape poverty and gain opportunities. However, China's success requires responsible international behavior. The RMB issue is a point of contention, not just for the US, but for many of China's trading partners who compete globally. It's undervalued, and China intervenes significantly to maintain that. We've encouraged China to gradually transition to a market-based system, something they've done before. They also need to shift to a more balanced growth strategy, focusing on their domestic market and empowering their people to consume, boosting their growth and reducing global imbalances. This communique, I believe, signals to China and others that allowing currencies to reflect market fundamentals is the best way to ensure everyone benefits from trade. I expect China to make progress on this. President Hu's visit in January provides an opportunity to continue this progress. This requires adjustments for China, and we understand it won't happen overnight, but it needs addressing, and I'm confident it can be. Regarding Congress, I believe we'll naturally see talented individuals rise to the top with good ideas on jobs, investment, economic growth, and addressing our challenges. Speaker Pelosi has been an outstanding partner, as has Harry Reid in advancing difficult legislation. I look forward to collaborating with the entire leadership team to address the issues that matter to the American people.
label: General

sentence: Regarding birthright citizenship, are you still committed to signing that executive order, sir? [SEP] We'll address that matter later. Please, next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Bush, what specific steps do you believe Africa must take to improve its situation, what kind of leadership do you expect to see emerge, and how will the U.S. assist in this transformation? Also, what are your objectives for this five-nation tour, and how will you ensure continuity in your efforts after you leave office? [SEP] Well, I've been to Africa before, and I'm here to remind people that it's in our interest to help Africa deal with diseases, promote trade, and educate children. Africa has changed for the better, thanks to African leaders. We've helped with conflict resolution and promoted democracy. Our aid program now requires good governance in return for our assistance. I'm confident in the leaders I've met, and I'm glad to be here.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, following China's expulsion of Wall Street Journal reporters, is your administration contemplating reciprocal actions concerning Chinese journalists operating within the United States? [SEP] I'm currently awaiting a full briefing on the matter. We're actively reviewing the situation. I consider their actions unfair, particularly given the access we afford them. We anticipate reaching a decision in the near future.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, considering the economic disparities between the U.S. and nations like Greece, how can your administration justify its economic policies when many Americans feel left behind, especially in light of the austerity measures imposed on Greece by foreign financial institutions? [SEP] Look, it's not exactly a fair comparison, is it? We're talking about the United States, not some little country struggling with debt. When I took office, we were losing jobs faster than you could count 'em. The economy was in freefall. We stepped in, used our brains, and turned things around. The key is to mix things up: fix the system, spend wisely, and get the economy growing. When the economy's booming, you've got more money to pay off debt. Cutting spending when things are bad just makes it worse. Now, we've got the advantage of the dollar being the top dog. People trust us. But the main thing is, we learned from our mistakes. We got back on our feet faster than anyone else. We're putting people back to work and boosting the economy. That's how you fix things for everyone.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. You still expect to meet Kim Jong Un? [SEP] No, no. Listen. Excuse me. Wait.
label: Dodging

sentence: President Obama, there are widespread reports that Chen Guangcheng is currently under U.S. protection. Can you address these reports directly? Furthermore, what specific assurances have you sought from the Chinese government regarding his safety and well-being, and what options are being considered for his long-term future? [SEP] I am, of course, following the news regarding the situation. However, I'm not in a position to offer any specific comments at this time. I will say that human rights are always a topic of discussion with . We believe that is stronger when it respects human rights. We want to see be strong and prosperous. Regarding North Korea, we have been very clear that provocations will only lead to further isolation. We are unified with Japan and South Korea in insisting that North Korea abide by international norms. As for the missile launch, we believe it undermines efforts to achieve resolution through dialogue. We need to call for restraint on the part of D.P.R.K.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Are you open to the possibility of a direct dialogue with Iranian officials? [SEP] Just to be clear, the question is specifically about the potential for direct meetings with representatives from Iran, is that right?
label: Clarification

sentence: Given your export goals and concerns about China's undervalued currency, what specific actions will your administration take to address this currency manipulation and ensure a level playing field for American businesses? [SEP] Well, we need to look at the whole economic relationship. The currency is just one part. When I first met President Hu, we were in a crisis. We needed to rebalance the world economy. That means we need to save more, cut debt, and be more competitive. We need the best education, more engineers, and a better infrastructure. But it also means a level playing field. With China, we need a win-win situation. It's not just about currency. We're making progress on government procurement and intellectual property. Steve Ballmer says only 1 in 10 customers in China pay for Microsoft products. We need better enforcement. China is taking steps, but more needs to be done. The RMB is undervalued. They've spent billions to keep it that way. President Hu says he's committed to a market-based system, but it's not fast enough. It would be good for both countries. They could buy more, and we could export more. He's worried about the transition, but it's the right thing to do.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, do you know if he received an invitation? [SEP] Frankly, I'm not involved in those details. I don't oversee the scheduling of news conferences. However, I can confirm that they maintain a strong working relationship, which is crucial.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Larry Kudlow said that there's a routine check-in call with China on the phase one trade deal. My question is: What if they bring up TikTok and also WeChat? Would you engage—would you instruct your team to engage them on that Executive order you just signed? [SEP] No, we have a deadline of September 15. And whether it's Microsoft, I understand—and others are negotiating—we also said that, obviously, it's worthless if we don't allow them into the country, so we said that the United States Treasury is going to be getting something out of this deal—something very substantial.But what we want is total security, but we have a deadline of September 15. So I know Microsoft and others are very interested in it, but that's our deadline. And it has to be proven to be totally secure. We don't want to have any information going into China with what we've been through.And I have to tell you—you talk about the deal—you mentioned the phase one deal. Well, the phase one deal, it's a very interesting situation because you've been hearing, the largest order of corn in history, the largest order of soybeans, the largest order of beef. They've done more than they've ever done.So you're going to have to figure that one out. With where I'm coming from, I could have—because they see my attitude. My attitude toward China is not friendly. But they have gone into orders that are extremely large, extremely large, and our farmers are very happy.But with what they did with respect to the pandemic, the plague that came in from China, it just is a different feeling. It's an incredible deal, but I have a very different feeling.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, what immediate actions can your administration take to reassure everyone that the US will actually meet its deficit reduction goals in the coming years? [SEP] I apologize. Would you mind repeating the question? And perhaps speak a bit louder into the microphone.
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, President Macron has labeled the Inflation Reduction Act as 'super aggressive' towards European businesses. Are you willing to offer exemptions to European industries to alleviate these concerns? [SEP] Let me address the question I actually heard. The United States makes no apologies for the legislation you're talking about, especially since I wrote it. It's a massive investment in climate change, the largest in history, so there will inevitably be glitches. For example, the provision about free trade agreements was intended to apply to allies, not literally every country with a free trade agreement. We can work these things out. The core principle is ensuring the United States, and hopefully Europe, doesn't have to rely on anyone else's supply chain. We want to be our own supply chain and share that with our allies. There are tweaks we can make to make it easier for European countries to participate or be self-sufficient. It was never my intention to exclude our allies. The goal was to prevent situations like the pandemic, where we couldn't get computer chips because China decided not to sell them to us. We invented those things! So, we're back in business, Europe is back in business, and we're going to create manufacturing jobs in America, but not at the expense of Europe.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, during this trip, you've emphasized state sovereignty as a key principle of international order. How does that align with the 'responsibility to protect' concept, which was once central to aiding victims? [SEP] Excuse me, how do I reconcile that with the 'responsibility to protect,' which used to be... what exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence: Having now surpassed George W. Bush in time served as President during wartime, and potentially concluding your presidency with troops still deployed in Afghanistan, Syria, and Iraq, how do you reconcile this reality with the promises made during your campaign? Furthermore, should the American populace resign itself to a state of perpetual conflict, even if it deviates from the conventional warfare of the 20th century? [SEP] That is indeed a multifaceted question. Firstly, regarding the State Department, I acknowledge the concerns. The exponential growth in information presents a significant challenge. The proliferation of email, text messaging, and smartphones has generated an unprecedented volume of data. While these technologies offer undeniable convenience, enabling real-time access to information previously unavailable to my predecessors, they simultaneously overwhelm the Department's capacity to effectively sort, classify, and secure this information against cyber threats. Overly restrictive classification practices, however, negate the benefits of this enhanced information flow. Secretary Kerry is actively pursuing various initiatives to address these challenges. This issue reflects a broader governmental trend. The volume of Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) requests, and the corresponding volume of responsive information, has increased dramatically. This presents significant challenges across all government agencies, particularly in the realm of national security. We are actively working to mitigate these challenges. Turning to the issue of war, when I assumed office, approximately 180,000 troops were deployed in Iraq and Afghanistan. That number has since been significantly reduced. Our troops are no longer engaged in active combat operations, but rather in training and advisory roles, with the exception of targeted strikes against ISIS in collaboration with Iraqi and Syrian partners. The nature of our military operations has evolved. However, your point regarding non-state actors operating within fragile states is well-taken. Our objective is to partner with these countries to enhance border security and eliminate terrorist threats. This process, as exemplified by Afghanistan, requires sustained commitment. While Afghan forces have become increasingly capable, they continue to require our support. We face a choice between withdrawing, potentially leading to state collapse and subsequent re-intervention, or maintaining a limited partnership to bolster their capacity. The absence of a clear-cut surrender scenario with non-state actors necessitates a hybrid approach, encompassing partnerships, state-building, conflict resolution, local collaboration, and targeted strikes. While interstate warfare has declined, this persistent, low-intensity threat poses a real danger and fuels societal anxieties. We must refine our approach. The release of data on civilian casualties resulting from drone strikes reflects our commitment to accountability. While imperfect, we are striving for continuous improvement. From the NSA to drone operations to Guantanamo, I am confident that my efforts will result in a more legally sound and ethically grounded framework. However, further work remains. This is a matter of constant deliberation. Thank you.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding North Korea's commitment to denuclearization in the document you signed today, how can you ensure they will follow through with action, rather than just making empty promises, a criticism you've often leveled at your predecessors and political opponents? [SEP] Can anyone guarantee anything in this world? Can I guarantee you'll sit up straight the whole time? No way. All I'm saying is they want a deal. That's my specialty. I've always been a dealmaker, a great one at that. I can tell when someone's serious about a deal and when they're not. Most politicians can't, but it's my thing. Honestly, this could've been done a long time ago. But I have a strong feeling – my gut, my talent – they want to make it happen. And a deal is good for everyone, especially China, who can't be thrilled about nukes so close by. China's been a big help. So, I think he's serious. Can I be 100% sure? No, but we'll find out soon enough as negotiations continue. Okay? Thank you. Next question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, two questions: Should President Zelenskyy cede any Ukrainian territory to secure a cease-fire with Russia? And should Russia be removed from the G-20? [SEP] On the G-20 issue, my view is yes, contingent on the consensus of the other members. I proposed that if Indonesia and others object, we should consider allowing both parties to attend the meetings in an observer capacity. Now, could you please repeat your first question?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Calderon, regarding the current situation in the Mexican Congress and the recent political ads comparing Mr. Lopez Obrador to Hitler and Mussolini, what is your opinion? Do you believe this contributes to the unity you've advocated for, especially concerning the energy bill debate in Congress? [SEP] Those comparisons speak volumes about the people making them. Congress is functioning as it should, with responsible participation from various parties. I condemn such tactics, which only damage the reputation of those responsible and undermine the credibility of parties like the PRD. I hope for strengthened institutional integrity and constructive dialogue. The matter of the ads is under investigation, and I trust the electoral authority will make an appropriate decision.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. So you're not negotiating and they say you have to negotiate, and you're not considering another plan B, then do you just wait it out, and we do go—we do see all these things happen? [SEP] Well look, Chuck, there arethere's a pretty straightforward way of doing this, and that is to set the debt ceiling aside, we pay our bills, and then we have a vigorous debate about how we're going to do further deficit reduction in a balanced way.Now, keep in mind that what we've heard from some Republicans in both the House and the Senate is that they will only increase the debt ceiling by the amount of spending cuts that they're able to push through andin order to replace the automatic spending cuts of the sequesterthat's $1.2 trillion. Say it takes another trillion or trillion-two to get us through one more year, they'd have to identify $2.5 trillion in cuts just to get the debt ceiling extended to next year2.5 trillion.They can't evenCongress has not been able to identify $1.2 trillion in cuts that they're happy with. Because these same Republicans say they don't want to cut defense; they've claimed that they don't want to gut Medicare or harm the vulnerable. But the truth of the matter is, is that you can't meet their own criteria without drastically cutting Medicare or having an impact on Medicaid or affecting our defense spending. So the math just doesn't add up.Now, whathere's what would work. What would work would be for us to say we've already done close to $2 trillion in deficit reduction, and if you add the interest that we won't be paying because of less spending and increased revenue, it adds up to about $2.5 trillion. The consensus is we need about $4 trillion to stabilize our debt and our deficit, which means we need about $1.5 trillion more. The package that I offered to Speaker Boehner before webefore the new year would achieve that. We were actually fairly close in terms of arriving at that number.So if the goal is to make sure that we are being responsible about our debt and our deficit, if that's the conversation we're having, I'm happy to have that conversation. And by closing some additional loopholes through tax reformwhich, Speaker Boehner has acknowledged, can raise money in a sensible wayand by doing some additional cuts, including making sure that we are reducing our health care spending, which is the main driver of our deficits, we can arrive at a package that gets this thing done.I'm happy to have that conversation. What I will not do is to have that negotiation with a gun at the head of the American people: the threat that unless we get our way, unless you gut Medicare or Medicaid or otherwise slash things that the American people don't believe should be slashed, that we're going to threaten to wreck the entire economy. That is not how, historically, this has been done. That's not how we're going to do it this time.
label: General

sentence: Q. What does that mean for NAFTA? Will you be pulling out of NAFTA? [SEP] I don't like NAFTA. I never liked it. It's been very bad for the United States. It's been great for Canada. It's been great for Mexico. Very bad for us.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding General Pace's controversial remarks about homosexuality, your silence has been noted. Would you care to share your personal view on whether homosexuality is morally wrong? [SEP] I'm not in the business of issuing moral pronouncements on personal matters. The 'don't ask, don't tell' policy, as it stands, serves our nation's interests effectively. Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, can you clarify the subjects you discussed with him? [SEP] We covered the same ground as the broader conference discussions. We spoke about the importance of stability and ensuring the Southern Hemisphere has access to change. It was a friendly, non-confrontational chat. He approached me and said some things. Thank you all. End of press conference.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the proposed $400 unemployment supplement, you've indicated that states will bear a portion of the cost. Which governors have signaled their willingness to sign on to this agreement? [SEP] Well, if they opt out, that's their decision. However, it will be their constituents who bear the brunt of that decision. I suspect their citizens will be displeased. They have the funds available. So, I anticipate their citizens will be displeased. But if they choose to opt out, that's their decision. Again, the states have the necessary financial resources.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Senator Obama's statements about Iraq, would you characterize them as lacking in experience or understanding? [SEP] Senator Obama needs to concentrate on winning his primary against Senator Clinton. Neither of them has secured their party's nomination. My party's nomination hasn't been decided either. There will be ample time to discuss the positions of whoever their candidate is. Good try, Sheryl. Do you have another question?
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. And as a follow-up to the NATO meeting today, will you suggest to him, or would you consider stopping military exercises in the Baltic States if that's something that he requests? [SEP] Well, perhaps we'll talk about that. But I will say that we are going to be talking about those three issues and many more. We'll be talking about it, Jeff. Okay?Go ahead. Go ahead.
label: General

sentence: Q. Can a package be discussed to allow an assault weapons ban? [SEP] I'll present the details later in the week.Chuck Todd, NBC.

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I wanted to follow up briefly on a question asked by Bloomberg. You said that Russia would be held accountable if it invades and it depends on what it does; it's one thing if it's a minor incursion and . . . we end up having to fight about what to do and what not to do.Are you saying that a minor incursion by Russia into Ukrainian territory would not lead to the sanctions that you have threatened? Or are you effectively giving Putin permission to make a small incursion into the country? [SEP] [] Good question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Can I just ask you also: DHS announced today that it is going to undertake a thorough review of the DACA program to decide whether to continue it, and if not, how to disband it. You had mentioned, after the Supreme Court ruling about DACA, that you were thinking about a path to citizenship for DACA recipients. Are you still thinking about that? [SEP] We're going to work with a lot of people on DACA, and we're also working on an immigration bill, a merit-based system, which is what I've wanted for a long time.That decision was an interesting decision, because it gave the President, as a President, more power than many people thought the President had. So the President is now, which happens to be me, in a position where I can do an immigration bill and a health care bill and some other bills. And you've seen some of them come along.We're going to do tremendous—we just signed it 3 days ago—we're doing tremendous prescription drug price reductions. Tremendous. It could be over 50 percent—whether it's favored nations clauses or anything else. I mean, it's tremendous numbers we're talking about.You know, you go to some countries, and they'll sell, like, a pill for 10 cents, and in the United States, it costs $2. And it's the same basic factory. It's the same everything. The United States bears the cost of all of these low prices that you see all over the world where people go to Canada to buy a prescription drug from the United States. Not going to happen with me. It's not going to happen with me.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Me? Okay. I'd be glad to.[The reporter continued in Turkish, and her question was translated by an interpreter as follows.]Mr. President, about FETÖ, we are not getting the best of news out of the United States. And the FETÖ office targeting Turkey is extensively invested in their daily works, but I can see certain traces that the U.S. Government is ready to understand more about FETÖ.So my question is: How do you perceive the situation developing vis-a-vis the Fethullahist terrorist organization and the American approach to FETÖ in that regard? Can we expect anything further? [SEP] Yes. Thank you. During this current visit, we are going to submit—as we already have, actually—a great deal of documents and evidence. And FETÖ is a terrorist organization, and he is the leader, the ringleader of this terrorist organization. They have killed 251 people in Turkey. They tried to undertake a coup against the Government, the state. And more than 1,000—more than 2,000 people have been injured. And the ringleader is living on an area of 400 acres in the United States, running his network all around the globe, and this is something unacceptable.And during this visit, as I've said before, we have introduced an additional array of documents. We will submit them to the relevant authorities, including Mr. President. And in the light of these documents, I think they will appreciate the situation. We send the terrorists back, if they ask for them, and I'm sure they will do the same for us. John of Fox [John Roberts, Fox News], please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, what legislative challenges do you anticipate if Republicans gain a majority in the House? [SEP] Yes, because it's going to be much closer if they take control.If they take—look, the predictions were—and again, I'm not being critical of anybody who made the predictions. I got it, okay? This was supposed to be a red wave. You guys—you were talking about us losing 30 to 50 seats and this was going to—we're nowhere near—that's not going to happen. And so there's always enough people in the—on the other team, whether it's Democrat or Republican, that the opposite party can make an appeal to and maybe pick them off to get the help. And so it remains to be seen.But look, I doubt whether or not—for example, all the talk—I'd ask the rhetorical—I don't expect you to answer, but the rhetorical question: Do you think that, you know, Senator Johnson is going to move to cut Medicare and Social Security? And if he does, how many Republicans do you think are going to vote for it?So it depends.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, isn't this about more than just 'fixing problems'? Was the seizure justified? Does the AG have your full support? And are you concerned about the Nixon comparisons? [SEP] My concern is the safety of our troops and intelligence officers. Leaks undermine their missions. The media shield law is an attempt to balance that with the public's right to know.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Madam President, Brazil sees itself as a global leader, while the U.S. views it as a regional one. How do you bridge this gap in perception? [SEP] Well, let me address the President's question too. We don't see Brazil as just regional; it's global. Look at the G-20, a major economic forum – Brazil's a key voice. The Paris climate talks need Brazil's leadership. Their renewable energy goals show that leadership. Brazil's a major global player. I told President Dilma we can't solve global issues alone. Global health? We need Brazil to prevent pandemics. Climate change, terrorism, poverty – all need Brazil. They're indispensable.I trust President Dilma completely. She's always been honest about Brazil's interests. She delivers on promises. The defense agreements we discussed in Panama? She got them through Congress – no easy feat. That shows she's reliable.This meeting builds on deeper cooperation. Differences will exist, but that's true of all allies. Common values, strong ties, similar histories – we should be strong partners.Part of my answer was given by [Obama], thanks. Countries face crises. That shouldn't diminish their role. A great country overcomes difficulties. That applies to countries, people, everything. It applies to US-Brazil relations. We have much in common. We both fought to overcome slavery. We have large Black populations, multicultural societies. These are assets.We're strong democracies. I congratulated [Obama] for overcoming the 2008 crisis. Brazil will overcome its current crisis. We'll do it decisively, with commitment.We'll resume growth and protect our gains of the last 12 years. We'll build a middle-class country. Reducing inequality is a major gain, and we must preserve it.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, the Iraq War led to significant loss of life, instability in the region, and a rise in extremism. How do you reconcile these consequences with your claim that the war was justified and made the world safer? [SEP] War is never easy. It's always difficult. But we had to act. We had to defend America. And we did what we believed was right. And we will continue to work with our allies to promote peace and stability in the Middle East.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Are you concerned that—about the legality of these Executive orders? [SEP] No, not at all.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. So not a full red line? [SEP] Look, I believe this is solvable. I think that fair-minded people can come to an agreement that does not cause the economy to go back into recession, that protects middle class families, that focuses on jobs and growth, and reduces our deficit. I'm confident it can be done.My budget, frankly, does it. I understand that—I don't expect the Republicans simply to adopt my budget. That's not realistic. So I recognize that we're going to have to compromise. And as I said on election night, compromise is hard and not everybody gets 100 percent of what they want and not everybody is going to be perfectly happy.But what I will not do is to have a process that is vague, that says we're going to sort of, kind of, raise revenue through dynamic scoring or closing loopholes that have not been identified. And the reason I won't do that is because I don't want to find ourselves in a position 6 months from now or a year from now where, lo and behold, the only way to close the deficit is to sock it to middle class families or to burden families that have disabled kids or have a parent in a nursing home, or suddenly, we've got to cut more out of our basic research budget that is the key to growing the economy in the long term.So that's my concern. I'm less concerned about red lines per se. What I'm concerned about is not finding ourselves in a situation where the wealthy aren't paying more or aren't paying as much as they should, middle class families one way or another are making up the difference. That's the kind of status quo that has been going on here too long, and that's exactly what I argued against during this campaign. And if there's one thing that I'm pretty confident about is the American people understood what they were getting when they gave me this incredible privilege of being in office for another 4 years.They want compromise. They want action. But they also want to make sure that middle class folks aren't bearing the entire burden and sacrifice when it comes to some of these big challenges. They expect that folks at the top are doing their fair share as well. And that's going to be my guiding principle during these negotiations, but more importantly, during the next 4 years of my administration.Nancy Cordes [CBS News].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. You and Prime Minister Gillard have outlined what is for us a significant new U.S. troop buildup. How much of this is because you're worried about the rise of China? And as of today's deal, U.S. Marines will be for the first time conducting exercises by themselves on Australian soil. Why is that, and what will they be doing?And, Mr. President, you also mentioned in your remarks that Afghanistan is not an easy mission. In the past few months, there have been three cases for Australia where our troops have been shot at by the Afghan soldiers who have been training, and sadly, four of our soldiers have died, and many others have been injured. Australian public opinion is strongly against our involvement continuing. You outlined the--just then, the drawdown. What can you say to the Australian people who don't want to wait, who want to leave immediately? [SEP] Well, first, with respect to these new initiatives, this rotational deployment is significant because what it allows us to do is to not only build capacity and cooperation between our two countries, but it also allows us to meet the demands of a lot of partners in the region that want to feel that they're getting the training, they're getting the exercises, and that we have the presence that's necessary to maintain the security architecture in the region.And so, as Julia mentioned, this is a region that's becoming increasingly important. The economy in this area is going to be the engine for world economic growth for some time to come. The lines of commerce and trade are constantly expanding. And it's appropriate then for us to make sure that not only our alliance, but the security architecture of the region is updated for the 21st century, and this initiative is going to allow us to do that.It also allows us to respond to a whole host of challenges, like humanitarian or disaster relief, that frankly, given how large the Asia-Pacific region is, it can sometimes be difficult to do, and this will allow us to be able to respond in a more timely fashion and also equip a lot of countries, smaller countries who may not have the same capacity, it allows us to equip them so that they can respond more quickly as well.And I guess the last part of your question, with respect to China, I've said repeatedly and I will say again today that we welcome a rising, peaceful China. What they've been able to achieve in terms of lifting hundreds of millions of people out of poverty over the last two decades has been nothing short of remarkable. And that is good not just for China, but it's potentially good for the region. And I know Australia's economy obviously has benefited by the increased demand that you're seeing in China.The main message that I've said not only publicly, but also privately to the Chinese is that with their rise comes increased responsibilities. It's important for them to play by the rules of the road and in fact help underwrite the rules that have allowed so much remarkable economic progress to be made over the last several decades. And that's going to be true on a whole host of issues.So where China is playing by those rules, recognizing its new role, I think this is a win-win situation. There are going to be times where they're not, and we will send a clear message to them that we think that they need to be on track in terms of accepting the rules and responsibilities that come with being a world power.With respect to Afghanistan, the impact of any loss of life among our troops is heartbreaking. And obviously, as President of the United States, there's no greater responsibility and nothing more difficult than putting our troops in harm's way. I think Prime Minister Gillard feels the same way that I do, which is we would not be sending our young men and women into harm's way unless we thought it was absolutely necessary for the security of our country.What we have established is a transition process that allows Afghans to build up their capacity and take on a greater security role over the next 2 years. But it's important that we do it right. As some of you are aware, I just announced that all remaining troops in Iraq will be removed. It would have been tempting, given that I have been opposed to the Iraq war from the start, when I came into office, to say, we're going to get you all out right away. But what I recognized was that if we weren't thoughtful about how we proceed, then the enormous sacrifices that had been made by our men and women in the previous years might be for naught.And what I'd say to the Australian people at this point is, given the enormous investment that's been made and the signs that we can, in fact, leave behind a country that's not perfect, but one that is more stable, more secure, and does not provide safe haven for terrorists, it's appropriate for us to finish the job and do it right. If I could just add to that and say, every time I have met President Obama and we've talked about our alliance, we've talked about our work in Afghanistan, and in our meetings, both formal and informal, the President has shown the greatest possible concern for our troops in the field. Now, the meetings we've had over the last few weeks at various international events have coincided with some of the most bitter and difficult news that we've had from Afghanistan, and every step of the way the President has gone out of his way to convey to me his condolences for the Australian people and particularly for the families that have suffered such a grievous loss. Laura MacInnis, Reuters.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, following Netanyahu's confirmation of the Israeli bombing raid in Syria, can you tell us the target, share your opinion on the strike, and evaluate its implications for the tense regional context involving Syria, Iran, and Israel, as well as the potential for U.S. intervention? [SEP] I cannot provide any information on that topic. What's your next question?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, you and the G-7 proposed an oil price cap on Russian exports to combat high gas prices. Are you confident this will reduce prices for American drivers? How long should they expect to pay a premium due to the war? [SEP] Remind me, what was the second part of the question? Was it about whether it would bring down the price?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, to follow on Chip's question, you said that the Speaker faces tough politics in his caucus. Do you have complete confidence that he can deliver the votes on anything that he agrees to? Is he in control of his caucus? [SEP] That's a question for the Speaker, not a question for me. My experience with John Boehner is--has been good. I think he's a good man who wants to do right by the country. I think that it's a--as Chip alluded to, the politics that swept him into the Speakership were good for a midterm election; they're tough for governing. And part of what the Republican caucus generally needs to recognize is that American democracy works when people listen to each other, we're willing to give each other the benefit of the doubt, we assume the patriotism and good intentions of the other side, and we're willing to make some sensible compromises to solve big problems. And I think that there are members of that caucus who haven't fully arrived at that realization yet.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: So, Mr. President, is ceding Ukrainian territory a viable option for a ceasefire with Russia, and should Russia be expelled from the G-20? [SEP] Regarding the G-20, the answer is yes, but it hinges on the group's stance. I brought it up earlier. If Indonesia and others object, perhaps we should consider allowing both parties to attend as observers. Now, remind me of the first part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you. This is a question for both of you. First, what is your reaction to Turkey shooting down a Russian plane today? And does this draw NATO into a confrontation with Russia? How do you keep this from spiraling out of control?And, President Obama, what does this incident mean for future prospects of military coordination—more military coordination with Russia? And, President Hollande, ahead of your trip to Moscow on Thursday, what are the prospects for closer military coordination with Russia, given what happened today? [SEP] Good Well, first of all, we're still getting the details of what happened And I expect to be in communications, potentially directly, with President Erdogan sometime over the next several daysTurkey, like every country, has a right to defend its territory and its airspace I think it's very important right now for us to make sure that both the Russians and the Turks are talking to each other to find out exactly what happened and take measures to discourage any kind of escalationI do think that this points to a ongoing problem with the Russian operations in the sense that they are operating very close to a Turkish border and they are going after a moderate opposition that are supported by not only Turkey, but a wide range of countries And if Russia is directing its energies towards Daesh and ISIL, some of those conflicts, or potentials for mistakes or escalation, are less likely to occurI also think this underscores the importance of us making sure that we move this political track forward as quickly as possible Like President Hollande, our view from the start has been that Russia is welcome to be part of this broad-based coalition that we've set up There's never been a point in time in which we said that we don't want Russia or other countries that may have differences with us on a whole host of other things to avoid working with us against ISILThe challenge has been Russia's focus on propping up Asad rather than focusing on ISIL I had a conversation with President Putin in Turkey, and I indicated to him at the time that to the extent that they make that strategic shift—focus on the Vienna process, where they have been constructive, to try to bring all the parties together; try to execute a political transition that all parties would agree to; and refocus attention on going after ISIL—then there's enormous capacity for us to cooperateUntil that happens, it's very difficult It's difficult because if their priority is attacking the moderate opposition that might be future members of an inclusive Syrian Government, Russia is not going to get the support of us or a range of other members of the coalitionBut I do think that there is the possibility of cooperation The sooner we agree to this political process, the less likely that you have the kinds of events that took place, apparently, today President Hollande The event that took place is a serious one, and we can only regret it Turkey is currently providing all of the information to NATO so that we can find out what truly happened and whether Turkey's airspace indeed was entered into But we must prevent an escalation; that would be extremely damageable The only purpose is to fight against terrorism and Daesh This is what we must do, all of us: we, Turkey, RussiaAnd what just took place, like Barack said, means that we must find a solution to the Syrian crisis, because we can see what the risks are otherwise: the risks of escalation I, therefore, will be traveling to Russia this week because we have this resolution of the Security Council, and it does show that we must take action against Daesh, against terrorism That resolution has been voted unanimously In a way, that was the broadest possible coalitionThen, I will ask President Putin, as I've done before and what I told the Russians a number of times already, that the strikes must be against Daesh, against terrorism, and those who precisely are threatening us They are threatening the Russians, like ourselves in Europe, like France that was targeted over the past few days We must, therefore, coordinate ourselves, cooperate, but on that basis, and make sure that we're all acting against Daesh And that will be part of the political process, one that must lead to the solution And we all know what the parameters of the solution are or are not We know that there's a deadlock todayLastly, I mentioned the aircraft carrier, which is in the east of the Mediterranean now As a matter of fact, there are also some Russian forces And I, therefore, agreed with President Putin that we must share our intelligence so that we can act in coordination We must not contradict ourselves And it's already the case, and we'll continue to do so[]
label: General

sentence: Q. Sir, are you at all concerned about that? [SEP] I've said all I intend to on that matter. Mary Bruce, ABC News, the floor is yours.

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the oil price cap initiative: Do you believe it will effectively reduce gasoline prices for American consumers, and for how long will they likely bear the financial burden of this conflict? sentence: Sir, the intelligence community has presented evidence of potential election interference from both Russia and China. How do you reconcile this with your previous statements, and what specific actions will your administration take to safeguard the integrity of the election? [SEP] Look, it's a complex situation. Could be happening, could not be. We're looking at all possibilities. But let me tell you, nobody wants to see me out of office more than certain foreign powers. We're on top of it.

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that you're deliberately undermining the Postal Service to suppress voting. How do you respond to that? [SEP] That's just fake news. I want a fair and honest election. But universal mail-in voting is a recipe for fraud and chaos. The Democrats know it, but they're pushing it anyway because they think it will help them win. I'm just trying to protect the integrity of the election. And Louis DeJoy is doing a great job cleaning up the mess at the Postal Service.

sentence: With all due respect, Mr. President, people are dying. When will testing be widely available? [SEP] We're doing everything we can. The Governors are very happy with the progress. We're working day and night to get tests to everyone who needs them.

sentence: Q. Would you support an investigation, sir? [SEP] Sure. Sure.

sentence: Mr. President, given your past pronouncements regarding Iran and Syria, specifically your designation of Iran as part of the 'axis of evil' and Syria as a state sponsor of terrorism, and in light of your stated openness to any strategy that ensures victory, would you be amenable to collaborating with these nations if their assistance proved indispensable to achieving success in Iraq? [SEP] It is the global expectation that Iran and Syria will contribute constructively to the stabilization of Iraq, a point we have articulated with utmost clarity. Regarding Iran, our concerns are multifaceted and profound. The primary question is whether they will facilitate the success of Iraq's nascent democratic institutions. Secondly, their support for the Lebanese democracy, specifically the Siniora Government, is of paramount importance to this administration. However, the most pressing issue remains Iran's potential acquisition of nuclear weapons. Our position is unequivocal: a path of cooperation, not isolation, is in the best interests of both the Iranian government and its people. We will continue to emphasize that their support for terrorism and pursuit of nuclear weapons will only lead to further isolation from the international community. Our diplomatic efforts are ongoing, and the Iranian government is fully cognizant of our position on Iraq, as is the Iraqi government itself. We are committed to supporting the sovereignty and stability of Iraq, and the Iraqi government has conveyed to Iran the imperative of non-interference in their internal affairs. Concerning Syria, our message remains consistent: refrain from undermining the Siniora Government in Lebanon, facilitate the return of the Israeli prisoner captured by Hamas, prevent Hamas and Hezbollah from plotting attacks against democracies in the Middle East, and contribute to stability within Iraq. They are fully aware of our position.
label: General

sentence: President, what's the European perspective on your abrupt decision to pull out of Syria? [SEP] As I stated before regarding Syria, my concern is with my country's stance. I won't comment on other countries' actions, but we unequivocally condemn Turkey's recent behavior. Is that clear enough?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Would you agree to an interview with the Special Counsel or the legal team who is advising him? [SEP] Excuse me, excuse me. The whole Russia thing was an excuse for the Democrats losing the election, and it turns out to be just one excuse. I mean, today Hillary blamed Nigel Farage. That one came out of nowhere. So that was just an excuse for the Democrats losing an election that, frankly, they have a big advantage in the electoral college. They should always be able to win in the electoral college, but they were unable to do it.So there has been absolutely no collusion. It's been stated that they have no collusion. They ought to get to the end of it, because I think the American public is sick of it.Go ahead.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, given the concerns about potential abuses of power, what steps are you taking to ensure transparency and accountability within the Justice Department? We're providing training and resources to ensure that our employees understand their ethical obligations. We're also cooperating fully with any investigations into potential wrongdoing.

sentence: Q. But they should still have that public guarantee then? [SEP] You know, there is an implicit guarantee, as you said. They ought to be focusing on the missions they're expected to do. sentence: President Biden, your administration has pledged to reduce carbon emissions and combat climate change. However, some critics argue that your policies are not ambitious enough to meet the urgency of the crisis. What specific steps are you taking to accelerate the transition to a clean energy economy, and how do you address concerns about the economic impact of these policies? [SEP] We're committed to tackling the climate crisis with the seriousness it deserves. We're investing in clean energy technologies, rejoining the Paris Agreement, and setting ambitious emissions reduction targets. We see climate action as an opportunity to create jobs and build a more sustainable economy. We're working with businesses, labor unions, and communities to ensure a just transition.

sentence: Mr. President, critics suggest the video gives Kim Jong Un legitimacy by showing you as equals. Is that a fair assessment? [SEP] Look, I don't see it that way. Remember the Olympics? They made it a success by participating. So, if this meeting can save lives, it's an honor for me to be there, building a relationship with a powerful leader who controls a country with nuclear weapons.

sentence: Q. I've been saving them up. First of all, Republican Leader Kevin McCarthy said last night that, It is clear we are going to take the House back. sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Prime Minister, I hope you'll also indulge me with two questions, since I'm far from home. Currently, based upon the joint statement of September, Minister Motegi and Ambassador Lighthizer are discussing and talking about this matter.So we agreed to accelerate the talk as such; that was the agreement I reached with .

sentence: In light of your acknowledgment that the timing of North Korea's willingness to negotiate remains uncertain, would the United States contemplate augmenting sanctions and intensifying pressure on North Korea to facilitate progress? [SEP] I prefer not to offer any commentary on that matter at this time. Our existing sanctions regime is already quite comprehensive. I am hesitant to discuss the possibility of escalating sanctions further. They are already substantial. It is important to remember that there are many good people in North Korea who also have lives to lead. My personal perspective evolved considerably after developing a rapport with Chairman Kim. They possess their own distinct point of view. I sincerely hope that, for the sake of , Japan, and indeed, even —I recently engaged in discussions with President Xi, a figure widely respected—I conveyed that it is untenable to have a nuclear state in such close proximity. And he concurs. He, too, desires a resolution to this issue.

sentence: Mr. President, considering the substantial financial resources allocated to economic recovery, what specific benchmarks should the public use to evaluate the effectiveness of your policies? Should they prioritize stock market performance, housing market stability, or employment rates, and when should they anticipate seeing measurable improvements, or will contingency plans be implemented? We also need to fix the credit markets so businesses can get the loans they need. And we need to stabilize the housing market, working with the Fed and the FDIC to prevent foreclosures and support housing values. The most important thing is that we stop losing jobs and start growing again. It's going to be a tough year, but I'm hopeful that we'll see progress next year. Next question, please.

sentence: Mr. President, what is the official position of the United States regarding the recognition of [Country]? [SEP] I would direct your attention to the Ahtisaari plan for guidance.
