Having said that, I'm not going to give them a pass when it comes to the central Government's reconciliation efforts.I also said in my speech, local politics will drive national politics. And I believe that. I believe that as more reconciliation takes place at the local level, you'll see a more responsive central Government.Yes. Axelrod [Jim Axelrod, CBS News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, looking at Venezuela, what are the potential unintended consequences of escalating sanctions, and how are you preparing to address them? [SEP] We're carefully considering all the potential consequences of our actions. We're working with our allies and partners to develop a comprehensive strategy that addresses the humanitarian crisis and promotes a peaceful resolution to the political crisis. We're also prepared to adjust our approach as needed, based on the evolving situation on the ground.
label: General

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, the data suggests the US has struggled with the pandemic. Are you saying Dr. Birx's assessment was inaccurate? [SEP] The fake news media only focuses on the negative. We've made tremendous progress! We have vaccines coming, therapeutics are working, and our economy is roaring back. We're rounding the corner, folks. Dr. Birx is a good person, but she gets pressured by the Democrats. They're always trying to undermine our success.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding a potential conversation with President Putin, what's your approach? And with the Ukrainian war at a possible turning point, do you believe President Zelenskyy's insistence on Crimea's return before negotiations is realistic? [SEP] Look, there's one rational way this war concludes: Putin withdraws from Ukraine, period. But that doesn't seem to be happening. He's paying a heavy price for his failure, yet he's inflicting incredible carnage on Ukrainian civilians, bombing nurseries, hospitals, children's homes. It's sickening. That being said, I have no immediate plans to contact Mr. Putin. Let me choose my words carefully: I'm prepared to speak with Mr. Putin if he demonstrates a genuine interest in finding a way to end this war. He hasn't done so yet. If that occurs, in consultation with our allies, I'll gladly sit down with him to explore his intentions. But he hasn't taken that step. In the meantime, it's crucial that we support the Ukrainian people. The notion that Putin can defeat Ukraine is beyond comprehension. Imagine attempting to occupy that country for years to come. He's miscalculated at every turn. He believed he'd be welcomed by Russian speakers.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President, you campaigned on unifying the country and accomplishing big things. Many observers see these as conflicting goals, given the current political climate. Is it truly possible to achieve both simultaneously, and if so, how? [SEP] It's not only possible, it's essential. We must strive for both unity and progress. As long as I'm privileged to serve, I'll dedicate myself to finding that balance.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, despite sanctions and aid, Maduro remains in power in Venezuela. Are you concerned about losing momentum, and what's the projected timeline for a resolution? [SEP] The situation in Venezuela is dire, a true tragedy. We're exploring all options, including tougher sanctions. We're committed to supporting the Venezuelan people and ensuring they have access to food, medicine, and other essential supplies. It's a complex situation, and it's difficult to predict how long it will take to resolve. But we're not giving up.
label: General

sentence: Q. Which way are you leaning? [SEP] I would say we love them both. I love Gettysburg but it's—this is simpler. It would be magnificent. The White House is a—the White House is the White House. Gettysburg is one of the great and historic sites of our country—frankly as far as I'm concerned of the world. So one of those two. I'll probably be announcing it over the next week or so maybe less.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, can you just give us the names? It's a simple question. [SEP] With all due respect, I'm not going to play that game. I'm not going to compromise my principles just to satisfy your curiosity. The answer is no, and I think that should be respected.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I have a question for the Prime Minister as well. Mr. President, under what—you've said repeatedly that you are willing to walk away from the negotiations if they don't do well. Under what exact conditions would you be walking away from that summit? And if the summit does go well, will you be inviting North Korean leader Kim Jong Un to the United States? [SEP] Well, the answer is yes to the second part of your question. But certainly, if it goes well. And I think it would be well received. I think he would look at it very favorably. So I think that could happen.All I can say is, I am totally prepared to walk away. I did it once before. You have to be able to walk away. If you're not going to be able to walk away—we didn't walk away from the horrible Iran deal that was signed. And if you look at what's happened since I signed that deal, Iran—and in all fairness, I say it with great respect for the people of Iran—but Iran is acting a lot differently. They're no longer looking so much to the Mediterranean. They're no longer looking so much to what's going on in Syria, what's going on in Yemen and lots of other places. They're a much different country over the last 3 months.And again, I say that with hope that maybe something can happen. But when you mention sanctions, we're putting sanctions on Iran, the likes of which nobody has ever seen before, including, frankly, . That would have been the next phase, if we did it or find it necessary to do.But nuclear to me is always first. And we're going to be fine, with respect to Iran. But we also, Saagar, got something out of it that's very important. A lot of the people that write about this, some of whom I have great respect for, but they haven't picked it up: Iran is not the same country that it was a few months ago. They're a much, much different group of leaders. And I hope at some point they'll come to us and we'll sit down and we'll make a deal that's good for them and good for us and good for everybody. And it will be great for Iran. I expect it to be—I want it to be—great for Iran.But if they would have walked—our side—from some of the horrible provisions that you know as well as I do, and probably everybody sitting here knows, we could have had a great deal. Nothing wrong with a deal, but there's something wrong with that deal. We had a great opportunity to make a phenomenal deal.So I am totally prepared to walk. It could happen. Maybe it won't be necessary. I hope it won't be necessary to walk because I really believe that Kim Jong Un wants to do something that is going to be great for his people and also great for his family and great for himself.Okay? Thank you very much.Chairman of the State Affairs Commission Kim Jong Un of
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, regarding Mayor Bowser's recent order, which, admittedly, doesn't apply to Federal land, will you advise Federal properties, including the White House and military bases, to adhere to it? [SEP] We're considering all options and will make a determination in the next 24 hours. We'll keep you posted.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, to be clear, is your position that individuals holding opinions contrary to your own should be subject to legal action? [SEP] It's not about disagreeing. It's about outright falsehoods. When someone deliberately spreads misinformation, especially when it causes harm, then we'll let the legal process run its course. It's about holding people accountable for what they say.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Senator McConnell's recent statement on the CARES II relief package, he claims it's perfectly tailored for the current crisis, yet it omits your proposed payroll tax cut. In light of this, do you still consider the package perfectly tailored to address the needs of the American people? [SEP] Look, I'm a big fan of the payroll tax cut. It would be a tremendous benefit to the American worker. However, the Democrats have made it clear that they are opposed to it. They don't seem to prioritize the needs of the working class. So, last night, I informed the Republicans – who have been working tirelessly on this package and are committed to doing what's right for the country – that while I believe a payroll tax cut would be beneficial, it's unlikely to gain Democratic support. As you know, we need their votes to pass this legislation. While we hold a majority, it's not sufficient to overcome their opposition. That's why we have an election coming up. So, we need to secure Democratic votes, and it's clear that we won't get them on this issue. I believe it would be a significant boost for the American worker. But if we can't secure their support, we must move forward. A payroll tax cut would have been a real game-changer. Perhaps something will materialize in the future.
label: Implicit

sentence: And when is the final deadline for Kosovo's declaration of independence, sir? [SEP] A what, now?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. I had a question to President Duda. After the meeting that you have had today at the White House, do you have the feeling that the probability that Polish expectations concerning permanent American presence in our country are closer to being implemented? Are they going to be a fact? [SEP] Ladies and gentlemen, today, myself and Mr. President had a tête-à-tête meeting, a private meeting, and then we met also with our staff. We had long conversations, very honest discussions, and very strong at certain points, as well, in terms of diagnosis of the situation in the area of military security and energy security alike.And I am convinced that all of us are going to draw appropriate conclusions from these discussions. Because as I said, both sides presented their positions in many—absolutely many elements. They are concurrent—as far as the assessment of the situation currently is—what kind of steps need to be taken in order to protect both the issue of security and the issue of interests. These are business-related issues.I am convinced that, ladies and gentlemen, you are going to see the results of both our meetings today and of the declaration that we have signed together with Mr. President. Of course, we are talking about long-term processes, so I'm sure that you are going to see how this is going to be filled with content. And you will see concrete facts that will appear on the maps and also in agreements and in purchases that are going to be realized. Jon Decker of Fox, please.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, will you still sign that executive order on birthright citizenship, as you previously stated? [SEP] That's a question for another time. Let's move on.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. ——and hosting next year's G-7 at your property. What reassurances, if any, can you give the American people that you are not looking to profit off the Presidency? [SEP] Well, I'll tell you what: I've spent—and I think I will, in a combination of loss and opportunity, probably, it will cost me anywhere from three to five billion dollars to be President. And the only thing I care about is this country. Couldn't care less. Otherwise, I wouldn't have done it.People have asked me, What do you think it costs? And between opportunity, not doing things—I used to get a lot of money to make speeches. Now I give speeches all the time. You know what I get? Zippo. And that's good. And I did a lot of great jobs and great deals that I don't do anymore. And I don't want to do them, because the deals I'm making are great deals for the country. And that's, to me, much more important.Doral happens to be within Miami. It's a city. It's a wonderful place. It's a very, very successful area of Florida. It's, very importantly, only 5 minutes from the airport; the airport is right next door. It's a big international airport, one of the biggest in the world. Everybody that's coming—all of these people with all of their big entourages come. It's set up so—and, by the way, my people looked at 12 sites. All good, but some were 2 hours from an airport. Some were 4 hours from—I mean, they were so far away. Some didn't allow this, or they didn't allow that.With Doral, we have a series of magnificent buildings; we call them bungalows. They each hold from 50 to 70 very luxurious rooms with magnificent views. We have incredible conference rooms, incredible restaurants. It's like—it's like such a natural—we wouldn't even have to do the work that they did here. And they've done a beautiful job. They've really done a beautiful job.And what we have also is Miami. And we have many hundreds of acres, so that in terms of parking, in terms of all of the things that you need, the ballrooms are among the biggest in Florida and the best. It's brandnew. And they want—my people wanted it. From my standpoint, I'm not going to make any money. In my opinion, I'm not going to make any money. I don't want to make money. I don't care about making money. If I wanted to make money, I wouldn't worry about $3 billion to $5 billion. Because that's what—I mean, at some point, I'm going to detail that and will show.But I think it's just a great place to be. I think having it in Miami is fantastic. Really fantastic. Having it at that particular place, because of the way it's set up, each country can have their own villa, or their own bungalow. And the bungalows, when I say, they have a lot of units in them. So I think it just works out well.And when my people came back, they took tours, they went to different places. I won't mention places, but you'll have a list, because they're going to give a presentation on it fairly soon. They went to places all over the country. And they came back, and they said, This is where we'd like it to be. Now, we had military people doing it. We had Secret Service people doing it. We had people that really understand what it's about. It's not about me, it's about getting the right location. I think it's very important.Jonathan.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, you're facing a rebellion from Republican—key Republican Senators who want you to change course and begin reducing the U.S. combat role. Given the mixed report that you present today, how do you persuade Republicans to stick with you as they look ahead to the next elections? [SEP] A couple of things—first of all, I respect those Republicans that you're referring to. I presume you're referring to friends of mine, like Lugar—or Senator Lugar, Domenici, yes. These are good, honorable people. I've spoken to them, and I listen very carefully to what they have to say.First of all, they share my concern that a precipitous withdrawal would embolden Al Qaida. And they also understand that we can't let Al Qaida gain safe haven inside of Iraq. I appreciate their calls, and I appreciate their desire to work with the White House to be in a position where we can sustain a presence in Iraq.What I tell them is this—just what I've told you—is that as the Commander in Chief of the greatest military ever, I have an obligation, a sincere and serious obligation, to hear out my commander on the ground. And I will take his recommendation and—as I mentioned—to talk to Bob Gates about it, as well as the Joint Chiefs about it, as well as consult with Members of the Congress, both Republicans and Democrats, as I make a decision about the way forward in Iraq.And so I—you know, I value the advice of those Senators. I appreciate their concerns about the situation in Iraq, and I am going to continue listening to them.Toby [Tabassum Zakaria, Reuters].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the financial market turmoil, do you expect housing prices to continue falling? Will the difficulty in obtaining loans impact the broader economy? And what measures are you prepared to take, including potential government bailouts for homeowners at risk of losing their homes? [SEP] David, I'm not an economist, so I'll leave the specific economic forecasts to the experts. My focus is on the underlying strengths of our economy, and I believe people will make rational choices based on the facts. We have strong job creation, rising real wages, and low inflation. The global economy is also strong, which benefits our exports and growth. The liquidity in the system is a key factor, and I'm told it's sufficient for market corrections. We must show compassion for those facing home loss. Regarding 'bailouts,' if you mean direct grants to homeowners, I don't support that. But ensuring that financial institutions like the FHA have the flexibility to help people refinance, I do support that. We also need greater transparency in financial documents and improved financial literacy. Many hardworking Americans signed up for loans without fully understanding the terms. Government should enhance financial education initiatives, and we're already investing in that.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, critics suggest your administration's response to the current health crisis is akin to fiddling while Rome burns. You previously downplayed the severity, referring to it as 'little fires.' How do you address the perception that the situation is far more serious than you initially portrayed? [SEP] Look, we're dealing with a few flare-ups, that's all. Some states are doing great, others, not so much. Florida's got a terrific governor, Texas too. They're smart people, they'll figure it out. We're giving them all the resources they need. The hospitals are doing fine, and we're working with them to make sure they have everything they need. It's really not as bad as the fake news media makes it out to be.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, Valentinovna from Sputnik News Agency. During your negotiations, did you discuss the possibility of inspections at North Korea's nuclear facilities? [SEP] Could you please speak up? And remind me, which news organization are you with?
label: Clarification

sentence: Chancellor Scholz, beyond aspirations, what concrete steps is Germany undertaking to mitigate its reliance on Russian energy? And how do you respond to critics who argue that Germany's dependence on Russian gas compromises Europe's ability to effectively address the situation in Ukraine? Mr. President, your thoughts? [SEP] Let me jump in. We're looking at ways to replace lost Russian gas with LNG, working with allies. Russia needs to sell that gas and oil; it's a big part of their budget. If cut off, they'll be hurt too. It's not just one-way. We're working to help compensate for lost gas in Europe. We're ready for anything, preparing sanctions. On LNG, most is gas. We'll modernize our economy and switch to hydrogen faster than people think. Thank you.
label: General

sentence: Concerning the Israeli-Palestinian situation: President Bush, given your intervention in Iraq over UN resolutions, why not demand Israel's compliance with similar resolutions regarding Palestine, thus fostering peace and ending the occupation? And President Abbas, did you ask President Bush to push for a complete settlement freeze to allow for productive talks? [SEP] Yes, but could you clarify the specific point you were making about the UN? I want to make sure I understand your argument.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Welcome, Mr. President.Mr. President, to start with you: Your advisers often talk about how important—how critically important—you view face-to-face interaction. I'm wondering, after spending 2-plus hours face to face with President Zelenskyy, what you learned or what you took from the meeting that perhaps you couldn't glean or learn in the phone calls or videoconferences.And somewhat tied to that, was there any discussion related to the U.S. assessments that Russia would not take escalatory action now that Patriots are being sent, will be delivered—a Patriot battery will be delivered? [SEP] Let me answer the first question—the first part of your question. You know, I get kidded for saying that there's—all politics is personal. It's all about looking someone in the eye. And I mean it sincerely.I don't think there's any, any, any substitute for sitting down face to face with a friend or a foe and looking them in the eye. And that's exactly what's happening at this moment. We've done that more than once, and we're going to continue to do it.And the winter is setting in, and Putin is increasingly going after civilian targets and women and children, orphanages. This guy is—well—but he's going to fail. And he's going to fail. He's already failed, because he now knows that there's no way he's ever going to occupy all of Ukraine. There's no way in which he's going to be accepted by the Ukrainian people.And so he's failed in the past. And it was very important for him and everyone else to see that President Zelenskyy and I are united, two countries together, to make sure he cannot succeed.And I think—I may be mistaken, but I know—I judge every leader by the way they—what they say to me, their consistency, and looking me in the eye.This guy——[]——has in his—to his very soul is who he says he is. It's clear who he is. He's willing to give his life for his country and all the folks who are with—came with him today.And so I think it's—he—it's important for him to know we are going to do everything in our power—everything in our power—to see that he succeeds.[] Thank you so much. What was the second part of your question?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, some observers believe you deliberately avoided discussing gun violence during your first term and in 2012. You supported renewing the ban on semiautomatic rifles, but did little else. Where have you been on this issue? [SEP] Jake, I've been President, dealing with the worst economic crisis since the Depression, the auto industry's near collapse, and two wars. I haven't been idle. We all need to reflect on our priorities. Keeping our children safe should be paramount. I'm committed to doing everything we can to achieve that. It involves many things: healthcare, education, jobs for parents. These aren't side issues. But gun violence is central. That's why I trust Joe will take this seriously. Thank you.
label: General

sentence: So, what exactly is it that you're after? [SEP] Look, it's a total witch hunt, a disgrace to our country. We've got the head of the World Trade Organization here, and he has to listen to this garbage about a perfect call. Nobody ever mentions the transcription, nobody ever talks about the call itself, because there's nothing there. Read it! Somebody should just read the call! Everyone would say, 'That's an impeachable offense?' If that were impeachable, Lyndon Johnson and Kennedy would have been out of office on day one. It's a hoax, plain and simple. You know it's a hoax better than anyone. Go ahead, next question.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify, do you still consider climate change a hoax, or has your position evolved? [SEP] Let me be clear, I never said it was a complete hoax. Some aspects of it are, let's say, overblown. The numbers are manipulated. We're working to have the cleanest air and water, and frankly, our numbers are fantastic. But you know, other countries aren't doing their part. They're polluting the world. Greta should be talking to them. We have a beautiful ocean, the Pacific, and it's filled with garbage from other countries. So, no, not a hoax, but it's also their problem.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: You once said you'd use political capital to solve the Israel-Palestine conflict. Have you done that? And how does that conflict relate to your goals in Iraq? [SEP] What matters most is that everyone agrees on the goal: two states, side by side, in peace. We're putting a lot of effort into getting people on the same page, which is a big change if you know anything about the Middle East.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, many are questioning the constitutionality of some of your decisions. Do you believe the War Powers Act is constitutional? What about the debt limit? And do you consider marriage a civil right? [SEP] Wow, that's quite a mix! Chuck, you should be on the Supreme Court! I'm not a Supreme Court Justice, so I won't put on my constitutional law professor hat. Let's focus on the substance of this. There's been too much noise about process and congressional consultation. Let's talk about what actually happened. Muammar Qadhafi, responsible for more American deaths than almost anyone before Usama bin Laden, was threatening to massacre his people. As part of an international coalition, under a nearly unprecedented U.N. mandate, we took out air defense systems so the coalition could enforce a no-fly zone and protect the people on the ground. I told the American people we wouldn't put troops on the ground and wouldn't carry the lion's share of the operation. We've done exactly what I said we would. Our allies have carried a big load, and we've protected thousands in Libya. No U.S. casualties, no risk of escalation. This operation is limited in time and scope. We've consulted with Congress throughout. So, a lot of this fuss is politics. We've done exactly what we said we'd do, under a U.N. mandate, and protected thousands of lives. Qadhafi is pinned down. The War Powers Resolution came up after Vietnam, when we had half a million soldiers there and lost tens of thousands of lives. Congress wanted to prevent that from happening again. I think consultation is appropriate, but our actions don't violate the War Powers Resolution. So, I don't even need to address the constitutional question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the proposed $2 trillion economic package, if you were to settle on the 'middle-ground' option, would you insist on specific stimulative measures, perhaps an extension of the payroll tax cut or unemployment insurance, as a condition for your approval? [SEP] Well, both those measures certainly have merit. The payroll tax cut provided a tangible benefit to American families, offsetting rising costs. Continuing it would be advantageous. And unemployment insurance remains vital given the current job market. Supporting families while they seek employment is crucial for the broader economy. Now, we could achieve significant discretionary cuts, paired with targeted reductions in non-healthcare mandatory spending, like ethanol programs. This could create space for a tax cut benefiting ordinary families. However, I must emphasize, this is not my preferred approach. Think of it as a tiered solution. We can address the immediate needs, but to truly resolve the issue for the long term, we need bolder decisions and compromise. If we're serious, we can stabilize the situation for a decade or more, fostering a more favorable business environment and restoring public confidence in Washington.
label: General

sentence: Q. Democrats are insisting that the Federal bailout package include help for homeowners facing foreclosure, other assistance for middle class citizens, such as possibly expanding the jobless benefits. Is that completely out of the question? [SEP] We're going to work with Congress to get a bill done quickly. I called lears of both Chambers, both parties yesterday to thank them for the initial statements coming out of the meeting that they had with Secretary Paulson and Chairman Bernanke. I found a common unrstanding of how severe the problem is and how it is necessary to get something done quickly, and I think we will.And we'll continue to work with them. It is essential that the package be robust and strong to address the problem. I know—look, I'm sure there are some of my friends out there saying, I thought this guy was a market guy; what happened to him?Well, my first instinct wasn't to lay out a huge Government plan. My first instinct was to let the market work, until I realized that—upon being briefed by the experts, of how significant this problem became.And so I cid to act and act boldly. It turns out that there's a lot of interlinks throughout the financial system. The system had grown to a point where a lot of people were pennt upon each other, and that the collapse of one part of the system wouldn't just affect a part of the financial markets, it would affect the average citizen. And how? Well, it'd affect their capacity to borrow money to buy a house or to finance a college loan. It'd affect the ability of a small business to get credit. In other words, the systemic risk was significant, and it required a significant response, and Congress unrstands that. And we'll work to get something done as quickly and as big as possible.There's going to be billions—hundreds of billion dollars at risk. This is a big package, because it was a big problem. And, you know, I tell our—I will tell our citizens and continue to remind them that the risk of doing nothing far outweighs the risk of the package and that, over time, we're going to get a lot of the money back. But right now the Government need to send a clear signal that we unrstood the instability could ripple throughout and affect the working people and the average family, and we weren't going to let that happen.You want to call on somebody? Presint Uribe. I never choose the—— Presint Bush. You never choose the questioner? I will. Presint Uribe. But here today I have to do this. Presint Bush. Well, I'll be glad to do it. Presint Uribe. We have two Juan Carlos here. Juan Carlos RCN Juan Carlos Caracol. Presint Bush. I only saw one Carlos.[]Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC)/Colombia Free Tra Agreement[The reporter asked a question in Spanish, and no translation was provid.] Presint Uribe. Entendio? Presint Bush. No, but I'll play like I unrstood it. [] What was the question? I got to ask my translator. [] Presint Uribe. What can do the United States to help us in rescue the hostages who keep in captivity—— Presint Bush. What did we do to help? Presint Uribe. Yes, actually you are doing very much to help us in—against illicit drugs. And the first question he ma was about how we can unblock the free— the approval of the free tra agreement. Presint Bush. Yes. Thank you. First of all, it is—a government has to be effective and efficient in orr for any help to work. In other words, we could—our intentions could be great to help al with FARC or extremists. But unless there's a well-organized government head by termined learship, that help doesn't work.And so the progress that's been ma is a tribute to the Colombian Government and Presint Uribe. The United States is a partner. But the truth of the matter is, the credit goes to the Uribe Government.And we will continue to stand with a Government that's willing to do hard things. And there's nothing harr than to al with FARC. But it's unniable that progress is being ma and that the FARC is weaker, FARC is on the run. People are leaving FARC because of the generous hand that the Government has reached out with.I unrstand how important the free tra agreement is to Colombia. It's not only economically important, because, as the Presint said, if the—there's doubt about the free tra agreement, investment will become nervous. And without investment, it's very hard for the Colombian economy to continue to sustain growth, and without economic growth, it's hard to be in a hopeful society.Secondly, the free tra agreement is more than just an economic agreement, it is a statement of friendship, it's a statement of common values. And if this agreement were not to pass, it would emboln the voices of populism in the neighborhood, to the triment of a Government which has been very strong in aling with human rights and human dignity and the market.And so I appreciate the Presint being here if this statement will help clarify the issue once again. We're going to go to New York and talk to—and remind people here in the Nation's Capital that this is an issue that affects a lot more than countries—than just Colombia. And my hope is that when people fully analyze the—what's good about it from our perspective and what's good about it from Colombia's perspective and the strategic implications inherent in this bill, that they will get a vote up and it will pass. And we'll work to see that it passes.Michael [Mike Emanuel, FOX News]. .
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, is the White House insisting on including funding for the FBI building in the coronavirus bill? [SEP] The FBI building is a critical issue. It's old, it's dangerous, and it needs to be replaced. I'm not sure about the specifics of this bill, but we're committed to getting the FBI a new, state-of-the-art facility. It's a matter of national security.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, Vice President Biden mentioned a conversation where he said there's a 30% chance of failure even with our best efforts. Can you elaborate on what you discussed and if you agree with that assessment? [SEP] You know, I honestly don't recall the specific conversation Joe's referring to. However, I think what he was trying to convey – and I wouldn't assign a specific number to it – is that given the immense challenges we face, any single action we take will only be a partial solution. As I said before, not everything we try will work perfectly. We're dealing with unprecedented problems, and while there's general agreement among economists on the path forward, we still have to address the financial system, housing, and regulatory structures. These are all complex issues, so I think that's the general point Joe was making.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Trump, what specific evidence or intelligence led to the decision to ban Huawei, and what assurances can you provide that similar actions against other companies will be based on concrete evidence rather than speculation or political considerations? [SEP] We have very good intelligence, the best. We know what's going on. Huawei is a threat, a big threat. We're not going to let them spy on us or steal our technology. We're protecting America, and that's what I'm going to do.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. No, no, no. So I think the—one way to follow up on that is you noted that you felt like there was a shift in terms of people being willing to show more decency in this moment. You've often talked about breaking the fever or kind of a transition from this moment that we faced over the last several years. Do you feel like the election is what represents that? Do you feel like the fever has broken, I guess? [SEP] Well, I'm not—I don't think we're going to break the fever for the super-mega-MAGA Republicans. I mean—but I think they're a minority of the Republican Party. I think the vast majority of the members of the Republican Party, we disagree strongly on issues, but they're decent, honorable people. We have differences of agreement on issues.But they—you know, I worked with a lot of these folks in the Senate and the House for a long time. And you know, they're honest, and they're straightforward. They're different than mine, but they're—you know, they're decent folks.And so I think that the rest of the world—and a lot of you have covered other parts of the world, and you know—the rest of the world is looking at the United States. I guess the best way to say this is to repeat what you've—some of you've heard me say before.The first G-7 meeting—for the public, that's the seven largest democracies—when I went to—right after we got elected, in February, after I got sworn in in January. And I sat down at a table—a roundtable with the six other world leaders from the European Union, the United—and Canada, et cetera, and said, America is back. And one of them turned to me and said: For how long? For how long? It was a deadly earnest question: For how long?And I looked at them. And then another one went on to say—and I'm not going to name them—went on to say, What would you say, Joe, if in fact you went—we went to bed tonight here in England, woke up the next morning and found out that thousands of people had stormed the Parliament of Great Britain—gone down the hall, broken down the doors, two cops ended up dying, a number of people injured, and they tried to stop the confirmation of an election? It's not the same situation, obviously, as we have. And he said, What would you think?And what—I ask the rhetorical question: What would you all think? You'd think England was really in trouble. You'd think democracy was on the edge if that happened in Great Britain. And so that's the way people were looking at us, like, When is this going to stop? Nothing like this has happened since the Civil War. I don't want to exaggerate. But literally, nothing like this has happened since the Civil War.And so what I find is that they want to know: Is the United States stable? Do we know what we're about? Are we the same democracy we've always been? Because, look, the rest of the world looks to us—I don't mean that we're always—like we're always right. But if the United States tomorrow were to, quote, withdraw from the world, a lot of things would change around the world. A whole lot would change.And so they're very concerned that we are still the open democracy we've been and that we have rules and the institutions matter. And that's the context in which I think that they're looking at: Are we back to a place where we are going to accept decisions made by the Court, by the Congress, by the Government, et cetera?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given that I represent the New York Times, may I pose a question before the other journalists? [SEP] Since you're from where, now?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, your response fails to address the specific accusations of being a liar and a racist. Can you directly refute these claims, providing concrete examples or evidence to counter Mr. Cohen's testimony? Furthermore, why should the American people believe you now, given your past documented instances of misleading statements and racially charged rhetoric? [SEP] The man's a proven liar! He's admitted it himself! Why would anyone believe anything he says? This is all about politics, pure and simple. They're trying to smear me because they can't beat me. The American people are smart; they see through this charade. We're doing great things for this country, and they're desperate to stop us. But they won't succeed. We're going to keep winning, winning, winning!
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, even after seven investigations, the Pentagon hasn't gotten to the bottom of the friendly fire incident. When did you, personally, find out it wasn't enemy fire? [SEP] I can't recall the precise moment. But the instant I learned that the accepted facts were wrong, I insisted on a full investigation to get to the truth.
label: General

sentence: Q. Is it more or less than '16? [SEP] I'm running a country. I'm—I don't know—you know, I don't have the luxury. I watched other people over the years. I watched one, sort of, fairly recently—not too long ago—go into a cabin, lock himself into a cabin, and he came out, and he wasn't very effective. You know, he had so much—so many things going on. Sometimes, you can go too much in that stuff, you know. Sometimes, you can go too much.I mean, look, I've had—I'd never debated before, but then I debated a lot 4 years ago. And if you look at the polls—those polls that come out—hundreds of thousands of people in TIME magazine and all of the different polls; I think there's about seven or eight of them—according to those polls, I won every debate—every single debate, in the primaries and then when I debated Crooked Hillary. I won every debate.I mean, this isn't me saying—I felt I did—but this isn't me saying it; this is the polls. You had a TIME magazine poll. You had this, that. And I guess they take them off the internet or they get phone calls or something. But according to that, I won every debate, and I felt I did. But I understand the subject. Now, Chris is tough. I hope that Chris is going to be equally tough on Joe Biden. But I watched the young lady, who I won't—I won't say her name, but it was embarrassing the way she was getting him along.So I just asked the question about drugs. I think it's something that would be appropriate, because you can't have a President that needs that kind of help.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, to be absolutely clear, are we aiming to eradicate ISIS entirely, or is the strategy merely to contain and diminish their influence? [SEP] Our unwavering goal is to dismantle ISIL's capacity to threaten regional stability. This is a long-term endeavor demanding sustained commitment. Terrorist networks, like Al Qaeda, often leave behind remnants capable of causing disruption. However, we are focused on significantly weakening ISIL's systemic aggression, which has terrorized Muslims, Kurds, and others throughout the region, to the point where it no longer poses the same level of threat.
label: General

sentence: President Obama, Senator Leahy's proposal for a truth and reconciliation committee regarding the Bush administration's actions is gaining traction. What are your thoughts? [SEP] Well, I've heard about the proposal. My understanding is that Senator Leahy is trying to ensure accountability. We'll certainly give it a look, but my priority remains moving forward and focusing on the challenges facing the country today.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, in a worst-case scenario, could the U.S. military be deployed to secure Pakistan's nuclear arsenal? [SEP] We have contingency plans for various scenarios, but I'm not going to discuss classified information or speculate on hypothetical situations.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, considering the logistical challenges and the evolving nature of the virus, what specific metrics are you using to determine the feasibility of providing another billion doses of vaccines globally, and how does that align with the goal of ending the pandemic by 2022? [SEP] Look, we're aiming to do everything we can, and the possibility of another billion doses is definitely something we're exploring for 2022, maybe stretching into 2023. But I'm not going to overpromise. I've been very careful throughout this whole thing to only say what I know and what I think we can do. The G-7 is united in the belief that we have to stay at this until the whole world is covered, not just because it's the right thing to do, but because it's in our own self-interest. You can't build a wall high enough to keep out new strains. This is going to be a constant project, and we're working on systems to detect future pandemics early. We're not just giving vaccines, we're helping countries manufacture their own. It's a huge logistical effort, and we're working on it. Last question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Is it hard Brexit? [SEP] Is it heartbreaking?
label: Clarification

sentence: Question.Middle East Peace Process/Israeli Settlements Q. [Inaudible]—Mr. President GeorgeW. Bush, you lead the superpower in this world. You launched war against Iraq after the Iraqi leadership refused to implement the United Nations resolutions. My question now is, what the problem to ask Israel just to accept and to respect the United Nations resolutions relating to the Palestinian problem, which—[inaudible]—facilitating the achievement of ending the Israeli occupation to the Arab territories and—[inaudible]—facilitating also the solution between Palestinians and the Israelis?And for Mahmoud Abbas, did you ask President George Bush to ask Israel to freeze settlements fully in order to enable negotiations from success? [SEP] Yes, but tell me the part about the U.N. thing again? What were you—I couldn't understand you very well.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering the shifting global power dynamics, what do you perceive as the paramount security challenges facing your administration, and what concrete steps are you taking to mitigate those risks? [SEP] The most urgent threat is, without a doubt, an attack on the homeland. We're constantly working to prevent that. North Korea's nuclear ambitions are still a major issue. We need a strong verification system to ensure they're not developing weapons. And Iran, of course, is a dangerous player in the region. We're working with our partners to counter their influence.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, Afghan President Karzai has publicly blamed Pakistani intelligence for a recent terrorist attack. Furthermore, reports suggest Al-Qaeda is rebuilding its strength in the border region. Do you agree with President Karzai's assessment? And do you believe the new Pakistani government has the will and the ability to effectively combat these terrorists? [SEP] We are taking President Karzai's accusations very seriously and will be working with Afghan intelligence to investigate them fully. There is no question that extremists are operating out of Pakistan and crossing into Afghanistan, which is a concern for all of us. We all face a common enemy in those who use violence to disrupt or prevent democracy. Al-Qaeda is still present, although we have weakened them significantly. We have applied pressure on them globally, including in Pakistan, and will continue to do so with the help of our Pakistani allies. I am confident that the Pakistani government understands the dangers posed by these extremists. I will have the opportunity to discuss this further with the Pakistani Prime Minister next week. Pakistan is an ally and a friend. The United States, Pakistan, and Afghanistan all share a common enemy. I vividly remember a meeting at the White House with Presidents Musharraf and Karzai where we discussed the need for cross-border cooperation to prevent dangerous elements from training and entering Afghanistan, and then returning home with skills that could be used against the government. We made some hopeful progress, but it remains a tough fight. We were encouraged by the Provincial elections in that region. We will continue to work to help the government deal with extremists and develop an effective counterinsurgency strategy that incorporates economic development aid. It is a challenge, and we can address it much better together than separately. Thank you, it's been a pleasure.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, polls suggest that moderates and Independents who voted for you in 2020 are now dissatisfied. How do you plan to win them back? [SEP] Those polls are often inaccurate and don't reflect the true sentiment of the American people. We are focused on delivering results for all Americans, regardless of their political affiliation. We believe that our policies will ultimately speak for themselves.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given that this is your third budget and year in office, and you've expressed a willingness to serve only one term if necessary to achieve important goals, why not extend an invitation to Republicans for immediate negotiations? What actions are you undertaking to cultivate the spirit of cooperation essential for bipartisanship? And, do you anticipate that the markets will remain stable for the next two years? [SEP] Whoa, Jackie, slow down! [] I'm running out of mental RAM here.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, thank you. I'm wondering, were you notified of any positive coronavirus cases within the White House today? [SEP] I apologize, I didn't quite hear you. Could you please repeat that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, to be absolutely clear, do you believe the use of nuclear weapons on Hiroshima and Nagasaki was the correct decision? [SEP] Hold on, you're asking about a few things there. Can you repeat the core question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. So you believe they are aiding Syria? [SEP] It's a general statement that we expect them not to be proliferating.Race Relations/
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, some interpret your tweet as undermining a key medical expert during a public health crisis. How do you respond to that criticism? [SEP] The job we've done is incredible. The best. Just look at the numbers. We're bigger than almost everyone, except China and India. And those countries have massive problems, huge flare-ups. You don't see that reported, do you? Other countries thought they were done with it, and then, boom, it comes back. Like Florida. We thought we were good, and then it came back. But we're doing great. I told Dr. Birx that myself. She's in my office all the time. I respect her. But Pelosi? She's treated her terribly. Very nasty. I'm just saying, look at what we've accomplished. Ventilators, testing – sixty million tests! Nobody else is even close. And many are rapid. Nobody has anything like that. So, we're doing great.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given your past successes with federal contracting on issues like LGBTQ+ rights, is it safe to assume you'd use a similar strategy here? [SEP] We're exploring all available options, but I won't be telegraphing our strategy in advance. A full announcement will be made when we're ready.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding the goals for Prime Minister Maliki, is there a deadline? Also, you emphasize the U.S. fighting Al Qaeda. Does that imply Iraqis are solely responsible for stopping sectarian violence, excluding U.S. troop involvement? And Prime Minister Maliki, why was last night's meeting canceled? [SEP] Could you remind me of the initial part of that rather multifaceted inquiry?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given the importance of bipartisan support for voting rights legislation, what specific outreach efforts are you planning to undertake to engage with Republican lawmakers and address their concerns about potential federal overreach in state election matters? [SEP] We're committed to working with Republicans to find common ground on voting rights. We're reaching out to them through various channels, including direct conversations, meetings with key stakeholders, and public forums. We're listening to their concerns and working to address them in a way that respects state authority while also protecting the fundamental right to vote. We believe that we can find a bipartisan solution that strengthens our democracy and ensures that every American has the opportunity to participate in the electoral process.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. So you all had the call. You said that you told him that he had made a mistake. What was his response and did he acknowledge that? [SEP] No, I didn't tell him anything. I said, What happened? And I got the impression that he didn't realize he said what he might have said. I didn't see him say it.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Iraq, if troop levels are reduced to pre-surge levels, will that be the end of the drawdown, or are further reductions possible before you leave office? Also, does the Iraqi government's decision to host Ahmadi-nejad undermine efforts to isolate Tehran? [SEP] On the latter point, Iraq is a neighbor. The message to Iran must be: stop sending sophisticated equipment that is killing our people. We are negotiating a long-term security agreement with Iraq precisely to create space for their democracy to develop. My message to Ahmadi-nejad is: stop exporting terror. The international community is serious about isolating Iran until they come clean about their nuclear ambitions. There will be action at the UN next week. As for troop levels, there will be endless speculation. My decision will be based on the advice of Secretary Gates, General Petraeus, and the Joint Chiefs. My only criterion is success. Failure in Iraq would have enormous consequences for world peace and U.S. security. So, the question is: what does it take to succeed? I will not let politics drive my decision. I sent more troops in because the situation was unacceptable, and now we are succeeding. Ambassador Crocker and General Petraeus will report back, and you will see the decisions unfold.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Canada's potential economic stimulus, did that topic arise during your discussions today? Furthermore, considering the next four years, what's your outlook on the Canada-U.S. relationship, specifically concerning the automotive industry, border regulations, and the implementation of a carbon market? [SEP] Wow, you managed to pack in a whole lot of inquiries there. Let me see... remind me of the first one again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Any restrictions on who can give? Will you take foreign money for this? [SEP] Yes, I'll probably take some foreign money, but don't know yet, Ken. We just haven't—we just announced the deal, and I frankly have been focused elsewhere, like on gasoline prices and, you know, my trip to Africa, and haven't seen the fundraising strategy yet. And so the answer to your question—really, I can't answer your question well.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the rockets from Gaza and the settlements, what concrete steps should Israel take given the escalating threats? And did you receive any firm commitments from the Prime Minister regarding illegal outpost removals? [SEP] We are working towards a peaceful resolution in the region.
label: General

sentence: Q. I just wanted to ask you quickly, sir, if you believe that Iraq will be able to defend, sustain, and govern itself by the time you leave office? [SEP] Mike, I believe Iraq will be able to defend, govern, and sustain itself; otherwise, I'd pull our troops out. See, you all got to understand that, and the parents of our troops must understand, that if I didn't believe we could succeed and didn't believe it was necessary for the security of this country to succeed, I wouldn't have your loved ones there. That's what I want these parents to hear.And that's a backhanded way of getting me to put a timetable. My answer is, we'll work as fast as we can get the job done.Mark and then Richard.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Just to make sure I understand, are we discussing option A or option B? [Laughter] [SEP] Or, dare I suggest, a synthesis of the two? Please, continue.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, if Tedros is removed from his position at the WHO, would you then consider supporting the organization again? Or do you believe his resignation is a necessary step towards reform? [SEP] We're conducting a thorough investigation. I'm not personally acquainted with the gentleman, but I'm aware of the issues. The WHO has treated the United States unfairly, much like the World Trade Organization, which is now starting to align itself properly. Why did previous presidents allow China to be classified as a developing nation, allowing them to exploit the United States? I've been addressing this since day one, and we're taking it very seriously. I have concerns with both the World Health Organization and the World Trade Organization. I'm not sure which is worse, to be honest, but we'll resolve it. Okay?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Since most of the surge troops were in place during the July report, will you continue the surge regardless of General Petraeus's assessment if there is no progress in Iraq by September? [SEP] You're asking me to speculate about what I will be thinking in September. I would prefer to wait for General Petraeus to brief me. I'll be glad to answer your questions then.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Your administration has cited Al Qaida leaders, such as Zawahiri, as saying that if we leave prematurely, it would be a glorious victory for Al Qaida. But the reason that we can't leave or haven't been able to leave is not because we're getting defeated in any way militarily; it's because the Iraqis can't get it together so far. So why can't we counter those messages and, obviously, not withdraw precipitously, but begin some sort of gradual withdrawal that prevents ethnic cleansing, but also allows our military to get out? [SEP] Well, there's a lot of discussion about a scenario in which our troop posture would be to guard the territorial integrity of the country of Iraq, to embed and train, to help the Iraqi security forces deal with violent elements in their society, as well as keep enough Special Forces there to chase down Al Qaida. As a matter of fact, that is something that I've spoken in public about, said that's a position I'd like to see us in. However, I felt like we needed to send more troops to be able to get the situation to quiet down enough to be able to end in that position.And in terms of my own decisionmaking, as I mentioned earlier, I definitely need to be in consultation, and will be, with General David Petraeus, who asked for the additional troops in the first place, troops which have been in place—fully in place for about 3 weeks.And so I would ask Members of Congress to give the general a chance to come back and to give us a full assessment of whether this is succeeding or not. And it's at that point in time that I will consult with Members of Congress and make a decision about the way forward, all aiming to succeed in making sure that Al Qaida and other extremists do not benefit from a decision I might have to make.Mark [Mark Silva, Chicago Tribune].
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, can you provide specific examples of what Kim Jong Un has indicated he's willing to do on human rights? [SEP] Look, it's a process. It takes time. He's got a lot on his plate. But he understands the importance of it. He's a smart guy. He'll figure it out. We're building a relationship, and that's the most important thing. You can't just demand everything overnight.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, you've emphasized the U.S.-Japan alliance and a free Indo-Pacific. But you're going to China, which is neither free nor open. How can the U.S. promote freedom there without clashing with China? And Prime Minister, Trump wants Japan to beef up its defense. He wants to sell you arms, and some say he was bummed you didn't shoot down that North Korean missile. Did that come up, and what's your message about Japan's defense role? [SEP] Mark, thanks. Let me jump in on the Prime Minister's answer for a sec. He'll be blasting those missiles out of the sky once he finishes buying all that sweet military gear from us. Like we did in Saudi Arabia, boom, missile gone. That was like hitting a needle in the sky, no damage. So, Japan's gonna buy a ton of our stuff, the best stuff, like the F-35, total stealth, and all kinds of missiles. Jobs for us, safety for Japan. Now, China, I like President Xi. He's a friend. But he reps China, I rep the U.S. We see things differently, but we're on the same page with trade. The problem is, for years, they've been ripping us off. It's been a very unfair situation. Our trade deficit is huge, like $350 billion to $504 billion, not even counting intellectual property. We're talking to China about it, it's gotta come down. It's gotta be fair, or reciprocal. I like reciprocal the best. People get it. If you charge me this, I charge you the same. It's fair. We're gonna start doing that. We've got countries charging us a hundred percent, and we charge them nothing. Not anymore. It takes time, you know, legal stuff. But it's coming. You're gonna see the U.S. take very strong action against countries that have been treating us unfairly. It's already started, but the legal stuff is done. Big changes are coming. As for Japan's defense, we buy a lot from the U.S. The North Korean situation is tough, so we gotta boost our defense. F-35A, SM-3 Block IIA, Aegis vessels, all from the U.S. We'll shoot down missiles if we need to, with the U.S. working together.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, you're not considering any independent investigation or oversight from the U.S. government? And you're not prepared to reassess your support for President Uribe, despite these serious allegations? [SEP] We believe that the Colombian government is best positioned to investigate these allegations and to ensure that justice is served. We will continue to support their efforts to strengthen their institutions and to combat drug trafficking and paramilitary activity.
label: Implicit

sentence: In light of your focus on loyalty, how did you react to Scott McClellan's perspective on the Iraq War? And given the positive developments in Iraq, what advice would you impart to Senator Obama as he gauges the situation? [SEP] I'm not commenting on Scott's book. As for Obama, my advice is to listen closely to Crocker and Petraeus. It's tempting to let politics interfere with sound judgment. That's why I opposed fixed withdrawal deadlines. We can't let polls dictate our actions. Listen to the experts on the ground. It's difficult, with groups like MoveOn.org putting pressure on candidates. But they'll gain valuable insights firsthand. John.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, just to be absolutely certain, regarding Meng Wanzhou's situation, will that also be deferred until the final stage, or is there any chance the U.S. could abandon the extradition attempt? [SEP] Come again? I'm not sure I followed you there.

sentence: Mr. President, given Mayor Bowser's recent order in DC, will you encourage federal properties, including the White House and military bases, to adhere to it? [SEP] We're evaluating our options and will announce our decision shortly. Stay tuned.

sentence: Q. So my question is: Do you think that they are putting together a real alliance, the Chinese and the Russians? And do you believe that you need to begin speaking with President Xi about some form of arms control if he's going to get up to a level of weapons similar to what the United States and Russia have right now? [SEP] No and yes. No, I don't think there's a lot of respect that China has for Russia or for Putin. I don't think they're looking at it as a particular alliance. Matter of fact, they've been sort of keeping their distance a little bit.I do think that it remains to be seen whether Xi Jinping has decided that—or backed off of his initial judgment that he wanted Ukraine—excuse me, China to have the most powerful military in the world, as well as the largest economy.And—but he's a long way from both. But I think talk about nuclear weapons and location and the number of them and access is important to discuss.Thank you all so very, very much.[.] . Thank you very, very much. We'll do another—we'll do another hour in—a little later. Thank you so much. [] Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: So, Mr. President, are we talking about total annihilation, or just, you know, keeping them in their box, so to speak? [SEP] Look, what we're trying to do is make sure ISIL ain't a problem for the region anymore. It'll take time and effort, no doubt. Like with Al Qaeda, you're always gonna have some stragglers causing trouble. But we gotta degrade their operation to the point where they can't terrorize folks like they have been. That's the long and short of it.
label: General

sentence: Q. Sir, why did you decide on $400, when previously families were receiving $600? [SEP] Yes.

sentence: Mr. President, turning to voting rights, Republican state legislatures are pushing through laws that restrict voting access, specifically targeting minority and young voters who were crucial to your victory. Are you worried that if you fail to pass voting rights legislation, your party will lose seats in the upcoming 2022 elections? [SEP] What truly worries me is the deeply un-American nature of this whole thing. It's just plain wrong. States are making it illegal to give water to people waiting in line to vote, stopping voting at 5 PM when folks are just getting off work, and making absentee ballots almost impossible to get. It's all designed to keep people from voting. I'm going to focus on three things: getting the House bill passed, educating the American people, and getting Republican voters on board because they think this is garbage. I'm talking about the voters, not the politicians. I'm convinced we can stop this because it's the most awful thing. This makes Jim Crow look like a joke. I'm going to do everything I can, with my friends in Congress, to make sure this doesn't become law.
label: Deflection

sentence: Regarding Iraq, will you sign an interim agreement with Prime Minister Maliki, or leave it to your successor? [SEP] We're working on a strategic framework agreement that covers a lot of ground, including security. The goal is to transition to an overwatch role, with U.S. troops providing training, logistical support, and special ops. This agreement needs to be in place before the end of the year, unless the U.N. mandate is extended. So, we're working on both the strategic framework and the security agreement simultaneously.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, Robert Novak says you're the most isolated president he's ever seen. What do you say to those who claim you're even more isolated than Nixon was during Watergate? [SEP] What does he mean by 'isolated'?

sentence: Mr. President, to be blunt: are you actively trying to block testimony that could be damaging? A simple 'yes' or 'no' would suffice. [SEP] I'm focused on running the country.

sentence: Mr. President, what do you hope to accomplish on your trip to Africa, and how will the U.S. assist in the continent's transformation? [SEP] I visited Africa early in my presidency too. This is my second trip, to remind everyone that it's in our interest to address diseases like malaria and HIV/AIDS, to encourage trade, and to support education. Ghana is a perfect place to see this firsthand. Africa has changed for the better since I became President, thanks to African leaders. Conflict resolution has improved, as seen in Liberia. The U.S. has been a helpful partner, not imposing solutions. Democracy is advancing, with examples like John Kufuor. Our aid program now requires good governance in return, such as fighting corruption and investing in education. I believe in setting high expectations for African leaders. I'm confident in the leaders I've met on this trip. It's been a fantastic trip.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Trump, aside from a congratulatory call, what is your assessment of the current political landscape, and can you offer any concrete information about planned personnel changes, specifically regarding General Kelly's continued role in your administration? [SEP] Well, as we implement changes, we'll inform you accordingly. There's no grand secret. Many administrations make adjustments following midterm elections. I will state that, for the most part, I'm very pleased with this Cabinet. We're achieving significant progress.
label: Implicit

sentence: What's your response to the Red Cross report? [SEP] Haven't had a chance to review it. And let me be clear: this administration does not condone torture. Next question.

sentence: Mr. President, some have suggested your prior endorsement of Tony Blair influenced his decision to step down. Do you believe your words played any role in his departure? [SEP] Well, I haven't taken a poll on that. Whether I'm responsible for his decision? I really couldn't say. It's his decision, after all.

sentence: Mr. President, what concrete steps will you take to advance your pro-life agenda? [SEP] We're working very hard on it, and we've had tremendous success. People are very happy with the progress we're making. It's a complex issue, and there are strong opinions on both sides, but we're committed to protecting the sanctity of life.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, given the Russian actions and the ongoing situation in Ukraine, wouldn't a stronger, more immediate response be warranted to truly deter further aggression? [SEP] The situation in Ukraine is a complex one, and we are constantly evaluating the effectiveness of our response. Sanctions are a tool, not a magic bullet, and their impact takes time to fully materialize. We are seeing signs that the Russian economy is feeling the pressure, and we will continue to monitor the situation closely and adjust our approach as needed. It's a delicate balance between applying pressure and avoiding escalation, and we believe we are striking the right chord at the moment.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. From the podium, please.Pandemic Adviser Atlas. Okay. And we have all the people that are involved in the actual vaccine distribution here, but we were just going through this. As of the end of the year, we will have over a hundred million doses manufactured. The people who are on the prioritized list of—including high risk, including first responders—will have the ability to take the vaccine—no one is being mandated to be vaccinated—at the latest, in January.And as we said yesterday and—or I think yesterday—there will be hundreds of millions of doses delivered for people to take it during the first quarter. And so that, by April, every single American who wants to be vaccinated will have the ability to be vaccinated. It's not a forced vaccination, of course. Q. And when did you—Dr. Fauci said today—basically echoed Dr. Redfield's comments that Q2, Q3—at some point the summer of next year—the entire country, potentially, or at least as many Americans that need to be vaccinated will be vaccinated. Is that the timeline? [SEP] We'd like to beat that number, yes. But we think we will.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. And Boris Johnson and Michael Gove? [SEP] So I know Boris. I like him. I've liked him for a long time. He's—I think he'd do a very good job. I know Jeremy. I think he'd do a very good job. I don't know Michael. But would he do a good job—Jeremy? Tell me. []Okay?. Okay. Good. Thank you very much, everybody. Thank you. Thank you very much.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Jason Collins? Do you want to say anything about it? [SEP] Yes. I'll say something about Jason Collins. I had a chance to talk to him yesterday. He seems like a terrific young man. And I told him I couldn't be prouder of him.One of the extraordinary measures of progress that we've seen in this country has been the recognition that the LGBT community deserves full equality, not just partial equality, not just tolerance, but a recognition that they're fully a part of the American family.And given the importance of sports in our society, for an individual who has excelled at the highest levels in one of the major sports to go ahead and say, this is who I am, I'm proud of it, I'm still a great competitor, I'm still 7 foot tall and can bang with Shaq[]and deliver a hard foul, and for, I think, a lot of young people out there who are gay or lesbian who are struggling with these issues, to see a role model like that who is unafraid, I think it's a great thing.And I think Americans should be proud that this is just one more step in this ongoing recognition that we treat everybody fairly and everybody is part of a family, and we judge people on the basis of their character and their performance and not their sexual orientation. So I'm very proud of him.All right?
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. As you prepare to leave office, sir, who is designated to officially sign this agreement? [SEP] Our negotiating team is on site and ready. While my presence at the final signing is uncertain, they are authorized to conclude the agreement, considering the substantial groundwork already completed.
label: General

sentence: Q. I'll be very respectful, sir. What did Kim Jong Un say to you to give you the confidence that, for once in the history of North Korea, they are not cheating the system and gaming the world and gaming the people who will have to go in and make sure that they're actually giving up their nuclear arsenal? What did he say to you? [SEP] Yes, I mean, very fair question. He actually mentioned the fact that they proceeded down a path in the past, and ultimately, as you know, nothing got done. In one case, they took billions of dollars—during the Clinton regime—took billions of dollars and nothing happened. That was a terrible thing, and he actually brought it up to me.And he said we have never gone this far. I don't think they've ever had the confidence, frankly, in a President that they have right now for getting things done and having the ability to get things done. And he was very firm in the fact that he wants to do this. I think he might want to do this as much or even more than me, because they see a very bright future for North Korea.So you never know. Right? We never know. But I'll tell you what, we signed a very comprehensive document today, and I think most of you have been given that document. But we signed a very, very comprehensive document, and I believe he's going to live up to that document. In fact, when he lands—which is going to be shortly—I think that he will start that process right away.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. What's your message for President Moon, who has effectively reached the glass ceiling, as far inter-Korean cooperation is concerned, due to sanctions? And what's next for U.S.-R.O.K. military drills? [SEP] Well, I like President Moon very much. We have a great relationship. Believe it or not, I have a great relationship with almost every leader. A lot of people find that hard to understand, but I do. But some take advantage of our country like you wouldn't believe. And when they know I know it—which I know in every case—maybe it sort of freezes them up a little bit. But we do; we have a lot of good relationships.We'll be calling President Moon very soon, as soon as I get by the phone, on the plane. And he'll be one of the first calls. I'll be calling Prime Minister Abe of Japan, telling him about where we are and what we're doing. But I'll be making those calls.No, he's working very hard. President Moon is working very hard. He'd love to see a deal, and he's been very helpful.Okay? Thank you. Go ahead, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, in light of your poignant remarks on the Rwandan genocide, the perpetrators remain at large, especially in Congo. Given your call for tangible outcomes, what specific measures will the U.S. implement to bring these individuals to account for their actions? [SEP] Understood.

sentence: Q. Just to confirm, the date by which Kosovo is expected to be independent is...? [SEP] A fall?

sentence: Q. And your own family, sir? [SEP] What's that?

sentence: Q. In essence, are you signaling a willingness to scrap the filibuster, Mr. President? [SEP] I have answered the question./Tax Code Reform/Deficit Spending/The President's Agenda

sentence: Mr. President, now that Israeli Opposition Leader Netanyahu has publicly acknowledged Israel's bombing raid in Syria, can you disclose the target, express your support or disapproval, and assess its impact on regional dynamics involving Syria, Iran, and Israel, and the potential for U.S. involvement? sentence: Q. Right here. [Laughter] How are you doing? [SEP] There you are. How are you?

sentence: Sir, given the troop surge deployment timing relative to the July report, are you prepared to continue the surge irrespective of General Petraeus's findings, even without significant Iraqi political advancement by September? label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. There have been a lot of questions about the constitutionality--constitutional interpretations of a few decisions you've made, so I'll just simply ask: Do you believe the War Powers Act is constitutional? Do you believe that the debt limit is constitutional, the idea that Congress can do this? And do you believe that marriage is a civil right? [SEP] Well, that was a hodgepodge. [] Chuck, we're going to assign you to the Supreme Court, man. []I'm not a Supreme Court Justice, so I'm not going to put my constitutional law professor hat on here. Let me focus on, initially, the issue of . I want to talk about the substance of because there's been all kinds of noise about process and congressional consultation and so forth. Let's talk about concretely what's happened.Muammar Qadhafi, who, prior to Usama bin Laden, was responsible for more American deaths than just about anybody on the planet, was threatening to massacre his people. And as part of an international coalition, under a U.N. mandate that is almost unprecedented, we went in and took out air defense systems so that an international coalition could provide a no-fly zone, could protect--provide humanitarian protection to the people on the ground.I spoke to the American people about what we would do. I said there would be no troops on the ground. I said that we would not be carrying the lion's share of this operation, but as members of NATO, we would be supportive of it because it's in our national security interests and also because it's the right thing to do.We have done exactly what I said we would do. We have not put any boots on the ground. And our allies--who, historically, we've complained aren't willing to carry enough of the load when it comes to NATO operations--have carried a big load when it comes to these NATO operations. And as a consequence, we've protected thousands of people in ; we have not seen a single U.S. casualty; there's no risks of additional escalation. This operation is limited in time and in scope.So I said to the American people, here's our narrow mission. We have carried out that narrow mission in exemplary fashion. And throughout this process we consulted with Congress. We've had 10 hearings on it. We've sent reams of information about what the operations are. I've had all the Members of Congress over to talk about it. So a lot of this fuss is politics.And if you look substantively at what we've done, we have done exactly what we said to do, under a U.N. mandate, and we have protected thousands of lives in the process. And as a consequence, a guy who was a state sponsor of terrorist operations against the United States of America is pinned down, and the noose is tightening around him.Now, when you look at the history of the War Powers Resolution, it came up after the Vietnam war in which we had half a million soldiers there, tens of thousands of lives lost, hundreds of billions of dollars spent, and Congress said, you know what, we don't want something like that happening again. So if you're going to start getting us into those kinds of commitments, you've got to consult with Congress beforehand.And I think that such consultation is entirely appropriate. But do I think that our actions in any way violate the War Powers Resolution? The answer is no. So I don't even have to get to the constitutional question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue your administration is only targeting cities run by Democrats. Is this merely a political stunt? [SEP] Well, unfortunately, the cities facing these problems are all run by Democrats. You have radical-left Democrats running cities like Chicago and many others. That's just a fact. Look at Chicago. Mayor Lightfoot sent me a letter yesterday, and I think they want us to help. Eventually, they'll want us to go in full force, but for now, we're sending extra people to assist. We're arresting a lot of bad people. As for the coronavirus, I think we've done amazing things.
