Compare our statistics to other countries, and you'll see impressive numbers for the United States, especially in the future.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, do you support Kosovo declaring independence from Serbia? And would the United States recognize it as an independent state?And, Mr. President, as head of the African Union, how do you get more peacekeepers into Darfur? [SEP] Well, first, on Kosovo, our position is that its status must be resolved in order for the Balkans to be stable. Secondly, we have strongly supported the Ahtisaari plan. Thirdly, we are heartened by the fact that the Kosovo Government has clearly proclaimed its willingness and its desire to support Serbian rights in Kosovo. We also believe it's in Serbia's interests to be aligned with Europe, and the Serbian people can know that they have a friend in America. Finally, the United States will continue to work with our allies to do the very best we can to make sure there's no violence. And so those are the principles going into the Kosovo issue.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your direct engagement with the North Korean leader, despite the lack of progress on human rights, sends the wrong message to oppressive regimes worldwide. How do you respond? [SEP] I'm doing what's best for America. I'm trying to prevent a war. I'm not going to let human rights concerns stand in the way of that. We can talk about human rights later.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, given the pattern of provocations after U.S. overtures and the Republican pushback against your Cuba strategy, what was Fidel Castro's role in the discussions? Did you bring him up with Raul? And will you personally intervene with Congress to prevent them from blocking embassy funding? [SEP] Lesley, I'm afraid we're going to have to wrap it up there. We're simply out of time to delve into this further.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Well, and given the fact that you do hold that position about gay marriage, I wonder if you thought about just—once you'd made the decision to weigh in, why not just argue that marriage is a right that should be available to all people of this country? [SEP] Well, that's an argument that I've made personally. The Solicitor General in his institutional role going before the Supreme Court is obliged to answer the specific question before them. And the specific question presented before the Court right now is whether Prop. 8 and the California law is unconstitutional.And what we've done is we've put forward a basic principle, which is—which applies to all equal protection cases. Whenever a particular group is being discriminated against, the Court asks the question, what's the rationale for this—and it better be a good reason. And if you don't have a good reason, we're going to strike it down.And what we've said is, is that same-sex couples are a group, a class, that deserves heightened scrutiny, that the Supreme Court needs to ask the State why it's doing it. And if the State doesn't have a good reason, it should be struck down. That's the core principle, as applied to this case.Now, what the Court—the Court may decide that if it doesn't apply in this case, it probably can't apply in any case. There's no good reason for it. If I were on the Court, that would probably be the view that I'd put forward. But I'm not a judge, I'm the President. So the basic principle, though, is let's treat everybody fairly; let's treat everybody equally. And I think that the brief that's been presented accurately reflects our views.Ari Shapiro [National Public Radio].
label: Explicit

sentence: Prime Minister Netanyahu is about to be indicted with corruption allegations. Do you wish to tell him something on this occasion? [SEP] Look, he's been a great Prime Minister. I don't know about his difficulty, but you're telling me something that, you know, the—people have been hearing about. But I don't know about that. I can say this: that he's done a great job as Prime Minister. He's tough, he's smart, he's strong. He is very defensive. His military has been built up a lot. They buy a lot of equipment from the United States, and they pay for it. Of course, we give them tremendous, as you know, subsidy, also. Four billion dollars is a lot each year. But they are—they've been very good. They've been incredible, actually, in many ways.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, could you explain the absence of Dr. Fauci and Dr. Birx from today's proceedings? [SEP] They're actively engaged in addressing the pandemic. They're invaluable members of the team.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Given the Pentagon's findings on Sergeant Bergdahl's desertion, and the controversy surrounding the Taliban prisoner exchange without the required congressional notification, some critics suggest you prioritized political expediency over national security. How do you respond to those accusations, and can you assure the American public that this decision will not set a dangerous precedent? [SEP] Look, the bedrock principle here is that we don't abandon our service members. Period. We had reason to believe Sergeant Bergdahl's health was deteriorating rapidly. The Qataris offered a chance for exchange, and we acted swiftly. We kept Congress informed to the best of our ability, given the urgency. As for the released Taliban, they're being monitored. There's always a risk, but I wouldn't have authorized this if I thought it endangered our national security. This is about bringing an American home, plain and simple.
label: Implicit

sentence: Can you give us even a rough estimate? Is it dozens, hundreds, thousands? [SEP] I wouldn't want to speculate without having the precise figures in front of me. I can assure you that we are working diligently to gather the information and will provide it to you as soon as possible.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Despite your initial commitment, Guantanamo remains open after two years. What unforeseen challenges have hindered its closure, and what alternative strategies are you considering to address the long-term detention of suspected terrorists? [SEP] The most important thing is the safety of the American people. Guantanamo, it's a problem. It's a way for Al Qaeda to recruit people. We're going after them hard, my administration is doing a great job. We're making progress, but we also need to think about our values. That's why I want to close Guantanamo, not because the people there are doing a bad job, but because it's become a symbol. We can keep these people somewhere else. The problem is what to do with these dangerous people, people who have engaged in terrorism. We need to give them lawyers, but we can't just release them. It's a balance, security and our Constitution. It's not easy, but it's important. It's what makes America special.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, following yesterday's attack on the Inter-Continental Hotel, are you concerned about the Afghan forces' ability to maintain security, particularly in Kabul? [SEP] Let's be clear, the troop drawdown hasn't even begun. We've always known Afghanistan is a dangerous place, and these incidents are, unfortunately, to be expected. The real question is whether Afghan security forces are improving overall. Kabul, largely policed by Afghan forces, is significantly safer than it once was. That said, isolated attacks will likely continue for some time. Our mission isn't complete, but as I've stated before, the tide of war is receding. We're transitioning, much like we did in Iraq. While occasional attacks still occur there, Iraq has maintained a democratic government. We believe a similar approach is appropriate here. Even with our presence, Afghanistan wouldn't be perfectly safe. But we can improve their ability to defend themselves.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that focusing solely on the 'start' of denuclearization without verifiable steps allows North Korea to maintain its nuclear arsenal. How do you respond to that? [SEP] These are the same people who said I couldn't win, the same people who said the economy would crash. They're wrong, folks, they're always wrong. We're dealing from a position of strength, a position of power. We have the best negotiators, the best dealmakers. We're going to get a deal that's good for America, good for the world. You can trust me on that.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the European bailout, there appeared to be some friction with European leaders about funding. You highlighted that TARP was a U.S.-funded initiative. Are you now assured that European leaders will finance this firewall independently, without seeking external aid, and that they'll take the required steps? Also, how challenging was it to promote stimulus measures when your own efforts are currently stalled in Congress? [SEP] The discussion about stimulus measures was brief, some time ago. We talked about ways to boost economic growth, which don't always mean government spending. The rebalancing agenda, for example, can significantly increase global demand through adjustments by countries, without traditional fiscal stimulus. There wasn't a dispute with the Europeans. They agree it's important to show that the European project is strong, that they're committed to the euro, and that they're determined to solve the crisis. European leaders know this starts with a unified approach. We've seen all the pieces for dealing with the crisis put in place, which we think are the right ones. First, a solution for Greece, involving debt reduction, reforms, and structural changes, despite recent issues. Second, recapitalizing Europe's banks, which is key for market confidence. Third, creating a firewall to show that Europe is supporting the euro. The details are being worked out. We gave them some ideas. The G-20 will assist and cushion the global economy from market shocks as Europe works through these issues. They have a strong partner in us. But European leaders know that the markets want a strong signal of Europe's support for the euro.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the G20 communique's commitment to avoid competitive currency devaluations, what specific actions do you expect from China, and what are your thoughts on the Democratic Party needing fresh leadership? [SEP] We want China to do well. Their economic growth has lifted millions out of poverty, which is good for everyone. But with that success comes responsibility. The RMB's value is a concern, not just for us, but for many of China's trading partners. They need to move towards a market-based system. As for the Democratic Party, I think new talent will emerge organically, bringing fresh ideas to the forefront. Speaker Pelosi and Harry Reid have been excellent partners, and I look forward to working with the entire leadership team.
label: General

sentence: Q. Concerning the conversations you had with Kim Jong Un, was a written account produced? [SEP] Pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, what specific outcome are you hoping to achieve with this impeachment inquiry? [SEP] It's a total witch hunt. A complete and utter hoax. It's terrible for our country. We have the head of the World Trade Organization here, and he has to listen to this nonsense about a perfect call. Nobody talks about the transcription. Nobody talks about the call itself, because there's nothing there. Read it! Anyone can read it. And they'll say, 'That's an impeachable offense?' If that were impeachable, Lyndon Johnson and Kennedy would have been out of office on day one. It's a hoax. You know it's a hoax.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, what assurances—what assurances do you—what assurances do you have that providing F-16s won't escalate this war? [SEP] I have a flat assurance from the—from Zelenskyy that they will not—they will not use it to go on and move into Russian geographic territory. But wherever Russian troops are within Ukraine in the area, they would be able to do that.Thank you all very, very much. Appreciate it.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Edward Snowden, Rick Ledgett at NSA suggested discussing amnesty. What's your view? What conditions would prompt you to consider a plea deal or amnesty? And what do you say to Americans who view Snowden as a hero who exposed surveillance abuses? [SEP] Major, I must be careful, as Snowden is indicted and faces charges. The Attorney General and courts will decide. I can't comment directly, but I'll address the heart of it. I've said this is a critical discussion. But the leaks damaged the US and our intel. We could have had this debate without that harm. For instance, the US, despite flaws, upholds the law, privacy, civil liberties, and our Constitution. Because of these leaks, nations that do what Snowden fears—surveillance, targeting dissidents, suppressing the press—criticize the US. That's a skewed view. This debate is vital, but it hurt US intel and diplomacy. I'll leave Snowden's case to the courts and Attorney General.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, can you detail the assurances you gave Prime Minister Netanyahu regarding U.S. support if diplomatic efforts with Iran fail and Israel considers military action? [SEP] Well, anyone advocating for war needs to explain the potential costs and benefits to the American people. I'm focused on a peaceful resolution. The international framework we've established is putting unprecedented pressure on Iran. They've indicated a willingness to return to negotiations, and we need to explore that opportunity while maintaining pressure. I won't disclose the specifics of my conversation with Prime Minister Netanyahu, but my public statements reflect our private discussions. Israel is a sovereign nation and must make its own security decisions. Sanctions are having a significant impact on Iran, affecting their oil industry and central bank. They're considering returning to the negotiating table, making it in everyone's interest to pursue a peaceful resolution. The notion that we face an immediate decision is inaccurate. We've made an unprecedented commitment to Israel's security. Friends offer honest advice, and this issue is not just about Israeli interests; it's about U.S. interests as well. Military action always comes at a price, and we must consider it carefully. We don't play politics with war. We've taken a careful, thoughtful approach over the past three years, and I intend to continue doing so.
label: General

sentence: Q. General Kelly said on—just last week that you believe that Cuba could stop the attacks against Americans. Do you believe them, that Cuba is—do you believe Cuba is responsible? [SEP] I do. I think Cuba knew about it, sure. I do believe Cuba is responsible. I do believe that. And it's a very unusual attack, as you know, but I do believe Cuba is responsible, yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. I was in Congressman Clyburn's district yesterday in South Carolina. You opened this news conference talking about him. I spoke to a number of Black voters who fought to get you elected, and now they feel as though you are not fighting hard enough for them and their priorities. And they told me they see this push on voting rights more as a last-minute PR push than it is a legitimate effort to get legislation passed.So what do you say to these Black voters who say that you do not have their backs, as you promised on the campaign trail? [SEP] I've had their back. I've had their back my entire career. I've never not had their back. And I started on the voting rights issues long, long ago. That's what got me involved in politics in the first place.And I think part of the problem is—look, there's significant disagreement in every community on whether or not the timing of assertions made by people has been in a most timely way. So I'm sure that there are those who are saying that: Why didn't Biden push the John Lewis bill as hard as he pushed it the last month? Why didn't he push it 6 months ago as hard as he did now?The fact is that there is—there's a timing that is not of one's own choice; it's somewhat dictated by events that are happening in country and around the world as to what the focus is.But part of the problem is, as well, I have not been out in the community nearly enough. I've been here an awful lot. I find myself in a situation where I don't get a chance to look people in the eye, because of both COVID and things that are happening in Washington, to be able to go out and do the things that I've always been able to do pretty well: connect with people, let them take a measure of my sincerity, let them take a measure of who I am.For example—I mean, as I pointed out in South Carolina, you know, last time, when I was chairman of the Judiciary Committee, I got the Act extended for 25 years, and I got Strom Thurmond to vote for it. That's what I've been doing my whole career. And so the idea that I—that I didn't either anticipate or because I didn't speak to it as fervently as they want me to earlier.In the meantime, I was spending a lot of time—spent hours and hours and hours talking with my colleagues on the Democratic side, trying to get them to agree that if in fact this occurred, if this push continued, that they would be there for John Lewis and—anyway.So—but I think that's—that's a problem that is my own making by not communicating as much as I should have. Yet you find that when you deal with Members of the Black Caucus and others in the United States Congress, I still have very close working relationships.So it's like every community. I'm sure that there are those in the community, in—I'm a big labor guy. I'm sure there's people in labor saying, Why haven't they been able to do A, B, C, or D?So it's just going to take a little bit of time.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, how would Republican control of the House impact your administration's agenda? [SEP] Yes, because it's going to be much closer if they take control.If they take—look, the predictions were—and again, I'm not being critical of anybody who made the predictions. I got it, okay? This was supposed to be a red wave. You guys—you were talking about us losing 30 to 50 seats and this was going to—we're nowhere near—that's not going to happen. And so there's always enough people in the—on the other team, whether it's Democrat or Republican, that the opposite party can make an appeal to and maybe pick them off to get the help. And so it remains to be seen.But look, I doubt whether or not—for example, all the talk—I'd ask the rhetorical—I don't expect you to answer, but the rhetorical question: Do you think that, you know, Senator Johnson is going to move to cut Medicare and Social Security? And if he does, how many Republicans do you think are going to vote for it?So it depends.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the coronavirus vaccine, once it becomes available, who will be prioritized to receive it first? Also, what is your assessment of Russia's vaccine development efforts? [SEP] We're working closely with medical experts to determine the fairest and most effective distribution plan. As for the Russian vaccine, we're monitoring developments closely, but our priority is ensuring that any vaccine used in the United States meets the highest safety and efficacy standards.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. Blair, what's your take on David Cameron's policies? [SEP] With all due respect, it's not my place to offer unsolicited advice to the current leadership. My focus is on the broader strategic picture, the enduring alliance between our nations, and the shared values that underpin it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Do you believe you can find common ground with them? [SEP] Ask me again in eight years, how about that? I'm all for bipartisanship, but right now, they're just obstructing. They're opposing tax cuts that would strengthen our country, which is a tough position to defend. I think some Democrats will eventually support our tax plan.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Following your meeting with Prime Minister Singh, what specific steps is the United States taking to assist India in combating terrorism originating from Pakistan? [SEP] He's a fine leader, a very fine leader.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, Secretary Blinken's performance has been criticized recently. Do you have full confidence in him, and are there any plans to make changes in the State Department leadership? [SEP] He is a valued member of the team. We're always looking at performance, but I have no announcements to make at this time. We'll have more to say on this matter shortly.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You're looking for Republican help on the economic proposals that you unveiled this week, and you also mentioned the small-business bill. But you're at odds with them over tax cuts. Is there room for a middle ground whereby, for example, the tax cuts on the wealthy could be extended for a period of time and then allowed to expire? [SEP] Well, certainly there is going to be room for discussion. My hope is, is that on this small-business bill that is before the Senate right now, that we actually make some progress. I still don't understand why we didn't pass that 2 months ago. As I said, this was written by Democrats and Republicans. This is a bill that traditionally you'd probably get 90 percent or 100 percent Republican support. But we've been playing politics for the last several months. And if the Republican leadership is prepared to get serious about doing something for families that are hurting out there, I would love to talk to them.Now, on the high-income tax cuts, my position is, let's get done what we all agree on. What they've said is they agree that the middle class tax cut should be made permanent. Let's work on that. Let's do it. We can have a further conversation about how they want to spend an additional $700 billion to give an average of $100,000 to millionaires. That, I think, is a bad idea. If you were going to spend that money, there are a lot better ways of spending it. But more to the point, these are the same folks who say that they're concerned about the deficits. Why would we borrow money on policies that won't help the economy and help people who don't need help?But setting that aside, we've got an area of agreement, which is, let's help families out there who are having a tough time. As I said, we could, this month, give every American certainty and tax relief up to $250,000 a year. Every single American would benefit from that. Now, people who make $250,000 a year or less, they'd benefit on all their income. People who make a million dollars would benefit on a quarter of their income. But the point is, is that that's something that we can all agree to. Why hold it up? Why hold the middle class hostage in order to do something that most economists don't think makes sense?
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, [muffled audio] from the BBC. In your negotiations regarding North Korea, did the issue of allowing international inspectors access to their nuclear sites come up? [SEP] I'm having difficulty hearing you. Can you please speak more clearly? And tell me again, who do you work for?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. What can you do about that? And if the CDC is right in saying that the spread is inevitable, are you going to be dealing with stock market issues and economy issues for some time to come here? [SEP] Well, I really think the stock market—of something I know a lot about—I think it took a hit maybe for two reasons. I think they look at the people that you watched debating last night, and they say, if there's even a possibility that can happen, I think it really takes a hit because of that. And it certainly took a hit because of this, and I understand that also, because of supply chains and various other things and people coming in.But I think the stock market will recover. The economy is very strong. The consumer is the strongest it's ever been. Our consumers are incredible. They're incredible. That's why we're doing well, and other countries have not, even before the virus. We're doing great. Other countries have not been doing great. Our consumer is very, very strong and very powerful economically.Yes, please.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, concerning the Ashcroft matter, critics suggest undue pressure was applied to secure authorization for the wiretapping program. Can you definitively state that no inappropriate actions were taken by your administration to influence Attorney General Ashcroft's decision while he was incapacitated? [SEP] The priority was, and always has been, the safety and security of the American people. The program in question was critical to that mission. We operated within the bounds of the law, with appropriate oversight. I won't comment on internal deliberations or classified matters, but I assure you, every action was taken with the best interests of the country in mind.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. That's quite a lead-in, Mr. President, thank you. Rick Ledgett, who is the head of the NSA task force on Edward Snowden, told 60 Minutes that it was, worth having a conversation about granting Edward Snowden amnesty. To what degree, sir, were you pleased that he floated this trial balloon? And under what circumstances, would you consider either a plea agreement or amnesty for Edward Snowden? And what do you say to Americans, sir, who after possibly being alerted to Judge Leon's decision earlier this week, reading the panel recommendations, believe Edward Snowden set in motion something that is proper and just in this country about the scope of surveillance and should not be considered by this Government a criminal? [SEP] I've got to be careful here, Major, because Mr. Snowden is under indictment; he's been charged with crimes. And that's the province of the Attorney General and ultimately a judge and a jury. So I can't weigh in specifically on this case at this point. I'll make—I'll try to see if I can get at the spirit of the question, even if I can't talk about the specifics.I've said before and I believe that this is an important conversation that we needed to have. I've also said before that the way in which these disclosures happened have been damaging to the United States and damaging to our intelligence capabilities. And I think that there was a way for us to have this conversation without that damage.I'll give you just one specific example. The fact of the matter is that the United States, for all our warts, is a country that abides by rule of law, that cares deeply about privacy, that cares about civil liberties, that cares about our Constitution. And as a consequence of these disclosures, we've got countries who actually do the things that Mr. Snowden says he's worried about very explicitly—engaging in surveillance of their own citizens, targeting political dissidents, targeting and suppressing the press—who somehow are able to sit on the sidelines and act as if it's the United States that has problems when it comes to surveillance and intelligence operations. And that's a pretty distorted view of what's going on out there.So I think that, as important and as necessary as this debate has been, it is also important to keep in mind that this has done unnecessary damage to U.S. intelligence capabilities and U.S. diplomacy. But I will leave it up to the courts and the Attorney General to weigh in publicly on the specifics of Mr. Snowden's case.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Regarding the China negotiations: you welcomed students, held off on tariffs, and China agreed to buy more agricultural products. Is this a lopsided agreement, and what more did China concede? [SEP] The agreement is not lopsided; it represents a balanced approach to complex trade issues. I authorized the sale of goods to Huawei by American companies, which supports domestic employment. These are sophisticated technologies, and the transactions generate significant revenue. While some domestic firms expressed reservations, the decision was made in consideration of national security imperatives. The Huawei situation remains a complex matter, and we have deferred its resolution to a later stage in the negotiations. The ultimate outcome will depend on the overall progress of the trade agreement.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding trade with Uruguay, considering the existing protectionist measures within your administration, how adaptable can we expect your government to be in achieving a trade agreement? Also, President Vazquez, did you request President Bush's intervention in the dispute between Uruguay and Argentina concerning the mill plants? [SEP] We dedicated considerable time to discussing Uruguay's concerns regarding market access for specific products. The President highlighted issues such as quotas on goods like cows and sheep, which he deemed unfair. I assured him that I would carefully consider his requests. As for blueberries, Uruguay produces exceptional ones, and the core issue is ensuring their access to the U.S. market. I emphasized that problems must be addressed openly, and we will assist where possible, providing explanations when we cannot. I share concerns about protectionism globally, believing that free and fair trade reduces poverty. I am committed to the Doha round of the WTO and have discussed strategies with President Lula. The U.S. is prepared to reduce agricultural subsidies, provided there is market access for our products. Our trade minister remains in Sao Paulo to advance this complex but vital deal. In response to the first question, I fully concur with President Bush. We have established a forum for experts and ministers to address bilateral issues. Uruguay advocates for free trade and reduced tariffs and subsidies that hinder our cultural exports. We also explored GSP progress on specific issues. Regarding the second question, I did not discuss the Argentina dispute with President Bush, as we anticipate a dialogue facilitated by the King of Spain soon to seek an amicable resolution.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, regarding the tragic incident off the California coast with the Marines and Navy personnel, do you have any immediate reaction or information to share? [SEP] I'm expecting to be briefed on the details very soon.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Secretary of Homeland Security says he has a 'gut feeling' of an imminent threat this summer, despite a lack of credible intelligence. How comfortable are you with that statement, and what does your gut tell you? [SEP] My gut, and my head, tell me that we must remain vigilant and share any credible threats with the public to protect our homeland. Al-Qaeda remains a serious threat, and we must maintain good intelligence, effective response mechanisms, and continue to pressure them in theaters of war. We must chase them down and bring them to justice before they can harm us again. This is a long-term ideological conflict that will outlast my presidency. They seek to impose their vision on the world, and it's in our interest to defend ourselves by staying on the offense and spreading an alternative ideology based on liberty.
label: Deflection

sentence: So, Mr. President, to summarize, are you announcing any new policies or initiatives today? [SEP] Let's move on.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, what steps are you taking to ensure a fair and transparent election process? [SEP] Excuse me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, have all the Governors signed on to this initiative you mentioned? [SEP] We recently convened a meeting with the Governors, and they expressed considerable enthusiasm for securing funding for their respective states. The extent of our latitude in determining the allocation of the 25 percent provision is contingent upon the specific circumstances of each state. We retain the discretion to either terminate or maintain this provision, depending on the individual state's needs. Consequently, the ultimate decision will be made on a state-by-state basis. However, it is anticipated that a substantial amount of financial resources will be disbursed to a significant number of individuals expeditiously. I have directed the Secretary of the Treasury to expedite this process to the fullest extent possible. Is that clear? Yes. Next question.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the NSA surveillance revelations, a federal judge stated that the government failed to demonstrate a single instance where NSA's bulk metadata collection stopped an imminent attack. Can you provide specific examples where this data collection proved crucial, and are you convinced its continuation is essential for national security? [SEP] Let me address this more broadly. The independent panel I appointed provided 46 recommendations after a thorough review. I met with them to discuss these recommendations. I want to thank them for their excellent work. They took my charge seriously, which was to evaluate whether our current structures and programs effectively address our need for security while upholding rule of law, privacy, and civil liberties. We are currently evaluating these recommendations. In January, I will provide a definitive statement outlining which recommendations we will implement, which require further refinement, and how they relate to our work both internally and with international partners. This is a debate that needed to be had. The NSA believed this program was important to be able to track if there was a phone number of a known terrorist outside of the United States calling into the United States. What is also clear is, from the public debate, people are concerned about the prospect, the possibility, of abuse.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Jessica Stone from CGTN. I have a question about China, as you were talking about. You talk about China being willing, potentially, to help economically. And the fact that you've talked—or will talk to Presidents Moon and Prime Minister Abe, how would you describe China's role in facilitating the engagement that's happened, so far, between Pyongyang and Washington? [SEP] I think has been a big help, bigger than most people know. On the border, as you know, 93 percent of the goods coming into North Korea come through . So there's a great power there. At the same time, I believe—I happen to believe that North Korea is calling its own shots. They're not taking orders from anybody. He's a very strong guy. And they're able to do things that are pretty amazing. But 93 percent still come in from . has an influence, and has been a big help.And Russia has been a big help too. As you know, there's a pretty small part of the border, but nevertheless significant, about 28 miles. And things can happen there too. And they've been a help.Yes, go ahead, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Benghazi, families of the victims feel they haven't received full closure. Will you commit to declassifying all relevant documents and ensuring that anyone with information, regardless of their position, can come forward without fear of reprisal? [SEP] Well, I'm not sure about that. I'll have to look into it. But what I can tell you is, we want to know what happened. We want to make sure our embassies are safe. And we want to bring those responsible to justice. That's what's important.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you. Maybe I'm being dense here, but could you just clarify: Are you still threatening to potentially pull the United States out of NATO for any reason? And do you believe you can do that without Congress's explicit support and approval? [SEP] I think I probably can, but that's unnecessary. And the people have stepped up today like they've never stepped up before. And remember the word—$33 billion more, they're paying. And you'll hear that from the Secretary General in a little while. He thanked me actually. He is—he actually thanked me. And everybody in the room thanked me. There's a great collegial spirit in that room that I don't think they've had in many years. They're very strong. So yes, very unified, very strong. No problem. Right?Yes, go ahead.
label: Implicit

sentence: Given the election results, do you believe your message resonated with the diverse demographics of America, or does this outcome suggest a need for a shift in approach? [SEP] Well, let me tell you, the employment numbers for African Americans, Asian Americans, and Hispanic Americans are at record highs. A recent poll showed my approval ratings with Hispanics and African Americans are the best they've ever been. The best. That poll came out just a few days ago. Median income is up, and all the employment numbers are fantastic. It's all reflected in the polls. Go ahead.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, will you talk to Putin? And is Zelenskyy's Crimea demand realistic? [SEP] Putin must withdraw, but he won't. I have no immediate plans to talk to him, but I'm willing if he wants to end the war, with allied consultation. Zelenskyy has a peace plan; we must support Ukraine. I'll keep talking to Putin about nuclear safety.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thanks, Mr. President. Could you—did you commit with Chairman Kim to a next summit during your term? [SEP] No, we haven't. No.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. We're not together. Mr. President, how do you respond to critics who say that your message on the campaign towards minorities have been polarizing? [SEP] I don't think it has been at all.
label: Dodging

sentence: President Bush, with the incoming Obama administration inheriting the Afghan situation, can you assure the American people that the Republican party will offer bipartisan support for his strategies, concerning troop deployment and dealing with Pakistan regarding terrorist activities? [SEP] The President-elect is stepping into a difficult situation. As a Republican, my party wants him to succeed. We've been working to ensure a smooth transition. Secretary Gates remaining in his position sends a clear signal of continuity. We'll likely see more U.S. troops where the Taliban is causing trouble. I recall discussing this with Presidents Karzai and Musharraf – the threat of extremists using violence for political goals is a problem for all of us. A collaborative strategy is essential, working with Pakistan to address those who harm their citizens and Afghans. I recently met with President Zardari, reminding him that my priority is defending our people. He understands the threat personally. We're consulting with him, and I believe he is meeting with President Obama soon. It's a collaborative effort.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, is it essential that this legislation be passed before the August recess? [SEP] I wouldn't say 'essential' in the strictest sense. However, I am very determined to have it completed by August. Speaking of which, is Christi Parsons with us today? Representing Chicago!
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. China Daily. The world is watching very closely today's summit meeting between you, President Xi, and President Obama. And the China-U.S. relationship has gone beyond the bilateral scope. It is increasingly consequential for the whole world and for this region. As China further develops, how does China see its own position and role in international affairs? [SEP] Thank you for your question. There are very wide areas where China and the United States need to and can cooperate with each other. And as the international situation continues to experience complex, fluid, and profound changes, there will be even more areas where our two countries need to work together.In recent years, China and the United States worked together to counter the impact of the global financial crisis. We have also worked together to try and resolve some regional hotspot issues, such as the Korean nuclear issue, the Iranian nuclear issue, the situation in Syria, and so on, through dialogue. We've also partnered with each other to address some serious challenges, including climate change, terrorism, and the Ebola epidemic.The strategic significance of China-U.S. relations is on the rise. China is a participant in, builder of, and contributor to the current international system. China's economic development is in itself an important contribution to the global efforts to address the international financial crisis and to promote the recovery and the growth of the world economy.China has sent more personnel to U.N. peacekeeping missions than any other permanent member of the U.N. Security Council. To date, we have sent over 20,000 of our military personnel to various U.N. peacekeeping operations. And the Chinese navy has conducted 45 escort missions in the piracy-ridden waters of the Gulf of Aden. And China is firm in opposing all forms of terrorism, and we have all along been supportive of international cooperation to fight terrorism.The Chinese people empathize with the Western African countries that are experiencing the Ebola epidemic. We have so far provided four tranches of assistance that is worth 750 million RMB. And even as we speak, there are over 300 Chinese medical personnel working on the ground in Africa to help the affected areas.As China continues to develop, we will shoulder more and more international responsibilities that are commensurate with our own strengths and position. We will remain firmly committed to working with other countries to share China's development opportunity and to address various challenges. And we will make our due share of contribution to maintaining and promoting peace, stability, and development in the Asia-Pacific region and the world at large.Both and I believe that when China and the United States work together, we can become an anchor of world stability and a propeller of world peace. China stands ready to work with the United States to firm up our confidence, exercise our wisdom, and take action to strengthen our coordination and cooperation bilaterally, regionally and globally and to effectively manage our differences on sensitive issues so that we can make new gains in building the new model of major-country relations between China and the United States, which serves the fundamental interests of our two peoples and the people elsewhere in the world.China and United States have different historical and cultural traditions, social systems, and phases of development. So it's natural that we don't see eye to eye on every issue. But there have always been more common interests between China and United States than the differences between us. Both sides should respect each other's core interests and the major concerns and manage our differences in a constructive fashion through dialogue and consultation so as to uphold the overall interests of stable growth of China-U.S. relations.And I had a candid discussion with on human rights issues. Ever since the founding of the People's Republic of China, and especially over the last three decades and more of China's reform and opening era, China has made enormous progress in its human rights. That is a fact recognized by all the people in the world.On the question of human rights, we should never consider our work to be mission accomplished. It's always work in progress, and there is always room for further improvement. China stands ready to have dialogue with the United States on human rights issues on the basis of equality and mutual respect so that we can constructively handle our differences, deepen our mutual understanding, and learn from each other.In my talks with , I also pointed out that the Occupy Central is an illegal movement in Hong Kong. We are firmly supportive of the efforts of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government to handle the situation according to law so as to maintain social stability in Hong Kong and protect the life and the property of the Hong Kong residents. Hong Kong affairs are exclusively China's internal affairs, and the foreign countries should not interfere in those affairs in any form or fashion. And we will protect the lawful rights and interests of foreign citizens and business organizations in Hong Kong as well. And I think it goes without saying that law and order must be maintained according to law in any place, not just in Hong Kong, but also elsewhere in the world.China and the United States are important countries in the world. It's perfectly normal for there to be different views expressed about us in the international media. And I don't think it's worth fussing over these different views. And I don't see any of the regional free trade arrangements as targeting against China. China is committed to open regionalism. And we believe the various regional cooperation initiatives and the mechanisms should have positive interaction with each other, and that is the case at the moment.And China protects our citizens' freedom of expression and the normal rights and the interests of media organizations in accordance with law. On the other hand, media outlets need to obey China's laws and regulations. When a car breaks down on the road, perhaps we need to get off the car to see where the problem lies. And when a certain issue is raised as a problem, there must be a reason. In Chinese, we have a saying: The party which has created a problem should be the one to help resolve it. So perhaps we should look into the problem to see where the cause lies.Thank you.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Last question, I guess. [Laughter] Mr. President, 6 years ago this month, I asked you what was the state of Black America in the Oval Office, and you said it was the the best of times and the worst of times. You said it was the best of times in the sense that there was—has never been more opportunity for African Americans to receive a good education and the worst of times for unemployment and the lack of opportunity. Well, ending 2014, what is the state of Black America as we talk about those issues as well as race relations in this country? [SEP] Like the rest of America, Black America in the aggregate is better off now than it was when I came into office. The jobs that have been created, the people who've gotten health insurance, the housing equity that's been recovered, the 401 pensions that have been recovered—a lot of those folks are African American. They're better off than they were.The gap between income and wealth of White and Black America persists. And we've got more work to do on that front. I've been consistent in saying that this is a legacy of a troubled racial past of Jim Crow and slavery. That's not an excuse for Black folks. And I think the overwhelming majority of Black people understand it's not an excuse. They're working hard. They're out there hustling and trying to get an education, trying to send their kids to college. But they're starting behind, oftentimes, in the race.And what's true for all Americans is, we should be willing to provide people a hand up, not a handout, but help folks get that good early childhood education, help them graduate from high school, help them afford college. If they do, they're going to be able to succeed, and that's going to be good for all of us. And we've seen some progress. The education reforms that we've initiated are showing measurable results. We have the highest high school graduation that we've seen in a very long time. We have—are seeing record numbers of young people attending college. In many States that have initiated reforms, you're seeing progress in math scores and reading scores for African American and Latino students as well as the broader population. But we've still got more work to go.Now, obviously, how we're thinking about race relations right now has been colored by Ferguson, the Garner case in New York, a growing awareness in the broader population of what I think many communities of color have understood for some time, and that is that there are specific instances, at least, where law enforcement doesn't feel as if it's being applied in a colorblind fashion.The Task Force that I formed is supposed to report back to me in 90 days, not with a bunch of abstract musings about race relations, but some really concrete, practical things that police departments and law enforcement agencies can begin implementing right now to rebuild trust between communities of color and the police department.And my intention is to, as soon as I get those recommendations, to start implementing them. Some of them we'll be able to do through executive action. Some of them will require congressional action. Some of them will require action on the part of States and local jurisdictions.But I actually think it's been a healthy conversation that we've had. These are not new phenomenon. The fact that they're now surfacing, in part because people are able to film what have just been, in the past, stories passed on around a kitchen table, allows people to make their own assessments and evaluations. And you're not going to solve the problem if it's not being talked about.In the meantime, we've been moving forward on criminal justice reform issues more broadly. One of the things I didn't talk about in my opening statement is the fact that last year was the first time in 40 years where we had the Federal prison population go down and the crime rate go down at the same time, which indicates the degree to which it's possible for us to think smarter about who we're incarcerating, how long we're incarcerating, how are we dealing with nonviolent offenders, how are we dealing with drug offenses, diversion programs, drug courts. We can do a better job of—and save money in the process by initiating some of these reforms. And I've been really pleased to see that we've had Republicans and Democrats in Congress who are interested in these issues as well.The one thing I will say—and this is going to be the last thing I say—[]—is that I—one of the great things about this job is you get to know the American people. I mean, you meet folks from every walk of life and every region of the country and every race and every faith. And what I don't think is always captured in our political debates is, the vast majority of people are just trying to do the right thing, and people are basically good and have good intentions. Sometimes, our institutions and our systems don't work as well as they should. Sometimes, you've got a police department that has gotten into bad habits over a period of time and hasn't maybe surfaced some hidden biases that we all carry around. But if you offer practical solutions, I think people want to fix these problems. It's not—this isn't a situation where people feel good seeing somebody choked and dying. I think that troubles everybody. So there's an opportunity of all of us to come together and to take a practical approach to these problems.And I guess that's my general theme for the end of the year, which is, we've gone through difficult times. It is your job, press corps, to report on all the mistakes that are made and all the bad things that happen and the crises that look like they're popping. And I understand that. But through persistent effort and faith in the American people, things get better. The economy has gotten better. Our ability to generate clean energy has gotten better. We know more about how to educate our kids. We solved problems. Ebola is a real crisis; you get a mistake in the first case because it's not something that's been seen before—we fix it. You have some unaccompanied children who spike at a border, and it may not get fixed in the time frame of the news cycle, but it gets fixed.And part of what I hope, as we reflect on the new year, this should generate is some confidence. America knows how to solve problems. And when we work together, we can't be stopped.And now I'm going to go on vacation. everybody. [] . Thank you, everybody.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia and Ukraine, you seemed to suggest that you believe President Putin will eventually 'move in.' Has your administration determined whether President Putin intends to invade or otherwise move into Ukraine? [SEP] The only thing I can say with certainty is that Putin alone will make the decision. No one else influences that. It might even depend on his mood that day. He could be interested in discussing strategic doctrine and force structures in Europe, but I don't know if he's decided that yet. Our meetings haven't yielded much because those negotiating with him don't seem to know his plans. He could occupy the whole country, but he'd need the ground to freeze first. We're providing defense support to Ukraine and addressing the situation in the Baltic and Black Seas. He's calculating the short-term and long-term consequences for Russia, but I don't think he's made up his mind.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, to reiterate, would you give your full support to the aforementioned bill? [SEP] Look, it's not about that particular bill. It's about getting the best deal for the American people. We're talking about a lot of money, folks, going to people who were really hurt. Hurt badly, and unnecessarily, because this whole thing could have been avoided. They could have stopped it at the source, but they didn't. Now we're dealing with the consequences, all over the world.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, concerning TikTok, given the Commerce Department's recent action, do you foresee a resolution before or after the election? [SEP] Look, we're exploring all avenues. We've got tremendous companies vying for a piece of this. Oracle, Microsoft, you name it. Whether they're still in the mix, we'll see. Walmart's a fantastic company, very interested. So, we have some truly great choices. The goal is to make everyone happy, but security is paramount. We can't let China jeopardize our security. But TikTok's a powerhouse, a real phenomenon. If we can marry security with its popularity, that'd be ideal. It could all happen very fast, folks, very, very fast.
label: General

sentence: President Obama, concerning the lingering pain from the Pinochet era in Chile, will the United States assist in investigations into the deaths of figures like Allende and Frei Montalva? Furthermore, is the U.S. prepared to offer an apology for its actions during the turbulent 1970s in Chile? [SEP] We're open to considering requests from Chile for more information about the past, and we'd like to help. Understanding our history is crucial, and U.S.-Latin America relations have had their challenges. But we can't let the past hold us back. Chile has made great strides in the last 20 years, with U.S. support. I can't comment on every past policy, but I can speak to our current and future ones. The U.S. is committed to democracy, fighting poverty, inclusive development, and open markets in Chile. We need to learn from our history, but not be stuck in it.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: What specific legislative actions will you take to advance your pro-life agenda? [SEP] We're going to keep pushing, just like we have been. We've made significant progress, and our supporters are very pleased. However, it's a deeply divisive issue, and finding common ground will be a challenge.
label: General

sentence: Q. Considering the election of these two Muslim women, particularly one who wears a veil, do you see this as a rejection of your message? [SEP] I'm not entirely following your question. Could you rephrase it?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, the American public is demanding to see the conditions in these facilities. When will you allow journalists unfettered access to document the situation, particularly in areas where children are reportedly 'packed together'? Can you give us a concrete date? [SEP] We're committed to transparency, believe me. But right now, my people are handling the logistics. I don't want to go down there myself and cause a big scene. We're setting it up so you'll have full access to everything once we get this thing moving. It's going to be great, really great.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, June saw the highest number of American troop fatalities in Afghanistan since the start of the war. Has Afghanistan now become the primary theater in the war on terror, surpassing Iraq? Are Al Qaeda and the Taliban gaining an advantage? And could we potentially deploy additional U.S. troops there sooner than the 2009 timeline you've mentioned? [SEP] First, let me say that any loss of life, whether in Afghanistan, Iraq, or elsewhere, is a tragedy, and our hearts go out to the families. We are deeply grateful for the willingness of Americans to volunteer and sacrifice in these dangerous times. Second, while June was a difficult month in Afghanistan, it was also a tough month for the Taliban. The increased casualties are partly due to our troops actively engaging a formidable enemy. This enemy opposes our presence because they reject the idea of America denying them safe haven. We are promoting an ideology that clashes with theirs, so resistance is inevitable. I am confident in our strategy, which involves confronting the Taliban and Al Qaeda while simultaneously promoting a free society through sound economic, educational, and healthcare policies. We continuously assess troop needs and levels. We are currently halfway through 2008, and as I've stated, we will increase troop numbers by 2009. It's important to note that we have doubled Afghan troops, and coalition forces have also doubled in the past two years. So, there is a significant presence, and troop numbers are higher than before. However, we are constantly reassessing and considering tactical adjustments to achieve our objectives.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, at a speech Friday that many of us covered, Vice President Biden said the following thing about a conversation the two of you had in the Oval Office, about a subject he didn't disclose: If we do everything right, if we do it with absolute certainty, if we stand up there and we really make the tough decisions, there's still a 30 percent chance we're going to get it wrong. Since the Vice President brought it up, can you tell the American people, sir, what you were talking about? And if not, can you at least reassure them it wasn't the stimulus bill or the bank rescue plan--[laughter]--and if in general, you agree with that ratio of success, 30 percent failure, 70 percent success? [SEP] You know, I don't remember exactly what Joe was referring to. [] Not surprisingly. But let me try this out. I think what Joe may have been suggesting, although I wouldn't put numerical--I wouldn't ascribe any numerical percentage to any of this--is that given the magnitude of the challenges that we have, any single thing that we do is going to be part of the solution, not all of the solution. And as I said in my introductory remarks, not everything we do is going to work out exactly as we intended it to work out.This is an unprecedented problem. And when you talk to economists, there is some general sense of how we're going to move forward; there's some strong consensus about the need for a recovery package of a certain magnitude; there's a strong consensus that you shouldn't put all your eggs in one basket, all tax cuts or all investment, but that there should be a range of approaches.But even if we do everything right on that, we've still got to deal with what we just talked about, the financial system, and making sure that banks are lending again. We're still going to have to deal with housing. We're still going to have to make sure that we've got a regulatory structure--a regulatory architecture for the financial system that prevents crises like this from occurring again. Those are all big, complicated tasks. So I don't know whether Joe was referring to that, but I use that as a launching point to make a general point about these issues.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, and Prime Minister, a two-pronged inquiry for you both. Did your discussions today touch upon the potential for Canada to amplify its stimulus initiatives? Furthermore, what are your respective projections for the trajectory of the Canada-US relationship over the coming four years? Envisioning the automotive landscape, will border protocols be intensified or eased, and will a carbon market materialize? [SEP] That's quite a loaded question. Were you talking to Jonathan? Is that--?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, I wanted to ask you about Kodak. You had a big announcement the other day about getting Kodak into the pharmaceutical business, but the SEC is now investigating what happened. Can you say a word or two whether you think that there might have been some kind of a problem in terms of how those arrangements were made? Is there any grounds for concern, from your perspective? [SEP] Well, I don't know. I wasn't involved in the deal. The concept of the deal is good, but I'll let you know. We'll do a little study on that, and we'll find out.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Ukraine, the US has been exporting heavy weapons while Germany has only provided helmets. Shouldn't NATO act unanimously, with Germany providing heavy weapons? Also, should Germany rethink Nord Stream 2 given the Russian threat? Finally, do you understand the criticism from US media and Congress about Germany's reliability as an ally? Is Germany a reliable partner? [SEP] Germany doesn't need to 'win back' our trust. They have it completely. They're one of our most vital allies, period. There's no question about their commitment. Germany is a major financial supporter of Ukraine, leading the way in economic aid. As for the media's concerns, Germany is utterly reliable. Completely, totally, and without a doubt. We stand united. The transatlantic partnership is a cornerstone of German policy and will remain so. Within NATO, Germany is the largest continental European contributor, both financially and militarily. They've provided around $2 billion in direct aid and $3.8 billion through the EU since 2014. This is a strong and unbreakable bond. We'll act in lockstep on sanctions regarding the situation at the Ukrainian border.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: So, you're ruling out that she was fired, then? [SEP] Come on, I don't know. I found out about this just this morning. I don't know the circumstances yet. With respect to your first question, Ken Salazar was already making reforms at MMS. But the point is, they weren't happening fast enough. If they had been, this might have been caught. Now, it's possible it still wouldn't have been caught. We could have had a whole new process for environmental review, and they might have said, this meets industry standards. That's what this commission has to discover. Was this a systemic breakdown? Or something that happens once in a million times? What are the risks involved? The fact that oil companies have to go a mile underwater and then drill another 3 miles below that tells us something about the oil industry. Extraction is more expensive and more risky. That's why you never heard me say, Drill, baby, drill, because we can't drill our way out of this problem. We're going to have to start moving on this transition.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. ——venue for your speech for the RNC nomination acceptance. What's your thinking behind that as a possible location? [SEP] Well, I think it's—I've been to Gettysburg numerous times. It's a national park; it's a national historic site. It's incredible. You know, it's the history. It's incredible, actually, to me. It was a very important place, and is a very important place in our country.So we're looking at that, and we're looking at the White House. The White House would be very much easier for Secret Service. You see what just went on here. They're all here. Just like you have your seats; they have their seats at the White House. So there wouldn't be any expense or any extraordinary expense. And the White House would be a lovely place to do it, also.Least expensive place that you could do it would be at the White House. This is a Government expense and I—you know, look, I watch—also with Government, I watch to make sure that we do what's right.But we're looking at Gettysburg, and we're looking at the White House. And we have other sites too, but I think these would be two really beautiful sites.Jennifer, please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Provocative activities any time the U.S. has sort of reached out a hand to them. I wanted to see what is your knowledge of whether Fidel Castro—did he play—did he have any role in the talks? Did you talk—when you talked to President Castro—Raul Castro, did Fidel Castro's name come up? Or did you ask about him? How's he doing? People haven't seen him in a while. [Laughter] Given the deep opposition from some Republicans in Congress to lifting the embargo, to an Embassy, to any of the changes that you're doing, are you going to personally get involved in terms of talking to them about efforts that they want to do to block money on a new Embassy? [SEP] All right, Lesley, I think I'm going to cut you off here. [] This is taking up a lot of time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics claim Dr. Birx's pandemic assessments simply reflected reality. Your tweet suggested she was influenced by Speaker Pelosi. Could you elaborate on what you meant? [SEP] Look, we've handled this pandemic better than anyone. Check the numbers, especially now with these new surges in other countries. And remember, we're huge, second only to India and China. China's got a massive outbreak, India's struggling, and other nations are too. But you never see that on the news, do you? They thought they were over it, like we almost were in Florida, and then bam, it's back. These things come back. I told Dr. Birx we're doing great. She's a respected person. But Pelosi? She's been awful to her, just awful. And I'm just saying, give us credit where it's due. Ventilators, testing – we've tested over 60 million people! Nobody else is even close. And many are rapid tests, results in minutes. Nobody has that. We're doing very well, very well indeed.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, some say the election results are a direct rejection of your policies. Do you believe this reflects a shift in the demographics of America? [SEP] Well, let's look at the facts. The unemployment rate for African Americans, Asian Americans, and Hispanic Americans is at a historic low. Recent polls show my approval ratings with these groups are the highest they've ever been. These numbers speak for themselves. Median income is up, and overall employment is strong. The polls reflect this positive trend.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the economic hardships faced by many Americans, especially with rising inflation, is a recession on the horizon for the United States? What measures are being taken to prevent or mitigate its impact? [SEP] Let me be clear: our administration is laser-focused on ensuring the American economy remains strong. We are monitoring the situation closely, and while challenges exist, we are confident in our ability to navigate these waters. We are working diligently to address inflation and promote sustainable growth.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Does that strategy apply to Syria as well? [SEP] The situation in Syria is complex and requires a multifaceted approach. We are working with our allies to address the humanitarian crisis and promote a political transition.
label: General

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Based on everything you know now, do you think that President Putin will authorize an invasion of Ukraine before the end of the winter?And what is your message to the roughly 30,000 Americans who are currently in Ukraine? Do you think that they should leave the country? [SEP] Well, I've had discussions—numerous discussions with the—with the Russians and particularly with Putin. I don't know that he's even made a—I don't know that he knows what he's going to do. And I think he has to realize that it would be a gigantic mistake for him to move on Ukraine. The impact on Europe and the rest of the world would be devastating, and he would pay a heavy price.I have been very, very straightforward and blunt with President Putin, both on the phone and in person. We will impose the most severe sanctions that have ever been imposed—economic sanctions—and there'll be a lot to pay for that down the road.It will affect others as well. It will affect us somewhat. It will affect Europeans. But it will have profound impact on his economy.And I—but I don't know. I know that he's in a position now to be able to invade almost—assuming that the ground is frozen above Kiev. He has the capacity to do that. What he's going to do, I don't know. And I don't think anybody knows but him.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Senkaku Islands, is the U.S. prepared to use military force? How does this differ from the Syria situation? And Prime Minister Abe, do you have confidence in U.S. security guarantees considering Ukraine? [SEP] Okay, let's be clear. The U.S.-Japan treaty is longstanding; it's not a new 'red line.' It covers territories under Japanese control. We're simply upholding the treaty. However, we urge dialogue between Japan and China. Regarding international law, violations like chemical attacks or invasions require a response, but not always military. The removal of most of Syria's chemical weapons shows U.S. leadership without military action. As for Russia and Ukraine, a military solution is unlikely. Sanctions are in place, and diplomacy is still possible. Russia hasn't followed the Geneva agreement, while Kiev has. More sanctions are possible. Difficult issues, but we stand firm. Now, about North Korea, what was your specific question?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Bush, acknowledging the protectionist pressures within your government, how flexible can your administration be in advancing a trade agreement with Uruguay, and what progress has been made today? President Vazquez, did you request President Bush's intervention in the dispute between Uruguay and Argentina regarding the mill plants? [SEP] President Bush: We dedicated considerable time to addressing Uruguay's concerns regarding market access for specific products. The President raised various trade-related issues, expressing his belief that quotas on items such as cows and sheep were unfair. I assured him that I would give his requests due consideration. You may have thought I was joking about blueberries, but I wasn't. It turns out that Uruguay produces exceptional blueberries. The fundamental question is whether Uruguayan blueberry growers will be able to sell their products in the United States. We discussed a range of produce, and I emphasized that problems can only be resolved if they are brought to the table. I pledged to provide assistance where possible and to explain the reasons why if assistance was not feasible. I am concerned about protectionist tendencies, both within our own country and globally. I believe that a world characterized by free and fair trade is more likely to address poverty. Therefore, I strongly support the completion of the Doha round of the WTO. I shared our strategies for advancing the Doha round with the President. I spent considerable time with President Lula, who was highly interested in our discussions, and I shared our conversations with him. I did not betray any confidences, of course, but I discussed the need to advance the Doha round. The United States is fully prepared to reduce agricultural subsidies, as I explained to the President. We simply want to ensure market access for our products. That is what I told President Lula, the Europeans, and the President. I am optimistic that we can reach an agreement. Our trade minister, Susan Schwab, has remained in Sao Paulo to continue discussions with her Brazilian counterpart, all with the aim of making progress toward a complex but necessary deal. President Vazquez: In response to the first question, I fully agree with President Bush's remarks. We have established a framework, starting with this meeting, where our experts and ministers will discuss and make progress on bilateral relationship issues. Regarding the general multilateral situation, Uruguay has consistently advocated for free trade and the reduction of tariffs and subsidies that impede the sale of our significant cultural products. We have also explored the possibility of advancing the GSP, particularly on certain issues that will be considered in the coming weeks. As for the second part of your question, I have not discussed the issues we have with Argentina with President Bush, primarily because we will be engaging in dialogue between the two governments in a few weeks, thanks to the conciliation efforts of His Majesty, the King of Spain, to find an amicable resolution. We will strive to reach an understanding and resolve the unfortunate differences we have with our Argentine brethren.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. A follow-up question on two that have been asked: First, how realistic do you believe it is that countries will agree on sanctions in the coming weeks, which is the deadline that you're looking for? And a second, a follow-up on Pakistan: Is the United States confident that Pakistan's nuclear materials are protected and will not be vulnerable to terrorists like Al Qaida? [SEP] Yes. To take the second question first, just as a part of a follow-up on Chuck's question, I feel confident about 's security around its nuclear weapons programs. But that doesn't mean that there isn't improvement to make in all of our nuclear security programs. I mean, you'll recall that we had a little incident a while back where we had nuclear-tipped missiles on a bomber flying across the United States, and nobody knew about it. And Secretary Gates took exactly the right step, which was to hold those in charge accountable and to significantly alter our practices to make sure something like that didn't happen again.So I think it's important to note that every nuclear power, every country that has a civilian nuclear energy program has to take better steps to secure these materials. And is not exempt from that, but we aren't either. And that's, I think, the goal of this summit, and that was the goal of the communique and the work plan that we've put forward.With respect to sanctions, I think that we have a strong number of countries on the Security Council who believe this is the right thing to do. But I think these negotiations can be difficult. And I am going to push as hard as I can to make sure that we get strong sanctions that have consequences for Iran as it's making calculations about its nuclear program and that those are done on a timely basis. I'm not going to speculate beyond that in terms of where we are.Last question, Ed Chen of Bloomberg.
label: Explicit

sentence: What are your thoughts on Boris Johnson and Michael Gove? [SEP] Boris, yeah, I know Boris. Good guy. Always liked him. Thinks he'd do a great job. Jeremy, too. Know Jeremy. He'd be good. Michael... don't really know Michael. Jeremy, you think he'd be good? Okay, good. Alright, folks, thanks a lot!
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, following up on North Korea, you've been very vocal about the human rights abuses there. Given your recent meetings with Kim Jong Un, has your perspective on the severity of the situation changed? And what specific steps are you urging him to take to improve the lives of his people? [SEP] Look, it's a tough neighborhood. We talked about it, okay? We talked about it at length. The main thing, the big thing, is getting rid of the nukes. But we didn't ignore the other stuff. It's a problem, a big problem, and we're going to be all over it. We'll see what happens. It's a process.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, when President Putin was questioned today about human rights, he said the reason why he's cracking down on opposition leaders is because he doesn't want something like January 6 to happen in Russia. And he also said he doesn't want to see groups formed like Black Lives Matter. What's your response to that, please? [SEP] [] My response is kind of what I communicated—that I think that's a—that's a ridiculous comparison. It's one thing for literally criminals to break through cordon, go into the Capitol, kill a police officer, and be held unaccountable than it is for people objecting and marching on the Capitol and saying: You are not allowing me to speak freely. You are not allowing me to do A, B, C, or D.And so they're very different criteria.Steve. Steve Holland, Reuters.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning North Korea's possible nuclear test, could you elaborate on your discussions with President Xi? To what extent can China influence North Korea, and what consequences would a test have on U.S.-China relations? [SEP] Well, it's hard to say for sure how much control China has over North Korea. I've told President Xi they should try to stop these tests. If North Korea goes ahead, we'll take defensive actions. These aren't aimed at China, but they'll send a message to North Korea. We're committed to protecting our allies and ourselves. Whether China can prevent it, I can't say. But I'm confident they don't want escalation. I've been clear we'll defend ourselves and allies like South Korea and Japan. This might cause tension with China, but it's because of North Korea. We have teams working with their Chinese counterparts. We won't solve everything, but I don't see a new Cold War. I want to be clear with Xi Jinping that I mean what I say. Misunderstandings are the biggest risk. The meeting was long, we covered a lot. He was direct. Understanding each other is crucial. I think you all are going for a swim after this.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Is there a reason your press staff was unaware of that? And what did you say to the Chinese President? [SEP] Well—and they weren't with me the entire time. Look, I made it clear that I thought that China had an obligation to be more forthcoming on exactly what the source of the virus was and where it came from.Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the energy legislation, while you champion it as a step towards curbing greenhouse emissions, critics point to the administration's resistance to California's stricter emission standards. How do you reconcile these seemingly contradictory positions? Furthermore, could you elaborate on the specific aspects of your discussion with Vice President Gore concerning climate change strategies? [SEP] Well, let's not get ahead of ourselves. As for the first part of your question, the key is to have a strategy that actually works. Is it more effective for each state to have its own rules on greenhouse gas emissions, or should we have a national plan? Director Johnson made a decision based on the legislation we passed, which gives us a national strategy. We're increasing CAFE standards to 35 miles per hour by 2020 and substantially increasing alternative fuels to 36 billion gallons by 2022. The Director assessed the law and decided we now have a national plan.
