[SEP] Addressing your second point first, I made it abundantly clear to Mr. Putin that we possess considerable cyber capabilities. He's aware of this, though the specifics remain undisclosed. Should they contravene these established norms, our response will be in the cyber realm. He understands this much.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, Germany is pushing for renewed action from the Middle East Quartet. Considering the limited success of past efforts and the challenges of influencing a superpower like the US, can you provide an example of a time when a European leader convinced you to change your mind on a key issue? [SEP] I wouldn't say it's a 'change of mind,' exactly, but my European friends have shown me that the UN is important for convincing parliaments to do hard things. Getting UN resolutions helps countries like Denmark or Holland get their parliaments on board. I've never felt like the US *needs* UN approval, but I see that other countries rely on it, and I respect that. So, I've learned something from my allies there. I listen to Angela Merkel a lot. She's got a lot of wisdom. Don't know if that helps her, but she gives me good advice. The US needs good relations with Europe to get things done, whether it's trade or peace or security. Relations can be tough, not everyone agrees. But Angela helps me deal with common problems so our alliance works. I am a strong believer in this multilateral effort in these international fora, because it shows clearly where the redline is to those who do not wish for democracy. And this is what we need to do, time and again make it clear to them where the limits are, where the redlines are. No back rubs. []
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. So you'll talk about both? [SEP] Talk about both.Vice President Michael R. Pence's Record as Governor of Indiana/
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the situation in Afghanistan seems intractable. What specific metrics are you using to determine success, and when will the American people know if this review has actually made a difference? [SEP] We're looking at a range of indicators, from security improvements and economic development to governance reforms and the strengthening of Afghan institutions. It's not just about military gains; it's about building a sustainable society. And we will continue to assess our progress and adjust our strategy as needed. The American people will know we're making a difference when they see a more stable and prosperous Afghanistan, capable of providing for its own security and future.
label: Deflection

sentence: Prime Minister, addressing this in both English and French: The RCMP's visit to your party headquarters, coupled with Elections Canada's allegations, has raised serious questions. Can you clarify whether you were aware of the alleged scheme, and will it be used again in future campaigns? [SEP] This is simply a continuation of a long-standing disagreement. Elections Canada believes that certain local campaign expenses should be classified as national expenses. We have a different interpretation. We reviewed this matter thoroughly at the time and remain confident in our position. Our party is committed to upholding the law, both in its letter and as it has been historically interpreted. During the last election, we operated in accordance with established legal precedents. Should those interpretations evolve, we will, of course, adapt accordingly, ensuring that the same standards are applied to all political parties. [In French, then translated:] As I mentioned previously, Elections Canada contends that some of our local expenditures should be considered national expenses. We disagree with this assessment, which is why we have pursued legal recourse. Ultimately, we will respect the law and its interpretations, as we have consistently done in the past.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Dilma, there appears to be a divergence in how Brazil and the U.S. view Brazil's role on the world stage. How can these differing viewpoints be reconciled to strengthen bilateral relations? [SEP] I appreciate President Obama's comments. Every nation faces difficulties, and Brazil is no exception. However, these challenges do not diminish our global significance. Brazil is dedicated to overcoming these obstacles and maintaining a robust partnership with the U.S. We share a common history, a commitment to democracy, and a diverse population, all of which serve as a foundation for continued collaboration.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Navalny poisoning, with Germany pointing fingers at Russia, what specific actions should the U.S. take, and what message should we send to the Kremlin? How should the international community respond? [SEP] Look, it's a terrible situation, and we're monitoring it closely. Nobody's been tougher on Russia than me, believe me. We're also making incredible progress on other fronts. We're on the verge of a historic peace deal in the Middle East, something nobody thought was possible. And let's not forget Nord Stream 2 – I was the first to call out Germany for funding Russia's energy dominance. We're also in crucial nuclear non-proliferation talks with Russia, far more important than this global warming hoax. As for Navalny, we need concrete proof before jumping to conclusions, but we're taking it very seriously. It's a tragedy, a terrible thing.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, were there any ultimatums regarding ransomware? How will you measure success with these working groups on Russian meddling and cybersecurity? [SEP] It's simple. On cybersecurity, will they act against ransomware criminals on their territory? They didn't before. Will they act now? We'll see. What can we commit to regarding violations of international norms? What will we agree to do? There are real opportunities to move forward. People are realizing this is a real problem. What if a ransomware outfit in Florida targeted their oil lifeline? That would be devastating. It's in everyone's interest to act. We'll see what happens with these groups.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the potential use of chemical weapons, do you have specific intelligence indicating that President Putin is deploying, positioning, or considering the use of these weapons? And would the U.S. or NATO respond militarily if he were to use them? [SEP] I can't answer the first question; I'm not going to share intelligence data. But on the second question, we would respond if he uses chemical weapons. The nature of our response would depend on the nature of their use.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, after these recent successes, are you ready to declare a comeback? And looking ahead to 2011, are you concerned about bipartisan cooperation on issues like deficit reduction and tax reform? [SEP] Look, we took a shellacking in the midterms, and I take responsibility. But what's happened isn't a victory for me, it's a victory for the American people. Democrats and Republicans can disagree, argue, but still find common ground. We did it with taxes. I still think tax cuts for the wealthy are wrong when we have deficits. We'll disagree on spending. We need to invest in education and R&D, but also cut what doesn't work. We can get things done even if we don't agree on everything. That's my goal.
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, what is the United States prepared—what action is the United States prepared to take if there is another confrontation with Iranian ships in the Strait of Hormuz? Your National Security Adviser this morning spoke about consequences if there was a repeat.And, Mr. Prime Minister, why is there no three-way meeting scheduled on this trip? [SEP] The National Security Adviser was making it abundantly clear that all options are on the table to protect our assets.She's referring to, Mr. Prime Minister, the fact that our ships were moving along very peacefully off the ian border in territorial water—international waters, and ian boats came out and were very provocative. And it was a dangerous gesture on their part. We have made it clear publicly, and they know our position, and that is, there will be serious consequences if they attack our ships, pure and simple. And my advice to them is, don't do it.
label: General

sentence: Sir, just to confirm, are you saying the NHS should be part of the discussions? [SEP] Pardon? What was that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia's claim of evacuating the Kherson region, do you see this as a turning point in the conflict, potentially giving Ukraine the upper hand in peace talks with Moscow? [SEP] Well, it's curious, isn't it, that they waited until after the election to announce this Kherson withdrawal? We've known about their intentions for a while. It certainly highlights the significant challenges facing the Russian military. As for whether it will lead to peace negotiations, it will at least give everyone a chance to reassess their positions during the winter. Whether Ukraine is willing to compromise with Russia remains to be seen. I'll be at the G-20, though Putin reportedly won't be there. It will be an opportunity to gauge the next steps. Nancy, CBS.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, some say the election results indicate a disconnect between your administration and the concerns of ordinary Americans. Do you agree? And, on a lighter note, any thoughts on the resemblance between Nancy Pelosi and Bob Bullock? [SEP] That's an inside joke, so I will pass. I'm an optimistic guy. I knew we'd lose seats, just not that many.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. And are you now braced for long impeachment saga? [SEP] Well, I thought we won. I thought it was dead. It was dead. The Mueller report—no obstruction, no collusion. You look at all of the things that happened.Corey Lewandowski was fantastic the other day, as a person that they have been tormenting. You look at all the people that they've tormented, all the legal fees. People came here with bright eyes; they wanted to make life so great for other people. And they left where they spent hundreds of thousands of dollars in legal fees that they didn't have. And it's a sad thing. What these Democrats have done to ruin lives is so sad.I've seen people with only good intention. They came to Washington because they wanted to make the United States and the world a better place. And they went home; they were dark. They got hit by Mueller's subpoenas. I think there were 2,500 subpoenas or some ridiculous number. Five hundred people were interviewed, and yet they don't interview Joe Biden and his son.If you're Democrat, you have automatic protection. That's years and years of people putting in certain people into positions. But when you look at all of the—all of the trauma that these fakers, of course—and the press—look, the press is—much of the press is not only fake, it's corrupt. These stories they write are corrupt; they're so wrong. And they know that.You know, it used to be—I used to get great press until I ran for politics. I mean, I used to be the king of getting good press. I was very good at it. And I got good. I mean, they covered me well for what—otherwise, I probably wouldn't be here. And once I ran, I said, Boy, this is incredible. But if you see the way they treat my family—used to be treated great. My family worked so hard. The people that work with me—these people—all of these people, they work so hard. They've done such a good—look, we have the greatest economy we've ever had. We have a military—$2½ trillion. We've rebuilt our military. You don't hear the vets complaining. We got choice approved. It couldn't be approved.But when you see what happened with the viciousness, and when you see little Adam Schiff go out and lie and lie and stand at the mike—smart guy, by the way—stand at the mike and act like he's so serious. And then, he goes into a room with Nadler, and they must laugh their asses off. They must laugh their asses off.But it's so bad for our country. People have said—Rush Limbaugh—great man; Sean Hannity said it. A lot of people have said it. Mark Levin. They said they don't know if one man anywhere in the world, with all the men they know—or woman—that could handle what I've had to handle. And I think that's true, but I handle it. To me, it's like putting on a suit.All right, how about one more question? A question on the economy. A question on the economy.Go ahead. Go ahead.
label: Dodging

sentence: And what about Johnson and Gove? [SEP] Boris? Top bloke. Always rated him. Think he'd do a smashing job. Jeremy? Know Jeremy. Good egg. Reckon he'd be up to the task. Michael? Can't say I know him. Jeremy, what do you reckon? Good? Right then, cheers everyone!
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the leak of the Hadley memo before your meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki, did you personally authorize an investigation, or did your Chief of Staff do so under your direction? And if the leak was unauthorized, do you suspect an internal effort to undermine your Iraq policy or sabotage that crucial meeting? [SEP] Let me think... an investigation... I don't have a clear recollection of ordering one. I do remember being quite frustrated with the constant leaks. You in the press are always digging for information, which is understandable, but the leaking of classified documents is a serious matter. It's a persistent problem, not unique to this administration. We've had numerous leaks, some from unknown origins, so I won't speculate on the source. It's notoriously difficult to find the leaker. There may be an ongoing investigation; I honestly don't know at this moment. But I firmly believe that those who leak classified information, in violation of the law, should be held accountable. Consequences are essential to deter such behavior.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Despite your rhetoric on Iran and Syria, would you consider working with them if it advanced our goals in Iraq? [SEP] Well, they know what we expect. Iran needs to help Iraq succeed, and they also need to help Lebanon. The big issue is their nuclear program. We're making it clear to them that sponsoring terrorists will lead to more isolation. As for Syria, they need to stop undermining Lebanon and stop supporting terrorists. They know our position.
label: General

sentence: Q. But they are not currently under investigation, correct? [SEP] Peter, I'm not prepared to discuss those matters at this juncture.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: But they're not under investigation, correct, sir? [SEP] I'm not at liberty to discuss that, Peter.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Bush, regarding trade negotiations with Uruguay, what specific areas of flexibility can your administration demonstrate to expedite a trade agreement, and what concrete progress has been achieved in today's discussions? Additionally, President Vazquez, did you broach the subject of the mill plant dispute with Argentina and request President Bush's intervention? [SEP] We dedicated a significant portion of our discussion to addressing Uruguay's concerns regarding market access for specific products. The President articulated various trade-related issues, including concerns about quotas imposed on items such as cows and sheep. I assured him that I would give due consideration to the requests he articulated. You may have perceived my remarks about blueberries as facetious, but I assure you they were not. Uruguay produces exceptional blueberries, and the fundamental question is whether their producers will be afforded the opportunity to market their product within the United States. We engaged in discussions regarding a variety of agricultural products, and I emphasized that identifying and addressing problems requires open and transparent communication. We will provide assistance where feasible, and where not, I will furnish a comprehensive explanation. I also harbor concerns regarding protectionist tendencies, both domestically and internationally. I firmly believe that a world characterized by free and equitable trade is more likely to effectively combat poverty. Consequently, I am a staunch advocate for the successful completion of the Doha round of the WTO. I shared our strategies for advancing the Doha round with President Lula, being careful not to divulge any confidential information. The United States is prepared to reduce agricultural subsidies, contingent upon securing market access for our products. I remain optimistic that we can achieve a mutually beneficial agreement. Our trade minister, Susan Schwab, remains in Sao Paulo engaging in discussions with her Brazilian counterpart. In response to your initial question, I fully concur with the sentiments expressed by President Bush. We have established a platform, commencing with this meeting, where our experts and ministers will engage in discussions and make progress on matters pertaining to bilateral relations. Uruguay has consistently advocated for free trade and the reduction of tariffs and subsidies. We are also exploring the possibility of making progress with the GSP. Regarding your subsequent question, I did not discuss the issues we have with Argentina with President Bush, as we will be engaging in dialogue with Argentina in the near future, thanks to the conciliation efforts of His Majesty, the King of Spain, to seek a mutually agreeable resolution to our differences.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Bush, critics are questioning the timing of your push for immigration reform. Why now, after so many years of inaction? [SEP] They talked about . [] Excuse me. I wasn't there. []No, that's a legitimate question, and the question is, why now? Why do I think something positive can happen? Well, first of all, the legislative process takes awhile in the United States. I don't know about Mexico, Mr. President, but sometimes legislators, you know, debate issues for awhile before a solution can be achieved. And we had a very—by the way, we haven't had a serious debate on migration until recently. A law was passed in 1986, and then there really wasn't a serious debate until pretty much starting after the year 2000, if my memory serves me well. I've always known this is an important issue because I happened to have been the Governor of Texas. And so I'm very comfortable about discussing the issue and have elevated the issue over the past years. And Members of Congress have taken the issue very seriously, but it's hard to get legislation out of the Congress on a very complex issue.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, critics argue that previous bank bailouts disproportionately benefited large corporations while failing to provide sufficient relief to struggling homeowners. How will this new plan address these concerns and ensure that ordinary Americans receive tangible benefits? [SEP] We are committed to helping all Americans, not just the big banks. This plan will include measures to support homeowners and prevent foreclosures. We will work with lenders to provide affordable mortgage options. We will ensure that everyone has a fair chance to succeed. We are focused on creating an economy that works for everyone, not just the wealthy few.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, on this trip you’ve emphasized state sovereignty. How does that align with the responsibility to protect civilians from atrocities? [SEP] I'm sorry, how do I reconcile sovereignty with what, exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, considering the ongoing tunnel operations, is a genuine ceasefire achievable at this juncture? Should we adjust our strategy moving forward? [SEP] Well, let's remember the proposed ceasefire allowed Israel to continue dismantling those tunnel networks, and they can do so without leveling Gaza's population centers. Dismantling those tunnels is absolutely necessary. There's a way to do it while minimizing bloodshed. Past conflicts have shown the devastating costs. The images we've seen – children, defenseless women, Israelis living in fear – are heartbreaking. A ceasefire that safeguards Israel's security, ensures they aren't constantly threatened by rockets, and acknowledges the Palestinian need for a decent life is crucial. It's a tough challenge, filled with anger and despair, but we must persevere. American leadership means stepping up when others won't. While these crises may pose tangential risks to the US, like ISIS, they aren't direct attacks. We intervene because of our unique responsibilities. We must be humble about our limitations, recognizing our finite resources after a decade of war. But we try. When John Kerry works to broker peace, we should support him, not criticize his efforts prematurely. No other nation is making such efforts. Our involvement usually leads to better outcomes, not perfect or immediate, but better. This applies to the Middle East, Ukraine, and Iraq. I'll conclude by reminding everyone that during my first term, the focus was on the economy and job creation. Our actions worked, and the economy improved. Six consecutive months of over 200,000 jobs created – a 17-year milestone – demonstrate the power of persistence.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, following up on your statement about a softer tone, many are skeptical. How can you assure the American people that this isn't just lip service, and what specific changes in your communication strategy can we expect to see moving forward, especially given the new Congressional landscape? [SEP] Let me be clear: I'm not going to be pushed around. The media has been relentless in their attacks, and I have a duty to defend myself and my administration. A softer tone doesn't mean weakness. It means being more strategic in how we communicate our message. We'll focus on facts, on results, and on what's best for the American people. And if that requires a more measured approach, then so be it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, were there any ultimatums given concerning ransomware? And how will you define success for these working groups on Russian meddling and cybersecurity? [SEP] It's pretty straightforward. On cybersecurity, are they going to take action against ransomware criminals on their territory? They didn't do it before. Are they going to act now? We'll find out. What can we commit to in terms of anything affecting violating international norms that negatively affects us? What are we going to agree to do? I think we have real opportunities to move. People who are very well-informed are starting to think, this could be a real problem. What happens if that ransomware outfit were sitting in Florida and took action on their single lifeline to their economy: oil? That would be devastating. It's in everybody's interest that these things be acted on. We'll see what happens from these groups we put together.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, what would be the military repercussions for North Korea if they fail to uphold the commitments you've mentioned? Is military intervention a possibility? [SEP] I'd rather not delve into that, as I don't want to sound threatening. They are aware of the potential consequences. Seoul, with its 28 million inhabitants, is a massive city bordering the DMZ. A conflict there could result in catastrophic losses, potentially 20, 30, even 50 million lives. It's an honor to be working towards preventing such a tragedy.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Following up on Major's question, some Republicans on Capitol Hill--John McCain and Lindsey Graham, for example--have said that up to this point, your response on Iran has been timid and weak. Today it sounded a lot stronger. It sounded like the kind of speech John McCain has been urging you to give, saying that those who stand up for justice are always on the right side of history, referring to an iron fist in Iran--deplore, appalled, outraged. Were you influenced at all by John McCain and Lindsey Graham accusing you of being timid and weak? [SEP] What do you think? [] Look, the--I think John McCain has genuine passion about many of these international issues, and I think that all of us share a belief that we want justice to prevail. But only I'm the President of the United States, and I've got responsibilities in making certain that we are continually advancing our national security interests and that we are not used as a tool to be exploited by other countries.I mean, you guys must have seen the reports. They've got some of the comments that I've made being mistranslated in , suggesting that I'm telling rioters to go out and riot some more. There are reports suggesting that the CIA is behind all this, all of which are patently false. But it gives you a sense of the narrative that the ian Government would love to play into. So the Members of Congress, they've got their constitutional duties, and I'm sure they will carry them out in the way that they think is appropriate. I'm President of the United States, and I'll carry out my duties as I think are appropriate. All right?
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your actions have undermined the integrity of the office. Can you definitively state that you never pressured the Ukrainian President to investigate a political rival, and why should the American people trust your version of events? [SEP] That whole thing is a witch hunt, plain and simple. They're trying to take me down, but they won't succeed. The call was perfect. There was no quid pro quo. They're the ones who are corrupt, not me. And the American people know it. They see through the lies and the fake news. They know I'm fighting for them, and they're with me all the way.
label: Deflection

sentence: You mentioned low-level drug offenders, but a significant portion of your commutations also involved firearm offenses. How do you justify this apparent contradiction, given your stance on gun control? [SEP] Right.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: What's your strategy for furthering your pro-life agenda? [SEP] We'll keep pushing, that's the plan. I've been pushing, and I think I've done a pretty good job. People are happy with me. But it's a tough issue for both sides, without a doubt.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the public is looking to you for guidance. Can you offer any specific advice on precautions Americans should take, or are you solely relying on the CDC's recommendations? [SEP] I have complete faith in our experts. They are the best in the world. I am listening to them. I am confident they will guide us through this.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, aside from the extra-NATO alliance, are you actively considering allowing a U.S. military presence in Brazil to address the situation on the Venezuelan border, and was this specifically discussed with President Trump? [SEP] Yes, we talked about the possibility of Brazil becoming a great allied extra-NATO. Recently, we requested that food was sent through Boa Vista, the capital of Roraima State, through our friends from America, so that humanitarian aid was provided to .At this point in time, this is where we stand. So for as much as it is possible for us to do together to sort out the issue of the n dictatorship, Brazil will be more than willing and ready to fulfill this mission and take freedom and democracy to that country, which up until recently was one of the wealthiest countries in South America. But nowadays, people are starving to death; they are suffering violence, lack of medication. They're—it's something terrible that's going on in there. And we need to put an end to this issue, which is pervasive to the whole wide world. . Mr. President, please.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, you've stated you know Mr. Trump well. Considering his decision to run, would you still be campaigning if he weren't in the picture? Did his choice affect your own? [SEP] The fact is, I would still be running if he wasn't. I do know him well. He's not hard to know. The question is whether or not there's more to finish the job. We have an opportunity to put ourselves in a position where we are economically and politically secure for a long time. There's still a contest between autocracies and democracies, and we're the leading democracy in the world. It's something I know a fair amount about. It's something I care about and something that I have found a willingness of an awful lot of our allies and friends to follow. We have to finish the job and nail it down.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, what's the bare minimum you hope to achieve from these initial talks, and how long before you know if he's serious about denuclearization? [SEP] The minimum is establishing a relationship, starting a dialogue. As a dealmaker, that's where you begin. I'd like more, of course. But at least we'll have met, seen each other, and hopefully, liked each other. That's the baseline. As for seriousness, I'll have a good sense very quickly.
label: General

sentence: Q. But coming from you, it has more weight. Do you feel like U.S. schools should be preparing for a coronavirus spreading? [SEP] I would think so, yes. I mean, I haven't spoken specifically about that with the various doctors, but I would think so, yes. I think every aspect of our society should be prepared. I don't think it's going to come to that, especially with the fact that we're going down, not up. We're going very substantially down, not up.But yes, I think schools should be preparing and, you know, get ready just in case. The words are just in case. We don't think we're going to be there. We don't think we're going to be anywhere close. And again, if you look at some countries, they are coming down. It's starting to go in the other direction.This will end. This will end. You look at flu season. I said, 26,000 people? I've never heard of a number like that. Twenty-six thousand people going up to sixty-nine thousand people, Doctor, you told me before. Sixty-nine thousand people die every year—from 26 [26,000; .] to 69 [69,000; .]—every year from the flu. Now, think of that. It's incredible.So far, the results of all of this that everybody is reading about—and part of the thing is, you want to keep it the way it is. You don't want to see panic, because there's no reason to be panicked about.But when I mentioned the flu, I said—actually, I asked the various doctors. I said, Is this just like flu? Because people die from the flu. And this is very unusual. And it is a little bit different, but in some ways it's easier and in some ways it's a little bit tougher.But we have it so well under control. I mean, we really have done a very good job.Go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: So, the $600 is still on the table? [SEP] We'll see what happens. The money's there.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Given your contrasting ideologies with President-elect Obama, what are your primary reservations regarding his potential policy implementations? [SEP] I'm not in the business of predicting the future. He'll assess each situation and act accordingly. My time's done. I'm exiting the stage. One person in the spotlight at a time, that's my philosophy. I wish him success. It's not just lip service; the stakes are high. There are still threats to America. He'll also face economic challenges. I made tough decisions during the financial crisis, using taxpayer money to stabilize things, even if it meant helping Wall Street, who caused the mess. But Obama will face similar dilemmas. I wish him well.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Good for the business--for the climate, though, but not required for your signature--is that what I heard? [SEP] I'm sorry, I lost you on that one.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with all these subpoenas being issued, why can't you cooperate with the investigations? [SEP] Come again? Bipartisanship?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, isn't China's currency policy a direct impediment to your administration's economic objectives? [SEP] We have to consider the entire economic relationship. Back in '09, at the G-20, we were facing a major financial crisis. We couldn't continue with the US borrowing and consuming so much. We needed to rebalance the global economy. That means we need to save more, reduce debt, and make structural reforms to be more competitive. Education, infrastructure, fiscal responsibility are all key. But it also requires fair trade. We're discussing government procurement and intellectual property with China. The currency is part of the equation. They've intervened significantly. President Hu has expressed commitment to a market-based system, but progress is slow. I've emphasized that it would benefit both countries, boosting China's domestic demand. While President Hu is concerned about potential disruptions, I remain optimistic that he will ultimately implement a fully market-based currency program.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, setting aside the legal ramifications, what lessons should the government learn from the Snowden affair regarding transparency and oversight of intelligence agencies? [SEP] We need to make sure that our intelligence agencies are doing their job, but we also need to make sure that they're not overstepping their bounds. There needs to be proper oversight, and there needs to be transparency. But we also can't hamstring them so much that they can't do their job. It's a very difficult balance to strike.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given Russia's countermeasures and the troop buildup, can you confidently say the sanctions are achieving their desired effect? [SEP] The situation is complex, and it's too early to declare complete success. However, the Russian economy is undeniably feeling the strain. Putin faces a clear choice: de-escalation and dialogue, or further economic pain. We remain committed to a diplomatic solution that respects Ukraine's sovereignty, and the sanctions are a key tool in that effort.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, you promised more troops to Afghanistan and a withdrawal from Iraq in 16 months. What's your timeline for withdrawing from Afghanistan? Also, will you overturn the Pentagon policy banning media coverage of flag-draped coffins, given then-Senator Biden's criticism of it? [SEP] Your question is particularly poignant given recent events. We've just received news of four American servicemembers killed in Iraq. My thoughts and prayers are with their loved ones. The most sobering moment of my presidency has been signing letters to the families of our fallen heroes. It's a stark reminder of the weight of this office. Regarding media access to the dignified transfer of our fallen, we're currently reviewing those policies in collaboration with the Department of Defense. I'll reserve judgment until that review is finalized. Afghanistan is a complex and significant undertaking. Thanks to the dedication of our troops and the diplomatic efforts of Ambassador Crocker, Iraq has seen a relatively peaceful election. The political system appears to be stabilizing. We haven't witnessed the same progress in Afghanistan. The government seems detached from the people. The Taliban and Al Qaida maintain a presence in the FATA region. We haven't seen a sustained effort to eradicate those safe havens. We're undertaking a comprehensive reassessment. General Petraeus and Richard Holbrooke are collaborating on a regional strategy. We require enhanced coordination between our military, diplomatic, and development initiatives. This will be a challenging endeavor, but Afghanistan served as the staging ground for the 9/11 attacks. I recently met with the families of 9/11 victims, a powerful reminder of the dangers of allowing those safe havens to persist. We cannot permit Al Qaida to operate with impunity. We must work tirelessly to eliminate those safe havens. I don't have a definitive timeline to share at this time. But I will not allow Al Qaida or bin Laden to operate with impunity.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, concerning Ukraine, could you clarify what specific actions you wanted Mr. Biden to investigate, and what evidence you had at the time to warrant such an inquiry? [SEP] The Bidens, they're a mess. Total mess. Everyone knows it. Millions of dollars, folks, millions! This kid knows nothing, nothing! And you're asking me? Ask them! It's a disgrace, a total disgrace, what they've done.

sentence: May I publish this conversation in the New York Times? [SEP] I acknowledge your request. Thank you.

sentence: President Obama, what are your thoughts on a congressional investigation into the release of the Lockerbie bomber, and Prime Minister Cameron, have you ruled out a government investigation? [SEP] Well, let me start. We were all disappointed and angry about the release. We welcome any information that helps us understand why it happened. I support Prime Minister Cameron's efforts to clarify the situation. The key thing is that we disagreed with the decision. It was a bad one. We have strong ties with the UK in fighting terrorism, and we need to maintain that cooperation. As for an inquiry, there's already been one by the Scottish Parliament. We'll see if more information needs to be published. We'll cooperate with the congressional hearing.
label: Implicit

sentence: Aside from Huawei, which other Chinese tech companies are on your radar for potential restrictions in the United States? [SEP] Huawei is the main concern, right? Huawei is not welcome here. And I've made this clear to European countries and others. Australia has been fantastic. But Huawei isn't coming here. We've warned certain countries considering Huawei that they can use them, but we won't share intelligence. And they've all backed away. Look at the U.K., they seemed to be leaning that way, but now they've changed their tune—Scotland Yard.

sentence: Regarding John Brennan, what's the latest? And concerning the Africa Summit and the Ebola situation, any updates? Sir, I was under the impression we were going to inquire about your birthday celebrations. [SEP] Hold on, where are the birthday greetings?

sentence: Mr. President, how can you guarantee that North Korea will follow through on its commitment to denuclearization, and not just engage in empty rhetoric? I'm a dealmaker. I know when someone's serious, and they are.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Red Cross report on CIA interrogation techniques, and the stalled closure of Guantanamo, who is truly calling the shots on this issue, and when do you anticipate its closure? [SEP] Well, let's be clear. Closing Guantanamo has always been a stated goal, but it's not as simple as snapping your fingers. We face resistance from other nations unwilling to repatriate detainees – nobody wants these folks. And frankly, the Senate isn't exactly clamoring to house them here either. As for progress, we *are* working to transfer detainees, ensuring humane treatment upon return. Trials are a priority, but the legal complexities are immense. So, while I can't give you a definitive timeline, we're actively addressing this. And, by the way, you said 'nothing has taken place'? That's simply untrue. Now, about that Red Cross report...
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Nigeria's request for Tucano aircraft to address internal security challenges, could you expedite the release of at least two units before 2020? sentence: Given the uncertainty around North Korea's willingness to negotiate, would the U.S. consider intensifying sanctions to increase pressure? My perspective shifted after getting to know Chairman Kim. He has his own viewpoint. I'd rather not discuss this further. Hopefully, for the sake of South Korea, Japan, and even President Xi, who doesn't want a nuclear state nearby, this situation will resolve itself.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. If I could follow up—— Q. Mr. President——Coronavirus Outbreak in China/Coronavirus Containment Efforts Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You mentioned the drop of spread in China, the coronavirus cases. Is the U.S. Government considering evaluating similar measures in the U.S. in case the situation gets worse? [SEP] Some measures. We've been in very close contact with China, including myself with President Xi. He very much wanted this to happen. He wanted this to get out and finished and be done. He worked—he's been working very, very hard, I can tell you that. And they're making a lot of progress in China.You probably saw Starbucks are now opened again. You probably saw that—as I mentioned, Tim just came out, and he said Apple is back to normal in terms of production in their facilities in China. They've made a lot of progress.

sentence: Sir, you credited your victory to God. Reflecting on the past two years, how would you characterize the role of faith in your presidential duties? [SEP] The role of faith? sentence: However, you failed to acknowledge that your supporters were also present in Portland this weekend, discharging paintball guns and some type of pepper spray at individuals. If the package doesn't deliver the results we expect, we're prepared to take further action. We're constantly evaluating the economic situation and will adjust our policies as needed. We're committed to doing everything we can to get the economy back on track and create jobs for American workers.

sentence: Mr. President, your team says the Iran framework agreement is non-negotiable, only its implementation can be adjusted. How can we address concerns about no military site inspections and immediate sanctions lifting within this framework? Also, regarding Cuba, did you discuss the 45-day waiting period for removing them from the state sponsor of terrorism list with President Castro, and do you believe there are no impediments to opening embassies once they are removed? [SEP] Okay, one last try on Iran. We have a political framework with Iran and the P-5-plus-1. Some parts, like centrifuge reductions in Natanz, are very specific. Others are just intentions, and the details matter. How we interpret those details will be negotiated. It's wrong to say everything's done. We have a framework that, if implemented, will prevent Iran from getting a nuclear weapon. But the details are key, and there will be tough negotiations. That's what I said from the start. On Cuba, we didn't get into that level of detail. The state sponsor of terrorism recommendation is coming to me. Congress can review it too. The Embassy concerns are mostly on Cuba's side. They haven't had an American Embassy in a while. We're used to this, like with China and Vietnam. We're ready to move forward and improve dialogue, which will improve prospects for the Cuban people. Thank you to the Latin American countries and the people of Panama. I'm optimistic about this region because of its people.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, are you now regretting your earlier statements commending China for their openness regarding the coronavirus? [SEP] My approach is always to treat China with respect.

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Mr. Putin's intentions, do you see any indication he's shifting away from his disruptive role, especially concerning NATO and the U.S.? Also, when you presented him with the list of critical U.S. infrastructure, was the potential penalty for interference clearly defined, or was it left ambiguous? What was his reaction? He's aware of this, though the specifics remain undisclosed. Should they violate established norms, our response will be in the cyber domain. He understands this.

sentence: Mr. President, are there any other Chinese technology companies that the administration is considering restricting from operating within the United States? [SEP] The primary focus remains on Huawei. Their presence in the U.S. is not permitted, and I have communicated this stance to various European nations and other countries. I have cautioned some that utilizing Huawei technology could impact our intelligence-sharing arrangements. Consequently, many have reevaluated their positions. For instance, the U.K. initially appeared inclined to adopt Huawei, but they have since withdrawn.

sentence: Q. But what kind of boycott do you envision? [SEP] Oh, I don't know. That's up to people. But I wouldn't recommend it. If they want to hold political speech, if they want to let you not do what everybody is doing; if they want to wear a MAGA hat or if they want to wear a Blue Lives—you know what Blue Lives Matter, right? That's police men and women. That's a terrible thing. That's a terrible thing.So they're using their power over these people, and these people want to wear whatever it is that we're talking about. You know that. And so I would be very much in favor if people don't want to buy there. And you know what? They'll be able to get a good job, because we set a jobs record over the last quarter, as you know. The most jobs ever in the history of our country. You'll be able to get another good jobs. I think it's disgraceful that they did this.Please, go ahead, in the back.

sentence: Q. Sir, what measures are being taken to protect workers who are hesitant to return to work due to health concerns? [SEP] The Governors are handling it. They know their states. They'll make sure it's safe. Businesses can implement safety protocols, testing, all that stuff. And let's be clear, this is temporary. We want to get back to normal. We want packed restaurants, full stadiums. We're not going to let this virus change us forever. We're Americans. We're resilient.

sentence: Sir, regarding your Attorney General and Deputy Attorney General, following the midterms, what assurances can you give the American people about their continued service in your administration? The midterms were a success, a tremendous success, and we're going to continue to build on that. I'll address personnel matters at the appropriate time.

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. What is your view of Russia's announcement today that it will, quote, fundamentally scale back its military operations near Kyiv and another northern city in Ukraine? Do you see this as possibly the war beginning to come to an end, or do you see this as Russia trying to buy time and to recalibrate for a new military effort? [SEP] We'll see. I don't read anything into it until I see what their actions are. We'll see if they follow through on what they're suggesting. There are negotiations that have begun todayor not begun, continued; today: one in Turkey and others.I had a meeting with the heads of state of four allies in NATO: France, Germany, the United States, and Great Britain. And there seems to be a consensus that let's just see what they have to offer; we'll find out what they do. But in the meantime, we're going to continue to keep strong the sanctions. We're going to continue to provide the Ukrainian military with their capacity to defend themselves. And we're going to continue to keep a close eye on what's going on.Thank you. I call on Dawn Tan, Channel NewsAsia.

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Ukraine, what specific concerns did you have about Mr. Biden's actions that led you to request an investigation? [SEP] Look, the Bidens are corrupt. sentence: Sir, are you concerned about reports of declining morale among troops in Iraq who are serving multiple tours of duty? [SEP] What I'm hearing from the commanders is that the concern is with the family members. Our troops, who have volunteered to serve this country, are willing to go into combat multiple times, but the concern is with the people on the home front. That's one reason I go out of my way to constantly thank the family members. I'm talking to our commanders. Their job is to tell me what the situation is on the ground. I know there's concern about the home front. I haven't heard deep concern about the morale of the troops in Iraq.

sentence: Mr. President, what military repercussions will North Korea face if they fail to uphold their commitments? Is military intervention a possibility? [SEP] Well, I'd rather not delve into specifics – I don't want to sound threatening, you see. They understood the situation. You've seen what could have happened. Seoul, a city of 28 million, is right next to the border. New York, with its 8 million, seems big, but Seoul is enormous. If things had escalated, we're talking about potentially losing 20, 30 million people. It's an honor to be involved in this, because we could have lost, you know, 30, 40, 50 million people. Seoul, one of the world's largest cities, is just across the border.

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the situation in Syria, you've repeatedly stated that Assad must go. Could you provide a more concrete timeline or strategy for achieving this goal? Are we likely to see a resolution within the next year? [SEP] Look, we've been clear: Assad's actions are unacceptable. As for a precise timetable, these situations are fluid. There's no easy fix, no magic wand. We're applying pressure, supporting the opposition, and exploring diplomatic avenues like the Geneva talks. The situation is complex, and frankly, I couldn't tell you when it will be resolved.

sentence: Mr. President, surveys indicate that inflation is a top concern for Black voters. In the next two years, what concrete assurances can you provide to improve their financial well-being, while simultaneously averting a potential recession? [SEP] Well, let's consider the facts. Black unemployment has decreased significantly under my administration. The number of Black-owned small businesses is at an all-time high. We are also providing downpayment assistance for home purchases through the Small Business Administration, as homeownership is the primary means of wealth accumulation for most middle-class families. While I cannot guarantee the complete eradication of inflation, I believe we can make significant progress. We have already reduced gasoline prices by over a dollar per gallon. However, the oil companies are not acting in the nation's best interest. Six of them collectively generated over $100 billion in profits last quarter. Historically, they would have either invested in expanding refinery capacity or passed on savings to gas stations, but they are not doing so now. We are also addressing the costs that disproportionately impact families, such as prescription drug prices. We are implementing measures to lower these prices substantially, beginning next year. For instance, we are capping the cost of insulin at $35 per month. We are focused on reducing all of the expenses that families face on a monthly basis – from mortgage payments to food costs to gasoline prices to medical bills. We have already enacted legislation to address these issues, and it is beginning to take effect. I am optimistic because we are continuing to experience growth at a sustainable pace, and we are not currently in a recession. I am confident that we can achieve what economists refer to as a soft landing, gradually reducing prices without triggering an economic downturn.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. ——and I wonder if—are you giving Russian President Vladimir Putin the upper hand heading into your talks, given that you are challenging these alliances that he seeks to break up and destroy? [SEP] See, that's such dishonest reporting, because—of course, it happens to be NBC, which is possibly worse than CNN. Possibly. Possibly.
label: Dodging

sentence: Senator McCain has been quite vocal about his stance on Vladimir Putin, suggesting a more assertive approach. Do you believe his assessment is accurate, and how would a change in leadership in Russia, or the lack thereof, impact our relationship? [SEP] Look, McCain's got his opinions, and he's entitled to 'em. My style is different. I believe in building bridges, even with guys like Putin. You gotta be able to sit down and talk straight, without blowing up the whole relationship. We see eye-to-eye on some stuff, like fighting terrorists and keeping nukes out of the wrong hands. But on other stuff, like how they treat the press, we're miles apart. But that's why you gotta keep talking. As for Russia changing, that's their business. We just gotta make sure they know it's in their best interest to play nice with the West. It's a complicated dance, but it's one we gotta keep doing.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, what's the maximum amount you're willing to offer Congress beyond your current proposal? [SEP] We're going to see what happens. We'll take care of the states. They're working hard, setting up quarantine zones and making hospital rooms available. We're working very well with them. If Congress wants to give us the money, great. It wasn't easy for the wall, but we got it done. We'll put the money to good use.

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your administration has downplayed the threat of foreign interference in past elections. What assurances can you provide to the American people that this administration is taking the necessary steps to prevent foreign meddling in the upcoming election and protect the democratic process? But you know, the Democrats, they're always trying to blame someone else for their problems.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Are you going to send 15,000 troops to the border? [SEP] You've been reading the same documents as I have; you know exactly what I'm doing. You know exactly what I'm doing.So go ahead. What's your next question?

sentence: With Admiral McRaven's recent testimony highlighting the ambiguity surrounding procedures for captured terrorists, what assurances can you give to our military personnel that their actions will be legally sound, and that the pursuit of intelligence won't be compromised by a lack of clear guidelines? We have a system, a very thorough system, for dealing with these situations. We'll use all the options available to us – military tribunals, civilian courts – whatever works best. The most important thing is to get the intelligence and keep America safe. That's the bottom line.

sentence: With numerous states enacting restrictive laws targeting LGBTQ+ individuals, particularly transgender youth, what concrete federal actions, beyond symbolic gestures, will your administration take to directly challenge these state laws and protect the rights of affected families? [SEP] Look, it's simple. We're not standing idly by. We're strengthening physical safety, addressing civil rights violations, and ensuring mental health support. We're fighting against these hateful bills targeting transgender children. These are our kids, our neighbors. And to those families considering leaving the country, I want to say directly: we have your back. On AI, it's clear this technology poses risks, and we're working with other countries to mitigate those risks.

sentence: Mr. President, Iran: framework agreement, non-negotiable? Cuba: 45-day wait, discussed with Castro? Embassies, any roadblocks? [SEP] Iran: framework's got stuff like centrifuge cuts, Fordow changes. But details matter, gotta negotiate. Can't say it's all done. Framework works if we do it right, stops the bomb, but details are key. Tough talks ahead, like I said. Cuba: didn't talk details. I'll look at the list, Congress will too. Embassy stuff's probably on Cuba's side, they're not used to us. Big change for them. We're ready, improve things, help Cubans. Thanks Latin America, Panama. People are great, that's why I'm optimistic.

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia and Ukraine, you mentioned assessing Putin's intentions. Has your administration determined whether President Putin plans to invade or move further into Ukraine? [SEP] The bottom line is this: Putin's the one making the decisions. It's all on him. Nobody else has any say in it. And frankly, I think his decision will depend on how he's feeling that day. He might want to talk about strategic issues, but who knows what he's really thinking? Even his own advisors probably don't know. We've had meetings, but they haven't been very productive. If he wants to invade, he'll have to wait for the ground to freeze. We're providing support to Ukraine and keeping an eye on the situation. He's considering the consequences, but I don't believe he's made a final decision yet.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Obama, Senator Leahy has suggested a truth and reconciliation committee to examine the Bush administration's actions. Do you support this, and will you rule out prosecuting Bush officials? [SEP] I'm not familiar with the details of Senator Leahy's proposal, so I can't offer a specific opinion on it. However, I want to assure everyone that my administration will operate with the utmost integrity, adhering to the rule of law and respecting human rights. We do not engage in torture, we comply with the Geneva Conventions, and we uphold due process, even as we vigorously pursue those who threaten our nation. These principles are not mutually exclusive; they reinforce each other. While no one is above the law and clear instances of wrongdoing should be addressed, my primary focus is on looking ahead and uniting our nation. This includes supporting the dedicated members of our intelligence community who have worked tirelessly to protect America, often facing unfair criticism. I will carefully consider Senator Leahy's proposal, but my overall goal is to ensure that we are moving forward in the right direction.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given that a significant portion of the surge troops were already in place during the July report, are you committed to continuing the surge, regardless of General Petraeus's assessment, if there's no substantial political progress in Iraq by September? [SEP] With all due respect, you're asking me to predict my mindset months from now. I'd prefer to wait for General Petraeus to brief me upon his return. I'll be happy to address your questions then.

sentence: So, are you denying that she was terminated? [SEP] Look, I can't tell you. I only learned about this this morning. I don't yet know the details. Regarding your initial question, Ken Salazar was already implementing changes at MMS. But the reality is, they weren't happening quickly enough. If they had been, this might have been prevented. Then again, it's possible it still wouldn't have been. We could have had a completely new environmental review process, and they still might have said, this meets industry standards. That's what this commission needs to determine. Was this a systemic failure? Or a one-in-a-million occurrence? What are the inherent risks? The fact that oil companies now have to drill a mile underwater and then another 3 miles below that tells us something about the oil industry. Extraction is becoming more expensive and inherently more risky. That's precisely why you never heard me say, Drill, baby, drill, because we can't simply drill our way out of this predicament. We're going to have to begin transitioning.

sentence: Mr. President, the U.S. has a disproportionately high death rate from COVID-19 compared to other countries. How do you account for that? [SEP] I'll have to double-check those numbers. sentence: Assuming the drug proves safe and effective, would your administration prioritize its rapid availability to the American public? sentence: Mr. President, considering the controversy surrounding Sergeant Bergdahl's capture and the potential risks associated with releasing Taliban prisoners, some perceive this exchange as a gamble with American security for a single individual. Was this decision driven by genuine concern for Sergeant Bergdahl's well-being, or were there other political considerations at play, such as bolstering your legacy or expediting the closure of Guantanamo? [SEP] The suggestion that this was about anything other than bringing an American soldier home is frankly offensive. Sergeant Bergdahl was in dire straits. We had an opportunity to get him back, and we took it. The released Taliban are being monitored, and we're confident in our ability to address any potential threats. This was about fulfilling our sacred obligation to leave no one behind, a principle that transcends politics.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, to be blunt, are you saying that your administration favors keeping these unaccompanied minors here, or are you planning to deport them down the line? [SEP] We have to look at each case individually. This young man, for example, has a mother ready to take him home. That's a pretty compelling reason to send him back.
label: Dodging

sentence: In your assessment, what was the key takeaway from last week's election results? And is there still an opportunity to implement the 'course correction' you alluded to before critical decisions are made by our European allies? [SEP] The American people, I believe, recognize the interconnectedness of the modern world. The forces of globalization are irreversible. They understand that their professional lives, or those of their children, may be characterized by greater fluidity, requiring adaptability, continuous learning, and reskilling. They are, I believe, prepared for this reality, provided that the rules of engagement are equitable. While a majority of Americans continue to support international trade, they harbor concerns regarding fairness and reciprocity in market access. There is a prevailing anxiety about a potential race to the bottom in terms of wages and labor standards. I previously advocated, albeit unsuccessfully, for the Trans-Pacific Partnership, arguing that it would address these concerns by strengthening labor and environmental protections, leveling the playing field, and ultimately benefiting American workers and businesses. However, this argument faces resistance given the collective memory of plant closures and offshoring. Thus, the election results reflect a desire for a change in direction. Rhetoric focused on curbing immigration surges and opposing unfair trade agreements resonated with voters. As we transition to governance, a more nuanced approach is required. We must ensure an orderly and lawful immigration process, recognizing that immigration, when properly managed, contributes to economic vitality, dynamism, and entrepreneurship. Historically, America's success has been predicated on these factors. Regarding trade, severing existing agreements, such as the one with Mexico, is not a straightforward solution. Global supply chains are deeply integrated. Components sourced from Mexico enable automotive plants to maintain operations and even expand production. Therefore, it is incumbent upon progressives to acknowledge and address legitimate anxieties, offering concrete solutions such as a higher minimum wage, stronger worker protections, robust financial regulations, and trade agreements that prohibit exploitative labor practices. Addressing inequality is also paramount. This constitutes our strategic imperative. And I am confident that we can achieve success. The world will continue to look to the United States for leadership. Our example matters. The path to ensuring that all citizens benefit from the global economy lies not in isolationism, but in enhanced international cooperation.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. June was the deadliest month for U.S. troops in— since we began the war in Afghanistan. Has Afghanistan replaced Iraq as the central front of the war on terror? And is Al Qaida and the Taliban taking the upper hand? And also, is it possible that we could send additional U.S. troops there sooner than the 2009 date that you've been talking about? [SEP] First of all, any time a troop loses their life, whether it be in Afghanistan, Iraq, or elsewhere, our hearts go out to their families. And I am so appreciative that, in a time of danger, Americans are willing to step up and volunteer and sacrifice.Secondly, it has been a tough month in Afghanistan, but it's also been a tough month for the Taliban. You know, one reason why there have been more deaths is because our troops are taking the fight to a tough enemy. You know, an enemy who doesn't like our presence there because they don't like the idea of America denying safe haven. America is pressing an ideology that's opposite of theirs, and so of course there's going to be resistance.I am confident that the strategy is going to work, which is to confront the Taliban, confront elements of Al Qaida, and, at the same time, encourage the growth of a free society by good economic policy, good education policy, and good health policy.We're constantly reviewing troop needs, troop levels. We're halfway through 2008; as I said, we're going to increase the troops by 2009. One thing, however, that you've got to understand is that we have doubled Afghan troops—coalition troops have doubled from 2 years ago. So there is an active presence, and there are more troops there than there were. But we're constantly reassessing and seeing whether or not we can change tactics in order to achieve our objective.Toby [Tabassum Zakaria, Reuters].
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, to clarify your earlier statement regarding Russia and Ukraine: are you suggesting that a small-scale Russian incursion wouldn't warrant the full force of the sanctions you've previously threatened? [SEP] We're monitoring the situation closely.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, could you elaborate on the phone calls you've had with Kim Jong Un? What topics were discussed? [SEP] Those conversations are confidential. However, I can tell you that we've had numerous productive discussions. We've fostered significant relationships at various levels, including at the highest levels. That's why we were able to achieve this breakthrough. But I'm not going to disclose the details of our private conversations.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You just said that you reject President Putin's approach to Syria and his attacks on moderate opposition forces. You said it was a recipe for disaster. But what are you willing to do to stop President Putin and protect moderate opposition fighters? Would you consider imposing sanctions against Russia? Would you go so far as to equip moderate rebels with antiaircraft weapons to protect them from Russian air attacks? And how do you respond to critics who say Putin is outsmarting you, that he took a measure of you in Ukraine and he felt he could get away with it? [SEP] Yes, I've heard it all before []
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, critics claim your stance on Ukraine's NATO aspirations sends the wrong message to Putin, potentially undermining efforts to achieve a lasting peace. What's your response? [SEP] Let's be clear: Ukraine will join NATO. The question is when. You can't join during a war. That's just the reality. Putin has already lost this war. He's in a very difficult situation. He can end it tomorrow if he wants. But the outcome is clear.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, given the evolving situation in Ukraine and the potential for renewed discussions with President Putin, what specific objectives will guide your approach? Furthermore, considering President Zelenskyy's stated condition of Crimea's return for any negotiation, do you see this as a realistic and achievable demand at this juncture? [SEP] The clear and direct path to resolving this conflict is for Putin to completely withdraw his forces from Ukraine. However, it appears he is unwilling to do so, despite the significant consequences and the devastating impact he is inflicting. I currently have no immediate plans to engage with Mr. Putin directly. I am prepared to consider discussions if he demonstrates a genuine and demonstrable interest in finding a way to bring an end to the conflict, and if such discussions are conducted in close coordination with our allied partners. As of this moment, he has not taken such steps. It is absolutely critical that we continue to provide unwavering support to the Ukrainian people in their fight for freedom and sovereignty. The notion that Putin could somehow prevail over Ukraine is simply beyond comprehension. He has fundamentally miscalculated the situation from the very beginning. He mistakenly believed that he would be greeted with open arms by the Russian-speaking populations within Ukraine. I urge you to revisit his address at the time of the invasion. He expressed a desire to emulate Peter the Great. He emphasized the supposed significance of Kyiv as the historical and cultural heartland of Russian identity. He has been proven wrong on every single count. Therefore, the fundamental question that must be addressed is this: how does he extricate himself from the predicament he has created? I am prepared, should he be willing to engage in meaningful dialogue, to ascertain what his objectives are and what he is prepared to do to achieve a peaceful resolution. However, I will only proceed in close consultation and collaboration with our NATO allies. I will not act unilaterally or independently. Regarding your specific question concerning the preconditions established by President Zelenskyy, I believe it is essential for us to recognize that, as Ukraine continues to resist the ongoing aggression, enduring war crimes and attacks on its civilian infrastructure while simultaneously undertaking a courageous counteroffensive, President Zelenskyy has presented a comprehensive 10-point peace plan that deserves serious consideration. I firmly believe that we must maintain our engagement with him and his government, as Ukraine has demonstrated a genuine and unwavering commitment to addressing these critical issues. We acknowledge and commend this commitment to finding a peaceful resolution. For a number of years, I had the responsibility of overseeing the implementation of the Minsk Agreements, which were designed to de-escalate the conflict in the region. During the most recent meeting between President Zelenskyy and President Putin, which was the only such meeting to take place, in December 2019, I was present alongside Chancellor Merkel. I can personally attest to the fact that I witnessed a President Zelenskyy who was genuinely sincere in his willingness to engage in constructive dialogue and negotiations. From the time of his election until May of the following year, President Zelenskyy consistently demonstrated a strong desire to participate in discussions and negotiations aimed at finding a peaceful resolution. It was President Putin who harbored the desire to initiate and wage war, and I personally observed this during my visits to both Russia and Ukraine in early February. Consequently, it is entirely legitimate and reasonable for President Zelenskyy to establish certain conditions for negotiations to proceed. We must work diligently to identify the elements that could pave the way for a comprehensive and lasting peace agreement, but it is ultimately his prerogative to inform us when the time is right and to articulate the choices that are available to the Ukrainian people. Having stated this, I will continue to engage with President Putin, as necessary. In fact, we addressed this very matter this morning with President Biden, as we consistently strive to prevent escalation and to achieve tangible and meaningful results. I will engage with him regarding the security and safety of nuclear facilities in the contested regions, with particular emphasis on the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant. Over the past several months, we have undertaken significant efforts at the Chernobyl nuclear plant, and Mr. Grossi and his agency, the IAEA, are continuing to conduct important and essential work to ensure its safety and security. Thank you.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: So, Mr. President, how long is this annexation plan on hold, in your estimation? [SEP] What do *you* think? We're betting everything on peace. We've got a deal with the Emirates. We're hammering out the details – embassies, flights, trade – and then we're going to roll that out across the region. Can't say how long it will take. We're putting peace first, but the annexation isn't dead. It's just on hold until we've exhausted every chance for peace.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given the historic election of two Muslim women, one veiled, to the House, would you consider this a rejection of your message? [SEP] I beg your pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, despite your assurances, many Americans remain concerned about the availability and accuracy of testing. What specific metrics are you using to measure the success of your testing strategy, and what benchmarks must be met to ensure that testing is truly accessible and reliable for all Americans? [SEP] We're using all the best metrics, the most accurate data. We have the best people working on this, the smartest scientists, the most dedicated doctors. We're constantly monitoring the situation, and we're making adjustments as needed. We're doing everything we can to protect the American people. And frankly, we're doing a better job than anyone else could have done. We're number one in the world!
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Oh, thank you. You mentioned climate activists before, and I want to ask something about them. You're touting agreements. Other world leaders have touted agreements. But the atmosphere around the conference here is skeptical, and it's pretty angry.Climate activists feel like decades and decades of COPs have led to broken promises. And they feel like even if all of these goals are reached that you're talking about in the last few days, it's just not enough right now.And I'm wondering what you would say to the people outside who are really angry at this conference, especially at this moment where Joe Manchin has expressed—you know, has created more doubt that your climate legislation will pass. And you've got a very conservative Supreme Court about to take a look at whether your EPA can regulate greenhouse gas emissions. What's your message to people outside who just worry this all isn't enough right now, given the crisis? [SEP] Well, first of all, I think anyone who is focused on the environment should be worried. We've got a lot more to do beyond what we've done. We've done more than we've ever done though; that's the point. And more has to be done.And I don't find—I didn't have a single member of the—this conference come up to me and say: Are you going to pass what you have? And what do you think is—how is that going to affect it? And what are you going to do? What they're looking at is what, in fact, has happened in terms of everything from dealing with deforestation to what we're going to do on Build Back Better and how we've been able to focus now.I mean, when is the last time you heard world leaders sit down together and agree that what they're going to do is, when they deal with the needs of the infrastructure of other countries, that they're going to focus, first and foremost, on whether or not what the climatic—what the climate impact is on that?So I think—look, this is a—there's a reason for people to be worried. I'm worried. I'm worried if we don't continue to move forward and make the kind of progress we're now making, that it's going to—I mean, we—we throw into jeopardy the prospect that we're going to be able to keep the temperature from rising above 1.5 degrees Celsius.But I'm optimistic because I think there's a—how can I say it? I guess maybe the best way to say it to you, Scott, is: What I feel is that the populations of each of our countries have a different perspective than they did at COP25.I think there is—I mean, not because of necessarily any of the leaders of any of our countries, including mine—that all of a sudden, people are seeing these things happening they never thought would happen.They're seeing people drown in their basements in Queens, New York, because of flooding and rain. They're seeing that, you know, more territory burned down in the United States, just since the first of the year, than—it makes up the entire landmass of the State of New Jersey. They've seen a hurricane with a hundred—top winds of 178 miles an hour.I mean—so they're looking at these things. They're seeing more—the waters warming. They're seeing a whole range of things occurring around the world that haven't happened. And it's, sort of, like, Whoa, whoa.Because I don't get what I used to get when I started—I don't—there's no reason why anyone would remember this, but back when a fine Republican, a guy named Dick Lugar, was—from the State of Indiana—and he and I were either the chairmen or ranking members of the Foreign Relations Committee. This was over 20 years ago. We ended up proposing—and it worked, but it got no enthusiasm—a thing for debt-for-nature swaps. And people looked at us like: What in the hell are you doing? Why are you forgiving the debt so Brazil won't, you know, burn down more of their forest? Or, Why are you doing that so they will do—now everybody goes: Whoa. What else can you do? What else can you do?So I think there's a whole different attitude that's out there. And I think this is being led—and I'm not being solicitous here—I think this is being led by, you know, my granddaughters and their friends, that generation. I think they're out there going whoa, and they're having a profound impact—having a profound impact on their parents and their grandparents about what's happening.And then all these climactic and—climatic things have happened that they—that people are now paying attention like they never did before.So, you know, there's a lot more to do. And it's going to determine whether or not we are going to be able to fund what we're talking about.But, for example, even if the funding didn't come from some of the governments, you have the private sector now engaged, where they're talking about investing—literally, the need to invest over trillions of dollars off the sidelines. It's bankers that are now deciding they've got to—I talked, a long time ago, with you all about—that you have major corporate America pricing in the price of carbon. It matters.So things are changing. We just have to have the right stewardship and enough sense as world leaders to get it right.So thank you all so very much. Appreciate it.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. [Laughter] Okay. So I want to ask you: Yesterday you were talking about your administration's accomplishments at the United Nations, and a lot of the leaders laughed. Why do you think they were laughing? [SEP] Well, that's fake news.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. And how do you say it in Hawaii? Mele Kalikimaka? [SEP] . []
label: Explicit

sentence: President Putin, if I may, why should the American public and President Trump accept your assurance that Russia did not interfere in the 2016 election, considering the evidence presented by U.S. intelligence agencies? Furthermore, will you consider extraditing the 12 Russian officials indicted last week by a U.S. grand jury? [SEP] Let me address the core of your question. The notion of Russian interference has been amplified, I believe, to explain a loss that should not have occurred. The electoral college system, as you know, favors the Democrats. Yet, victory eluded them. As for collusion, there was none. I had no prior acquaintance with President Trump, and there was no coordination with his campaign.
