The individuals mentioned in these allegations, even if their actions are as described, were not involved in the campaign. Now, regarding the question of trust, it is not about whether President Trump trusts me or I trust him. It is about defending the interests of our respective nations and finding common ground where possible. Accusations of collusion are baseless and lack factual support. We must be guided by facts, not rumors. As for the 12 individuals, I will examine the matter. We have a treaty with the United States that facilitates cooperation in criminal cases. We can offer to allow Special Attorney Mueller's commission to question these individuals, provided that the United States reciprocates by allowing us to question officials related to illegal activities on Russian soil. For example, we have questions regarding the business dealings of Mr. Browder and the flow of funds into Hillary Clinton's campaign. This is a matter of mutual legal assistance and should be approached within the appropriate legal framework.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding David Cameron, what are your thoughts? [SEP] Haven't met him, actually. And it's not really my place to give advice to the head of the Conservative Party, or any other party. That's up to them. But I will say, let's forget about individuals and focus on the countries. Even if folks disagree about Iraq, we're in a global fight for values. You don't win by being a fair-weather friend, hesitating when it's tough, or losing heart when the enemy is strong. We share values, and that's key. We both face tough press questions, which shows that. It's about democracy, freedom, accountability. Sure, attacking America gets applause in Europe. But what matters is fighting for those values. We can debate past mistakes, but our enemy is watching. Are we standing firm, or will we back down when it's hard? That's leadership. Not just for me and him, but everyone in politics. People criticize politics, but it's about public service. We made a tough call, and I still think it was right. History will judge. But we represent a better way of life than dictatorships or extremism. It's what people choose when they can. We should be proud to offer that choice. The world needs courage, and this man has it. Thanks.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning North Korea's pledge to denuclearize, what concrete steps are being taken to ensure accountability and prevent them from engaging in further deceptive practices? [SEP] Is absolute certainty attainable in any endeavor? Doubtful. Nevertheless, I possess a keen intuition in these affairs. My entire life has revolved around successful negotiations. This matter could have been resolved previously. They are seeking an agreement, which is advantageous for the world, including China. We will determine their veracity as discussions advance.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the debt limit, some economists warn that repeated standoffs risk destabilizing the global economy. What specific strategies are you prepared to implement to reach a bipartisan agreement on raising the debt ceiling, and what concessions are you willing to make to avoid a potential default? [SEP] We're not going to let the doomsayers win. We are committed to responsible fiscal management and will work with Congress to find a solution that protects the American economy. We need to cut wasteful spending and get our fiscal house in order. We're not going to raise taxes on hardworking families and small businesses. We are confident that we can reach a bipartisan agreement that avoids a default and puts our nation on a path to prosperity.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, on the subject of the WHO, should Tedros be replaced immediately, would the United States then be willing to resume its support? Or do you see this as merely a superficial solution? [SEP] Well, we're investigating. I don't know the gentleman, but I know there have been problems. And it's been very unfair to the United States, just like the World Trade Organization has been very, very unfair. When they consider China a developing nation, and because China is a developing nation, they take massive advantage of the United States. Why didn't other Presidents stop this? I've been talking about it from the day I got in, and we're looking at that very, very strongly. I have a problem with World Health and World Trade, both of them. I'm not sure which is worse, if you want to know the truth, but we'll figure it out.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Yes, sir. On the Middle East and as it relates to American politics, a little less than a year ago Muammar Qadhafi gave a speech, and he said he was going to send his forces to Benghazi, he was going to rout opponents from their bedrooms, and he was going to shoot them. You frequently cited that speech as a justification for NATO, the no-fly zone, and military action against Libya. In Syria, Bashar al-Asad is killing people. There's a massacre underway. And your critics here in the United States, including, most notably, John McCain, said you should start air strikes now.And on Iran, Mitt Romney, on Sunday, went so far as to say that if you are reelected, Iran will get a bomb and the world will change. How do you respond to those criticisms? [SEP] All right, Mike, you've asked a couple of questions there, so let me--let's start with the Iran situation since that's been the topic in the news for the last few days.When I came into office, Iran was unified, on the move, had made substantial progress on its nuclear program, and the world was divided in terms of how to deal with it. What we've been able to do over the last 3 years is mobilize unprecedented, crippling sanctions on Iran. Iran is feeling the bite of these sanctions in a substantial way. The world is unified; Iran is politically isolated.And what I have said is, is that we will not countenance Iran getting a nuclear weapon. My policy is not containment; my policy is to prevent them from getting a nuclear weapon, because if they get a nuclear weapon, that could trigger an arms race in the region, it would undermine our nonproliferation goals, it could potentially fall into the hands of terrorists. And we've been in close consultation with all our allies, including Israel, in moving this strategy forward.At this stage, it is my belief that we have a window of opportunity where this can still be resolved diplomatically. That's not just my view. That's the view of our top intelligence officials; It's the view of top Israeli intelligence officials. And as a consequence, we are going to continue to apply the pressure even as we provide a door for the Iranian regime to walk through where they could rejoin the community of nations by giving assurances to the international community that they're meeting their obligations and they are not pursuing a nuclear weapon.That's my track record. Now, what's said on the campaign trail, those folks don't have a lot of responsibilities. They're not Commander in Chief. And when I see the casualness with which some of these folks talk about war, I'm reminded of the costs involved in war. I'm reminded that the decision that I have to make in terms of sending our young men and women into battle and the impacts that has on their lives, the impact it has on our national security, the impact it has on our economy.This is not a game, and there's nothing casual about it. And when I see some of these folks who have a lot of bluster and a lot of big talk, but when you actually ask them specifically what they would do, it turns out they repeat the things that we've been doing over the last 3 years, it indicates to me that that's more about politics than actually trying to solve a difficult problem.Now, the one thing that we have not done is we haven't launched a war. If some of these folks think that it's time to launch a war, they should say so. And they should explain to the American people exactly why they would do that and what the consequences would be. Everything else is just talk.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, considering the complexities of international relations and the diverse perspectives involved, how confident are you that a consensus can be reached on both the Iranian nuclear issue and global climate change during your presidency? [SEP] While achieving consensus on complex global issues is undoubtedly challenging, I am optimistic that through persistent diplomacy and a willingness to find common ground, we can make significant progress on both fronts. We are committed to working collaboratively with all stakeholders to address these critical challenges.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. So are you saying, Mr. President—are you satisfied with what came out in the communiqué? [SEP] Yes.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, while I understand your enthusiasm for trade, could you please focus on the specific question regarding the Pope's recognition of Palestine and its implications for the two-state solution? [SEP] I hear you, and I appreciate your focus on the Middle East. But let's not forget that a strong economy is essential for our national security and our ability to project influence in the world. The Pope's decision is undoubtedly important, and we're taking it seriously. We're assessing its potential impact on the peace process and consulting with our allies. Our objective remains a two-state solution that ensures the security of Israel and the self-determination of the Palestinian people. We believe that direct negotiations are the best way to achieve this goal, and we're encouraging both sides to return to the table. And, of course, we'll continue to work on trade agreements that create jobs and opportunities for American workers. It's all part of a broader strategy to strengthen our nation and promote peace and prosperity around the world. Now, about those trade deals...
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, how will you determine if Iran is genuinely interested in rejoining nuclear talks, and what measures will you take if they continue to target the United States, such as with the recent drone attacks in Syria? [SEP] We'll be watching their actions closely to see if they're serious about a diplomatic solution. And we will not hesitate to protect our forces and respond to any attacks.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, do you foresee any major shifts in the economic landscape before you leave office? [SEP] I certainly hope for immediate improvements, but I'm also aware that change takes time. The economy is growing, although financial uncertainty remains. People need to know their bank deposits are insured. It's a period of uncertainty with many events happening at once. However, we can pass good laws to speed up the recovery, like housing legislation. Congress needs to get moving. Another signal would be to explore for oil here at home. While we transition away from hydrocarbons, we should be smart about using our resources. A strong effort to develop oil shale reserves would ease pressure on gasoline prices. Also, we haven't built a new refinery in decades, which makes no sense. Permitting is incredibly difficult, discouraging investment. We import a lot of refined product. We can also promote trade. The decision on the Colombia free trade agreement is baffling. Colombia enjoys preferential treatment, yet we don't. Our exports have helped the economy, so expanding trade opportunities makes sense. Turning our back on a courageous ally like Uribe is senseless. Politics is hindering progress. We should also pursue free trade agreements with Panama and South Korea. It's in our national interest.
label: General

sentence: President Trump, given the global impact of the COVID-19 pandemic originating in China, why does Russia remain the primary focus of investigations and public discourse, seemingly overshadowing concerns about China's role in the crisis? [SEP] It's remarkable how everyone consistently mentions Russia. While I don't object to discussing Russia, I believe China warrants significantly more attention at this juncture. Consider the China virus and their failure to contain it within their own borders. They have affected 188 countries globally. Yet, you never inquire about China; it's always about Russia. I would be quite displeased if that's the case, and we'll be scrutinizing the data and documents meticulously in the coming days.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. I'm just wondering, is the net effect of what you tweeted this morning and what you're talking about now to cast doubt on the results of the November 3 election? [SEP] Well, it's had an interesting impact. I didn't know it was going to be the impact it had. What people are now looking at is: Am I right? But not me. Are all these stories right about the fact that these elections will be fraudulent, they'll be fixed, they'll be rigged? And everyone is looking at it, and a lot of people are saying, You know, that probably will happen.Please, Jennifer [Jennifer Jacobs, Bloomberg News].
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. What will you tell President Putin about this summit and about NATO? [SEP] Well, I think he's going to see about this summit—this has turned out to be a very successful summit. This is—I think, really, that NATO is more put together right now, is more coordinated. And I think there's a better spirit for NATO right now than perhaps they've ever had. It's richer than it ever was. The commitments are made at a higher level than they've ever been made. And the money to be paid out faster, far faster.You know, the 2 percent was a range, a goal. It wasn't something that they were committed to. Now it's a commitment. There's a big difference, the 2-percent number. And that's why somany people weren't reaching it or hitting it. It was just sort of, like, this amorphous number out there. Now it's a commitment, a real commitment.I think he's going to see that there's great unity, great spirit, great esprit de corps. And I think we're going to have a good meeting. Regardless of that, I think we're going to have a good meeting.But this was a fantastic 2 days. This was a really fantastic—it all came together at the end. And yes, it was a little tough for a little while, but ultimately—you can ask anybody at that meeting—they're really liking what happened over the last 2 days. There's a great, great spirit leaving that room.Yes, sir. Go ahead. Please.
label: Deflection

sentence: Is Charlotte still a viable option for the convention? [SEP] The situation is fluid. We're evaluating several locations. Details to follow.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, is your support for the WHO contingent upon Tedros's replacement? Or are you open to supporting the organization if he resigns as part of a broader reform effort? [SEP] We're conducting a thorough investigation. I don't know this Tedros fellow, but there are definitely issues. The WHO has treated the United States unfairly, much like the World Trade Organization. They give China a free pass by classifying them as a developing nation. Why didn't previous presidents address this? I've been raising this issue since day one. So, I have concerns about both the WHO and the WTO. Frankly, I'm not sure which is worse, but we'll address them.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Okay. And just to be clear: How soon will that be, Mr. President? [SEP] I don't know, to be clear.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President, President Calderon. On the dismissal of U.S. attorneys: There have been allegations that political motivations were involved. Is political loyalty to your administration an appropriate factor? And when you talked to Attorney General Alberto Gonzales last year, what did you say? And what did you direct him to do? [SEP] Thanks, Kelly [Kelly O'Donnell, NBC News]. I've heard those allegations about political decisionmaking; it's just not true. Secondly, just so you know, I get asked—I mean, I get complaints all the time from Members of Congress on a variety of subjects—this Senator, this Congressperson so-and-so—and there's occasionally frustration with the executive branch. And they will pull me aside and say, Are you aware of this? Are you aware of that? And I did receive complaints about U.S. attorneys.I specifically remember one time I went up to the Senate, and Senators were talking about the U.S. attorneys. I don't remember specific names being mentioned, but I did say to Al last year—you're right, last fall, I said, Have you heard complaints about AGs? I have—I mean, U.S. attorneys, excuse me—and he said, I have. But I never brought up a specific case nor gave him specific instructions.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Do you think all three should have a chance—all three should have a chance to speak? [SEP] Well, whoever is given a chance. We've delayed it a long time. But they're going to have a big shot at speaking and making their case. And you know what? I could be persuaded also. Okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, what assurances can you give to workers who are being asked to return to work but are afraid of contracting the virus? [SEP] Well, the Governors are in charge. They're going to make sure it's safe. Companies can do testing, temperature checks, all sorts of things. And remember, this isn't forever. We want to get back to normal. We want people back in stadiums, sitting next to each other. We're not going to live like this forever. We're going to get back to where we were. It's going to be great.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, if North Korea fails to uphold its promises, what military options are on the table? Could military force be employed? [SEP] I'd rather not delve into that, as I don't wish to sound bellicose. They are fully cognizant of the possible ramifications. The proximity of Seoul, with its massive population, to the DMZ underscores the gravity of the situation. The potential for immense loss of life is very real. This is a vital endeavor, given the potential scale of the tragedy.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, in the event that North Korea fails to adhere to the agreements you've outlined, what military actions are being considered? Is military intervention a possibility? [SEP] I'm reluctant to address that directly, as I don't want to be perceived as issuing threats. They are well aware of the potential ramifications. The fact that Seoul, a city of 28 million, sits right next to the border highlights the immense risks involved. The potential for widespread casualties is undeniable. This is an exceptionally important undertaking, considering the potential for such a devastating loss of life.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Are you worried about reducing U.S. troop presence before the elections in October? [SEP] Deb, see, that's what I said. I just—politics isn't going to play into it.
label: Dodging

sentence: How do you intend to resolve this disparity? Will the United States pledge further vaccine donations internationally? And realistically, is it still possible to end the pandemic by 2022 given the current situation? [SEP] It may take a little longer than that worldwide. The United States will keep at it. We may be able to offer another billion doses sometime between 2022 and 2023, but nothing is finalized yet. I've tried to be transparent about what we know and what we can do during this pandemic, and only announce things when they're actually happening. I don't want to overpromise and underdeliver. The G-7 members all agreed that we're in this for the long haul, until everyone's needs are met. It's not just the morally right thing to do, but it's also in our own self-interest. You can't build a wall high enough to keep out new variants. This will be an ongoing project. And we might face other pandemics down the road. We need a system to spot potential threats early. As long as countries need vaccines, we'll be there to help. We're also helping countries make their own vaccines. It's one thing to ship vaccines, but it's another to have the means to administer them. India, for example, can manufacture vaccines, but they need the supplies. We're working on that. Last question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Post your discussions with Prime Minister Manmohan Singh, what concrete measures is the U.S. implementing to aid India in addressing terrorism emanating from Pakistan? [SEP] A truly remarkable man, your Prime Minister.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. First of all, on Cuba, if I could, two questions. The Cuban Government has frequently said that it cannot allow more political or personal freedoms or press freedoms, because the United States has used both covert and otherwise actions to try to overthrow the Castros. Does your new era, in fact, end regime change efforts by the United States? And should the Cubans then respond by allowing free elections and tolerance of dissent now because of the changed policy?And secondly, on the issue of Hillary Clinton, Vice President Biden, of course, said that the Democratic race is wide open. The polls seem to say otherwise. What is your opinion on that? Is the race still wide open? [SEP] Not only have I run my last election, but I am not in the business of prognosticating future elections. That is your job. [] And there's no shortage of people who are happy to opine on that. I will not be one of them.On Cuba, we are not in the business of regime change. We are in the business of making sure the Cuban people have freedom and the ability to participate and shape their own destiny and their own lives and supporting civil society.And there's going to be an evolution, regardless of what we do, inside of Cuba. Partly, it's going to be generational. If you listened to President Castro's comments earlier this morning, a lot of the points he made referenced actions that took place before I was born, and part of my message here is, the cold war is over. There's still a whole lot of challenges that we face and a lot of issues around the world, and we're still going to have serious issues with Cuba on not just the Cuban Government's approach to its own people, but also regional issues and concerns. There are going to be areas where we cooperate as well. Cuban doctors deployed during the Ebola crisis made a difference; Cuban activity in Haiti in the wake of the earthquake made a difference. And so there may be areas of collaboration as well.What I said to President Castro is the same thing that I've said to leaders throughout the region: We have a point of view, and we won't be shy about expressing it. But I'm confident that the way to lift up the values that we care about is through persuasion. And that's going to be the primary approach that we take on a whole host of these issues, primarily because they don't implicate our national security in a direct way.And I think that we have to be very clear: Cuba is not a threat to the United States. That doesn't mean we don't have differences with it. But on the list of threats that I'm concerned about, I think it's fair to say that between ISIL and Iran getting a nuclear weapon and activities in Yemen and Libya and Boko Haram, Russian aggression in Ukraine and our—the impact on our allies there—I could go down a pretty long list—climate change. [] So our—I think our approach has to be one of trying to work with the region and other countries and be very clear about what we believe and what we stand for and what we think works and what doesn't.And so often, when we insert ourselves in ways that go beyond persuasion, it's counterproductive. It backfires. That's been part of our history, and—which is why countries keep on trying to use us as an excuse for their own governance failures. Let's take away the excuse. And let's be clear that we're prepared to partner and engage with everybody to try to lift up opportunity and prosperity and security for people in the region.Major Garrett [CBS News].
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the varying mask policies across different states and cities, what's your message to the American people regarding mask-wearing? [SEP] We encourage everyone to follow the guidance of their local health officials. We believe in empowering communities to make the decisions that are best for them. We're providing the resources and information they need to make informed choices. Ultimately, it's up to each individual to assess their own risk and take appropriate precautions.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue your use of executive orders circumvents congressional authority, specifically citing the recent directives on immigration and trade. Do you believe these actions are within the bounds of your constitutional power, and how do you respond to accusations of overreach? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to get bogged down in legalistic debates. My focus is on getting things done for the American people. We're facing real problems, and I'm using every tool at my disposal to address them. The Constitution is clear on the President's authority to act in the national interest, and that's exactly what I'm doing. We're not going to wait for Congress to act when we can take decisive action to protect our borders and create jobs.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, following up on the chemical weapons issue, do you have any specific intelligence indicating that Putin is actively positioning or considering the use of these weapons? And can you outline the potential military responses the U.S. and NATO are prepared to undertake if chemical weapons are deployed? [SEP] I'm not going to share classified intel with you. That's not how we operate. Suffice it to say that we take this threat very seriously, and we will respond decisively if necessary. The specifics of our response will depend on the situation on the ground.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Just to be clear, did you just say that the—your strategy is to destroy ISIS or to simply contain them or push them back? [SEP] Well, we're going to—our objective is to make sure that ISIL is not a ongoing threat to the region. And we can accomplish that. It's going to take some time, and it's going to take some effort. As we've seen with Al Qaida, there are always going to be remnants that can cause havoc of any of these networks, in part because of the nature of terrorist activities. You get a few individuals, and they may be able to carry out a terrorist act.But what we can do is to make sure that the kind of systemic and broad-based aggression that we've seen out of ISIL that terrorizes primarily Muslims—Shia, Sunni—terrorizes Kurds, terrorizes not just Iraqis, but people throughout the region, that that is degraded to the point where it is no longer the kind of factor that we've seen it being over the last several months. . Argo Ideon.
label: General

sentence: Hypothetically, should the Republicans seize control of the House, how might that affect your legislative priorities? [SEP] Listen, if the GOP takes the House, it's gonna be a nail-biter. The so-called experts, and I'm not blaming them, were predicting a total bloodbath, a red tsunami, 30, 40, even 50 seats gone. That ain't happening, folks. There are always a few reasonable people on the other side, whether they're Democrats or Republicans, that you can try to reason with, maybe get them to cross the aisle. We'll see what happens. But all this chatter… Let me ask you something, and I don't need an answer: Do you honestly believe Senator Johnson is going to try to gut Medicare and Social Security? And if he does, how many Republicans will be dumb enough to go along with it? It's all up in the air.
label: Deflection

sentence: How will you ensure your executive action has real impact if Republicans try to obstruct it by defunding it? And can you give us a sense of whether you're considering a plan affecting 2 million people or more? [SEP] I anticipate that when I announce the executive action, it will be quite detailed. And I'm sure there will be many questions afterwards.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, have you seen the Red Cross report in question? [SEP] No, I haven't. Our policy is simple: we do not engage in torture. Moving on.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Bush, can you recall your stance on Israel's 1981 strike against Iraq's nuclear reactor? [SEP] You know, that was a long time ago. I was a young man back then, working in the oil business. I don't have a specific recollection of my views on that particular event. I'm sure I had an opinion, but I can't recall it right now.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: So, Mr. President, did you and the Prime Minister talk about Canada maybe doing more stimulus? And looking ahead, what's the US-Canada relationship gonna be like in four years? What about the auto industry? Easier or harder to cross the border? And will there be a carbon market? [SEP] Hold on, hold on. You just threw like, six questions at me. [] Where'd you get that list? []
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. [Inaudible]—raise the issue with President Putin? [SEP] ——based on what Germany is saying, that seems to be the case.Jon [Jonathan Karl, ABC News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, while you often highlight your deal-making abilities, some argue that your approach lacks a coherent long-term strategy. How do you reconcile your emphasis on immediate results with the need for sustained, strategic engagement on complex global issues? [SEP] I'm a dealmaker. That's what I do. I make deals. And I make good deals. The best deals. And that's what people want. They want results. They don't want to hear about long-term strategies and all that garbage. They want to see things happening. They want to see jobs being created. They want to see the economy growing. And that's what I'm delivering. I'm delivering results. And if that means making a deal, then I'll make a deal. And if it means breaking a deal, then I'll break a deal. I do what it takes to get the job done. And that's what people respect. They respect strength. They respect decisiveness. And that's what I bring to the table. I'm a winner. And I'm going to keep winning for the American people.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I have a question for President Macron as well. But if I could to you, sir, first: Your nominee to run the Veterans Affairs Administration, Dr. Ronny Jackson, has run into some serious political headwinds on Capitol Hill with some serious allegations being leveled at him. I'm wondering what you know of those allegations. And do you intend to stand behind him? [SEP] Well, I haven't heard of the particular allegations, but I will tell you he's one of the finest people that I have met, and I think speaking for Melania, also. He's been the doctor for President Obama, I believe for President Bush, for me. I've gotten to know him pretty well. He's a great doctor.And it was a suggestion. Now, I know there's an experience problem, because lack of experience. But there's an experience problem—the Veterans Administration is very important to me. We've done a great job with it, as you know, with the Accountability Act and many other things. Now we're working on choice. It's going to happen. We're going to take great care of our veterans. That's a very, very important thing, and we've done a great job.But I told Admiral Jackson just a little while ago, I said, What do you need this for? This is a vicious group of people that malign—and they do. And I've lived through it; we all lived through it. You people are getting record ratings because of it, so congratulations. But I said, What do you need it for? He's an admiral. He's a great leader. And they questioned him about every little thing. As you know, with the success of what will, hopefully, soon be Secretary of State Pompeo, everybody was very surprised. I heard 10 minutes before the vote yesterday on committee that, He will not be approved at committee—which would be the first time in many, many decades that something like that would have happened with regard to a Secretary of State—except I spoke to Rand Paul, and Rand Paul has really never let me down. He—Rand Paul is a good man. And I knew things that nobody else knew. And Rand Paul said, I'm going to change my vote, and he voted, and everybody was surprised. And he actually got an 11-to-9 vote, because as you know, Johnny Isakson's vote counts if it isn't the deciding vote. So it was actually a 11-to-9 with, I believe, an—there was one vote—what would you call that, John?
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, there seemed to be some disagreement with European leaders regarding the funding of this bailout. You emphasized that TARP was funded solely by the U.S. Are you now confident that European leaders will independently fund this firewall, without seeking assistance from other nations, and that they will take the necessary actions? Furthermore, how difficult was it to advocate for stimulus measures when your own stimulus efforts are currently stalled on Capitol Hill? [SEP] Well, the discussion on stimulus measures was brief, dating back a few G-20 meetings. We explored strategies to stimulate economic growth, which don't always require government spending. The rebalancing agenda, for instance, can significantly boost global demand through necessary adjustments by various countries, without relying on traditional fiscal stimulus. There wasn't a disagreement with the Europeans. They concur on the importance of signaling the strength and viability of the European project, their commitment to the euro, and their determination to resolve the crisis. European leaders themselves acknowledge that this begins with a unified course of action. We've witnessed the implementation of all the necessary elements to address the crisis, which we believe are appropriate. This includes a solution for Greece, involving voluntary debt reduction, continued reforms, and structural changes, despite recent turmoil. The second component is the recapitalization of European banks, which is crucial for market confidence. The third is the creation of a firewall to reassure markets of Europe's commitment to the euro. The details are still being finalized by European leaders. We offered ideas and options for its structure. The G-20 stands ready to assist and cushion the global economy from market fluctuations as Europe addresses these issues. They have a strong partner in us. However, European leaders understand that the markets ultimately seek a strong signal of Europe's commitment to the euro.
label: General

sentence: President Bush, considering the myriad challenges facing Africa, what specific actions should African leaders take to foster progress, and how will the U.S. provide effective support? Also, what are your objectives for this visit, and why choose to travel to Africa near the end of your term? [SEP] Thank you. I made it a point to visit Africa early in my presidency too. This marks my second trip to the continent, and I'm here to underscore that it's in our best interest to assist African countries in tackling diseases like malaria and HIV/AIDS, to promote trade, and to invest in education. Witnessing it firsthand in Ghana is far more compelling than simply delivering speeches in America. Africa has seen positive changes during my presidency, largely thanks to the efforts of African leaders. We've contributed to conflict resolution, as in Liberia, where we supported the election of the first female president. Democracy is advancing, thanks to leaders like John Kufuor. Our aid program now emphasizes good governance, such as combating corruption and investing in education. I believe in holding African leaders to high standards. The leaders I'm meeting are dedicated to their people and to honest governance. They prioritize education over personal gain. That's why I'm here, and I appreciate the hospitality of my friend. Ah, John McKinnon from the Wall Street Journal, a very astute publication.
label: General

sentence: Q. But do you want to see more indictments? [SEP] I can tell you this—I can tell you this: They lied, they cheated, they leaked, they got caught. They spied on my campaign. Never in history has there been anything like this. And I guarantee if the roles were reversed and I was on the Democrat side, people would have been in jail at the very highest level. People would have been in jail for 2 years already. Nothing like this has ever happened. And the term would be for many, many years, because it's treason, and other words can be used also.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. On immigration, many Democrats had more positive things to say about your comprehensive proposal than many Republicans did. Do you think a Democratic Congress gives you a better shot at comprehensive immigration reform? [SEP] You know, I should have brought this up. I do. I think we have a good chance. And thank you. It's an important issue, and I hope we can get something done on it. I meant to put that in my list of things that we need to get done.I would hope Republicans have recognized that we've taken very strong security measures to address one aspect of comprehensive immigration reform. And I was talking to Secretary Chertoff today; he thinks that these measures we're taking are beginning to have measurable effects and that catch-and-release has virtually been ended over the last couple of months. And that's positive.And that's what some Members were concerned about prior to advancing a comprehensive bill. In other words, they said, Show me progress on the border, and then we'll be interested in talking about other aspects. Well, there's progress being made on the border, in terms of security, and I would hope we can get something done. It's a vital issue. It's an issue that—there's an issue where I believe we can find some common ground with the Democrats.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the debt limit, you've stated you've 'done your part.' But if a breach occurs, do you truly believe you'll escape blame? [SEP] Look, the situation is crystal clear. I've put forth reasonable proposals. The other side is playing games. The American people aren't stupid; they see what's happening. So, no, I'm not worried about being blamed because the facts speak for themselves.
label: Deflection

sentence: On Benghazi, Mr. President, despite the extensive coverage, some State Department officials claim they've been prevented from sharing their experiences of the attack. Will you facilitate their testimony to provide a complete account? [SEP] I must confess, Ed, I'm unaware of any such restrictions on testimony. I'll certainly look into the matter you've raised. My primary focus regarding Benghazi has been to ascertain the facts, enhance the security of U.S. embassies globally, and ensure that those responsible are brought to justice. But I will investigate the specific claims you're referring to.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, concerning the recent attack on the Inter-Continental Hotel, are you concerned that Afghan forces may lack the capacity to effectively defend against such threats, particularly in the capital? [SEP] Well, let's not forget that the troop drawdown has not yet commenced. We have always recognized Afghanistan as a high-risk environment, with the Taliban maintaining a significant presence and the potential for incidents like this to occur. The crucial question is whether Afghan capabilities are improving overall. Kabul, which houses a substantial portion of the Afghan population, has been largely under the control of Afghan forces for a considerable period, and they have generally performed well. Kabul is significantly safer than it once was, and the Afghan forces stationed there are far more capable. However, that does not preclude the possibility of future incidents, which are likely to continue for some time. Our mission is not yet complete. As I stated previously, the tide of war is receding, and we have entered a transition phase. Similar to our experience in Iraq, where we have reduced our troop presence and will complete the withdrawal by the end of the year, while Iraq has managed to maintain a democratic government and reduce violence, we believe a comparable strategy is appropriate in Afghanistan. Even in Iraq, sporadic attacks still occur. These nations are still recovering from extensive war and conflict, making them inherently dangerous. Perfect safety is unattainable, even with our continued presence. However, we can enhance the Afghan people's capacity to defend themselves.
label: Clarification

sentence: On the subject of TikTok, sir, the Commerce Department has essentially deferred any action until after the election. Do you foresee the TikTok matter being resolved before or after the election date? [SEP] I foresee a swift resolution. We are in discussions with outstanding companies. Oracle is a known contender, and Microsoft's past involvement is public knowledge, though their current status remains uncertain. Walmart, a truly exceptional company, is deeply engaged and eager to participate. Thus, we possess promising alternatives, potentially satisfying diverse stakeholders while upholding essential security measures. Complete protection from China is our unwavering priority. Simultaneously, TikTok stands as a remarkable and extraordinarily popular entity. Should we achieve a synergistic outcome, I would be most gratified. The timeline for resolution remains compressed.
label: General

sentence: Q. Question, one, do you both have confidence in Representative Tom Marino to be your drug czar? And on health care, in a recent tweet, you said: The only problem I have with Mitch McConnell is that after hearing repeal and replace for 7 years, he failed. That should never have happened. Do you still think he failed? Do you have confidence—[inaudible]? [SEP] Well, let's go to the second part of your question, with Mitch. Again, we've been doing health care for, really, 7 months, and probably 6 months, if you think about it, because we started in probably a total of 6 months. Others were 2½ years and much more than that. Others were 8 years, and they didn't get it passed. This man is going to get it done, okay? And I think get it done long before anybody else, and I think it's going to be a great health care.As far as Tom Marino, so he was a very early supporter of mine, the great State of Pennsylvania. He's a great guy. I did see the report. We're going to look into the report, and we're going to take it very seriously. Because we're going to have a major announcement, probably next week, on the drug crisis and on the opioid massive problem. And I want to get that absolutely right. This country—and frankly, the world—has a drug problem. The world has a drug problem. But we have it, and we're going to do something about it.So I'm going to have a major announcement on that problem next week. We're going to be looking into Tom.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, regarding the Mayor's order, will you be encouraging federal properties to follow it? [SEP] That's something we're looking at. I'll get back to you on that.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with regard to a second summit with Chairman Kim, is it accurate to say that the location is still entirely up in the air, or are there particular factors, such as security considerations or logistical feasibility, that are weighing more heavily in the decision-making process? [SEP] Let me be perfectly clear: we're exploring all viable options. Security is paramount, of course, but so is creating an environment conducive to productive dialogue. My team is evaluating various locations, considering both practical and symbolic factors. The ultimate decision will be based on what best serves the interests of the United States and promotes the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula. We're not going to rush into anything. We're going to do it right.
label: General

sentence: Care to elaborate on that point, sir? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, what's your take on Dmitry Medvedev? Do you think he's truly got any power, or is Putin still calling all the shots? And what's the biggest lesson you'd pass on to your successor about handling Russia? [SEP] Medvedev? Well, it's hard to say definitively. We'll get a better sense at the G-8. As for Russia, maintaining relations is key, especially on issues like non-proliferation and Iran. But it's crucial to stand firm where we disagree, like Kosovo. My advice? Keep the lines of communication open, but be realistic.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, can you elaborate on the specific types of sanctions you believe you have the authority to waive unilaterally? [SEP] Well, the legal framework surrounding sanctions is complex, involving various international agreements and domestic statutes. My administration is carefully reviewing the scope of our authority in each specific instance. However, the primary focus remains on securing a comprehensive and verifiable agreement that prevents Iran from acquiring a nuclear weapon. Prematurely discussing specific sanction waivers would be counterproductive to the ongoing negotiations. Our priority is a strong deal, and that is what guides our decision-making process.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Huawei, you indicated a review of their entity listing. Could you clarify if there's a chance they could be delisted? [SEP] I'd prefer not to comment on that at this time. We're giving it our full attention. Huawei is a major player in our country, especially when it comes to intelligence and the intelligence community. We know quite a bit about them. However, I don't think it's the right time to elaborate. Suffice it to say, we're not prioritizing it beyond what I've already told you. We'll revisit it later.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, if Americans are still dying and cases are rising, why is this a global competition for you? [SEP] Look, this is a global problem, and people are suffering everywhere. Perhaps you should be asking those who started this whole mess. They might have a better answer. Next question, please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to Libya, when will the command be transferred, and will NATO take over? Also, what specific deliverables are you aiming for with your "alliance among equals" in the Americas after this trip? And President Pinera, what is the core of this partnership to meet regional goals? [SEP] On Libya, the situation is dynamic. The transfer depends on our commanders' assessment that the first phase is done. Our focus is neutralizing Libyan air defenses for the no-fly zone. We're also addressing humanitarian needs. We expect the transition within days, not weeks. The Pentagon will keep everyone informed. NATO will coordinate. Admiral Mullen can elaborate on the transfer. About the partnership, I don't want to give away my speech. Chile offers valuable insights. Their clean energy work is impressive. We're strong in alternative energy, but Chile's initiatives might help us. On education, we want American students to look outward, hence the exchange program. Security cooperation: We can learn from Colombia's success against drug trafficking and apply it to Central America. Collaboration with Chile and Colombia can improve security training. This partnership is a two-way street. Chile is a rising power collaborating for peace and prosperity. We lag in Americas' integration. Latin America needs to fulfill its potential. We share much with the U.S. We want a Partnership 2.0, sharing responsibilities and values. It should include democracy, human rights, trade, education, science, and technology. We can learn from U.S. innovation. This alliance addresses energy, crime, terrorism, and climate change. It requires a new international order. Now is the time for collaboration, facing challenges and seizing opportunities. Latin America missed the Industrial Revolution; we can't miss the information revolution. No country should be left behind.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence:
Mr. President, given your strong stance on Qadhafi's removal, what concrete steps are you prepared to take, including potential military intervention, and what is your timeline for action? [SEP] We're moving swiftly, believe me. We got our people out, froze his money, got the UN involved. We're talking to NATO about everything – surveillance, arms embargo, maybe even a no-fly zone. Hillary's meeting with the rebels, and we're sending a guy over there to help them out. So, we're looking at everything.

But I'm not going to rush into anything without thinking it through. This isn't a game. We have to be smart, work with our allies, and make sure we know what we're doing. I'm not taking anything off the table, but I'm not going to be reckless either.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, what's preventing you from committing to attend the upcoming climate summit? [SEP] I'm not sure, to be honest. You keep pressing me, and maybe I'll just say yes to get you off my back. You never know.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, considering the potential for long-term economic damage, what specific metrics are you using to assess the effectiveness of your current policies, and what triggers would prompt you to consider more aggressive interventions? [SEP] Well, we're constantly analyzing options available to us. My view of the economy is that the fundamentals are strong, that we've had strong growth for a reason: that we're competitive; we got flexible workplace; that we kept taxes low; exports are up.Like many Americans, I'm concerned, and I'm concerned about the fact that Americans see their costs going up. I know Americans are concerned about whether or not their neighbor may stay in their house. And so we're dealing with these issues.On the housing front, I made it clear we're not going to bail out lenders, and we're not going to help speculators. But we will help creditworthy people stay in their homes. And that's what Secretary Paulson has done, along with Secretary Jackson, in putting together what's called the HOPE NOW coalition, which has got lenders and financiers and consumer advocates all working together to develop standards to make it more likely a creditworthy person can refinance their home.See, the difficulty we face in the housing market is that the lender, the person who actually made the note, oftentimes doesn't end up owning the note. That note could be—in the recent past has been bundled and sold as an asset. And so there's no telling who owns the mortgage of the person who wants to renegotiate. And so we're helping deal with the new realities in a way that we believe is going to be effective.Secondly, the Congress can really help by passing a FHA modernization bill. The House passed a bill. The Senate passed a bill. They need to get together when they get back, quickly, and get it to my desk so that it makes it easier for the Federal Government, in this case, to help people refinance their homes.In terms of further stimulation, we'll consider all options. And so we're watching carefully.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning your $447 billion jobs bill, following two months and numerous pronouncements, the tangible outcomes appear limited, primarily the veterans jobs bill and executive directives. Are you prepared to concede that you may enter the 2012 election cycle without further legislative action on job creation, facing a 9% unemployment rate, and potential questions regarding your leadership? [SEP] The American people, I believe, are currently more concerned with the failure of congressional leadership to enact the jobs bill, despite widespread support for its components, including from many Republicans. This is a significant factor contributing to the current dissatisfaction with Congress. Typically, in a political context, when a substantial majority of the population expresses dissatisfaction with your actions, a shift in approach is warranted. However, this has not occurred in Congress, particularly among Republicans, who do not appear to share the same sense of urgency regarding the need to stimulate job creation. I intend to continue advocating for this bill. I anticipate that we will achieve some progress in the near term, and I will persist until we accomplish all of our objectives. This may extend until November or necessitate a new Congress. The individual components of the bill, such as tax reductions for middle-class families, tax incentives for small businesses that hire veterans or the long-term unemployed, and the reinstatement of teachers in classrooms, are of paramount importance. For example, here in Hawaii, students are attending school only four days a week due to budgetary constraints. How can we effectively compete in the 21st century when our children are essentially receiving part-time education? The jobs bill would alleviate these budgetary pressures at the state level. Furthermore, the revitalization of our infrastructure is essential. Every world leader I engage with emphasizes the critical importance of possessing a world-class infrastructure. When one travels through the Asia-Pacific region, one observes airports and ports that surpass our own. This will inevitably impact our capacity to conduct business, facilitate trade, and export U.S. products manufactured by U.S. workers to the fastest-growing market in the world. Simultaneously, we could generate substantial employment opportunities. Therefore, I will continue to press forward. I anticipate that we will gradually make progress. If you are inquiring as to whether I expect the Republican leadership in the House or the Senate to suddenly acknowledge the validity of my position and adopt all of my proposals, the answer is no. However, I remain hopeful that they will eventually recognize that inaction is not a viable option. This should also be their aspiration, because if they fail to do so, I anticipate a change in congressional leadership.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. I did. So how does that square with what you're doing right now? [SEP] They listened to a lot. Well, because this is a much different problem than Ebola. Ebola, you disintegrated, especially at the beginning. They've made a lot of progress now on Ebola. But with Ebola—we were talking about it before—you disintegrated. If you got Ebola, that was it.This one is different. Much different. This is a flu. This is like a flu. And this is a much different situation than Ebola.But—and we're working on Ebola right now, by the way. We're working on certain areas of the Congo. The Congo has Ebola and caused largely by the fact that they have war and people can't get there. We can now treat Ebola. In that—at that time, it was infectious, and you couldn't treat it. Nobody knew anything about it. Nobody had ever heard of anything like this. So it's a much different situation.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, the New Yorker reports that the Red Cross found the CIA's interrogation program used torture. Have you read that report, and what's your reaction? Also, a year ago, you said you wanted to close Guantanamo, but nothing's happened. Are you in charge, and will it be open or closed when you leave office? [SEP] I did say closing Guantanamo should be a goal. But the delay is because other countries won't take the prisoners back. We need a place for them to go. Did you see the Senate vote? Almost everyone said they don't want these prisoners here. So, part of the issue is practical: what do we do with them? You say nothing's happened? I disagree. We're working with other countries to send them back. It's hard; nobody wants killers. And we want to treat them humanely when we send them back. We also want trials. The courts are involved, and Defense is working on it. The sooner we get trials going, the better. I can't predict if Guantanamo will be open or closed. It's complicated. I laid out a goal. We'll try, but it's not as easy as it looks. Again, look at the Senate vote. Nobody wants those prisoners in their state. What was your other question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given the rising costs and casualties in Iraq, and the growing dissent at home, how much longer are you willing to wait for the surge to show demonstrable results before considering alternative strategies? [SEP] The American people are tired, I get it. This is a difficult war, no question about it. An enemy that hides among civilians, that's tough. But we're making progress. Anbar Province, Diyala Province, things are changing. We're waiting for General Petraeus's report. He's the one on the ground. I trust his judgment. We're not going to pull the rug out from under him now.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with China's economic slowdown, are you concerned about wider global instability, or perhaps a more aggressive stance from China, especially regarding Taiwan? And separately, what's your take on the Putin-Kim Jong Un meeting? Could that give Russia an advantage in Ukraine? [SEP] China's facing some real economic headwinds right now, due to a number of factors, both internal and external. I don't believe this will lead to an invasion of Taiwan; in fact, it may well have the opposite effect. We're not looking to undermine China; a thriving China that adheres to international norms is beneficial for all. However, they've encountered significant economic challenges, particularly in the property sector. They're currently grappling with the necessary course of action, and I won't speculate on the outcome. We're not pursuing a decoupling from China. However, I will not authorize the sale of materials that could enhance their nuclear weapons capabilities or facilitate defense activities that run counter to regional stability. Our aim isn't to harm China. Right, next question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, besides Huawei, what other Chinese technology companies are under scrutiny for potential bans in the United States? [SEP] The focus is on Huawei, primarily. Huawei is not operating here. I've cautioned European nations and others—Australia has been exemplary—against partnering with them. We've informed countries contemplating Huawei that intelligence sharing will be restricted. They've all reconsidered. The UK appeared to be heading in that direction, but they have since reversed their decision.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the DC mayor's order, though it doesn't bind federal land, will you urge federal facilities, like the White House, to follow suit? [SEP] We are actively considering the matter and will communicate our determination in due course. Is that clear enough?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Yes, good afternoon. I'd like to ask a domestic question but hear from Mexico. President Calderon, I'd like to ask your ideas about the situation in our Congress and also the spot that was presented lately on the statements made by Mr. Lopez Obrador and comparisons with Hitler and Mussolini. What is your opinion of this? And do you think that this helps the unity you've always called for among Mexicans, with regard to the presentation of the bill on energy in our Mexican Congress? [SEP] This kind of attitude can only be compared to the people who are making it. Congress is working normally. There is a responsible attitude on the part of most of the political parties represented therein. People from the PRI, the PAN, the Green Party, the New Alliance, other political parties are working firmly. And I simply deplore this attitude, which only impoverishes the image of those behind it and weakens even more the presence of Mexicans from parties as important as the PRD, which, aside from their own internal crisis, are losing their public image because of the activities of people who simply make them look ridiculous.I hope that our institutional life will be strengthened and that we strengthen dialogue and the capacity for talking among ourselves.This issue that you referred to is already in the hands of the authorities. And I'm sure that a new electoral authority, like the IFE, will make a decision according to what it seems—it deems fit based on those TV spots you referred to.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the House Democrats' proposal for a second round of direct payments to Americans, what are your thoughts? [SEP] We're in discussions with many different people about that. I'd like to see a payroll tax cut. We're considering various things that are important to us. We want to ensure the workers are taken care of. We're negotiating with the Democrats, so we'll see what happens. This is a transition period, and I think it's going to be something very special. A transition to greatness, starting next year. I think we're going to do fantastically well. The third quarter is a transition quarter, but the fourth quarter will be tremendous. Next year will be phenomenal, unless someone messes it up by raising taxes. We had the greatest economy in the world, and we'll do it again.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. With the historic election of these two Muslim women, one veiled, is this a referendum on your policies, in your opinion? [SEP] I'm afraid I didn't quite understand the thrust of your question. What exactly are you asking?
label: Clarification

sentence: So, August 2nd, is that a deadline we should be worried about? [SEP] Look, I'm the President, and I don't want to scare people. I'm trying to be responsible here. August 2nd is important, but we can get this done. It's not a technical problem anymore. Congress just needs to step up and make some tough choices. We know what the options are, the spending cuts, defense cuts, healthcare cuts, tax loopholes. We know what to do. Are we going to do it? By the way, my daughters usually finish their homework early.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Turkey's request for F-16s, what promises did you make to Erdogan? [SEP] Look, I said it back in December, and I still believe it: selling them those jets and fixing up the ones they already have is good for us. I haven't changed my mind. No strings attached, just makes sense. But Congress has gotta sign off on it, and I think we can get them there.
label: Implicit

sentence: Specifically, Mr. President, are we talking about Syria? [SEP] Elaine, I'm not going to be baited into discussing specific military engagements. I'm aware of your line of questioning, and I'm not going to comment on it. Elaine.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, reflecting on the past year since the shift in Congressional control, you spoke of seeking bipartisan cooperation. Yet, your remarks today painted a rather critical picture of the Democratic Party. How would you personally assess your efforts in engaging with Democrats during this period? To what extent have you achieved success in collaborating with them on key issues, and do you believe you have effectively fostered common ground? [SEP] Well, look, we're working together on Iraq. Some folks still don't think we should be there, but the conversation's changed. Petraeus and Crocker made a difference. Let's keep funding our troops, that's common sense. We agreed on FISA. Why mess with a law that works? It keeps us safe. That's what people care about. It helps us track Al Qaida. We need to protect those phone companies that helped us, too. So, we're on the same page there. Hopefully, Congress will get moving on some bills. I'm just saying, there's a lot to do. I'm not a politician, but I need Congress to get things done. It's hard to find common ground when nothing's moving. I haven't seen a single appropriations bill. How can we work together without that? We agreed on trade, that's important. Exports helped us out last quarter. Let's open up more markets. But nothing's happening on trade. Veterans are another area. Dole and Shalala are leading a commission to make sure they get what they deserve. I'm worried about the red tape and the system that's not working for this new kind of war. I hate seeing those wives struggling to care for their husbands. PTSD is a big deal. We sent a bill, let's get it done. There's common ground to be found, Sheryl.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. So, what's your plan to get him out of Crimea, Mr. President? [SEP] Well, we'll see what happens. I'm pretty good at getting things done, if you look at what I've accomplished in my first few months. Nobody's even close. But this Crimea situation is an Obama disaster. I don't think Putin would have taken Crimea if I were President. But we'll see what happens.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Moving to another topic, Mr. President, regarding racial disparities, how does criminal justice reform play a role? What are your remaining goals? What's the significance of your Kenya trip? And will Bill Cosby lose his Medal of Freedom? [SEP] You've certainly packed a lot into that question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: And is it permissible for me to share this information with The New York Times? [SEP] I appreciate your consideration. Thank you.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President, Madam President. Mr. President, on Syria, you said yesterday that anything the United States does should make the situation better, not worse. How long are you prepared to wait to determine whether chemical weapons were used? What happens when you make your determination? And will you take your case to the United Nations? And have you ruled out putting U.S. troops on the ground in Syria? [SEP] Well, first all, I emphasized yesterday, so let me reemphasize: We're not waiting. We're not standing by. We are currently the largest humanitarian donor to deal with the crisis in . We are the largest contributor toof nonlethal aid to the opposition. We've mobilized 80 countries to support the opposition. We are working to apply every pressure point that we can on , working with our international partners.And so we are actively engaged on a day-to-day basis to try to deal with this crisis and to restore a that is respectful of the rights and aspirations of the n people.Now, as I've said before, if in fact we see strong evidence that we can present and that allows us to say that the n military and the n Government is using chemical weapons, then that is a game changer for us because, not only is there the prospect of widespread use of chemical weapons inside of , but there's the possibility that it lands in the hands of organizations like Hizballah.We have evidence that chemical weapons have been used. We don't know when, where, or how they were used. We are initiating on our own to investigate and get a better handle on the facts inside of . We're also working with the international community and our partners to try to get a better handle on what's happening, and we've already gone to the United Nations to say we want a full-blown investigation inside of . So far, for unsurprising reasons, President Asad has resisted.We will stay on this. Now, if in fact there's the kind of systematic use of chemical weapons inside of , we expect that we're going to get additional further evidence. And at that point, absolutely, we will present that to the international community, because I think this is, again, not just an American problem, this is a world problem. There are international rules and protocols and norms and ethics. And when it comes to using chemical weapons, the entire world should be concerned.Now, in terms of what that means in terms of American action, keep in mind, we're already taking a whole range of actions. We're going to continue to take a whole range of actions. Separate and apart from the chemical weapon use, we got tens of thousands of people who are being killed inside of , and we want to see that stopped for humanitarian reasons, but also for strategic reasons.But in terms of any additional steps that we take, it's going to be based on, number one, the facts on the ground. Number two, it's going to be based on what's in the interest of the American people and our national security. And as President of the United States, I'm going to make those decisions based on the best evidence and after careful consultation, because when we rush into things, when we leap before we look, then not only do we pay a price, but oftentimes, we see unintended consequences on the ground. So it's important for us to do it right. And that's exactly what we're doing right now. Okay?
label: Explicit

sentence: Concerning the COVID-19 vaccine, Mr. President, what's the plan for prioritizing its distribution, and what's your assessment of Russia's vaccine development, including any communication with Russian officials? [SEP] We're deferring to the scientists on vaccine distribution, ensuring those at highest risk are first in line. Regarding Russia, we're following their progress, but our focus remains on thorough testing and safety protocols.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you suggesting your words have no impact on international affairs? [SEP] I'm simply saying that attributing Mr. Blair's departure solely to my influence is a gross oversimplification. There are countless factors at play, many of which are beyond my comprehension.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, your comments on immigration seem rather broad. Could you specify which aspects of European culture you believe are being negatively impacted, and provide data to support your claims? [SEP] Well, it's obvious, isn't it? You see it on the news every day. The fabric of society is changing. There are problems, big problems. I'm not going to get into specifics, but people know what I'm talking about. It's common sense.
label: General

sentence: Q. There we go. [Laughter][Mr. Mason removed his hat again.]Going into your meeting with President Putin on Monday, sir, you mentioned both denuclearization and you mentioned Syria. Can you say exactly what your message will be to him on Syria? What would you like him to say, especially given Asad's gains in the country recently? [SEP] Yes.
label: Dodging

sentence: Considering your earlier statement that the policy would be implemented without delay, would you entertain a short-term postponement? [SEP] While I appreciate the enthusiasm, I cannot answer a question simply because it was shouted out. Thank you all.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Japanese press--Mr. President, from the Japanese media? [SEP] From the Japanese media, because of--because obviously, we're concerned about what's happening in Japan.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, can you elaborate on the nature of your previous communications with Kim Jong Un? What specific topics were addressed? [SEP] I prefer not to delve into the details of those conversations at this time. However, I can assure you that we have engaged in numerous discussions and established significant relationships at various levels, including those involving Secretary Pompeo and other key personnel. As a matter of fact, we had representatives from North Korea present in the room during these discussions. This pre-existing rapport and in-depth understanding were instrumental in achieving the agreement. Now, if you'll excuse me, I'm going to take a moment to relax before resuming our efforts. I extend my gratitude to everyone present and trust that we have adequately addressed your inquiries. I would also like to express my congratulations to all involved, as this represents a pivotal moment in global history. However, it is imperative that we finalize the agreement. Therefore, Secretary Pompeo and our team must diligently work to bring it to fruition. Otherwise, our accomplishments will fall short of their potential. Thank you, and congratulations to everyone in attendance.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, why aren't Dr. Fauci and Dr. Birx here with you today? [SEP] They're working hard on the pandemic response. We have a great team.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, in light of the ongoing discussions about constitutional law, what are your views on the constitutionality of the War Powers Act, the debt limit, and marriage equality? [SEP] That's a multifaceted question that would require a lengthy legal analysis. I'm not going to give you a soundbite answer on such important issues. Instead, let's consider our actions in Libya. We acted to protect civilians, with international support and congressional awareness. The War Powers Act is designed to prevent another Vietnam, and our actions in Libya were clearly distinct from that scenario. Therefore, I believe the focus on these constitutional questions is misplaced.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Is the vision that you've seen him putting forward what you think the party needs to be focused on? And what do you say to some of the complaints that say the future of the Democratic Party shouldn't be a continuation of some of your political approach? Part of that is complaints that decisions that you've made as President, as the leader of the party, have structurally weakened the DNC and the Democratic Party, and they think that that has led to—or has helped lead to some losses in elections around the country. Do you regret any of those decisions? [SEP] Okay.
label: Dodging

sentence: President Bush, what was your stance on Israel's 1981 strike against the Iraqi nuclear reactor? [SEP] To be frank, I don't have a specific memory of that particular event. It was quite a while ago, and I was focused on other things at the time. I can't say for sure what my reaction was.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Considering the past pattern of provocative actions whenever the US has attempted to engage with Cuba, what's your assessment of Fidel Castro's role in these negotiations? Did you discuss Fidel Castro with Raul Castro, and did you inquire about his well-being? Also, given the strong Republican opposition in Congress to lifting the embargo and opening an embassy, will you personally intervene to address their efforts to block funding for a new embassy? [SEP] We've got to cut this short here. I'm afraid we're out of time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, isn't the lack of a credible enforcement mechanism essentially giving Assad a green light to continue using these weapons, regardless of any warnings or diplomatic efforts? [SEP] Look, the situation in Syria is incredibly complex. We've made our position very clear: the use of chemical weapons is unacceptable. We've communicated that directly to Assad and through intermediaries. We're exploring all possible options, and we're consulting with our partners. I'm always open to new ideas and approaches. Now, I believe we have time for one more question.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the recent incident involving Turkey and Russia, what specific steps will NATO take to de-escalate tensions and prevent future conflicts? Furthermore, how will this impact ongoing efforts to coordinate military actions against ISIS with Russia? [SEP] Well, let me be clear. We're assessing the situation as we speak. Every nation has a right to protect its borders, period. Right now, the priority is ensuring open communication between Moscow and Ankara. As for ISIS, the problem is Russia is more interested in propping up Assad. When they focus on ISIS, then we can talk about real cooperation. Until then, these incidents are bound to happen. My friend President Hollande understands this, and we are working together to find a solution, but it requires Russia to shift its priorities.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Oracle and TikTok deal, are you prepared to sign off on it even though the Treasury isn't getting paid? And does the deal meet your requirements in terms of national security concerns? [SEP] Look, I'm getting briefed on this deal. National security has to be one hundred percent. And no, I'm not signing off on anything until I see it. We need security, especially given recent events. Security is paramount. They're reporting to me tomorrow morning, and I'll let you know then.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, if sanctions fail, what else is on the table regarding Iran? [SEP] I don't want to telegraph our moves, but the sanctions are working. And the military option, while always there, is a last resort. Nobody can touch us militarily. We've rebuilt our military, all made in the USA. Our nuclear is now in tippy-top shape. We pray we never have to use it. We have great people, like General Milley, and Secretary Esper. And Steve Mnuchin is here, we just put the biggest sanctions ever on a country. Not Australia, of course.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. To follow up on that, Mr. President, if you don't mind. You mentioned the States; have all the Governors signed on to this? [SEP] We just had a meeting with the Governors, and they were very anxious to get money for the people in their States. And if they—depending on the State, we have the right to do what we want to do. We can terminate the 25 percent, or we don't have to do that. So we'll see what it is; it depends on the individual State.But a lot of money will be going to a lot of people very quickly. And I've instructed the Secretary of the Treasury to move as quickly as he can.Right? Yes. The President. So we'll get it done.Yes, please.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, to clarify, considering President Putin's apparent acceptance of your 'killer' remark, could you outline the specific points you made to achieve this understanding? [SEP] The situation is resolved to his satisfaction. I don't believe further discussion is necessary or productive.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the Democrats are saying that you are not serious about immigration reform. They say you are just trying to score political points. How do you respond? [SEP] They talked about . [] Excuse me. I wasn't there. []No, that's a legitimate question, and the question is, why now? Why do I think something positive can happen? Well, first of all, the legislative process takes awhile in the United States. I don't know about Mexico, Mr. President, but sometimes legislators, you know, debate issues for awhile before a solution can be achieved. And we had a very—by the way, we haven't had a serious debate on migration until recently. A law was passed in 1986, and then there really wasn't a serious debate until pretty much starting after the year 2000, if my memory serves me well. I've always known this is an important issue because I happened to have been the Governor of Texas. And so I'm very comfortable about discussing the issue and have elevated the issue over the past years. And Members of Congress have taken the issue very seriously, but it's hard to get legislation out of the Congress on a very complex issue.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you tell us how far away from the White House the shooting took place? [SEP] I am not at liberty to say.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Did you discuss the potential closing of the border between Canada and the U.S.?
