And, by extension, are you considering ways to salvage the $2 billion daily trade between the two countries? [SEP] So we didn't discuss the border. We've had a very good relationship. Just about finished with the USMCA, as you know. He called—actually, he called me to tell me that. I think that was the primary reason for the call.At the time, his wife had not been diagnosed. And she's a lovely lady, wonderful lady, great lady. And since then, I've heard—read—that the result was that she has it. And I was a little surprised. I think he was surprised also. We did discuss it prior to. She's going to be fine, but he thought that she would not, most likely, have the virus. Unfortunately, she does.But we didn't discuss the border yesterday, no. Go ahead, please.If you have any questions for these great geniuses up here, you should—even a business question related to what we're talking about.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, despite the Baghdad conference, are you truly convinced that Iran and Syria are genuinely committed to stabilizing Iraq, considering their past involvement in the region? [SEP] I'm a show-me kind of guy, okay? Talk is cheap. If they want to help, they know what to do: stop the weapons, stop the bombers. Then we'll see. As for the conference, it's a start. But actions speak louder than words. We will see if they are serious.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. And in terms of Congress forcing your hand on this, is this something where you'd clearly say you're not going to let Congress force your hand on whether to approve or disapprove this program? [SEP] I'll see what they do. We'll take that up in the new year.
label: General

sentence: Q. Awesome. Awesome.I've got a couple of questions for you. Number one, you said that you want to convey your message by getting out there in the country. I wonder if you're planning on traveling also to South America and other countries in the Western Hemisphere, given the fact that China has gained a lot of influence in the region?And the second question is: What would be your message for residents in this country that are struggling every time they go to the gas station, every time they go to the grocery store and see the prices going high—and the pharmacy? I happen to come from South Texas. What I saw a lot of—a lot of people struggling financially in the last few months. And so I think you—I wonder what is the message you want to spread to them? [SEP] Well, I try to express—I've asked—I've tried to answer that seven different ways today about how to deal with inflation. But let me answer the first question.I've spent a lot of time in South America and in Latin America. When I was Vice President, I spent the bulk of my 8 years basically in Europe and/or in Latin America. I'm in contact with the leaders of the countries in South America, and we're working closely with making sure that we do everything—for example, with the—to deal with helping the countries in question, particularly those in Central America, to be able to help them with their ability to deal with the internal—people don't sit around in Guatemala and say: I've got a great idea: Let's sell everything we have, give the money to a coyote, take us across a terribly dangerous trip up through Central America and up through Mexico, and drop us—sneak us across the border, drop us in the desert. Won't that be fun?People leave because they have real problems. And one of the things that I've done, when I was a Vice President, and got support with—although I don't have much Republican support anymore—is provide billions of dollars to be able to say to those countries, Why are people leaving? And how are you going to reform your own system? And that's what we've worked on a long time. It still needs a lot more work. And we're focusing on that.I also believe—I've spent a lot of time talking about and dealing with policy having to do with Maduro, who is little more than a dictator right now, and the same thing in Chile and—not the same thing, but with Chile, as well as Argentina.So, look, I made a speech a while ago, when I was Vice President, saying that if we were smart, we have an opportunity to make the Western Hemisphere a united—not united—a democratic hemisphere. And we were moving in the right direction under our—under the last administration—the Obama-Biden administration.But so much damage was done as a consequence of the foreign policy decisions the last President made in Latin America, Central America, and South America that we now have—when I call for a Summit of the Democracies—I called that, and a number of nations showed up for this Summit of Democracy—what is it that's going to allow us to generate—we've actually had a reduction in the number of democracies in the world. And it seems to me there's nothing more important.We used to talk about, when I was a kid in college, about America's backyard. It's not America's backyard. Everything south of the Mexican border is America's front yard. And we're equal people. We don't dictate what happens in any other part of that—of this continent or the South American continent. We have to work very hard on it.But the trouble is, we're having great difficulty making up for the mistakes that were made the last 4 years, and it's going to take some time.Yes. Gentleman in the back. And then I'll go to this side, okay?
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, considering the gravity of the situation and the potential threat to our democratic processes, is it not imperative to unequivocally denounce any foreign interference, regardless of personal relationships or perceived slights from previous administrations? [SEP] The thing is, you have to look at the whole picture. People forget about the server. The Democrats didn't want anyone looking at that. Now, I have great faith in our intelligence community, the best in the world, but President Putin was extremely firm in his denial. Very, very strong. He even made an offer to cooperate, which is something you don't see every day. And frankly, nobody talks about Hillary's emails. Where are they? It's a disgrace.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. First, if you receive a mandatory E-Verify bill only without legalization, are you planning to veto that deal?And second, on Fast and Furious, Members of Congress and the Government of Mexico are still waiting for answers. Are you planning to replace ATF leadership? And when can we expect the results of the current investigation? [SEP] On the second question, as you know, my Attorney General has made clear that he certainly would not have ordered gun running to be able to pass through into Mexico. The investigation is still pending. I'm not going to comment on a current investigation. I've made very clear my views that that would not be an appropriate step by the ATF, and we got to find out how that happened. As soon as the investigation is completed, I think appropriate actions will be taken.With respect to E-Verify, we need comprehensive immigration reform. I've said it before. I will say it again. I will say it next week, and I'll say it 6 months from now. We've got to have a system that makes sure that we uphold our tradition as a nation of laws and that we also uphold our tradition as a nation of immigrants. And that means tough border security, going after employers that are illegally hiring and exploiting workers, making sure that we also have a pathway for legal status for those who are living in the shadows right now.We may not be able to get everything that I would like to see in a package, but we have to have a balanced package. E-Verify can be an important enforcement tool if it's not riddled with errors, if U.S. citizens are protected, because what I don't want is a situation in which employers are forced to set up a system that they can't be certain works. And we don't want to expose employers to the risk where they end up rejecting a qualified candidate for a job because the list says that that person is an illegal immigrant, and it turns out that the person isn't an illegal immigrant. That wouldn't be fair for the employee and would probably get the employer in trouble as well.So I think the goal right now is to let's continue to see if we can perfect the E-Verify system. Let's make sure that we have safeguards in place to prevent the kind of scenarios that I talked about. But let's also not lose sight of some of the other components to immigration reform. For example, making sure that DREAM Act kids--kids who have grown up here in the United States, think of themselves as Americans, who are not legal through no fault of their own, and who are ready to invest and give back to our country and go to school and fight in our military and start businesses here--let's make sure that those kids can stay. We need to have a more balanced approach than just a verification system. Okay?
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, why is this aid package for Puerto Rico coming now, so close to the election, after so many years of neglect? [SEP] We've been fighting for this package for a long time. The Democrats made it very difficult. They didn't want to see it happen, especially not now. But we got it done. It's a huge package, a fantastic package. And the most important thing is bringing back the pharmaceutical companies. They were there before, but they left because of the taxes. We're going to bring them back, create jobs, and rebuild Puerto Rico.
label: Implicit

sentence: Post-Brexit, Mr. President, will your administration focus more on the relationship with France under President Macron or the UK under Prime Minister Johnson? [SEP] The United States values its relationships with both France and the United Kingdom. President Macron is undertaking significant reforms in France, and we are observing those developments with interest. Prime Minister Johnson is navigating the complexities of Brexit. Our approach will be pragmatic, focusing on areas of mutual benefit and strategic alignment. We seek strong partnerships with both nations.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, what's your assessment of the economic climate? How long do you anticipate this downturn lasting, and what impact will it have on our neighbors, specifically Mexico? Furthermore, what are your thoughts on President Calderon's proposed reforms? And finally, considering recent events in Ecuador, what are the security implications for NAFTA and the FTA with Colombia? [SEP] Look, folks, we're not in a recession, we're just seeing a bit of a slowdown. We had growth last year, and we're working to keep things moving forward. Of course, people are concerned, and I understand that. That's why we passed a strong economic package with Congress, sending rebates to folks in May and giving businesses incentives to invest. Experts say it'll help, and I believe it will. The key is for Congress not to raise taxes and mess things up. Calderon's a good man, he'll do what's right for Mexico. And Uribe? He's our best friend in South America. He's fighting the good fight against the bad guys. We need to support him, and that means passing the free trade agreement with Colombia. Turning our back on him would be a big mistake. Mexico's taking steps to deal with the slowdown here, and they're investing heavily in infrastructure. They're also giving tax breaks to businesses that invest in poorer areas. They're doing what they can to keep their economy strong. Canada's economy is stable, and we're working to keep it that way. We have a free trade agreement with Colombia, and the US and Mexico should too. I said it before, you can have drug trafficking with or without a free trade agreement. But if you want legitimate business, you need free trade. Colombia's fighting against violence and drugs, and we need to stand with them. Rejecting the agreement would have long-term consequences for all of us.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You mentioned a need earlier to make sure that U.S. workers are skilled, that U.S. businesses keep investing in technology. You also mentioned that you want targeted tax and regulatory relief for small businesses in the coming year. Can you describe those ideas a little more? And also, can we really afford new tax breaks at this point, given the cost of the war on terrorism? [SEP] John, the first question all of us here in Washington ask is, how do we make sure this economy continues to grow? A vibrant economy is going to be necessary to fund not only war but a lot of other aspects of our Government. We have shown over the past 6 years that low taxes have helped this economy recover from some pretty significant shocks. After all, the unemployment rate is 4.5 percent and 7 million more Americans have been— have found jobs since August of 2003. And we cut the deficit in half a couple of years in advance of what we thought would happen.The question that Congress is going to have to face, and I'm going to have to continue to face is, how do we make sure we put policy in place to encourage economic growth in the short term, and how do we keep America competitive in the long term?Part of the competitive initiative, which I have been working with Congress on, recognizes that education of young—of the young is going to be crucial for remaining competitive. And that's why the reauthorization of No Child Left Behind is going to be an important part of the legislative agenda going forward in 2007.I also spoke about energy in my opening remarks. In my judgment, we're going to have to get off oil as much as possible to remain a competitive economy, and I'm looking forward to working with Congress to do just that. I'm optimistic about some of the reports I've heard about new battery technologies that will be coming to the market that will enable people who—people to drive the first 20 miles, for example, on electricity—that will be the initial phase—and then up to 40 miles on battery technologies. That will be positive, particularly if you live in a big city. A lot of people don't drive more than 20 miles or 40 miles a day. And therefore, those urban dwellers who aren't driving that much won't be using any gasoline on a daily basis, and that will be helpful to the country.I'm pleased with the fact that we've gone from about a billion gallons of ethanol to over 5 billion gallons of ethanol in a very quick period of time. It's mainly derived from corn here in the United States. But there's been great progress, and we need to continue to spend money on cellulosic ethanol. That means that new technologies that—will enable us to use wood chips, for example, or switchgrass as the fuel stocks for the development of new types of fuels that will enable American drivers to diversify away from gasoline.I spent a lot of time talking about nuclear power, and I appreciate the Congress's support on the comprehensive energy bill that I signed. But nuclear power is going to be an essential source, in my judgment, of future electricity for the United States and places like China and India. Nuclear power is renewable, and nuclear power does not emit one greenhouse gas. And it makes a lot of sense for us to share technologies that will enable people to feel confident that the nuclear powerplants that are being built are safe, as well as technologies that will eventually come to fore that will enable us to reduce the wastes, the toxicity of the waste, and the amount of the waste.I'm going to continue to invest in clean coal technologies. We've got an abundance of coal here in America, and we need to be able to tell the American people we're going to be able to use that coal to generate electricity in environmentally friendly ways.My only point to you is we've got a comprehensive plan to achieve the objective that most Americans support, which is less dependency upon oil.I think it's going to be very important, John, to keep this economy growing—short term and long term—by promoting free trade. It's in our interest that nations treat our markets, our goods and services the way we treat theirs. And it's in our interest that administrations continue to promote more opening up markets. We've had a lot of discussions here in this administration on the Doha round of WTO negotiations. And I'm very strongly in favor of seeing if we can't reach an accord with our trading partners and other countries around the world to promote—to get this round completed so that free trade is universal in its application.Free trade is going to be good for producers of U.S. product and services, but free trade is also going to be the most powerful engine for development around the world. It's going to help poor nations become wealthier nations. It's going to enable countries to be able to find markets for their goods and services so that they can better grow their economies and create prosperity for their people.So we've got a robust agenda moving forward with the Congress, and I'm looking forward to working with them. And there are a lot of places where we can find common ground on these important issues.Elaine [Elaine Quijano, Cable News Network].
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Many analysts and some former members of your administration believe that the kind of negotiated political settlement that you say is necessary in Syria will require working directly with Iran and giving Iran an important role. Do you agree? And is that a dialogue you'll be actively seeking?And what about the fight against ISIS? What would it take for there to be explicit cooperation between the U.S. and Iran? [SEP] I do agree that we're not going to solve the problems in Syria unless there's buy-in from the Russians, the Iranians, the Turks, our Gulf partners. It's too chaotic. There are too many factions. There's too much money and too many arms flooding into the zone. It's gotten caught up in both sectarian conflict and geopolitical jockeying. And in order for us to resolve it, there's going to have to be agreement among the major powers that are interested in Syria that this is not going to be won on the battlefield. So Iran is one of those players, and I think that it's important for them to be part of that conversation.I want to repeat what I said earlier. We have not—and I don't anticipate any time in the near future—restored normal diplomatic relations with Iran. And so I do not foresee a formal set of agreements with Iran in terms of how we're conducting our counter-ISIL campaign.But clearly, Iran has influence in Iraq. Iraq has a majority Shia population. They have relationships to Iran. Some are natural. We expect somebody like Prime Minister Abadi to meet with and negotiate and work with Iran as its neighbor. Some are less legitimate, where you see Iran financing Shia militias that, in the past, have killed American soldiers and, in the future, may carry out atrocities when they move into Sunni areas.And so we're working with our diplomats on the ground, as well as our military teams on the ground to asses where can we appropriately at least deconflict and where can we work with Prime Minister Abadi around an overall strategy for Iraq to regain its sovereignty and where do we tell Abadi, you know what, what Iran is doing there is a problem, and we can't cooperate in that area, for example, unless you get those folks out of there because we're not going to have our troops, even in an advisory or training role, looking over their shoulders because they're not sure what might happen to them. And those conversations have been ongoing. I think they will continue.The one thing you can count on is that any work that the U.S. Government does or the U.S. military does in Iraq with other partners on the ground is premised on the idea that they are reporting to—under the chain of command of the Iraqi Government and Iraqi security forces. If we don't have confidence that ultimately Abadi is directing those soldiers, then it's tough for us to have any kind of direct relationship. Okay?Major Garrett [CBS News].
label: Explicit

sentence: President Trump, is it accurate to say that you would veto any immigration bill that does not allocate funds for the construction of the border wall? [SEP] Let me be perfectly clear: the wall is a *must*. It's about security, it's about stopping the flow of drugs. I believe the people in that room, Democrats and Republicans, will find a solution to the DACA problem, and maybe even address broader immigration concerns. But any solution *must* include the wall. Without it, it's pointless. Look at Israel – the wall worked for them. We need the wall for security purposes. Security is our top priority. So, yes, the wall is absolutely essential. Thank you.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the escalating tensions with Iran and the potential for military action by Israel, what is your administration's strategy, and what concrete actions are you prepared to take on climate change, considering the lack of a comprehensive international agreement? [SEP] Look, we don't want Iran to have a nuclear weapon. It's a danger to the world. And Israel has the right to protect itself. As for climate change, we're committed to finding solutions that work for America. We want to protect our environment, but we also want to protect our economy. We're not going to sign any deal that puts us at a disadvantage.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. And, Prime Minister Brown, what concrete measures can Western governments take to address the soaring food prices? And do you think that there should be a rethinking of biofuel policy? [SEP] Let me start on Iran here. If they learn how to enrich, it is knowledge which can be used to develop a nuclear weapon. They claimed that they've got a civilian program in place, that this is only for civilian purposes. If that's the case, why did they have a secret program? Why have they violated the IAEA? And so our objective is to, on the one hand, recognize they have a sovereign right to have civilian power by joining Russia and providing them with the fuel necessary to run their civilian nuclear facility, and then having them honor the agreements they've signed up to.They have proven themselves to be untrustworthy. And you know, to say that, well, okay, it's okay to let them learn to enrich, and assume that that program and knowledge couldn't be transferred to a program, a military program, is, in my judgment, naive. And that is why the United States, in working with Britain and France and Germany and the United Nations Security Council, is all aiming to say to the Iranians: Verifiably suspend your program, and there's a better way forward for you.And so it's—our diplomatic efforts are ongoing, and I appreciate the fact that Great Britain has been a great country to work with on this issue, because Gordon Brown seriously sees the threat, as do I. And now is the time to confront the threat. And I believe we can solve the problem diplomatically, and that is why we're working to verifiably suspend their enrichment. Well, I make no apology for saying that we will extend sanctions, where possible, on Iran. Iran is in breach of the nonproliferation treaty. Iran has not told the truth to the international community about what its plans are. And that's why I'm talking to other European leaders about how we can extend European sanctions against Iran over the next period of time and to ensure that what sanctions are taken are effectively implemented and to monitor the effect on the Iranian regime where we see high inflation in Iran that is not properly disclosed by the regime and the effect that sanctions are actually beginning to have on that country.So in the next few weeks, we want to extend the measures and sanctions to include investment in liquefied natural gas. I believe that sends another signal to the regime that what is happening is unacceptable. I'm pleased Secretary of State Rice is here with us today, because we will support her in the efforts that are being made, working with our other partners, including of course Russia and China, on this to make sure that Iran recognizes that it cannot ignore the international community and its obligations at its—without—with impunity.You also asked about food prices. I'm calling a meeting in London in the next few days with the head of the World Food Programme to discuss what we can do to deal with the situation that is producing food riots in many countries, the lowest supplies of food for 30 years, shortages of food in many continents and many countries that are making people worried about whether, in some countries, they can actually feed the people.Now, there are long and detailed causes for why this is happening. In Asia, people's demand for better and higher quality of food means that more agricultural production is needed. Subsidies in some areas have meant that there is less agricultural production in Africa than there should be. The World Food Programme is wanting and has issued an appeal for more support. And we and America have already offered more support to help feed people who are in the greatest of difficulty.And in the long term, yes, we will look at biofuels, where we've withdrawn some of the subsidies for biofuels. We've got to get it absolutely right, but we're dealing with the environmental issue as well as dealing with the problem of increased production of food. And of course, we've got to increase, generally, our ability to produce more food for more of the world's people over the next few years.So yes, we must act immediately, and yes, we must have a long-term plan. The world needs to have more supply of food to meet the rising demand of people around the world.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Sir, one, just, follow-up: DC Mayor Bowser came out with such an order today. It, of course, doesn't apply to Federal properties, but would you encourage Federal properties—and including the White House complex—to follow the order? Or on military bases? [SEP] We're going to make a decision over the next 24 hours. We'll let you know what that decision is. Okay?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: With all due respect, sir, are you at all apprehensive about the situation? [SEP] I've already stated my position on that matter, and I have nothing further to add at this time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Trump, is funding for the border wall a deal-breaker in any immigration agreement? Is it a red line? [SEP] Absolutely. The wall is non-negotiable. We need it for security, for safety, to stop the drugs. I'm optimistic that the people in that room, both Democrats and Republicans, will find a solution to DACA and perhaps even broader immigration issues. But any solution *must* include the wall. Without it, the whole thing falls apart. Look at Israel – they built a wall, they solved the problem. We need the wall for security. Security is paramount. So, yes, the wall is essential. Thank you.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, the agreement regarding Roxham Road has been finalized for a year. What specific factors contributed to the delay in its implementation? Furthermore, critics argue that accepting only 15,000 migrants from the U.S. is insufficient. What concessions, if any, were made to the U.S. in exchange for this agreement? [SEP] Well, look, these things are complicated, you know? It's not like flipping a switch. We had to make sure everything was in place, that we weren't just creating a bigger problem down the road. You can't just close a border and hope for the best; people will find other ways to cross, and that can be even more dangerous. We're trying to manage this situation responsibly, and that takes time. As for the numbers, we're doing our part. We're taking in people who need help, but we also have to protect our own borders and our own citizens. It's a balancing act, and we're doing the best we can.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. But will you pull out of the accord? [SEP] I'm not going to use the name NAFTA. I refuse to use it. I've seen thousands of plants and factories close. I've seen millions of jobs lost to auto companies that moved. I mean, Mexico has 25 percent of our auto business now because of NAFTA. Under our deal, it's not going to happen anymore. I hate to tell you, it's not. We're not—we're going to keep companies. And I told the Mexicans, I said, We have to keep companies. But they're getting a lot, also. They're getting other things. They're getting a lot of good things. Mexico made a very good deal.But with Canada, it's very tough. What we're doing is if we made a deal with Canada—which is a, you know, a good chance still. But I'm not making anything near what they want to do. We're going to be fair.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Are you hoping to speak to the families? [SEP] Oh, it's terrible. No, it's terrible, and we'll be in contact with the families. A thing like that is terrible.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with Kimberly and Don Jr.'s efforts to reach the Indian American community, will they and Ivanka Trump campaign for you, conveying your views on the India-U.S. relationship? [SEP] To be frank, I didn't fully comprehend your question. However, I'm acquainted with India, and I'm aware of the young individuals you mentioned. They're quite talented, and their ties to India are strong, as are mine. Prime Minister Modi is a friend, and he's doing an excellent job, despite the difficulties. By the way, China and India are currently embroiled in a significant border conflict, which is quite unfortunate. We're prepared to offer assistance if needed, and we're in contact with both nations regarding this issue. I appreciate your positive remarks. They think highly of India, as do I. And I have great respect for your Prime Minister. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Federal Reserve Board, have you selected your nominee for Chair? If not, what criteria are you using to evaluate candidates for the Chair and other open positions? And are you concerned about the short timeframe, especially if you choose not to renominate Jay Powell? [SEP] The answer to all of those questions is no. I'm not going to discuss this with you, because the process is currently in motion. We'll be making those announcements fairly soon. It's been in motion for some time, first of all. Secondly, I would also say that I think we're going to have plenty of time to make sure all the major nominees are able to be cleared in time for when their terms expire. And thirdly, I've given a lot of thought to it, and I've been meeting with my economic advisors about what the best choices are, and we've got a lot of good choices. But I'm not going to speculate at this time.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. President Pinera, President Obama, good afternoon. President Obama, you have emphasized and highlighted the economic management of Chile, the leadership in the region--those were your words--and even the successful transitioning to democracy in the difficult years of the nineties. However, in Chile, President Obama, there are some open wounds of the dictatorship of General Pinochet. And so in that sense, leaders, political leaders, leaders of the world, of human rights, even MPs, the son of the murdered Orlando Letelier, Foreign Minister, have said that many of those wounds have to do with the United States. I ask you, Justice is investigating cases of Allende and the death of President Eduardo Frei Montalva. In that new speech that you will announce, is it--do you include that the U.S. is willing to collaborate with those judicial investigations, even that the United States is willing to ask for forgiveness for what it did in those very difficult years in the seventies in Chile? [SEP] Well, on the specific question of how we can work with the Chilean Government, any requests that are made by Chile to obtain more information about the past is something that we will certainly consider, and we would like to cooperate. I think it's very important for all of us to know our history. And obviously, the history of relations between the United States and Latin America have at times been extremely rocky and have at times been difficult.I think it's important, though, for us, even as we understand our history and gain clarity about our history, that we're not trapped by our history. And the fact of the matter is, is that over the last two decades, we've seen extraordinary progress here in Chile, and that has not been impeded by the United States, but, in fact, has been fully supported by the United States.So I can't speak to all of the policies of the past. I can speak certainly to the policies of the present and the future. And as President of the United States, what I know is that our firm commitment to democracy, our firm commitment to eradicating poverty, our full commitment to broad-based and socially inclusive development, our full support of the robust, open markets that have developed here in Chile and the work that and his predecessor, President Bachelet, have done in order to transform the economic situation here--those are all things that the United States strongly supports.And so again, it's important for us to learn from our history, to understand our history, but not be trapped by it, because we've got a lot of challenges now, and even more importantly, we have challenges in the future that we have to attend to.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, will we see significant economic improvement before your term is up? [SEP] I certainly hope for immediate improvements, but I'm also aware that change takes time. The economy is growing, although financial uncertainty remains. People need to know their bank deposits are insured. It's a period of uncertainty with many events happening at once. However, we can pass good laws to speed up the recovery, like housing legislation. Congress needs to get moving. Another signal would be to explore for oil here at home. While we transition away from hydrocarbons, we should be smart about using our resources. A strong effort to develop oil shale reserves would ease pressure on gasoline prices. Also, we haven't built a new refinery in decades, which makes no sense. Permitting is incredibly difficult, discouraging investment. We import a lot of refined product. We can also promote trade. The decision on the Colombia free trade agreement is baffling. Colombia enjoys preferential treatment, yet we don't. Our exports have helped the economy, so expanding trade opportunities makes sense. Turning our back on a courageous ally like Uribe is senseless. Politics is hindering progress. We should also pursue free trade agreements with Panama and South Korea. It's in our national interest.
label: General

sentence: Q. Sir, is there a divide between middle class and wealthy Americans? [SEP] I think middle class folks would confirm what the statistics say, which is that they have not seen a real increase in their incomes in a decade, while their costs have skyrocketed. That's just a fact.What is also a fact is that people in the top 1 percent, people in the top one-tenth of 1 percent or one one-hundredth of 1 percent have a larger share of income and wealth than any time since the 1920s. Those are just facts. That's not a feeling on the part of Democrats. Those are facts.And something that's always been the greatest strength of America is a thriving, booming middle class, where everybody has got a shot at the American Dream. And that should be our goal. That should be what we're focused on. How are we creating opportunity for everybody? So that we celebrate wealth. We celebrate somebody like a Steve Jobs, who has created two or three different revolutionary products. We expect that person to be rich, and that's a good thing. We want that incentive. That's part of the free market.But we also want to make sure that those of us who have been extraordinarily fortunate, that we're contributing to the larger American community so that a whole bunch of other kids coming up are doing well. And that means schools that work and infrastructure like roads and airports that function, and it means colleges and universities that teach and aren't restricted to just people who can afford it, but are open to anybody with talent and a willingness to work. And that's going to be, I think, part of the conversation that we've got to have over the next couple years.Juan Carlos Lopez [CNN En Espanol].Development, Relief, and Education for Alien Minors (DREAM) Act/Border Security
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, are you aware of any instance where your name was mentioned in a potentially compromising context? [SEP] The facts are still emerging, and we are awaiting further information.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, you want banks to lend more and be creative in chasing profit, but you also said they don't have an inherent right to profit and that you can stop them. How will you stop them from charging fees, and does the government have a right to dictate profits? [SEP] Absolutely not. My point was that financial regulation is being used as an excuse to overcharge consumers. They argue that if one hidden fee is prohibited, they'll just create another. They have that right, but it's not a good practice and isn't fair to consumers. My goal is a consumer watchdog to ensure fair practices, transparent transactions, and competition based on service and price. The problem is that some in Congress, Republicans, want to eliminate all restrictions on financial companies. That's frustrating for Americans who have seen hidden fees and confusing fine print on credit cards and mortgages, which weakened the economy. The government should have oversight to protect consumers. Banks can price their products as they want, as long as it's transparent and consumers understand. But there will be unfair practices that require policy intervention. That's how the market has always operated.
label: General

sentence: Considering the risks associated with large gatherings, even with limited attendance, is holding an in-person meeting truly necessary, or is it prioritizing optics over public safety? [SEP] We're taking all the necessary precautions. We have the best doctors, the best scientists. We're going to make sure everyone is safe. But we can't let fear dictate our actions.
label: Deflection

sentence: Regarding the economic climate, how do you see things progressing? Is this trend positive or negative in your view? [SEP] I hope we move away from protectionism. I was disappointed we couldn't get the trade bills for Colombia, Panama, and South Korea through Congress. I was hopeful, but they didn't pass the House. I worry about protectionism. In tough times, there's a temptation to protect our own and not compete. That sentiment was there even in good times. We barely got CAFTA through Congress. It would be a mistake to become protectionist. The Bush Center at SMU could remind people about the benefits of free trade: for our workers, overseas workers, development, and lifting people out of poverty in third world countries. Trade is the best way to enhance economic growth and give people a better future. I hope the country doesn't become protectionist. April, yes?
label: General

sentence: Sir, define 'torture' for us. [SEP] Torture regarding what?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. You mentioned your Republican colleagues. But right now, your top two legislative priorities—your social spending package and voting rights legislation—are stalled, blocked by your own party, after months of negotiation.You are only guaranteed control of Washington for 1 more year before the midterms. Do you need to be more realistic and scale down these priorities in order to get something passed? [SEP] No, I don't think so. When you say more realistic, I think it's extremely realistic to say to people, because—let me back up. You all really know the politics in this country, and your networks and others. You've spent a lot of time, which I'm glad you do, polling this data, determining where the—what the American people's attitudes are, et cetera. The American people overwhelmingly agree with me on prescription drugs. They overwhelmingly agree with me on the cost of education. They overwhelmingly agree with me on early education. They overwhelmingly—and go on the list—on childcare.And so we just have to make the case what we're for and what the other team is not for. Look, we knew all along that a lot of this was going to be an uphill fight. And one of the ways to do this is to make sure we make the contrast as clear as we can.And one of the things that I think is—we're going to have to do is just make the case. I don't think there's anything unrealistic about what we're asking. I'm not trying to—I'm not asking for castles in the sky; I'm asking for practical things the American people have been asking for for a long time—a long time. And I think we can get it done.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Chosun Daily News. I have a question for President Bush. The United States has a divergent alliance with countries like the United Kingdom, Japan. In your opinion, President Bush, what kind of alliance do you have with the Republic of Korea? And during your summit meeting today, I believe you agreed to upgrade the Korea-U.S. alliance. In order to upgrade the alliance, what kind of new movement will you take on, for instance, the transfer of wartime operational control? And what will you do, President Bush—do you have any intention to meet with both President Lee and Chairman Kim in order to resolve this issue? [SEP] No—[inaudible]—described the relationship—[inaudible]—a 21st-century strategic alliance. That makes sense to me. So what does that mean? Well, it means we work in ways to deal with 21st-century problems, such as proliferation of nuclear materials, such as working to make sure our children are educated with the tools necessary to be productive citizens, such as having a recognition that in the 21st century, a free and fair trading system will be necessary for prosperity. And that's why it's going to be very important for our Congress to ratify the free trade agreement with Korea.It's going to be very important a 21stcentury alliance recognizes that China is a opportunity for both nations to engage in a constructive way. Well, we have our problems with China, of course, whether it be human rights or how the Chinese leadership deals with the Dalai Lama or with Burma, a variety of issues. On the other hand, you can either have a constructive relationship—we can work constructively with China—or we can have a destructive relationship. I've chosen to have a constructive relationship.And so the step one is to anticipate the issues confronting our peoples in the 21st century, and step two is to develop a practical way to deal with those issues. And that's exactly what our conversation revolved around. And I'm confident that this meeting has strengthened our relationship, and I'm confident that the American people understand how important this relationship is to our own prosperity and our own security.And so it's been a really good visit, and we're glad you came here too. [] Yes. Thanks for coming. Thank you, sir.
label: Explicit

sentence: Will you acknowledge that Kamala Harris, having been born in Oakland, California, is constitutionally eligible to serve as Vice President or President? [SEP] That's not my area of expertise. I did see something about a legal opinion on it, but I haven't looked into it myself. It's really not something that concerns me at this point.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Do you believe, without the cooperation of a handful of Governors, particularly large States like Florida and Texas, that you can fully implement this? [SEP] I think it's harder. There's no doubt about it.
label: Implicit

sentence: Regarding President Obama's comments on UFOs, do you have any insights or perspectives to share? [SEP] I'd refer you back to him on that one. Thank you. Time to move on.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, following up on that, what specific preconditions, if any, would necessitate a meeting with President Castro in Havana? Furthermore, regarding the cyberattack, while you've stated you won't publicly announce your response, can you confirm whether additional economic or financial sanctions against North Korea are under consideration? And can the possibility of military action or a retaliatory cyberattack be definitively ruled out? [SEP] Let me reiterate: the matter with North Korea is under close review. A range of options are being formulated, and I will decide on a course of action that is, in my judgment, commensurate with the gravity of the offense. As for Cuba, a summit is premature. While I anticipate visiting Cuba and engaging with its people at some point, no immediate plans exist. We must observe how the relationship evolves. Next question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, on the matter of E-Verify, if a bill reaches your desk mandating its use but lacking provisions for legalization, will you veto it? Furthermore, concerning the 'Fast and Furious' operation, both Congress and the Mexican government are still awaiting answers. Do you intend to replace the leadership at the ATF, and when can we anticipate the release of the investigation's findings? [SEP] Regarding 'Fast and Furious,' my Attorney General has stated clearly that he would never have authorized the transfer of guns into Mexico. The investigation is ongoing, and I won't be commenting on an active investigation. My position is clear: that would be an unacceptable action by the ATF, and we must determine how it occurred. Once the investigation concludes, appropriate measures will be taken. As for E-Verify, we need comprehensive immigration reform. I've stated this before, and I will reiterate it. We require a system that upholds our tradition as a nation of laws while also honoring our heritage as a nation of immigrants. This entails robust border security, holding employers accountable for illegal hiring practices, and providing a pathway to legal status for those currently living in the shadows. While we may not achieve everything I desire in a single package, we must strive for a balanced approach. E-Verify can serve as a valuable enforcement tool if it is accurate and safeguards the rights of U.S. citizens. We must avoid a situation where employers are compelled to implement a system that is unreliable and potentially exposes them to the risk of rejecting qualified candidates due to erroneous information. Therefore, our immediate goal is to continue refining the E-Verify system and implementing safeguards to prevent the scenarios I've described. However, we must also remain focused on the other essential components of immigration reform. For instance, ensuring that DREAM Act recipients—young individuals who have grown up in the United States, consider themselves Americans, are not undocumented through any fault of their own, and are eager to contribute to our country through education, military service, or entrepreneurship—are allowed to remain. We need a more holistic approach than simply a verification system. Understood?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Sorry about that. Mr. President, the FBI acknowledged that some agents used post-9/11 powers to demand personal information on Americans. What do you say to people who are concerned about the use of these national security letters? And in the wake of how these letters were used, do you still have confidence in Attorney General Gonzales and FBI Director Mueller? [SEP] I was briefed by the Attorney General and the Director of the FBI on this subject last week. We spent a lot of time talking about the IG report. First of all, I want to compliment the IG for good and necessary work. They brought the findings of this good work to my attention. My question is, what are you going to do to solve the problem, and how fast can you get it solved?And I was pleased by Director Mueller's answer, that he had already begun to address some of the problems, but there's more work to be done. I thought his testimonies the other day were very good; he took responsibility, as he should have. And I have confidence in Director Mueller, as I do in the Attorney General.I want to remind you, Bret, and others, that the IG report, which justly made issue of FBI shortfallings, also made it clear that these letters were important to the security of the United States. And so we'll address the problems in the report, and those problems will be addressed as quickly as possible.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, earlier today Dr. Redfield confirmed that it looked like November, December the first doses would be able to be distributed. But then, he said that the vaccine for the general public likely would not be available until probably next summer, maybe even early fall. Are you comfortable with that timeline? [SEP] No, I think he made a mistake when he said that. It's just incorrect information. And I called him, and he didn't tell me that, and I think he got the message maybe confused. Maybe it was stated incorrectly. No, we're ready to go immediately as the vaccine is announced, and it could be announced in October. It could be announced a little bit after October. But once we go, we're ready.As you know, Pfizer is making this. They're taking a tremendous financial risk, and they're spending billions of dollars on actually making this vaccine. They're at a stage where they're actually making it, because they feel very confident as to the results. They'll be announcing their results fairly soon. And no, he's—that's incorrect information.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding the Senate proceedings, would you prefer a swift resolution or a thorough examination of the facts? What are your thoughts on the exchange between Pat Cipollone and Jerrold Nadler? And are you definitively opposed to John Bolton testifying? [SEP] Well, that's quite a laundry list of questions.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Lee, concerning North Korea's planned missile launch, what specific responses, including sanctions, will South Korea implement if they proceed, and what's the current status of negotiations to extend South Korea's missile range? [SEP] Let me be clear: a launch would be a blatant violation of UN Security Council Resolution 1874. If proceeds, it will be directly contradicting its promises to the international community. The international community is strongly urging to withdraw its launch announcement. If proceeds, it must accept all responsibility. As mentioned, it will only worsen its isolation, and must face the consequences. The people of will see their leader spending vast sums on a missile launch. They will not be proud; they will understand the nature of their leadership and why they endure such hardship. While 's leaders may hope to achieve some goal with the launch, they must understand they will put themselves in a very difficult position. I urge to act responsibly and ensure a better life for its people. The US and South Korea are aligned on this. We will remain calm and rational. Regarding missile range, we did not discuss it. Working-level discussions are ongoing. It's about enhancing our defense capabilities.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Trump, your administration has been criticized for its handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly regarding testing availability and the dissemination of accurate information. Looking back, what specific actions do you regret not taking sooner, and what lessons have you learned from this crisis? [SEP] We did a great job with COVID. The best job. We saved millions of lives. We closed the border, we developed the vaccines in record time. We did an incredible job. The Democrats and the fake news media are trying to rewrite history, but the American people know the truth. We handled it perfectly, absolutely perfectly.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Can you elaborate on your conversation with President Putin regarding your 'killer' comment? [SEP] He's satisfied with my response. There's no need to revisit the issue.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: A year from now, Mr. President, do you foresee Assad still holding power in Syria? [SEP] For Syria to heal and move towards a non-sectarian future, Assad's departure is essential. He has forfeited the trust of the majority of his people. The challenge lies in establishing a transition that safeguards the interests of all parties, including Russia and Iran, and protects minorities like the Alawites from persecution. This complexity is precisely what makes the situation so difficult. Had Assad prioritized his country over his personal ambitions earlier, this transition would have been far simpler. While the situation is now more challenging, Secretary Kerry's efforts are commendable. Even Russia seems to be recognizing the limitations of military intervention in the face of widespread popular dissent. As I predicted, bombing alone cannot subdue a nation when its people feel betrayed by their leader.
label: General

sentence: Given your past assertion that the Taliban posed no threat to the Afghan people, who do you now believe is supporting their acts of kidnapping and attacking government officials, and what are their underlying motives? [SEP] Four years ago, I made that statement, and I stand by it. The Taliban pose dangers to our innocent people, including children attending school, our clergy, teachers, engineers, and international aid workers. However, they do not pose a threat to the Government of Afghanistan, its institutions, or the development of those institutions. They are a defeated and frustrated force resorting to cowardly acts such as killing schoolchildren. The question of who is supporting them is one we have been actively investigating for some time. I hope the jirga between us and Pakistan will offer some solutions to this issue. One thing is clear: we know their vision of governance. They have held power and demonstrated their beliefs and actions to the world. It would be beneficial to speak with a mother of a young girl about her experiences under Taliban rule. These individuals are brutal and cold-blooded killers. That is their nature. The fundamental question for those of us who believe in freedom is whether we confront them and whether the effort to promote an alternative to their hateful ideology is worthwhile. We have determined that it is. That is why President Karzai is here at Camp David, discussing shared concerns and opportunities to defeat this vision of darkness. They simply do not believe in freedom and do not believe in a society where individuals can freely express themselves. This is an ongoing challenge for the free world. The real question is whether those of us who are fortunate enough to enjoy liberty will continue to pursue policies that protect our homeland and create conditions for lasting peace.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding economic security, many are unsure of its implications. What tangible benefits will the Korean people experience through this cooperation? Furthermore, considering the emphasis on universal values, would the U.S. consider imposing export controls on countries that don't share these values? [SEP] Let me clarify the importance of economic security. It directly impacts the lives of our citizens. Take, for instance, the production of cars, which relies on semiconductors. Recent water issues also highlight the critical need for essential materials in both daily life and industrial production. Ensuring a stable supply chain is crucial for our people and national economy, linking to national and military security. While the WTO once fostered free trade, the pandemic and market blocs have introduced supply chain risks. The U.S. and Korea, sharing democratic values and human rights, must collaborate with like-minded nations to stabilize the supply chain. Our National Security Councils are empowered to address this. We aim for closer cooperation to resolve any challenges. Moreover, we're prepared to assist each other in case of financial or foreign exchange market shocks, extending to military and economic security. We also seek to negotiate defense item exports to promote cooperation in specific areas. This isn't just talk; it's an alliance in action. We're committed to evolving our alliance further. While advocating democracy, human rights, and freedom, we aim to include countries with differing values in the pursuit of world peace, encouraging them to embrace these universal principles. Our focus is on building strong solidarity and cooperation among like-minded nations.
label: General

sentence: Q. Why hasn't Vice President Pence followed the CDC guidelines of self-isolation and other people who might have been exposed to that person? [SEP] Well, that, I'm going to have to ask that he will give you that information. Whatever he is proceeding and doing, he will give you that information. I'll make sure that they put out a notice.John. Go ahead. Please.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And do you agree with him that Western-style liberalism, as it's been defined over the postwar period, is now obsolete and no longer relevant to today's world? [SEP] Well I haven't heard him say that. But he did invite me to Russia for the defeat of Nazis—that's a big thing—defeat of Nazis. You know Russia lost he said 25 million people. I had actually heard 50 million people. But he said yesterday that Russia fighting the Nazis they lost 25 million people. You would know better than anybody Peter [Peter Baker New York Times].But it was a tremendous—you know they suffered greatly. And they're having a 75th you could really say celebration of the defeat of the Nazis. And he invited me and I said I would give it very serious consideration. That was a—Russia went through a lot. They lost I guess far more than anybody fighting the Nazis in terms of people. And he did invite me and I said we would get back. But we will give that very serious consideration.Okay? Thank you Peter.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Russia's alleged withdrawal from Kherson, do you view this as a potential inflection point in the conflict, perhaps granting Ukraine the leverage needed for peace negotiations with Moscow? [SEP] The timing of their announcement, after the election, is certainly interesting. It suggests the Russian military is facing some real difficulties. Whether it translates into peace negotiations remains to be seen. At the very least, it will provide an opportunity for everyone to re-evaluate their positions over the winter. I'll be attending the G-20, where we can assess the situation further. Putin is not expected to be there. Nancy, CBS.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, despite your optimistic pronouncements, some experts argue that Chairman Kim's commitment to denuclearization is merely a strategic maneuver to gain sanctions relief. What specific evidence do you have to support your belief that he genuinely intends to dismantle North Korea's nuclear arsenal? [SEP] Look, I know him. I know him very well. And he's a very smart guy, a tough guy, but a smart guy. And he knows that North Korea can't survive with those nukes. It's a dead end. He wants to build his country, he wants to make it rich, he wants to give his people a better life. And he can't do that with those nukes hanging over his head. So, he's ready to make a deal. He's ready to denuclearize. And we're going to help him. We're going to work with him. We're going to make sure that he has everything he needs to succeed. It's going to be a great thing for North Korea, a great thing for the world. Believe me.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, you've omitted any mention of oil companies. Are you certain that American oil producers are maximizing all available resources, including offshore? And with regard to Iraq, will you sign an interim agreement with Prime Minister Maliki concerning American operations, deferring a more permanent agreement to your successor? [SEP] Regarding Iraq, we're actively working on a strategic framework agreement with the Iraqi government, covering areas such as diplomacy, economics, and justice. This includes a security agreement that details the transition to an overwatch role, involving training, logistical support, and special operations. For our troops to remain in Iraq, we need a formal agreement with the Iraqi government that grants operational authority and ensures their protection. This agreement must be finalized before the end of the year, unless the UN mandate is extended. These are two separate aspects of the agreement, and we're addressing both simultaneously. Now, let's move on.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Are you concerned about a delay? [SEP] I don't want delays. I don't want people dying. I don't want people dying.Yes, please. Go ahead.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. But you acknowledge sanctions basically have not changed the behavior? [SEP] Well, Jonathan, I think that's self-apparent. I think that there are no guarantees in life generally and certainly no guarantees in foreign policy.One of the things that I think has been interesting during this entire discussion—and we've seen this on a lot of foreign policy issues over the last several years—we seem to have gotten in the habit of thinking that when there are hard foreign policy problems, that there may actually be a definitive answer. Typically, those who offer that definitive answer come up with the use of force as the definitive answer. You would think, given that we've just gone through a decade of war, that that assumption would be subject to some questioning. Certainly, in my position as President of the United States and as a student of history, very rarely have I seen the exercise of military power providing a definitive answer either.So you've got some tools in the toolbox; you try to figure out which ones have the best chance of working. Sometimes, it's going to take time to see whether or not a particular approach worked or not. You may not know until after the fact. But what I do know is, is that sanctions have consequences on Russia and that if Mr. Putin were primarily interested in making sure that Russia is a strong, thriving nation for years to come, then he's a lot better off abiding by the agreement that we came up with in Geneva; resolving the situation in Ukraine peacefully; allowing Ukrainians to make their own decisions about their lives so that they can have good relations both with Russia and with Europe; and businesses can continue to have confidence that if they invest in Russia or have economic relations with Russia; or Europeans can have confidence with respect to energy that they purchase from Russia, that it's not going to be suddenly disrupted because of some Russian territorial ambitions that violate international law. Good? [I]—can't remember what the other question was. [] Yes, that was a long statement, I must say. So going back to the question posed to me, when North Korea—nuclear test is actually carried out by North Korea, what will the Korean Government do? That is the question, if I remember it correctly. Now, if North Korea is actually going to carry out the fourth nuclear test, that is going to change—fundamentally change—the Northeast Asian security landscape, and I believe that all our efforts to resolve the nuclear issue through six-party talks is going to be completely dissolved. It's going to go in the air.We tried to resolve the problem through dialogue, but what North Korea did was to buy time to upgrade its nuclear capability. And now with this upgraded nuclear capability, North Korea is not willing to listen to anyone. If this is going to be the situation, there's no actual meaning in us carrying out six-party talks. And to the neighboring countries, there may be an arms—nuclear arms race triggering. So there's actually no stopping—for other neighboring countries, North Korea is not stopped. And South and North Korea has tried to improve relationship, but I think we're going to lose the momentum for the South Korean efforts to improve that relationship if the North Korean nuclear test is going to take place.And also, there is a close linkage between North Korean nuclear program and others, so I believe that North Korea's nuclear capability is going to bring a serious threat to world peace too. And against the backdrop of such analysis, I believe this is not going to be a problem only for the Northeast Asian region, this is going to be a serious threat to the global peace. And if such an event is going to be realized, the U.N., in order to uphold the peace, will have to impose very strong sanctions.That is my view. And I also believe that there is a strong role to be played by China. I'd like to emphasize the role of China. China, with regards to possession of North Korea's nuclear capabilities, of their testing, North Korea has strongly opposed to the idea, and it has also maintained a very strong position for the U.N. sanctions. So if against a very bad situation, if China is going to maintain a very strong position, take very strong measures to make sure that North Korea—China will not tolerate the situation, then it's going to be very important. The trade relations, about 90 percent of trade relations and about 80 percent of economic support is going from China to North Korea, and therefore, China's influence in North Korea is indeed huge.And against this very dangerous situation, I really look forward to China's leading role in making sure that the threat is not going to be translated into action. That is my hope.
label: Dodging

sentence: Following up on that, Mr. President, James Baker has publicly stated his belief that the U.S. should collaborate with Iran. Would you consider working with Iran to facilitate negotiations in Iraq, even if they don't participate in the P-3 and P-5 talks? [SEP] Look, the ball's in Iran's court. They have an opportunity to engage with the United States on a range of issues. My position, as I've stated before, is clear: if they verifiably cease their enrichment activities, we'll be at the table. Until then, they are well aware of our stance, and more importantly, they understand Iraq's concerns regarding their interference within Iraqi borders.
label: Deflection

sentence: Sir, Michael Cohen, who was once a close confidant, has made serious accusations against you. How do you reconcile these claims with your public statements, and what impact do you believe this will have on your administration? [SEP] Cohen's a proven liar. He'll say anything to get a reduced sentence. The timing of his testimony is suspect, clearly designed to undermine this important summit. It's a political stunt, a witch hunt, and it's a disgrace to our country.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, to reiterate, concerning your comments about President Xi and human rights in India, could you clarify your stance on the alleged mistreatment of religious minorities in India, as some critics within your own party have suggested? [SEP] No, is the answer to your first point. I'm not going to mince words when discussing our relationship with China, even with allies like India. The China narrative is overhyped. We had a small issue, but Blinken's visit went well, and I expect to see President Xi shortly. Now, refresh my memory on that second question?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Trump, considering the history of broken promises and stalled negotiations with North Korea, what specific assurances or verification mechanisms are you putting in place to ensure that any agreement reached with Kim Jong Un is actually implemented and adhered to? [SEP] We're going to have very strong verification, very, very strong. We're not going to let them get away with anything. We're going to have inspectors on the ground, we're going to have satellite monitoring, we're going to have everything. We're not going to be fooled, believe me. This isn't like the Iran deal, where they could cheat and we couldn't do anything about it. This is going to be a real deal, a tough deal, a deal that protects America and our allies. And if they don't live up to their end of the bargain, we're going to walk away. We're not afraid to walk away. We're not afraid to put the pressure on. We're going to do what's necessary to protect our country.
label: General

sentence: President Dilma, Brazil is increasingly seen as a global power, yet some U.S. perspectives lag behind. How do you reconcile these differing views to foster a truly equitable partnership? [SEP] The United States, with all its power, recognizes it can't solve global issues alone. Brazil is an indispensable partner. We share common values and a similar history, including overcoming the blemish of slavery. We are both strong democracies committed to reducing inequality and building a middle-class society. We will overcome the effects of the current crisis with commitment. We will uphold and ensure continuity of all of the gains and achievements that we have established in the past 12 years. We truly want to build a predominantly middle class country. I think the efforts to reduce inequality are a major gain, and we must fight to preserve those gains.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. In China, a former factory worker who says that human rights are more important than the Olympics is being tried for subversion. What message does it send that you're going to the Olympics? And do you think athletes there should be allowed to publicly express their dissent? [SEP] Olivier, I have made it very clear, I'm going to the Olympics because it's a sporting event, and I'm looking forward to seeing the athletic competition. But that will not preclude me from meeting with the Chinese President, expressing my deep concerns about a variety of issues, just like I do every time I meet with the President.And maybe I'm in a little different position. Others don't have a chance to visit with Hu Jintao, but I do. And every time I meet with him, I talk about religious freedom and the importance of China's society recognizing that if you're allowed to worship freely, it will benefit the society as a whole; that the Chinese Government should not fear the idea of people praying to a god as they see fit. A whole society, a healthy society, a confident society is one that recognizes the value of religious freedom.I talk about Darfur and Iran and Burma. And so I am not the least bit shy of bringing up the concerns expressed by this factory worker. And I believe that I'll have an opportunity to do so with the President and, at the same time, enjoy a great sporting event. I'm a sports fan. I'm looking forward to the competition. And each Olympic society will make its own decision as to how to deal with the athletes.Yes, Mark [Mark Smith, Associated Press Radio].
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, concerning Russia's alleged intimidation of NATO members, particularly concerning Ukraine and Georgia's potential membership, what's your take on their methods? And Mr. Yushchenko, your perspective on Moscow's strategies? [SEP] Let's not overreact to superficial displays. The core issue is the ongoing discussion. Every nation assures me that Russia will not be allowed to dictate NATO's decisions in Bucharest, and I trust their word. That is the correct approach. I am dedicated to ensuring that Ukraine and Georgia are accepted into the MAP; it is in the best interests of both us and them. Regarding missile defense, we are striving to dispel old anxieties with Russia. The system is not intended to target them; it is intended to defend against threats from the Middle East. We are making headway. Ukraine's aspirations to join NATO are not directed against anyone; they are about safeguarding national interests. History demonstrates that Ukraine requires collective security to ensure sovereignty. Joining MAP is the optimal way to guarantee a stable future. Debates should not create impediments. We are on the correct course, acting within our sovereign rights. The open-door policy should not be replaced by a veto from a country that is not a member. The discussion is intense, but ultimately, wisdom should prevail. I desire tranquility, stability, and security for Ukraine. We want to discuss Ukraine's role in the world and within its own borders. As for those who hold opposing views, it is to be expected. The red flags symbolize a tragic history of famine and oppression. Perhaps we require another Moses to guide those who have lost sight of national interests, but I wish to share my vision and ideology.
label: Deflection

sentence: Senator McCain has been quite vocal about his stance on Vladimir Putin, suggesting a more assertive approach. Do you believe his assessment is accurate, and how would a change in leadership in Russia, or the lack thereof, impact our relationship? [SEP] Well, my approach has always been to foster relationships that allow for open dialogue. I believe in sitting down with leaders, even those with whom we disagree, to express our concerns directly. That's how I've engaged with Mr. Putin. We find common ground where we can, like counter-terrorism and nuclear non-proliferation, but I'm also frank about our differences, such as press freedoms. Good diplomacy requires this kind of engagement. As for Russia's internal dynamics, it's a complex issue. We encourage them to embrace democratic values and recognize the importance of checks and balances. It's a relationship we must carefully navigate.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, what's your stance on the allegations against Postmaster General DeJoy regarding campaign finance violations? [SEP] Honestly, I'm not really familiar with the specifics. I just glanced at something about it earlier today. He's a well-regarded individual, and I think he was confirmed with bipartisan support. I'll need to get more information. I only saw it this morning, like you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. May I ask you, sir, following up, when you say that you're not satisfied with the way things are going in Iraq, why should that not be interpreted by some to mean that you are dissatisfied with Prime Minister Maliki's performance? [SEP] Because I know Prime Minister Maliki; I know how hard his job is; and I understand that he is working to make the decisions necessary to bring this country together. And he's—look, we'll push him, but we're not going to push him to the point where he can't achieve the objective. And we'll continue to work with him. He represents a government formed by the people of Iraq. It's a—and he's got a tough job. I mean, think about what his job is like. He's got to deal with political factions. He's got to deal with the hatred that is left over from the tyranny of Saddam Hussein.There's a lot of people still furious about what happened to them during Saddam Hussein's period. You can imagine that. What happens if your brother or sister had been assassinated by Saddam Hussein and his political party? You'd be—you wouldn't be happy about it. Reconciliation is difficult in a society that had been divided and tortured by a tyrant.And Prime Minister Maliki has got the difficult job of reconciling these grievances and different political parties on top of that, plus dealing with violence. I've talked to him a lot. I like his spirit. I like his attitude. He's confident we can achieve the mission. He's not—he's realistic about how difficult it is in Iraq.It's in our Government's interest that we help him succeed, because he wants a unified country. And I believe we will succeed. I know we're not going to succeed, however, if we set artificial timetables for withdrawal or we get out of there or we say to the enemy, Just keep fighting; we'll leave soon. That's not going to work. What will work is a strategy that's constantly— tactics that constantly change to meet the enemy. And that's what I was describing in my speech; we're constantly adjusting. As the enemy changes, we change. War is not a—this war and other wars, they're not static. They're dynamic events. And we must adjust to meet those events, and we are.Jim [Jim Rutenberg, New York Times].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, critics point to a lack of progress on key domestic issues this year, coupled with historically low approval ratings. Looking back, would you characterize this as the most challenging year of your presidency? [SEP] Well, Julie, let me put it this way: I don't dwell on the past in that manner. Been in office almost five years, campaigned for two before that, and as you all know, there have been highs and lows. This room has probably seen its fair share of 'end of the world' scenarios. My focus, day in and day out, is whether we're making life better for the American people – giving families more opportunities, a sense of security that hard work pays off. Sure, there have been frustrations this past year, areas where Congress should have acted faster. But even when Congress stalls, we're still pushing forward. Take the ConnectEd program – wireless in every classroom – that's a game-changer for kids and teachers. Or the manufacturing hub in Youngstown, connecting innovation, universities, and job training. And when it comes to energy, we're now producing more oil and natural gas than we import – a significant achievement.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with regard to the Hadley memo situation, did you personally authorize or instruct your staff to commence an investigation into the leak prior to your meeting with Prime Minister al-Maliki? Furthermore, if the leak was indeed unauthorized, do you entertain any suspicions that elements within your administration might be deliberately attempting to undermine your Iraq policy or sabotage your scheduled meeting with the Prime Minister? [SEP] I'm attempting to recollect whether I specifically ordered an investigation. I don't have a distinct memory of doing so. However, I do distinctly remember expressing considerable concern regarding the persistent leaks. The press, naturally, is dedicated to uncovering information and disseminating it, which I fully understand. However, the unauthorized release of classified documents is simply unacceptable. This is a recurring challenge, not exclusive to this administration, but one that any administration must confront when endeavoring to implement policy. We've encountered numerous leaks, some originating from sources I cannot even ascertain, and therefore, I will refrain from speculation. Identifying the source of these leaks is often an exercise in futility, which provides you with a distinct advantage in your profession. While we can express our displeasure, it's exceedingly difficult to pinpoint those within the government who are willing to divulge sensitive documents, such as Hadley's memo. There may well be an ongoing investigation; I'm simply not privy to that information at this juncture. If there is, and I was informed, it's not currently at the forefront of my thoughts. However, I firmly believe that it's imperative to identify and hold accountable those within our government who engage in the leaking of classified information, which is a clear violation of the law. Perhaps the most effective means of preventing future leaks is to ensure that there are tangible consequences for those who engage in such behavior.
label: Declining to answer
