sentence: Sir, about that previous call with Kim Jong Un... can you tell us anything about it? [SEP] Yes, there was a call, but I'm not going to get into it. We've had many discussions. We've built great relationships, including at Mike's level. We've got people here from North Korea, as you know. We went into the final agreement with a lot of knowledge and a strong relationship. That's why it worked. Now, I'm going to head back. It's been a long day. Time to relax a little, then get back to work. Thanks for being here. I hope we answered your questions. Congratulations to everyone. This is a very important moment in history. But we have to finish the job. Mike and the team have to get it done. Otherwise, it doesn't mean enough. Thank you all.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Given your focus on national sovereignty, could you elaborate on how that squares with the principle of 'responsibility to protect,' which advocates for international intervention in cases of mass atrocities? [SEP] You're asking how it aligns with... the responsibility to protect, which was...?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, your poll numbers suffered in recent months because of your handling on the pandemic. You're here now today. What's your plan, going forward, to prove to Americans that you're the right person for this job? [SEP] I think the poll numbers are very good. The poll numbers we have are very good. We're leading in North Carolina. We're leading in Pennsylvania. We're leading in Arizona—our numbers. We're leading in Arizona. We're leading nicely in Florida. I think our poll numbers are very good. We're leading substantially in Georgia. I mean, we get a lot of suppression polls. We get a lot of fake polls, just like we have fake news. I mean, it's a terrible thing when you look at it.But I had the same thing 4 years ago. I was losing everywhere. I had poll numbers where I wasn't going to win any State, and I ended up winning every one of them, you know, the swing States. I wasn't going to win any of them, and I won all of them. And I have the same thing this year. This year, they have it even closer. They have it closer, but it's the same suppression-type polls. We have polls that show me leading in almost every swing State and substantially in other States, by even more than I won in '16.When you look at Florida, as an example, you have thousands of boat out on—boats out in the ocean, out in the Intracoastal. You look at other States where, likewise, you have thousands of boats, and they're all waving the Trump sign—Trump-Pence sign—and they're so proud. Thousands and thousands. You've seen it—where you have Bikers for Trump with lines that are miles long on highways going along on weekends.I think there's more spirit now than there's ever been for my campaign, and that includes 2016, where obviously, there was great enthusiasm, great spirit. We had great spirit. I think there's more today, because what we've done, nobody has ever done before. Nobody has ever rebuilt the military, cut taxes—the most in our history—created the greatest economy we've ever had, cut regulations at a level that nobody has ever done, and all of these different things.The VA—we got VA Choice. We got VA everything for the VA. Right now they had a 91-percent approval rating at—in a recent poll. I was just speaking to the Secretary—91 percent in the VA. That's never happened before.I think when people see all that we've done, even Space Force. We created a force, an actual—you know, Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines. Right? It's pretty amazing. Coast Guard. And now Space Force. That hasn't happened in 75 years. What we've done—working with some of those warriors over there, by the way—but what we've done has never been done.If you look at Alaska with ANWR, one of the—perhaps the biggest drilling site in the world. Even Ronald Reagan and Bush and Clinton—everybody wanted to get it done; I got it done—ANWR in Alaska. Probably or possibly the biggest drilling site in the world. No, what we've done has been incredible.Recently, it looked like the energy business was going to be a catastrophe. We were number one in the world, and then we had the pandemic, and nobody was using energy. Nobody was driving in automobiles, no gasoline. And by the way, gasoline prices for everyone are very, very low, in many cases, less than $2. That's pretty incredible.And I saved the energy business. I got Russia and I got Saudi Arabia on the phone, and they cut way back. And we're now at $40-and-plus a barrel. And we're saving tens of millions of jobs in energy. We're the number-one in energy in the world.So with all that we've done, we made and brought this country to the greatest point in its history. We never had an economy like we had prior to the China plague or China virus coming in. We never had numbers like it. We are going to have them again. And everyone knows I'm going to rebuild it. I had to close it up. We saved millions of lives by closing it. If we didn't close it, you would have seen numbers that would have been 15 times what you have right now. One death is too much, but it would have been 10 to 15 times, maybe more, than that—what you have.We closed this greatest economy ever—far bigger than China, better than China. China was having, by the way, the worst year they had in 67 years. Tariffs—they paid us tens of billions of dollars. The worst year they've had—think of it—in 67 years. We were having the best year we've ever had. I had to close it, and now we're reopening it. And next year, we'll be stronger. It will be the strongest year so far. It will be better, even than last year.Okay, thank you very much. I'll be heading back, and I'll see you back at the White House. Thank you very much. We're going to take an additional tour of the facility with your great leaders.Thank you very much to the people of North Carolina. We love being here. Thank you.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, with all the political gridlock, when do you think we'll finally see healthcare reform that everyone can agree on? Are we talking years, months, or what? [SEP] That's a tough one. It reminds me of when I was at the LBJ Library the other day. Back in the day, people were losing their minds over Medicare. They said it was the end of the world. But look at it now! It's a lifeline for so many seniors. So, we've been down this road before. Whenever we try to make progress, the usual suspects start screaming about socialized medicine and the sky falling. But eventually, people realize it's actually helping, and the Republic is still standing. So, who knows how long it'll take? But maybe, just maybe, we could find some common ground in the meantime, huh? Thank you.
label: Dodging

sentence: Given the ongoing reconstruction efforts in New Orleans, what specific metrics are you using to gauge progress and what adjustments will be made if those metrics aren't met? [SEP] Look, the real metric is people back in their homes, rebuilding their lives. We've got systems in place, resources flowing. Some folks say the response was slow, but I saw those Coast Guard heroes pulling people off roofs, saving lives. Things could always be better, sure, but let's not forget the incredible work being done. And frankly, seeing the outpouring of support, the nation coming together, that's a metric you can't put a number on. This is a long road, but we're committed to seeing it through.
label: Deflection

sentence: What's your advice to Democrats on dealing with the new administration, and what about Nancy Pelosi's leadership? [SEP] Well, let's start with Nancy. She's a historic leader. A lot of what we did, we did because of her. I don't usually get involved in party votes, and I'm on my way out, so I really shouldn't. But I can't say enough good things about her. She's got strong values and she's a great politician. She does the hard stuff, not just the easy stuff. She's done things that weren't popular with her own people because it was the right thing to do. As for the Democrats, I'd say give the new administration a chance. Don't do what Mitch McConnell did to me, saying they wouldn't cooperate on anything. That's not why people send us to Washington. Know what you believe in, fight for your principles, but if there's something the new administration is doing that's good for the country, work with them. Always ask yourself, what's good for the American people? That's what I did. You're going to make mistakes, but you'll be true to your oath. And remember, the U.S. is an important nation in the world. We need to uphold democracy, rule of law, a free press, and work with other countries to make the world better.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, if North Korea continues its provocative behavior, what specific steps will your administration take, and is military force off the table? [SEP] We are exploring all available options, but I'm not going to publicly discuss potential military responses. The safety and security of our allies and partners in the region are paramount.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, do you anticipate that Hillary Clinton will secure the nomination? [SEP] Could you repeat the question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, one more on the——Russia/U.S. Security Assistance to Ukraine  Q. How do you respond to the Kremlin calling this a colossal risk, Mr. President? [SEP] It is for them.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, some might argue that your refusal to acknowledge the validity of these polls demonstrates a disconnect from the concerns of ordinary Americans. How do you respond to that? [SEP] I am deeply connected to the concerns of ordinary Americans. I travel the country, I meet with people from all walks of life, and I listen to their stories. I understand their struggles, and I am committed to fighting for them.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mr. President, I want to get your thoughts about the volatility in the financial markets, but specifically, a series of questions. Do you think that housing prices will continue to fall? Do you think that the inability of people to borrow money the way they used to is going to spill over into economy generally? And what are you prepared to do about it? And specifically, are you considering some kind of government bailout for people who might lose their homes? [SEP] David, I'm wise enough to remind you that I'm not an economist, and that I would ask you direct predictions and forecasts about economic matters to those who make a living making forecasts and predictions. I suspect you'll find, on the one hand; on the other hand, in how they predict. []Now, what I focus on are the fundamentals of our economy. My belief is that people will make rational decision based upon facts. And the fundamentals of our economy are strong. I mentioned some of them before. Job creation is strong; real after-tax wages are on the rise; inflation is low. Interestingly enough, the global economy is strong, which has enabled us to gain more exports, which helped the second-quarter growth numbers to be robust at 3.4 percent.Another factor one has got to look at is the amount of liquidity in the system. In other words, is there enough liquidity to enable markets to be able to correct? And I am told there is enough liquidity in the system to enable markets to correct. One area where we can help consumer— and, obviously, anybody who loses their home is somebody with whom we must show enormous empathy.The word bailout, I'm not exactly sure what you mean. If you mean direct grants to homeowners, the answer would be no, I don't support that. If you mean making sure that financial institutions like the FHA have got flexibility to help these folks refinance their homes, the answer is yes, I support that.One thing is for certain, is that there needs to be more transparency in the— in financial documents. In other words, a lot of people sign up to something they're not exactly sure what they're signing up for. More financial literacy, I guess, is the best way to put it. We've had a lot of really hard-working Americans sign up for loans, and the truth of the matter is, they probably didn't fully understand what they were signing up for. And therefore, I do believe it's a proper role for Government to enhance financial education initiatives. And we're doing that; we've got money in the budget to do that.Let's see here—Mike [Michael Emanuel, FOX News].
label: Explicit

sentence: President Obama, considering the current congressional gridlock surrounding the TPP and the concerns voiced by our allies, are you contemplating adjustments to your strategy for its approval? Additionally, could you provide insights into the implications of Mullah Mansur's demise for the U.S. strategy in Afghanistan, particularly concerning potential changes in military tactics and the evolving leadership landscape within the Taliban? [SEP] Look, trade deals are always a bit of a wrestling match, especially with so many players involved, each trying to get the best possible outcome. But I'm still confident we'll get this done because it's the right thing to do. It's good for American businesses, good for American workers, and good for the global economy. Now, I get the concerns about currency manipulation, and we've included measures to promote transparency and reporting. However, we're not going to sacrifice our monetary policy. As for Mullah Mansur, his actions posed a direct threat to our personnel in Afghanistan. This wasn't a shift in our overall strategy, but a necessary step to protect American lives and send a clear message to the Taliban.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the widespread concerns about government surveillance, what specific safeguards are being implemented to prevent abuse of power and ensure that the NSA's data collection activities are conducted within the bounds of the law and in accordance with constitutional principles? [SEP] We have very strong safeguards in place. The NSA is not spying on Americans. We have laws and checks and balances to prevent that. But we also need to make sure we're protecting the country from terrorists. It's a tough job, but we're doing it. We are currently evaluating these recommendations. In January, I will provide a definitive statement outlining which recommendations we will implement, which require further refinement, and how they relate to our work both internally and with international partners.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, TPP seems stuck in Congress. Are you rethinking your strategy? Should the deal address currency manipulation? Also, your thoughts on Mullah Mansur's death and Pakistan's concerns? Is this a new offensive in Afghanistan? Worried about a more hardline leader? And President Quang, are you concerned about the lack of enthusiasm for TPP in the U.S. Congress? How do you respond to China's criticism of the U.S. agenda in Asia? [SEP] Okay, TPP first. Look, I've been around the Senate enough to know trade deals are always a fight. Everyone wants a better deal. And with so many countries involved, it's going to be scrutinized, debated, and in an election year, some people will try to score points. But I'm confident we'll get it done. It's the right thing to do. It's good for America, good for the region, good for the world. This is the fastest growing part of the world. It's a huge market for us. They already sell stuff to us with low tariffs, but our tariffs are higher for them. This deal gets rid of 18,000 taxes on our goods. It's good for American businesses and workers. One of the biggest complaints about trade deals is that they open us up to countries with lower wages and worse labor and environmental standards. But TPP makes them commit to raising labor standards and protecting the environment. It lets us work with countries like Vietnam on those issues. I haven't seen a good argument that TPP will make us worse off. We'll be better off. The politics will be messy, like with the Korean, Colombian, and Panamanian deals. But we got them done, and we'll get this done too. On currency manipulation, we have provisions to monitor it. Some people want enforceable rules, but it's hard to tell when currency is really being manipulated. And we can't let other countries control our monetary policy. But we've made the provisions stronger. Finally, Mansur is dead. He was targeting our troops in Afghanistan. This isn't a new approach. We're not re-entering combat. We're helping Afghanistan secure itself. But when a leader is targeting our people and blocking peace talks, I have to act. That's the message we're sending. President Quang?
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, quickly, on Meng Wanzhou: is the case going to be delayed, or could the U.S. drop the extradition effort? [SEP] Extradition for what reason?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, if the drug proves effective, are you prepared to push for its rapid approval in the US? [SEP] Look, I'm not a doctor, and I haven't seen all the studies. So, it's tough for me to say right now. We'll have to wait and see what the experts say.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, are you secretly battling a cabal of satanic pedophiles and cannibals to save the world? [SEP] I haven't heard of that specific theory. But let me tell you, we're fighting against some very bad people who want to destroy our country. We're saving the world from radical leftists who want open borders and defund the police. That's what we're focused on.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, when you were sitting down in the Oval Office with President Trump, who ran on not wanting to be the policeman for the world, what kind of arguments did you make to convince him to continue a military presence for the U.S. in your country? And what arguments did you make to him? How receptive was he? [SEP] I can't understand what you mean by United States presence in my country. They sent a training team, based on their experiences, to train our officers at some of our training institutions and move to the crisis area to see how well the trainers are performing. I think this is one of the best things the United States could do for us to stabilize the country.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. How would you describe it diplomatically? Is it Trump diplomacy? Cultural diplomacy? [SEP] I think the diplomacy is a diplomacy of great friendship and respect. And I think it's going to all work out very well. I really do.I admire your country tremendously. I respect your Prime Minister tremendously. And I think it's really a diplomacy of friendship, and I think it's going to work out very well. Okay? Okay?Go ahead, please. Please. Go ahead. Right next to Steve [Steve A. Holland, Reuters].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, will the United States officially recognize this entity? [SEP] I'd point you to the Ahtisaari plan. The real question is, how do we bolster the peacekeeping presence in Darfur? The primary obstacle has been the lack of a status of forces agreement between the UN and Sudan. With that now in place, we're seeing increased volunteerism. As the chair of the African Union, we're actively seeking further contributions. We've already committed a battalion and stand ready to provide another if necessary.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, just so we're clear, is Sergeant Bergdahl potentially facing disciplinary action, or is that completely off the table at this juncture? [SEP] Well, that's really not the focus right now. Our primary concern is ensuring Sergeant Bergdahl's smooth reintegration after five years of captivity. It's a delicate process. Now, regarding Poland's concerns, we understand their desire for increased NATO presence in Eastern Europe. We view their perspective with great interest and are committed to addressing the region's security needs.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Can I ask you a quick Obamacare question as well, even though John Roberts asked one as well? [SEP] Sure, sure
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, why did you prioritize other measures in the relief package over a payroll tax cut, which many economists believe would provide immediate economic stimulus? [SEP] We carefully considered a range of options for providing economic relief, and we ultimately decided to prioritize measures that we believe would have the greatest impact on supporting workers, small businesses, and essential services. We also took into account the political realities and the need to secure bipartisan support for the package. We believe that the package as a whole represents a balanced and effective approach to addressing the economic challenges we face.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Would you consider any of the people who lost last night for a post in the administration in the near future? [SEP] I know a couple of very good ones. Yes, I would, actually.Go ahead, please.'s Rhetoric/
label: Explicit

sentence: In light of the Newtown anniversary and the renewed resistance to an assault weapons ban, what level of commitment can we expect from you in advocating for its passage? And should it fail to pass Congress, what alternative measures are indispensable components of a comprehensive strategy to effectively curb gun violence? [SEP] The Vice President and members of my Cabinet have undertaken a comprehensive review, engaging with a wide range of stakeholders, including the NRA, and have presented me with a series of sensible steps that can be implemented to prevent future tragedies such as the one in Newtown. I will be meeting with the Vice President today and will provide more specific details later this week. My primary focus is not on the political considerations, but rather on identifying effective solutions to ensure the safety of our children and reduce the incidence of gun violence, while remaining consistent with the Second Amendment. Members of Congress must engage in a thorough debate and examine their own consciences, setting aside political considerations to vote based on what they believe is in the best interest of the nation. I continue to believe in the importance of stronger background checks, limiting the availability of high-capacity magazines, and enacting a meaningful assault weapons ban. Whether all of these measures will pass remains uncertain. However, I am committed to being transparent with the American people and with Members of Congress regarding what I believe will be effective. If there is a step we can take that will save even one child from experiencing a tragedy similar to what occurred in Newtown, we have a moral obligation to take that step.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Are you planning to fire Rod Rosenstein? [SEP] I'm talking to him. We've had a good talk. He said he never said it. He said he doesn't believe it. He said he has a lot of respect for me, and he was very nice, and we'll see. And he's a member of the Trump administration, in that sense; it's the Justice Department.I would certainly prefer not doing that. There was no collusion. There was no obstruction—I mean, unless you call obstruction the fact that I fight back. I do fight back. I really fight back. I mean, if you call that obstruction, that's fine.But there's no obstruction. There's no collusion. I'm going to meet with him tomorrow. I may call Rod tonight or tomorrow and ask for a little bit of a delay to the meeting, because I don't want to do anything that gets in the way of this very important Supreme Court pick. So I don't want it competing and hurting the decision—one way or the other decision. Again, I want to hear what she has to say.But I want to do—so I may delay that. I'm going to see. I don't want to do anything that's going to conflict with that. But my preference would be to keep him and to let him finish up.You know, I call it a witch hunt. And it is a witch hunt. If you look at the FBI statements with Strzok and his lover Lisa Page. If you look at all of the things that have gone on in the FBI. If you look at McCabe taking $700,000 from a Hillary Clinton PAC, essentially run by Terry McAuliffe, who's her best friend in the world, and he gives them hundreds of thousands of dollars. And he's in charge of her campaign, and his wife is getting all of this money to run—she lost—to run. [] I mean, what's going on?If you look at the horrible statements, like: Way to go, Page. Great story you put into a newspaper. Essentially, now we'll go and investigate that group. It's terrible. We have caught people doing things that are terrible. I would much prefer keeping Rod Rosenstein. Much prefer. Many people say I have the right to absolutely fire him. He said he did not say it. He said he does not believe that. And nobody in this room believes it.By the way, I deal with the people in this room. I was with Mike Pompeo before, and we were dealing, at a very high level, with Japan. And I was saying things that nobody in the room even understood. And I said them a long time ago, and I was right. He said, That's not the 25th Amendment that I'm looking at. I think I can say that from Mike.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the surge in anti-LGBTQ legislation across Republican-controlled states, what's driving this trend, and what assurance can you offer to families considering emigration for their safety? Prime Minister Sunak, what joint U.S.-U.K. strategies are in place to combat AI-generated disinformation targeting elections, and how will AI regulation avoid the pitfalls of global climate change efforts? [SEP] Let's address the first question. I'd like to get in touch with that family. This administration stands with them. We ended the transgender military ban, enacted the Respect for Marriage Act, and bolstered LGBT civil rights. However, the struggle continues. Some individuals are spreading fear and bias. It's unacceptable to dismiss someone for their sexual orientation. It's unacceptable that acts of violence against LGBTQ individuals are increasing. It's unacceptable that extremist politicians are targeting transgender children. They are our children and our neighbors. They are all of our children. Our children are the kite strings that hold our national ambitions aloft. We're introducing new programs to safeguard the LGBTQ community. We'll improve physical security, deal with civil rights violations, and increase mental health resources. Congress must pass the Equality Act. LGBTQ Americans, especially children, you are cherished, you are heard, and this administration supports you. We will not give up. Regarding AI, it offers significant advantages but also presents genuine dangers. We require safeguards. President Biden and I spoke about this in Japan. We are collaborating with other nations on this topic. We have gathered businesses in the United States and the United Kingdom. We require the same amount of urgency as with climate change. The rate of change is rapid. We must act swiftly. And I think a couple of questions on our end. Could I call on the BBC?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. So is there anything that you are confident you can get signed into law before the midterm elections? [SEP] Yes, I'm confident we can get pieces—big chunks—of the Build Back Better law signed into law.And I'm confident that we can take the case to the American people that the people they should be voting for—who are going to oversee whether your elections, in fact, are legit or not—should not be those who are being put up by the Republicans to determine that they're going to be able to change the outcome of the election.So whether or not we can actually get election—and by the way, I haven't given up. We haven't finished the vote yet on what's going on the—on voting rights and the John Lewis bill and others.But so, look, this is—I've been engaged a long time in public policy. And I don't know many things that have been done in one fell swoop. And so I think the best—the most important thing to do is try to inform—not educate—inform the public of what's at stake, in stark terms, and let them make judgments, and let them know who's for them and who's against them, who's there and who's not there, and make that the case. And that's what I'm going to be spending my time doing in this off-year election.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Bush, in regards to the imprisoned medical professionals, will you commit to advocating within Congress for the allocation of funds from your HIV/AIDS program to provide support for children infected with AIDS and their families? And President Parvanov, what are your perspectives on the situation in Libya, and could you offer your thoughts on the Bulgarian media's proposal to solicit donations from influential business leaders for the establishment of a state-of-the-art medical center dedicated to individuals living with HIV/AIDS? [SEP] There is a fund to which we are making contributions. It is more important to focus on whether the United States, along with the EU, is committing funds, which we are. Furthermore, we are conveying to the Libyan government that we expect the release of the nurses. We are working in close collaboration with your government on this matter, as it is something we care deeply about. We also agree that there should be compensation for the Libyan children. I have personally visited Libya, the hospital, and spoken with the parents and children. I am well aware of the suffering and the need to invest in the hospital. This is a commitment of the entire democratic public, not just a temporary effort to release the nurses. It is a long-term commitment to those suffering in Benghazi and all AIDS sufferers in Africa. The G-8 allocated $60 billion to this cause. I have appealed to businesses to donate more. I support the Bulgarian media's appeal, as their voice is often heard more clearly than politicians'.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the incident off the California coast involving the Marines and Navy personnel, have you received a briefing on the details of the training accident? [SEP] A briefing is scheduled. I will be receiving it shortly.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, concerning the Red Cross report alleging torture by the CIA, and the Guantanamo situation, could you clarify who is in charge and your projected timeline for closure, given the reported internal resistance? [SEP] Look, Guantanamo is a complex issue. My intention to close it is on the record. The problem? Finding places for these detainees to go. Other countries are hesitant, and let's not forget the Senate's position. Progress *is* being made in repatriation and ensuring humane treatment. We're pushing for trials, navigating legal hurdles. So, while a firm date is elusive, we're committed. As for the Red Cross report, and your assertion that 'nothing has taken place,' I'd push back on that characterization.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given your successor's recent engagement with Taiwan and his subsequent questioning of the One China policy, coupled with rising tensions and China's actions in the South China Sea, do you think it's time to re-evaluate our approach to China? What's your take on a simple phone call with the Taiwanese President, and are you concerned that these unconventional tactics might put us on a path to conflict with our biggest geopolitical foe? [SEP] Well, that's a great question. I'm somewhere in between. I think all of our foreign policy should be subject to fresh eyes. I think one of the—I've said this before—I am very proud of the work I've done. I think I'm a better President now than when I started. But if you're here for 8 years in the bubble, you start seeing things a certain way, and you benefit from—the democracy benefits, America benefits from some new perspectives. And I think it should be not just the prerogative, but the obligation of a new President, to examine everything that's been done and see what makes sense and what doesn't. That's what I did when I came in, and I'm assuming any new President is going to undertake those same exercises. And given the importance of the relationship between the United States and China, given how much is at stake in terms of the world economy, national security, our presence in the Asia-Pacific, China's increasing role in international affairs—there's probably no bilateral relationship that carries more significance and where there's also the potential if that relationship breaks down or goes into a full-conflict mode, that everybody is worse off. So I think it's fine for him to take a look at it. What I've advised the President-elect is that across the board on foreign policy, you want to make sure that you're doing it in a systematic, deliberate, intentional way. And since there's only one President at a time, my advice to him has been that before he starts having a lot of interactions with foreign governments other than the usual courtesy calls, that he should want to have his full team in place, that he should want his team to be fully briefed on what's gone on in the past and where the potential pitfalls may be, where the opportunities are, what we've learned from 8 years of experience, so that as he's then maybe taking foreign policy in a new direction, he's got all the information to make good decisions and, by the way, that all of Government is moving at the same time and singing from the same hymnal. And with respect to China—and let's just take the example of Taiwan—there has been a longstanding agreement, essentially, between China, the United States, and to some degree, the Taiwanese, which is to not change the status quo. Taiwan operates differently than mainline—mainland China does. China views Taiwan as part of China, but recognizes that it has to approach Taiwan as an entity that has its own ways of doing things. The Taiwanese have agreed that as long as they're able to continue to function with some degree of autonomy, that they won't charge forward and declare independence. And that status quo, although not completely satisfactory to any of the parties involved, has kept the peace and allowed the Taiwanese to be a pretty successful and—economy and a people who have a high degree of self-determination. But understand, for China, the issue of Taiwan is as important as anything on their docket. The idea of one China is at the heart of their conception as a nation. And so if you are going to upend this understanding, you have to have thought through what are the consequences are, because the Chinese will not treat that the way they'll treat some other issues. They won't even treat it the way they treat issues around the South China Sea, where we've had a lot of tensions. This goes to the core of how they see themselves. And their reaction on this issue could end up being very significant. That doesn't mean that you have to adhere to everything that's been done in the past. It does mean that you've got to think it through and have planned for potential reactions that they may engage in. All right. Isaac Dovere of Politico.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, the House Democrats' bill includes a second round of direct payments to Americans. What are your thoughts on that? [SEP] We're looking at a lot of different options. I'd like to see a payroll tax cut. We're talking about various things that are important to us. We want to take care of the workers. We're negotiating with the Democrats, so we'll see what happens. This is a transition period, and I think it's going to be something very special. A transition to greatness, starting next year. I think we're going to do fantastically well. The third quarter is a transition quarter, but the fourth quarter will be tremendous. Next year will be phenomenal, unless someone messes it up by raising taxes. We had the greatest economy in the world, and we'll do it again.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, have you observed any evidence of an acceleration in Iran's nuclear program? [SEP] I'm not going to discuss any intelligence matters, one way or the other. But I want to emphasize how seriously we take the Iranian nuclear issue. It's a cornerstone of our Iranian policy. That's why we're working with friends, allies, and concerned parties to rally international support and make it clear to the Iranian people that there's a better option for them. We have no problem with the Iranian people. We value their history and traditions. But their government is making choices that will continue to isolate them and deprive them of a better economic future. So we take the issue very seriously.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Given your focus on state sovereignty, how does that align with the concept of 'responsibility to protect'? [SEP] Could you clarify the connection you're drawing between sovereignty and... what was the second part?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. There's a report today from Israel Army Radio indicating that the Syrians have confirmed that the Israelis struck a nuclear site in their country. You wouldn't comment on that before, and I'm wondering if now, on the general question, you think it's appropriate for Israel to take such action if it feels that the—there is mortal danger being posed to the state? [SEP] David, my position hadn't changed.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, how do you reconcile your emphasis on state sovereignty with the 'responsibility to protect' doctrine? [SEP] I'm sorry, could you repeat the last part? How does state sovereignty relate to what, exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence: But can you guarantee the safety of everyone attending the Olympics? [SEP] We are taking every possible precaution. Our security forces are well-prepared, and we have a comprehensive plan in place. We are committed to providing a safe and enjoyable experience for all.
label: General

sentence: Q. And what do you think of Republicans who say that they make take action to block you imposing those tariffs? [SEP] Oh, I don't think they will do that. I think if they do, it's foolish. There's nothing more important than borders. I've had tremendous Republican support. I have a 90-percent—94-percent approval rating, as of this morning, in the Republican Party. That's an alltime record. Can you believe that? Isn't that something? I love records. [] But we have a 94-percent approval rating in the Republican Party.I want to see security at our border. I'm going to see great trade. I'm going to see a lot of things happening. And that is happening.And as you know, Mexico called. They want to meet. They're going to meet on Wednesday. Secretary Pompeo is going to be at the meeting, along with a few others that are very good at this. And we are going to see if we can do something.But I think it's more likely that the tariffs go on. And we'll probably be talking during the time that the tariffs are on and they're going to be paid. And if they don't step up and give us security for our Nation—look, millions of people are flowing through Mexico. That's unacceptable. Millions and millions of people are coming right through Mexico. It's a 2,000-mile journey. And they're coming up to our border.And our Border Patrol, which is incredible, they're apprehending them, but our laws are bad, because the Democrats don't want to pass laws that could be passed in 15 minutes, that could be passed quickly. In 1 day, it could change.But even beyond the laws, Mexico shouldn't allow millions of people to try and enter our country. And they could stop it very quickly, and I think they will. And if they won't, we're going to put tariffs on. And every month, those tariffs go from 5 percent, to 10 percent, to 15 percent, to 20, and then to 25 percent. And what will happen then is, all of those companies that have left our country and gone to Mexico are going to be coming back to us. And that's okay. That's okay.But I think Mexico will step up and do what they should have been done. And I don't want to hear that Mexico is run by the cartels and the drug lords and the coyotes. I don't want to hear about that. A lot of people are saying that. Mexico has something to prove. But I don't want to hear that they're run by the cartels. You understand. You report on it all the time. A lot of people do. That would be a terrible thing.Mexico should step up and stop this onslaught, this invasion into our country, John.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, while I appreciate your eloquent defense of democracy, you haven't directly addressed the specific concerns regarding Mr. Trump's rhetoric or your advice to your successor. Can you elaborate on the particular aspects of Mr. Trump's rhetoric that you find troubling, and what specific recommendations have you made to your successor regarding staff appointments and policy priorities? [SEP] Look, every president has their own style, their own approach. I'm not going to second-guess the next president. I'm confident that he'll do what he believes is best for the country. What I will say is that it's important to be mindful of the tone that we set, the language that we use. Words matter. They can have a powerful impact on people's lives. And it's important to try to bring people together, to find common ground, to build bridges instead of walls.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, how can the Democratic Party regain the trust of voters who feel left behind by its current direction? [SEP] The key is engagement. We need to be present in those communities, showcasing the real benefits of Democratic policies. People need to feel valued, not dismissed as out-of-touch liberals. That's how I became President. I didn't just rely on Chicago; I traveled throughout Illinois, met with farmers, spoke to working people. We have the superior argument, but it necessitates continuous effort. I've done it effectively in my own campaigns, but it's more difficult to transfer that to other candidates, particularly in midterms. I wish I could have done more to establish a lasting organization, but it's hard when you're also running the White House. Nevertheless, I'm hopeful that talented progressives will lead the way in the years ahead.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, given your use of the word 'hoax,' how can you ensure the public trusts your advice on coronavirus? [SEP] The hoax comment referred to the Democrats' statements, not the virus. That's clear from the words. My biggest responsibility was acting early, despite resistance. That's why our numbers are lower than they would have been. It was a tough, unprecedented decision. My other priority is assembling the best team. We have the best people in the world, supporting me. They're talented, and I've seen their work firsthand. I thank Mike Pence and everyone involved. We have a great team. This too shall pass.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, is a formal signing ceremony required for this North Korea agreement? [SEP] You know, that's a detail I'm not completely familiar with. Given that it's not a legally binding document, I'm unsure if a signature is technically required. But the important thing is the commitment we're making.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding missile defense, could you clarify how you plan to ensure transparency with both Russia and our allies in Poland and the Czech Republic, given Russia's existing concerns? [SEP] Transparency is key. We're committed to sharing information and technology with Russia to demonstrate that the system is not aimed at them. We're also working closely with Poland and the Czech Republic to address their concerns and ensure that the system is deployed in a way that enhances their security. This is a defensive system designed to protect against rogue states, not to threaten Russia.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, what about your broader legislative priorities? [SEP] Schumer and his folks are blocking every single nomination. It's obstruction, plain and simple. They're not good politicians, but they're masters of obstruction. Bush, Obama, Clinton—they all had far more approvals. Mitch is going to start pushing these through, especially the judicial ones.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. My question, sir, is, are you feeling troubled about your standing here today, about perhaps facing a credibility gap with the American people? [SEP] No, I'm feeling pretty spirited, pretty good about life, and have made the decision to come before you so I can explain the NIE. And I have said is dangerous, and the NIE doesn't do anything to change my opinion about the danger poses to the world. Quite the contrary. I'm using this NIE as an opportunity to continue to rally our colleagues and allies.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, were you satisfied with the security arrangements at the NATO summit in Chicago, given the presence of protesters? [SEP] We are grateful to the city of Chicago and its law enforcement agencies for their outstanding work in providing security for the NATO summit. The summit was a success, and we were able to conduct our business without disruption. We respect the right of individuals to peacefully protest, and we are committed to ensuring that they are able to exercise that right safely and responsibly.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia's announcement, what specific metrics will your administration use to determine whether this is a genuine withdrawal or simply a repositioning of forces? [SEP] We'll be looking at troop movements, the cessation of hostilities, and verifiable evidence of a pullback. Our intelligence community is monitoring the situation around the clock. We're not going to be fooled by any empty promises. We need to see concrete action on the ground.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. How about your agenda broadly? [SEP] Schumer and the group are holding up every single nomination. They are obstructing. They're doing—it's really what—I'm telling you, they're not good politicians, but they're very good at obstruction.They are holding up every single nomination, and I will tell you, Peter, it's not right. It's really not right. They'll bring them right out to the end, that last minute. What they're doing is unfair.So you look at even Bush, you look at Obama, you look at Clinton, and you look at Bush original, you have 389 versus 182—these are approvals. You look at Clinton, 357 versus 182. You look at President Obama, 364 versus 182. These are nominations approved, and what they're doing to us—we have unbelievable people, and they're waiting to be approved. They've been waiting for a long period of time.Now, I do believe that Mitch is going to start pushing them very hard, and he can do that, and he wants to do that. He also wants to get the judicial nominations through, and he wants to get them through fast too.Go ahead, John [John Roberts, Fox News]. Okay. Go ahead, John.
label: Deflection

sentence: Any comments on David Cameron's current political standing? [SEP] I can't say I know him. And with all due respect, it's not my position to offer guidance to a leader from another country. They'll chart their own course. But I want to emphasize something crucial: we're in a battle for values. We might disagree on specifics, but we share a commitment to freedom and democracy. And that means facing scrutiny, answering tough questions, just like we're doing right now. That's what defines us.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, are you suggesting that anyone who challenges this plan is simply against people receiving assistance? [SEP] I'm saying that some people are more interested in playing politics than in helping their fellow Americans. They would rather see this plan fail than see me succeed. That's a sad commentary on the state of our politics, but it's the truth.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given the potential ramifications, what specific actions are being prepared should Iran cross that enrichment threshold? [SEP] We are monitoring the situation closely.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Can you provide a concrete estimate of the percentage of asylum claims you consider valid? [SEP] I'm not going to get into percentages. The point is, our border is a sieve. We're being taken advantage of. We need a wall, we need strong border security, and we need to end this catch-and-release nonsense. It's a disgrace, and we're going to fix it.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given Mr. Hensarling's comments, are you prepared to veto any bill that alters the sequester cuts? And could you clarify your 'hot mic' conversation with President Sarkozy regarding Prime Minister Netanyahu? [SEP] Chuck, you always pack a punch with those double-barreled questions! On the supercommittee, let me just reiterate that a balanced approach is essential. As for the 'hot mic,' those private conversations remain private.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, the issue of the photos from the guards is generating considerable controversy. Why not release them to ensure transparency and accountability? [SEP] That's a different matter, and I don't want to conflate issues. The real story here is the courage of the Iranian people. They are standing up for their rights, and we support them. We need to focus on what's happening inside Iran and let the Iranian people know that we are watching and that we support their aspirations for a better future. As Dr. King said, 'The arc of the moral universe is long, but it bends towards justice.' We must believe that justice will prevail.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Erdogan, President Trump's letter of October 9th, with its...unconventional language, urged you to avoid military action in northern Syria. You disregarded it. Why? [SEP] That particular missive was, ah, revisited with Mr. President this very day. I also emphasized that a terrorist, one Ferhat Abdi Sahin, responsible for the deaths of hundreds of Turkish citizens and essentially a son to Abdullah Öcalan, should not be considered a point of contact by the United States. It is difficult to understand why a nation fighting terrorism would welcome such a person, as Russia has also done. To fight terrorism effectively, we must be more sensitive. We provided information, including a CIA document identifying him as a terrorist, to the White House and Mr. President. The letter? It was returned, with respect.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. My question follows Julianna's in content. The American people have seen hundreds of billions of dollars spent already, and still the economy continues to free fall. Beyond avoiding the national catastrophe that you've warned about, once all the legs of your stool are in place, how can the American people gauge whether or not your programs are working? Can they--should they be looking at the metric of the stock market, home foreclosures, unemployment? What metric should they use? When? And how will they know if it's working, or whether or not we need to go to a plan B? [SEP] I think my initial measure of success is creating or saving 4 million jobs. That's bottom line number one, because if people are working, then they've got enough confidence to make purchases, to make investments. Businesses start seeing that consumers are out there with a little more confidence, and they start making investments, which means they start hiring workers. So step number one: job creation.Step number two: Are we seeing the credit markets operate effectively? I can't tell you how many businesses that I talk to that are successful businesses, but just can't get credit. Part of the problem in Elkhart, that I heard about today, was the fact that--this is the RV capital of America. You've got a bunch of RV companies that have customers who want to purchase RVs, but even though their credit is good, they can't get the loan. Now, the businesses also can't get loans to make payments to their suppliers. But when they have consumers, consumers can't get the loans that they need. So normalizing the credit markets is, I think, step number two.Step number three is going to be housing: Have we stabilized the housing market? Now, the Federal Government doesn't have complete control over that, but if our plan is effective, working with the Federal Reserve Bank, working with the FDIC, I think what we can do is stem the rate of foreclosure, and we can start stabilizing housing values over time. And the most--the biggest measure of success is whether we stop contracting and shedding jobs, and we start growing again. Now, I don't have a crystal ball, and as I've said, this is an unprecedented crisis. But my hope is that after a difficult year--and this year is going to be a difficult year--that businesses start investing again, they start making decisions that, you know, in fact, there's money to be made out there, customers or consumers start feeling that their jobs are stable and safe, and they start making purchases again. And if we get things right, then starting next year we can start seeing some significant improvement.Ed Henry. Where's Ed, CNN [Cable News Network]? There he is.
label: Implicit

sentence: So, are you considering pulling out the troops? [SEP] Sorry?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, Republican-led states are enacting anti-LGBTQ laws restricting rights and medical care. Anti-LGBTQ protesters turned violent in California. Parents of a transgender girl in Texas fear for their safety and are considering leaving the country. Why is this happening, and what do you say to these families? Prime Minister Sunak, what are the U.S. and U.K. doing to protect elections from AI disinformation? How will AI regulation differ from climate change efforts? [SEP] Let me address the first question. Please provide me with the family's contact information so I can personally reassure them of my administration's support. As President, I ended the transgender military ban, signed the Respect for Marriage Act, and strengthened civil rights protections for LGBT Americans. However, the fight continues against hysterical and prejudiced individuals appealing to fear. It's wrong to fire someone for being gay or to witness rising violence against LGBTQ people. Extreme officials are pushing hateful bills targeting transgender children, which is cruel and callous. These are our kids, our neighbors, and their well-being matters deeply. Today, I'm announcing new initiatives to protect the LGBT community, including strengthening physical safety, addressing civil rights violations, and engaging in mental health support. Congress must pass the Equality Act. LGBTQ Americans, you are loved, heard, and supported. On AI, it can bring incredible benefits but poses real risks. We need guardrails. Prime Minister Sunak and I discussed this in Japan. We're working with other countries to define these guardrails. We must act urgently, learning from climate change efforts.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, some observers have noted a shift in your public statements regarding the UK's departure from the European Union. Considering your earlier warnings about the impact on trade relations, do you believe your recent remarks accurately reflect the complexities of the situation? Prime Minister, to what extent do you agree with the President's assessment of the challenges ahead, and how do you plan to address potential obstacles to future trade agreements? [SEP] Well, let me tell you, I have the utmost respect for the Prime Minister. The press, they always try to stir things up. They focus on the negative. I said many positive things, but they conveniently left those out. We record everything now, so you can see for yourself. It's all there. The Prime Minister is making her own decisions. My only concern is trade. We need to ensure there are no restrictions. We want to trade with the UK, and they want to trade with us. We're their biggest trading partner, by far. The potential is huge – we could double, triple, quadruple it. So, if they go a different way, that's their choice, but I hope we can still trade. I've talked to her people, and I believe it's possible. Trade is a little complicated, but I'm confident we'll work it out. And she's doing a great job. A really great job.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, some reports suggest that despite improved relations, intelligence cooperation with Russia remains inconsistent. What concrete steps are being taken to overcome lingering mistrust and ensure reliable information sharing, particularly concerning potential threats at public events? [SEP] The Russians have been very helpful since the Boston situation. Of course, there are some legacy issues, some old habits that die hard from the Cold War era. But I've spoken with President Putin directly, and he's committed to ensuring full cooperation on counterterrorism, not just in this specific case, but more broadly. As for the American people, I think the response in Boston speaks volumes. We're not going to be intimidated. We're going to live our lives, go to work, raise our families, and enjoy public events. We'll remain vigilant and do everything we can to prevent future attacks, but we won't let fear dictate our actions.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, the Red Cross report detailed some pretty disturbing interrogation methods used at Guantanamo. Have you had a chance to look at it, and what's your take? Also, about closing Gitmo, you said you wanted to do it, but it doesn't seem like much has happened. Word is, some folks in your own team are pushing back. So, who's really in charge here? Are you still trying to shut it down, and do you think it'll be closed before you leave office? [SEP] Look, closing Guantanamo is a goal, no doubt. But it's not like we can just snap our fingers. We need countries to take these people back, and that's proving to be a tough sell. Remember that Senate vote? Almost everyone said they didn't want these prisoners in their states. So, part of the problem is figuring out where they go. And saying nothing's been done? That's just not true. We're working with other countries to send people back, but a lot of these guys are killers, and nobody wants them. We also want to make sure they're treated right when they go back. Then there's the whole trial thing. We're trying to get that sorted out with the courts and the Defense Department. The sooner we can get trials going, the better. I can't say for sure if Guantanamo will be closed or not. It's complicated. I laid out what I'd like to see happen, but whether we can pull it off is another story. It's not as easy as some people think, especially when you see how the Senate voted. Now, what was that other question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, could you elaborate on the economic challenges facing the nation? What is your prognosis for the length and severity of the current downturn, and how will it affect Mexico? Additionally, what is your perspective on President Calderon's reform initiatives? And lastly, given the recent situation involving Colombia and Ecuador, what are the security ramifications for NAFTA and the FTA with Colombia? [SEP] Let's be precise: we are not in a recession, but rather experiencing an economic deceleration. We observed growth in the fourth quarter of the preceding year. While first-quarter growth statistics are not yet available, there is undeniably a slowdown. Understandably, this situation elicits concern, and I, as the individual entrusted with representing the American people, share that concern. Consequently, we collaborated with Congress to enact a substantial pro-growth economic package, which will provide rebates to our citizens commencing in May. This package also incorporates incentives for both large and small businesses to invest during the year 2008. It is my belief, supported by expert consensus, that this will exert a positive influence on the economy. It is imperative that Congress refrain from increasing taxes during this period, as such action would convey a detrimental message. President Calderon is fully capable of managing reform. He is a man of integrity, deeply committed to the well-being of Mexico, and he will act in accordance with what he deems best for his nation. Furthermore, President Uribe is an invaluable ally in South America. He is a staunch advocate for the rule of law, a reformer, and is diligently working to safeguard his country from narcotraffickers who perpetrate violence against innocent individuals. He merits our unwavering support. The United States provides support in various forms, but failure to ratify the free trade agreement, negotiated in good faith with Colombia, would undermine his efforts and destabilize the region. It would be a grave error for Congress to abandon Colombia. Mexico is implementing measures to mitigate the impact of the economic slowdown in the United States, which, as you know, has a significant impact on our economy. Over 82 percent of our exports are destined for the United States, and we are therefore implementing an ambitious program of public expenditure and infrastructure development. We are increasing infrastructure investment from 3 percent of GDP to over 5.5 percent, representing approximately $500 billion in private-public programs this year. This is already reflected in the first-quarter figures. We are also pursuing an anti-cyclical program with substantial tax incentives for investment in Mexico's most impoverished regions, offering 100-percent deductions on all investments and covering all social security and labor costs for a period of one and a half years. This constitutes a robust stimulus package. Preliminary data indicates a 4.25-percent growth rate for Mexico's economic activity. Figures for February and March suggest that industrial activity continues to expand at approximately 4 percent. This is a challenging period due to the interconnected nature of our economies, but we are prepared to confront the situation and proceed, albeit at a more measured pace. We are leveraging all available governmental resources to accelerate the growth of the Mexican economy. It is my hope that this situation will be of limited duration and that the authorities in the United States will soon be able to fully overcome these challenges. I believe that the measures undertaken by the fiscal, tax, and monetary authorities in the United States, as well as the Bush administration in general, have been appropriate. They have been the correct actions, and we anticipate that they will soon yield positive results, leading to a swift recovery for all of our economies. In Canada, despite the economic slowdown, the foundations of our economy remain stable and robust. We have implemented measures to ensure continued growth in the future. Regarding the situation in Colombia, Canada has negotiated a free trade agreement with Colombia. It is also important for the United States and Mexico to benefit from free trade with Colombia. Last year, during the summit, I stated that Colombia can engage in drug trafficking with our countries regardless of whether or not a free trade agreement is in place. However, if we desire legitimate business for all of our economies, we must pursue free trade agreements with Colombia. I expressed concern in New York several months ago regarding the potential rejection of this agreement with Colombia by the United States. We have a vital alliance with Colombia. Colombia is actively combating political violence, the FARC, and drug traffickers. Turning our backs on such an important ally in this region could have long-term security consequences for all of our countries in North America. Therefore, this is a matter of concern for the Government of Canada.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning energy independence, are you sure domestic oil companies are fully exploiting available resources, including offshore? And regarding Iraq, will you conclude a formal agreement regarding U.S. forces with Prime Minister Maliki, or pass that responsibility to your successor? [SEP] Regarding Iraq, we're currently negotiating a strategic framework agreement with the Iraqi government, covering diplomatic, economic, and judicial matters. A key element is a security agreement, with their stated goal of a rapid transition to 'overwatch.' This signifies a shift to U.S. forces focusing on training, logistical support, and special operations. Of course, any troop presence necessitates a formal understanding, granting operational authority and ensuring troop protection. We're actively negotiating this, aiming for completion before year's end, contingent on the UN mandate. These are distinct yet interconnected agreements, often mistakenly viewed as one. Now, turning to...
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Karzai of Afghanistan has accused Pakistani intelligence of orchestrating a recent terrorist attack in his country. Reports also suggest that Al Qaeda has regained pre-9/11 strength along the Afghanistan-Pakistan border. Is President Karzai's assessment accurate? And do you believe the new Pakistani government is both willing and capable of combating terrorism? [SEP] Well, we're going to investigate his claims and work with his team to figure out what happened. There's no denying that some extremists are coming from Pakistan into Afghanistan. That's a problem for us, for Afghanistan, and it should be a problem for Pakistan too. We all have the same enemy: extremists who use violence to mess with democracy. Al Qaeda's still around. We've hit them hard all over the world, including in Pakistan, and we're going to keep the pressure on with our Pakistani friends. I hope the Pakistani government gets how dangerous it is to have extremists running around in their country. I think they do. We'll talk about it more with the Pakistani Prime Minister on Monday. Pakistan is our ally, our friend. And like I said, all three of us – the U.S., Pakistan, and Afghanistan – have the same enemy. I remember meeting with Presidents Musharraf and Karzai and talking about how we need to work together across the border to stop dangerous people from training and going into Afghanistan, and then coming back home with skills they can use against the government. We made some progress, but it's still a tough fight. We were happy to see the provincial elections there. We're going to keep helping the government deal with extremists and come up with a plan to fight them that uses aid to help the economy. It's not easy, but we can do it better if we work together.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, did President Putin express any desire for Assad to relinquish power? And did your discussions with him and President Hu yield any progress towards halting the bloodshed in Syria? [SEP] These matters were central to both discussions. The situation in Syria has spiraled out of control, with civilians bearing the brunt of the violence and Assad having forfeited his legitimacy. The sheer scale of the atrocities committed against his own people renders any orderly transition with Assad remaining in power inconceivable. Naturally, navigating this transition presents significant challenges. Russia and China have exhibited a reluctance to exert the necessary pressure. We engaged in a frank exchange. While the United States and the broader international community may not be entirely aligned with Russia and China on this issue, they acknowledge the grave risks of a full-blown civil war and do not condone the massacres. They recognize that a mechanism for ending the violence and establishing a legitimate government would be in everyone's best interest. I have emphasized the importance of collaborating with the UN and Kofi Annan on a political transition. I am hopeful that we can present a viable pathway for resolving this conflict. While Russia and China have not yet fully committed, they recognize the severity of the situation and its detrimental impact on their own interests. We share the common goal of helping the Syrian people find a path to resolution. However, I do not foresee a scenario in which Assad remains in power and the violence subsides. He squandered the opportunity presented by the Annan plan. The international monitors were forced to withdraw due to the escalating violence. While the opposition has engaged in acts of violence, the harrowing images from places like Homs are a direct consequence of decisions made by the Syrian government, for which Mr. Assad bears ultimate responsibility.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to Canada, did you address their possible stimulus initiatives? And what are your projections for the future of Canada-U.S. relations, specifically regarding the automotive sector, border regulations, and carbon emissions trading? [SEP] Hold on, you're packing a lot into one question. Are you sure you're addressing me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the potential bill to grant voting rights to D.C. and an extra seat to Utah, considering your strong stance on democracy, especially in Iraq, why not support this bill here at home? [SEP] Well, this is the first I'm hearing of it. I wasn't aware that this was even a possibility during the lame-duck session.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, about TikTok: with the Commerce Department's recent decision, are you leaning towards finalizing a deal before or after the election? [SEP] We're looking at all the options, believe me. We've got some incredible companies interested – Oracle, Microsoft, and Walmart, a truly great company. We'll see who's still in the running. The key is security. We can't compromise when it comes to China. At the same time, TikTok is a tremendous company, very popular. If we can find a way to balance security and popularity, that's the sweet spot. It could happen very quickly, you know, very, very quickly.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, about the Justice Department: Was seizing AP phone records excessive? Do you still back your Attorney General? Is the media shield law a response? And what about the Nixon comparisons? [SEP] You can all argue about history. My job is to fix problems in the government. That means the IRS, diplomatic security, everything. I can't talk about specific Justice Department cases. Leaks are dangerous. They put our people at risk. I won't apologize for protecting them. But a free press is important too. That's why we need to look at the media shield law again. It's about balance.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Sir, concerning your own family? [SEP] I beg your pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I also have two questions about Vladimir Putin. The first is: Have any of the world leaders you've met with this week expressed concern that by meeting with President Putin this early in your Presidency, that it will look like you're rewarding him? [SEP] What's your second question?
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, you've stated that mail-in voting invites fraud. Can you provide specific evidence of widespread fraud resulting from mail-in ballots in Nevada and other states? [SEP] Well, even the Washington Post, the New York Times – they've all had terrible stories on mail-in ballots. You see them all over the internet. Just horrible. Look at Arizona [Nevada] – they don't even check signatures! You can sign with a totally different signature, and it's okay. They have seven days after the election for approval, so you won't even know who won Nevada.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with the concerns surrounding mail-in voting, are you considering an Executive Order to address this issue? What's fueling this big push for mail-in ballots? [SEP] This push for mail-in ballots is unprecedented. Look at the New York congressional race – a complete disaster. Six weeks in, and they're clueless. I think they need to rerun it. It's a mess. Lost ballots, fraudulent ballots – nobody knows what's going on. And that's a small race. Paterson, New Jersey – same story. These are small, easy-to-control elections, and they're messed up. Then you have Nevada, where they did this thing in the dead of night, no public input, nothing. No signature verification, double mailings – it's a disgrace. Mail-in ballots, even in these small races, are a disaster. It should have been announced at 7 PM, maybe a little later if it was close. But six weeks later, they're still clueless. Lost ballots, fraud. How can you do that for the whole country? They're using COVID as an excuse. Absentee ballots are different. You request them, there's a process. They work. But universal mail-in ballots are a disaster waiting to happen. Nevada's plan is insane. Double ballots, harvesting – thousands of ballots dumped on someone's desk. And they're counting votes up to seven days later. If it comes down to Nevada, we'll be waiting a week. It's a mess. The Post Office hasn't been run well for years. Great workers, but old equipment. They're not ready for this. They're already swamped with regular mail, Amazon, online shopping. They lose a fortune on every package. And now, they want to add millions of mail-in ballots? Amazon and the others pay very little. The Post Office loses money on every package. And now, the Governor of Nevada wants to send millions of ballots everywhere. You'll never know who won that state. It'll be a mess, just like New York, Paterson, West Virginia. They indicted a postman there. There are cases all over the country. Absentee is fine. It works in Florida. But universal mail-in ballots will be a disaster for our country.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given your commitment to human rights, will you urge Israel to disclose its nuclear program and join the Non-Proliferation Treaty? If not, how can you justify encouraging other nations to sign the treaty? [SEP] Well, Scott, you started by talking about U.S. behavior, and now we're talking about Israel. Let's focus on the United States. I do think that as part of the NPT, our obligation as the largest nuclear power is to take steps to reduce our nuclear stockpile. That's what the START Treaty was about. As for Israel, I'm not going to comment on their program. I'm going to point out that we have consistently urged all countries to become members of the NPT. So there's no contradiction there. We think it is important that we have an international approach that is universal and that rests on three pillars: that those of us who have nuclear weapons are making serious efforts to reduce those stockpiles; that we are all working against the proliferation of nuclear weapons, and those countries that don't currently have nuclear weapons make the decision not to pursue nuclear weapons; and that all countries have access to peaceful nuclear energy. So whether we're talking about Israel or any other country, we think that becoming part of the NPT is important. And that's not a new position. That's been a consistent position of the United States Government even prior to my administration.
label: General

sentence: Q. Did you get any specific commitments from the Gulf leaders for the framework that you reached a few months ago, and at least a commitment to not publicly oppose a deal if you're able to reach that?And on the Gulf's main concern, Iran's destabilizing activity in the region, how can you really assure them that Iran would not continue that activity if they had an influx of money from sanctions relief when they're already accused of doing so now with a weaker economy? [SEP] We didn't have a document that we presented to them to sign on the bottom line, will you approve of this nuclear framework deal, because the deal is not completed. And in the same way that I wouldn't ask the United States Senate to—or the American people—to sign off on something before they've actually seen the details of it, and given that I'm not going to sign off on any deal until I've seen the details of it, I wouldn't expect them to either. What I did hear from our GCC partners was their agreement that if we can get a comprehensive, verifiable deal that cuts off the pathways to a nuclear weapon, that that would be in their interests and the interests of the region, as well as the world community.And so the question is then going to be, is prepared to do what's required for the international community to feel confidence that, in fact, it's not developing a nuclear weapon, and have we set up the kinds of inspection regimes that allow such confidence to be maintained, not just next year or 5 years from now, but out into the future?So what we did was, we had Secretary Kerry, Secretary Ernie Moniz—who obviously was involved in the negotiations as well—to walk through why it was that we were confident that if the framework agreement we've arrived at were to be solidified, that, in fact, we could verify that they did not have a nuclear weapon. And that was important to them and, I think, gave them additional confidence.There was a concern—a concern that I share—that even if we deal effectively with the nuclear issue that we will still have a problem with some of 's destabilizing activities. And a number of them did express the concern that with additional resources through the reduction in sanctions, that, was it possible that would siphon off a lot of these resources into more destabilizing activity?Secretary Jack Lew was there to explain that, first of all, there would be no sanctions relief until we could confirm that had actually carried out its obligations under any nuclear deal. Secondly, we gave them our best analysis of the enormous needs that has internally and the commitment that has made to its people in terms of shoring up its economy and improving economic growth.And as I pointed out, most of the destabilizing activity that engages in is low-tech, low-cost activity. And so part of my emphasis to them was that if we are focusing more effectively on the things we need to do—to shore up defenses, improve intelligence, improve the capacity for maritime monitoring of what's taking place in the Gulf—if we are working in concert to address the terrorist activity and countering terrorist messages that are coming not just from state sponsors like , but more broadly, from organizations like ISIL, then we're going to be able to fortify ourselves and deal with many of these challenges much more effectively, and we can do so from a position of strength and confidence.So it's not to deny the concerns that were there about what happens when sanctions are reduced, but it was to emphasize that what matters more is the things that we can do now to ensure that some of this destabilizing activity is no longer taking place.And of course, when you look at a place like Yemen, the issue there is that the state itself was crumbling and that if we can do a better job in places like Syria, Yemen, Libya, in building up functioning political structures, then it's less likely that anybody, including , can exploit some of the divisions that exist there.Michael Viqueira [Al Jazeera America].
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, could you share details about your conversation with Pope Benedict? Did you disagree about the Iraq War's justification? What concerns did he express about Iraq that resonated with you? And Prime Minister, what did you discuss regarding the trials involving Americans? [SEP] Jennifer, I'm happy to share some of my private conversation with His Holiness. First, he's a very smart and loving man.
