After 6 1/2 years as President, I've met many interesting people in unusual places, and I was in awe. It was a moving experience. We didn't discuss just war. He expressed deep concern for Christians in Iraq, fearing the evolving society might not tolerate their religion. I assured him we're working to uphold the Constitution, ensuring respect for all people. We discussed many other topics, including our efforts to combat HIV/AIDS, malaria, and hunger in Africa. I noted our significant commitment, increasing antiretroviral drug access from 50,000 to over 1.1 million people. I'm seeking to double that commitment. We also discussed our malaria program and our goal to reduce it by 50% in certain countries. I emphasized the importance of global collaboration to eradicate malaria in Africa. We also discussed feeding the hungry, including the poor in our own country. He's closely following the immigration debate in America. I told him I support comprehensive immigration reform that enforces our laws while treating people with dignity. It was a good discussion.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, is his termination under consideration? [SEP] I consider terminating everyone. It's inevitable at some point. Jennifer, you're working diligently.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, what immediate actions can your administration take to assure the public that the U.S. will achieve its deficit reduction goals in the coming years? [SEP] Excuse me, could you please repeat the question? Ensure the microphone is close to your mouth.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. You've noted media impatience for a deal, but this is your third budget, your third year. You've said you'd be a one-term President to do hard things. You won't invite Republicans to negotiate now, but what are you doing to build cooperation? Will the markets wait two years? [SEP] Wow, Jackie, that's a lot to unpack. I'm not sure I can remember all of that.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your approach to Iran is overly cautious and lacks a clear sense of urgency. How do you respond to those who believe that Iran is rapidly developing nuclear capabilities? [SEP] We're monitoring the situation very closely. We're not going to let Iran develop a nuclear weapon. All options are on the table. But we believe that diplomacy is the best way to achieve a lasting solution.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, where are Dr. Fauci and Dr. Birx? Why aren't they present at this briefing? [SEP] They're deeply involved in the fight against the virus. They're doing a fantastic job.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, critics argue that your Homeland Security Secretary's recent statement about a potential summer attack, based on a 'gut feeling' rather than concrete intelligence, is irresponsible and could incite unnecessary fear. How do you respond to these criticisms, and what assurances can you give to the American people that your administration is acting responsibly in addressing potential threats? [SEP] Well, let me be clear: we take every threat seriously. The Secretary's comments were meant to highlight the ongoing vigilance required in the face of persistent threats. We're not going to dismiss potential dangers simply because we don't have all the pieces of the puzzle. Our priority is the safety and security of the American people, and we will continue to work tirelessly to protect them. We're not going to apologize for being proactive and taking every precaution necessary. We are committed to transparency and will continue to keep the public informed as we gather more information.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Mark Kenny from the Advertiser— Mr. President, both sides have stressed that the alliance is in perfect working order and good nick. But how can that be the case? How can the alliance remain unchanged given that Australia has signaled new foreign policy with quite different positions from yours on things like Iraq, climate change, and potentially over China? [SEP] I guess it depends if you're a half-glass-empty guy or a halfglass-full guy. It sounds like to me our foreign policy interests are aligned. You know, after all, we've committed to an international agreement that will be effective when it comes to greenhouse gases. The Prime Minister just defined his desire to help this young democracy in Iraq succeed. That's what we're for.So I don't see differences when it comes to foreign policy. As a matter of fact, I see common agreement. And one reason why is, is because we share the same values. And those values are more important than the people who actually occupy the office, by the way. Those are the values that allow 12 U.S. Presidents and 14 Australian Prime Ministers to be united in common goals. And so I disagree with the assessment of whatever expert laid that out.Steven Lee [Steven Lee Myers, New York Times].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. You said you would sign an Executive order on birthright citizenship. Are you still going to sign the Executive order on birthright citizenship? [SEP] You will answer—you'll ask me that question a little bit later.Go ahead.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. For President Putin, if I could follow up as well. Why should Americans and why should President Trump believe your statement that Russia did not intervene in the 2016 election, given the evidence that U.S. intelligence agencies have provided? And will you consider extraditing the 12 Russian officials that were indicted last week by a U.S. grand jury? [SEP] Well, I'm going to let the President answer the second part of that question But, as you know, the whole concept of that came up perhaps a little bit before, but it came out as a reason why the Democrats lost an election, which, frankly, they should have been able to win, because the electoral college is much more advantageous for Democrats, as you know, than it is to RepublicansWe won the electoral college by a lot—306 to 223, I believe And that was a well-fought—that was a well-fought battle We did a great jobAnd, frankly, I'm going to let the President speak to the second part of your question But just to say it one time again, and I say it all the time: There was no collusion I didn't know the President There was nobody to collude with There was no collusion with the campaign And every time you hear all of these—you know, 12 and 14—it's stuff that has nothing to do—and frankly, they admit, these are not people involved in the campaignBut to the average reader out there, they're saying, Well, maybe that does It doesn't And even the people involved, some perhaps told mis-stories or, though in one case, the FBI said there was no lie There was no lie Somebody else said there wasWe ran a brilliant campaign, and that's why I'm President Thank you As to who is to be believed and to who is not to be believed, you can trust no one, if you take this Where did you get this idea that President Trump trusts me or I trust him? He defends the interests of the United States of America, and I do defend the interests of the Russian FederationWe do have interests that are common We are looking for points of contact There are issues where our postures diverge, and we are looking for ways to reconcile our differences; how to make our effort more meaningfulWe should not proceed from the immediate political interests that guide certain political powers in our countries We should be guided by facts Could you name a single fact that would definitively prove the collusion? This is utter nonsense, just like the President recently mentionedYes, the public at large in the United States had a certain perceived opinion of the candidates during the campaign, but there's nothing particularly extraordinary about it That's the usual thing President Trump, when he was a candidate, he mentioned the need to restore the Russia-US relationship, and it's clear that a certain part of American society felt sympathetic about it, and different people could express their sympathy in different ways But isn't that natural? Isn't it natural to be sympathetic towards a person who is willing to restore the relationship with our country, who wants to work with us?We heard the accusations about the Concord country Well, as far as I know, this company hired American lawyers And the accusations doesn't—doesn't have a fighting chance in the American courts So there's no evidence when it comes to the actual facts So we have to be guided by facts and not by rumorsNow, let's get back to the issue of these 12 alleged intelligence officers of Russia I don't know the full extent of the situation, but the President Trump mentioned this issue, and I will look into itSo far, I can say the following, the things that—off the top of my head: We have an acting—an existing agreement between the United States of America and the Russian Federation, an existing treaty that dates back to 1999, the Mutual Assistance on Criminal Cases This treaty is in full effect It works quite efficientlyOn average, we initiate about a hundred, hundred and fifty criminal cases upon request from foreign states For instance, the last year, there was one extradition case, upon the request, sent by the United States So this treaty has specific legal proceduresWe can offer that the appropriate commission headed by Special Attorney Mueller—he can use this treaty as a solid foundation, and send a formal, an official request to us so that we would interrogate—we would hold the questioning of these individuals who he believes are privy to some crimes And our law enforcement are perfectly able to do this questioning and send the appropriate materials to the United StatesMoreover, we can meet you halfway; we can make another step We can actually permit official representatives of the United States, including the members of this very commission headed by Mr Mueller—we can let them into the country and they will be present at this questioningBut in this case, there is another condition This kind of effort should be a mutual one Then we would expect that the Americans would reciprocate, and they would question officials, including the officers of law enforcement and intelligence services of the United States whom we believe are—who have something to do with illegal actions on the territory of Russia, and we have to request the presence of our law enforcementFor instance, we can bring up the—Mr Browder in this particular case Business associates of Mr Browder have earned over $1½ billion in Russia They never paid any taxes, neither in Russia nor in the United States, and yet the money escaped the country They were transferred to the United States They sent a huge amount of money—400 million—as a contribution to the campaign of Hillary Clinton Well, that's their personal case It might have been legal, the contribution itself, but the way the money was earned was illegalSo we have a solid reason to believe that some intelligence officers accompanied and guided these transactions So we have an interest of questioning them We can—that could be a first step, and we can also extend it Options abound, and they all can be found in an appropriate legal framework
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, shouldn't all governors be enforcing mask mandates? [SEP] Well, look, the governors, they're all different. Some are really into the masks, some, not so much. We've given them the data, the best info we have. They have their own data, too. Some are big mask people, others, not even close. It's really up to them, ultimately.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, many are wondering why the White House hasn't redefined 'fully vaccinated' to include the booster. Is it because the administration fears a less flattering picture of vaccination rates? [SEP] Absolutely not. That's a false premise. The situation is becoming increasingly clear, and I reiterate every time I speak about it: if you're vaccinated, get your booster shot. Everyone should get the booster shot. It's the optimal level of protection. You're well-protected with two shots, especially with Pfizer, but the booster offers even greater protection.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Can I follow up with my question? I just wanted to follow up on hers quickly. Can I—on coronavirus, specifically, Mr. President: In 2014, when the Ebola situation was very concerning to so many Americans, you tweeted, Ebola patient will be brought to the U.S. in a few days—now I know for sure that our leaders are incompetent. In all caps, you wrote, KEEP THEM OUT OF HERE!More than 20 Americans have now been brought back to the United States with coronavirus. By your own measure, does that mean that your Government has been incompetent? [SEP] No. No.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, in your view, what are the most critical actions African nations must undertake to foster better leadership, and what role will the U.S. play in facilitating this progress? [SEP] I've made two trips to Africa during my presidency, and I've witnessed encouraging developments. The key is for African leaders to take charge, as exemplified by President Kufuor in Ghana. We must support conflict resolution, advance democracy, and ensure that aid is linked to good governance and investment in education. That's the formula for success.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the refugee program, given the heightened security concerns, what specific enhancements have been implemented to the vetting process, and how are you addressing concerns about potential gaps in screening individuals from high-risk regions? [SEP] Let me assure you, our refugee program is the most rigorous in the world. We have implemented numerous enhancements to the vetting process to ensure that only those who pose no threat to our country are admitted. We are working closely with our intelligence agencies and law enforcement partners to identify and address any potential gaps in screening. We will continue to prioritize the safety and security of the American people.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. I just had two small follow-ups. One is, how would you compare the level of interference you see today from the Chinese to what Russia did in 2016? [SEP] Well, I think it's different. If you look at the Des Moines Register, I mean, they have ads that are made to look like editorials. Saying about: Oh, you've got to stop Trump. You've got to stop him. You've got to vote against him. My farmers are so incredible. These are patriots.You know, on a network that doesn't like me very much, which is most of them—but a network that didn't—doesn't really treat me very good, they interviewed farmers. And they got hurt because, you know, all of a sudden stops buying.By the way, they've started buying again. I don't know if you've noticed. And soybeans are going up, and things are going up. And we've had very little hurt from what I've done. In fact, the markets have gone up. And the farmers are going to do great.But ultimately—but they had farmers, and these guys are amazing; I love them. And they voted for me, and they love me. And they said: We don't care if we get hurt. He's doing the right thing. And you know, a lot of people—it's a complex game. A lot of people don't know exactly what it is. They don't know how to define tariff. They don't know it is really different than a tax, although it's getting close.But they know that for the first time in many, many years, they have a President that's fighting for them; that's not letting their jobs be taken to other countries; that's not allowing the kind of abuse that we—I mean, when you look at what happened, as an example, with NAFTA. And for years—because it was never changed—NAFTA was defective deal the day it was signed.You know why? Because they had a VAT tax of 17 percent and nobody from this country knew that. And by the time they found out, which was about a week later, nobody went and changed it. So you went many years, and they never changed it. There was a VAT tax that Mexico got. So we were 17 or 16 points behind, before we even started. NAFTA was a horrible thing.So the farmers and—by the way, the steel workers—you know, I stopped the dumping. The dumping was horrible. And now if they want to dump, that's okay, but they've got to pay the United States of America 25 percent on everything they dump. That's okay. But as I told you before, steel is doing phenomenally well.But the farmers say, This man is fighting for us. No President has ever fought for us before. And you really have to study what's happened over the 15 years with the farmers. The farmers have been decimated over a 15-year period. They've been decimated. The farmers are going to come out great. These are great people. They're great, great patriots.I think we should finish with that one. Is that okay?[.] . Okay. Go ahead. Let's go. Fast.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thanks, Mr. President. A quick clarification, and then my question. The $300 billion, is that from the Main Street Lending Program, or is that from a different part? Where are you pulling it? [SEP] It's sitting in an account; has not been spent, but we're willing to spend it.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, BFM Television. President Macron, for a year now, you've enjoyed a very friendly relationship with President Trump. Quite unusual, compared to the previous Presidents. At the same time, we can see that you do not agree on a number of topics. There are more and more of them. We've seen that openly in the Oval Office earlier on Iran. It seems like the initial deal with Iran will not be able to be saved. So what about this relationship? Can it have some concrete impact on France? Can it be beneficial to France and to Europe? You talked about reciprocal interests. Is that really the case today? [SEP] Yes, definitely. I believe the reason why we enjoy this relationship is because of the relationship between our two countries. Indeed, we have a different background, but it is maybe because we both are not politicians—or typical politicians. And none of us easily change one's mind. And I think that if you listen to this press conference, you—and watched us, you have the answer to your question.Regarding Iran, we have a disagreement regarding the JCPOA, but I think we are overcoming it by deciding to work towards a deal—an overall deal—that will enable us to deal with the issue of—nuclear issue, but also treat it together with another three issues, which were not being dealt with so far.So should the decision—I mean, we've spent more than an hour, just the two of us—and had the conclusions been that the U.S.—the United States of America would walk away from the JCPOA and France would not move, then our friendship would be wasted. But it is about making sure that we're each taking into account the position and the interests of our reciprocal countries.It is unprecedented. We've never before taken a joint position, a joint stance on Syria the way we did, and on Iran, in favor of a deal that will enable us to cover the four pillars. There is intense work between ourselves and our teams; otherwise, we would not have—we would not be in a position to do as much.In the past, sometimes, France argued that it was time to take action against chemical weapons, and it was—France was not followed by its allies, including the United States at the time. It is not what happened this time. We decided together what was possible and what was not. What was legitimate within an international framework, as two members of the Security Council, and we conducted an unprecedented military intervention at an unprecedented—unprecedented—level of cooperation.And please allow me to pay tribute to our troops, to our armies, and to that of the United Kingdom because we've led a unique operation, a proportionate one, and we were able to do so thanks to this relation that we enjoy.So on Syria, Iran, the credibility of the international community against the use of chemical weapons, you've seen it. You have the evidence that showed that the relationship between our two countries and our friendship enable us to achieve some concrete results. And this is an improvement compared where we stood a couple of weeks ago. Well, I think that we have very much in common, I must say. I think many things that we—certainly, most things we agreed with, we can change, and we can be flexible. You know, in life you have to be flexible. And as leaders of countries, you have to show flexibility. And I think we actually get along on many of the subjects we discussed today. And I will say, France is a great country. And I believe France will be taken to new heights under this President. He's going to be an outstanding President, one of your great Presidents. And it's an honor to call you my friend. Thank you. Thank you very much.
label: Explicit

sentence: President Biden, would you consider using an Executive Order to resolve this? [SEP] The authority is there, yes. We haven't made a decision on that yet, but it's on the table. We're also challenging this in Nevada through the courts. Speaking of which, we're finalizing a comprehensive healthcare plan that we'll be releasing soon, hopefully before the month is out. And next month, we'll be focusing on immigration reform. So, we're making progress on multiple fronts.
label: Implicit

sentence: And does that policy extend to Syria? [SEP] With respect to Syria, we are carefully considering all available options to achieve a lasting peace and stability in the region.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, how can you justify this action when it appears to contradict the message you're sending to the American people? [SEP] You're mistaken in your assessment. These activities fall within the scope of permissible conduct. The regulations specifically allow for these types of political engagements.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: On the topic of tax adjustments, can you specify whether these changes would primarily impact corporations or individual taxpayers? Furthermore, to provide market stability, could you give a broad estimate of the percentage adjustment you foresee on either side? [SEP] I'm not going to spell it out for you. I'm just saying I'm prepared to make a minor adjustment.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, are you absolutely firm that any immigration deal *must* include funding for the border wall? Is that a non-negotiable condition? [SEP] Look, it's simple. No wall, no deal. We need the wall. It's about security, it's about stopping the drugs flooding our country. I'm confident the folks in that room, Democrats and Republicans, will find a solution to the DACA problem, and maybe even broader immigration issues. But the wall is the key. Without it, nothing else works. Just look at Israel – they built a wall, problem solved. We *need* the wall for security, plain and simple. So, yes, the wall is essential. Thank you.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the recent phone call between your successor and the President of Taiwan, and the subsequent questioning of the One China policy, are you concerned about the potential ramifications for US-China relations? Specifically, with China's recent actions in the South China Sea, do you believe a reassessment of our China policy is necessary, and what are your thoughts on the wisdom of using such a sensitive issue as a bargaining chip? [SEP] Well, that's a very insightful question. I believe a balanced approach is warranted here. While I commend the intention to bring fresh perspectives to our foreign policy, particularly regarding a relationship as critical as that with China, it's imperative to proceed with caution and a thorough understanding of the historical context and potential consequences. The One China policy, as you know, has been a cornerstone of our diplomatic engagement for decades, and any deviation from that requires careful consideration. I've consistently advised the President-elect to ensure his team is fully briefed and that any policy shifts are undertaken in a systematic and deliberate manner. The stakes are simply too high to act impulsively or without a clear understanding of the potential repercussions. Regarding the specific issue of Taiwan, it's crucial to recognize the sensitivity surrounding this matter for China. It's not merely a political issue; it's deeply intertwined with their national identity. Therefore, any actions that could be perceived as undermining the One China policy must be carefully weighed against the potential benefits. While I believe in exploring new avenues for negotiation and engagement, it's equally important to maintain stability and avoid unnecessary escalation of tensions.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. My question for President—for President Putin. Thank you. Two questions for you, sir. Can you tell me what President Trump may have indicated to you about officially recognizing Crimea as part of Russia?And then secondly, sir, do you—does the Russian Government have any compromising material on President Trump or his family? [SEP] [] President Trump and—well, the posture of President Trump on Crimea is well known, and he stands firmly by it He continued to maintain that it was illegal to annex it We—our viewpoint is different We held a referendum in strict compliance with the UN Charter and the international legislation For us, this issue—we—[inaudible]—to this issueAnd now to the compromising material Yes, I did heard these rumors that we allegedly collected compromising material on Mr Trump when he was visiting Moscow Now, distinguished colleague, let me tell you this: When President Trump visit Moscow back then, I didn't even know that he was in Moscow I treat President Trump with utmost respect But back then, when he was a private individual, a businessman, nobody informed me that he was in MoscowWell, let's take St Petersburg Economic Forum, for instance There were over 500 American businessmen—the high-ranking, the high-level ones I don't even remember the last names of each and every one of them Well, do you remember—do you think that we try to collect compromising material on each and every single one of them? Well, it's difficult to imagine an utter nonsense of a bigger scale than thisWell, please, just disregard these issues and don't think about this anymore again And I have to say, if they had it, it would have been out long ago And if anybody watched Peter Strzok testify over the last couple of days—and I was in Brussels watching it—it was a disgrace to the FBI, it was a disgrace to our country, and, you would say, that was a total witch huntThank you very much, everybody Thank you Thank you
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Red Cross report on CIA interrogation and your promise to close Guantanamo, what's the status? Is Guantanamo closing, and what about the torture allegations? [SEP] Guantanamo's closure is the goal. The problem is finding places to send these people. The Senate doesn't want them here. We're working on it. Trials are also important. As for the Red Cross, what was the specific question again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Is there a record, a transcript perhaps, of your dialogue with Kim Jong Un? [SEP] Say what?

sentence: Q. And for the Finnish Prime Minister [President; White House correction], do you envision the possibility of the U.S. having a permanent military base in Finland? [SEP] Like I told, we are discussing on DCA, the defense cooperation agreement, and it has a lot of elements. They are still open. But we are open on negotiations, and I know that our counterpart is also very open. So let us see.

sentence: Q. So I wouldn't be wrong in saying the President thinks Vladimir Putin authorized the hack? [SEP] Martha, I've given you what I'm going to give you.What was your second question? []

sentence: Mr. President, won't commuting Chelsea Manning's sentence embolden leakers and groups like WikiLeaks? How do you reconcile this with WikiLeaks' supposed ties to Russian election meddling? Also, Julian Assange has offered to come to the US. Will you facilitate this, and what would his legal fate be? [SEP] Let's be clear: Chelsea Manning served a substantial prison sentence. It's not as if she faced no repercussions. She underwent a trial, acknowledged her actions, but her sentence was disproportionate compared to others. Commuting, rather than pardoning, felt right. Justice was served, and the message remains: utilize established channels and whistleblower protections. I understand some find them inadequate, but national security is paramount, and lives are at stake. As for WikiLeaks, I haven't commented extensively on them. The intelligence community's conclusions regarding their involvement in Russian hacking were inconclusive. I don't monitor Assange's online activity. The Justice Department is handling his case. We must strike a balance between accountability and transparency while safeguarding ourselves from those who seek to exploit our openness. In Manning's situation, I carefully examined the specifics and determined that commutation was warranted.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, while I understand the need to protect classified information, the public deserves to know the level of threat we face. Can you provide any general assessment of the credibility and severity of the intelligence regarding potential chemical weapons use? Additionally, what specific consultations have you had with NATO allies regarding a coordinated response? [SEP] We take all intelligence seriously. We're constantly monitoring the situation, and we're in close contact with our allies. We're prepared to respond to any threat. But I'm not going to telegraph our punches. I'm not going to give Putin any information that could help him. We're going to keep him guessing.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, following up on your remarks, you mentioned a shift towards greater decency. Do you believe this election represents a turning point, a break from the divisiveness of the past few years? [SEP] The super-mega-MAGA Republicans? Probably not. But they're a minority. Most Republicans are decent, honorable people, even if we disagree on policy. I've worked with many in the Senate and House, and they're honest and straightforward. The world is watching us. At the first G-7 meeting, I said, 'America is back.' One leader asked, 'For how long?' Another asked what I'd say if thousands stormed the British Parliament to stop an election confirmation. Not the same, but it would signal a democracy in crisis. People want to know if the U.S. is stable, if we still uphold our values and institutions. That's the big picture.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the election of the two Muslim women, one veiled, does this represent a rebuke of your message? [SEP] I'm sorry, what was that?

sentence: Mr. President, to be clear, are you now more open to the possibility of abolishing the filibuster? [SEP] I've already given you my answer.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, did the capture of Mr. Libi comply with international law? [SEP] We know that Mr. al-Libi planned and helped to execute plots that killed hundreds of people, a whole lot of Americans. And we have strong evidence of that. And he will be brought to justice.Mark Knoller [CBS News].

sentence: Q. If I could just follow up on a related matter: Mr. President, are you prepared to impose limits on intelligence-sharing with Britain if they do not put in place some restrictions on Huawei? [SEP] No, because we're going to have absolutely an agreement on Huawei and everything else. We have an incredible intelligence relationship, and we will be able to work out any differences. I think we're not going to have it. We did discuss it. I see absolutely no limitations. We've never had limitations. This is a truly great ally and partner, and we'll have no problem with that. Okay?. Thank you. Francis.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, your former confidant, Michael Cohen, has publicly accused you of being a liar and a racist. Given his long-standing proximity to you and your business dealings, how can the American people trust your account of events over his, particularly concerning the Russia investigation and your knowledge of his activities? [SEP] Look, it's a total fabrication. This whole thing is a witch hunt. They trotted out Cohen, a convicted liar, right in the middle of critical peace talks. It's a disgrace! He's trying to get a reduced sentence, so he'll say anything. The timing alone proves it's a political hit job. But the real story is, even he admitted, under oath, no collusion. That's all that matters. No collusion! This is just a desperate attempt to undermine my administration and distract from our successes. It's a shame, a total shame.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, are there any other Chinese technology companies, besides Huawei, that your administration is actively investigating for potential security risks? [SEP] The big one is Huawei, right? They're not here, and I'm keeping them out. I've told other countries, like in Europe, and Australia has been great, that Huawei is a no-go. We told some countries thinking about using Huawei that if they did, we wouldn't share intelligence with them. And they all backed off. Look at the UK; they were going that way, but now they're pulling back. Scotland Yard.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the eligibility of Kamala Harris to serve as Vice President, given the 'anchor baby' claims, can you definitively state whether she meets the legal requirements? [SEP] I only recently became aware of these questions regarding her eligibility. Apparently, a highly respected lawyer has raised some concerns. I honestly couldn't say whether there's any validity to these claims. I would have assumed the Democrats vetted her thoroughly.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, do you believe the Justice Department's seizure of phone records from Associated Press journalists was an overreach? Do you still have confidence in your Attorney General? Is the renewed interest in a media shield law a direct response to this? And how do you feel about comparisons to the Nixon era? [SEP] Well, folks can draw whatever parallels they want. My focus is on fixing problems. As for the Justice Department, I won't comment on pending cases. But let me be clear: protecting national security is paramount. Leaks put lives at risk. At the same time, a free press is essential for holding government accountable. That's why we need to find the right balance, and that's what the media shield law is all about.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President—— The President. Yes. Yes.Executive Action on Coronavirus Relief  Q. Mr. President, you said that this will pretty much take care of the entire situation. But, as you said, there's not money for reopening schools, other important items. Is your administration willing to go back to Democrats to try to actually negotiate some of these big things? [SEP] Well, the answer is yes, but we have money to do other things, and we have a lot of money that was unspent, and we'll be able to do things with the money that was unspent. We have significant money that was unspent, and we will be able to use that for different purposes.Go ahead.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Before or after the election? Your election this year? [SEP] Before. I think—I think we'll have a deal before.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, given the potential for economic fallout, many are questioning your strategy of negotiating with Republicans on spending caps. How can you assure the American people that these negotiations won't result in a recession or disproportionately impact vital social programs? [SEP] We're approaching these negotiations with our eyes wide open. We understand the risks, and we're prepared to walk away if Republicans insist on policies that would harm the American people. We're committed to protecting Social Security, Medicare, and other essential programs, and we're not going to agree to any cuts that would hurt working families. We're also committed to fiscal responsibility, and we believe we can find common ground with Republicans on ways to cut wasteful spending and reduce the deficit. We're confident that we can reach a bipartisan agreement that is fair, responsible, and protects the interests of all Americans.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, sources indicate potential staff turnover in the White House, with General Kelly's name frequently mentioned. What's the status? [SEP] We have a fantastic team. People are always evaluating their options. We're focused on delivering results for the American people.

sentence: Chancellor Scholz, with respect, beyond general statements, what are the specific, quantifiable targets Germany has set for reducing its dependence on Russian energy, and what are the timelines for achieving these targets? Furthermore, how do you counter the argument that Germany's reliance on Russian gas weakens Europe's ability to effectively confront the situation in Ukraine? Mr. President, your input? [SEP] Let me jump in. We're exploring options to replace lost gas from Russia with LNG, working with allies. Russia needs to sell that gas and oil; it's a big part of their budget. If cut off, they'll be hurt too. It's not just one-way. We're working to help compensate for lost gas in Europe. We're ready for anything, preparing sanctions. On LNG, most is gas. We'll modernize our economy and switch to hydrogen faster than people think. Thank you.
label: General

sentence: Sir, you've spoken about the importance of direct communication and the challenges posed by Russia and China. Given your relationship with President Xi, will you call him, as a friend, to request that China grant WHO investigators access to investigate the origins of COVID-19? [SEP] Look, we know each other. We are not friends. It's a business relationship.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: President Obama, with respect to the open wounds from the Pinochet dictatorship, and the calls for the US to atone for its involvement, will you commit to full transparency and potential reparations? [SEP] The United States values its relationship with Chile and recognizes the complexities of its past. We are prepared to examine specific requests for information and assistance related to historical events. However, my primary responsibility is to the future. We must not let the shadows of the past obscure the bright prospects of our shared future.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, many are concerned that the situation in Syria is spiraling into a regional conflict. What measures are you taking to prevent further escalation and protect U.S. interests in the region? [SEP] We're working to de-escalate the situation. We're coordinating with our allies to ensure stability in the region. We're prepared to take action if necessary to protect our interests.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, will you finalize an agreement with Iraq before leaving office, or will that be left to the next administration? [SEP] We're in negotiations with the Iraqi government on a long-term strategic partnership. This includes security arrangements, economic cooperation, and diplomatic ties. Our aim is to establish a framework for continued cooperation, but the details are still being worked out.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Sir, a question from overseas media, if I may? [SEP] Which country are you representing?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, some experts believe we're nearing peak oil production. If this is true, why haven't you invested more in renewable energy research? [SEP] Well, we've invested significantly in ethanol, particularly cellulosic ethanol. But energy policy must be comprehensive. We're in a transition period. Congress has focused on intermediate and long-term steps like biofuels and hydrogen, but not enough on the present. Regarding peak oil, there are reserves to be found in ANWR. Also, about 27 million gallons of diesel and gasoline could be produced from domestic crude oil that's currently unused. We can explore in environmentally friendly ways using new technologies. However, ANWR is a litmus test issue for many in Congress. Mentioning ANWR shouldn't mean you don't care about the environment, but that you care about gasoline prices.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering the Red Cross's report on CIA interrogation techniques and the continued operation of Guantanamo Bay despite your stated desire to close it, could you elaborate on the specific challenges hindering its closure? Is the resistance from your Vice President, Attorney General, and Homeland Security Secretary a significant factor? What specific actions are you taking to overcome these obstacles, and can you provide a realistic timeline for the closure of Guantanamo? [SEP] Look, the situation with Guantanamo is multifaceted. It's not just about wanting to close it; it's about finding suitable alternatives for the detainees. We've been working diligently with other countries to arrange transfers, but many are hesitant to accept individuals with a history of violence. As for the internal discussions, we're a team, and we have robust debates on policy. The Senate vote reflects the broader concerns about housing these detainees domestically. We are actively pursuing legal avenues for trials and ensuring humane treatment for all detainees. So, while progress may seem slow, we are committed to finding a resolution. Now, regarding the Red Cross report...
label: Clarification

sentence: With his intentions now clear, what does his ambition signify for the democratic landscape of Russia? [SEP] I anticipate seeing him at the alumni gathering for 'Persons of the Year,' though the date remains uncertain. I presume he was recognized for his significance as a leader. However, the fundamental question is, significance toward what end? What will Russia resemble a decade from now? My hope is that Russia embraces checks and balances, free and fair elections, and a vibrant press. That they recognize that Western values rooted in human rights and human dignity are conducive to a better nation. As for his potential premiership, I am uncertain, having not discussed it with him. Until that transpires, we must observe and wait. The actions of the new Russian President next year will be intriguing. We will likely meet on several occasions, and it will be insightful to observe how foreign policy is conducted and what role President Putin assumes. At this juncture, I can only wait and see.
label: General

sentence: Sir, to be blunt, are you attempting to raise $200 million for your library? Will you disclose donors? Will you cap contributions? Yes or no answers, please. [SEP] The library's a priority, and we're exploring all options for funding. We'll be transparent where required, but we also respect donor privacy. It's a balance, a very delicate balance.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Given the apparent weakening of sanctions against North Korea by China, Russia, and South Korea, what measures will you take to preserve the sanctions regime and retain leverage over these countries? [SEP] Look, we have plenty of leverage. Tremendous leverage, in fact. Despite my good relationship with President Xi – a man I respect and like – we're having tough talks on trade, which likely affects China. But I have to do what's necessary. The border is more open now than when we started, but that's the reality. We have a massive trade deficit with China, and we must address it. This impacts my relationship in terms of the border. I don't believe it affects my personal feelings toward President Xi. We weren't initially ready to take this route, but as we prepared, it impacted the border, which is unfortunate. But I have no choice. For our country, I must act. South Korea will do whatever it takes to secure a deal. If that means no trade, then we won't trade. They won't trade either. They might pursue some work with our concurrence, as we're very far down the line on a document developed over months. The rhetoric and sanctions were both crucial. I'm unsure which was more important. They were both important.
label: General

sentence: Given the ongoing efforts to reinforce the Finnish-Russian border fence, Mr. President, what specific developments have recently caused you concern? Furthermore, as a leader bordering Russia, what further actions do you advocate to deter Putin's aggression? [SEP] From the outset of our application process, we meticulously anticipated every conceivable challenge and devised appropriate responses. This careful preparation has ensured a relatively stable situation. While we remain hopeful for continued calm, I want to emphasize the increased sense of security among the Finnish people. Currently, 80% of our population supports NATO membership, and a similar percentage is committed to defending our allies. This reflects Finland's unwavering stance.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, what specific assurances did President Xi give you regarding preventing a North Korean nuclear test? [SEP] It's not about assurances, it's about a shared understanding of the situation. Look, I can't definitively say that China can control North Korea. But I made it crystal clear to President Xi that they have a duty to try and convince North Korea to stop these nuclear tests. I also told him that if North Korea goes ahead, we will have to take defensive steps. These steps aren't targeted at China, but are meant to send a clear message to North Korea that we will defend our allies, our homeland, and our interests. Whether China has the power to fully control North Korea is hard to know. But I'm confident they don't want things to escalate further. I've made it clear that we will defend ourselves and our allies – South Korea and Japan – and that this would mean a bigger US presence in the region, which isn't about China, but about North Korea's actions. Our teams are talking to their Chinese counterparts to try and work through these issues. We won't agree on everything, but I don't think a new Cold War is necessary. I want to make sure that all leaders, especially Xi Jinping, understand my intentions and actions. That's the most important thing. Our meeting lasted three and a half hours, and we talked about a lot. President Xi was very straightforward, and I think we have a good understanding of where each other stands.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, given the year-long finalization of the Roxham Road agreement, could you elaborate on the reasons behind the protracted delay? Additionally, with Canada's commitment to accepting 15,000 migrants, what specific compromises were made to the United States in return? [SEP] Well, no, I'm not disappointed. This is a very difficult situation. How do we deal with what's going on in Haiti, where gangs have essentially taken over the government? They're in charge. So, I think what the Prime Minister has said makes sense. The most important thing we can do, and it will take time, is to improve the capacity of the police departments to deal with the problems. That will take a while. We're also looking at whether the international community, through the UN, can play a larger role. There's a real concern because there are several million people in Haiti, and the diaspora could cause some real, how can I say it, confusion in the Western Hemisphere. So, I think what the Prime Minister is suggesting, and we're also contributing, is to increase the efficiency and capacity of the police training and methods. We're also talking to others in the hemisphere who are prepared to help. It's a work in progress.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. With regard to domestic travel: Should Americans feel safe or should Americans at all be traveling to states such as Washington State, New York, and other hotspots within this country?And a follow-up on Brazil: You're asking people who come back from America—from Europe—Americans who are coming back from Europe to self-quarantine for a couple weeks. You were in a picture with somebody who now has coronavirus from Brazil, at Mar-a-Lago. How is that different? [SEP] Well, I'll tell you, first of all, I'm not coming back from someplace.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. In conversations that you've had over the past couple of days with the Asian-Pacific leaders, have any of them brought up the rhetoric that we're seeing from Republican Presidential candidates when it comes to China? And does that kind of rhetoric or posturing jeopardize the progress that your administration has made with China and the Asian-Pacific region as a whole? [SEP] I think most leaders here understand that politics is not always measured or on the level, and so most of our discussions have to do with substance: How do we put our people back to work right now? How do we expand trade? How do we expand exports?I've been very frank with Chinese leaders, though, in saying that the American people across the board--left, right, and center--believe in trade, believe in competition. We think we've got the best workers in the world. We think we've got the best universities, the best entrepreneurs, the best free market. We're ready to go out there and compete with anybody. But there is a concern across the political spectrum that the playing field is not level right now.And so in conversations with President Hu and others, what I've tried to say is we have the opportunity to move in a direction in which this is a win-win: is benefiting from trade with the United States; the United States is benefiting as well. Jobs are being created in the United States and not just in . But right now things are out of kilter. And that is something that is shared across the board, as we saw with the recent vote on the Chinese currency issue in the Senate.And I think leaders in the region understand that as grows, as its economic influence expands, that the expectation is, is that they will be a responsible leader in the world economy, which is what the United States has tried to do. I mean, we try to set up rules that are universal, that everybody can follow, and then we play by those rules, and then we compete fiercely. But we don't try to game the system. That's part of what leadership's about. has the opportunity to be that same type of leader. And as the world's second largest economy, I think that's going to be important not just for this region, but for the world. But that requires them to take responsibility, to understand that their role is different now than it might have been 20 years ago or 30 years ago, where if they were breaking some rules, it didn't really matter, it did not have a significant impact. You weren't seeing huge trade imbalances that had consequences for the world financial system.Now they've grown up, and so they're going to have to help manage this process in a responsible way.Laura Meckler [Wall Street Journal].
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, regarding the CIA interrogation program and the Red Cross report alleging torture, what's your response? Furthermore, a year after your promise to close Guantanamo, it remains open, reportedly due to internal resistance. Who's calling the shots? Will it be closed by the end of your term? [SEP] Closing Guantanamo is the aim, but repatriation is difficult. The Senate opposes bringing detainees here. So, where do they go? We're working on repatriation, but many are dangerous. Humane treatment is also a concern. Trials are being worked on by the courts and Defense. I can't say if Guantanamo will close. It's complex, as the Senate vote shows. Regarding the Red Cross report, I will look into it. Now, what was your other question?
label: Clarification

sentence: On the executive action, how will you ensure its effectiveness against potential Republican funding blockades? And could you clarify if you're now considering a figure of 2 million or more? [SEP] Well, let's just say that when we roll out the details of this executive action, it will be comprehensive, leaving no stone unturned. I expect there will be ample opportunity for follow-up questions then.

sentence: Q. With all due respect, sir, what specific topics were on the agenda during your conversation with him? [SEP] We addressed the matters pertinent to the overall discussions at the aforementioned conference. We emphasized the importance of stability and ensuring equitable access to progress for the Southern Hemisphere. The exchange was amicable; he approached me and expressed certain sentiments. Thank you all for your presence. This concludes the press briefing. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the Paris attacks, what impact will they have on the climate negotiations? Furthermore, how do you address concerns regarding the U.S.'s ability to persuade developing nations to invest in climate solutions, particularly given Republican opposition? Finally, what are your thoughts on allegations of intelligence manipulation concerning assessments of the ISIL campaign? [SEP] My administration demands unbiased intelligence. Accurate information is paramount for effective policy-making. Any irregularities at CENTCOM will be thoroughly investigated. Regarding Paris, it is imperative that we demonstrate resilience in the face of terrorism. We must not allow fear to dictate our actions. A robust climate agreement is essential. 160 nations have committed to emission reduction targets. Accountability and transparency are crucial. Climate finance is vital to enable developing nations to pursue sustainable development. We are making substantial progress towards meeting our financial commitments. The attacks in Paris must not impede our efforts to address climate change.
label: General

sentence: Excuse me, Mr. President, could you clarify which media outlet you're referring to? [SEP] Which one are you with?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. No. Is that okay with you? [SEP] It's your baby. []

sentence: So, no commitment to a specific timeframe then? Are you suggesting that the infrastructure bill's implementation could be delayed indefinitely pending this review? [SEP] Absolutely not. We are fully committed to delivering on our promise to rebuild America's infrastructure. The review is simply a necessary step to ensure that we do it right. We anticipate having a clearer picture of the timeline in the coming weeks, and we'll be sure to keep the public informed.

sentence: Q. Tuesday night, sir? [SEP] After Thanksgiving. [] And I'm sure that at that point, if there are further questions, that we'll be answering them to the satisfaction not just of you, but to the satisfaction of the American people. Ms. Smita Prakash.

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Mr. Putin's actions, do you observe any indication that he is deviating from his established pattern of disruption, notably towards NATO and the United States? Furthermore, in relation to the list of critical infrastructure you provided, were the penalties for interference clearly articulated, or were they intentionally left undefined? What was his response to this? [SEP] Regarding the second inquiry, I conveyed to Mr. Putin our substantial cyber capabilities. While the precise nature of these capabilities remains undisclosed to him, their significance is understood. Any violation of these fundamental norms will be met with a cyber response. He is cognizant of this.

sentence: President Trump, to be perfectly clear, are there any limitations on U.S. companies selling to Huawei, and what specific actions will be taken against Turkey if they acquire the S-400 system from Russia? [SEP] So, Turkey, it's an interesting situation. Erdogan, I have a great relationship with him. He's a tough cookie. He was going to wipe out the Kurds, who helped us with ISIS. I told him not to, and he didn't. Now, the previous administration wouldn't sell him the Patriot missile, even though he's a NATO member. So, he went to Russia and bought the S-400. Then, we wanted to sell him the Patriot, but he already bought the S-400. He also bought over a hundred F-35s, paid a tremendous amount of money. Now, they're saying he can't use the S-400 because it's not compatible and Russia could access the F-35. Honestly, he was treated unfairly. They wouldn't sell him the Patriot initially. It's a mess, and it's not really his fault.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. No, is that correct: You're waiting for Congress? [SEP] Well, I am. You know, there's a theory that I can do it without the approval, but I'd rather get the approval so that we have it. But there's a theory I could take the $300 billion. It's money that we have—money that we built up and money that we haven't spent, and I would love to give it to the American people as a very powerful stimulus. So yes.I think there is a theory that I could do it without having to go back, but I think it would be appropriate to go back, and I would ask Congress to approve it. It's a very simple approval. It's—literally, it's a one-sentence approval, and the Democrats should do that. The Republicans will do that. They would be glad to do that. So we'll see whether or not they do it. Okay?Please, in the back.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. What is the impact—[inaudible]? [SEP] I can't hear you too well. Sorry, got a flawed mike. Martha, what did you do to the mike? []

sentence: Mr. President, your administration is issuing a business advisory for Hong Kong tomorrow. Can you explain why you believe this is necessary? Also, regarding your Build Back Better agenda, have you discussed the $3.5 trillion framework with Senators Manchin and Sinema, and are you confident they will support it at that level? If they require you to reduce some components, will you be able to maintain the support of progressives? [SEP] Well, the situation in Hong Kong is concerning. China isn't living up to its commitments. As for Build Back Better, we're working with everyone to get it done. It's important for the American people.

sentence: President Calderon, what are your views on the situation in the US Congress and the commercial comparing Lopez Obrador to Hitler and Mussolini? Does this foster Mexican unity concerning the energy bill? [SEP] This kind of behavior is a reflection of those who perpetrate it. Congress is operating normally, with most parties acting responsibly. The PRI, PAN, Green Party, New Alliance, and others are working diligently. I deplore this behavior, as it damages the reputation of those responsible and further weakens the image of the PRD. I hope our institutions will strengthen dialogue. This matter is currently under review by the authorities. The IFE will render a decision based on the TV spots.

sentence: President, if the U.S. were to militarily intervene in Venezuela, what would be Brazil's position? [SEP] Well, some issues are strategic and can't be discussed publicly. These reserved issues will be discussed if they haven't been already, but not publicly. I remember a debate where a candidate wouldn't reveal his plan to fight ISIS, saying, If I say, I will no longer be able to beat it. It's a matter of strategy. We'll honor everything discussed, but certain information can't be debated publicly.

sentence: Q. Sir, is it your assessment that Mrs. Clinton will secure the nomination? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, are you deliberately avoiding my question? [SEP] I'm not avoiding anything. I'm prioritizing a clear and comprehensive message for the public. Your question, while perhaps important to you, is not my priority at this moment.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, setting aside the political motivations, do you believe your conduct has been above reproach? [SEP] I think my conduct has been perfect. Absolutely perfect. I'm doing a great job, the economy is booming, and we're making America great again. The Democrats are just jealous. They're desperate to find something, anything, to impeach me on, but they have nothing.
label: Deflection

sentence: President Obama, considering President Trump's approach to climate change and Russia, have your concerns been allayed? Are you concerned about the future of European-Russian relations? And following the election, will you announce your candidacy? [SEP] I've always made it a point to avoid meddling in other nations' political affairs. Chancellor Merkel has been an outstanding partner, a constant presence since my time in office. While we haven't always agreed on every issue, her core values, integrity, and commitment to the German people have been unwavering. Her decision to seek re-election is hers alone, and ultimately, it's up to the German people. As for Russia, my approach has remained consistent: a desire for constructive engagement tempered by a firm defense of our values and international norms. They're a major global player, and cooperation is essential, but we must also be clear about our differences. I hope the incoming administration will adopt a similar approach. I'm encouraged by President-elect Trump's commitment to NATO. My conversations with President Putin have been direct: we will not tolerate cyberattacks or interference in our elections. We need to establish international norms in cyberspace to prevent a dangerous escalation. The peaceful transfer of power in the US is a testament to our democratic principles. We will continue our strong cooperation with Germany, and I will approach my interactions with President-elect Trump with an open mind. From a European perspective, respecting territorial integrity is essential for maintaining peace. We must stand firm against any attempts to undermine it and pursue political solutions through processes like the Normandy format. Russia is our neighbor, and we desire a positive relationship, but we must also address our disagreements. I will announce my future political intentions when the time is appropriate.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, about Putin: Do you think he okayed the hack himself? And was it to boost Trump? Trump brings up Saddam and the WMDs that never showed up. Can you say definitively it wasn't China or some random guy, like Trump suggests? And do Trump's comments give Russia a boost? [SEP] The upcoming report, before I'm out of here, will connect all the dots. I don't want to jump the gun. But the intel I've seen makes me pretty sure Russia was behind the hack.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. This is a question for both of you, but first for President Bush. Mr. President, many analysts say that the best thing for the approval in Congress of the free trade agreement would be the victory in November of Senator Obama. Do you agree? [SEP] First of all, I think the best thing for the country will be the victory of McCain. I'm a big believer in Senator John McCain and his capabilities to do this job. It's very important that we get the tra bill out of politics and into the realm of strategic thought. It's in our strategic interests that we get this bill done. It's good for our economies, and it's good for our national security interest.?
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Venezuela, despite the sanctions and aid, Maduro remains in power. Are you concerned about losing momentum, and what's the estimated timeline for a resolution? [SEP] Well, nobody's giving me a specific date. They've been there for quite some time, both him and the guy before him. Sooner or later, things are going to change. But we haven't really put the hammer down with the sanctions yet. We could do that. All options are on the table, believe me. We've only done sanctions that are kind of in the middle. We can go a lot harder if we need to. It's a real shame, and we're just trying to help the people who are starving and dying in the streets. What's going on there is a disgrace. It used to be one of the richest countries in the world, and now it's just a mess. No food, no water, no air conditioning, no power. The power was out for a long time last week, and it's probably going to happen again because it's barely hanging on. It's very sad, Roberta. Very sad to see, okay?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I'd like to ask you about the Justice Department. Do you believe that the seizure of phone records from Associated Press journalists this week—or before that was announced recently this week was an overreach? And do you still have full confidence in your Attorney General? Should we interpret yesterday's renewed interest by the White House in a media shield law as a response to that? And more broadly, how do you feel about comparisons by some of your critics of this week's scandals to those that happened under the Nixon administration? [SEP] Well, I'll let you guys engage in those comparisons, and you can go ahead and read the history, I think, and draw your own conclusions.My concern is making sure that if there's a problem in the Government, that we fix it. That's my responsibility, and that's what we're going to do. That's true with respect to the IRS and making sure that they apply the laws the way they were intended. That's true with respect to the security of our diplomats, which is why we're going to need to work with Congress to make sure that there's adequate funding for what's necessary out there.Now, with respect to the Department of Justice, I'm not going to comment on a specific and pending case. But I can talk broadly about the balance that we have to strike. Leaks related to national security can put people at risk. They can put men and women in uniform that I've sent into the battlefield at risk. They can put some of our intelligence officers, who are in various, dangerous situations that are easily compromised, at risk.U.S. national security is dependent on those folks being able to operate with confidence that folks back home have their backs so they're not just left out there high and dry and potentially put in even more danger than they may already be. And so I make no apologies, and I don't think the American people would expect me as Commander in Chief not to be concerned about information that might compromise their missions or might get them killed.Now, the flip side of it is, we also live in a democracy where a free press, free expression, and the open flow of information helps hold me accountable, helps hold our Government accountable, and helps our democracy function. And the whole reason I got involved in politics is because I believe so deeply in that democracy and that process.So the whole goal of this media shield law—that was worked on and largely endorsed by folks like the Washington Post editorial page and by prosecutors—was finding a way to strike that balance appropriately. And to the extent that this case—which we still don't know all the details of—to the extent that this case has prompted renewed interest about how do we strike that balance properly, then I think now is the time for us to go ahead and revisit that legislation. I think that's a worthy conversation to have, and I think that's important.But I also think it's important to recognize that when we express concern about leaks at a time when I've still got 60,000-plus troops in Afghanistan and I've still got a whole bunch of intelligence officers around the world who are in risky situations—in outposts that, in some cases, are as dangerous as the outpost in Benghazi—that part of my job is to make sure that we're protecting what they do, while still accommodating for the need for information, so—or the need for the public to be informed and be able to hold my office accountable.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering the criticism that the U.S. is lagging behind other nations in coronavirus testing, what specific steps are you taking to increase testing capacity and ensure that the public has access to accurate and timely information about the spread of the virus? [SEP] Let me tell you, we have the best people working on this. The smartest people. We're doing a tremendous job. We're testing everybody that needs to be tested. And we're finding very little problem. Very little problem. It's like the flu. You know, you wash your hands, you stay home if you're sick. We're working on a vaccine. We're going to have a vaccine very soon. So, we're doing a great job. The best job. Nobody could do a better job than we're doing. The fake news media is trying to make this into a bigger deal than it is. But we have it totally under control.
label: Deflection

sentence: Prime Minister, with respect, the details emerging from Elections Canada are deeply troubling. Did you have prior knowledge of this alleged scheme, and can you definitively state that such practices will not be repeated in future elections? [SEP] The situation is as follows: Elections Canada holds a particular interpretation regarding local versus national spending, an interpretation with which we disagree. We acted in accordance with our understanding of the law at the time, and we have always strived to uphold the integrity of the electoral process.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, if sanctions prove insufficient to curb Iran's behavior, what other non-military tools are available, and are you prepared to deploy them? [SEP] We have many options, believe me. But I'm not going to discuss them publicly. The sanctions are having a tremendous impact, a devastating impact. And if we had to use the military, we would win. We always win. Our military is the best in the world, by far. We've spent a lot of money, rebuilt it from the ground up. It's incredible. The best people, the best equipment. We're doing a fantastic job.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Obama, concerning Mexico's human rights record, the drug war, threats to Calderon, and visa problems, what's your stance? [SEP] I'm afraid the translation was lost on me. Could you rephrase that?
label: Clarification

sentence: And what's the timeline on that? [SEP] Hard to say exactly, but we're aiming for a swift resolution. Next question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the allegations of campaign finance violations, can you assure the American people that your campaign acted within the bounds of the law? [SEP] My campaign was the greatest campaign in history. We did everything right. These are just baseless accusations from the fake news media.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the potential consequences of military action against Iran, what specific diplomatic efforts are currently underway to address the concerns surrounding their nuclear program, and what conditions would be necessary for the US to support a military option? [SEP] We're pursuing a multi-faceted diplomatic strategy. We're working with our allies in Europe, Asia, and the Middle East to put pressure on Iran to come clean about their nuclear program. We're also engaging in direct talks with the Iranians, but only if they're willing to negotiate in good faith. As for military action, that's always an option on the table, but it's not our preferred option. We believe that diplomacy is the best way to resolve this issue, but we're not going to take any options off the table. The conditions for supporting a military option would be if we had exhausted all other options and we were convinced that Iran was on the verge of developing a nuclear weapon.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, rockets and settlements: what's the plan? [SEP] Yes.[]
label: Dodging

sentence: You advocated for middle-class tax relief during your campaign. How do you intend to bridge the partisan divide and convince Democrats to back this proposal? [SEP] They know where I stand. It's up to them to decide if they want to help the American people.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to journalists accessing facilities, when can the American people expect to see for themselves these facilities? When will you be transparent? [SEP] Transparency is key, and we're dedicated to it. My team's on it, setting things up. I'm staying away for now to avoid causing a ruckus with my security detail. Once we've got everything squared away, you'll get the full tour. It's all about timing, folks.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, your recent remarks at a fundraiser seemed to label President Xi a dictator, a term rarely used by sitting U.S. Presidents. Do you believe this complicates our relationship with China? Also, regarding India, how do you respond to critics who say your administration is ignoring human rights issues there? [SEP] The answer to the first part is simply, no. When we're dealing with allies and partners, including India, the idea that I'd avoid saying what I think about China? That's just not going to happen. I think the supposed crisis in our relationship with China is overblown. We had an incident, sure, but Secretary Blinken had a good trip. I expect to meet with President Xi soon. It hasn't really changed anything. And the second question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Given the Supreme Court's decision regarding vaccine mandates, are you considering alternative strategies, such as mandating vaccinations for domestic flights, to increase vaccination rates? Also, could you clarify your strategy for Build Back Better, specifically whether you intend to pursue a piecemeal approach by passing 'big chunks' of the bill separately? [SEP] The Supreme Court's ruling was unfortunate, but the private sector is stepping up on testing. Now, regarding Build Back Better, what part of it are you interested in?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, on the matter of the Israeli-Palestinian situation, when do you anticipate a resolution, and do you approve of Israel's conduct? [SEP] The aim is a sustainable ceasefire. Hamas must cease firing rockets into Israel. It's their decision. We're collaborating with Egypt to halt arms smuggling. Nations providing weapons to Hamas must cease. Regarding Israel, they have the right to self-defense, but we must also address the humanitarian crisis. What was the second part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Are you confident this legislation will pass within your first year in office? [SEP] We're pushing this forward as quickly as possible. I'm being very aggressive on all fronts. Ultimately, the legislative schedule isn't up to me. We'll be working closely with the leaders in Congress to see what we can accomplish.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, with anti-LGBTQ laws proliferating in Republican states, some families are considering leaving the country. What do you say to them? [SEP] Let me first say, I want the contact information for that family. I will personally reach out and assure them that this administration stands with them. I was proud to end the ban on transgender troops, sign the Respect for Marriage Act, and strengthen civil rights protections for LGBT Americans. But the fight is far from over. We are facing hysterical and prejudiced individuals who are spreading fear and hate. It is wrong for people to be discriminated against because of their sexual orientation or gender identity. We must protect transgender children from hateful legislation. These are our children, and we must support them. Today, I am announcing new initiatives to protect the LGBT community, including strengthening physical safety, addressing civil rights violations, and providing mental health resources. Congress must pass the Equality Act. To all LGBTQ Americans, especially children, know that you are loved, you are heard, and this administration has your unwavering support. On the issue of AI, it presents both incredible benefits and real risks. We must work with other countries to establish guardrails. We need the same urgency we apply to climate change. Now, I'd like to call on the BBC.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Just to stay on that subject, if we may. Mr. Prime Minister, first of all, would you be prepared to talk to your predecessors, Tony Blair and Gordon Brown, to get their agreements to release any documents if they are relevant to the paper search that the Cabinet Secretary will undergo?And, Mr. President, can I ask you--the Prime Minister says he opposes an inquiry. Hillary Clinton has demanded an inquiry. Where do you stand? [SEP] Well, go ahead, David. Well, first of all, on the documents, the proper process here is that the Cabinet Secretary should look back over this decision and the circumstances surrounding it, should identify those documents that should be published. It should be right that Ministers in the previous Government should be consulted about the publication of those documents. And of course we will consult with them over that.But in my view, there is absolutely no harm to be done in giving the fullest possible explanation of the circumstances surrounding this decision. I think the key thing, though, to remember is that in the end, it was a decision by the Scottish Executive.On the issue of an inquiry, as I said, I'm not currently minded to hold an inquiry because I think publishing this information, combined with the inquiry that has already been, will give people the certainty that they need about the circumstances surrounding this decision. But the key thing is to get the information out there so people can see. But I don't think there's any great mystery here. There was a decision taken by the Scottish Executive, in my view, a wholly wrong and misguided decision, a bad decision, but the decision nonetheless. That's what happened. And I don't think we need an extra inquiry to tell us that that's what happened. But the information, as I said, will be gone over and published, as appropriate. And of course I'll be consulting with previous Ministers and Prime Ministers, as you should do in the normal way. I think the simple answer is, we should have all the facts; they should be laid out there. And I have confidence that Prime Minister Cameron's government will be cooperative in making sure that the facts are there. That will not negate the fact that, as the Prime Minister indicated, it was a very poor decision and one that not only ran contrary to, I think, how we should be treating terrorists, but also didn't reflect the incredible pain that the families who were affected still suffer to this day. And my administration is in regular contact with these families, and this was a heartbreaking decision for them that reopened a whole host of new wounds.So my expectation is, is that the facts will be out there, and, as David indicated, with all the facts out, I think we're going to be back to where we are right now, which it was--it's--it was a decision that should not have been made and one that we should learn from going forward.Laura Meckler [Wall Street Journal].
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, as a representative of the New York Times, would you permit me to pose a question before recognizing another member of the press? [SEP] You are from where?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, on the matter of Cuba, the Cuban government often cites past U.S. interventions as justification for limiting freedoms. Does your new policy definitively end U.S. regime change efforts, and should Cuba then respond by allowing free elections and tolerating dissent?
