Furthermore, concerning Hillary Clinton, Vice President Biden believes the Democratic race is still wide open, despite what the polls suggest. What are your thoughts on that? [SEP] Well, I'm done running for office, and I'm not in the business of predicting future elections. That's your job. There are plenty of people who are happy to offer their opinions on that. I won't be one of them. Regarding Cuba, our focus is not on regime change. It's on ensuring the Cuban people have freedom and the ability to shape their own destiny and lives, and on supporting civil society. There will be an evolution within Cuba, regardless of what we do. Partly, it's generational. President Castro's comments this morning referenced actions that occurred before I was even born, and part of my message is that the Cold War is over. We still face many challenges and issues around the world, and we will still have serious issues with Cuba regarding its government's approach to its own people, as well as regional concerns. There may be areas where we can cooperate. Cuban doctors made a difference during the Ebola crisis, and Cuban activity in Haiti after the earthquake was significant. I told President Castro what I've told leaders throughout the region: we have a point of view, and we won't hesitate to express it. But I believe the best way to promote the values we care about is through persuasion. That will be our primary approach on these issues, mainly because they don't directly threaten our national security. Cuba is not a threat to the United States, although we have differences. Among the threats I'm concerned about, I would list ISIL, Iran's nuclear ambitions, activities in Yemen and Libya, Boko Haram, Russian aggression in Ukraine, and climate change. Our approach must be to work with the region and other countries, clearly stating what we believe in and what works. Often, when we intervene in ways that go beyond persuasion, it's counterproductive and backfires. That's been part of our history, which is why countries use us as an excuse for their own governance failures. Let's remove that excuse and be clear that we're prepared to partner and engage with everyone to promote opportunity, prosperity, and security in the region.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, in light of the violence in Delhi, what did Prime Minister Modi communicate to you regarding the citizenship law, and how concerned are you about religious violence in India? [SEP] We engaged in a discussion about religious freedom. The Prime Minister was remarkably forthcoming in his statements. He is a strong proponent of religious freedom. He asserted that India has made significant efforts to foster a climate of great and open religious freedom. I raised this question before a substantial gathering of individuals today. We engaged in a lengthy conversation on the matter. I genuinely believe in his sincerity. With respect to the specific attack, I am aware of it, but I did not discuss it with him. That is a matter for India to address. As for Harvey Weinstein, I'm not a fan.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Can you clarify whether the perpetrator was male or female, and what kind of weapon was involved? [SEP] At this point, I have no knowledge of either of those aspects.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, the withdrawal led to the rapid collapse of the Afghan government and the resurgence of the Taliban. What steps could have been taken to prevent this outcome, and what responsibility does the U.S. bear for the current situation? [SEP] We planned for every contingency. But the Afghan government collapsed faster than anyone anticipated. We did everything we could to support them. But ultimately, they weren't willing to fight for their own country. And we can't fight their battles for them.
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, your immediate response to the Biden-Harris campaign launch? [SEP] I saw a bit. Enough to know. She was brutal to him, said horrible things. Now she's suddenly his biggest fan? Give me a break. Her poll numbers were terrible. She's all about raising taxes and destroying our energy industry. Pennsylvania won't stand for it. We're doing great things. Our military is the strongest it's ever been. I'm very surprised he chose her. Very surprised. She said terrible things about him. It's hard to believe, frankly.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Does the shutdown anxiety in any way affect your timing at all on immigration action? [SEP] No, I think the main concern I have is making sure that we get it right, and that's what we're focused on at this point, because any executive action that I take is going to require some adjustments to how DHS, the Department of Homeland Security, operates, where it's deploying resources, et cetera; how are folks processed; what priorities are set up. And so I want to make sure that we've crossed all our t's and dotted all our i's—that that's my main priority. And we are going to close with Jim Avila [ABC News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the constitutionality of the War Powers Act, the debt limit, and marriage as a civil right, what are your personal interpretations of these issues? [SEP] That's quite a legal buffet you've presented! I'm not a judge, and I won't pretend to be one here. Let's focus on the situation in Libya. Qadhafi was a menace, and our actions were justified under international law and served our national interests. We consulted with Congress, and our mission was limited and successful. The War Powers Act is a separate issue, born from the Vietnam War, and our actions in Libya don't violate it. So, I'll leave the constitutional debates to the legal scholars.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. The troops that are massing on the border are more highly trained. They seem to have more sophisticated weaponry, according to intelligence. Does that make you reconsider—as a few Democrats have suggested—providing lethal aid to Ukraine, given those troop movements? [SEP] Well, keep in mind that the Russian Army is a lot bigger than the Ukrainian Army. So the issue here is not whether the Ukrainian Army has some additional weaponry. At least up until this point, they've been fighting a group of separatists who have engaged in some terrible violence, but who can't match the Ukrainian Army.Now, if you start seeing an invasion by Russia, that's obviously a different set of questions. We're not there yet. What we have been doing is providing a whole host of assistance packages to the Ukrainian Government and to their military, and we will continue to work with them to evaluate on a day-by-day, week-by-week basis what exactly they need in order to be able to defend their country and to deal with the separatist elements that currently are being armed by Russia.But the best thing we can do for Ukraine is to try to get back on a political track.David Ohito, the Standard.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, critics say you're using executive actions too much because Congress is blocked. Is that fair? [SEP] My job is to get things done for the American people. I'm bound by the Constitution; I'm bound by separation of powers. When Congress can't agree, I have to look at what I can do within the law. Congress has the power of the purse, for example. I would love to fund a large infrastructure proposal right now that would put millions of people to work and boost our GDP. We know we've got roads and bridges and airports and electrical grids that need to be rebuilt. But without the cooperation of Congress, what I can do is speed up the permitting process, for example.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. On climate change and the decision that was issued yesterday by the U.S. Supreme Court, what's your reaction to that decision? And don't you think that this makes some kind of broad caps on greenhouse gas emissions more or less inevitable? [SEP] First of all, the decision of the Supreme Court is—we take very seriously. It's the new law of the land. And secondly, we're taking some time to fully understand the details of the decision. As you know, this decision was focused on emissions that come from automobiles. My attitude is, is that we have laid out a plan that will affect greenhouse gases that come from automobiles by having a mandatory fuel standard that insists upon 35—using 35 billion gallons of alternative fuels by 2017, which will reduce our gasoline usage by 20 percent and halt the growth in greenhouse gases that emanate from automobiles. In other words, there is a remedy available for Congress, and I strongly hope that they pass this remedy quickly.In terms of the broader issue, first of all, I've taken this issue very seriously. I have said that it is a serious problem. I recognize that man is contributing greenhouse gases, that—but here are the principles by which I think we can get a good deal. One, anything that happens cannot hurt economic growth. And I say that because, one, I care about the working people of the country, but also because, in order to solve the greenhouse gas issue over a longer period of time, it's going to require new technologies, which tend to be expensive. And it's easier to afford expensive technologies if you're prosperous.Secondly, whatever we do must be in concert with what happens internationally because we could pass any number of measures that are now being discussed in the Congress, but unless there is an accord with China, China will produce greenhouse gases that will offset anything we do in a brief period of time.And so those are the principles that will guide our decisionmaking. How do you encourage new technology? How do you grow the economy? And how do you make sure that China is—and India are a part of a rational solution?Let's see here—how about Bret Baier [FOX News]?
label: Explicit

sentence: And what about the retirement age specifically? [SEP] I'm not going to delve into the specifics right now. As I mentioned, Jake, we've discussed all the points you raised. But I'm not going to ask for even--well, let me rephrase that: If you're a senior citizen and a change might cost you an extra hundred or two a year--or even if it doesn't affect current retirees--but someone who's 40 today might have to pay a bit more 20 years down the line, the least I can do is ensure that those earning a million dollars or more also contribute. That's the kind of balanced, shared sacrifice approach that I believe most Americans support.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you. Your top foreign policy advisers have warned that Russia is now ready to attack Ukraine. But there's still little unity among European allies about what a package of sanctions against Moscow would look like. If the U.S. and NATO aren't willing to put troops on the line to defend Ukraine and American allies can't agree on a sanctions package, hasn't the U.S. and the West lost nearly all of its leverage over Vladimir Putin?And given how ineffective sanctions have been in deterring Putin in the past, why should the threat of new sanctions give him pause? [SEP] Well, because he's never seen sanctions like the ones I promised will be imposed if he moves, number one.Number two, we're in a situation where Vladimir Putin is about to—we've had very frank discussions, Vladimir Putin and I. And the idea that NATO is not going to be united, I don't buy. I've spoken to every major NATO leader. We've had the NATO-Russian summit. We've had other—the OSCE has met, et cetera.And so I think what you're going to see is that Russia will be held accountable if it invades. And it depends on what it does. It's one thing if it's a minor incursion and then we end up having a fight about what to do and not do, et cetera.But if they actually do what they're capable of doing with the forces amassed on the border, it is going to be a disaster for Russia if they further invade Ukraine, and that our allies and partners are ready to impose severe costs and significant harm on Russia and the Russian economy.And you know, we're going to fortify our NATO allies, I told him, on the eastern flank—if, in fact, he does invade. We're going to—I've already shipped over $600 million worth of sophisticated equipment, defensive equipment to the Ukrainians.The cost of going into Ukraine, in terms of physical loss of life, for the Russians, they'll—they'll be able to prevail over time, but it's going to be heavy, it's going to be real, and it's going to be consequential.In addition to that, Putin has—you know, has a stark choice: He—either deescalation or diplomacy; confrontation or the consequences.And look, I think you're going to see—for example, everybody talks about how Russia has control over the energy supply that Europe absorbs. Well, guess what? That money that they earn from that makes about 45 percent of the economy. I don't see that as a one-way street. They go ahead and cut it off—it's like my mother used to say: You bite your nose off to spite your face. It's not like they have all these wonderful choices out there.I spoke with the Prime Minister of Finland. And you know, we're talking about concern on the part of Finland and Sweden about what Russia is doing. The last thing that Russia needs is Finland deciding to change its status. They didn't say they're going to do that, but they're talking about what, in fact, is going on and how outrageous Russia is being.We're finding ourselves in a position where I believe you will see that there'll be severe economic consequences. For example, anything that involves dollar denominations, if they make—if they invade, they're going to pay; they're not going—their banks will not be able to deal in dollars.So there's—a lot is going to happen.But here's the thing: My conversation with Putin—and we've been—how can we say it? We have no problem understanding one another. He has no problem understanding me, nor me him. And the direct conversations where I pointed out—I said: You know, you've occupied, before, other countries. But the price has been extremely high. How long? You can go in and, over time, at great loss and economic loss, go in and occupy Ukraine. But how many years? One? Three? Five? Ten? What is that going to take? What toll does that take? It's real. It's consequential.So this is not all just a cakewalk for Russia.Militarily, they have overwhelming superiority, and on—as it relates to Ukraine. But they'll pay a stiff price—immediately, near term, medium term, and long term—if they do it.Umm—I'm sorry. Okay. David Sanger, New York Times./North Atlantic Treaty Organization
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, can you outline specific measures your administration will implement to guarantee the US meets its deficit reduction goals, fostering investor confidence? [SEP] Excuse me, could you repeat the question a little louder?
label: Clarification

sentence: Given the extended timeline for troop withdrawal, U.S. forces in Afghanistan face heightened risks. How do you justify this to them, assuring them of the mission's continued value and its eventual conclusion? President Ghani, acknowledging the sacrifices of U.S. troops, how do you convey that their ongoing commitment is worthwhile? [SEP] Leo, it's crucial to remember that our timeline for withdrawal to an Embassy-centered presence by the end of 2016 remains unchanged. Our transition out of a combat role is also unchanged. I recognize the inherent risks for our troops in Afghanistan; it's a dangerous environment. However, casualties have significantly decreased as we've drawn down. It's been over 90 days since two Americans were killed there, precisely because we're no longer in a combat role. The Afghan security services have made considerable sacrifices, stepping up as we've drawn down. They're fighting with courage and tenacity, continually improving. But we can't minimize the sacrifices our military families make. Some will rotate back into Afghanistan for a few extra months. We're essentially adjusting the drawdown pace to compensate for the delayed government formation and to ensure we're effectively assisting Afghan security forces, preventing a need to return due to terrorist activities originating from Afghanistan. We're on track, and as Commander in Chief, I believe providing additional time to assist with logistics, equipment usage, training, advising, and strategic input is a prudent decision. President Ghani, as Commander in Chief, is conducting a thorough review to assess strengths and weaknesses for enhanced joint planning. Our troops and their families make immense sacrifices. This means some who would have returned home will remain in Afghanistan under the revised schedule. However, we've reduced our presence from 100,000 to under 10,000, and they're not on the front lines. Force protection remains a priority. The drawdown completion date remains unchanged. General Campbell and others on the ground believe this additional timeframe to support Afghan security forces is a worthwhile investment. We're asking our troops to fight for our freedom and a more stable world. This raises a point about budgetary considerations. It's an opportune time for Congress to re-evaluate their budgets. Maintaining defense and nondefense budgets at 2006 levels hinders our ability to effectively perform our duties, both in terms of national security and domestic priorities, ensuring our troops have a strong economy, quality education for their children, college access, and the veterans benefits they deserve. That would be a fitting tribute to their sacrifices. President Ghani, your perspective?
label: Implicit

sentence: Regarding the suspension of the West Bank annexation, Mr. President, could you provide any insight into the expected duration? [SEP] Well, what are your thoughts? I'm curious. We are, of course, focusing all efforts on achieving a lasting peace. Our agreement with the Emirates is paramount. We are working diligently to finalize all aspects – diplomatic missions, air travel, trade – and then extend that model to the broader region. As for the specific timeframe, I cannot provide a definitive answer. However, we have placed peace above the question of sovereignty, though it remains a consideration. It is simply being postponed to allow peace every opportunity to succeed.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, Blair apologized for Iraq if he was wrong. Any regrets on your end? Should Afghanistan have been the main focus? Prime Minister, is the Lisbon Treaty finished, and what's the plan for Europe now? [SEP] History'll sort out the details, like troop numbers and where they were. Gettin' rid of Saddam was the right call for our safety, for peace, and for the Iraqi people. Now, it's about helpin' Iraq build a democracy, not just a copy of ours, but a government that listens to its people. Was it worth it? Absolutely, in this fight we're in, with Afghanistan and Iraq as the big battlegrounds. A free Iraq makes dealin' with Iran easier and gives hope to folks in the Middle East who want change. We gotta pick freedom over just keepin' things quiet. Look at Zimbabwe, shows you government matters. Freedom changed Europe and Asia. You think it can change the Middle East? Some folks don't think everyone can handle freedom, sayin' only Westerners can run things. I don't buy that. Freedom can bring peace, 'less we give up and hide. I'm sure gettin' rid of Saddam was right. Everyone wants freedom, and Iraq's a democracy 'cause of what we did. Gotta make sure Iraqis have a reason to care about their country. About Europe, I'm meetin' with Ireland's leader. Everyone in Europe has to sign the treaty. They all get to decide how they do it. We're gonna talk about it in the House of Lords this week. Ireland needs some time to figure things out and tell us what they're gonna do. Everyone in Europe thinks Ireland should get that time, that's what David Miliband will tell you.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, could you define the precise objective of your strategy regarding ISIS: is it eradication, containment, or simply a tactical retreat? [SEP] Our overarching objective is to ensure that ISIL no longer constitutes a persistent threat to regional stability. This is an achievable goal, albeit one that will require sustained effort and time. As demonstrated by the example of Al Qaeda, residual elements invariably retain the capacity to inflict harm, a consequence inherent to the nature of terrorist operations. A small number of individuals can perpetrate acts of terror. However, we are capable of significantly degrading ISIL's systemic and widespread aggression, which terrorizes Muslims, Kurds, Iraqis, and other populations throughout the region, to the point where it no longer exerts the dominant influence it has wielded in recent months.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, considering the rising coronavirus cases in the U.K. compared to several Schengen countries, why was the U.K. granted an exemption from the travel ban? And given the recent increase in cases there, are you now considering adding the U.K. to the restricted list? [SEP] Well, the decision was based on recommendations from our medical professionals, and we are constantly reevaluating the situation as new data emerges. The U.K.'s numbers have indeed seen a concerning uptick, so we are actively considering including them on the list. We might even look at removing some countries as well, depending on how things develop.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding the alleged incident, can you confirm the identity of the individual involved and the nature of the weapon used? [SEP] Unfortunately, those details remain unclear to me at this time.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. And my follow-up—my second question; it's a little bit different topic, but it's one that a lot of people are talking about. Ghislaine Maxwell is in prison, and so a lot of people want to know if she's going to turn in powerful people. And I know you've talked in the past about Prince Andrew, and you've criticized Bill Clinton's behavior. I'm wondering, do you feel that she's going to turn in powerful men? How do you see that working out? [SEP] I don't know. I haven't really been following it too much. I just wish her well, frankly. I've met her numerous times over the years, especially since I lived in Palm Beach, and I guess they lived in Palm Beach. But I wish her well, whatever it is. I don't know the situation with Prince Andrew. I just don't know. I'm not aware of it.Yes, please. Go ahead.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Was the perpetrator male or female? What kind of weapon was used in the attack? [SEP] Those details are still under investigation. I don't have that information at this time.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, do you anticipate a resolution to this conflict before you leave office? Furthermore, what are your thoughts on Israel's conduct? [SEP] The objective is a durable cease-fire. This entails Hamas ceasing its rocket attacks on Israel. If they persist, a sustainable cease-fire becomes unfeasible. The choice lies with Hamas. We are collaborating with Egypt to stem the influx of arms into Gaza, which empowers Hamas's attacks. Nations providing weapons to Hamas must cease, and the international community must exert pressure. Hamas must disarm. Countries bordering Gaza must curb smuggling. This is a formidable task, given the presence of tunnels and the opportunities for those seeking to undermine democracy to supply weapons. Remind me again of the second part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, you've spoken extensively about unifying the country, a key promise from your campaign. Yet, your actions and rhetoric often seem to deepen existing divisions. How do you reconcile these seemingly contradictory approaches? [SEP] Look, unifying the country is a process, not an event. It requires consistent effort and a willingness to engage with diverse perspectives. As long as I am in office, I will keep striving to bring people together and find common ground.
label: General

sentence: President Bush, in your assessment, what are the most critical actions Africa needs to undertake to improve its prospects, what qualities of leadership do you hope to see develop, and how will the U.S. support this progress? Furthermore, what do you hope to accomplish on this five-nation tour, and how will you ensure that your initiatives continue after your presidency? [SEP] I'm here in Africa because it's important. We need to help them with health, trade, and education. Africa's doing better, thanks to its leaders. We've helped with peace and democracy. We expect good governance in return for our aid. I believe in these leaders, and I'm happy to be here.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Following reports from international organizations, shouldn't there be accountability for the events that have transpired? [SEP] The global community is observing the situation closely. The ian government must realize that how it manages the internal dissent, stemming from the ian people, will shape 's future and its international standing. Speaking of , I believe Nico Pitney from the Huffington Post is present.
label: General

sentence: Q. Could you please clarify the specific actions your administration is undertaking to guarantee a transparent and impartial election process? [SEP] Excuse me, could you say that again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Is this considered a threat against you, Mr. President? [SEP] It's too early to say definitively. We're awaiting further information from the authorities.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Seattle's City Council's decision to defund their police department, resulting in Chief Carmen Best's resignation, what implications do you believe this has for the nation, and what are your thoughts on the 'defund the police' movement? [SEP] Look, Seattle's situation is a mess, plain and simple. They let Antifa run wild and now they're surprised when things fall apart? The police chief, a very capable woman, was basically forced out. They slashed the police budget, making it impossible for them to do their jobs. It's a disgrace. And now they'll see the consequences. Crime will rise, and people will get hurt. It's a tragic error, a disaster waiting to happen. Portland's in the same boat, clueless. They'll be begging for our help soon enough. We know how to fix these problems, very quickly.
label: Implicit

sentence: You've asserted that mail-in voting is an invitation to fraud. Can you offer documented instances of significant fraud arising from mail-in ballots in Nevada or other states? [SEP] The news outlets, even the ones you wouldn't expect, have covered it. The evidence is out there. Do your research.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning voting access, are you worried about the ease with which citizens can exercise their right to vote? [SEP] Look, I'm hearing good things, very good things, about how things are running in Georgia. Tremendous efficiency, people are saying. But these are state issues, frankly. You really need to talk to the governors about that. It's their call, not mine.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Biden, regarding the recent announcement of accepting citizens from Venezuela, Haiti, Cuba, and Nicaragua, what is the specific timeline for this process? Are there plans to increase the number of individuals accepted or include additional countries in this initiative? Furthermore, what is the total investment in technological upgrades within the United States? President López Obrador, how will Mexico prepare to accommodate the migrants being expelled from the United States? Could you elaborate on the purpose and function of the new migration center in southern Mexico? Following this summit, can we expect significant changes in migration policies and the treatment of migrants? Finally, President Biden, concerning fentanyl, what concrete steps will be taken to combat its production and distribution? What impact has the detention of Ovidio Guzmán had on the Cartel of the Pacific, a major fentanyl producer? Also, did the energy sector consultations under the USMCA/T-MEC agreement come up during discussions with Prime Minister Trudeau? [SEP] Well, we're working closely with Mexico and Canada on migration. It's a complex issue, and we need a regional solution. We're providing humanitarian assistance and working to address the root causes of migration. As for fentanyl, we're cracking down on drug trafficking and working with our partners to stop the flow of this deadly drug. We're committed to securing our border and protecting our communities.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. As far as your Cabinet goes, do you think you'll see more turnover in your Cabinet? [SEP] Well, I don't know. I think for next year—I mean, generally speaking, a lot of times I understand when, if we win, a President will ask for the resignation of everybody and then bring back the people he wants. That's happened before, Steve. And I could see something like that happening. I think that makes sense.No, I have a very good Cabinet—I mean, with few exception. I wouldn't say I'm thrilled with everybody, frankly. []. But I have—overall, I think we have a very good Cabinet.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, following up on the Prime Minister's comments regarding Palestinian statehood, what tangible steps could he take to regain your confidence as a reliable partner in the peace process? Also, could you comment on the alleged spying by Israel during the Iran nuclear negotiations? And President Ghani, what specific reasons make you optimistic about engaging in reconciliation talks with the Taliban, and what role, if any, do you envision for the U.S. in facilitating these discussions? [SEP] On the matter of alleged espionage, I maintain a consistent policy of not commenting on intelligence matters in such a public forum. Regarding the possibility of a nuclear agreement with Iran, we have diligently briefed Congress, the Israelis, and other global partners on the progress. Should an agreement be reached that effectively prevents Iran from obtaining a nuclear weapon, its details will be fully transparent and open for public scrutiny. I am confident that any such agreement will be beneficial for American, Israeli, and regional security. Conversely, if the terms are unsatisfactory, no agreement will be made. Concerning Israel's relationship with the Palestinians, the crux of the issue lies in the perceptions of both the Palestinians and the Israeli people regarding what is achievable. Prior to the election, Prime Minister Netanyahu stated that a Palestinian state would not be established during his tenure. While he later suggested conditions under which it might be possible, these conditions appear unlikely to be met in the near future. The fundamental question is whether a process and framework can be established to provide Palestinians with hope for a secure state alongside Israel. This is not about creating a Palestinian state overnight, but about creating a process that gives hope. Given the Prime Minister's statements, this seems difficult to envision. My current evaluation pertains specifically to the future of Israeli-Palestinian relations and does not affect our unwavering commitment to Israel's security. It is imperative that we evaluate the situation honestly and avoid basing our public diplomacy on unrealistic expectations. This is not a personal matter between Prime Minister Netanyahu and myself; it is a substantive policy difference with far-reaching implications for both countries and the region.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering the concerns about the national debt, what specific spending cuts or revenue increases are you willing to consider to offset the cost of this stimulus package and ensure long-term fiscal sustainability? [SEP] We need to have a serious conversation about our long-term fiscal challenges. We're willing to look at a range of options, including spending cuts and revenue increases. But we need to do it in a way that doesn't harm the economy or hurt working families. We're committed to finding a balanced approach that addresses our fiscal challenges while also investing in the things that will help us grow the economy and create jobs.
label: Implicit

sentence: Given your previous assertion that the policy would be implemented immediately, might you consider a brief delay? [SEP] I understand the urgency, but I cannot set a precedent of responding to questions based on who shouts the loudest. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: To be clear, does your previous statement encompass the ongoing conflict in Syria? [SEP] I'm not going to comment on it, one way or the other.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, with your meeting with President Hollande this week to ramp up efforts against ISIL, have you observed any shift in Russia's military focus in Syria towards targeting ISIL? Under what circumstances, even temporarily, would you consider President Assad remaining in power if it facilitated a broader alliance against ISIL? Given your stance against working with Russia if their aim is to prop up Assad, is defeating ISIL a realistic objective? [SEP] First, let me assure you, destroying ISIL is not just realistic; it's our unwavering goal. We will achieve it using every facet of American power and in concert with our coalition partners. It will be accomplished. It would certainly be beneficial if Russia redirected its efforts towards ISIL. Following ISIL's claim of responsibility for the downing of their plane, I believe President Putin is increasingly aware of the significant threat ISIL poses to Russia. The critical question is whether they can strategically align themselves to effectively partner with us and the other 65 nations in the counter-ISIL campaign. This remains uncertain. Initially, their strikes in Syria primarily targeted the moderate opposition, perceived as a threat to Assad, with the apparent goal of bolstering the Assad regime. This does not aid our efforts against ISIL; in some respects, it strengthens them, as ISIL is also combating many of the groups targeted by Russia. During our discussions in Turkey, I emphasized to President Putin the necessity of targeting those responsible for the deaths of Russian citizens, which were not the groups they were currently attacking. They must adjust their priorities. More broadly, as I stated to President Putin previously, the issue with Assad extends beyond human rights concerns. It is practically inconceivable that Assad can regain legitimacy in a country where a significant majority despises him and will continue fighting as long as he remains in power, perpetuating the civil war. Therefore, the objective in Vienna is to facilitate a political transition process, involving all relevant nations, including Saudi Arabia, Turkey, Iran, and Russia, to establish a new government, quell the fighting, and enable us to refocus on combating this barbaric organization. While Russia has not explicitly committed to Assad's removal, they have agreed to the political transition process. We will ascertain in the coming weeks whether we can shift Russia's perspective. It is crucial to maintain a Syrian state to prevent complete chaos, as seen in other regions. The international community and the United Nations must collaborate to preserve a Syrian state and facilitate an orderly political transition. This will be challenging, but it is our focus. The United States and its coalition partners maintain that Assad's continued rule is untenable. We cannot halt the fighting. Even if our sole priority were ISIL, the United States could not suppress the opposition to Assad's rule. This is a practical issue, not merely a matter of conscience. Many members of our coalition, including President Hollande, share this view.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, building on that, if no ultimatums were explicitly stated concerning ransomware, what specific leverage does the U.S. have to ensure cooperation, and what metrics will indicate genuine progress in these cybersecurity initiatives? [SEP] The leverage is mutual self-preservation, plain and simple. Nobody wants their critical infrastructure held hostage. As for metrics, we're looking for concrete actions: arrests, prosecutions, dismantling of ransomware networks. Words are cheap; we need to see results on the ground. We're talking about verifiable, measurable outcomes, not just promises.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, can you point to any concrete examples that prove the mail-in ballots in Nevada and other States will lead to widespread fraud? [SEP] The evidence is all over the place. I mean, you just have to look. Even the liberal media is starting to admit it. They’re not going to tell you the whole story, but they’re starting to admit it. And you see what’s happening in Nevada. They don’t even check the signatures. It’s crazy. It’s totally crazy.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. On Aleppo, your views that what happens there is the responsibility of the Russian Government, the Iranian Government, the Asad regime have been pretty well aired. But do you, as President of the United States, leader of the free world, feel any personal, moral responsibility now at the end of your Presidency for the carnage that we're all watching in Aleppo, which I'm sure disturbs you, which you said disturbs you?Secondly, also on Aleppo, you've again made clear your practical disagreements with the idea of safe zones. And President-elect Trump has, throughout his campaign—and he said again last night—that he wants to create safe zones in Syria. Do you feel like, in this transition, you need to help him toward implementing that? Or was that not something that you should be doing? [SEP] Good. Mike, I always feel responsible. I've felt responsible when kids were being shot by snipers. I felt responsible when millions of people had been displaced. I feel responsible for murder and s that's taken place in South Sudan that's not being reported on partly because there's not as much social media being generated from there.There are places around the world where horrible things are happening, and because of my office, because I'm President of the United States, I feel responsible. I ask myself every single day, is there something I could do that would save lives and make a difference and spare some child who doesn't deserve to suffer. So that's a starting point. There's not a moment during the course of this Presidency where I haven't felt some responsibility. That's true, by the way, for our own country. When I came into office and people were losing their jobs and losing their homes and losing their pensions, I felt responsible, and I would go home at night, and I would ask myself, was there something better that I could do or smarter that I could be that would make a difference in their lives, that would relieve their suffering and relieve their hardship?So, with respect to Syria, what I have consistently done is taken the best course that I can to try to end the civil war while having also to take into account the long-term national security interests of the United States.And throughout this process, based on hours of meetings—if you tallied it up, days or weeks of meetings where we went through every option in painful detail, with maps, and we had our military, and we had our aid agencies, and we had our diplomatic teams, and sometimes, we'd bring in outsiders who were critics of ours—whenever we went through it, the challenge was that, short of putting large numbers of U.S. troops on the ground, uninvited, without any international law mandate, without sufficient support from Congress, at a time when we still had troops in Afghanistan and we still had troops in Iraq and we had just gone through over a decade of war and spent trillions of dollars, and when the opposition on the ground was not cohesive enough to necessarily govern a country, and you had a military superpower in Russia prepared to do whatever it took to keep its client state involved, and you had a regional military power in Iran that saw their own vital strategic interests at stake and were willing to send in as many of their people or proxies to support the regime—that in that circumstance, unless we were all in and willing to take over Syria, we were going to have problems, and that everything else was tempting because we wanted to do something and it sounded like the right thing to do, but it was going to be impossible to do this on the cheap.And in that circumstance, I have to make a decision as President of the United States as to what is best——[] . I'm sorry, what's going on?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, what is your response to the disrespectful treatment of Saddam Hussein after his execution, and when can we expect a detailed outline of your Iraq policy? [SEP] I'm not going to give you a date for the announcement. As for the first question, I want you to focus on the upcoming speech. I want you to think about it, internalize it.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, with Russia claiming to reduce military activity around Kyiv, do you believe this signals a de-escalation, or a strategic repositioning? [SEP] We'll have to wait and see. I'm not reading too much into it until we observe concrete actions. We'll see if they follow through on their stated intentions. Negotiations are underway, both in Turkey and other locations. I recently consulted with the heads of state of key NATO allies: France, Germany, and the United Kingdom. The consensus is to observe their proposals carefully and assess their actions. In the interim, we will maintain stringent sanctions, continue to bolster the Ukrainian military's defensive capabilities, and maintain vigilant observation of the evolving situation. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, are you giving any consideration—or did you give any consideration to the Governor and mayor's request not to come to Kenosha tomorrow? [SEP] No, because Kenosha was something we did a good job on. The Governor didn't want us there. He didn't want the National Guard, as you know. He was very reluctant. But I give him credit because, ultimately, he said yes. And as soon as he said yes, the problem ended.But I have to see the people that did such a good job for me. And we're meeting with numerous people. And we have tremendous support in the State of Wisconsin. So I promised them, when it all gets taken care of, we'll go.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. I'm wondering, basically, what is your reaction to that? Do you think that is that something that America—that the next President needs to worry about? [SEP] I strongly disagree with the assessment that our moral standing has been damaged. It may be damaged amongst some of the elite, but people still understand America stands for freedom, that America is a country that provides such great hope.You go to Africa, you ask Africans about Americans' generosity and compassion; go to India, and ask about, you know, America's—their view of America; go to China and ask. Now, if—no question, parts of Europe have said that we shouldn't have gone to war in Iraq without a mandate, but those are a few countries. Most countries in Europe listened to what 1441 said, which is disclose, disarm, or face serious consequences.Most people take those words seriously. Now, some countries didn't, and even though they might have voted for the resolution. I disagree with this assessment that, you know, people view America in a dim light. I just don't agree with that. Now, I understand that Gitmo has created controversies. But when it came time for those countries that were criticizing America to take some of those detainees, they weren't willing to help out. And so, you know, I just disagree with the assessment, Mike.I'll remind—listen, I tell people, yes, you can try to be popular. In certain quarters in Europe, you can be popular by blaming every Middle Eastern problem on Israel, or you can be popular by joining the International Criminal Court. I guess I could have been popular by accepting Kyoto, which I felt was a flawed treaty, and proposed something different and more constructive.And in terms of the decisions that I had made to protect the homeland, I wouldn't worry about popularity. What I would worry about is the Constitution of the United States and putting plans in place that makes it easier to find out what the enemy is thinking, because all these debates will matter not if there's another attack on the homeland. The question won't be, you know, were you critical of this plan or not. The question is going to be, why didn't you do something?Do you remember what it was like right after September the 11th around here? In press conferences and opinion pieces and in stories—that sometimes were news stories and sometimes opinion pieces—people were saying, How come they didn't see it? How come they didn't connect the dots? Do you remember what the environment was like in Washington? I do. When people were hauled up in front of Congress, and Members of Congress were asking questions about, How come you didn't know this, that, or the other? And then we start putting policy in place—legal policy in place—to connect the dots, and all of a sudden people were saying, How come you're connecting the dots?And so, Mike, I've heard all that. I've heard all that. My view is, is that most people around the world, they respect America. And some of them doesn't like me, I understand that, some of the writers and the, you know, opiners and all that. That's fine; that's part of the deal. But I'm more concerned about the country and our—how people view the United States. They view us as strong, compassionate people who care deeply about the universality of freedom.Roger [Roger Runningen, Bloomberg News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, given your emphasis on state sovereignty, how do you reconcile that with the concept of 'responsibility to protect' that was so prevalent previously? [SEP] I'm sorry, could you repeat the latter part of your question regarding the responsibility to protect? I want to make sure I understand it correctly.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with all due respect, the American public is still confused about the Snowden affair. Mr. Ledgett's comments on amnesty have only added to the confusion. Can you give us a straight answer: Is there any scenario, any at all, where your administration would consider a plea agreement or amnesty for Edward Snowden, and what message would that send to other potential leakers? [SEP] Look, I understand the public's concern, and I appreciate the question. But I can't get into hypotheticals. Mr. Snowden's case is in the hands of the Justice Department. What I will say is this: We're constantly reviewing our intelligence policies to ensure they strike the right balance between security and freedom. The way Mr. Snowden went about it was wrong. It damaged our intelligence capabilities and gave cover to regimes that don't share our values. But the conversation about surveillance is one we needed to have. So, we're trying to learn from this experience and move forward in a responsible way.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Besides the stimulus checks, what can you offer to those who are struggling financially? [SEP] The best thing we can do is make the tax cuts permanent. There's a lot of economic uncertainty. And therefore, one way to deal with uncertainty is for Congress to make the tax cuts permanent.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, to ensure the US meets its deficit reduction goals, what immediate actions can your administration take to inspire confidence? [SEP] Pardon me? Could you articulate your question again? I didn't quite catch that.
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Mr. President, veteran journalist Robert Novak has suggested you're more isolated than any president he's seen, even Nixon during Watergate. What's your reaction to Novak's assessment? [SEP] What metrics is Novak using to define isolation, exactly?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Putin seems pleased with your answer concerning the 'killer' comment. Could you provide your side of the story? [SEP] Putin's happy. What more do you want me to say?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, what's your reaction to Biden and Harris kicking off their campaign right before your speech? [SEP] I barely watched. A few seconds was enough. He picked her, and that's his problem. She was nasty to him, said awful things. Now she's suddenly his biggest fan? It's a joke. She wants to raise taxes, destroy the energy industry – good luck with that in Texas and Pennsylvania! And she's soft on crime. Law enforcement supports me, not them. We've got the strongest military ever, thanks to me. Biden's pick was a disaster. She's a loser. She attacked him more than I ever did. Can you believe it?
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. I'm wondering—the debate is coming up this week. Do you anticipate Joe Biden being held to task? And will he be able to answer those questions at the debate? [SEP] I don't know. I mean, we're going to find out, because a lot things are going to come up in the debate. That may be one. I mean, the son didn't have a job. He had some big difficulties. And then, all of the sudden, he's making millions of dollars as soon as his father becomes Vice President. No, I think that'll come up. I don't think Joe can answer it, frankly. I think there's only one reason he made all that money.And then, you have to say: What about Joe's involvement? And why did Joe not give the billion dollars over to Ukraine, as an example, until such time as they let go of a Prosecutor that was investigating the company that his son was involved with?I mean, there are some bad questions. I don't think they have answers. And if we had a media that was fair—even just reasonable—this would be the biggest story for years and years and years. Then, you'd really be entitled to real Pulitzer Prizes, not the fake committee that gives you these fake awards.So, I mean, it's a really fair question. But it's hard to believe, when you see the kind of money that he has made from China, from Russia, where the wife of the mayor of Moscow gives him $3½ million and nobody even has any question about it.Why did he get $3½ million? I'll tell you why: Because Joe Biden was in on it. Joe was in on it. There's no way that he wasn't. And uses Joe Biden's plane—Air Force Two. Uses Joe—and they go to China, and then he comes back, and he never mentioned it to his father that he just got a billion and a half dollars?And now it's turning out that it's much more money than that, Rudy. It's true. . It's turned out to be much more money from China. They have—a member of the Chinese Communist Party gave him a lot of money. And the press has no interest in these stories. It's just—it's very disheartening for the people of our country.Please.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. America is Back was your motto at the first NATO summit last year. And you've come to this summit here and the one in Germany after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned constitutional protections for abortion, after the shootings in Buffalo and Texas, at a time of record inflation, and as new polling this week shows that 85 percent of the U.S. public thinks the country is going in the wrong direction.How do you explain this to those people who feel the country is going in the wrong direction, including some of the leaders you've been meeting with this week, who think that when you put all of this together, it amounts to an America that is going backward? [SEP] They do not think that. You haven't found one person, one world leader to say America is going backwards. America is better positioned to lead the world than we ever have been. We have the strongest economy in the world. Our inflation rates are lower than other nations in the world. The one thing that has been destabilizing is the outrageous behavior of the Supreme Court of the United States on overruling not only v. , but essentially challenging the right to privacy.We've been a leader in the world in terms of personal rights and privacy rights, and it is a mistake, in my view, for the Supreme Court to do what it did.But I have not seen anyone come up to me and do anything other than—nor have you heard them say anything other than: Thank you for America's leadership. You've changed the dynamic of NATO and the G-7.So I can understand why the American people are frustrated because of what the Supreme Court did. I can understand why the American people are frustrated because of inflation. But inflation is higher in almost every other country. Prices at the pump are higher in almost every other country. We're better positioned to deal with this than anyone, but we have a way to go.And the Supreme Court—we have to change that decision by codifying v. .
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, what's your strategy for reaching out to voters who feel disconnected from the Democratic Party's message? [SEP] The answer is simple: show up. We need to be in those communities, demonstrating the positive impact of Democratic policies. People need to know they're being heard, not written off as coastal elites. That's how I won. I didn't just focus on Chicago; I traveled across Illinois, connected with farmers, spoke to working families. We have the stronger argument, but it demands consistent effort. I've done it successfully in my own campaigns, but it's challenging to replicate that for other candidates, especially during midterms. I wish I could have done more to create a sustainable organization, but it's difficult when you're also managing the White House. However, I'm optimistic that talented progressives will take the lead in the future.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding North Korea's commitment to denuclearization, what specific mechanisms are in place to ensure verifiable progress and prevent them from reverting to past patterns of deception? [SEP] Can anyone truly guarantee anything? No. However, I possess a strong sense for these matters. My entire career has been predicated on successful deal-making. This opportunity should have been pursued long ago. They desire a resolution, which benefits the global community, including China. We'll ascertain their sincerity as negotiations progress.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, given your views on firearms, how do you justify commuting sentences for individuals convicted of gun-related crimes? [SEP] I consider all aspects of the case before making a decision.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, you mentioned your belief that the North Korean crisis will resolve itself. Can you point to any concrete achievements of your diplomatic efforts thus far? And do you still consider direct dialogue a fruitless endeavor? [SEP] Look, I'm not one to broadcast the specifics of ongoing negotiations, especially when dealing with sensitive matters like this. We prefer to keep our strategy under wraps. However, I firmly believe that North Korea should act responsibly, not just for their own sake, but for the benefit of the entire world. There are compelling reasons for them to do so. I see positive developments, yes. We are projecting strength. They know we possess unparalleled power. We've deployed three of the world's largest aircraft carriers, strategically positioned. We also have a nuclear submarine in place. We are taking numerous steps, hoping—praying, even—that we won't have to resort to using them. That being said, I truly believe it's in North Korea's best interest to come to the table and forge an agreement that benefits both their people and the global community. I perceive some progress, but let's wait and see.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Okay, Mr. President, one quick follow-up. Considering Governor Ron DeSantis's impressive victory in Florida, who do you perceive as the more formidable competitor: Ron DeSantis or former President Trump? And how does that influence your decision-making process? [SEP] Well, let them duke it out. [Next question, please.]
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with the House vote on Iraq looming, and your Press Secretary's warnings about the message Congress sends to our adversaries, do you believe a vote against your policy empowers the enemy and hinders your efforts? Furthermore, what steps are you taking to dissuade Democratic leaders from restricting funds for Iraq? [SEP] Well, let's be clear. Congress has the right to voice its opinion, and I'm fully aware of the Democratic stance, and even some Republicans. They disagreed with my initial decision. That doesn't mean they're not patriotic citizens, just that they hold a different view. I considered their perspectives but concluded they wouldn't lead to a self-governing, self-sustaining nation and a strong ally against terror. However, I hope this non-binding resolution doesn't morph into a binding policy that ties the hands of our troops. It's contradictory to unanimously support General Petraeus and then deny funding for the strategy he deemed necessary, as he testified before the Senate. I'm making it clear to Congress, right now, that they must fund our troops and provide the flexibility needed to succeed. It's also interesting to see a declaration against a plan before it's even had a chance to work. Again, I understand. Now, remind me of the other part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, The New Yorker's report alleges the Red Cross found the CIA's interrogation program amounted to torture. Have you read it, and what's your reaction? Also, a year ago you pledged to close Guantanamo, yet little has changed, reportedly due to resistance from your VP, AG, and Homeland Security Secretary. Who's truly in charge? Will Guantanamo be open or closed when you leave office? [SEP] Guantanamo is a national goal to shut down, but some nations won't take back detainees. The Senate overwhelmingly opposes bringing them here. So, practically, where do they go? You say nothing's happened? We're working with nations to repatriate people, but many are killers. We also want humane treatment upon return. We're also working to get trials running. Courts and Defense are working on it. I can't predict Guantanamo's fate. It's complicated, as the Senate vote shows. As for the Red Cross report, I'll have to look into that. And your other question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. With your term ending, Mr. President, who possesses the authority to finalize this agreement? [SEP] The negotiators present are fully empowered. While I may not be here for the final signing, they have the mandate to proceed, given the extensive progress already made on the text.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, is it accurate that your administration is actively urging the NIH and FDA to accelerate the rollout of this? [SEP] The reports I'm getting are very positive – above 50 percent, which is great. We've also got some things approved at 31 percent, which is not bad at all. It's having a real impact. But the part about the White House pushing this – that's not something I'm aware of. I'll have to check on that.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: With the Speaker facing internal challenges, are you confident in his ability to secure the necessary votes for any agreements reached? [SEP] That's really a question for the Speaker himself. My interactions with John Boehner have been positive. I believe he's a good person who wants what's best for the country. The political climate that brought him to power is proving difficult for governing. The Republican caucus needs to understand that compromise is essential for American democracy to function.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the Coronavirus death rates, statistics indicate the US has one of the highest per capita death rates globally. How do you account for this discrepancy, given the administration's handling of the pandemic? [SEP] Well, you see, a significant portion of those numbers originated from New York, as you know. New York and New Jersey were particularly hard-hit regions. If you exclude them from the calculation, and consider a state like Florida, for instance, our figures are considerably lower. Not to disparage New York, but it's a densely populated area, quite crowded. However, even with New York factored in, I'll need to verify the precise figures, but we're among the lowest. They've done an exceptional job. Next question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. ----but shouldn't the Iranian regime know that there are consequences? [SEP] I answered the question, Chuck, which is that we don't yet know how this is going to play out. Okay?Jake Tapper [ABC News].
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. You don't think the sell-off had to do with the coronavirus—[inaudible]? [SEP] Oh, I think it did. I think it did. But I think you can add quite a bit of sell-off to what they're seeing. Because they're seeing the potential. You know, again, I think we're going to win. I feel very confident of it. We've done everything and much more than I said we were going to do.You look at what we've done. What we've done is incredible, with the tax cuts and regulation cuts and rebuilding our military, taking care of vets and getting them choice and accountability. All of the things we've done—protecting our Second Amendment. I mean, they view that—the Second Amendment, they're going to destroy the Second Amendment.When people look at that, they say, This is not good. So you add that in. I really believe that's a factor. But no, this is—what we're talking about is the virus. That's what we're talking about. But I do believe that's—I do believe—in terms of CNBC and in terms of Fox Business, I do believe that that's a factor. Yes. And I think after I win the election, I think the stock market is going to boom like it's never boomed before—just like it did, by the way, after I won the last election. The stock market, the day after, went up like a rocket ship.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, after your meeting with President Putin in Geneva, you stated he didn't want a cold war. Given the troop buildup near Ukraine, cyber attacks, and demands for a sphere of influence, do you still believe that? Has your view of him changed, and if he invades, would you consider a containment policy? [SEP] I still believe he doesn't desire a full-scale war. However, I believe he will test the West, the United States, and NATO as much as possible. He will pay a heavy price for it, a price he doesn't currently foresee. He will regret it. He views the fall of the Berlin Wall and the loss of the Soviet empire as a tragedy for Russia. He has vast territory, but is trying to find his place between China and the West. I'm unsure if he knows what he'll do. My guess is he will move in. He feels compelled to act. He wants guarantees that Ukraine won't join NATO and that strategic weapons won't be stationed there. We can negotiate the second point, depending on his actions. The first point is more complex, as international treaties allow countries to choose their alliances. However, Ukraine joining NATO in the near term is unlikely. There's room to work if he wants to. But I think, as usual, he's going to—well, I probably shouldn't go any further. But I think it will hurt him badly.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, assuming the drug proves effective, would you push for its accelerated approval within the US regulatory framework? [SEP] Look, I'm not a doctor, and I haven't seen all the evidence. It would be irresponsible of me to comment without a full understanding of the facts. We'll have to wait and see.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, in 2012, you tweeted that Obama's complaints about Republicans stopping his agenda are BS, in your words, since he had full control for 2 years. You wrote, He can never take responsibility. But today you've said about some of the challenges right now in Congress and in Washington, I'm not going to blame myself, I'll be honest. They're not getting the job done. So what's different then than now? [SEP] Well, let me just explain what's different. We have nominations pending right now, and we have 182 approved—if you look at this: the number that he had approved was 65 percent and 70 percent, and we have 39 percent. They're holding up every single nomination.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Jacksonville, some might see your actions as pushing too far, too fast, especially with schools reopening and the baseball season starting. Isn't Jacksonville an example of overreach? [SEP] Well, take baseball, for instance – we were just talking about it. You're looking at an empty stadium. Randy Levine, a great friend from the Yankees, asked me to throw out the first pitch on August 15th at Yankee Stadium. I asked, 'What's the crowd going to be like?' And, you know, there isn't one. It's going to be interesting for Mariano. He's not used to that. I've been to many games where he walks in, and the place goes wild. I think it'd be just as good without the crowd. Some people are just born with it.I don't know if this is just for baseball players, but I've never seen a pitcher break so many bats as Mariano. He's got the all-time record. I asked him how he does it, and he said, 'Parents.' Great parents, when you get right down to it. Right? How do you do that? It's called parents.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, regarding coronavirus prevention, how should Americans prepare? Should they alter their routines? [SEP] Well, I don't think they should change their routines too much. But let me defer to the experts here. Anthony, perhaps you could address that? Or Bob? What are your thoughts?
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, the media is impatient for a bipartisan deal, but this is your third budget. You've said you'd rather be a one-term president if it meant doing the hard things. Why not invite Republicans to negotiate now? If not, how will you build cooperation for bipartisanship? Will the markets wait two years? [SEP] I needed to jot all that down, Jackie. My brain's about to explode.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, have you decided who you will nominate to chair the Federal Reserve Board? And if not, what are your key considerations as you evaluate candidates for Fed Chair and other open seats? Given the timing, are you concerned about a potentially compressed timeline, especially if you don't renominate Jay Powell? [SEP] No, no, and no. I'm not going to discuss it with you. The process is underway. We'll be making announcements soon. It's been in the works for a while, number one. Number two, I believe we'll have ample time to ensure all major nominees are confirmed before their terms expire. And number three, I've given it considerable thought and consulted with my economic advisors on the best choices. We have many qualified candidates. But I'm not going to speculate now.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, are you confident that this legislation will be enacted within the first year of your administration? [SEP] We're aiming to get the ball rolling this year, and I'm pushing as hard as I can. Some say I'm doing too much at once. We're moving full steam ahead on all fronts. Ultimately, I can't control the legislative calendar. We'll be working with the leaders in Congress to see what's possible.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President, to follow up on the filibuster: So do you believe it should take 60 votes to end a filibuster on legislation or 51? [SEP] [] If we could end it with 51, we would have no problem. You're going to have to—the existing rule—it's going to be hard to get a parliamentary ruling that allows 50 votes to end the filibuster, the existence of a filibuster.But it's not my expertise, in what the parliamentary rules and how to get there are. But our preoccupation with the filibuster is totally legitimate, but in the meantime, we've got a lot we can do while we're talking about what we're going to do about the filibuster.Let me get here. Okay, Cecilia Vega [Cecilia Vega, ABC News].
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, about the leaks suggesting the U.S. spied on South Korea – did that come up with President Yoon? Did President Biden give him any promises? [SEP] On that, we're talking to South Korea, sharing what we need to. The U.S. is looking into it, and there's a lot going on. We gotta let the investigation play out. We'll keep talking about it. Last question.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, to reiterate my colleague's point about Russian meddling, can you promise the American people you'll reject any foreign support in the upcoming election? Moreover, regarding the replacement of Acting DNI Maguire with Ambassador Grenell, whose qualifications in intelligence are questionable, how do you rationalize this decision? [SEP] Listen, I've said it before, and I'll say it again: I don't need or want any help from any country. And as for CNN, your network, didn't they have to issue a correction recently? What was the substance of their apology, if you recall?
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, on the matter of immigration, if Congress presents you with an E-Verify bill that lacks a legalization component, will you veto it? And turning to Fast and Furious, with both Congress and Mexico still seeking answers, are you considering changes in ATF leadership? When can we anticipate the results of the investigation? [SEP] In response to the second question, my Attorney General has made it abundantly clear that he would never have sanctioned gun running into Mexico. The investigation remains ongoing, and I will refrain from commenting on it at this time. Upon the investigation's completion, appropriate actions will be taken. With respect to E-Verify, we are in need of comprehensive immigration reform. We must uphold our dual traditions as a nation of laws and immigrants. This demands robust border security, targeting employers who illegally hire and exploit workers, and establishing a pathway to legal status for those currently living in the shadows. While we may not be able to secure everything we would like in a single package, a balanced approach is paramount. E-Verify can serve as a valuable enforcement tool, provided it is accurate and safeguards the rights of U.S. citizens. We must prevent errors that inadvertently harm qualified candidates. Our objective is to refine E-Verify and implement the necessary safeguards. Moreover, we must address the situation of DREAM Act children, who deserve the opportunity to contribute to our nation. A mere verification system is insufficient.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, I'm from Brooklyn, so you'll understand me. The President. Yes. I understand you very well.Health Care Reform  Q. My question is on health care. How is it possible to keep premiums down and cover preexisting conditions without the individual mandate to fund it? [SEP] Well, first of all, what we're doing—and we're—if you look at the Department of Labor also—Secretary separately—Secretary Azar, what they've done. They've come up with some incredible health care plans, which is causing great competition and driving the prices right down.But we are getting rid of the individual mandate, because it was very unfair to a lot of people. But at the same time, we're covering the people that need it. But the individual mandate was a disaster, because people that couldn't necessarily afford it were having to pay for the privilege of not having to pay for health care. And it was bad health care at that.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, the possibility of military action against Iran's nuclear facilities is being openly discussed in Israel. What is your assessment of this debate, and what message do you have for our allies in the region? [SEP] Look, if you were in Israel's shoes, you'd be worried too. You have a country in your neighborhood saying they want to wipe you off the map. Developing a nuclear weapon is a good way to do that. So, we need to work together to stop them. There's a sense of urgency, and I share that urgency. We're hopeful we can get this done diplomatically. And by the way, I think we can get a global climate change agreement too. It's essential.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Sir, are you suggesting the National Health Service is negotiable in a trade deal? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, Iran has indicated a willingness to resume nuclear talks by the end of November. How will you determine whether the Iranians are genuinely committed to these talks? And what measures are you prepared to take against Iran if it persists in carrying out attacks against the United States, such as the recent drone strikes targeting U.S. forces in Syria? [SEP] Well, in a sense, those are two distinct issues. One is whether or not we rejoin the JCPOA. And that depends—that's why I met with my colleagues here in Rome, who are part of the original group of six nations that came together to advocate for negotiating a change, a situation that I believe we are still suffering from due to President Trump's very poor judgment in withdrawing from the JCPOA. So that's one issue. And its resolution will depend on their actions and the willingness of our allies, who are part of the original agreement, to stand with us and ensure that there is an economic price to pay for them if they fail to return. With regard to the issue of how we will respond to actions taken by them against the interests of the United States—whether they are drone strikes or anything else—we will respond, and we will continue to respond. Cecilia Vega, ABC. It's hard to recognize you all with masks on. I apologize. Climate Change/
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. But just to put a fine point on it, are you actively discussing ways to remove him as a part of that political transition? The President. No.Major Garrett [CBS News].Possibility of a Federal Government Shutdown/Immigration Reform/Bipartisanship Q. Thank you, Mr. President. As you well know, the continuing resolution expires on December 11. Many things you've talked about on this trip are related to that: funding for coalition operations in Iraq and Syria, the Ebola outbreak, not to mention day-to-day Government operations. What are the odds the country will see itself in a shutdown scenario? How much do you fear the Government will shut down? And to what degree does your anxiety about this or your team's anxiety about this influence the timing of your decision on immigration and executive action? [SEP] I take Mitch McConnell at his word when he says that the Government is not going to shut down. There is no reason for it to shut down. We traveled down that path before. It was bad for the country, it was bad for every elected official in Washington. And at the end of the day, it was resolved in the same way that it would have been resolved if we hadn't shut the Government down. So that's not going to be productive, and I think that Leader McConnell and Speaker Boehner understand that.But this goes to a broader point that I've made previously and I'll just reiterate: It is in the nature of democracy that the parties are going to disagree on certain issues. And in our system, because we don't have a parliamentary system, it means that you can have a Congress of one party and a President of another, and they disagree on some really fundamental issues. And the question then is, how do you deal with that? Well, the sensible way to deal with it is to say here are the issues we don't agree on, and we'll fight like heck for our position, and then, we'll work together on the issues that we do agree on. And that's how it's always been; that's how it was with Ronald Reagan when he was dealing with a Democratic Congress. There was no—at no point did the Democrats say, well, because we don't agree with Ronald Reagan on XYZ issue, then we can't work with him on Social Security reform or tax reform or other issues. He said, okay, we'll fight on that, we'll join together on that, and as a consequence, the country will make progress.And I would expect that same attitude in this instance. I understand that there are members of the Republican Party who deeply disagree with me and law enforcement and the evangelical community and a number of their own Republican colleagues about the need for immigration reform. I get that. And they've made their views clear, and there's nothing wrong with them arguing their position and opposing legislation. But why they would then decide we're going to shut down the Government makes about as much sense as my decision to shut down the Government if they decide to take a vote to repeal health care reform for the—is it 53d or 55th time? I mean, I understand that there's a difference there, but let's keep on doing the people's business.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, were you made aware of any confirmed COVID-19 cases within the White House today? [SEP] Today, you say?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. So, the deadline for Kosovo's independence is...? I just want to be clear. [SEP] A drop, you say?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. Won't that drive private insurers out of business? [SEP] Well, why would it drive private insurers out of business? If private insurers say that the marketplace provides the best quality health care, if they tell us that they're offering a good deal, then why is it that the Government, which they say can't run anything, suddenly is going to drive them out of business? That's not logical.Now, I think that there's going to be some healthy debates in Congress about the shape that this takes. I think there can be some legitimate concerns on the part of private insurers that if any public plan is simply being subsidized by taxpayers endlessly, that over time they can't compete with the Government just printing money.So there are going to be some, I think, legitimate debates to be had about how this private plan takes shape. But just conceptually, the notion that all these insurance companies who say they're giving consumers the best possible deal, that they can't compete against a public plan as one option, with consumers making the decision what's the best deal, that defies logic, which is why I think you've seen in the polling data overwhelming support for a public plan. All right?
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, while employment numbers may be strong, are there specific policies you're considering to further address economic disparities among different racial and ethnic groups? [SEP] We're working on a lot of things. We're creating opportunity zones, we're investing in education, and we're supporting small businesses. We want to make sure that everyone has a chance to succeed. We're doing more for African Americans and Hispanics than any other president has ever done.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Sir, can you confirm if there were any reported coronavirus infections among White House staff today? [SEP] I'm sorry, I can't make out what you're asking.
label: Clarification
