sentence: Mr. President, regarding Mr. Putin's satisfaction with your explanation about your 'killer' comment, could you elaborate on the specifics of your conversation with him? [SEP] Look, he accepted my response, didn't he? What purpose would be served by rehashing the details? Let's move on.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Will you visit the site? [SEP] I beg your pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given Nigeria's urgent need for the Tucano aircraft to combat internal security threats, could you expedite the release of at least two units before 2020? Furthermore, when might we anticipate a presidential visit to Nigeria? [SEP] I'm sorry, could you repeat the first part of your question? I didn't quite catch it. But Nigeria, beautiful place, I'd love to visit.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, as you reflect on your presidency, what was the biggest surprise or challenge you encountered when you first took office, and did you discuss this with President-elect Trump? [SEP] It took me a while to get comfortable, no doubt about it. This job is one of a kind. It's a constant stream of information and challenges, even more so these days because the world is so interconnected. Events that might have been isolated in the past now have immediate global consequences. The speed of information and the need for quick responses are unprecedented. I shared these insights with the President-elect, emphasizing the importance of having a strong team, especially the Chief of Staff, National Security Advisor, and White House Counsel. You need a good system for gathering information and making decisions. I've been fortunate to have an exceptional team, which has enabled me to make sound choices. I also discussed the importance of unity and representing all Americans, as he mentioned on election night. His initial actions and how he presents himself will be crucial in setting the tone for his presidency. After a divisive election, gestures matter. Reaching out to those who didn't support him and addressing their concerns can help move the country forward.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. So, are we talking about a hard Brexit scenario? [SEP] Are we talking about a broken heart?
label: Clarification

sentence: President, what's your strategy for advancing your pro-life agenda moving forward? [SEP] We're pushing hard, and we've been very successful. People are very happy with what we've accomplished. It's a tough issue, no doubt about it, but we're making progress.
label: General

sentence: Q. With the benefit of hindsight, what aspect are you referring to? [SEP] Can you specify the particular issue you have in mind?
label: Clarification

sentence: So, to reiterate, you believe the NHS should be on the table for negotiation? [SEP] I didn't catch that. Could you repeat it?
label: Clarification

sentence: So, they are not presently the subject of an investigation, sir? [SEP] I have no comment on that, Peter.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Would you and members of Congress be willing to enroll in the same healthcare plan as the general public? [SEP] Look, I'd have no problem with that. But let's be clear, as President, I have access to top-notch medical care, 24/7. This isn't about me; it's about ensuring everyone has access to quality healthcare, which they currently don't. The real issue is fixing the system for all Americans.
label: General

sentence: In light of the recent attempts to connect with Cuba, what's your perspective on Fidel Castro's participation in the talks? Did you mention Fidel during your conversation with Raul Castro? How is he doing? Considering Republican opposition to lifting the embargo, will you personally engage with them to prevent blocking funds for a new Embassy? [SEP] I'm going to have to interrupt you here. This is using up too much time.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, are you concerned that China's economic slowdown could destabilize the global economy or provoke aggressive actions, particularly concerning Taiwan? Separately, what are your thoughts on the Putin-Kim Jong Un meeting and its potential impact on the war in Ukraine? [SEP] Well, China's facing some serious economic headwinds right now, due to a bunch of factors – global growth, their own policies, you name it. I don't think that's going to push them to invade Taiwan. Actually, it might have the opposite effect; they might not have the same resources they used to. But let me be clear: we're not trying to hurt China. We all benefit when China plays by the rules and its economy thrives. They've hit some snags, especially in real estate, and they're figuring out how to deal with it. I'm not going to predict the outcome, but we're not looking to decouple. What we won't do is sell them stuff that helps them build more nukes or engage in aggressive military actions. But we're not trying to undermine them. Next question.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, why have you chosen not to attend the proceedings? [SEP] Look, I'm focused on the real issues facing the American people. Sitting in some courtroom drama, while perhaps entertaining for some, doesn't solve the problems we're tackling every day. I'd rather be out here working for the forgotten men and women of this country.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: President Bush, considering your extensive travels in Africa, what specific, actionable steps do you believe African nations must take to foster sustainable progress, and how will the U.S. tangibly support these efforts beyond mere rhetoric? Furthermore, what concrete deliverables do you anticipate from this tour, and how will you ensure these initiatives endure beyond your presidency? [SEP] Well, thanks. I've been to Africa before, early in my term, to show it's in our interest to fight diseases, promote trade, and fund education. Being in Ghana shows what I mean. Africa's changed since I became President, thanks to African leaders. We've helped resolve conflicts, like in Liberia, and supported democracy. Our aid now demands accountability, like fighting corruption. The leaders I've met are committed to their people. This trip shows that, and I appreciate Ghana's hospitality. John McKinnon from the Wall Street Journal is here, a sophisticated paper, no question.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, regarding the alleged poisoning of Alexei Navalny, what specific measures will the United States implement against Russia, and what message will you convey to President Putin? How should the global community respond? [SEP] It's a very sad situation, and we are investigating the matter. No one has been more firm with Russia than myself. We are also making great progress on other fronts. We are about to secure a historic peace agreement in the Middle East, which no one thought possible. And let's not forget Nord Stream 2; I was the first to warn Germany about its dependence on Russian energy. We are also engaged in critical nuclear non-proliferation discussions with Russia, which are far more important than this global warming hoax. As for Navalny, we need solid proof before drawing conclusions, but we are taking it very seriously. It's awful, simply awful.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. So what do you think? Will you show up at your trial any day, in any way, shape, or form? [SEP] I'd love to go. Wouldn't that be great? Wouldn't that be beautiful?
label: General

sentence: Q. But in terms of criticism that you're, sort of, supporting a dictator instead of an American Vice President? [SEP] Well, when I look at what's been done by our Vice President and the President, when I look at the horrible Iran deal that they made, look what happened since I terminated the Iran deal. Look what has happened to Iran.Iran, when I first came into office, was a terror. They were fighting in many locations all over the Middle East. They were behind every single major attack, whether it was Syria, whether it was Yemen, whether it was individual, smaller areas, whether it was taking away oil from people. They were involved with everything.Now they're pulling back, because they're got serious economic problems. We have massive—as you know, massive sanctions and other things. I mean, we just said the other day: steel, copper, different elements of what they used to sell. The oil is essentially dried up. And I'm not looking that—to hurt Iran at all. I'm looking to have Iran say, No nuclear weapons. We have enough problems in this world right now with nuclear weapons. No nuclear weapons for Iran.And I think we'll make a deal. I think Iran—again, I think Iran has tremendous economic potential. And I look forward to letting them get back to the stage where they can show that. I think Iran—I know so many people from Iran. These are great people. It has a chance to be a great country, with the same leadership. We're not looking for regime change. I just want to make that clear. We're looking for no nuclear weapons.If you look at the deal that Biden and President Obama signed, they would have access—free access—to nuclear weapons, where they wouldn't even be in violation, in just a very short period of time. What kind of a deal is that?So we can't have that. Plus, there were many other things they did that were very bad. So I don't take sides as to who I'm in favor or who I'm not, but I can tell you that Joe Biden was a disaster. His administration, with President Obama, they were basically a disaster when it came to so many things, whether it was economy, whether it was military, defense. No matter what it was, they had a lot problems. So I'm not a fan.
label: Deflection

sentence: Given that you've labeled Iran as part of the axis of evil and Syria as a state sponsor of terrorism, and considering your statement that your administration will consider any proposal that helps us achieve victory, would you be willing to collaborate with Iran and Syria if it were determined that they could contribute to success in Iraq? [SEP] It is clear that the world expects Iran and Syria to assist Iraq. We've communicated this expectation clearly to them. Regarding Iran, we have multiple concerns. Firstly, will they support the success of Iraq's nascent democracy? Secondly, will they support Lebanon's democracy, specifically the Siniora Government, which is a priority for this administration? The most pressing issue is Iran's potential acquisition of nuclear weapons. Our concerns regarding Iran are numerous. Our position is clear: isolation is not the path forward for the Iranian government and people. We will continue to emphasize that their support for terrorism will lead to further isolation. We are actively engaged in diplomatic efforts. The Iranians are aware of our position on Iraq, and more importantly, they are aware of the Iraqis' position. We are supporting a sovereign government. The Iraqis have conveyed to the Iranians: help us succeed by not interfering in our internal affairs. As for Syria, our message remains consistent: do not undermine the Siniora Government in Lebanon; assist Israel in recovering the prisoner captured by Hamas; prevent Hamas and Hizballah from plotting attacks against democracies in the Middle East; and provide assistance within Iraq. They are also aware of our position, Jessica.
label: General

sentence: Given the current situation at the border, what specific percentage of asylum seekers do you deem legitimate? [SEP] I'm not going to put a number on it. What I will say is this: we're a nation of laws, and we need to enforce our borders. The situation is a mess, thanks to these ridiculous catch-and-release policies. We're sending the National Guard down there, but Congress needs to act. We need a wall, and we need it now. People are pouring into our country, and it's a disaster. We need to change the laws, and we need to do it fast.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, acknowledging the media's eagerness for a resolution, this marks your third budget. You've expressed willingness to serve only one term if it means making the tough choices. Why not invite Republicans to the negotiating table today? Furthermore, what steps are you taking to cultivate the spirit of cooperation you mentioned? And do you believe the markets will remain patient for two years? [SEP] That's quite a question, Jackie. I'm running out of brainpower here.
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding ISIS, many suggest a containment strategy. Do you agree with this approach, or do you believe complete annihilation is the only acceptable outcome? Given the limitations of airstrikes, what role do you see for ground forces, specifically the Free Syrian Army, in eradicating ISIS in Syria? [SEP] With an organization causing such widespread destruction, containment is not an option. We must dismantle them. Look at Al Qaeda in the FATA: we pushed them back, degraded their capabilities, shrunk their territory, and eliminated their leadership. Over time, their ability to conduct major attacks diminished. Will remnants remain? Of course. We'll hunt them down, just as we do with Al Qaeda or al-Shabaab. But our goal is to dismantle this network so they can't threaten us. I'm pleased our allies agree. Regarding Syria, we won't deploy U.S. troops to control conflict zones. It's not necessary. We need effective partners on the ground to push back against ISIS. The moderate coalition is one option; we've worked with them. They've been outgunned, so we'll support them more effectively. Remember, when U.S. forces put ISIS on the defensive, ground forces can achieve significant results, even if initially struggling. This strategy is evolving, and we'll consult with our allies. Ultimately, we'll do whatever it takes to ensure ISIS doesn't threaten the U.S. or our partners. Next question.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, your predecessor often blurred the lines between politics and the Justice Department. What specific safeguards have you put in place to ensure its independence and prevent any appearance of political influence? [SEP] The safeguard is me. My actions speak louder than words. I have maintained a strict separation, refusing to comment on ongoing investigations or suggest any course of action. That's the standard, and I intend to uphold it.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. As you know, Senate Democrats, Harry Reid, sent you a letter begging you, essentially, to take—consider some sort of executive action on this debt ceiling issue. I know you've said you're not negotiating on it. Your administration has ruled out the various ideas that have been out there, the 14th Amendment. But just this morning, House—one of the House Democratic leaders, Jim Clyburn, asked you to use the 14th Amendment and even said, sometimes that's what it takes. He brought up the Emancipation Proclamation as saying it took executive action when Congress wouldn't act, and he compared the debt ceiling to that. So are you considering a plan B, and if not, why not? [SEP] Well, Chuck, the issue here is whether or not America pays its bills. We are not a deadbeat nation. And so there's a very simple solution to this: Congress authorizes us to pay our bills.Now, if the House and the Senate want to give me the authority so that they don't have to take these tough votes, if they want to put the responsibility on me to raise the debt ceiling, I'm happily to take it. Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader in the Senate, had a proposal like that last year, and I'm happy to accept it. But if they want to keep this responsibility, then they need to go ahead and get it done.And there are no magic tricks here. There are no loopholes. There are no easy outs. This is a matter of Congress authorizes spending. They order me to spend. They tell me, you need to fund our Defense Department at such and such a level; you need to send out Social Security checks; you need to make sure that you are paying to care for our veterans. They lay all this out for me, andbecause they have the spending power. And so I am required by law to go ahead and pay these bills.Separately, they also have to authorize the raising of the debt ceiling in order to make sure that those bills are paid. And so what Congress can't do is tell me to spend X, and then say, but we're not going to give you the authority to go ahead and pay the bills.And I just want to repeat, because I think sometimes the American people, understandably, aren't following all the debates here in Washington: Raising the debt ceiling does not authorize us to spend more. All it does is say that America will pay its bills. And we are not a deadbeat nation. And the consequences of us not paying our bills, as I outlined in my opening statement, would be disastrous.So I understand the impulse to try to get around this in a simple way. But there's one way to get around this. There's one way to deal with it. And that is for Congress to authorize me to pay for those items of spending that they have already authorized.And the notion that Republicans in the House, or maybe some Republicans in the Senate, would suggest that in order for us to get our way on our spending priorities, that we would risk the full faith and credit of the United States, that, I think, is not what the Founders intended. That's not how I think most Americans think our democracy should work. They've got a point of view; Democrats in Congress have a point of view. They need to sit down and work out a compromise.
label: Implicit

sentence: Ms. Maxwell's incarceration has sparked speculation about who she might implicate. In light of your previous criticisms of Prince Andrew and Bill Clinton, what's your perspective on this? [SEP] I must confess, I haven't been following that situation with great interest. I simply extend my best wishes to her. I've encountered her on several occasions, particularly during my time in Palm Beach. Regarding Prince Andrew, I possess no specific knowledge. Next question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Sir, everyone's already talking about 2020. Is Pence locked in as your VP again? [SEP] Haven't asked him yet, but I'm hoping! Hey Mike, you in? Stand up, buddy! Swear you'll do it! Just kidding! You gonna do it? Good! Yes, he's in!
label: Dodging

sentence: Sir, regarding Russia's supposed Kherson evacuation, do you believe this marks a pivotal moment in the conflict, potentially empowering Ukraine to negotiate peace with Moscow? [SEP] It's certainly noteworthy that they waited until after the election to announce this, something we anticipated for some time. This clearly demonstrates the Russian military's very real problems. At the very least, this will provide time for all parties to re-evaluate their positions over the winter months. Whether or not Ukraine will be willing to compromise with Russia remains to be seen. I'm heading to the G-20, and while President Putin is unlikely to attend, other world leaders will be present. This will give us a chance to consider potential next steps.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, have all the Governors given their approval to this initiative? [SEP] We just met with the Governors, and they were very eager to get money for their States. Depending on the State, we have the authority to do what we want. We can terminate the 25 percent, or we don't have to. We'll see; it depends on the individual State. A lot of money will be going to a lot of people very quickly. I've instructed the Secretary of the Treasury to move as quickly as he can. Right? Yes. The President. So we'll get it done. Yes, please.
label: Deflection

sentence: With oil prices soaring, is it time to reconsider filling the Strategic Petroleum Reserve? [SEP] I've looked into it, and I don't think it would affect prices. We're buying about 67,000 to 68,000 barrels a day to fill the SPR, which is only one-tenth of one percent of the 85 million barrels a day global demand. It's in our national interest to fill the SPR in case of a major disruption. Al Qaeda, for example, might target oil facilities. An attack in a major exporting country would hurt our economy and those who oppose Al Qaeda. The SPR is necessary to deal with that. If I thought it would help prices, I'd consider it, but at one-tenth of one percent, the cost-benefit analysis doesn't support it. It would cost us oil in case of a national security risk.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, after your meeting with President Zelenskyy, what specific takeaways did you get from that face-to-face that you couldn't have gotten from a call? Also, did you discuss whether Russia would escalate now that we're sending Patriots? [SEP] Okay, first part of your question. People make fun of me for saying politics is personal, right? It's all about looking someone in the eye. And I mean that. You can't beat sitting down with someone, friend or foe, and looking them in the eye. That's what we're doing. We've done it before, we'll do it again. Winter's coming, and Putin's hitting civilians, women, kids, orphanages. This guy... well... he's gonna fail. He already has failed, because he knows he can't take all of Ukraine. The Ukrainian people won't accept him. He's failed before. It's important for everyone to see that Zelenskyy and I are together, united, to make sure he doesn't succeed. I judge leaders by what they say, if they're consistent, and if they look me in the eye. This guy is who he says he is, down to his soul. He'll die for his country. It's important for him to know we'll do everything we can to help him succeed. Thanks. What was the second part?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to the Weinstein case, do you think justice was served? [SEP] You know, I've been focused on other things, much bigger things, frankly. I understand there was a verdict, but I haven't really followed the details. I will say, though, that it's always a sad situation when something like this happens. It's very sad. But I'm not going to comment on the specifics of the case, because I just haven't had the time to look into it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, are you aware of any new coronavirus infections within the White House as of today? [SEP] You're asking about today?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Russia and Ukraine, you mentioned assessing Putin's intentions. Has your administration determined whether President Putin plans to invade or move further into Ukraine? [SEP] Look, the truth is, it's all up to Putin. He's the one in charge, and nobody else's opinion matters. What he decides to do is entirely his call. Frankly, it probably depends on his mood that day. He might want to discuss strategic issues, but who knows? I doubt even his own people know what he's planning. We've had meetings, but they haven't been very fruitful. If he's going to invade, he'll need the ground to freeze first. We're providing assistance to Ukraine and monitoring the situation closely. He's weighing the consequences, but I don't think he's made a final decision yet.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, could you outline your administration's efforts to guarantee a free and fair election? [SEP] Pardon?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given your emphasis on curbing greenhouse gases through national legislation, why did your administration prevent California from enforcing its own stricter emissions standards, and what specific insights did you gain from your conversation with Vice President Gore regarding climate change strategies? [SEP] We believe a national strategy is the most effective way to address greenhouse gases. The new energy bill sets national standards for fuel efficiency and renewable energy, which will significantly reduce emissions across the country. Allowing individual states to set their own standards could create a confusing and inefficient system. I had a good conversation with Vice President Gore about climate change. We discussed the need for international cooperation and technological innovation to address this global challenge. We're committed to working with all stakeholders to develop a comprehensive and effective climate policy.
label: General

sentence: Q. Or do you trust your own instincts more? [SEP] I don't think I have. They've said it could be worse, and I've said it could be worse too.
label: Implicit

sentence: Sir, the extended drawdown in Afghanistan exposes American soldiers to heightened danger. How do you explain this to them, convince them the mission remains valuable, and promise a definitive conclusion? [SEP] The plan is still to normalize our presence by the end of '16. That's not changing. Look, being in Afghanistan has risks, no doubt. But casualties are way down since we ain't in a combat role. The Afghan security forces are fighting hard and getting better. Sure, some folks might have to stay a bit longer, but we've gone from 100,000 troops to less than 10,000, and they're not fighting. This extra time helps the Afghans get their act together, so we don't have to go back. It's worth it for our freedom and a more stable world. And frankly, Congress needs to pony up the dough to support them.
label: Implicit

sentence: President Lopez Obrador, regarding migration, how will Mexico handle the migrants expelled from the U.S.? And President Biden, what concrete steps on fentanyl are you taking after Ovidio Guzmán's detention? Also, did the USMCA energy consultations come up? [SEP] Well, as you know, we're working closely with the United States on migration, and we're committed to protecting migrants' rights. We're also addressing the root causes of migration by investing in development in Central America. As for fentanyl, we're cooperating with Mexico to combat drug trafficking. We discussed a lot of topics.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the ransomware attack red lines, could a military response be on the table? Furthermore, considering President Putin's characterization of you as 'experienced' and your previous remark about him having no soul, has your perspective on him evolved following this meeting? [SEP] Thank you. That will be all for today.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Do you think it will change before you leave office? [SEP] I certainly hope it changes tomorrow. But it's—I'm also realistic to know things don't change on a dime. But nevertheless, the economy is growing. There's obviously financial uncertainty. We've talked about the decisions on the GSEs here. People need to know that if they've got a deposit in a commercial bank, the Government will make good up to $100,000 worth of their deposit. There's no question, it's a time of uncertainty. There's a lot of events taking place at the same time. But we can pass some good law to help expedite the recovery.One such law is a good housing—piece of housing legislation. The Congress needs to get moving on it. Another such law is to send a signal that we're willing to explore for oil here at home. I fully understand that this is a transition period away from hydrocarbons, but we ought to be wise about how we use our own resources. I think it would be a powerful signal if we announce that we're going to really get after it when it comes to oil shale. There's enormous reserves in the western States. And I think if the world saw that we're willing to put a focused, concerted effort on using new technologies to bring those reserves to bear, which would then relieve some pressure on gasoline prices, it would have an impact.The other thing is, is that—I'm sure you know this, April, but we haven't built a refinery—a new refinery in the United States since the early seventies. It makes no sense. And yet you try to get one permitted, it is unbelievably difficult to do. People aren't willing to risk capital if they're deeply concerned about how their capital is going to be tied up in lawsuits or regulations. And we import a lot of gasoline, refined product, from overseas.So there's some things we can do to send signals that it's important that we can get the economy—take advantage of the positive aspects and get it moving stronger again.The other thing is trade. It is—I don't understand the decision on the Colombia free trade market—free trade agreement. The Congress has given preferential treatment to goods coming out of Colombia through the Andean Trade Preference Act. In other words, Colombia businesses can sell into our country relatively duty free. And yet we don't have the same—we don't get the same treatment. Now, why does that make sense? It doesn't.You know, trade—our trade or exports have helped keep the economy growing, April, as paltry as it may be. Doesn't it make sense for us to continue to open up further opportunities to sell goods? I think it does. I do not understand why it's okay for Colombia to be able to sell into our country close to duty free, and we don't have the same advantage. And secondly, turning our back on somebody like Uribe makes no sense at all. He is a courageous fighter against terrorists. And yet our Congress won't even bring up a free trade agreement with Colombia.Anyway, it's—politics is just choking good sense. And the other thing is, is that once we get moving on Colombia, we need to get moving on Panama and South Korea. It's in our country's interest we do that.Olivier. Olivier [Olivier Knox, Agence France-Presse].
label: Implicit

sentence: President Bush, regarding this bill about voting rights in DC and Utah, are you completely uninformed about it? [SEP] I must confess, I'm not familiar with the specifics of that particular piece of legislation. I'd need to be briefed on it before offering an opinion.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, with Prime Minister Blair's departure, are you apprehensive that the new British leadership might reassess its stance on the Iraq War, potentially diverging from the current allied approach? [SEP] Tony Blair, I'll miss him. He's a guy who could see the big picture. A long-term thinker. He kept his word, which is rare in politics. When Tony Blair tells you something, you can take it to the bank. We had a great relationship, good discussions. So, yeah, I'll miss him. A remarkable guy, a good friend. I'm looking forward to meeting his successor. The relationship between Great Britain and America is vital. It's stood the test of time. When we work together, we can do great things. We share common values, a great history. So I'm looking forward to working with Gordon Brown, I guess it'll be him. I shouldn't say that, shouldn't predict. But the pundits say it'll be him. I've met him, found him open and engaging. People make all kinds of characterizations about people in politics, but I found him easy to talk to, a good thinker.
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. Should the NHS be on the table, sir? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. If you can get the Congress to protect telecom companies from lawsuits, then there's no recourse for Americans who feel that they've been caught up in this. I know it's not intended to spy on Americans, but in the collection process, information about everybody gets swept up, and then it gets sorted. So if Americans don't have any recourse, are you just telling them when it comes to their privacy to suck it up? [SEP] The—I wouldn't put it that way, if I were you, in public, Bill. I mean, you've been around long enough to—anyway, yes, I—look, there's—people who analyze the program fully understand that America's civil liberties are well protected. There is a constant check to make sure that our civil liberties of our citizens aren't—you know, are treated with respect. And that's what I want, and that's what most—all Americans want.Now, let me talk about the phone companies. You cannot expect phone companies to participate if they feel like they're going to be sued. I mean, it is—these people are responsible for shareholders; they're private companies. The Government said to those who have alleged to have helped us that it is in our national interests, and it's legal. It's in our national interests because we want to know who's calling who from overseas into America. We need to know in order to protect the people.It was legal. And now, all of a sudden, plaintiffs' attorneys, class-action plaintiffs' attorneys, you know—I don't want to try to get inside their head; I suspect they see, you know, a financial gravy train—are trying to sue these companies. And first, it's unfair. It is patently unfair. And secondly, these lawsuits create doubts amongst those who will—whose help we need.I guess you could be relaxed about all this if you didn't think there was a true threat to the country. I know there's a threat to the country. And the American people expect our Congress to give the professionals the tools they need to listen to foreigners who may be calling into the United States with information that could cause us great harm. So, on the one hand, the civil liberties of our citizens are guaranteed by a lot of checks in the system and scrutinized by the United States Congress.And secondly, I cannot emphasize to you how important it is that the Congress solve this problem. The Senate has solved the problem. And people say, would you ever compromise on the issue? The Senate bill is a compromise. And there's enough votes in the House of Representatives to pass the Senate bill. It's a bipartisan bill. And the House leaders need to put it on the floor. Let the will of the House work. In my judgment, it happens to be the will of the people to give the professionals the tools they need to protect the country.Elaine [Elaine Quijano, Cable News Network].
label: Implicit

sentence: So, what's your take on why he changed his mind? Do you attribute it to your remarks? [SEP] I'm just pointing out that Biden is acting extreme. And now you're all writing about it. Interesting, isn't it?
label: General

sentence: Q. Two questions, if I may. First, did you learn anything new about Chairman Kim through this meeting?And secondly, of course, while this was going on, the drama back in Washington, your former lawyer, Michael Cohen—who worked for you for 10 years; his office right next to yours, right by yours at Trump Tower—he called you a liar, a conman, a racist. What's your response to Michael Cohen? [SEP] Well, it's incorrect. And you know, it's very interesting, because I tried to watch as much as I could. I wasn't able to watch too much because I've been a little bit busy. But I think having a fake hearing like that and having it in the middle of this very important summit is really a terrible thing. They could've made it 2 days later or next week, and it would've been even better. They would've had more time.But having it during this very important summit is sort of incredible. And he lied a lot, but it was very interesting, because he didn't lie about one thing. He said no collusion with the Russian hoax. And I said, I wonder why he didn't just lie about that, too, like he did about everything else?I mean, he lied about so many different things, and I was actually impressed that he didn't say, Well, I think there was collusion for this reason or that. He didn't say that. He said, No collusion. And I was, you know, a little impressed by that, frankly. Could've—he could've gone all out. He only went about 95 percent instead of 100 percent.But the fact is, there is no collusion. And I call it the witch hunt. This should never happen to another President. This is so bad for our country. So bad. You look at this whole hoax, it's a—I call it the Russian witch hunt and now add the word hoax. It's a very, very bad thing for our country. But I was impressed with the fact that he—when—you know, because the most important question up there was the one on collusion. And he said he saw no collusion. So we'll see what happens. But it was pretty shameful, I think.Yes, ma'am. Please. Please.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. And did he call you to congratulate you? And if I could also just invite you, since this is quite a gathering we've got here, to go ahead and talk about the staff changes that you expect in the White House, while we're here. We're eager to hear about them. Is General Kelly going to stay on? [SEP] Well, I think what I'll do is—as we make changes, we'll sit down and talk to you about it. No, I mean, there's no great secret. A lot of administrations make changes after midterms. I will say that, for the most part, I'm very, very happy with this Cabinet. We're doing a great job.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Prime Minister Najib's alleged corruption and human rights violations, what specific message did you convey to him during your meeting? [SEP] Look, concerning the refugee situation, the Paris attacks were a recent and impactful event. Understandably, people are concerned, which influenced legislative actions. However, it's crucial to remember the rigorous vetting process refugees undergo, often taking 18 to 24 months. While the House legislation might seem straightforward, it risks hindering the refugee program, effectively denying aid to those in dire need. My 'betrayal of values' comment referred to suggestions of prioritizing certain religions or fearing vulnerable children. Regarding Prime Minister Najib, I generally avoid commenting on ongoing investigations, especially in foreign countries. However, I emphasized the importance of transparency, accountability, and rooting out corruption, which are vital for development. I also stressed the significance of civil society and a free press. While countries progress at different paces, these principles are essential for progress. Myanmar's recent elections are a positive step, and we aim to encourage such advancements through initiatives like the Open Government Partnership and TPP. Our goal is a world where people are treated fairly, with rule of law, transparency, and equal rights. These are American and universal values. Thank you.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: But they are not currently being investigated, are they, sir? [SEP] I'm not going to comment on that matter, Peter.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And can you why you didn't secure those details in this agreement? [SEP] Because there's no time. I'm here 1 day. We're together for many hours intensively, but the process is now going to take place. And I would be surprised, Mike, if they haven't even started already. They have started; they blew up their sites. They blew up their testing site.But I will say, he knew, prior to coming—you know, this wasn't, like, a surprise. It wasn't like we've never discussed it. We discussed it. Mike discussed it very strongly with his counterpart in North Korea. They knew that this was—let's say they didn't agree to that I couldn't sign any agreement. There was no agreement that could have been signed. So they understood that.And it wasn't a big point today because, really, this had been taken care of, more than any other thing. Because it was all about this. This has been taken care of before we got here. So when we brought that up today, you see the language. It's very strong. It's in the document.Yes, ma'am./North Korea-South Korea Relations
label: Explicit

sentence: Were you able to identify the individual responsible? [SEP] I'm afraid I don't know the answer to that question.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Mr. President, given the stalled TPP in Congress, are you changing your strategy to gain approval, and should the agreement address currency manipulation? Also, your comments on the Taliban leader's death and Pakistan's concerns? [SEP] Well, on TPP, trade deals are always a tough sell, especially in an election year. Everyone wants a better deal. But I'm confident we'll get it done because it's good for America, good for the region, good for the world. It opens up huge markets for us. As for currency manipulation, we have provisions to monitor it, but binding commitments are tricky because they could affect our own monetary policy. On the Taliban leader, it doesn't change our approach. We're not re-entering combat. But we have to protect our people. President Quang?
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, given the strong opposition from the Republican majority in Congress, as expressed by Senator McConnell, what specific strategies are you considering to overcome their resistance if you choose to pursue executive action on immigration? [SEP] We're always looking for ways to work together and find common ground. We believe that a comprehensive approach to immigration reform is essential for our economy and our national security. We're open to hearing different perspectives and finding solutions that work for everyone.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, during your discussions, did you address the recent leaks revealing U.S. intelligence activities targeting South Korea? And did President Biden offer any guarantees regarding this matter? [SEP] We are engaged in communication between our nations, exchanging pertinent information. An investigation is currently underway in the United States, and various factors are at play. We must await the findings of the investigation. We intend to maintain communication on this issue. This concludes our questioning.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Thanks, Mr. President. I wanted to ask about your relationship with China now that you've been in office for a couple months. There's obviously the meeting in Alaska that was a little theatrical, and there's the continued human rights abuses.So today I'm wondering: Are you more likely than you were when you came into office to maintain tariffs on China? Are you considering banning imports of forced-labor products? And would you consider cutting off U.S. investment or Chinese access to international payment systems? [SEP] Well, look, they're each specifically legitimate questions, but they only touch a smidgen of what the relationship with China really is about.I've known Xi Jinping for a long time. Allegedly, by the time I left office as Vice President, I had spent more time with Xi Jinping than any world leader had, because President Obama and the Chinese President Hu decided we should get to know one another since it was inappropriate for the President of the United States to spend time with the Vice President of another country. But it was obvious he was going to become the new leader of China.So I spent hours upon hours with him alone with an interpreter—my interpreter and his—going into great detail. He is very, very straightforward. Doesn't have a democratic—with a small D—bone in his body. But he's a smart, smart guy. He's one of the guys, like Putin, who thinks that autocracy is the wave of the future and democracy can't function in an ever—an ever-complex world.So, when I was elected and he called to congratulate me, I think to the surprise of the China experts who were—his people were on the call as well as mine, listening—we had a 2-hour conversation. For 2 hours. And we made several things clear to one another. I made it clear to him again what I've told him in person on several occasions: that we're not looking for confrontation, although we know there will be steep, steep competition.Two, that we'll have strong competition, but we'll insist that China play by the international rules: fair competition, fair practices, fair trade.Thirdly, in order to compete effectively, I indicated that we're going to deal with China effectively, and we're going to need three things to do that. I tell him, our people. First, we're going to invest in American workers and American science. I said that all through the campaign and I say it again. And we're—and I'm setting up my administration to be able to do that, which is that, you know, back in the sixties, we used to invest a little over 2 percent of our entire GDP in pure research and investment in science. Today, it's 0.7 percent. I'm going to change that. We're going to change that.The future lies in who can, in fact, own the future as it relates to technology, quantum computing, a whole range of things, including in medical fields. And so what I'm going to do is make sure we invest closer to 2 percent.One of the reasons why I've set up the—the PAB [PCAST]*—the President's board with scientists and the like, again—is we're going to invest in medical research—cancer, Alzheimer's, diabetes, the things—industries of the future—artificial intelligence, quantum computing, biotech. And we're going to make real investments. China is outinvesting us by a long shot, because their plan is to own that future.The third—the second thing we're going to do is, we're going to reestablish our alliances. And I've been very clear with him, it's not anti-Chinese. And we've talked about it.I want to make sure that, for example, later today, after this—as a matter of fact, shortly after this, which is fine; we've been going close to an hour. I'm happy to go longer. But one of the things that I'm going to be doing, I'm going to be speaking with the 27 heads of state in Europe and very shortly—I think within the next hour or so. I don't know the exact time.And earlier this month—and apparently, it got the Chinese's attention; that's not why I did it—I met with our allies and how we're going to hold China accountable in the region: Australia, India, Japan, and the United States—the so-called Quad. Because we have to have democracies working together.Before too long, I'm going to have—I'm going to invite an alliance of democracies to come here to discuss the future. And so we're going to make it clear that in order to deal with these things, we are going to hold China accountable to follow the rules—to follow the rules—whether it relates to the South China Sea or the North China Sea or their agreement made on Taiwan or a whole range of other things.And the third thing, and the thing that I admire about dealing with with Xi is, he understands—he makes no pretense about not understanding what I'm saying any more than I do him—I pointed out to him: No leader can be sustained in his position or her position unless they represent the values of the country. And I said as—And, Mr. President, as I've told you before, Americans value the notion of freedom. America values human rights. We don't always live up to our expectations, but it's a value system. We are founded on that principle. And as long as you and your country continues to so blatantly violate human rights, we're going to continue, in an unrelenting way, to call it to the attention of the world and make it clear—make it clear—what's happening.And he understood that. I made it clear that no American President—at least one did—but no American President ever back down from speaking out of what's happening to the Uyghurs, what's happening in Hong Kong, what's happening in-country. That's who we are. The moment a President walks away from that, as the last one did, is the moment we begin to lose our legitimacy around the world. It's who we are.So I see stiff competition with China. China has an overall goal, and I don't criticize them for the goal, but they have an overall goal to become the leading country in the world, the wealthiest country in the world, and the most powerful country in the world. That's not going to happen on my watch, because the United States are going to continue to grow and expand.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, what constitutes a successful initial meeting, and how quickly will you assess his commitment to denuclearization? [SEP] The minimal objective is to establish a rapport, to initiate a dialogue. As a negotiator, that is the essential first step. While I aspire to achieve more, a positive initial encounter is paramount. Regarding his commitment, I anticipate gaining a clear understanding swiftly.
label: General

sentence: Q. And NATO expansion to Georgia and Ukraine? [SEP] Well, I think that neither Ukraine or Georgia are currently on a path to NATO membership, and there has not been any immediate plans for expansion of NATO's membership. I know that Russia has—at least on background—has suggested that one of the reasons they've been concerned about Ukraine was potential NATO membership. On the other hand, part of the reason that the Ukraine has not formally applied for NATO membership is because of its complex relationship with Russia. I don't think that's going to change anytime soon, obviously.So as I said yesterday, we have a commitment that includes a military commitment to our NATO members. For nonmembers, we want to support those countries based on our belief in principles and ideals that are important not just in Europe, but around the world, including territorial integrity and sovereignty. And so we're going to do everything we can to support Ukraine in its elections, its economy, and to continue to try to isolate Russia in response to the actions that it's taken. But I think it would be unrealistic to think that the Ukrainian people themselves have made a decision about that, much less the complex process that's required in order to actually become a NATO member. About energy, of course, as just said, we in Europe have to solve some of our problems. We have been working on that. For instance, we have opened now a new gas route, the first time ever that we'll have gas from Eastern part of Europe not coming from Russia. It will be from Azerbaijan, the southern corridor. We have made progress in many areas of the internal market, interconnections, reverse flows, and so on and so forth. We are working on that.But it's certainly good news that United States have this policy of putting gas from shale gas in the international market, because it's a blessing for the United States, as just said, but I would say it's also a blessing for the world, because countries like European countries and others would be less dependent on energy coming from, let's say, difficult spots. And we know about these licenses. We have, of course, welcomed the remarks that just confirmed now that with the FTA, this is going to be much easier than with the licenses that are already being given to companies around the world to trade.And most importantly, also we have decided to increase our cooperation in the field of energy. Already next week, under the chairmanship of John Kerry and Cathy Ashton, there will be the ministers responsible for energy meeting to see what also can be done innovative in this field.But Europe is working very decisively to reduce its energy dependency. And that's one of the reasons why the European Commission have been pushing for so many years, as you know, to achieve the internal market, to develop the interconnections, and to have a true European energy policy. And I believe now among leaders—we have discussed this and the chairmanship of Herman Van Rompuy in the last European Council—there is a great awareness and commitment of this. This was a wakeup call—very, very strong—for Europe to go forward in terms of the energy integration and also a policy for energy security.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Did you get a flu shot? [SEP] I did.I was in South Carolina last night. We had a tremendous rally. I've been around. I think we're going to be in very good shape.You know, you're talking about 22 people right now in this whole, very vast country. So I think we'll be in very good shape.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, did the protests in Chicago overshadow the positive messages you hoped to convey during the NATO summit? [SEP] We believe that the NATO summit in Chicago was a success, and that it provided an opportunity to showcase the strength and unity of the alliance. The summit was also an opportunity to highlight the city of Chicago and its vibrant culture. While we respect the right of individuals to peacefully protest, we believe that the summit ultimately served as a platform for advancing our shared goals and values.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. On fentanyl? On fentanyl and energy consultations? [SEP] Yes, we are doing that. Just as I was telling you that in the case of migration, first there were brothers and sisters from Central America and also from Mexico, but now, in recent times, a lot of migrants from Venezuela, from Nicaragua, Colombia, Ecuador.We do have a situation. This is a—these are changes in places where we're—places where people are being pushed to leave their towns, their place of origin for many reasons.And with drugs, we have a case in point. It is not cannabis. It's not marijuana. It's not poppies—poppy. It's not only cocaine either. Now, we have fentanyl and chemicals, which are some of the most dangerous type of substance and very harmful for people because they are causing so many deaths.So then, we're working on this in an organized manner. In the case of Mexico, this led us to make all the ports in the customs offices to be controlled by the armed forces in Mexico, all the sea customs office, because fentanyl and other chemicals come from Asia, and they are processed in labs. And we are avoiding the entrance of those chemical substances, and we are destroying labs.The Navy Secretariat is in charge of managing ports and customs—sea customs offices. For instance, we had so much trafficking of chemicals in the port of Manzanillo and also in Lázaro Cárdenas. Now, the Navy is in charge of controlling those customs.And all the customs, the land customs offices along the border line are now under the responsibility of the Ministry of Defense—National Defense Ministry.So we are combating fentanyl and those chemicals, and we're doing this because we care. Nothing human is alien to us. We truly care being able to help and to be of help—the situation in the United States—deaths because of overdose of fentanyl.And—but just as we discussed today, this is not only an issue of the United States. The thing is that if we do not face this problem, this scourge, we are going to suffer it ourselves as well. So we have to act in a coordinated fashion. And that is something we have been doing, and we discussed it in this summit. It is in the communique we are about to give you. And we are defending life—the life.As I was telling you—I was telling Prime Minister Trudeau and President Biden—their teams, I was telling them as well: We only have two campaigns—publicity or propaganda campaigns—in the Government, in my administration. One is dedicated or devoted to not consuming drugs: Say no to drugs. Because we have to also think of that. It became quite a famous thing—public fame. Everything related to gangs. They are even series of gangs and organized crime—gangs of organized crimes.And this is like an apology of that which is desirable, because there are residences, very rich homes in those series, very luxurious homes, and the cars. Men and women—all very good looking—very handsome men and women well dressed with jewelry all over the place, with a lot of power. And they pick up the phone, and they call the head of the police force, head of the military, or even a President of a country. And that's what's being disseminated all over.But we have seen a series on the damage caused by fentanyl, how, in 6 months, the life of a young person is destroyed. And what those doses contain, they have muriatic acid. Do people inform about the situation? Do people let other people know about this? No, of course not. So we are going to be launching an information campaign.As I was telling the President and the Prime Minister, I said vapers—yes, they say: Well, they're not bad. I mean, they just have five substances. That's it. But they're not bad.We did some research on this. Over 30 substances, harmful and cancer-causing substances in those devices people smoke with. However, because of the lobbying, corruption as well, the publicity or advertising management, then—this is being allowed.And there are many parents and mothers, fathers who don't even know the damage that their—our children are going through because of vapors. We have to look into this.But, really, this is not only the responsibility of the Government, this is also the responsibility of the media. You can also help us so much on this to, you know, spread the word, to inform people. Radio stations, television networks—they should be devoting time for this to inform people, to guide people on this on how bad drugs can be for people's health and that people can be successful and they can be happy without having, without needing to fall into drug addiction, those mortal traps.Well, all this, that's what we've been discussing. I think I'm taking more than the time that I should have taken. It's cold outside.Thank you so much, everyone. Thank you from the bottom of my heart. Thank you. Thank you so much. I want the record to show: I don't know what questions I didn't answer. I'm prepared later. Thank you very much. []
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. And would you tell us what those are? [SEP] No. [] I will tell them when I make the announcement. But it was—it's a good try though. That was a good angle. [] Jim and I go way back, although he actually—he was famous, I was not. He used to be a broadcaster in Chicago, so I used to watch him on TV. You've aged a little better than I have. [] Yes.All right. People of Australia, thank you again for your wonderful hospitality.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Vice President Biden's recent remarks about a 30% chance of failure despite best efforts, could you shed some light on the Oval Office conversation he alluded to? And can you assure the public it wasn't about the stimulus or bank rescue? [SEP] Honestly, the specifics of that particular conversation escape me at the moment. But let me offer a broader perspective. Joe might have been suggesting that the challenges we face are so immense that no single action will be a complete solution. As I've said before, not everything we try will work perfectly. We're dealing with unprecedented circumstances. Economists generally agree on the need for a substantial recovery package, a diversified approach combining tax cuts and investments. However, even with the best plan, we still have to address the financial system, ensure banks are lending, tackle the housing crisis, and establish a robust regulatory framework. These are complex tasks. So, while I can't recall the exact context of Joe's remarks, I hope this provides some clarity on the overall situation.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Regarding the Al-Qaeda intelligence report, could you comment on it, please? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: With respect, Mr. President, what specific deliverables are you hoping to achieve in these talks with Kim Jong Un, beyond just having a meeting? What constitutes a successful outcome in your view? [SEP] Look, a successful outcome is peace. It's a big thing, peace. I'm going in there with a very open mind, a very positive attitude. This is a guy, Kim Jong Un, nobody really knows him. He's a bit of a mystery, a real unknown. But I think he wants to do something great for his people. And I think we can help him do that. We're talking about denuclearization, of course, that's the big one. But we're also talking about trade, we're talking about investment, we're talking about a brighter future for North Korea. It's a long shot, I know, but you gotta try. You gotta give it your best shot. And that's what I'm going to do. I'm going to go in there and I'm going to try to make a deal, a great deal, for America and for the world.
label: General

sentence: President Obama, with the TPP encountering resistance in Congress, are you planning a different strategy for approval, and should currency manipulation be a factor? Finally, your thoughts on the death of Mullah Mansur and Pakistan's reaction, please. [SEP] We're pushing hard to get TPP across the finish line, and we're confident it will benefit American workers and businesses. As for the Taliban leader, we took decisive action to protect our troops.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, in addition to members of your own party, the American public is clamoring for a change of course in Iraq. Why are you so resistant to that idea, and how much longer are you willing to give the surge to work before considering a change in this policy? [SEP] First, I understand why the American people are—you know, they're tired of the war. There is—people are—there is a war fatigue in America. It's affecting our psychology. I've said this before. I understand that this is an ugly war. It's a war in which an enemy will kill innocent men, women, and children in order to achieve a political objective. It doesn't surprise me that there is deep concern amongst our people.Part of that concern is whether or not we can win, whether or not the objective is achievable. People don't want our troops in harm's way if that which we are trying to achieve can't be accomplished. I feel the same way. I cannot look a mother and father of a troop in the eye and say, I'm sending your kid into combat, but I don't think we can achieve the objective. I wouldn't do that to a parent or a husband or a wife of a soldier.I believe we can succeed, and I believe we are making security progress that will enable the political tract to succeed as well. And the report, by the way, which is, as accurately noted, is being submitted today, is written a little less than a month after the full complement of troops arrived.I went to the country in January and said, I have made this decision. I said what was happening on the ground was unsatisfactory in Iraq. In consultation with a lot of folks, I came to the conclusion that we needed to send more troops into Iraq, not less, in order to provide stability, in order to be able to enhance the security of the people there. And David asked for a certain number of troops—David Petraeus asked for a certain number—General Petraeus asked for a certain number of troops, and he just got them a couple of weeks ago.Military—it takes a while to move our troops, as the experts know. You just can't load them all in one airplane or one big ship and get them into theater. We had to stage the arrival of our troops. And after they arrived in Iraq, it took a while to get them into their missions. Since the reinforcements arrived, things have changed.For example, I would remind you that Anbar Province was considered lost. Maybe some of you reported on that last fall. And yet today, because of what we call bottom-up reconciliation, Anbar Province has changed dramatically. The same thing is now beginning to happen in Diyala Province. There are neighborhoods in Baghdad where violence is down. There are still car bombs, most of which have the Al Qaida signature on them, but they're declining. In other words, so there's some measurable progress.And you asked, how long does one wait? I will repeat, as the Commander in Chief of a great military who has supported this military and will continue to support this military, not only with my—with insisting that we get resources to them but with— by respecting the command structure, I'm going to wait for David to come back— David Petraeus to come back and give us the report on what he sees. And then we'll use that data that—his report to work with the rest of the military chain of command and Members of Congress to make another decision if need be.Yes, Martha [Martha Raddatz, ABC News].
label: Explicit

sentence: If Congress rejects USMCA, does that mean the end of NAFTA? [SEP] Well, NAFTA was a terrible deal, the worst ever made, frankly. But we'll see what happens. Nancy and Chuck are too busy with their witch hunt to focus on what's important. They can't beat us at the ballot box. We're winning in Ohio, Iowa, Pennsylvania, North Carolina. We just won two big races, one by a huge margin. So, we're doing great. But these Democrats, they can't beat us, so they want to impeach me. It's a disgrace.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And regarding your family, Mr. President? [SEP] Pardon me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with Russia banning food imports and Secretary Hagel warning of a potential invasion of Ukraine, are we seeing evidence that the sanctions are ineffective? [SEP] We can't definitively say if the sanctions are failing yet. They're designed to exert significant pressure on the Russian economy. If you examine the markets, the outflow of capital, and the economic forecasts, you'll see that the Russian economy has essentially ground to a halt. There's been a massive flight of capital, and new investment is scarce. This presents President Putin with a choice: pursue diplomacy to resolve the issues in eastern Ukraine, respecting Ukraine's sovereignty, or continue on his current course, which will ultimately harm his economy and his people. We're doing precisely what we should be doing, and we're pleased that our European allies and partners are with us. However, the problem isn't solved. Fighting persists, civilians are dying, and we've seen the tragic consequences in the loss of the Malaysian airliner. We need to get back on track with serious discussions to ensure that all Ukrainians are heard, that they can participate in the political process, and that reforms are implemented to protect Russian speakers and decentralize power. Only when President Putin acknowledges Ukraine's independence can we say the problem is truly resolved. In the meantime, the sanctions are having their intended effect.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Excuse me, could you repeat the question regarding Mrs. Clinton's nomination? [SEP] Come again?
label: Clarification

sentence: Q. There was some uncertainty that brewed back in the United States over your statement that you said, When he says—when he tells me that, I believe that he means it. That was taken in some circles, including Senator John McCain, to think that you believe that he is saying he did not interfere in the election. Could you, once and for all, definitively, sir—yes or no—say whether or not you believe that President Putin and/or Russia interfered in the election? [SEP] What I said there—I'm surprised that there's any conflict on this. What I said there is that I believe he believes that, and that's very important for somebody to believe. I believe that he feels that he and Russia did not meddle in the election.As to whether I believe it or not, I'm with our agencies, especially as currently constituted with their leadership. I believe in our intel agencies, our intelligence agencies. I've worked with them very strongly. There weren't seventeen as was previously reported; there were actually four. But they were saying there was seventeen; there were actually four. But as currently led by fine people, I believe very much in our intelligence agencies.Now, at the same time, I want to be able—because I think it's very important—to get along with Russia, to get along with China, to get along with Vietnam, to get along with lots of countries, because we have a lot of things we have to solve. And frankly, Russia and China in particular can help us with the problem, which is one of our truly great problems.So I'm not looking to stand and start arguing with somebody when there's reporters all around and cameras recording and seeing our conversation. I think it was very obvious to everybody. I believe that President Putin really feels—and he feels strongly—that he did not meddle in our election. What he believes is what he believes.What I believe is that we have to get to work. And I think everybody understood this that heard the answer. We have to get to work to solve Syria, to solve , to solve Ukraine, to solve terrorism.And, you know, people don't realize Russia has been very, very heavily sanctioned. They were sanctioned at a very high level, and that took place very recently. It's now time to get back to healing a world that is shattered and broken. Those are very important things. And I feel that having Russia in a friendly posture, as opposed to always fighting with them, is an asset to the world and an asset to our country, not a liability.And by the way, Hillary Clinton had the reset button. She wanted to get back together with Russia. She even spelled reset wrong. That's how it started, and then it got worse. President Obama wanted to get along with Russia, but the chemistry wasn't there. Getting along with other nations is a good thing, not a bad thing, believe me. It's a good thing, not a bad thing.Okay, second.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, do you still intend to try to hold an in-person G-7 meeting in the United States at some point in August and September? And have you already sent out invitations to do so? [SEP] No, we haven't sent out invitations. We're talking to them. As you know, I was on the phone with many of them yesterday with respect to Lebanon, which is truly one of the saddest, most catastrophic things I've ever seen. And they have no idea how many people have died. They're having revolution right now in that country. It's just a terrible thing. And—but I was—yesterday, 8 o'clock in the morning, we had a—our time—we had a big teleconference call. Some of those people were there.I'm much more inclined to do it sometime after the election. We were going to do it in September. They'd like to do it. We could do it through teleconference, or we could do it through a meeting. But I sort of am now suggesting—I told my people yesterday, actually, Why don't we do it sometime after the election when things are a little bit—you have a little bit more time to think about it, because that's very important.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, what distinction do you draw between the current situation in Iraq and a civil war? And are you concerned that labeling it as such would undermine the argument that we are fighting the central front of the war on terror there? [SEP] Zarqawi's strategy was to incite sectarian violence, as evidenced by the Samarra bombing and subsequent attacks. We've been in this phase for some time. Our objective is to work with the Iraqis to foster conditions where the majority of the population sees a peaceful path forward. I will discuss this with Prime Minister Maliki in Jordan, focusing on strategies to address the sectarian violence and ensure Iraq can govern and sustain itself. We will continue to pursue Al Qaeda to prevent them from establishing a safe haven.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. I'm Toshi Ogata with Asahi Shimbun, a Japanese newspaper. I have two questions on the tragedy in Japan. So you already touched on the issue in your opening statement. I'd like to ask about your personal feeling on the situation. You went to Japan last year; you went to Kamakura. Now a tsunami hit the coast of Japan, and waves washed away cars and houses, and Japanese people are devastated. I just want to ask about your personal thoughts and feelings on that.And secondly, you also touched on the possibility of assistance from the United States to Japan. And the Japanese Government publicly said that Japan asked for help from U.S. forces in Japan. Are you waiting to provide those assistance? [SEP] The answer to your second question is yes. And so I already told Prime Minister Kan that we will provide whatever assistance that they need. My understanding is that the main assistance that we're going to be able to provide them is lift capacity, the ability for us to, I think, help in the cleanup.Obviously, when you have a tsunami like this as well as an earthquake, you have huge disruptions both in the infrastructure; you have boats and houses and cars that are washed into main thoroughfares, and that requires heavy equipment. And so any assistance that we can provide, we will be providing.I'm heartbroken by this tragedy. I think when you see what's happening in Japan, you are reminded that for all our differences in culture or language or religion, that ultimately, humanity is one. And when we face these kinds of natural disasters, whether it's in New Zealand or Haiti or Japan, then you think about your own family, and you think how would you feel if you lost a loved one, or if your entire lifesavings were gone because of the devastation.And the Japanese people are such close friends of ours, and I have such a close personal friendship and connection to the Japanese people--in part because I grew up in Hawaii, where I was very familiar with Japanese culture--that that just makes our concerns that much more acute.But I am very confident, though, obviously, that the Japanese people are so resourceful, Japan is such a powerful economy and such an advanced economy technologically, that Japan will successfully rebuild. And it has experience dealing with natural disasters. It has dealt with them before and will deal with them again. And Japan, I'm sure, will come back stronger than ever, hopefully, with our help. All right?Thank you very much, everybody.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Thank you, sir. Jeff Mason from Reuters. Mr. President, I'd like to ask you about your use of the word treason. You've used it repeatedly in the last few days. Do you consider anyone who opposes you treasonous? [SEP] No. No. I consider when they lie; when they stand before our great body in our great Chamber, and they make up a story that's fiction, like Schiff did. He took that perfect conversation I had with the Ukrainian President, and he made it into a total lie. It was a total fabrication. And you do admit that. It was a total fabrication.He said, This is what . . .—and the only ones that don't like my conversation are the ones that never read it. But they heard Shifty Schiff. That's what I call a lie. And because of the fact that he's—he's lying about the President of the United States and as to what the President says—you know, I—believe it or not, I watch my words very carefully. There are those that think I'm a very stable genius. Okay? I watch my words very, very closely. And to have somebody get up and to totally fabricate a conversation that I had with another leader and make it sound so bad—it was so evil. And now I see this that just came out minutes ago, where he met at a time that was impossible to have done unless there's corruption involved.And just so you know, we've been investigating, on a personal basis—through Rudy and others, lawyers—corruption in the 2016 election. We've been investigating corruption, because I probably will—I was going to definitely—but I probably will be bringing a lot of litigation against a lot of people having to do with the corrupt investigation, having to do with the 2016 election.
label: Explicit

sentence: So, Mr. President, to be absolutely clear, these individuals are not currently under investigation? [SEP] Peter, with all due respect, I am not at liberty to discuss ongoing investigations.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President Park, in order to induce North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons, what is most important is the concerted actions of the international community. With regard to this, during your meeting with President Obama today, I would like to ask what was said and the views that you shared. And with regard to this, what Russia and China—the role that they're playing in terms of inducing North Korea to abandon its nuclear weapons, how do you feel about that? President Obama, Regarding the young leader of North Korea, Kim Jong Un, I would appreciate your views about the leader of North Korea. And if you were to send a message to him today, what kind of message would you send to him? [SEP] The shared objective is clear: North Korea must abandon its nuclear weapons and become a responsible member of the international community. This is vital for peace on the Korean Peninsula and the world, and it also serves North Korea's own development. To encourage this shift, we must act together. China's influence is significant, so their participation is crucial. China and Russia, along with the international community, share the goal of a denuclearized Korean Peninsula and are cooperating to guide North Korea. China has actively participated in adopting and implementing U.N. Security Council resolutions regarding North Korea's missile fire and nuclear testing. Russia is also firmly committed to denuclearization and has actively supported U.N. Security Council resolutions. They've also worked hard to include a stern message to North Korea in the G-8 Foreign Ministers meeting's joint statement. These efforts are vital to sending a unified message that their nuclear weapons are unacceptable and urging North Korea to make the right decision. I don't know Kim Jong Un personally, so I can't comment on his personal characteristics. However, his actions have been provocative and seem to lead to a dead end. We will maintain a strong deterrent capability and won't reward provocative behavior. But we remain open to North Korea taking a peaceful path of denuclearization, abiding by international commitments, rejoining the international community, and achieving security and prosperity for its people. If North Korea's current path hasn't led to a strong, prosperous nation, now is the time for Kim Jong Un to re-evaluate and change course. If he chooses a different path, the international community would welcome it. China, Russia, Japan, and other key players in the six-party talks have made this clear. But there must be changes in behavior. Actions speak louder than words, and so far, we haven't seen actions indicating a willingness to move in a different direction.
label: Implicit

sentence: So, Mr. President, to be absolutely clear, you would sign a budget that continues to fund the government, even at the reduced levels mandated by the sequester, even if it's not your preferred option? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to box myself in with you guys. But I think it's fair to say that we had a deal, a budget agreement. There's no reason to revisit that. Speaker Boehner was part of it, the whole leadership was. If the bill I get reflects those commitments, then yeah, I'll sign it, because I want to keep things running for the American people. Okay? Next question.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. Can you elaborate on your family's role, sir? [SEP] Excuse me?

sentence: If American lives are still being lost daily, why is there such an emphasis on this as a global competition, Mr. President? [SEP] This is a global pandemic, and people are suffering everywhere. Maybe you should be asking China about their role in all of this. I'm sure they have their own explanation.
