sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. And a couple of questions for you to follow up on some answers that I didn't quite hear from you, if you would allow me a couple of questions.First of all, do you think these women—all three of them—are liars? Yes or no? The President. Have they been what? Q. Are they liars? [SEP] I can't tell you. I have to watch tomorrow. I have to read. I just heard about one a little while ago. I can tell you her lawyer is a low life, okay? So I can't tell you whether or not they're liars until I hear them.I don't know what happened today because I've been very busy with Japan, with South Korea, with , and about seven other countries, as you know, and I chaired the Security Council. So I don't know about today's person that came forward. I do know about the lawyer. And you don't get much worse, bad reputation too. Take a look at his past.So, as far as the other women are concerned, I'm going to see what happens tomorrow. I'm going to be watching—you know, believe it or not. I'm going to see what's said. It's possible that they will be convincing.Now, with all of that being said, Judge Brett Kavanaugh has been, for many years, one of the most respected people in Washington. He's been on, I guess you'd call it, the second highest court. And every single person knows him; a lot of people know him well. And those people don't believe what's going on. I can always be convinced. I have to hear it.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, is a meeting with Barbara Lagoa scheduled at the White House? [SEP] Pardon? I didn't hear the question clearly.

sentence: President Bush, isn't it true that Senator Obama winning in November would grease the wheels for that free trade agreement in Congress? [SEP] Let me be clear: America benefits most from a McCain victory. I believe in his leadership. This trade deal needs strategic consideration, not political games. It's about our economy, our security, our future. That's what matters.

sentence: Mr. President, with climate change increasingly impacting communities worldwide, what specific steps are you taking to address the concerns of activists who feel that current efforts are falling short? [SEP] Look, I understand their frustration. We're facing a climate crisis, and we need to act boldly and urgently. That's why we're investing in clean energy, promoting energy efficiency, and working to reduce emissions across all sectors of our economy. We're also working with other countries to accelerate the global transition to a clean energy future. But we know that we need to do more, and we're committed to working with activists and other stakeholders to find new and innovative solutions.
label: Implicit

sentence: Switching gears, Mr. President, Russia claims to have withdrawn from the Kherson region. Do you see this as a turning point in the conflict, and does Ukraine now possess sufficient leverage for peace talks with Moscow? [SEP] Well, Nancy, it's interesting they waited until after our elections to announce that, something we knew was coming. That tells you something about the Russian military's problems, doesn't it? Secondly, this will give everyone a chance to reassess things over the winter. Whether Ukraine's ready to compromise with Russia remains to be seen. I'm heading to the G-20. Putin probably won't be there, but other leaders will. We'll see what the next steps might be. Nancy, CBS, right?
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Q. Thank you, Mr. President. A question on the South Korea free trade agreement. If U.S. concerns on autos and beef aren't adequately addressed over the next few weeks, at that point would it be better to just have no deal at all? [SEP] Well, I've always said that I'm not interested in signing a trade agreement just for the sake of an announcement, I'm interested in trade agreements that increase jobs and exports for the United States and, hopefully, also increase opportunities for our trading partners. I think that is achievable between the United States and Korea.But the whole issue here from my perspective, and has always been over the last couple of years, is do we have a deal that works for us? That's my first obligation. President Lee's obligation obviously is to make sure it works for Korea. I think we can get a win-win, but it was important to take the extra time so that I am assured that it is a win for American workers and American companies as well as for Korean workers and Korean companies, because I'm the one who's going to have to go to Congress and sell it.And from my perspective, again, I'm not interested in a announcement but then an agreement that doesn't produce for us. We've had a lot of those in the past, a lot of announcements, but at the same time, we see American manufacturing deteriorate and, as a consequence, a lot of concern back home. And understandably, I think there's a lot of suspicion that some of these trade deals may not be good for America. I think this one can be, but I want to make sure that when I present that trade agreement to Congress, I am absolutely confident that we've got the kind of deal that is good for both countries.Dan Lothian of CNN.
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, concerning the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, when will this end, and what is your stance on Israel's behavior? [SEP] Look, the goal is a lasting, sustainable peace. That means Hamas has to stop the rockets. It's their choice. We're working with Egypt to cut off the arms supply. Countries arming Hamas need to be held accountable. As for Israel, they have a right to defend themselves, but we need a two-state solution. It's a complex issue. Remind me of the second part of your question?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with the House vote on Iraq seemingly predetermined and your Press Secretary voicing concerns about the message conveyed to our adversaries, do you concur that a vote of disapproval empowers the enemy and weakens your strategic position? Furthermore, what actions are underway to dissuade the Democratic leadership from imposing constraints on your financial resources allocated to the Iraq mission? [SEP] Well, thank you. A few things to consider: First, I acknowledge that Congress intends to voice their perspectives, and the stance of the Democrats, along with some Republicans, is quite evident. I am aware that they disapprove of the course of action I've taken. However, let me be clear, this does not imply that I question their integrity or patriotism; they simply hold a different viewpoint. I have taken their perspectives into account, but I remain convinced that their approach would not lead to a nation capable of self-governance, self-sufficiency, and alliance in the fight against terrorism. Secondly, I sincerely hope that this non-binding resolution does not evolve into a binding policy that impedes our troops from executing the mission I have entrusted to them. It is perplexing to me that, on one hand, there is unanimous support for David Petraeus, yet on the other hand, there is reluctance to fund the very strategy he deemed essential to his job, a strategy he articulated before the Senate. I will unequivocally convey to the Members of Congress, starting immediately, that they must provide adequate funding for our troops and ensure the necessary flexibility to accomplish the task at hand. Furthermore, I find it intriguing that there is a condemnation of a plan that has not been afforded an opportunity to demonstrate its effectiveness. Again, I understand; I understand. What was the other aspect of your inquiry?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, with respect to the current Senate proceedings, would you favor a rapid conclusion or a detailed inquiry into the facts? What is your perspective on the exchange between White House Counsel Pat Cipollone and Jerrold Nadler? And do you stand firmly against the possibility of John Bolton testifying? [SEP] Those are several different questions.

sentence: Mr. President, with respect, your response seems to sidestep the specific question about whether you believe there's a 'war on women.' Can you clarify your position on that? [SEP] Look, I think it's important to focus on the issues that matter most to women, and that's what we're doing. We're not going to get drawn into partisan bickering or name-calling. We're going to focus on delivering results for women and their families.

sentence: Mr. President, can you confirm that the White House is actively encouraging the NIH and FDA to expedite the release of this? But the part about the White House actively encouraging this – that's news to me. I'll have to look into that further.

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Chavez's influence, do you believe it's accurately portrayed, or is it perhaps amplified in regional discussions? [SEP] You're asking for my opinion about...?

sentence: Q. Mr. President, former chairman of the House Transportation Committee, Republican Don Young, says there are about 500 bridges around the country like the one that collapsed in Minneapolis last week. And Young and other Transportation Committee members are recommending an increase in Federal gasoline taxes to pay for repairs. Would you be willing to go along with an increase in gasoline taxes of 5 cents a gallon or more? [SEP] First of all, Secretary Peters is gathering information and will report to the White House and report to the Nation about what she finds about whether there are any structural design flaws that may be applicable to other bridges. She's in the process of gathering this information now.The American people need to know that we're working hard to find out why the bridge did what it did, so that we can assure people that the bridges over which they will be traveling will be safe. That's step one.You know, it's an interesting question about how Congress spends and prioritizes highway money. My suggestion would be that they revisit the process by which they spend gasoline money in the first place.As you probably know, the public works committee is the largest committee—or one of the largest committees in the House of Representatives. From my perspective, the way it seems to have worked is that each member on that committee gets to set his or her own priority first, and then whatever is left over is spent through a funding formula. That's not the right way to prioritize the people's money. So before we raise taxes, which could affect economic growth, I would strongly urge the Congress to examine how they set priorities. And if bridges are a priority, let's make sure we set that priority first and foremost before we raise taxes.
label: General

sentence: Mr. President, can you address the serious allegations of bribery that have recently surfaced? [SEP] Hold on a second.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President, thank you very much. I'd like to ask you about Iraq. Thank you. Yesterday in Dayton, in your remarks, you said that the Iraqi offensive against criminals and militants in Basra was a sign of progress. But it's also triggered clashes with supporters of Muqtada Al Sadr. And this morning, U.S. forces were again fighting the Mahdi army in Sadr City. What does this say about progress in terms of reconciliation in Iraq among the various factions? And what can the United States do, what can you do, what can your administration do to help Prime Minister Maliki make progress in that area?And, Mr. Prime Minister, if I could ask you, when you're in Bucharest next week at the NATO summit, what's going to be your message to the European allies to try to bring them along, to have the same sort of commitment you just stated here and a commitment to have military operations with their forces in Afghanistan? [SEP] Yes, John, any government that presumes to represent the majority of people must confront criminal elements or people who think they can live outside the law. And that's what's taking place in Basra and in other parts of Iraq. I would say this is a defining moment in the history of a free Iraq. There have been other defining moments up to now, but this is a defining moment as well. The decision to move troops—Iraqi troops into Basra talks about Prime Minister Maliki's leadership.You know, one of the early questions I had to the Prime Minister was, would he be willing to confront criminal elements, whether they be Shi'a or Sunni? Would he, in representing people who want to live in peace, be willing to use force necessary to bring to justice those who take advantage of a vacuum or those who murder the innocent? And his answer was, Yes, sir, I will. And I said, Well, you'll have our support if that's the case, if you believe in evenhanded justice. And his decision to move into Basra shows evenhanded justice, shows he's willing to go after those who believe they're outside the law.This is a test and a moment for the Iraqi Government, which strongly has supported Prime Minister Maliki's actions. And it is an interesting moment for the people of Iraq, because in order for this democracy to survive, they must have confidence in their Government's ability to protect them and to be evenhanded.And so the other thing that's interesting about this, by the way, this happens to be one of the Provinces where the Iraq's are in the lead—Iraqis are in the lead. And that's what they are in this instance. And the United States, of course, will provide them help if they ask for it and if they need it. But they are in the lead. And this is a good test for them. And, of course, routing out these folks who've burrowed in society, who take advantage of the ability to be criminals or the ability to intimidate citizens, is going to take a while. But it is a necessary part of the development of a free society. In answer to your question on Afghanistan, the message I would take to our friends and partners in Europe when we get to Bucharest is, all of us have got to share the burden. And it's built on an assumption that all of us share a common strategy. So the first message, I think, for all of our friends and partners there in Bucharest is, we need to sign up to a common script, both military and civil, in terms of how we actually prosecute and succeed in this conflict. And I believe we can. No point in being there unless you believe you can.And then the second thing is, once you've signed up to a common script, a common strategy, which has both civilian and military dimensions to it in an integrated fashion, to then say to all of our friends and partners, let's all step up to the plate to make this work—and across the country of Afghanistan, not just in parts of it.I'm optimistic that we're going to make some progress in Bucharest. I know the President has put in a lot of effort with a lot of European leaders up until now. We've been talking to some ourselves. And I think we should look forward to a good outcome because the people of Afghanistan deserve a good outcome.If I could ask Mark Kenny for his question.
label: Explicit

sentence: Mr. President, considering the current intelligence, do you anticipate President Putin invading Ukraine before winter's end? And what's your message to the Americans in Ukraine – should they evacuate? [SEP] Look, I've spoken to Putin many times. Does he know what he's going to do? Maybe, maybe not. But invading Ukraine would be a colossal mistake, a disaster for Europe and the world. He'd pay a heavy price. I've been very blunt with him. We'd hit him with sanctions like he's never seen before, economic sanctions that would cripple his economy. It'll hurt us, it'll hurt Europe, but it'll devastate him. He has the capability to invade, sure, but what he'll actually do? Your guess is as good as mine. Nobody knows but him.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: And what if that well of patience dries up, sir? [SEP] Now, hold on a minute. Why are we even entertaining the possibility of it running dry? Let's focus on making sure it doesn't. That's the positive approach, the proactive stance. We're putting the pieces in place, working towards a solution. Let's see here, Stephen [Stephen Dinan, Washington Times].
label: Deflection

sentence: Q. What assurances can you give the American people that the intelligence this time will be accurate? [SEP] Ed, we know they're there; we know they're provided by the Qods Force; we know the Qods Force is a part of the ian Government. I don't think we know who picked up the phone and said to the Qods Force, Go do this, but we know it's a vital part of the ian Government.What matters is, is that we're responding. The idea that somehow we're manufacturing the idea that the ians are providing IEDs is preposterous, Ed. My job is to protect our troops. And when we find devices that are in that country that are hurting our troops, we're going to do something about it, pure and simple.Now David says, Does this mean you're trying to have a pretext for war? No, it means I'm trying to protect our troops; that's what that means. And that's what the family members of our soldiers expect the Commander in Chief and those responsible for our troops on the ground. And we'll continue do so.Yes, ma'am. You're not a ma'am. Martha [Martha Raddatz, ABC News].
label: General

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with this newly emerging syndrome now among young children, what do you say to parents who would like to get their children back to school, but are now looking at this and potentially afraid to do that? [SEP] Well, again it's a tiny percentage. But you're right, so we're looking into it very strongly. And the admiral, as he said, he's known about this for long before this happened. But it is a very, very small percentage. And people recover from that; the children recover from that. Right? Yes, sir. Most do recover from this, but it is a serious, and it can be a fatal, condition. So we do want to make sure that parents understand that high fevers, red rashes, particularly on your child, you may need to contact your health care provider. There are treatments for this. They work very effectively if gotten early, at least for the vast majority of the cases. The President. We're studying that very closely, and it's been on the radar for weeks actually, because we've seen this for quite a while. But it's been very rare, but we're looking at it very closely. It's very important to us.I think one of the things we're most proud of is—this just came out—deaths per 100,000 people, death—so deaths per 100,000 people: Germany and the United States are at the lowest rung of that ladder. Meaning, low is a positive, not a negative. Germany and the United States are the two best in deaths per 100,000 people, which, frankly, to me, that's perhaps the most important number there is.Please, go in the back, please./
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, in light of China's recent actions against the Wall Street Journal, what retaliatory measures are under consideration, specifically regarding Chinese journalists in the U.S.? [SEP] I'm still awaiting a comprehensive briefing on the situation. We're evaluating our options. I find their actions regrettable, as we provide considerable access to journalists here. We'll be making a decision on how to proceed shortly.

sentence: Mr. President, it's been a challenging year, perhaps the most difficult of your presidency. Your approval ratings have fluctuated and are currently low. Acknowledging the healthcare rollout issues, what do you personally consider to be your biggest mistake in decisions made or actions taken? sentence: Mr. President, the arms embargo on Iran is set to expire soon. Critics argue this will embolden Iran and destabilize the region further. How do you respond to these concerns, and what specific steps are being taken to mitigate any potential risks? [SEP] Look, we're fully aware of the concerns surrounding the arms embargo. Let me be clear: we're not naive about Iran's intentions. That's why we've been working closely with our allies in the region to enhance our collective security posture. We're bolstering our intelligence capabilities, strengthening our military presence, and actively working to counter Iran's destabilizing activities. The expiration of the embargo doesn't mean we're taking our foot off the gas. Quite the opposite. We're doubling down on our efforts to ensure the region remains secure and stable. We're prepared to use all available tools to deter Iranian aggression and protect our interests and those of our partners.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. But if you were to see the Crown Prince or the King, would you ask them to increase oil production? [SEP] No, I'm not going to ask them. I'm going to ask—there's—all the Gulf States are meeting. I've indicated to them that I thought they should be increasing oil production, generically, not to the Saudis particularly. And I think we're going to—I hope we see them, in their own interest, concluding that makes sense to do.And you know, they have real concerns about what's going on in Iran and other places in terms of their security as well—all of them.Tarina [Tarini Parti], the Wall Street Journal.
label: Explicit

sentence: Q. Mr. President, regarding the Pope's potential recognition of the Palestinian state and its impact on a two-state solution with Israel, could you share your thoughts on whether this is a beneficial step or a misstep, and how it might influence the prospects of the two-state solution you've previously discussed? [SEP] Look, let me first commend the Senate for their progress on granting me the authority to pursue trade agreements that are both smart and promote growth, not just in the Asia-Pacific region, but potentially in Europe as well. This also gives us the ability to enforce these agreements, something that hasn't always been the case. I want to thank the Senators who voted to support this, or at least to begin the debate. For those who didn't, I'll continue to make my case, providing them with the necessary information to understand that despite past issues with trade deals, our approach is the right one, not just for large corporations, but for small and medium-sized businesses, and most importantly, for American workers. I wouldn't support any agreement that I didn't believe would create jobs and opportunities for Americans to climb the ladder of success, with higher incomes and wages. That's my primary focus since taking office. The issue between myself and Elizabeth is not personal. The press likes to highlight disagreements between allies, but many of my closest friends in the Senate and House disagree with me on this issue. I understand their concerns about plants closing and jobs being shipped overseas. They worry about the enforcement of labor and environmental agreements and whether trade is truly fair. They share my deep concern about rising inequality and the impact of automation and globalization on the middle class. These are people whose values align with mine. They even released a progressive statement of principles that mirrored my agenda, except for trade. This is a policy difference, a disagreement on what's best for our constituents. I firmly believe that despite past problems, we're better off writing high-standard rules with strong enforcement on issues like child labor, deforestation, and intellectual property. If we don't, China and other countries will, disadvantaging our businesses and workers. As for outsourcing fears, companies seeking low-cost labor can already do so. Our opportunity lies in attracting companies back to manufacture here. Nike's potential return of 10,000 jobs due to new technologies is an example of this. But we need to be able to sell overseas to fully capitalize on these opportunities. That's why I argue with my progressive friends that we need to focus on shared objectives like a strong minimum wage, job training programs, infrastructure investments, stronger collective bargaining laws, and enforcement of overtime pay and paid sick leave. We need an honest conversation about our budgets and stop preserving loopholes for corporations that provide no economic benefit. These are the things that will address their concerns. Blocking a trade deal won't, especially since they acknowledge the existing rules are bad for U.S. workers. How does clinging to the status quo help them? It doesn't make sense. I support enforcement and the signed provisions. I have concerns about the currency language in the bill, but I need to discuss with Senators Schumer and Brown how to ensure it doesn't negatively impact our monetary policy. Now, remind me of your original question?
label: Clarification

sentence: President Calderon, what is your opinion on the situation in the US Congress and the advertisement comparing Lopez Obrador to Hitler and Mussolini? Does this promote Mexican unity regarding the energy bill? [SEP] This type of behavior is indicative of those who engage in it. Congress is functioning normally, with most parties acting responsibly. The PRI, PAN, Green Party, New Alliance, and others are working diligently. I condemn this behavior, as it damages the reputation of those responsible and further weakens the image of the PRD. I hope our institutions will strengthen dialogue. This matter is currently under review by the authorities. The IFE will make a decision based on the TV spots.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. Mr. President, with all due respect, your administration has consistently stated that Asad must relinquish power. Could you provide a more concrete timeline or strategy for achieving this goal? Are we likely to be discussing this same situation a year from now? [SEP] Look, ideally, Asad would have stepped down yesterday, last month, last year – the sooner, the better. My administration has been clear: Asad forfeited his legitimacy when he turned on his own people, silencing peaceful protests with violence. The situation has only worsened. As for how, there's no simple solution to such a complex and brutal situation. If there were, we would have implemented it already. Instead, we're maintaining international pressure, bolstering the opposition, and hoping that the Geneva talks, involving Russia and representatives, can lead to a political transition that all parties can accept. We will continue to support the opposition and address the humanitarian crisis, working closely with our allies, particularly Turkey, who are deeply invested in this. We'll be discussing this further this evening. Our views largely align, and we'll explore how we can work together, considering Geneva and beyond. Russia and China's involvement is crucial, given their permanent membership on the U.N. Security Council. Their participation will add significant weight. International pressure remains vital, and we've already provided over $1.5 billion in humanitarian aid. We maintain an open-door policy, given our 910-kilometer border with ; many families are divided. These efforts are vital for regional peace, especially as we strive to normalize relations between Palestinians and Israelis. We don't need further regional instability. We previously attempted to bring and Israel together for five rounds of discussions, but unfortunately, they stalled. I hope our future efforts, in partnership with the United States, will yield positive results. We're discussing all these issues. The U.N. Security Council's actions and the Geneva process are important. We'll continue to assess the situation together. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: With all the time you spend golfing, why haven't you met with the victims in person? [SEP] That's right.
label: Dodging

sentence: Q. Mr. President——The President's State of the Union Address/Impeachment/Investigation Into Russia's Interference in the 2016 U.S. Presidential Election  Q. Mr. President, but would you consider delaying the State of the Union if the impeachment trial has not ended by February 4? [SEP] I don't see it. No, I don't see it. No, I'm—you know, a very excellent writer, Bob Woodward—I guess he's doing another book on Trump, but this time, I'll actually give him an interview. He said, You're enjoying this, aren't you? I said, No, I'm not enjoying it. He said: No, you act like you're winning and you won. You're actually enjoying it. I said: I'm not enjoying it. I'm doing it because it's very important, what I'm doing.I consider what I've done here, with this whole witch hunt, from day one—with the insurance policy; with the horrible statements made between Strzok and Page; and McCabe; and Comey, who lied to Congress and did so many other bad things. He lied, and he leaked.When I finish, I think that this is going to go down as one of the greatest things I've done for our country. These are bad, corrupt people. These are bad people and very bad for our country.Thank you very much, everybody.
label: Explicit

sentence: Sir, with all due respect, wouldn't you agree that Senator Obama's stance on Iraq is somewhat premature, given the ongoing primary contest? [SEP] The Senator is entitled to his opinions, of course. However, I believe it's more prudent to address such weighty matters after the dust has settled in both the Democratic and Republican primaries. There will be ample opportunity for debate then. Let's move on.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, based on your insights, do you foresee President Putin authorizing an invasion of Ukraine before the winter concludes? And what guidance do you offer to the American citizens residing in Ukraine? [SEP] Well, I've engaged in extensive discussions with the Russians, especially with Putin. I'm uncertain if he's even reached a decision, or if he knows his next move. He must comprehend that invading Ukraine would be a catastrophic blunder, with dire ramifications for Europe and the world at large. He would incur a substantial penalty. I've been candid and direct with President Putin, both during our phone conversations and in person. We're poised to impose the most severe economic sanctions ever enacted, with significant long-term repercussions. While this would affect others, including us and Europeans, it would have a profound impact on his economy. He possesses the capability to invade, particularly if the ground above Kiev is frozen. However, his ultimate course of action remains uncertain. I doubt anyone but him knows for sure.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, given your previous statements about the decimation of core Al Qaeda, how do you reconcile that with the recent embassy closures due to terror threats across the Arab world and Africa? And, if you could, in the interest of transparency, would you comment on the drone strikes that have reportedly taken place in Yemen over the past few weeks? [SEP] Well, as I said in my National Defense University speech back in May, core Al Qaeda has been significantly weakened. However, I also emphasized that Al Qaeda and other extremist groups have spread into regional factions that pose serious threats. I refer you back to that speech where I specifically stated that while they are less likely to launch spectacular homeland attacks like 9/11, they still have the capacity to target our embassies and businesses, and to destabilize countries with weak security. That's precisely what we're seeing now. So, it's consistent to say that the centralized Al Qaeda that attacked us on 9/11 has been broken apart, but these regional organizations, like AAP, remain a threat. They can drive a truck bomb into an embassy wall and kill people. This requires a strategy to strengthen our partners, so they can manage these regional threats. We must remain vigilant and go after known terrorists who are plotting attacks or strengthening their capabilities. This is an ongoing process. We won't completely eliminate terrorism, but we can weaken it and strengthen our partnerships to prevent another 9/11. I won't discuss specific operations. Again, my speech in May detailed how we make decisions about potential lethal strikes, so I refer you to that.
label: Dodging

sentence: Given the documented issues with mail-in voting, are you contemplating an Executive Order to address the situation? What's driving the push for mail-in ballots? [SEP] This unprecedented push for mail-in ballots is deeply concerning. Look at the New York Congressional race – a complete and utter disaster. Six weeks in, and they haven't a clue what's happening. Frankly, I think that race needs to be rerun. It's a mess. Lost ballots, fraudulent ballots – nobody knows what's going on. It's a small race, thousands of people, and it's completely botched. Paterson, New Jersey – same story. These are small, easily controlled elections, yet they're a mess. Now, they're talking about Nevada, where they approved a ridiculous system in the dead of night, without public meetings, without any transparency. No signature verification, double mailings – it's a disgrace. Mail-in ballots, even in small races like that New York congressional race, are a disaster. It should have been announced at 7 PM, maybe 45 minutes later if it was close. But six weeks later, they're still clueless. They've lost ballots, there's fraud. How can you do that for an entire nation? They're using COVID as an excuse to push mail-in ballots. Absentee ballots are different. You request them, there's a process. They work. But universal mail-in ballots are a disaster waiting to happen. Nevada's plan is insane. Double ballots, harvesting – thousands of ballots dumped on someone's desk. They're counting votes up to seven days later. If it comes down to Nevada, we'll be waiting a week. It's a mess. The Post Office, frankly, hasn't been run well for years. Great workers, but old equipment. They're not prepared for this. They're already strained by regular mail, Amazon, online shopping. They lose a fortune on every package. And now, on top of that, they want to add millions of mail-in ballots? Amazon and the others pay very little. The Post Office loses money on every package it delivers. And now, the Governor of Nevada wants to send millions of ballots everywhere. You'll never know who won that state. It'll be a mess, just like New York, Paterson, West Virginia. They indicted a postman there for doing something bad. There are cases all over the country. Absentee is fine. It works in Florida. But universal mail-in ballots will be an embarrassment to our country.
label: Deflection

sentence: Mr. President, concerning Prime Minister Najib and the allegations against him, what specific points did you make about the investment funds scandal and the imprisonment of his political rivals? [SEP] Look, the refugee situation, especially after Paris, is sensitive. The vetting process is rigorous. Some proposals, while seemingly benign, could halt the program. Regarding Prime Minister Najib, I avoid commenting on active investigations. However, I stressed the importance of transparency and accountability. These principles are vital for any nation's progress.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, thank you. I have two questions: one regarding the Ahmaud Arbery case and another concerning the coronavirus. First, regarding the coronavirus, it's been reported that the Vice President is practicing some form of self-isolation. What message do you have for Americans who are asking: How can you ensure our safety? How can the government be reopened if even the Vice President is self-isolating? And why haven't testing capabilities reached a point where every American who wants a test can get one? [SEP] Well, first of all, the Vice President has been tested, and he's negative—he was tested yesterday, tested today, and he's negative. He's in very good shape. And I think that that's going to be fine. As far as Americans getting a test, they should all be able to get a test right now. They should be able to get a test. That's the problem with a question like that. We go through a whole announcement saying We're number one in the world by far, by a factor of two, and even three and four depending on where you're looking, and I get a question, When will everybody be able to get tested? If somebody wants to be tested right now, they'll be able to be tested. As far as the incident, I think it's horrible, and it's certainly being looked at by many people. I'm speaking to many people about it. He looked—I saw the picture of him in his tuxedo; it was so beautiful. I mean, he looks like a wonderful, young guy. Would have been a wonderful—I mean, just a wonderful guy. I think it's a horrible thing. I think it's a horrible thing. Now, with that being said, as you know, they're studying the case very carefully. They're interviewing everybody involved, and we'll see what happens. To me, it's a very sad thing. I spoke to a number of people that are very much involved in it. I've been following that one very closely. It breaks your heart to watch it. It breaks your heart. And certainly, the video was a—it was a terrible-looking video to me. But you have a lot of people looking at it, and hopefully, an answer is going to be arrived at very quickly. But it's something that is heartbreaking.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, if it's unfair and costing millions, why not just end it? [SEP] I've said what I have to say on that.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Mr. President, considering your Nobel Peace Prize and the potential military action in Syria, how do you reconcile these seemingly contradictory positions? Also, how did your discussion with Prime Minister Reinfeldt advance the resolution of the climate crisis? [SEP] Regarding the Nobel, I'd point you back to my acceptance speech, where I acknowledged my unworthiness compared to past recipients. I addressed the inherent tension between striving for peace and confronting a world rife with violence. The question is, what are our responsibilities in such a world? I ended the war in Iraq, began winding down Afghanistan, and promoted diplomacy. But the core question is: when do we act against actions that violate our common humanity? Seeing hundreds of children gassed, thousands of civilians killed, and having the chance to mitigate this, the moral choice is to act. It's a difficult part of the job. I'd rather focus on education than preventing chemical attacks on children. But as President, I can't avoid these questions. When bad things happen, everyone asks what the US will do. Libya, Rwanda, Sierra Leone, now Syria. That's the reality. And the second question, remind me?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, given the recent attack, how confident are you in the Afghan forces' capacity to handle security as we draw down troops? [SEP] Look, nobody is pretending Afghanistan is a picnic. The drawdown is still in the early stages. We anticipated events like this. The key metric is the overall trend of Afghan capacity. Kabul, a major population center, is already largely secured by Afghan forces, and they've shown real progress. Will there be more incidents? Absolutely. But we're in a transition phase, similar to what we saw in Iraq. They've managed to maintain a democratic government despite ongoing challenges. We're aiming for the same outcome in Afghanistan. Even in Iraq, attacks still happen. These are countries recovering from conflict. They won't be risk-free, even with our continued presence. Our goal is to empower the Afghan people to defend themselves.
label: Clarification

sentence: So, to finalize this, would you support that particular proposal? [SEP] Not that specific one, no, but we're making progress. We're getting closer to a deal. I'm very much in favor of sending significant funds to those who suffered unnecessarily because they could have prevented it. They could have stopped it from entering their country, from entering our country, from entering Europe, and from spreading across 188 countries worldwide. Please understand.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Mr. President, what specific measures can your administration implement immediately to instill confidence that the U.S. will meet its deficit reduction targets in both the medium and long term? [SEP] I beg your pardon, would you mind repeating the question? Kindly ensure the microphone is positioned closer to you.
label: Clarification

sentence: Sir, is it true that you're sending 15,000 soldiers to the border with Mexico? [SEP] You're reading the same news I am. You know what's happening. What's your next question?
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Do you believe you have the power to grant work permits to those who are here illegally, as some of your supporters have suggested? [SEP] What I certainly recognize with respect to immigration reform—and I've said this in the past—is that we have a broken system. It's underresourced, and we've got to make choices in terms of how we allocate personnel and resources.So if I'm going to, for example, send more immigration judges down to the border to process some of these unaccompanied children that have arrived at the border, then that's coming from someplace else, and we're going to have to prioritize. That's well within our authorities and prosecutorial discretion.My preference would be an actual comprehensive immigration law. And we already have a bipartisan law that would solve a whole bunch of these problems. Until that happens, I'm going to have to make choices. That's what I was elected to do.Margaret Talev, Bloomberg.
label: Dodging

sentence: Mr. President, with Governor DeSantis's recent win, many are speculating about a potential showdown between him and former President Trump. Are you actively strategizing based on the possibility of facing either of them in the upcoming election? [SEP] My focus right now is on the American people and delivering results for them. The political games will play themselves out, and I'll be ready for whoever emerges. [Moving on.]
label: Dodging

sentence: And what about your previous conversations with Kim Jong Un? Can you share any details about those discussions? [SEP] Look, I'm not going to get into the specifics. What I will say is that we've had a lot of discussions, and we've built some very important relationships, both at Mike's level and at other levels. We had people from North Korea in the room. So, when we went into this final agreement, we weren't going in blind. We had a tremendous amount of knowledge and strong relationships. That's why we were able to get it done. Now, I'm going to head back and take it easy for a bit, then the real work begins. I appreciate everyone being here. I hope we've answered your questions. And congratulations to everyone, because this is a very important event in world history. To be true to myself, I want to get it completed. Mike and our team need to get to work and finish the job. Otherwise, our efforts won't mean enough. So, thank you, and congratulations to everyone in the room.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Given the questions raised, will you publicly affirm Kamala Harris's eligibility to hold the office of Vice President or President, based on her birth in Oakland, California? [SEP] I'm not going to get involved in that. I saw something about a lawyer writing about it, but it's not something I'm focused on. There are much more important things to worry about.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Of those individuals seeking asylum in the U.S., what percentage do you believe are genuinely deserving of it? [SEP] I won't provide a percentage. We are a nation of laws, and we must have borders. Without borders, we have no country. I've been monitoring the caravan's progress. Mexican laws on immigration are very strict. It started with over a thousand people, now down to about a hundred. Mexico is a large country. We're dealing with the worst laws imaginable. We need changes in Congress quickly. We need a wall. Even though it's not a perfect wall, it will deter many. We need border security. We're sending National Guard troops to the border. We need a change in the law. Catch-and-release is ridiculous.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Q. And have you talked about that with him? [SEP] If I thought he was guilty of something like this, yes, sure.
label: Implicit

sentence: Q. Can you get at the microphone, sir? [SEP] I will. I will.So that's the story. Would anybody like a pen? Would anybody like a pen? Would anybody—— I do! The President. Why do we hand these—we'll hand these out to you in the back. Okay, fine.
label: Explicit

sentence: Given the current global health landscape, what specific benchmarks must be met for the U.S. to confidently commit to donating another billion vaccine doses, and how realistic is the 2022 target for ending the pandemic? [SEP] Well, let me be clear: our commitment is unwavering. The possibility of providing another billion doses is certainly on the table, potentially stretching into 2023. However, I'm hesitant to make promises I can't keep. We're constantly evaluating our capabilities and the global need. The G-7 consensus is that we're in this for the long haul, not just for moral reasons, but for our own security. Walls can't stop viruses. This will be an ongoing project, and we're building systems to detect future pandemics early. We're not just giving vaccines; we're helping countries manufacture their own. It's a massive logistical undertaking, and we're working on it. Last question, please.
label: Claims ignorance

sentence: Mr. President, the Attorney General's chief of staff claims Gonzales knew more about the U.S. attorney firings than he's letting on. How can the American people have faith in an Attorney General who's not being completely forthright? What's the deadline for him to fix this mess, and is it even fixable? [SEP] Attorney General Al Gonzales is a man of integrity and honesty, and he has my complete support. He's cooperating fully with Congress to ensure the truth comes out. He will testify and provide truthful testimony. The U.S. attorneys serve at the discretion of the President. I appointed them to 4-year terms, and they served those terms honorably. I appreciate their service. It's regrettable that these hearings have damaged their reputations. That was certainly not the intention of anyone in this administration. And let me reiterate: there is no credible evidence of any wrongdoing whatsoever.
label: Deflection

sentence: Are you saying you intend to withdraw the troops? [SEP] What was that?
label: Clarification

sentence: Mr. President, regarding Iran, how will you assess whether they are genuinely committed to re-entering nuclear talks by the end of November? And what consequences are you prepared to impose if Iran persists in attacking U.S. interests, such as the recent drone strikes in Syria? [SEP] We're dealing with two distinct issues here. One is the JCPOA and whether we rejoin it. That hinges on their actions and the willingness of our allies to ensure there's an economic price for failing to come back. The other is how we respond to attacks on U.S. interests, whether drone strikes or anything else. We will respond, and we will continue to respond.
label: Partial/half-answer

sentence: Q. You spoke earlier about 2014 being a breakthrough year, and you ended the year with executive actions on Cuba and immigration and climate change. But you didn't make much progress this year on your legislative agenda. And some Republican lawmakers have said they're less inclined to work with you if you pursue executive actions so aggressively. Are you going to continue to pursue executive actions if that creates more roadblocks for your legislative agenda? Or have you concluded that it's not possible to break the fever in Washington and the partisan gridlock here? [SEP] I think there are real opportunities to get things done in Congress. As I said before, I take Speaker Boehner and Mitch McConnell at their words that they want to get things done. I think the American people would like to see us get some things done. The question is going to be, are we able to separate out those areas where we disagree and those areas where we agree? I think there are going to be some tough fights on areas where we disagree.If Republicans seek to take health care away from people who just got it, they will meet stiff resistance from me. If they try to water down consumer protections that we put in place in the aftermath of the financial crisis, I will say no. And I'm confident that I'll be able to uphold vetoes of those types of provisions. But on increasing American exports, on simplifying our tax system, on rebuilding our infrastructure, my hope is that we can get some things done.I've never been persuaded by this argument that if it weren't for the executive actions, they would have been more productive. There's no evidence of that. So I intend to continue to do what I've been doing, which is, where I see a big problem and the opportunity to help the American people, and it is within my lawful authority to provide that help, I'm going to do it. And I will then, side by side, reach out to Members of Congress, reach out to Republicans, and say, let's work together; I'd rather do it with you.Immigration is the classic example. I was really happy when the Senate passed a bipartisan, comprehensive immigration bill. And I did everything I could for a year and a half to provide Republicans the space to act and showed not only great patience, but flexibility, saying to them, look, if there are specific changes you'd like to see, we're willing to compromise, we're willing to be patient, we're willing to work with you. Ultimately, it wasn't forthcoming.And so the question is going to be, I think, if executive actions on areas like minimum wage or equal pay or having a more sensible immigration system are important to Republicans, if they care about those issues, and the executive actions are bothering them, there is a very simple solution, and that is, pass bills. And work with me to make sure I'm willing to sign those bills.Because both sides are going to have to compromise. On most issues, in order for their initiatives to become law, I'm going to have sign off. And that means they have to take into account the issues that I care about, just as I'm going to have to take into account the issues that they care about.All right. I think this is going to be our last question. Juliet Alsprin [Juliet Eilperin, Washington Post].
label: Implicit

sentence: Mr. President, you mentioned closing racial gaps in government. How does criminal justice reform fit in, what gaps remain, and what's the significance of your Kenya trip? Also, should Bill Cosby's Medal of Freedom be revoked? [SEP] Well, April, you've certainly packed a lot into one question there. Let's just say...
label: Declining to answer

sentence: President, about the Justice Department and the Associated Press, was that an overreach? Do you still support your Attorney General? Is the media shield law a response? And what do you think of the Nixon comparisons? [SEP] You can make those comparisons yourselves. I'm focused on fixing problems in government, like the IRS and our diplomats' security. I can't comment on the Justice Department's specific case. But leaks can endanger people in uniform and intelligence officers. I won't apologize for protecting them. We also have a free press, and the media shield law was meant to balance that. This case has made people interested again, so we should look at it. I have troops in Afghanistan and intelligence officers in risky situations. I have to protect them while respecting the need for information.
label: Declining to answer

sentence: Sir, about this FBI building issue in the coronavirus bill, is the White House pushing for it, as the Washington Post claims? [SEP] Look, I don't know if it's specifically in *this* bill, but let's be clear: that FBI building is a disaster. It's old, it's falling apart, and it's not up to standard. They looked at sites way out in Maryland and Virginia, but I said, 'No, it needs to be near Justice.' So, I'm all for a new building, something that will last. Renovation is just a band-aid. They could even have a running track on top! So, we're going to get them a new building, one way or another. Thank you.
label: Claims ignorance
